title: Webster Says Prisoners Seek Informers Names
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI)  Sixteen percent of all requests under the Freedom of Information Act addressed to the Federal Bureau of Investigation come from prisoners, and many are seeking to identify the informers who landed them in jail, the bureau's Director, William H. Webster, told Congress today.

title: Notes on People
description: many because it was decided they'd done enough traveling for awhile.

title: U.N. Negotiations on Indochina CeaseFire Stalled
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 28 Negotiations in the Security Council designed to produce a call for a ceasefire in Vietnam and Cambodia came to a standstill tonight because of the conflicting positions held by the Soviet Union and China, diplomats conceded.

title: His Goal: To Get Team in Series
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 28 Pete Rose, for 16 years the symbol of the Cincinnati Reds, walked into the locker room of the Philadelphia Phillies at 7:30 this morning and began a tumultuous debut as the highestpriced defector in baseball history.

title: Canada to Send Kamikaze Kids Downhill
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 28 Our true goal, of course, is a big showing in downhill when the Winter Olympics are held here next February, said John Ritchie, head coach of Canada's men's Alpine team. In the meantime, we're out to show the European nations that our ski racers rate with the best in the world.

title: Dance: Harlem Troupe
description: THE test of any classical ballet company is, in fact, its classicism, and the Dance Theater of Harlem met that test with flying colors in its first performance of George Balanchine's Serenade Tuesday night at the City Center, in its third program of the season. The evening featured another company premiere, Billy Wilson's Mirage, but the main attraction of the engagement, which ends Sunday, will certainly be Serenade.

title: 3 Quakes Hit Mexico City
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 28 (AP)  Three moderately strong earthquakes shook Mexico City today. Two came shortly after II A.M. and the third shortly after President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France arrived at the airport. although it was not felt there.

title: Cloud of Charged Particles Discovered Around Jupiter
description: PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 28  The Voyager 1 spacecraft, now 3.5 million miles from Jupiter and closing in fast, has discovered a cloud of electrically charged particles circling Jupiter and has also detected a new type of verylow frequency radio emissions coming from the giant planet.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: JOHANNESBURG  Imagine Watergate at a point just before the coverup of the coverup began to come apart. To meet the political pressure for a housecleaning, three men involved in the affair have been fired or forced to resign. For the moment, the lid Is on the story. But the three men are beginning to sound angry, and if they talk...

title: GARDENING
description: I Fyou think in terms of the lowly leek rather than the luscious leek, you haven't been growing your own. And if you don't think of leeks at all, you're missing a gourmet vegetable that combines the finest quality of asparaguslike texture yith a mild kissingsweet onion flavor.

title: Base for Checking Soviet Testing Is Evacuated 20 Americans Safe
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The United States has been forced to abandon a secret electronic listening post in northeast Iran that had been used to monitor Soviet missile tests, Administration officials said today.

title: PENTAGON IS URGING INDIAN OCEAN FLEET
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The Defense Department is quietly seeking a new and sizable naval presence in the Middle East, including the creation of a small fleet of ships in the Indian Ocean to bolster American prestige in the region.

title: The Catbird Seat
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  It used to be that all baseball teams had their players report to their home parks a week or so before the season started. Despite the cold of Northern winter, the players would try to get into shape, and many days they would have to throw under the stands.

title: Carter Chided On Bank Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Two Senate committee chairmen rebuked the Administration today for failing to support legislation that would consolidate the nation's bank regulatory agencies into a single banking commission.

title: Court Mandates No Segregation Of the Retarded
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday against a New York City Board of Education proposal to segregate mentally retarded children who are carriers of hepatitis B from other publicschool children. The judge contended there was no evidence their presence had or would spread the viral disease.

title: Stage: Golden Pond At the New Apollo
description: WHEN it is doing what it dogs best, On Golden Pond is a modest, touching play about an old couple helping each other into the advancing chill of their last years:

title: Deaths
description: PALIOTTINicolina on February 28th, 1979. Beloved wife of the late Giovanni. Loving mother of Angelo J. Paliotto, Maria J. Paliotti, Doria E. Iraci. featherinlaw of Joseph P. lraci, M.D. Fond grandmother of Rosalie D. Iraci, M.D. and Joseph C. Iraci, M.D. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home, Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193rd Street. Mass of Christian Burial Sacred Heart R. C. Church. 9:45 A.M. Saturday. Interment Mount St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Hers
description: E VERYTHING was background music, for Delia the Midwesterner, compared with being successful in New York. The glamour of it, puzzling to her circle of native New Yorkers because they aspire to the country, where Delia sprains her ankle. At 10 she was a junior feminist before the word was out, chafing to put Cleveland behind her and be a contender. Now at 40 she has done it: In this stately grownup ritual beneath the motto, In God We Trust, Delia is about to be dubbed a Criminal Court judge. Off in a raised section to the right sits Delia's family. If her husband is envious, he's a good actor. In fact, Michael's beaming with pride. The only two their set to persevere in Marriage I, Michael and Delia operate according to the grownup equation, my gain equals yours. They demonstrate that marriage lives  secure, mature, darling Michael, it's whispered, being largely responsible.

title: The Region
description: WASHINGTON,  Nassau and Suffolk Counties will be the first exclusively suburban areas in the nation to be eligible for hundreds of millions of dollars in direct Federal grants and lowinterest Federal loans under its designation as an Economic Development District.

title: Fighting at Lang Son, A Key Chinese Goal, Now Reported Intense
description: Heavy fighting was reported in northern Vietnam yesterday around the provincial capital of Lang Son, which increasingly appeared to American and West European intelligence analysts to be the strategic prize sought by the invading Chinese troops.

title: Salyut Systems Reactivated
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 28 (Reuters)  Vladimir Lyakhov and Valery Rytunin today prepared for a long stay in space aboard the Salyut 6 space station. by putting its equipment back in running order.

title: Vietnam Fighting Overshadows Progress in Peking Trade Talks
description: PEKING, Thursday, March 1  Under sparkling winter sun, the United States Liaison Office here became the United States Embassy at noon today, completing the restoration of full diplomatic representation between China and the United States for the first time since the Communists came to power in China in 1949.

title: GIFTS TO AMERICANS BY SHAH REPORTED
description: A former United States Senator now working for Iran said yesterday that representatives of that country's new Goverrunent had uncovered documents in their embassy indicating widespread payments to prominent Americans, including members of Congress and the press, by the deposed Government of the Shah.

title: Ancient Nubian Artifacts Yield Evidence of Earliest Monarchy
description: Evidence of the oldest recognizable monarctiy in human history, preceding the rise of the earliest Egyptian kings by several generations, has been discovered in artifacts from ancient Nubia in Africa.

title: Books of The Times
description: ON page 256 of Jonathan Schwartz's first novel, Emily tells Paul: I think that most of us are only tuned in to dis tant stations where all kinds of things are happening to other people. We lis ten through the static to their heart breaks as if we were in some wellpro tected receiving chamber. Do you know what we overlook? That we are distant stations for anyone else who comes across our transmissions through our static. It's all one network; we're affiliates of the same conglom erate without seeing. We'll go on forever making believe that locally everything is okay; it's just the other folks who've got the bad end of the deal.

title: Device Cuts Power Use In Motors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it had developed a device that could substantially reduce the amount of energy consumed by electric motors.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Intimate Anniversaries: A Flower Blooms
description: NEW YORK CITY people don't know how hard we try, out here in the country, to dress up our days. While city life is a supermarket of readymade symbols, events and occasions, country people have to create their own. We are engaged in an eternal Easter egg hunt for something to respond to, something that will enable us to believe that we have not rusticated our sensibilities.

title: New U.S.Israeli Tensions Develop On Eve of Begin 's Arrival for Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  On the eve of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's arrival for talks with President Carter, new strains have developed in IsraeliAmerican relations over the differences holding up an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: Music: Acoustic Evening
description: RICHARD TEITELBAUM called the first composition in his Thursday evening per formance at the Kitchen Blends. The title could have served as well for the entire evening, for Mr. Teitelbaum's music is a blend on many different levels. It is a blend of electric and acoustic instruments, a blend of fresh and sometimes startling tone colors, and a blend of Western and Oriental forms and modes of expres sion, a blend of composition and im provisation.

title: Spaniards Voting Today but Not, It Seems, With Fervor
description: MADRID, Feb. 28  After a desultory campaign that appears to have aroused little enthusiasm, Spaniards vote in parliamentary elections tomorrow. Opinion polls suggest an extremely close race between Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez's Union of the Democratic Center and the Socialist Workers Party.

title: CITY'S INSTITUTIONS FACE 50% FUEL CUT
description: Fueloil distributors say they may have to cut deliveries to municipal institutions by as much as 50 percent this month, because their contracts with the city are too rigid to allow for the sharply rising prices on the open fueloii market. Affected would be housin.; projects, hospitals and prisons.

title: Stage: OneActers Based On Comedy Routines
description: THE two new oneacts sharing the stage at the WPA Theater are extended comedy routines dealing with the subject of sex. These are both playwriting exercises that never develop into plays.

title: Strong Earthquake Shakes Areas Of Alaska and of Yukon Territory,
description: ANCHORAGE, Feb. 28 (AP)  A strong, rolling earthquake shook wide areas of Alaska and Canada's Yukon Territory today, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or major daniarre.

title: Jersey Revokes License Of the Garden State Track
description: EAST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP, NJ., Feb. 28The New Jersey State Racing Commission revoked the temporary racing license of Garden State Park Race Track today for failure to comply with the conditions under which it was issued.

title: A.M.C. Cuts Option Price
description: DETROIT, Feb. 28 (AP)  The American Motors Corporation will slash the price of airconditioning on its poorerselling cars by 42 percent for the next three months, the company said today. The airconditioning option, bought by most motorists, will cost $299 instead of the usual $513 on the Spirit. Concord, Pacer and AMX models, the auto maker said. The cut will be in effect from March 1 through May 31.

title: Foes of Abortion Seek to Tighten Restrictions on Medicaid Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Groups opposing abortion hope that this year the controversial Hyde amendment, which they have used to chip away at the use of Federal funds for abortions, will provide the leverage to impose an even more restrictive ban on Government support of abortions.

title: Brown, in New York, Pushes His Cause
description: Insisting he had not yet decided whether to run for the Presidency, Guy. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California browsed through the city yesterday, seeking to convince leaders of various groups that neither he nor the constitutional amendment he advocates on a balanced Federal budget threatens their interests.

title: Amin, Threatened by Tanzanians, Asks 5 African Nations to Mediate
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 28 (AP) President Idi Amin of Uganda, apparently desperate, sought peace today amid reports of repeated victories by Tanzanian troops in the East African neighbors fourmonthold war.

title: JAMES J. PRIOR
description: James J. Prior, a former New York real estate man who specialized in theatrical and newspaper properties, died Tuesday at his home in St. Petersburg Beach, Fla. He was 71 years old and had been a resident of the Bronx.

title: Ski Conditions
description: Figures in parentheses show total trails and number open at each area. Skiarea forecasts appear on the weather page. For information: New York, (212) 7558100; New Jersey, (609) 2928456 Thursdays and Fridays from 2 to 4 P.M.; Pennsylvania, (717) 4215791; New Hampshire, (603)2242525; Vermont, (802) 2290531, and Massachusetts, (800)6285030.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: At about 5 P.M. last Saturday, Herbert Whitehead received a telephone call at his Paramus, N.J., home advising him that Local 584 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters had suddenly called a strike against the Greater New York Milk Dealers. Since then, his days have been filled with anxiety and uncertainty.

title: Pop: The Ultra vox Plays
description: LIKE Pallas Athena from the brow of Zeus, Ultravox has sprung from the high forehead of David Bowie. The English band that made its American debut in the wee hours of Wednesday morning at Hurrah's strikes a stylized, distant pose reminiscent of Mr. i3owie's, and it also traffics in a similar contrast between a heavily electronic, futuristic sound on the one hand,and conventionally catchy, rather oldfashioned melodies on the other. If the quintet weren't buzzing, clanking and whirring so weirdly (Listening to the music the machines make, runs a lyric from one of their songs), one couId almost hum along to the tunes.

title: Nonpatent Royalties Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a contract requiring a manufacturer to pay a royalty for the right to market a new invention remains enforceable even if the invention itself is later denied a patent.

title: OilShortage Options Prepared for Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  President Carter will shortly have before him an Iranian response plan comprising 13 to 15 immediate executive actions that can be taken to help overcome the oil shortage caused by the halt in petroleum imports from Iran, according to Administration officials and industry representatives here.

title: Injury Strikes Mets Before Camp Opens
description: Although the New York Mats full squad is scheduled to report today to training camp in St. Petersburg Fla., the team has already had its first casualty. Luis Rosado, a minor league catcher, apparently suffered a stress fracture of the fifth metatarsal bone in his right foot several weeks ago while playing winter ball in his native Puerto Rico. Rosado had complained of soreness for a couple of days after arriving In camp and when treatment did not relieve the pain, Tom McKenna, the trainer sent him for Xrays. The foot was placed in a cast and he'll be out of action five weeks. Rosado batted 270 as the regular catcher at the Mets Class AAA Tidewater farm in the International League last season.

title: Georgia and Auburn Score S. E. C. Upsets
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 28 (AP)  Eric Marbury, a freshman, scored the tiebreaking basket with 54 seconds remaining and hit a free throw with 15 seconds left as Georgia upset Mississippi State, 7572, tonight in the Southeastern Conference's first basketball tournament in 27 years.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Gala for Arts Center In Brooklyn on March 24
description: The Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College will stage a gala benefit performance March 24 at 8 P.M. in Whitman Hall to celebrate its Silver Jubilee Anniversary season. Proceeds will support the center.

title: Deaths
description: WADEDr. John B. We are greatly grieved at the untimely passing of our devoted colleague and extend our sincerest condolences to the bereaved family.

title: Bill Limiting Searches Of Newsrooms Passed By Connecticut House
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 28  A measure that would limit the ability of the police and prosecutors to search newsrooms was approved today by the Connecticut House of Representatives. The vote was 130 to 14.

title: Hotel Proposed For Akron Site
description: AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 28  After a year marred by job losses in the rubber industry, a closing of one of its two major downtown department stores and other industrial cutbacks, this northeastern Ohio city has received some good news.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: John R. Vogel Jr., 54, A Utilities Coordinator
description: John R. Vogel Jr., executive director of the New York power Pool, which coordinates the operations of the state's eight major electric utilities, died of cancer Monday at Ellis Hospital in Schenectady at the age of 54. He lived in Guilderland, a suburb of Albany.

title: Home Improvement
description: EVERY year when temperatures drop below freezing, many homeowners and apartment dwellers are plagued with the problem of windows and sometimes doors that sweat, or drip water on the inside. Even windows with storm sashes, which should prevent this, sometimes sweat.

title: Kucinich and Foes Claim Victory In Cleveland Vote on Fiscal Steps
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 28  While Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich exultantly claimed victory for his campaign against corporate influence, his opponents in Cleveland's large business community also found something to be pleased with in the results of yesterday's voting on ways to shore up the city's finances.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Energy

title: Albany Inquiry Issues Criticism Of State Insurers
description: The chairman of the New York State Commission of Investigation charged yesterday that pressure by the insurance industry was forcing the state to pay unnecessary ,fees to brokers for placement of casualty policies covering state agencies.

title: Mutual Fund Asset Record
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) The mutual funds industry scored a record in January for total net assets of all funds, reaching $59.9 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported today. The new asset figure eclipsed the previous high of $59.8 billion set in November 1972.

title: Deaths
description: GRIGGSSarah L. of N.Y.C. former. ly of Newton, N.J. on Tuesday at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Survived by one brother. Leavitt Griggs & nieces & nephews. For further information Smith McCracken. Newton, N.J.

title: Robert Vagt Is Named As Executive Director By the M.A.C. Board
description: Robert F. Vagt, the 31yearold executive director of the New York State Housing Finance Agency, was named yesterday as the new executive director of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, replacing Marilyn F. Friedman, who withdrew from consideration for permanent appointment to the cost.

title: DENIS M. M. ROOKE
description: Denis Monro Morley Rooke, an early aviator and stunt pilot, died Monday at his home in New York City. He was 86 years old.

title: Offshore Oil Leases Get Small Bids
description: The oil industry practically wrote off the Baltimore Canyon in the Atlantic yesterday, offering high bids totaling just $41.7 million at one of the most lackluster sales of offshore leases ever held by the United States Government.

title: SETBACKS REPORTED IN F.B.I. PROSECUTION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Government prosecution of L. Patrick Gray 3d, the former Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and two former bureau executives has been seriously jeopardized because a Federal judge here has refused to issue an order to protect national security information, sources familiar with the case said today.

title: Stars Tie Rangers On Manery Goal, 44
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 28 Which team would be hungrier, the Rangers, battling to finish second in their division and possibly third best in the National Hockey League, or the Minnesota North Stan, striving to get enough points just to get into the playoffs?

title: Advertising
description: ONCE again a research project by Meldrum & Fewsmith of Cleveland and the American Business Press has shown that cutting ad budgets in recession times leads to losses in both profits and sales. But there were some different aspects to the study this time than in 1958 and 1970, the previous wars in which the study was made.

title: TV: Mrs. Columbo Turns Detective
description: READERS have been inquiring about the absence of a prereview several weeks ago for NBCTV's new Supertrain series. They feel some advance warning might have prevented them from wasting their time on such electronic junk food.

title: 2 SENATORS PROPOSE CHECK ON RHODESIA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29  Two Senators will introduce a resolution tomorrow to send a team of private American citizens to observe the Rhodesian elections scheduled on April 20 and then to report to Congress on whether they were fairly conducted.

title: About New York
description: Immanuel Velikovsky was up at 5 o'clock last Monday morning in a quiet house on an island off the New Jersey shore, rising as if in tune with Venus, working on another book.

title: Save the Seeds for That Second Season
description: Leeks are biermials, inhabitants of that inbetween world twin annuals and perennials. The plants grow into flavorsome youth the first year, but do not mature and bear seed until their second growing season. Keep this in mind if you are beginning to save seeds from your past crops for replanting  an idea whose time has come with the increasing price of seeds today.

title: Deaths
description: ABPEULetlie, on February 27. 157.9. Beloved wile of Angel. Devoted mother of Rosemary Lutley and Pobert Abreu Dear grandmother of Jettrey Lutlev Peposing Andrew Torreorossa Funeral Home. 2265 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn through Friday. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery Saturday

title: CBS Is Sued by Painter Over a Book on Rothko
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  A painter here has sued CBS Inc. and its New York publishing house, charging that it implicated him in the death of the artist Mark Rothko.

title: Terrorist Suspects Slain in Italy
description: TURIN, Italy, Feb. 28 (AP) Two presumed terrorists, a man and a woman, died in an exchange of fire with the police on the outskirts of Turin, the authorities reported today. One policeman was slightly wounded. The reputed terrorists, apparently in their early 20's and heavily armed, were not identified.

title: Rod Carew: Yanks Copped Out
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 28  Not long after Rod Carew arrived here to begin swinging the bat for the California Angels, he drove his Porsche to a foreigncar repair shop for an estimate on a slipping clutch. The price was $700. which seemed expensive to him, especially when another Porsche owner mentioned that the same job had cost him only about $400 recently.

description: NNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS NAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS UNTIL 2:30 PM ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. title: Some Runs Curbed By T.W.A., National
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Trans World and National Airlines have canceled nearly 50 of their less popularly traveled flights originating in New York and Kansas City, Mo., as a result of aviation fuel shortgages.

title: A Life Far Above It All
description: S IXstories above West End Avenue, with only a web belt and a lot of cold air between him and the sidewalk, Carl Corder is taking care of business. At that height, wasted motion is not advisable, so his movements are models of economy: smartly efficient rubs with a sponge, brisk swipes with a squeegee. Then he pulls himself back inside, leaving another clean window behind.

title: Tight Supplies Seen
description: The Oil Minister of Kuwait, which has announced the largest price rise among oilexporting nations, said he expected supplies of crude to remain tight for the remainder of the year. Page D14

title: OPEC Approves Latest Price Rises
description: VIENNA, Feb. 28 (AP)  The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today approved separate oil price increases announced by several member countries, stating that these rises did not run counter to OPEC's longterm objectives.

title: The End of McGrawHill Fight
description: A $1 billion takeover bid by the American Express Company for McGrawHill Inc., the publishing giant, is scheduled to expire today, ending one of the most acrimonious episodes in Wall Street history.

title: Bridge:
description: For duplicate players seeking a social evening in a domestic setting, the best format, if the right number of players is available, is no doubt an individual. The ideal number is eight or nine, but 12 or 13 can also be managed. Scoring is by international match points and is carried out round by round so that players know their scores as the evening progresses.

title: Q &
description: Q.I have sliding windows and doors with steel frames and double insulating glass in each pane. Every winter the steel frame around each window and door gets wet on the inside and the water runs down into puddles on the sill which warp the wood and make the paint peel. What can/ do about it? Am I wrong in thinking that storm windows are unnecessary, since I have insulating glass in the windows?  J.R.R., Gaithersburg, Md.

title: Abu Dhabi Order for G.E.
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it had received an order valued at about $30 million for 10 PG 5341 gas turbines from the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for the onshore gas project of Abu Dhabi Gas Inaustries. Abu Dhabi Gas, which manages the overall project, is made up of Abu Dhabi National Oil, the Shell Oil Company, Compagnie Frangaise des Petroles and Partex. The turbines will be used within the boundaries of the United Arab Emirates, G.E. said.

title: 4 Swiss Bankers Convicted
description: LUGANO, Switzerland, Feb. 28 (AP)  Four senior officers of the defunct Weisscredit bank were convicted last night on charges of fraud and mismanagement in highrisk speculative operations through a company based in Liechtenstein. Officials said that the actions had caused losses of $150 million, chiefly at the expense of Italian investors. Rolando Zoppi, the 46yearold Swiss chief executive of the small private bank, received a fiveyear prison term.

title: Taxi Panel Criticized at Hearing As Drivers and Riders Air Views
description: Carol Lockwood carries a baseball bat, a knife and a teargas bomb in her taxicab because she is afraid of some of the people whom taxi regulations require her to pickup. Torn Leykis complained that cab driver had refused to take him to Roosevelt Island from midtown, then threatened him with a tire iron when he refused to get out of the taxi.

title: Khomeini Urges Iran's Moslems To Purge All Foreign Influences
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 28 (AP)  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini urged faithful Moslems today to purge American and ther foreign influence from Iran.

title: Sound
description: ON the heels of our recent foray into critical listening, let's leap from theory to practice and evaluate a recent speaker in terms of the guidelines lately proposed here. Listening to loudspeakers is not always a happy experience these days. Too often, companies try to top

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Jazz: Marian McPartland
description: OF the many aspects of Alex Wilder's music, which include brass quintets, children's songs and sly, witty and swinging octets,, as well as popular songs, he is probably best known as a writer of popular songs. Yet even the more familiar Wilder songs  While We're Young, I'll Be Around and

title: Nondrivers Ban In Suffolk Juries Upheld by Court
description: Suffolk County's practice of excluding from juries people who do not drive has been found constitutional by an appeals court in Brooklyn.

title: Trade Deficit in January Reached 11Month High
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The Government reported today a $3.1 billion trade deficit for January, the widest gap between exports and imports in 11 months and mainly reflecting increased purchases of foreign oil.

title: Iranian Kurds Return to Own Struggle
description: MEHABAD, Iran, Feb. 27  For us the revolution is nut over.

title: No Peril From Flooding Seen in Westway Project,
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28 (AP)  The State Transportation Department said today that a study it financed had found no possible flooding dangers from construction of the proposed Westway highway project in New York City.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar held its ground in foreign exchange trading abroad yesterday but fell in New York following the release of figures on the United States trade deficit for January.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: BRASS stair rods, once an oldfashioned necessity, have become a modern luxury. Today, carpeting is generally tacked down and this eliminates the need for rods to hold the carpet in place on the stairs.

title: Jackson Phillips, at 58; Moody's Bond Executive
description: Jackson Phillips, an authority on municipal bonds and executive vice president of Moody's Investor Services of New York, died Saturday at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center. He was 58 years old and made his home in Mountain Lakes, N.J.

description: Music

title: WHITE HOUSE TO ASK NEW RESOURCE DEPT.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  President Carter has approved a reorganization plan calling for a vast new Department of Natural Resources that would absorb the present Department of Interior and 35,000 employees and $2.65 billion In funds now in the Agriculture and Commerce Departments, high Administration officials disclosed today.

title: U.S. Issues a Broad Listing of Planned Regulations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The Carter Administration today unveiled the nation's first regulatory calendar, a compendium of expected new strictures that officials quickly hailed as a key step in the battle to control regulation.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Spring Study Program, The Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies. West 40th Street.

title: How to Get Collections Appraised
description: MORE often than you would believe, said Detective Robert Volpe, head of art and antiques investigation for the New York City Police Department, all a burglary victim has left to show for his art or antique collection is a blurred snapshot. What can the police do with that? And what can an insurance company do with such a blurred claim of loss? Not much. Establishing ownership and value, and facilitating police recovery of stolen goods, are the collector's responsibilities.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Fourteen months ago  on Nov. 7,1977  President Carter took a call in the Oval Office from Pennsylvania Congressman Joshua Eilberg. The Congressman, who was under investigation by the Republican U.S. Attorney in Philadephia, was agitated: He wanted that prosecutor, David Marston, fired.

title: Iran Developers Resign
description: David E. Lilienthal and John W. Macy Jr., chairman and president, re spectively, of the Development and Re sources Corporation, announced yes terday their resignations as officers and directors and their recommenda tion that the company, long involved with development in Iran, be dissolved.

title: CHARLES SWEENEY
description: DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 26 (AP) Charles Sweeney, former Stale Public Works Commissioner, died Sunday at Danbury Hospital at the age of 70. Mr. Sweeney, who lived here, joined the Public Works Department in 1955 and in 1967 he was appointed commissioner. He retired in 1S71. He was a former member of the Democratic Central Committee in the state.

title: Market Place
description: THAT $45 million purchase last week of shares UV Industries by Victor Posner's interests evidently is not going to go through. Judge Edward T. Gignoux of Federal District Court in Portland, Me., where UV Industries is incorporated, Issued a preliminary injunction yesterday enjoining Sharon Steel, which is controlled by Mr. Posner, from purchasing any UV shares. This, of course, includes the 1.3 million shares Mr. Posner attempted to buy last Thursday.

title: Victories for Them?
description: Who could disagree with President Carter's solemn admonition to a group of editors the other day to resist the temptation to see all change [in foreign relationships] as inevitably against the interests of the United States, as a kind of loss for us or a victory for them ? True enough; yet all the President's efforts at imagemaking cannot conceal the fact that the United States has indeed suffered major foreignpolicy reverses in Southern Asia that have in fact amounted to a loss for us and, inevitably, a victory for them.

title: Democratic Study Group Names Obey of Wisconsin as Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, FEB. 28  Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, prime mover in House reforms in recent years, was elected chairman of the Democratic Study Group today. He defeated Representative Richard L. Ottinger of Westchester by a vote of 173 to 74.

title: Demand Strong for Milk As Supply Falls in Strike
description: Supply and demand, a mophaired youth from a Brooklyn supermarket said yesterday as he scrambled to load containers of fresh milk into a Dollar RentaCaravan at the ramp of the struck Elmhurst Milk and Cream Company in Jamaica. Queens.

title: Grain Imports By China Soar
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) China is expected to import a record 12.2 million metric tons of grain this year, half of it from the United States, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Hawkins Is Named By Giants
description: In his first move since taking over as head coach of the Giants a week ago, Ray Perkins yesterday named the first three members of his staff, including as defensive coordinator a player once released by the New York Titans who went on to direct the 25th best pass defense in the 28team National Football League last year.

title: Lending Turkey a Hand
description: Fear that Turkey may go the way of Iran is spurring efforts in the West to help the country that defends NATO's southeastern flank. Unlike Iran, Turkey's problem is economic; its stability will require largescale aid and economic reform for four or more years. But the first task, and it will not be easy, is to pull Turkey through the next year.

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: For periods as shown (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) Me American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Music: Chamber by Bizet
description: Rank has its privileges, but they are sometimes exercised in devilishly disarming ways. Charles Wadsworth, to be specific, is artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center as well as a remarkably musical pianist. So, when he puts on his program a work for piano, four hands, does he exert his administrative rights find insist on playing the primo, or treble, part? Hardly. Mr. Wadsworth is far too cunning for that.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CLEVELAND, Miss. Feb. 28 (AP)  Margaret Wade, the Delta State women's basketball coach, will retire at the end of the season, official; said today. Her teams won three consecutive national titles,

title: E1 Maestro of Polo Wears Fame Quietly
description: In a city accustomed to the proclamations of a Joe Namath, a Muhammad All or a Reggie Jackson, the man billed as the world's best polo player went almost unnoticed here yesterday.

title: U.S. Announces Study On Radiation Hazards
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)  The Energy Department today announced the beginning of an extensive study of 250,000 people to determine whether cancer, leukemia and other fatal diseases are caused by radiation exposures even lower than those now permitted by safety standards.

title: Europe: Calm in the Oil Storm
description: BONN, Feb. 28  The contrast is striking. While the Carter Administration puts forward urgent plans to cope with disruption in oil supplies, Europe is generally calm in the face of the Iranian oil cutoff and the round of price rises it has fostered.

title: New Federal Rules Curb Meting Out Food Stamps
description: New Federal regulations will cause a typical fourperson welfare family in New York City to lose about $10 a month in foodstamp benefits starting today, with similar losses upstate, according to state and city officials.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 28 (AP) Texas In ternational Airlines offered a merger agreement package today worth $49.50 for each share of National Airlines common stock.

title: Bejart Rechoreographs 2 Ballets for March Series
description: Maurice Bejart's Ballet of the 20th Century will begin a threeweek engagement at the Minskoff Theater next Tuesday, with premieres of two familiar ballets rechoreographed by Mr. 13ejart. Seen on opening night will be his Gaiete Parisienne and Le Spectre de la Rose, as well as a new version of his Bolero.

title: Some in Iran Finding Islamic Law Harsh, its Justice Swift,
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 28Many civil libertarians here  particularly those who were active in the human rights movement that opposed the policies of the Shah  have taken great exception to the summary executions of 10 neonle. including eight generals since Feb. 11, after secret trials generally conducted in the middle of the night.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Climb 3%
description: Prices paid to farmers rose 3 percent in February to a level 24 percent above that of a year ago, the Department of Agriculture said yesterday.

title: Court Rule on Diplomats Retirement Stirs Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The Supreme Court's recent decision upholding mandatory retirement of career diplomats at the age of 60 has provoked debate at the State Department and a move in Congress to repeal the 33yearold requirement.

title: Col. Juanita Redmond Hipps, 66; Nurse on Bataan in World War II
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP)  Lieut. Col. Juanita Redmond Hipps, former Army nurse who served on Bataan and Corregidor in the early months of World War II, died Sunday at her home. She was 66 years old.

title: Knicks Routed By Spurs
description: SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 28 (AP) George Gervin pumped in 33 points, 18 in the third quarter, and five other San Antonio Spurs hit in double figures tonight as the Spurs easily routed the New York Knicks, 135112, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Deaths
description: ESPENSCHEIDGertrude k 81 veers, suddenly on February 26, 1979, of Park Slope. Brooklyn, NY, daughter of the late Nicholas & Csfelle Espenscheld. Interment prev ate Memorial services to be held at a later date.

title: Jane Byrne's Defeat of Mayor Shatters Image of Democratic Machine in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 28  Jane M. Byrne's victory over City Hall yesterday shattered the legend of the invincible Chicago Democratic machine.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Accelerators Inc., Austin, Tex., a producer of ionimplantation systems for the semiconductor industry, has named Walter J. Picker president, succeeding Bernard A. Peskin, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Find, Star Gelding, Dead at 29
description: GLYNDON, Md., Feb. 28 (AP)  Find, who won more money than any other Marylandbred thoroughbred, has been buried at Sagamore Farm. The gelding, who raced nine years for Alfred Vanderbilt, was found dead Monday, lying in the snow on a hill at the farm.

title: Carey Is Backed On a Bill to Aid MitchellLama
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28  Governor Carey and Democratic legislators announced Agreement today on a bill that would use limited rent increases and lowinterest loans to rescue the financially strained MitchellLama housing program for middleincome people.

title: Key Pay Pacts Brighten Labor Picture in Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 28  After weeks of strikes and disruptions, the British labor scene has taken a significant turn for the better, and some people, including Prime Minister James Callaghan, have begun saying that the worst is over.

title: Congressional Blacks Vow to Stir Campaign Against Budget Trims
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The Congressional Black Caucus told President Carter today that it intended to mobilize public opinion to fight his proposed reductions in social welfare programs.

title: 60Story Tower Sought For BonwitTeller Site
description: Donald J. Trump, the president of the Trump Organization, proposes to tear down the Fifth Avenue building occupied by Bonwit Teller and erect in its place a $100 million, 60story tower of bronzecolored glass combining retail stores, offices and condominium apartments.

title: Music of U.S., Egypt And Ireland at Concerts
description: The Alternative Center for International Arts, 28 East Fourth Street, will offer music from the United States, Ireland and Egypt this weekend. Tomorrow at 8 P.M., Khamis El Fino will play the oud, a 10stringed predecessor to the modern guitar. Accompanying Mr. Fino will be Aziza Ali, a dancer, and Joseph Israel Rass on the dumbek, a Middle Eastern drum.

title: Nigeria to Mediate in Chad's War
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 28  Chad's bitterly feuding leaders, President Felix Malloum, and Prime Minister Hissen Habrt, have accepted a Nigerian offer of mediation at a conference in the northern city of Kano next week, according to Government and diplomatic sources here.

title: Chains Sales Rose in January
description: The sales in January of 32 of the na tions largest retail chains were 12.3 percent greater than in January 1978, according to Chain Store Age, a trade publication.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Begin Says Grave Issues Still Block Peace Treaty
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 28 Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that grave issues continued to separate Egypt and Israel on their proposed peace treaty, and he asserted that the United States was supporting Egyptian proposals that were totally unacceptable to Israel.

title: Syracuse Conquers Bonnies
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 28  Syracuse University justified the highest national ranking it has ever had in basketball tonight when the Orange gained its 19th straight victory by beating St. Banaventure, 8371, in the first round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference playoffs.

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY FEB 28,1979

title: Chicago Is Her Kind of Town
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 28  Jane Byrne strolled down victory lane today, down the Magnificent Mile, the fashionable shopping stretch of Michigan Avenue. Cab drivers honked horns and shoppers shouted, Give em hell, Jane! and her bright red lipstick flashed like a Christmas wreath around her winner's smile.

title: ABRAHAM DREIER, 90, QUEENS BUSINESSMAN
description: Abraham Dreier, founder and chair.. man of the board of the Dreier Structural Steel Company in Long Island City, Queens, died last Thursday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 90 years old.

title: Hitting the Antiques Show Trail
description: YOU won't find it on your Mobil Guide map and no one has booked it for a packaged tour, but a group of New York and New England antiques dealers have locked up their snowbound shops, packed their covered wagons and hit the Old Chippendale Trail.

title: Egypt Says a Mideast Peace Pact Is Possible if Begin Is Reasonable
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Feb. 28 Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil said today that Egypt still believed a Middle East peace agreement was possible if the Israeli Prime Minister, Menachem Begin, was reasonable.

title: Ballet: Pennsylvanians In LaFontsee Premiere
description: THE PENNSYLVANIA BALLET returned to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday night and again demonstrated what a splendid organization it is. It's real grapany, an ensemble of dancers who maim harmoniously together. But its members also shine as soloists. A Comparable concern for excellence is evident in the company's musical standards, for its Pennsylvania Orchestra, conducted by Maurice Kaplow, is a fine one.

title: Backgammon:
description: FORT WORTH

title: Social Security and Sex Discrimination
description: Four decades ago, when Social Security benefits were first paid, only one marriage in six ended in divorce and only one married woman in six worked outside the home. Today, half of all marriages break up and half of all married women work. Yet Social Security benefits are still tailored to the tradition that each family has one breadwinner and that every marriage will endure.

title: Attendance of Handicapped Rises As SchoolBus Mediation Is Stalled
description: As Mayor Koch's kiddie liftrolled into its third day and parents found other means of transportation, nearly 50 percent of the handicapped children affected by the strike of schoolbus drivers managed to make it to their classrooms in New York City yesterday.

title: Saudis Alert Their Army in Response to Yemeni War
description: CAIRO, Feb. 28  Saudi Arabia has embarked on military and diplomatic moves to stop the war between two Arab neighbors along its southern border.

title: Remember, Thou Art Dust
description: Bishop Frances J. Mugavero, right, and Bishop John J. Snyder of the Diocese of Brooklyn, administering ashes to parishioners at St. James Cathedral during Ash Wednesday service. Roman Catholics throughout the world marked the beginning of Lent, a time of prayer and penance in preparation for Easter.

title: New Office for Job Service
description: Starting today the Queens office of the New York State Employment Service will operate from new quarters at 9745 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park. The office, which helps applicants find industrial, clerical, sales, apparel and service jobs, was previously at 4215 Crescent Street, Long Island City.

title: GOING OUT Gulde
description: NIGHT OF THE IGUANA Greenwict Village's Lone Star Cafe should be jumping  even more than usual. At a festive hoedown tonight hailing Texas Independence Day, a galaxy of top country music and blues performers among them Doug Sahm, Kinky Friedman, Robert Gordon, Dr. John, Elliot Murphy, the Frogman, Paul Butterfield and the Greasy Wheels band are doing their things until 4 A.M.

title: Soviet Launches Sattellite
description: MOSCOW, Feb 23 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union announced today the launching of Intercosmos 19, the latest in its series of satellites for studying the earth's outer atmosphere.

title: Court Halts Bank Credit To Iran
description: The latest development in what may become a series of shocks to the American banking system as a result of the violence in Iran has appeared in the form of a preliminary injunction temporarily prohibiting the Chase Manhattan Bank from honoring a letterofcredit commitment to an Iranian bank.

title: Protest on Coast Exposes Carter Political Wounds
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28  President Carter's now abandoned plan to speak in Los Angeles Friday night at a Democratic Party fundraising event has exposed a serious loss of support for the President amone California Democrats.

title: Better Drops Bid To Get Key Job As M.TA. Aide
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28  Stephen Berger withdrew today as a candidate for chief operating officer of the Metropolitan Transportation AUthority in what he called an attempt to resolve a conflict between himself and the chairman of the authority.

title: CelebrityStudded Opening for New Apollo
description: For the first time in a long time, West 43d Street welcomed a celebratory crowd of theater professionals and theater buffs last night. The occasion was the opening of On Golden Pond at the New Apollo Theater, and the enthusiasm for the restored legitimate house, between Times Squire and Eighth Avenue, bubbled into optimistic talk about the burgeoning plans for turning around the adjacent area.

title: Saving on Light Bills
description: WASHINGTON

title: Political Static on Public TV
description: Richard Nixon made no secret of his belief that public broadcasting's news and public affairs programs were unfriendly to him. Now, newly disclosed documents from the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy show in detail how his Administration tried to destroy such programs in the early 1970's. They offer cautionary lessons as the future of public broadcasting is being shaped.

title: Yanks Seek a Spot for Beniquez
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 28  Having polished the art of playing center field, Juan Beniquez now has mastered either the art of diplomacy or the art of selfpsychology. He was using one or the other todly when he discussed his undetermined status with the Yankees.

title: Three Children Die in Fire
description: EASTON, Pa., Feb. 28 (AP)  Three small children died last night in a fire that broke out in an apartment on the city's south side. The Northampton County Coroner, Joseph Reichel, said that the victims, a girl and two boys,, were the children of Kathleen Wright. Mrs. Wright was hospitalized in serious condition with burns.

title: World News Briefs
description: GENEVA, Feb. 28  The Soviet Union said today that the leader of a dissident labor union required psychiatric treatment for head injuries received while employed in a coal mine as an engineer.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury sold oneyear bills yesterday at a discount rate of 9.485 percent, a rate that is equivalent to a yield of 10.40 percent. These 52week bills represent the loftiest returns currently available in the vast Government securities market.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Kuwait Warns on Prices
description: KUWAIT, Feb. 28  The Oil Minister of Kuwait, which has raised oil prices by a larger amount than any other country in recent weeks, warned today that world supplies would probably remain tight throughout this year, presaging a total price rise by the end of the year that is likely to exceed the 14.5 percent agreed upon last December by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Social Security Unable to credit $69 Billion in Wages
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)  The Social Security Administration disclosed today that it had been unable to credit nearly $69 billion in wages to the correct workers accounts because of identification problems dating to 1937.

title: Stocks Mixed
description: The stock market turned in its best performance yesterday in five sessions by closing mixed despite the impact of rising oil prices and the unsettled international situation.

title: Time to Close Unneeded Hospitals
description: When Mayor Koch meets with Governor Carey today to discuss closing down unneeded hospitals in New York City, we hope they will finally stop ducking.

title: CANADA FINDS RISE OF 28% IN GAS SALES TO U.S. IS FEASIBLE
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 28  Canada's National Energy Board gave the green light today to a 28 percent increase in natural gas exports to the United States, an increase that would help Americans in their search for energy sources in the wake of Iran's cutoff of oil exports.

title: MANLEY ASTRACHAN
description: Manley Astrachan died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Talking Business
description: In past business cycles, the housing industry was used to make the economy cool off. Interest rates were rased higher than the ceilings that savings institutions were permitted to pay, and housing funds flowed elsewhere. That was considered unfair, and the system was changed after the money crunch of 1974 to make housing bear less of the burden.

title: Swiss Will Study Assets of Shah, But Delay Freezing His Accounts
description: BERN, Feb. 28 (Reuters)  The Swiss Government decided today to investigate assets held by the Shah of Iran in Switzerland, but it put off freezing his bank accounts, as demanded by the new Government in Teheran.

title: Washington Officials Foresee No Possibility Of Banning Saccharin
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Any chance that either Congress or the Carter Administration would impose a ban on the use of saccharin virtually ended today.

title: 900 Invited to See Ward Sworn In
description: More than 900 people  including all elected officials in New York City  have been invited to attend the official swearingin today of Deputy Mayor Haskell G. Ward, the black official who has been under fire since he joined the Koch administration a year ago.

title: Rossman Match Slated for April 14
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28 (UPI)  Victor Galindez, whose scheduled lightheavyweightg title fight in Las Vegas last Saturday was postponed because of a dispute concerning officials, said today he had agreed to fight Mike Rossman, the W.B.A. champion, on April 14 in Miami Beach..

title: Around the Nation
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 28 (AP)  The Board of Education backed off late today on its pledge to reopen the city's strikebound schools, but Gov. Joseph P. Teasdale vowed to act to end the 45dayold strike.

title: More Oil Units Cut Deliveries
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said yesterday that it was reducing worldwide deliveries of foreign crude oil by 9 percent. retroactive to Jan. 1, because of the cessation of Iranian exports. Other major oil companies have previously announced similar steps.

title: Inmate Wearing Officer Uniform Flees From Jail
description: A twiceconvicted murderer serving a life sentence in Trenton State Prison escaped from the Men's House of Detention in Brooklyn yesterday while awaiting trial on robbery charges.

title: Donald Burr, Singer, Actor and Director Of Broadway Shows
description: Donald Burr, a singer, actor and director who appeared in many Broadway shows, died Tuesday at Lyons (N.J.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and had lived for many years in Long Valley, N.J.

title: A New York Player Extends Miss Evert
description: DALLAS, Feb. 28  Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert took steps toword a finalround meeting today as both scored victories in a $200,000 women's indoor circuit tournament.

title: Design Notebook
description: FOR anyone who lived through the 19501s,Which Twin Has the Toni? is as much a pert of the culture of that decade as rcckandcoil and the New Look from Dior.With every ccotrived curl glued in place in duplicate, and two pairs of red, painted lips at once suggesting ana denying sensuality (the hair, of course, could never be disarranged), the two identical models (were there we or two?) were the epitome of the girdled, madeup, uptight, prelib woman. No wonder the next step was to let it all hang out. Of such marvelous trivia is the stuff of history made.

title: Iran Will Cut Ties With Oil Consortium
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 28  The newly appointed chairman of the National Iratiian Oil Company told 3,000 employees today at the company's headquarters that Iran would no longer work through the foreign oil consortium that, until last year, managed much of the country's oil production and marketed half of it.

title: Missing Ship's Lifeboat Found
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Feb. 28 (AP)  The owners of a West German tanker said today that the crew had discovered a capsized lifeboat belonging to the 37,000ton freighter Munchen, which is believed to have been lost in the Atlantic three months ago with 23 people aboard.

title: Martin J. Gilman, at 71; Maker of Football Gear
description: Martin John Gilman, a pioneering developer of footballpractice equipment and the owner of Marty Gilman Inc., of Gilman, Conn., died Feb. 21 at the W. W. Backus Hospital in Norwich, Conn., at the age of 71.

title: Dealers Find Home Is Where The Art Is
description: HOW else could Sarah Rentschler afford a penthouse? How else could Barbara Toll afford to live surrounded by art? To be sure, Miss Rentschler sometimes wishes she could retreat to the water tower on top of her building. Miss Toll got to the point where she chucked out her answering machine.

title: Gloom Befalls Bilandic. Partisans
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 28  The mood was somber and nobody was smiling at Schaller's Pump, a hangout for party regulars across the street from the Democrats 11th Ward headquarters in the Bridgeport section of Chicago, where Mayor Michael A. Bilandic lives.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Spiralshaped rain and snow clouds cover the Middle West and the upper and middle Mississippi Valley. Thick frontal rain and snow clouds are apparent over the northern Rockies and the Pacific Northwest. High and middle level clouds are scattered through the Southeast and the Southern Pacific States.

description: BROWNSTEINRoslyn, Pt Ridge field, N.J., beloved wife of Bernard, dear daughter of Lena Lichtio, de voted mother of Wendy Gordon and Jay, lovino sister of Shirley arid Mildred I.ichtig adored grandmother of Jodi Gordon. Services will be held at Gufferman.Musicant k eeitzman, corner of Park and Passaic Streets, Hackensack, on Friday. March 7, at 10 CM. Visitaloon at the chapel, Thursday, 7 PM

title: Focke, German Aviation Pioneer And Father of Helicopter, Dies
description: Heinrich Focke, the German aviation pioneer who was known as the father of the helicopter, died Sunday at his home in Bremen, West Germany. He was 88 years old.

title: Gene Kauffman, at 52; Headed Medical Center
description: Gene Kauffman, founder and president of the Multiphasic Medical Center in Hempstead, L.I., died at the Heart Institute in Miami Beach on Feb. 23. He was 52 years old and lived in Plainview. L.I.

title: Mobil in Accord to Acquire Bodcaw
description: The Mobil Corporation, the first of the oil companies to diversify about three years ago with the acquisition of Marcor, operators of the Montgomery Ward & Co. retail chain and the Container Corporation of America paper and packaging operation, reached an agreement in principle yesterday to acquire the Bodcaw Company, a Dallasbased producer of forest product, agricultural products, liner board, oil and gas.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Commission for Social Development 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Connecticut Mummy Mystery Unwinds
description: MIDDLETOIVN, Conn., Feb. 28 The mystery of the Egyptian mummy with three cylinders encased within its pelvic cavity began to unravel here tonight.

title: U.S. Monitoring War Through Space Photos And Radio Intercepts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)  Lacking observers anywhere near the battlefield, the United States is relying on a mosaic of intercepted radio messages and satellite photographs to keep track of the ChineseVietnamese war.

title: February's Last Day Brings Welcome Spring Temperatures
description: The Hudson River, recently clogged with ice; formed a placid backdrop for bike riders and a runner in shorts yesterday near the 79th Street Boat Basin. Under sunny skies temperature soared to a springlike 57 degrees in the city. Today may bring rain, with a possibility of snow, or sleet, as winter again returns to the metropolitan area.

title: The City
description: After a ninemonth investigation, the City Council's Ethics Committee completed specifications of conflictofinterest allegations against Councilman Eugene F. Mastropieri, Democrat of Queens.

title: ExMental Patient Arrested in SubwayHurling Killing
description: A 39yearold chronic mental patient, who allegedly spent much of his time menacing subway passengers in Greenwich Village, has been arrested for the murder of a Good Samaritan who was hurled to his death in front of a D train from the West Fourth Street station early Sunday.

title: Home beat;The Lowly Typewriter
description: BECAUSE this is an electronic machine, I have been able to give it a new topology, e plained Mario Bellini, the Italian furniture and industrial designer, referring to the new Olivetti ET 221 electronic typewriter. This is the lowest professional typewriter ever produced, Mr. Bellini continued. I've tried to stay away from the mechanical look and to give the machine as flat a profile as possible. Instead of having a movable keyboard or golfball typing element, the machine contains a series of electronic modules and a daisy wheel printer that can be changed to offer four type sizes. The machine operates quietly; can reverse type (white on black), has a multilingual capacity, can retype prestored information (addresses, form letters), and can print character by character, line by line or word by word. The keyboard, Mr. Bellini added, is a rich and concentrated piece, and includes normal typewriter keyboard, with additional functions placed either to its right or left. The machine's other surfaces have been kept as uncluttered as possible. Is there any reason for the typewriter's matte black finish? I was told Americans love charcoal black, Mr. Bellini said, half smiling. But seriously, I think that black is very professional color, will make the machine compatible with many different working environments and is the best choice for visually reducing its volume. The ET 221 will retail for $1,950 after March 15 from the Olivetti Corporation of America, 500 Park Avenue.

title: Soldier Held in Woman's Death
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 28 (AP)  A Fort Carson soldier from New London, Conn., has been arrested in the death of an 18yearold woman. Janet Berry. wnose body naa apparently been thrown down a 75foot embankment along a rural road, the police said. Specialist 4 Ronald Tasca, 27, was arrested and taken to E1 Paso County jail on suspicion of firstdegree ??urder.

title: House Defeats Measure to Raise The Limit on Federal Borrowing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (Reuters)  The House of Representatives defeated a bill tonight to raise the Federal borrowing limit. The vote was 222 to 194.

title: Bronx Man Is Accused Of Stealing Fuel Truck
description: A 48yearold Bronx man has been accused of stealing a 3,000gallon fuel truck and making almost $1,000 in oil deliveries to his friends.

title: Emily Workum, 75, Victim of Fall
description: Emily Workum, a pioneer in the Planned Parenthood movement, was killed instantly Monday when she was thrown from a horse near La Osa Ranch, about 70 miles south of Tucson, Ariz., where she was vacationing with her husband, Fifield Workum. Mrs. Worlmm was 75 years old and a resident of Bedford, N.Y.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Concert: Early Music
description: THE courtly mannered passions expressed by the Minnesingers of the 12th to 14th centuries and the more earthy bourgeois music that marked the succeeding German Renaissance Were the subject of a program by the New York Consort for Poetry and Music in camegie Kemal Hall on Wednesday night. It was one of several such concert presentations devoted to early music, as instructional as they are musically edifying, that the ensemble gives.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Deaths
description: ABREULeslle. on February 27, 1979. Beloved wife of Angel. Devoted mother of Rosemary Lutley and Robert Abrev. Dear grandmother Of Jeffrey Lutley. Reposing Andrew Torregrossa Funeral Home, 2265 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn through Friday. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery Saturday.

title: Stockholder Sues McGraw
description: Ira Barmak. a television producer who holds 7,000 shares of McGrawHill Inc., filed a classaction damage suit in Manhattan Federal court yesterday against the publishing company and 13 directors, charging them with violation of proxy rules and the issuance of false and misleading statements to block a $I billion takeover bid by the American Express Company.

title: Publishing: A New James Baldwin
description: JAMES BALDWIN has a new book coming from Dial this fall. Entitled, Just Above My Head, it deals with the intertwined lives from childhood to adulthood of a gospel singer, his bother and a WIMP eiri who is a child preacher.

title: IN THE NATION
description: President Carter was asked at his news conference this week about charges that he was exhibiting weak ness and impotency in his foreign policy. Keeping his cool almost to the point of rigor mortis, Mr. Carter said that it wasn't so, and anyway:

title: Webster Returns To Knicks Today
description: The Knicks will reactivate Marvin Webster today and the 7footlinch center should be ready to play in tomorrow night's game against the San Diego Clippers at Madison Square Garden.

title: NCR Unveils Computers; Technology In New Era
description: The NCR Corporation has announced five new computers, confirming that a new generation in computer technology Is entering the marketplace.

title: Dewey F. Bartlett, 59, ExOklahoma Senator
description: TULSA, Okla., March 1 (AP)  Former United States Senator Dewey F. Bartlett, who retired last month, died of cancer tonight.

title: Lebanese Voice Fears  As Saudi Peace Forces  Prepare to Withdraw
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 1  Saudi troops who have been serving as a buffer between Syrian soldiers and Lebanese Christian militiamen here prepared today to return home on Saturday, and Lebanese Government officials expressed fears that anew round of fighting mieht result.

title: Munson Still Mr. Tough Guy, Not Mr. Nice Guy
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. Gene Michael, as personable a player or coach as any who have been around the Yankees the last 10 years, has worked with Thurman Munson for most of that time. Not on Munson's hitting and catching but on his personality.

title: US. Reported to Reject  Saudi Missile Request
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (Reuters) The United States has rejected a request by Saudi Arabia to buy the Lance groundtoground missile now deployed in Europe as well as Israel, United States Government sources said today.

title: Mary McFadden: Life of Her Own Design
description: In her Park Avenue apartment, surtounded by works of art, Mary McFadden seems like some exquisite, pampered orchid of a woman whose responsibilities surely could be no heavier than what to pack for the weekend in Palm Beach.

title: The City
description: A guard at the Brooklyn House of Detention was suspended yesterday because he failed to intercept James Stout, a convicted murderer, who walked out of the jail's main entrance Wednesday wearing the uniform of a correction officer who had been overpowered by inmates.

title: Shoes and Ships and Sealing Wax
description: Professional foatball players union leaders and the club owners Management Council meet in New York today to discuss shoes and ships and sealing wax and cabbages and kings and why the sea is boiling hot and whether pigs have skins.

title: Carey and Byrne Sign Legislation For $1.4 Billion in Transit Projects
description: Amid the clutter of construction in the Port Authority Bus Terminal, the Governors of New York and New Jersey signed legislation yesterday to introduce a $1.4 billion package of masstransit improvements.

title: Television

description: WASHINGTON, March 1  The House of Representatives passed today by overwhelming voice vote a bill to extend retroactively a waiver on punitive duties on subsidized imports  legislation foreign countries deem essential to completela new round of trade liberalization negotiations.

title: House Rejects Ouster of Diggs; Will Send Case to Ethics Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)  The House turned back an attempt today to expel Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr., the Michigan Democrat convicted of accepting kickbacks from employees.

description: Below 42d Street

title: Ward Sworn In by Koch as Deputy Mayor
description: With 175 people looking on, only a few of whom were black elected officials, Haskell G. Ward was sworn in by Mayor Koch yesterday as Deputy Mayor for Human Services.

title: Rutgers, Pitt Eastern 8 Victors
description: PITTSBURGH, March 1 (AP) Daryl Strickland, who finished with 18 points, made two free throws with five seconds left to secure a 5552 victory for Rutgers over foulplagued West Virginia tonight in the semifinals of the Eastern Eight basketball tournament.

title: Small Towns Join Forces to Get Cable TV
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Small suburban cornmunities in the New York metropolitan area, bypassed when cabletelevision companies first started scrambling for lucrative contracts in the most densely populated areas, have started banding together to negotiate contracts that will, at last, get their residents on the cable.

title: Corco Pact with Seaoil
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, which has been operating under the protection of the Federal Bankruptcy Act for the last year, said yesterday that it had signed an agreement in principle with the Arabian Seaoil Corporation for Seaoil to take an interest in Corco

title: Over 2,400 U.S. Scientists Pledge To Shun Soviet Over Dissidents
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 More than 2,400 American scientists, inciucfing 13 Nobel laureates, pledged today to curtail sharply all cooperation with the Soviet Union to protest its imprisonment of the dissident scientists Yuri F. Orlov and Anatoly B. Shcharansky.

title: Mary Lieberthal Bride of Lawyer
description: The marriage of Mary Lieberthal to Donato A. Evangelista took place last evening at the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: United Press Internatinal
description: TWO POINTS AND A HARD LANDING are part of basketball as Kentucky's Chuck Verderber discovered after failing to prevent basket by Alabama's Reggie King in Wildcats 101100 victory in Southeastern Conference tourney in Birmingham, Ala.

title: Inflation. But Where's the Press?
description: The press has known that an inflationary crisis was coming since at least the summer of 1978, when speculation began on how President Carter would deal with continuing unemployment, rising deficits and the sliding dollar. Finally, on Oct. 24, he announced his program of wageprice guidelines. With so much time to gear up, why has the press, through its news analyses, columns and editorials failed so absymally to clarify causes and assess cures?

title: E.P.A., Citing Miscarriages, Restricts 2 Herbicides
description: Citing new findings suggesting that two widely used herbicides increase the danger of miscarriages in women, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency ordered an emergency ban yesterday on most uses of 2,4,5T and SiIves, which contain a key ingredient of Agent Orange, the poison used to defoliate vast jungle areas during the Vietnam War.

title: SCOTS AND WELSH VOTE ON SELFRULE
description: BANNOCKBURN, Scotland, March  In this village, the site of the greatest Scottish triumph over England, and in other communities across the country, the people of Scotland have cast their momentous votes for or against limited selfgovernment.

title: House Panel Investigating the Awarding of a Contract for Saudi Schools
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  A House subcommittee is looking into whether undue government influence was used to get a potentially lucrative foreign construction contract awarded to a Texas company whose major shareholder now is the Saudi Arabian who bought Bert Lance's bank stock last year.

title: Texaco To Close Stations
description: Texaco Inc., one of the country's major oil companies, announced yesterday that it would close 2,161 service stations in the Middle West and upstate New York. Altogether, these outlets account for only 5 percent of its market, the company said.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar, bolstered by traders ignoring some had news but feeling better about the American Government's control of the money supply, rose on currency markets at home and abroad yesterday.

title: Pizzeria Owner Held For Allegedly Plotting To Blow Up a House
description: For years, Frank Vono has been trou. bled by explosions and fires. Now, according to the police in Enfield, Cann., he has a problem with bombs, too. He was arrested yesterday and charged with planning to use one to blow up the house of an 81yearold woman with whom he had a disagreement on Zoning

title: China Now Holding Up Contracts With Japan
description: TOKYO, March 1  In a move that has shocked Japanese business officials, China has notified Japanese trading companies that it has not yet approved a large number of recent industrial plant and equipment contracts valued at about $2.9 billion, a leading businessman said here today.

title: Little Girls Try Out for Big Role in Remake of Shirley Temple Movie
description: An East Side movie theater was crawling with starstruck little girls yesterday. Some wore tight sausage curls a. la Shirley Temple. Others wore their best party dresses and tap shoes. One, named Cara, wore prim white gloves and insisted she could play a 6yearold, even though she was really the ripe old age of 8.

title: Screen: Albert Brooks Turns 'Real Life' Into Movie:Family is the Lens
description: ALBERT BROOKS explains, at the beginning of his drily funny first film, "Real Life," that his idea was to "depict day-to-day living in contemporary America and at the same time hold a motion-picture audience spellbound." Clearly, this wasn't going to be easy, nor would it be easy for his film to contemplate reality, because that, he admits proudly throughout the film, is a subject about which he knows absolutely nothing. But as it turns out, Mr. Brooks's ignorance is his secret weapon. And "Real Life" is his often very witty assault on manners, moviemaking, an allegedly typical American family and everything its members hold dear."Real Life" follows the adventures of a crew of film makers and scientists, commanded by Mr. Brooks, as they isolate a model family in Phoenix and proceed, in the interests of cinma vrit, to pester these people mercilessly, and invade their privacy in a variety of colorful ways. Its manner is deadpan and sly, so sly that some viewers may not find it comic at all. But for anyone well-disposed toward Mr. Brooks, who is never without his absolute insincerity and irrational good cheer, "Real Life" is full of delightful nonsense, a very funny account of one man's crusade to capture all the truth and wisdom that money can buy.Mr. Brooks is at his most droll as he outlines his project at the beginning of the film. Demonstrating an amusing fondness for anything that smacks of science, he explains how a computer has studied potential subjects and come up with "digital readouts of screen presence." There has also been testing for a "charisma factor," and development of a lot of fancy new cameras. "Quiet. Efficient. Expensive." says Mr. Brooks, bursting with hilarious and perfectly idiotic pride.Once the right family is chosen  a husband and wife played by Charles Grodin and Frances Lee McCain, and their two listless children  Mr. Brooks and his crew go to work, filming their subjects from odd, unflattering angles and never allowing them a moment's peace. When the wife visits her gynecologist, the film crew visits too  although Mr. Brooks, whose special forte is false reassurance, guarantees her that "I won't film anything that'll embarrass you. I couldn't use it anyway, I'm locked into a PG."Even so, the gynecologist is furious, not over an invasion of his patient's privacy, but because he has "had some bad experiences with the '60 Minutes' people." Mr. Brooks looks quite unsurprised by this news. The signal quality of his world view is that show business is  and has a perfect right to be  everywhere.Soon enough, both Mr. Brooks and his project have gone to pot. Aside from some footage of Mr. Yeager (Mr. Grodin), a veterinarian, accidentally killing a horse on the operating table, he hasn't exactly gotten to the heart of anything. And the studio executive in charge of this production (played as a telephone voice by the producer Jennings Lang) loses patience and decides to cut off Mr. Brooks's allowance. It would perhaps be unfair to reveal just how low Mr. Brooks is willing to sink in his efforts to salvage his film. But the ending of "Real Life" is the most uproarious of a good many inspired moments.Mr. Brooks, who was co-author of the screenplay with Monica Johnson and Harry Shearer, delivers any line as if it were part of a pitch to sell his audience a used car  preferably the kind with a nice new paint job but no working engine. He is all broad grins and happy handshakes, and Mr. Grodin and Miss McCain behave as if they were a little bit afraid of him, as well they should be. His is an entirely one-dimensional character, and "Real Life" has a one-note premise. But the flatness is deliberate and it works remarkably well, even in a feature-length format.If there are certain inconsistencies here and there, well, this is only the first film in what promises to be Mr. Brooks's long and lively career. And as he himself puts it, explaining why his project has strayed so far from its original plan: "There's no law that says we can't start real and end fake. What are they going to do, put me in movie jail?""Real Life" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains only a small amount of moderately strong language.

title: Takashimaya Retrenches on Fifth Avenue
description: The rising value of the Japanese yen is having its effect on Fifth Avenue.

title: Defeat of a Political Machine
description: CHICAGO, March 1 When it became apparent late Tuesday night that Jane M. Byrne really had toppled Mayor Michael A. Bilandic and the onceinvincible Chicago Democratic machine, the shock of initial incomprehension was almost as palpable among her supporters gathered at the Ambassador West Hotel, as in the rest of the city.

title: Slain Italian Was a Teacher
description: TURIN, Italy, March 1 (AP)  A woman killed in a exchange of fire between policemen and presumed terrorists was identified today as a 28yearold former teacher who had been missing since last year. Barbara Azzaroni was identified by her brother a day after she and an alleged comrade were shot. Police officers said she might have played a role in a number of terrorist assaults here, including two killings.

title: Profits Rose At Macy's In Quarter
