description: R.H. Macy & Company, the New York metropolitan area's largest retail chain, reported that its earnings for the quarter ended Jan. 27 climbed 11 percent to a record, while profits for the six months to that date were up 33.2 percent, also to a record.

title: Corporations Report Their Quarterly Sales and Earnings Results
description: For periods as (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchenge, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter

title: About Real Estate
description: The continuing problem of administering rents in New York's immense and diverse supply of apartment houses will come into focus again next week when the Rent Guidelines Board meets to reconsider the rent increases that it promulgated last year.

title: Art People
description: IT would be difficult to beat up much dissent to the proposition that in the domain of the fine arts CarlHenning Pedersen is the most distinguished living Dane. Already before 1939, and in &country adjacent to Germany, he took the side of

title: Satirical Italian Weekly Tells All About World War III
description: ROME, March 1  The war between Communist armies in Indochina has been a boon to the young writers and cartoonists of the far left who are putting out Italy's only satirical newspaper, II Male.

title: California's Executive Shuttle
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1  If it's March, then this must be San Francisco's turn to be headquarters for Thomas R. Wilcox, chairman of the Crocker National Corporation and its principal subsidiary, the Crocker National Bank. Come April, he will be back here for 30 days before heading north for another month.

title: Bridge:
description: The world's biggest team contest, the Grand National Teams, completed its preliminary stages last weekend throughout the metropolitan area. Winners of some of the Swiss team contests in suburban areas were:

title: Most Retailers Report Higher February Sales
description: Retail sales last month continued to run more than 10 percent above the level of a year earlier at most of the nation's largest retail chains. according to sales reports issued yesterday by 15 retail concerns. The exception was Sears, Roebuck & Company, the country's largest retailer, which had a 9.1 percent decline in sales from a year ago, its sixth consecutive monthly drop.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Frontal rain and snow clouds extend from the lake region through the Onio and Tenneesee Valleys to the central Gulf States. Frontal rain and snow clouds also cover the Northern Plains States, the Rockies and the Central and Southern Pacific States. High and middle level clouds are apparent over the Northeast

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets, paying little heed to the Government's reports of declining leading economic indicators and a substantial drop in the money supply, muddled along yesterday with few significant changes in prices and interest rates.

title: Experiment Indicates Little Risk In Some GeneSplicing Research
description: BETHESDA, Md., March 1  Results of some longawaited experiments to gauge the risks of genesplicing research were made public today, and they indicated virtually no hazard in the specific type of work involved.

title: Glasses Raised to Nursing Home and a 95th Birthday
description: There was a double celebration in Greenwich Village Wednesday night much hoisting of Guinness stout for Genevieve Camlian's 95th birthday and more than a few cheers for the rescue of the Village Nursing Home, where Miss Camlian lives.

title: 3 Indicted in Cocaine Sales
description: Three persons were indicted yesterday on Federal charges involving cocaine sales in Manhattan. Narcotics agents said they seized more than 17 pounds of cocaine in the apartment of Horacio Rueda at 328 East 85th Street. The two other defendants were identified as Calixto Agapito of Colombia and Martha Calderon of Miami.

title: YouthJob Funds Rise For Summer in 3 States
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have been allocated about $94 million to finance summer work and training jobs for disadvantaged youths.

title: State Legislators Split on U.S. Budget Convention
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  State legislators, who control whether Congress will be forced to call a constitutional convention on balancing the Federal budget, are as divided over the issue as members of Congress, who have little or nothing to say about it.

title: Italian ExDefense Chief Receives 2Year Term in Lockheed Scandal
description: ROME, March 1 Italy's highest court sentenced Mario Tanassi, a member of Parliament and former Defense Minister, to two years and four months in Jail today for corruption in connection with $1.6 million in bribes allegedly paid by the Lockheed Aircraft Company to Italian officials in 1970 and 1971.

title: At the Movies
description: Pollack and Redford team up again for Electric Horseman.

title: Economic Scene
description: GOTHIC economics, the dismal science at its most horrible, has been enjoying a growing vogue since the Iranian upheaval and the uprush of oil prices. But the trouble with Gothic economics is that it doesn't tell you how to avoid doom. it has no nlace for hatmv endings or soft landings.

title: Economic Indicators Fell by 1.2% In January for a 3d Straight Drop
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The Government index designed to forecast future economic trends posted its third consecutive monthly drop in January, providing a strong signal of a possible economic downturn.

title: Katz Portraits Step Out Of Their Frames
description: THAT paintings should one day get down from the wall makes perfect sense. Who are we to expect them to stay up there, awaiting our pleasure? What more natural than that they should want to step out, look around and get the feel of the third dimension?

title: Poll Shows Carter's Rating On Foreign Policy Is Down
description: Americans are increasingly critical of President Carter's handling of foreign policy, but most of them oppose the use of United States troops to settle international disputes, according to the latest sampling of The New York Times/ CBS Poll.

title: The U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: It's Murder at the Regency Theater Until May
description: Sherlock Holmes, Sam Spade, Miss Marple, Charlie Chan and an assortment of other sleuths, gumshoes and private eyes  not to mention assorted evil masterminds, oily weasels and varied malefactors  are taking up residence this weekend on Broadway at 67th Street.

title: Olympic Contract Signed
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, March 1 (AP)  The International Olympic Committee and the organizers of the 1984 Summer Games ended most a year of difficult negotiating when they signed a formal contract today that placed the Games in Los Angeles for the second time in 52 years.

title: Business and the Law
description: AWAITER at a restaurant overhears executives from the Mr. Widget Corporation plan a tender offer for the stock of XYZ Industries. The waiter tells coworkers at the restaurant, and instead of putting their money in the weekly football pool, they invest in XYZ, the target company.

title: Duke Scores in A.C.C. Tourney
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 1 (AP)  Jim Spanarkel sank two free throws with two seconds remaining today to stave off a Wake Forest rally and lift Duke to a 5856 triumph over Wake Forest in the opening round of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament.

title: Dance: Keen Company
description: ELIZABETE KEEN is choreagraphically reliable. She can put all kinds of dances together and make those dances interesting. Therefore, performances by the Elisabeth Keen Dance Company are apt to be pleasant. And the company's Wednesday evening performance at Playhouse 46 was, for the most part, quite pleasant.

title: Scientists Rejecta Pollution Link To Higher Urban Rates of Cancer
description: There is no evidence that air pollution accounts for higher rates of can in urban areas, researchers told a symposium on the environmental determinants of cancer yesterday. In fact, the researchers said, existing evidence suggests that air pollution generally plays little if any role in causing cancer.

title: St. John's ,and Iona in Met. Final
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 1 St. John's University, which has played in more postseason basketball tournaments than any other college in the nation, never worked harder for a tournament victory than it did tonight when it beat Wagner, 8682, in overtime in the first round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metropolitan regional tournament.

title: Trevor Potts Weds Pamela B. Walker
description: Pamela Buchanan Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grenville Kane Walker of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married last evening to Trevor Charles Bernard Potts of London, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Potts

title: It's Beginning to Look a Lot Like Spring
description: It seemed like May, rather than winter with three weeks to go, yesterday at Grand Army Plaza and Central Park South. A high temperature of 55 degrees, sunny skies and almostbalmy breezes provided a vernal atmosphere; horse carriages, strollers and occupied park benches abetted dayinMay setting. Clouds are expected today.

title: Begin Puts Onus on U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, March 1  Before boarding his plane for the flight to Washington, Prime Minister Begin said today that he believed it was the duty of the United States to convince the Egyptians to change their attitudes.

title: Wonderful Time for Postcard Fans
description: It's perhaps the fastestgrowing hobby in the world, third only to stamps and coins, and this Sunday, deltiologists from all over are planning to have a wonderful time.

title: Israelis Accused U.N. Soldier
description: HAIFA, Israel, March 1 (Reuters)  A Senegalese warrant officer serving with the United Nations Interim Forces in Lebanon was formally charged in District Court here today with having aided Israel's enemies. The officer, Papa Kolisar, attached to a supply unit, was detained last month after officials said explosive material and detonators were found in the spare tire of his jeep.

title: Yes, and No, on Reorganization
description: President Carter's proposal to consolidate three agencies into a Department of Natural Resources has, predictably, aroused Congressmen, special interest groups and bureaucrats who fear losing present leverage. But the proposal is, if anything, too modest; it sensibly follows along lines repeatedly proposed in the past by blueribbon commissions.

title: The Region
description: Pay scales continued to be lower on Long Island than in New York City last year, but while the margin widened for bluecollar workers, it narrowed for those in whitecollar jobs, according to Herbert Bienstock, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. He said average whitecollar pay levels in Nassau and Suffolk counties were 8 percent lower in 1978 than for comparable employment in New York City, compared with a 10 percent difference in the year before.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Auctions
description: Lifting the cup to porcelain.

title: ExBar Head May Be Disbarred
description: DES MOINES, March I (AP)  The Grievance Commission of the Iowa Supreme Court has recommended the disbarment of John D. Randall Sr., former president of the American Bar Association. Mr. Randall, 78 years old, of Cedar Rapids, was president of the association nine years ago. The panel said that it had based its conclusions on Mr. Randall's attorneyclient relationship with a business partner, the late Lubbell Myers. Final action is now up to the State Supreme Court.

title: PRICES FOR GASOLINE ARE VARYING WIDELY
description: The commercially lettered sign atop a Mobil gasoline pump on 11th Avenue had until a few days ago indicated 82.9 cents a gallon as the price for unleaded gas. Yesterday the sign was replaced by a handdrawn placard reading 85.9 cents.

title: The Pop Life
description: FOR a while there, it looked as if the only rock bands coining out of the British Isles were of the extreme punk/newwave variety. Of course, that's how it looked; even at the height of the new wave it was apparent that all sorts of veterans (Ian Dury) and anachronisms (Kate Bush) managed to sneak through under the newwave banner. As far as the American commercial market was concerned, the new British acts seemed longer on style than commercial potential.

title: Market Up; Dow Gains 7.02 Points
description: Natural gas and casino stocks, the market's standout groups in recent weeks, returned to favor yesterday to lead a brisk rally. Sharing honors in the march to higher prices were takeover situations and selected bluechip issues.

title: What's Behind Oil Price Rises?
description: On the energy scene, the winter of 1979 has been dreary.

title: A Symphony Concert That Pulls Out All the Stops
description: Piero Gamba is tenacious, to say the least. Nearly 20 years ago, he conceived the idea of founding an international symphony orchestra that would cut across linguistic and political barriers to achieve a greater spiritual fusion of man through the arts or, as Mr. Gamba put it more simply the other day, to create through musical harmony an example for all other spheres. In 1964, he launched the idea officially with the establishment of the Symphonicum Europae Foundation in Monte Carlo under the patronage of the late Queen Elisabeth of Belgium. Tomorrow night, at Carnegie Hall, the 15th anniversary of Symphonicum Europae will be celebrated rather spectacularly with a concert enlisting the services of at least a dozen wellknown musicians and theater personalities. The orchestra will be the Winnipeg Symphony, of which Mr. Gamba has been music director for the last seven years, and he, of course, will conduct.

title: Screen: Kaplan Makes 'Fast Break' Look Easy:Basketball Tale
description: "FAST BREAK," which opens today at three Manhattan theaters, stars Gabe Kaplan of television's "Welcome Back, Kotter" as a New York delicatessen clerk who becomes the basketball coach at a tacky Western college, where he guides to victory a group of players slightly less mismatched than the Bad News Bears. Though these basketball players are a good deal older than the baseball-playing Bears, they are much less foul-mouthed.The movie, written by Sandor Stern and directed by Jack Smight, is rather like a successful television situation comedy in that it is very cheerful without actually being very funny. As do some of our most popular standup comedians, Mr. Kaplan sort of floats over his material, always in charge of it, but never deeply involved. This is not a rebuke. It's a description of a particular kind of performing that probably originated in vaudeville, was carried into radio and nightclubs and now has reached its fullest expression on television.In the way that no one would expect Johnny Carson to disappear into a character he plays in a "Tonight" Show sketch, we accept Mr. Kaplan's public, talk-show personality as the hustling basketball coach at Cadwallader College. While Mr. Kaplan acts the role, he seems to be keeping up a running commentary on it. It's a nicely self-conscious performance in which the actor gives it all he's got, at the same time appearing to say. "Look, Ma, no hands!"The supporting cast includes Michael Warren, Harold Sylvester, Mavis Washington and Bernard King, as the black ("ethnic") players Mr. Kaplan imports to Cadwallader; Randee Heller, who looks like a brunette Farah Fawcett-Majors, who plays Mr. Kaplan's wife; Connie Sawyer, who plays his mother, and Bert Remsen as the coach of the Top Ten team that Cadwallader has to beat if the movie is ever to end."Fast Break," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), includes some vulgar language.

title: 2 Union Groups Seek Strike End On School Buses
description: Two of New York City's major labor organizations sought yesterday to help resolve the bitter dispute between striking bus drivers and the Board of Education

title: For Children
description: OWL PROWL led by Julio de la Torre, With a slide Show and an outdoor tour of owls' nesting places. Saturday at 8:30 P.M. at the Stamford Museum & Nature Center. 39 Scofleldtown Poad, 3/4 of a mile north of Exit 35 on the Merritt Parkway, function of Scoflelotown Road and High Ridoe Road. Stamford. Admission: Children, 50 cents; adults. $1; entrance fee. $2 per Car. Call (203) 3221646.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 1 (AP)  The Air Force made its fifth attack in two weeks today on a guerrilla base outside Rhodesia, bombing a camp 150 miles inside Mozambique, the military command announced. It said bombers attacked buildings occupied by guerrillas led by Robert Mugabe in the Mozambique Army's camp at Mutarara.

title: Pennsylvania Court Test Nears
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 1 (UPI) The Philadelphia Bar Association's Board of Governors has approved electronic media coverage of trial and appellate court proceedings in Pennsylvania on a oneyear experimental basis under strict guidelines. The coverage would indude television cameras, radio recording equipment and still cameras. The board's resolution is not the final Word, an association spokesman said today. The resolution will be sent to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court for consideration.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Associated Press
description: SEARCHING FOR BANK ROBBERS: Nonstriking New Orleans policemen and Louisiana State troopers outside an apartment in which they suspected bank robbers were hiding. The apartment, however, was empty. The strike by police continued yesterday, but the city's firemen reached an accord.

title: Market Place
description: AT what better time could a startup company like the Fuelteck Corporation have marketed its shares?

title: Miss Stoll Is Routed At Dallas
description: DALLAS, March 1 Martina Navratilova, relegated to a rare afternoon appearance before a smattering of fans turned in a primetime performance today in $200,000 Championships of Dallas tournament.

title: Scientists Create a Solid Form of Hydrogen
description: Physicists at the Carnegie Institution in Washington have reported that they have made a new form of hydrogen that is a transparent, icelike solid at room temperature. The achievement is an important step toward making metallic hydrogen, a substance that could revolutionize the transmission of electric power.

title: Settlement in Surgery Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 (AP)  An outofcourt settlement was reached today in a $7 million damage suit alleging that a San Francisco doctor, John Brown, botched a sexchange operation on a transsexual waitress, Julie Phillips. Her attorney, Melvin Belli, said that the settlement was enough for psychiatric help for the rest of Julie's life and a new operation. He would not disclose the amount of the settlement.

title: Police Strike Held Illegal;By a Court in Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 1 (AP)  A state appeals court, saying a police strike begins as anarchy and leads toward terrorism, ruled today that a 14dayold walkout by New Orleans police officers was illegal.

title: Changes in the City's Antipoverty Program
description: Quietly, last Feb. 16, an era ended in the life of the poverty program in New York. Most of the community corporations that had brokered the community action programs here lost the administrative financing they had received from the city. The result is that a lot of them will soon disappear. When you walk down 125th Street east from St. Nicholas Avenue, there are a lot of things that used to be like Charles's Gallery, which before that used to be Frank's steak and chop house and is now just another empty storefront. Farther on past Frederick Douglass Boulevard, there is an empty hulk that used to be Loew's Victoria theater, right by the famous Apollo, which barely escaped receding into the usedtobe.

title: Fall in Japan's Reserves
description: TOKYO, March 1 (UPI)  Japan's official reserve of gold and foreign currencies stood at $32.69 billion at the end of February, down $422 million from the previous month, the Finance Ministry said today. It was the first time in six months that Japan's official reserves have dropped. The ministry attributed the setback to the Bank of Japan's release of United States dollars on the Tokyo foreign exchange market to prevent the weakening of the yen against the dollar.

title: Bank President Testimony
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1  A. W. Clausen, Bank of America president, testified here yesterday before a Federal grand jury investigating the circumstances in which Alvin C. Rice, once seen as Mr. Clausen's most likely successor, left the bank last August.

title: TV Weekend
description: MOST of the weekend action is on Sunday, with the possible exception, for country music addicts, of a live sixhour marathon Saturday on Public Television from Nashville's Grand Ole Opry. The show will start on Channel 13 at 7, and there will be intervals for money pitches to help support the station.

title: Survey Based on Calls Made Feb. 27 and 28
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News survey is based on telephone interviews conducted from Feb. 27 to Feb. 28 with 1,113 adult men and women around the United States.

title: Cabaret: Philip Glass
description: PHILIP GLASS completed his own kind of hat trick Wednesday, when he opened a twonight run at the Bottom Line. In so doing, he became the first composer one can recall who performed his music  to standing ovations, besides  at such diverse locations as Town Hall, Carnegie Hal, the Metropolitan Opera and, now, New York's leading rockclub showcase.

title: Big Board To Trade In Futures
description: The board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday approved a comprehensive plan for developing an exchange to trade futures contracts in financial instruments.

title: Luce of Con Ed Recommended For U.S. Bench
description: Charles F. Luce, chairman and chief !executive officer of the Consolidated Edison Company, was among nine people Irecommended yesterday for two openings on the United States Court of ApDeals for the District of Columbia.

title: Spain's Governing coalition Appears to Win Elections
description: MADRID, Friday, March 2  Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez's centrist coalition appeared this morning to have won victory over the Socialist Party in final results from yesterday's parliamentary election. But the governing Union of the Democratic Center appeared to have fallen short of winning a majority in the 350member lower house.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the oil and gas operations of General Crude Oil, a subsidiary of the International Paper Company, for about $650 million.

title: Giants Hire a Linebacker Coach
description: Bill Parcells announced his resignation yesterday as the head coach of the Air Force Academy football team to become linebacker coach of the Giants and return home to New Jersey after 18 years.

title: Lull Is Reported in Asian Fighting After Vietnam's Loss of Lang Son
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 1 Western analysts reported today that a lull had set in on the ChineseVietnamese battlefield, with China's troops consolidating important gains and resupplying their forces.

title: BLACK VOTE CRUCIAL
description: CHICAGO, March 1  Black voters here, continuing a recent trend in other cities, played the key role in the first de feat of the city's Democratic machine in 50 years, voting 2 to 1 in favor of Jane M. Byrne who defeated Michael A. Bilandic I in Tuesday's mayoral primary.

title: Film: 'Norma Rae,' Mill-Town Story:Unionism in the South
description: BECAUSE so much of today's American labor movement seems to be too big and complicated to be easily understood, too rich to have time for the impoverished, and so powerful that its interests are as vested as those of any industry, stories about the early days of trade unionism have become expressions of a deep-seated, romantic longing. When the issues dividing labor and management can be clearly drawn, there is nothing quite as satisfying as collective effort to fight oppression. Workers are children of nature, born without sin. Bosses are devils. In such times faith can flourish. Salvation is not an abstract concept  it's a three-year contract.These are sentiments that Martin Ritt, the director, and Irving Ravetch and Harriet Frank Jr. (Mrs. Ravetch), his screenwriters, understand and fervently evoke in their often stirring new film, "Norma Rae." The movie, which opens today at Loews State 1 and other theaters, also provides Sally Field with the plum role of her career, an opportunity to demonstrate once and for all that she is an actress of dramatic intelligence and force, someone who no longer need be referred to in terms of her television credits.As Norma Rae, a small-town Southern mill worker, a widow with one legitimate child and another born out of wedlock, a resilient young woman of no great education but a lot of common sense, Miss Field gives a performance that is as firm and funny as the set of her glass jaw  and just as full of risk. It's a role loaded with the kind of sentimental temptations that might side-track a lesser performer. Miss Field, though, has found its tough truth and stuck to it. The performance, which gives dimension to the film, may well be the one that those of other actresses are measured against this year."Norma Rae" does not take place in the dim dark past of trade unionism. It is set in today's rural South, where the idea of collective bargaining is considered roughly on a par with membership in a Communist cell. After all  though the movie doesn't stress this  the highly publicized industrial boom in the post-World War II South was largely the result of the cheaper (nonunion) wages that lured manufacturers away from the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states."Norma Rae" is about the efforts of one young New Yorker, a glib, fast-talking Jewish organizer named Reuben Marshasky (Ron Leibman) to bring justice to the tiny town where Norma Rae, her father (Pat Hingle), her mother (Barbara Baxley), her husband-to-be, Sonny (Beau Bridges), and virtually everyone else are dependent upon the cotton mill, the town's only industry.The film's principal appeal, though, is not the manner in which this uphill struggle is fought and won, but in the way that Mr. Ritt, his writers and his cast reveal the natural resources of the characters  their grit, their emotional reserves and their complex feelings for one another. The politics of the film are worthy but they are never as surprising as the people, especially Norma Rae, whose personality is defined in her often comic, sometimes brutal, sometimes touching encounters with ex-husbands, lovers, children, parents, strangers.The film, which was shot in Alabama, places its characters in a recognizable social contest that neither parodies nor patronizes them. In short, swift, effective scenes "Norma Rae" dramatizes the limits imposed on imaginations by both poverty and tradition. Norma Rae's father is as wary of the union as any stockholder. Her mother, on the edge of deafness because of the noise in the weaving room where she works, is apathetic. At the first opportunity Sonny leaves the mill and takes a job in a service station. Without the efforts of Reuben Marshasky and this one particular woman, life would have gone on as before."Norma Rae" is not without blemish. Mr. Ritt and the Ravetches, who've been collaborating on films since "Hud" and "The Long Hot Summer," persist in equating the awakened social conscience with literature not always of the highest order. It's an endearing but dopey conceit that I associate first with the work of Clifford Odets. When Norma Rae is having her consciousness raised, it's signaled by the report that she's reading Dylan Thomas  offscreen. The platonic affair between Norma Rae and Reuben, played by Mr. Leibman in the television-breezy manner of his "Kaz" role, is given more time than her rocky, equally interesting relationship with her husband, a role that Mr. Bridges invests with more heft than seems to have been written into the script.There's also an unintentionally hilarious scene in which we see some local codgers sitting around a general store whittling, but they whittle with a ferocity that seems less down-home than Saturday Night Live.These are small objections. "Norma Rae" is a seriously concerned contemporary drama, illuminated by some very good performances and one, Miss Field's, that is spectacular."Norma Rae," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains some muted violence and mildly vulgar language.

title: 2 Dealers Had to Buy Oil At a Farm, Hearing Told
description: HAUPPAUGE, LI., March 1 Two independent fueloil dealers described today how they had driven out at midnight to the East End of Long Island the other day to buy oil from a chicken farmer who had more than enough oil to keen his coops warm.

title: Reported Crimes Drop By 6.5% in New York; Assaults Show a Rise
description: The number of major crimes reported in New York City declined last year, with most neighborhoods showing a drop in the crime rate, according to statistics made available yesterday by the Police Department.

title: Nominee for ArrnsControl Chief Is Easily Approved by the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (Reuters) The Senate confirmed President Carter's nomination of Lieut. Gen. George Seignious as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency today. He succeeds Paul C. Warnke, who resigned.

title: A.M.C. to Cut Car Output 32.5%
description: DETROIT, March 1  Faced with plummeting sales of its passenger cars as its Jeep sales are soaring, the American Motors Corporation today announced a 32.5 percent cutback in passengercar production. It will take effect March 12 and last through the end of production of 1979 models in late June. Production will be reduced to 610 cars a day from 904 a day, the company said.

title: Venezuela Denies Rise in Oil Prices
description: The Venezuelan Government yesterday denied published reports that it had raised crude oil prices by $1.20 a barrel.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Gerulaitis, Mayer Advance
description: MEMPHIS, March I (AP)  Thirdseeded Vitas Gerulaitis defeated an enraged Peter Fleming, and Sandy Mayer downed fifthseeded Bryan Gottfried tonight to advance to the quarterfinals of the $250,000 national indoor tennis championshins.

title: Chrysler Moving Ads Worth $120 Million To Agency Ford Used
description: The troubled Chrysler Corporation announced in New York yesterday that it would move all its automotive advertising to Kenyon & Eckhardt, for 34 years an advertising agency used by the Ford Motor Company.

title: China Will Pay 41 Cents on Dollar For American Assets Seized in 49
description: SHANGHAI, Friday, March 2 China agreed today to pay 91 cents on the dollar to American individuals and companies with claims of $196.8 million against the Chinese Government for property confiscated when the Communists came to nower in 1949.

title: City Restricting Disability Pay For Heart Cases
description: New York City's chief legal adviser ruled yesterday that policemen and firemen who seek higher retirement benefits because of a heart condition must prove that the condition arose from an accident in the line of duty.

title: A Barrel of Prevention
description: President Carter's request for standby authority to impose oil conservation measures is welcome. But his continuing reluctance to risk public outrage by using such authority is not. The oil shortage created by political upheavals in Iran may not yet have caused the crisis created by the Arab embargo of 1973. But the Government's failure to respond decisively by forcing down American oil consumption dims the hope for price moderation by the OPEC cartel. It also weakens the fragile alliance of oilconsuming nations and prolongs American dependence on fragile nations, with incalculable harm to foreign policy in general.

title: HighFashion Comfort, at a Price
description: Andre Laug is a Frenchman from Alsace who works in Italy and sells a lot of his clothes in the United States. He looks like an accountant or a banker, not a fashion designer, and is given to sensible statements, such as a dress is not a jail  it's like a home and you must feel comfortable in it.

title: Lettuce Strike: A Harvest of Frustrations
description: EL CENTRO, Calif., Feb. 28  The winter lettuce harvest is almost over in the Imperial Valley of California, but this year the biggest crop that was harvested here was not lettuce but frustration, bitterness and violence.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The index of leading economic indicators fell 1.2 percent in January, providing a strong signal of a possible economic downturn. The decline was the sharpest since January 1975, near the bottom of the last recession, and was the third in a row. Economists consider three consecutive monthly declines a meaningful, although not conclusive, indicator of an approaching business slowdown. [Page A1.]

title: A Grand Fling For Opera Fans
description: ALTHOUGH they are dignified by the word arias, hit tunes are just as much a part of opera as they are of the popular music world. Opera fans dote on them with the passion a teenager has for the latest topofthechart song. When they hear the introductory notes of a favorite opera excerpt they sigh quite audibly with ecstasy.

title: At a Camp for Burmese Refugees, Death Is Routine
description: MARICHAPALONG, Bangladesh, Feb. 28 Statistics at the camp for Burmese refugees here are kept on a blackboard in the thatched straw quarters of Rafique ulIslam, the officer in charge. Among the figures posted at noon were these: Deaths today2. Deaths to date1,583.

title: Golf Elite Pay Back Palmer
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 1  At the Masters a few years ago Ken Still, a golf professional who has won more than half a million dollars in his career, was watching Arnold Palmer on the practice tee. If Arnie needed his shoes shined. I'd shine them with my shim Still said to a fellow pro.

title: Congressional Chairmen Oppose President's Reorganization Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 Within an hour of President Carter's announcement today that he planned to create a new Department of Natural Resources, the chairmen of the Congressional committees most affected by the proposal came out against it.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Leukemia Patient Prepares to Bicycle Across the Country
description: Five years ago Robert Fisher was told he had terminal leukemia. Since then there have been various prognoses that the end might be at hand, the last one about a year ago.

title: Topics
description: A national beer company recently bought a familyowned brewery that has operated in Portland, Ore., for 123 years. It was only the latest illustration of the economies of scale. but it is a reminder of all the department stores, hotels, lumber mills, newspapers and myriad other businesses that have been taken over by outside interests, and not only in Portland. Absentee ownership is just as likely to make the citizens of Tulsa and Toledo and Tallahassee wonder about the social costs of centralization and concentration.

title: Khomeini Returns to the Holy City of Iran
description: QUM,Iran.March 1  Down streets scrubbed spotless by an army of peasants on its knees, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini returned today to Qum, the holy city in the desert where 16 years ago his fiery public utterances helped begin a revolution. Near dusk, beneath stately minarets, he told a throng of perhaps a million: The remaining one or two years of my life I will devote to you in keeping this movement alive.

title: Mahre Girds for Cup Ski
description: WILMINGTON, N.Y., March 1 Phil Mahre, the 22year old Alpine star from White Pass, Wash., who is in excellent position to become the first American to win the World Cup overall championship, was not content today after finishing a downhill trial run at Whiteface Mountain.

title: Marston Joins the Race For Philadelphia Mayor
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 1  David W. Marston, the former United States Attorney, declared today that Philadelphia's government was a national disgrace and announced that be would run for Mayor.

title: Ballet: Pennsylvanians Dance a New Harkavy
description: THE PENNSYLVANIA BALLET, now at the Brooklyn Academy of Music through Sunday afternoon, looks as fit as a fiddle this season. The dancing is tauter and more polished than ever. The company acts as if it were being exposed to new challenges.

title: Foster Wheeler Draws Interest
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, a major aircraft and space company, said yesterday that it owned almost 400,000 shares, or about 4.9 percent, of the Foster Wheeler Corporation, maker of processing plants and steam generating equipment.

title: Bank Takeover Study
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Muriel Siebert, Superintendent of the New York State Banking Department, has urged Congress to begin an immediate and intensive review of the recent dramatic growth in purchases of rrired Stares commercial banks by foreign banks.

title: Contributory Negligence in Foreign Policy
description: Thirty years ago, the American law of negligence was dominated by a theory Called contributory negligence, except in the field of admiralty and a few enlightened states. This doctrine held in essence that a plaintiff hurt by a defendant's negligent conduct, no matter how gross, had no recourse against the defendant if the plaintiff's own conduct exhibited some negligence no matter how small. The hardship resulting from this doctrine is readily apparent Since then, contributory negligence has been largely replaced by comparative negligence, according to which the liability of the defendant in cases of joint wrongdoing is determined by the degree to which each party is at fault: If the damage is $100 and the defendant was 60 percent responsible, compared with the plaintiff's 40 percent, the plaintiff, who previously would have lost the case altogether, recovers

title: 2 Are Attacked In City Subways; A 3d Dies in Fire
description: In the latest round of subway violence, a man was burned to death early yesterday at an Eighth Avenue subway entrance, another man was set afire aboard a Brooklynbound train and a third was shoved toward the edge of the same platform where a subway rider had been pushed to his death three days earlier.

title: New York Times Dividend
description: The New York Times Company announced that its board of directors had declared a regular quarterly dividend of 20 cents a share on its Class A and Class B common stock, payable March 26 to shareholders of record March 8. The board also declared a regular quarterly dividend of $1.375 a share on the 5 percent cumulative prior preference stock, payable April 2 to bolders of record March 8.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Advertising
description: LIFE SAVERS Bubble Yum is very much No. 1 in the market and proud of it. And, with its new ad agency, Foote, Cone & Belding, haying handled the creative thinking, this Saturday it will announce (to music and a waiting nation) that It's number yum yum Yum in bubble gum.

title: Jazz at Entermedia Puts Soloists in Spotlight
description: It isn't time for the NewportNew York Jazz Festival and its attendant rites yet, but the Entermedia Theater, Second Avenue and 12th Street, is having a jazz festival anyway. Unlike the events of the coming summer, Jazz at Entermedia will, not attempt to define the state of the art in all its variety, but then, it will not ravage the pocketbook either. For a $5 general admission ticket, one can hear Anthony Braxton, who is one of the most formidable solo saxophonists alive, on a bill with an exemplary quartet led by the cellist David Eyges tonight at 9. For another $5, one can go Saturday night and hear the tenor saxophonist Archie Shepp, making a rare New York concert appearance with his quartet, and the melodically and rhythmically incisive solo piano of Dave Burrell, also at 9.

title: Iranians at U.S. Embassy Charge Records Show Wide Corruption
description: Representatives of Ayatollah Rubollah Khomeini who have taken charge of the Iranian Embassy in Washington are engaged in a broad examination of the embassy's financial records, which they say has uncovered evidence of widespread corruption by officials of the former Iranian Government in the United States.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Paul J. Rizzo, a senior vice president who was named yesterday by the International Business Machines Corporation as a member of its corporate office and its corporate management committee, admitted to a heady feeling. And well he might.

title: BEGIN LANDS IN U.S., SAYING PEACE TALKS ARE IN DEEP CRISIS
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel arrived here today and began a critical round of talks on a Mideast peace agreement with President Carter tonight.

title: President's Stand on Reorganizing Seen as an Attempt to Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  White House officials call it the most searing internal dispute in the 25 months of the Carter White House, and it ended in the Oval Office at 10 o'clock Tuesday morning after 72 hours of intensive negotiations.

title: Bonn Court Backs Posts For Labor
description: BONN, March 1The West German Supreme Court ruled today that the country's codetermination law, which gives labor equal votes with shareholders on company supervisory boards, is constitutional.

title: Children's Song Inspires New Piano Composition
description: T. J. Anderson, composer and chairroan of the music department at Tufts University in Medford, Mass., who orchestrated Scott Joplin's ragtime opera Treemonisha in 1972, was haunted by a game his children and their friends played when the family lived in Atlanta.

title: Attempts to End The Milk Strike Resume Today
description: Both sides in the sixdayold milk strike agreed to resume talks through mediatom today, but the latest in a string of violent incidents and friction continued to cloud prospects for a quick settlement.

title: Miss White Leader By Stroke With a 66
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March 1  Donna Horton White, who has not won in her two years as a pro, shot a sixunderpar 66 today and took the firstround lead in the $100,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association's Bent Tree Classic.

title: U.S. Backs Specialist Test Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a New York Stock Exchange plan to establish minimum performance standards for specialists and to reallocate stocks away from specialists who fail to meet the standards.

title: Beauty and the Beast Are Dancing in Stratford
description: Story ballets are somewhat out of fashion these days. It takes an audacious soul to choreograph a new one. But Bruce Wells, a former soloist with the New York City Ballet and now choreographer in residence at New Haven's thriving young Connecticut Ballet, has done just that. Audiences will see his unusual project this weekend, when the company appears at the American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn., in a program that includes the premiere of Mr. Wells's Beauty and the Beast.

title: Boeing Aides Mishandled Secrets And Tried CoverUp, Inquiry Finds
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Investigators for the Department of Defense have concluded that six officials of the Boeing Aerospace Company violated national security restrictions last year by obtaining and transmitting top secret information concerning Government plans for developing a new intercontinental missile known as the MX.

title: A Gourmet's Guide of Where to Eat the Best Pastrami and Corned Beef in Town
description: Drawing by Nicolas Ascia

title: Kelly, Basketball Coach, Dismissed by St Peter's
description: JERSEY CITY, March 1 (AP)  St. Peter's College dismissed Bob Kelly. its head basketball coach, today as part of an administration move officials said was designed to upgrade the school's program.

title: U.S. Aides Say Loss of Post in Iran Impairs MissileMonitoring Ability
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Despite the Government's public assurances, wellplaced officials say privately that the electronic listening post in northeast Iran evacuated yesterday cannot be replaced for some time and that its loss will impair American ability to monitor the Soviet missile development and compliance with a new armslimitation accord.

title: Notes on People
description: The tension in Teheran has spilled over, in a way, into the life of Marion Javits, the wife of Senator Jacob K. Javits, and made it necessary for a policeman to be stationed for a time at the entrance of the Javits apartment on East 57th Street. On Feb. 16, an unidentified man called the police and said he had been present at a meeting of Iranian nationals who discussed the possibility of getting into the Javits apartment to confront Mrs. Javits or do something to her.

title: Voyager Closing In on 4 Large Satellites of Jupiter
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 1  Four virtually unknown worlds, the major satellites of Jupiter, were beginning to come into focus for intensive scientific exploration today as Voyager 1 sped in for Monday's close Jovian encounter.

title: Books: Breaking Down in Los Angeles
description: THE THURSDAY WOMAN. By Muriel Davidson. 274 pages. Atheneurn. $9.95.

title: U.S. Military Strength Dwindling, Republicans Say
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  The Republican National Committee issued a sweeping attack today on the Carter Administration's defense policies, saying that American military power was on the decline and that the United States was rapidly becoming No. 2.

title: Kosvgin Promises Continued Support for Vietnam
description: MOSCOW, March 1 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin said today that China's attack on Vietnam was cynical and barbarous act of international piracy.

title: Money Supply Off Again
description: The two most popular measures of the money supply continued their downward swing in the week ended Feb. 21, as M1 dropped by $2 billion and M2 declined by $1.8 billion, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Broadway
description: Persistence bringing Father's Day back to the stage.

title: Soviet Team Leads
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., March 1Two eightman teams of decathlon specialists from the United States and the Soviet Union met tonight at West Point's Army Field House in the first septathlon meet ever staged.

title: Regents Vote Down Plan For Student Certificates
description: ALBANY, March 1 The New York State Board of Regents overwhelmingly rejected today a proposal that would have permitted high schools to award certificates to students who complete their course work but fail to pass the new minimumcompetency tests.

title: Iranians Plead Ignorance About U.S. Listening Site
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 1 The Government of Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan said today that it had. not known American military men were still operating a secret electronic listening post near the Soviet border until it was taken over by left! revolutionaries.

title: Schlitz Shifts 2 Beer Accounts
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company announced yesterday that it was moving its Schlitz Light and Old Milwaukee beer accounts out of Cunningham & Walsh, New York, and, according to an official statement, its Schlitz Light is going to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, while Old Milwaukee goes to an agency now being selected.

title: Music: Rozhdestvensky Leads the Philharmonic
description: GENNADY ROZHDESTVENSKY, the Soviet conductor who is making his New York Philharmonic debut this season, appeared last night in the second week of his threeweek engagement and sent this reviewer away wondering if the onetime leader of the Bolshoi Theater orchestra might be auditioning to become our next popconcert maestro. His concert contained one serious if not precisely firstrate work by Prokofiev, but it was surrounded by cotton candy in a most oldfashioned programming style.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Lifeofcontract highs were set yesterday in active copper futures trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York.

title: As the Pressure Grows, Israel Acts to Mold Opinion
description: JERUSALEM, March 1  As the Mid. die East peace talks moved toward .another crisis this week, Israeli Govern. ment officials used two welltested maneuvers with devastating effect to mold public opinion here and abroad lust liefore a tense meeting in Washington between Prime Minister Menachem Begin and President Carter.

title: Rossman Denies Agreeing To a Galindez Fight Date
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 1 (UPI) Mike Rossman, the World Boxing As. sociation lightheavyweight champion. denied today reports that he had agreed to reschedule a fight with Victor Gal indez. the former champion.

title: Concern Over PlaneCollision Peril Heightened by Series of Close Calls
description: Deep anxiety among aviation officials in this country about the danger of plane collisions has been aggravated by an inexplicable threeweek run of accidents and close calls involving airliners.

title: A Sampler of Cable Costs and Services
description: East Orange, N.J.

title: China Again Asks Vietnam Talks
description: HONG KONG, March 1  China again urged Vietnam today to join talks to end their twoweekold border war, saying that Peking still hopes to see a settlement of the disputes between the two countries through peaceful negotiations.

title: First Iranian Oil In 2 Months Sold
description: The first shipment of oil to leave Iran in more than two months has been sold to the Japanese, according to traders in New York. They said the shipment was about 300,000 tons, a little over 2 million barrels.

title: Art: Landscapes Of Neil Welliver
description: NEIL WELLIVER has now clearly won the distinction of being one of the best landscape painters on the current art scene, and it is a scene crowded with competition. A number of separate develooments  most conspicuously, a revival of interest in Realism and other modes of representation, and the renewed respect for nature fostered by the ecology movement  have combined to stimulate an enormous new interest in landscape painting, and Mr. Welliver has been one of the leaders in this endeavor.

title: Books of The Times
description: REVERSALS. A PERSONAL ACCOUNT OF VICTORY OVER DYSLEXIA. By Eileen Simpson. 246 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $8.95.

title: Ski Conditions
description: All ski areas, from northern New England to Pennsylvania's Poconos, continue to have substantial snow depths. However, granular surfaces now exist almost everywhere because of below or near freezing nights and above freezing weather during daytime hours.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) Farmers rolled their last tractor caravan through downtown Washington today and pledged to continue their fight for higher farm prices in the halls of Congress.

title: Hugo Kolberg, at 80, Violinist; Concertmaster of 4 Orchestras
description: Hugo Kolberg, violinist and former concertmaster of the Berlin Philharmonic and various American orchestras, died in Hempstead (L.I.) General Hospital on Tuesday. He was 80 years old and lived in Hempstead.

title: State U. Is Said to Need $1 Billion
description: The Site University of New York will require nearly $1 billion in financing over the next decade to complete a number of planned construction projects and to replace a large inventory of detenorating equipment. according to state and university officials.

title: Where to Eat the Best Pastrami and Corned Beef in Town
description: T HEREis probably no type of food former New Yorkers miss more than what they commonly and lovingly lmow as deli, or, more precisely, pastrami and corned beef, those New YorkJewishEastern European delicatessen specialties. Whether they are in Chicago, Los Angeles, Miami or Tel AVIV, friends and relatives who return to New York on visits invariably ask first for a great big corned beef or pastrami on rye.

title: Rebel Gains Reported In Yemen
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, March I (AP)  Southern Yemen said today that rebel opponents of the Yemen Government had made significant battle gains.

title: Stage: Introducing Sweeney Todd
description: THE musical and dramatic achievements of Stephen Sondheim's black and bloody Sweeney Todd are so numerous and so clamorous that they trample and jam each other in that invisible but finite doorway that connects a stage and its audience; doing themselves some harm in the process.

title: Trade Winds Swirl As Met Camp Starts
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 The New York Mets held their first full workout of spring training today, with 45 players competing for 25 jobs and a persistent feeling in the air that a major trade was about to be swung.

title: MUSTAFA BARZANI, KURDS' LEADER, DIES
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Gen. Mustafa Barzani, the flamboyant Kurdish leader who unsuccessfully fought guerrilla wars in Iraq to gain autonomy for his fiercely nationalistic people, died today of a heart attack at Georgetown Univercity Hosnital here. He was 75 years old.

title: Hudson's Bay: Goal of Thomsons
description: TORONTO, March 1  Two investment holding companies of the family of the late Lord Thomson of Fleet announced today their bid to acquire a controlling interest in the Hudson's Bay Company.

title: Stage: Slugger Fails to Reach First
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I.

title: OPEC Welcomes Decision
description: VIENNA, March 2 (Reuters)  A spokesman for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today welcomed a decision by major consuming nations to reduce demand for oil by 2 million barrels a day.

title: Battered Wives Unite to Get Police to Act
description: In Oakland, Calif., a man went to the apartment of his estranged wife one afternoon, kicked down the door and beat her severely.

title: Credit Suisse: New WriteOff
description: ZURICH, March 2 (AP)  Credit Suisse will write off an additional $91 million for 1978 to cover possible losses from the 1977 Chiasso affair, Robert Jeker, the company's director general, said today.

title: N.F.L. Studies Charges That Eagles Violated Rules
description: Jack Danahy, director of security for the National Football League, disclosed yesterday that Commissioner Pete Rozelle had received the results of an investigation that might support allegations or serious rules iniraciions made public last December by a former Philadelphia Eagles punter.

title: West Sets 5% Cut in Oil Demand
description: PARIS, March 2 The United States and 19 other industrial countries agreed today to combat rising oil prices stemming from the loss of Iranian output by reducing their 1979 oil demand on world markets by 5 percent. or about 2 millions barrels a day.

title: ChinaClaims Agreement Pleases U.S. Companies
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  American companies responded with initial enthusiasm today to the newly announced settlement of the 30yearold claims dispute between the United States and China but said they would await more details of the agreement before assessing its fairness.

title: Mrs. Mueller, Miss Heiden Triumph in Speed Skating
description: INZELL, West Germany, March (AP)  Leah PoulosMueller won the sprint title and another American, Beth Heiden, took the allround crown at an international speed skating event today.

title: Notes on People
description: Messenger Back With $5 Million (P.S.: He Kept the Job)

title: Vatican and Poland Compromise On Form and Time of Papal Visit
description: ROME, March 2  The Vatican has compromised with the Polish Government on the format for the scheduled visit by Pope John Paul II, a native of Poland, according to informed sources in the church administration.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday.March 2, 1979

title: Levich Tells Soviet's Critics to Be Cautious
description: Western critics of Soviet repression should be more careful to avoid exaggerated accusations, because Moscow seeks constantly to undermine the credibility of criticism by exposing exaggerations, a former senior Soviet scientist said this week.

title: Article 8 -- No Title
description: Racing Results

title: Bridge:
description: Three of the country's topranked squads head a field of 32 teams competing in the Grand National Teams Tournament, which begins district knockout play in Manhasset, Li., and Baldwin, L.I., today. Play continues tomorrow in Manhattan, when the field will be reduced to four teams.

title: Earnings Down At Faberg
description: Faberge Inc, the producer of fragrances, reported yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter and all 1978 were substantially below the yearearlier levels, primarily because of expenses incurred in a plant closing.

title: Orlando Ballet Offers 4 Dances
description: The Orlando Ballet Company presented a program of four works Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, raising the question of how the group ever got there in the first place.

title: Manhattan Cable TV Offering Superstation via Satellite
description: The 57,000 subscribers to Teleprompter Manhattan Cable Television have had the first exposure in this area to the latest glamour child of satellite technology the socalled superstatiOn. And after a month's experience with it, they have doubtless found that the pioneer superstation  whose formal name is WTCGTV  is strikingly similar to the nonnetwork television stations in New York that concentrate on sports, old movies and syndicated fare, WORTV, WPIXTV and WNEWTV.

title: Dolores Costello, 73, Film Star
description: Dolores Costello, who was acclaimed for her starring role in the silent film The Sea Beast, and for her portrayals in Moby Dick and The Magnificent Ambersons, died Thursday in Fallbrook (Calif.) Hospital after a brief illness. She was 73 years old and had been living in retirement at her avocado farm near San Diego.

title: E.P.A. Sees a Cost of $50 Billion For Cleanup of Chemical Dumps
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)  The Environmental Protection Agency said today that the cost of cleaning up hazardous chemical waste dumps around the Country might range as high as $50 billion.

title: N.H.L. Results
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Yemen and Southern Yemen Agree to a CeaseFire
description: BAGHDAD. Iraq, March 2  Yemen and Southern Yemen have agreed to a ceasefire as a result of mediation efforts by Syria and Iraq, it was announced here today.

title: Asociated Press
description: GRIMACING REBOUND: North Carolina's Mike O'Koren coming down with rebound against Maryland's Albert King during the first half of A.C.C. tournament game at Greensboro, N.C., last night. North Carolina won, 10279.

title: FundRaising Oversight Agency Begun by Evanzelical Christians
description: CHICAGO, March 2 More than 1,100 evangelical Christian groups, with $1 billion in combined income for 1978, announced today the formation of an umbrella agency designed to show the public that the member groups are accountable for the funds they raise and spend.

title: Letter: On Power Plant Licensing
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadians Debate Gas Surplus
description: OTTAWA, March 2  In the aftermath of a report by the National Energy Board estimating that Canada had an exportable surplus of natural gas, the Government has found itself caught between those who oppose any exports and those who think the board's estimate is too low.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Kenneth De Lap's Ozone Dances In From Minneapolis
description: Ozone breezed down. from Minnesota to the American Theater Laboratory on Thursday night  the Ozone Dance Company, that is. It came to New York from Minneapolis, a city with much local dance activity, and consisted of Catherine Gasiorowicz, Anne Gunderon, Mary Richardson, Wendy Anderson, Ron Lybeck and its director and choreographer, Kenneth De Lap.

title: Deaths
description: HOLTZAbraham,on March 2, in Florida. Beloved husband of Zara. Lovaig father of Barbara and Kenneth Kehrer, Elsa and Richard Gary, Edward and Karen Fernbach, cherished grandfather of Stephanie Kehrer. Devoted brother ct Samuel Holtz and Laura Levitan. Graveside ser. vices New Mordefiere Cemetery, Pinelawn. Long island, Sunday, March 4, 11:00 A.M.

title: British Reserves Up
description: LONDON, March 2 (Reuters)  Britain's gold and foreigncurrency reserves rose by $539 million in February in a further sign of improvement in the country's economy, the Treasury announced today. The Treasury said that the reserves stood at $16.62 billion at the end of the month, the highest level since July of last year.

title: Cuite Son Loses His Hospital Job In Policy Dispute
description: Thomas J. Cuite Jr., the 38yearold son of the City Council majority leader, was discharged yesterday from his $55.000ayear job as vice president for finance of the Health and Hospitals Corporation in what was described as a basic difference of policy with the corporation's president, Joseph C. Hoffman.

title: The Tottering Idi Amin
description: Idi Amin's regime in Uganda has long been indefensible. Now, faced with a punitive counterinvasion by Tanzania, it appears unable even to defend itself. Morale is so low and disaffection so great that the nominally superior Ugandan military forces are in rout, with some units in open mutiny. An early end to President Amin's despotism would, of course, be heartening, but that issue should be resolved by Ugandans, not Tanzanians.

title: 22 Are Stricken After They Take Better Heroin
description: At least 22 men and women who accepted a Harlem drug pusher's free offer of a better kind of heroin suffered convulsions and spasms after injecting the drug into their veins, the police said yesterday. Four of the victims were reported to be comatose.

title: State Department Approves Sale of Three 747's to Libya
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)  The State Department has approved the sale lof three Boeing 747 planes to Libya, one of the Arab nations most supportive of Palestinian guerrillas, Congress was told today.

title: PRESIDENT CONFERS WITH BEGIN ON PACT; NO PROGRESS IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 President Carter and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel met for two and a half hours today, but apparently failed to make progress toward resolving the issues holding up completion of an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: Publicly Traded Funds
description: Unaudited net asset values of publicly traded trivrstmrlf shares, Icirme.rly listed as Ctosed End Funds. as of Friday. Also shown is the closing listed market price of each furies shares, with Me percentage difference between the net asset value and the stock price.

title: U.T.C. to Increase Pension Benefits
description: HARTFORD. March 2 (AP)  The United Technologies Corporation has announced that it will increase pension benefits for about 10,000 retired employees.

title: Trial of Gray and Aides Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)  A Federal judge agreed today to postpone the trial of L. Patrick Gray, a former Director of the F.B.I., and two of his top aides to give prosecutors more time to find a way to avoid revealing secret documents sought by the defense.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Clip Along the Easily Visible Dotted Lines, and Save
description: A helpful compendium of terms that you ought to know by now, or that you knew from time to time, probably, but kept forgetting.

title: Amin's Forces Reported Under Pressure on 2 Fronts
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 2 (AP) Tanzanian invaders, Ugandan guerrillas and mutinous troops were reported striking from the east and south today as the war between the East African neighbors seemed to enter a decisive stage.

title: Penn 94, Yale 81
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 2 (UPI)  Tony Price and Tim Smith combined for 39 points as Penn, the Ivy League champion, streaked to its 20th victory of the season tonight with a 9481 triumph over Yale at the Palestra.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Son of Frank Gifford Badly Hurt In Jersey Car Crash That Kills 2
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., March 2  Kyle Gifford, the 24yearold son of Frank Gifford, the former Giant football star and now an ABC sportscaster, was seriously hurt and two of his friends killed last night when their car went out of control on the Palisades Interstate Parkway here and crashed broadside into a tree in the highway's median. The impact split the vehicle, a leased 1978 Lincoln Continental, into three pieces.

title: Beach Boys Play Some Old and Some New Things
description: After 19 years, what remains to be said about the Beach Boys? Easily the most idolized and overanalyzed group in the history of American popular music, they have endured and exhausted the most ingenious exegetes. Still the suburban California celebrants of Fun, Fun, Fun  the 15yearold hit they included in their encore at Radio City Music Hall on Thursday evening  they hardly require reviews anymore. Their repertory, the professionalism with which they perform it, and their audience are fixed forever like flies in the amber of a golden summer. They recall the running joke on Saturday Night Live that Generalissimo Franco is still dead, except that the Beach Boys are still, miraculously, alive.

title: ELLIS M. DRAKE
description: Ellis M. Drake, the president of Alfred (N.Y.) University between 1949 and 1967, died Wednesday in Syracuse at the age of 77.

title: Your Money
description: BILLPAYING by telephone is considered one of the early stages of transition into the cashless society, a world that will operate without coins, bills or checks but rather with credit cards and computers.

title: Injured Jacobs Out of High Jump
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 2 Franklin Jacobs of Fairleigh Dickinson University, the defending champion and meet recordholder in the high jump, has withdrawn from tomorrow's IC4A indoor track and field championships at Jadwin Gym because of tendinitis in his left heel.

title: Canadian Reserves Fall
description: OTTAWA, March 2 (UPI)  Canada's official international reserves dropped $286.5 million in February as pressure on the Canadian dollar continued, Finance Minister Jean Chretien said today. The Government's selling of foreign currencies to buy Canadian dollars left the reserves on Feb. 28 at $4.1 billion (United States funds).

title: Bill Doll, Press Agent; Handled Mike Todd, Other Famous Figures
description: Bill Doll, a leading showbusiness press agent, died yesterday of cancer at the Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 63 years old

title: Views Vary on Approach To a Bilingual Education
description: Five years  and millions of dollars  after bilingual education was mandated for New York City's public schools, the program is fought with confusion over whether it has worked and in what form it should continue.

title: Duke, Tar Heels In Final
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 2 (AP)  Jim Spanarkel scored 18 points, including a field goal that snapped a 5353 tie, to lead secondseeded Duke to 6259 victory over North Carolina State tonight. Duke's victory set up a confrontation with North Carolina for the Atlantic Coast Conference championship tomorrow night.

title: Making the Taxis Run on Time
description: New Yorkers can hardly help noticing that their taxi service is as rough as their streets. While many drivers work responsibly, a growing number reject inconvenient destinations, take circuitous routes, extort money and collect several fares for a single trip. And not enough of them work at night.

title: About New York
description: The shipping clerk told two terrible sexorgan jokes. He was nervous in front of the nightschool class, but his nerve raced ahead of his wit and his first effort as a standup comic drew only a single merciful laugh and a collective wince.

title: HomeRule Plan Suffers Setback In British Votes
description: EDINBURGH. March 2  The campaign for home rule suffered a severe setback today as Scotland gave only ambiguous approval to plans for limited selfgovernment and Wales overwhelmingly rejected them.

title: Around the Nation
description: BALTIMORE, March 2 (AP)  An. up deliberated for more than five hotels today before convicting a former Ge Services Administration store manager Charles E. Phelps, on 13 counts of bribery, filing false claims and ccnspiracy to defraud the Government.

title: New England Power Plant Is Switching to Coal
description: BOSTON, March 2 (AP)  The largest fossilfueled power plant in New England was given tentative permission today to convert three of its four generators from oil to loweroriced coal.

title: The City
description: After several reports of fighting, harassing of pedestrians and and two incidents of men and women brandishing either a knife or a gun, the police swept along the sidewalks of Times Square last night and arrested 38 men in an hour. Sgt. Martin Wenzel, who was in charge of the task force, said it was the largest number of arrests in a sweep of the area in at least a year.

title: Denis Brott, Cellist From Canada
description: Denis Brott, a 28yearold cellist who is the son of Alexander Brott, the Canadian composer and conductor, was presented in his New York debut recital at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. on Thursday night by the Center for InterAmerican Relations in cooperation with the Canadian Consulate. He was assisted by Samuel Sanders, pianist.

title: Roland Hanna Starts Jazz Policy
description: Marty Ross, who has been a successful restaurateur (Marty's Bum Steer) and a notsosuccessful jazz impresario (Buddy's Place) has combined his interests in his current restaurant, Marty's, at Third Avenue at 73d Street. The restaurant is made up of several rooms of moderate size, and in one of them, softly lighted and looking out on a courtyard through a glass wall, Mr. Ross has started a jazz policy with the Roland Hanna Trio.

title: Kentucky 80, L.S.U. 68 Tennessee 75. Auburn 64
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 2 (AP)  Kyle Macy and Truman Claytor combined for 49 points tonight and led Kentucky, the defending National Collegiate champion, to an 8068 upset victory over eighthranked Louisiana State in the Southeastern Conference tournament.

title: Racing Entries
description: Aqueduct

title: BREZHNEV CONDEMNS CHINESE, BUT VOICES NO MILITARY THREAT
description: MOSCOW, March 2 Leonid 1. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, condemned China today as the most serious threat to peace in the whole world, but he stopped short of pledging military action if Chinese troops were not withdrawn from Vietnam.

title: Tanker Runs Aground Off Crete
description: ATHENS, March 2 (UPI)  A Liberian tanker carrying 95,000 tons of crude oil from Libya ran aground today on the south coast of Crete, spilling oil into the sea and threatening beaches, a Merchant Marine Ministry spokesman said. He said the 155,000ton Messiniaki Frontis ran aground 1.2 miles off Kali Limenes, to which it was heading for supplies.

title: Tuition Rise at State University
description: ALBANY, March 2  The executive committee of the State University of New York voted today to raise tuition for freshmen and sophomores by $150 a year. It acted after the failure of negotiations to avoid the increase by cutting the school's budget or finding alternative revenue sources.

title: Due Process for Juveniles
description: In confirming last week that juveniles have no right to jury trials, the United States Supreme Court may have fed the misguided belief that due process is not required because juvenile courts treat rather than punish teenage transgressors. Fortunately, guidelines recently published by the Juvenile Justice Standards Project of the American Bar Association and the Institute of Judicial Administration offer a welcome correction to current misapprehensions.

title: Temple 53, Lafayette 50 St. Joseph's 69, Bucknell 61
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 2 (AP) Bruce Harrold scored 14 points, including four free throws in the last 1:19, to lead Temple to a 5350 victory over Lafayette tonight in an East Coast Conference semifinal.

title: SmallBusiness Shows: Big Business
description: Fostering small business has turned into big business these days. One of the easiest ways for an individual to break into business for himself is to become part of a larger franchise or ditributing company, and a popular way to learn about these companies is through smallbusiness public exhibitions.

title: Robber Gets 4Year Term
description: A 24yearold Bronx man has been sentenced to four years in prison for the beating and $100 robbery of an elderly woman in her apartment. The man, Rudolph Cannon, was sentenced yesterday by Justice David Levy in State Supreme Court. He was convicted in January of robbing and beating 73yearold Mae Ferris on April 24, 1978..

title: Mrs. Moser Captures World Cup Downhill
description: WILMINGTON, N.Y., March 2 Strange things happened on 4,867foot Whiteface Mountain today.

title: Nancy Lopez, on 67, Tied for Lead in Golf
description: SARASOTA, Fla.. March 2 While Nancy Lopez was thrilling a large crowd with a fiveunderpar 67, Lori Garbacz was virtually unnoticed playing the second round of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Bent Tree Classic.

title: Unitex of Hong Kong Buying Dan River Stock
description: Dan River Inc., one of the nation's largest textile manufacturers, with sales last year of more than a halfbillion dollars, is apparently the takeover target of a tiny Hong Kong company called Unitex Ltd., a knitwear producer with an annual volume of barely $25 million.

title: Effect of Gold Auctions Disputed
description: Are the Treasury's monthly auctions of gold reducing gold imports, defending the dollar and trimming the nation's trade deficit as they were designed to do? Increasingly, gold traders say, the sales are having an onposite effect. The auctions, they say, are not only driving up the price of gold but also increasing imports of the metal.

title: China's Options for the Invasion's Last Act
description: The Chinese invasion of Vietnam apparently is nearing its end. The last act may be the capture of Lang Son, which could ,be exploited in propaganda as evidence of China's victory. Or it could be phased withdrawal over the frontier leaving behind thousands of Vietnamese casualties, ruined towns and a devastated countryside.

title: Sandra Melton Wed To Stephen Lessing
description: In St. Edward's Roman Catholic Church in Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday afternoon, Sandra A. Melton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Melton Jr. of Palm Beach and New York, became the bride of Stephen M. Lessing, son of Mrs. Lawrence A. Lessing Jr. of Islip, L.I., and the late Mr. Lessing. The bride's uncles, Msgr. Edward L. Melton and the Rev. John H. Melton, officiated.

title: Palmer's Site Easy For Pros
description: ORLANDO, Ha., March 2  The reason Arnold Palmer's face is red is that there are so many red numbers on the scoreboard, representing birdies and eagles. In his debut as the sponsor of the Citrus Classic. Palmer is sneered that so many players are embarrassing the golf course he had so meticulously prepared to be a backbreaker.

title: Nets Beat Bucks, 99 to 91
description: PISCATAWAY , N.3., March 2  was almost as if there was a magnet attached to the basket when Bernard King  from all angles and from all positionsshot tonight.

title: Byrne Approves UrbctnAid Bill For $23 Million
description: TRENTON, March 2 A $23 million urbanaid bill that was rewritten in the Assembly by suburban legislators as a show of strength was signed into law today by Governor Byrne.

title: More Bones and Gun Found At Slayings Suspect's Home
description: CHICAGO, March 2 (UPI)  New bones and a gun were found today at the home of John Wayne Gacy, the suspected killer of 32 young men and boys.

title: U.S. Says Secrets for F14 and Missile Could Be Compromised in Iran
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  The Defense Department said today that its secret technical and maintenance manuals for FI4 jet fighters and for the Phoenix missile system might have been compromised in Iran.

title: That's the Way the Ball Bounces
description: Brian Gottfried, upper left, registers frustration after misplaying a shot off the frame of his racquet while competing in the United States national indoor tennis championships at Memphis. Larry Bird, upper right, the No. 1 college basketball player on the No. team, watches the ball intently as he and his Indiana State teammates play in the Missouri Valley Conference playoffs at Terre Haute, Ind. Tracy Austin grimaces while stroking a winning forehand placement as she competes in the women's tennis tournament at Dallas. Carl Yastrzemski, working out in a Boston Red Sox spring training camp for the 19th straight year. keeps two wide eyes on the ball while taking a hard swing in the batting cage at Winter Haven. Fla.

title: Regents Urge Autonomous City U. And State Financing of Its Colleges
description: ALBANY. March 2  The New York State Board of Regents called today for the City University of New York to continue as an autonomous municipal university. But it asked for legislation that would make the state responsible for financial support of the senior colleges and give the Governor the right to pick a majority of the governing board.

title: High Rent Make3Adult Household a Way of Life
description: LOS ANGELES, March 2  When Margarita Samara, a 21yearold legal secretary, moved here from Atlanta not long ago, she discovered quickly that rents for apartments were so high she could not afford one, so she moved in with two other persons, a man and a woman.

title: 75 Cadets Fall I11 in Suspected Food Poisoning
description: After 75 cadets and seven faculty members at the State University Maritime College became ill, city health officials dispatched to the Bronx campus reported that the cause was less likely to be heavy seas than something in the galley.

title: Suiting Up for Warmer Weather
description: The temperature rose into the 50's, the sky cleared  and suddenly it was spring in New York this week.

title: Deaths
description: BARONSamuel L Age 88. Long time member of the Associated Millinery Men. died March 1. He will be interred at the Beth Oavkl CemeterY. Elmont?, N.Y. on Sunday at 11 A.M.
