description: International

title: Connors to Face Gerulaitis
description: MEMPHIS, March 2 (AP)  Jimmy Connors, the defending champion, defeated Sandy Mayer, 63, 62, tonight to gain the semifinals of the $250,000 United States national indoor tennis championships.

title: Associated Press
description: OHIO RIVER OVERFLOWS: Cincinnati police officers made their rounds using boats after river flooded eastern section of the city with up to five feet of water. I'm a ser geant now, but after this I should be an admiral, one officer commented as he guided his boat through the flooded 20block area. Most of 100mile section of U.S. 52 between Cincinnati and Portsmouth was closed after water crested at 59 feet, seven feet above flood level.

title: Soviet Teams Lead
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., March 2 Soviet teams led both the men's and the women's competitions at a combined septathlonpentathlon indoor meet tonight in the Army fieldhouse.

title: Judge Moves Rape Trial Of Hines to Birmingham
description: CULLMAN, Ala., March 2  Birmingham was named today as the site of two pending rape trials for Tommy Lee Hines, a mentally retarded black man convicted here of rape and sentenced to 30 years in prison.

title: Evert Rolls On In Dallas
description: DALLAS, March 2  Secondseeded Chris Evert withstood Sue Barker of England, 64, 64, tonight to advance to the semifinals of the $200,000 women's tennis tournament here.

title: Spurt in Violence on Subways Stirs a Debate on Safety
description: A sharp increase in violence in the New York City subway system  in which seven persons were murdered and one was accidentally shot to death in the first

title: The Region
description: The Federal Goverment filed a lawsuit against Robert D: Williams of Westbury, L.I., a psychology instructor at the State university at Stony Brook, charging that he had failed to repay $3,992 from two federally insured student loans and accrued interest dating from 1971

title: State Is About to Lose Its U.S. Riot Insurance Over Albany Dispute
description: ALBANY, March 2  Having failed to lower propertyinsurance rates charged customers in poor neighborhoods, New York State will lose Federal riotinsurance coverage tomorrow.

title: Patents
description: WASKINGTON

title: Beethoven's Quartet Performed With Grosse Fuge by juilliard
description: The undiminished fascination of Beethoven's last sonatas and quartets arises not only from their emotional depth and complexity, but also the extraordinary interpretive problems they continue to pose for player and listener alike. Perhaps even Beethoven wasn't entirely certain what to make of the Quartet No. 13 in Bflat (Op. 130), because he wound up writing two entirely different finales for it.

title: Steel Prices Up At Bethlehem
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 2 (AP) The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's secondlargest steel producer. increased prices today on some of its products by 4 to 6 percent.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE BIG RED TRAIN RIDE. By Eric Newby. Illustrated 267 pages. St. Martin's. $10.

title: ExCIA. Aide Tells of Life at Iran Listening Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  It was like an operation from the 21st century and it was so ironic, recalled Philip J. McCabe, a selfstyled former intelligence analyst who now runs a resort in Maine.

title: Plutonium Fallout Levels in Utah Termed Acceptable
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 2  Studies by the Atomic Energy Commission in 1971 and 1974 showed that plutonium levels at certain sites in Utah were as much as 3.8 times high& than inmost of the rest of the United States, but even these levels are within permissible Federal guidelines, according to an exert in the state.

title: Merrill Realigns Managers
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, the country's largest brokerage firm, said yesterday that it would add three new executive vice presidents to Its second tier of managers, and change the responsibilities of two of its three current executive vice presidents.

title: Arkansas 93, Texas Tech 77 Texas 70, Houston 65
description: HOUSTON, March 2 (AP)  U. S. Reed, a sophomore guard, scored a careerhigh 22 points, and Sidney Moncrief had 21 points and 13 rebounds tonight as Arkansas joined Texas in the Southwest Conference championship game with a 9377 victory over Texas Tech.

title: NoSmoking Areas Due In Government Buildings
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)  Government workers were told today that they might declare their offices nosmoking areas, and that common spaces such as classrooms ana conference rooms would also be made off limits for smokers.

title: Is Sparky in Yankee Wings?
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  Dozens of framed photos and trophies adorn Sparky Anderson's home here. But when the former manager of the Cincinnati Reds was asked which was his favorite memento, he pointed to a picture of Casey Stengel on the wall of his den. In it, Casey Stengel's mouth open and he appears to be debating someone, his left fist raised. He had a mystery about him, Sparky Anderson was saying now. I remember after my first year with the Reds, when we got a big year out of both Wayne Granger and Clay Carroll in the bull pen, he pulled me aside and said, I'll tell you right nowno two relief pitchers will ever repeat for you. One always goes. Get another one. He knew. Granger fell apart the next year. But there is another reason why Sparky An derson feels close to the memory of Casey Stengel these days.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Adoption Lawyer Throws a Party
description: Stanley Michelman threw a party in his midtown law office last night. He was celebrating his acquittal on charges of illegally selling babies, and the people who showed up included most of the trial jurors, scores of adoptive parents who had been his clients and dozens of children whose adoptions he arranged over the last eight years.

title: Watkins a Champion at the Lectern
description: Termite Watkins, a professional boxer from Houston, was saved by the school bell yesterday at Junior High School 17 on West 48th Street.

title: U.S. to Take No Action on Recruitment of Students
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  Immigration and Naturalization Service officials have held that no legal action will be taken against a dozen or so colleges that improperly recruited foreign students, because no law has been violated.

description: Energy

title: For the Creative, A Workshop Ends Procrastination
description: Elaine Sorel doesn't want to hear about your neuroses.

title: Deaths
description: PERLSTE INAnna (nee Toback)beloved wife of Marris. devoted mother of Natalie Smiley and motherinlaw of Chester Smiley. Dear sister of Irving Tobeck end Edith Solomon. Cherished grandmother of Chrlstopher Smiley, Susan Smiley and her husband Allan Ritchie. Ser. vices Sunday 11 a.m. at The Boulevard Park West Chapel, 115 West 79 Street. New York City

title: OBSERVER
description: Although the music recording industry now challenges television as the most powerful entertainment force in the country, American politicians have been slow to exploit the potential of this new imagebuilding mechanism.

title: Reporter's Notebook: A Day of Rest Amid Chaos m t
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 2 It is not clear how they will put Iran back together again. Of course there are countless ideas, but picking the best one to run with seems to be the problem.

title: A Majestic River, Rushing, Pounding. Likely It'll Be Dammed.
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BIG APPLE CIDER Word from uptown is that a new young cabaret troupe called Metropolis has extracted some tangy satiric juice from the New York scene. Among their sketchandsong targets are the New School, primitive art, affirmativeaction groups, block parties, the Hare Krishna sect, French cinema, Isaac Bashevis Singer and Mayor Koch.

title: Mets Ease a Pitching Problem
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 The New York Mets signed Pat Zachry to a oneyear contract today and thereby eased one of their many pitching problems. But Manager Joe Torre conceded that the bottom line was still this: I don't know where my pitchers are going to be on opening day, and I don't know who they're going to be.

title: Lyle Is Relieved to Be a Ranger
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 2 In his first six seasons with the Yankees, Sparky Lyle averaged 22 saves a year and compiled a 2.22 earnedrun average. In his seventh season, last year, Lyle registered nine saves and finished with a 3.47 e.r.a.

title: CENTRISTS PREPARE TO GOVERN IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, March 2  Prime Minister Adolfo Surez's centrist party, the clear winner of yesterday's parliamentary elections, appeared in a position today to govern Spain for the next four years.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Following an upward swing on Thursday, prices of copper futures dropped by almost the daily limit yesterday. One reason was profit taking; another was that skittish traders were reluctant to hold a position over a weekend, especially at a time of fastbreaking world events.

title: Natural Gas Stocks Advance
description: Takeover situations dominated Wall Street's attention yesterday as the lateblooming rally of Thursday afternoon slowly faded. Some stocks in the natural gas group extended recent gains. while the gold, gambling and glamour sectors generally moved lower.

title: Unions Hail Koch's Offer to Call Labor Aide on SchoolBus Strike
description: Mayor Koch's suggestion that Bruce McIver. the director of the city's Office of Municipal Labor Relations, could help to settle the dispute between striking bus drivers and the Board of Education was welcomed warmly yesterday by the drivers union and guardedly by the Schools Chancellor.

title: Justice Unit Acknowledges Inquiry On G.S.A. Chief Was Groundless
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  About a month after the White House said it was seeking a replacement for Jay Solomon, who initiated investigations of corruption at the General Services Administration, a

title: EXPERTS SURPRISED BY JUPITER'S CLOUD
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 2  The recently discovered plasma cloud circling Jupiter at the orbit of its satellite lo appears to be composed of extremely hot, electrified sulfur particles excited by energies in excess of 500 billion watts, Voyager 1 scientists reported today.

title: CLAIMS SETTLEMENT CHEERS BLUMENTHAL
description: SHANGHAI, March 2  Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal arrived here today jubilant over the conclusion of a ChineseAmerican agreement on the settlement of financial claims that for a time this week was blocked by complications.

title: Ashland Oil Buys From Iran Again
description: Ashland Oil Inc., the nation's largest independent petroleum company, announced yesterday that it would resume buying oil from Iran. The company said the first tanker would be loaded by the middle of next week and should reach the United States a few days after that.

title: CARTER'S AIDES SAY ARMS PACT IS NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 Carter Administration officials said today that a new SovietAmerican treaty limiting strategic arms was all but complete and that they expected to finish negotiations on the accord in the next few weeks.

title: In Canadian Prairie City, Very Cold Is Putting It Mildly
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba  To set the record straight once and for all, Winnipeg is not a very cold city. It is a very, very cold city. Indeed, Winnipeg, which is 250 miles north of Fargo, N.D., may be the world's coldest provincial capital still inhabited by 581,000 humans.

title: Princeton 61, Brown 50
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 2  Bob Roma, a senior center, scored 27 points and John Rogers chipped in 20 to lead Princeton to a 6150 triumph over Brown in an Ivy League contest.

title: New Orleans Firemen Bar Meeting in Fear of Police
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 2 (UPI)  Leaders of a firefighters union today canceled a meeting for members to vote on a proposed contract with the city, saying that they feared disruption by striking police officers.

title: Mondale, Hailing Carter, Is Optimistic on 80 Race
description: LOS ANGELES, March 2  Vice President Mondale said today that he believed President Carter would stand for reelection in 1980 and could overcome the 2toI lead enjoyed by Senator Edward M. Kennedy in most public opinion polls.

title: Leader of Small Italian Party Fails to Form Government
description: ROME, March 2  Ugo La Malfa, the leader of the small Republican Party, reported to President Sandro Pertini of Italy today that he had failed to form a new government.

title: Mrs. Byrne Seeks to Heal Rifts With Chicago's Democratic Organization
description: CHICAGO, March 2  As the official canvass of the Board of Election Commissioners was confirming Jane M. Byrne's upset victory over Mayor Michael A. Bilandic in Tuesday's primary election, Mrs. Byrne was working hard today to patch up her relationship with the wounded Chicago Democratic machine and its allies.

title: 2 States Block Plan to Hold 6 New England Primaries on Same Date
description: BOSTON, March 2  An attempt by election officials representing the six New England states to agree on a single date for the Presidential primaries next year foundered here today on the twin rocks of New Hampshire resistance and Rhode Island indifference.

title: Beatings of 2 Blacks by Policemen Spur Calls for Miami Review Board
description: MIAMI, March 2  The beating of a black schoolteacher and his son by police narcotics agents who had entered their home by mistake on a drug raid has led to renewed demands for the creation of a citizens review board in Miami.

title: Steel Antitrust Accord Is Set
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)  A proposed settlement of a 5yearold antitrust suit against nine companies that sell reinforcing steel in Texas was announced today by the Justice Department. The settlement is subject to approval by the Federal District Court in Houston.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Columbia 96, Harvard 82
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 2 With its four senior starters scoring in double figures, Columbia moved a step closer to a possible National Invitation Tournament bid tonight by defeating Harvard, 9682.

title: UV Seeks to Halt Sale of Its Shares
description: UV Industries, a maker of electrical equipment, said it would vigorously seek enforcement of a Federal court order that prohibits the sale of any UV shares that had been solicited by Goldman, Sachs & Company as part of the 1.3millionshare transaction the investment firm arranged for the Sharon Steel Corporation last week.

title: News of the Day, an Opera By Hindemith, Is Presented
description: Paul Hindemith's comic opera ;News of the Day had its premiere in Berlin in 1929, but it had to wait until ;Thursday night to be heard in New York, where it was given by the Manhattan School of Music. The work has

title: U.S. TO ALLOW PRICE OF GASOLINE TO RISE AN EXTRA 5C A YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  The Department of Energy announced a new ruling today that is expected to allow gasoline prices at the pump to go up an average of 4.9 cents a gallon this year and another 5.1 cents a gallon next year, on top of increases already imposed or anticipated because of inflation and the rising cost of imported oil.

title: Security First, Democracy Second Is Wrong, the South Korean Said
description: As we sat, in South Korea, in the building overlooking Freedom Bridge on the river Imjin, he said: Sometimes, when I come up here to the DMZ, I get literally sick. That's my birthplace up there. My father was a Presbyterian minister. In 1950 the Communist troops came through our town, dragged him out of the house, and shot him dead. We found his body in the river, roped to four others. Now here I am, a college professor well known among Government people as a critic of this regime. Some of them know my experience in the war. They know I have little reason to love the North Korean style of government. They are puzzled that I don't join them in their wild zeal for national security. When will they understand that security, by itself, is meaningless? What good is security if its price is the loss of our liberty? Right here the Govern ment has built a marble monument to Americans who fought for our liberty. Where is the liberty you fought for?

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Following is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value applicable to the capital Shares of duai Purpose Investment companies at close Of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market price, of best overthe, counter dealer to dealer asked pr,cri for the caPital shares of each company with the percentage differences discount or premium) between the net asset value and

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.. Answers appear on page 47.

description: The Standings

title: Alan Schneider Resigns as Head Of the Juilliard Theater Center
description: Alan Schneider has resigned as director of the Juilliard School's Theater Center, one of the country's leading acting schools, effective at the end of this semester. Next fall, he will become professor of drama and head of the graduate directing department at the University of California in San Diego.

title: To Moscow. the Choices in Asia Look Poor
description: MOSCOW, March 2  The Chinese invasion of Vietnam has confronted the Soviet Union with what may be its most difficult military decisions in the last decade, and from its vantage point none of the options look attractive.

title: DEWEY F. BARTLETT,
description: Former United States Senator Dewey F. Bartlett of Oklahoma, who retired in January after a single term, died of lung cancer Thursday night at his home in Tulsa.

title: U.N. Namibia Plan Seems Stalled
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 2 The United Nations proposals for a ceasefire to go into effect in South,West Africa on March 15 were in jeopardy today, diplomats and officials here conceded.

title: Eritrean Says Cuban Forces Have All Been Withdrawn
description: ROME, March 2 (Reuters)  All Cuban forces have been pulled out of Eritrea, but 2,000 Soviet soldiers and advis. ers remain, an Eritrean guerrilla spokesman said today.

title: Blue boy Attempting Stock Sale to Public
description: In the first move by a company owned and run by professed homosexuals to emerge from private ownership, Blueboy Inc. is attempting to go public.

title: U.S. Tackles Family Violence
description: The Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, which was created in 1968 to provide financial and technical help to improve law enforcement and the administation of criminal justice, is spending $1.77 million this fiscal year on 11 pilot projects dealing with family violence. It is spending $900,000 more to monitor the projects.

title: Milk Spoils and Prices Rise As Negotiations Fail Again
description: When it comes to the milk strike, there has been scant human kindness, especially between the dealers and the union. Talks broke down again yesterday before they even got going. It was the second fruitless attempt by mediators to get the parties to negotiate face to tace since tne walkout began fast Saturday night, disrupting deliveries of 2 million quarts a day to New York City and Long Island customers. The sticking point was the same: a demand by the Greater New York Milk Dealers that, as a condition for negotiations, Local 587 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters process $600,000 in gradually spoiling milk still trapped in the area's 11 struck plants.

title: Dr. Clifford A. Shillinslaw, at 64; CocaCola Bottling Co. Executive
description: Dr. Clifford A. Shillinglaw, senior vice president of the CocaCola Bottling Company, died Tuesday in New York Hospital. lie was G.1 years old and a resident of Manhattan and Atlanta.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Leafs Discharge Neilson; Johnston Sought as Coach
description: TORONTO, March 2 (AP)  The Toronto Maple Leafs dropped Roger Neilson as head coach today and immediately sought to replace him with Eddie Johnston, a former National Hockey League goaltender.

title: Lackluster Islanders Lose to Flames, 32
description: ATLANTA, March 2  After most National Hockey League games involving the New York Islanders, Coach Al Arbour is calm and mildmannered.

title: With a Stronger Dollar, Shakiness Affects Yen
description: With the United States dollar showing persistent strength in foreignexchange markets, the previously strong Japanese yen is showing signs of shakiness, currencymarket sources reported yesterday.

title: Antitrust Study At Firestone
description: CLEVELAND, March 2 (AP)  Two members of Congress from Ohio have urged the Federal Trade Commission to investigate antitrust implications of the proposed merger of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and the BorgWarner Corporation.

title: Suspect Indicted for 2 Rapes
description: Harold Lewis, 27 years old, of 362 Riverside Drive, was indicted yesterday for the rape of two young women on Manhattan's Upper West Side. Mr. Lewis is charged with raping a 21yearold college student on Dec. 15 and raping and sodomizing another young woman on Feb. 4. He was arrested on Feb. 24 in the Gold Rail bar at Broadway and 110th Street.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: LONDON, March 2 (AP)  British Airways has signed a $600 million contract for 19 Boeing 757's, making it the world's first purchaser of the 186seat, mediumrange jetliner, the British Government airline and RollsRoyce announced today

title: DePaul Five Upsets Notre Dame, 7672
description: CHICAGO, March 2 (UPI)  Curtis Watkins scored 21 points and Gary Garland added 17 to lead Dc Paul to a 7672 upset victory tonight over secondranked Notre Dame.

title: Thomsons Bid Stirs Inquiry
description: TORONTO, March 2 In the face of rising political and consumer opposition, Prime Minister Pierre Eliott Trudeau today ordered an antitrust investigation into the bid for control of the Hudson's Bay Company by the Thomson family.

title: Collegians Turn From Protest to Patrol
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 2 Three evenings a week, Evelyn Nusic walks into a dilapidated gray stable at Rutgers University, ties a wellworn saddle onto her 6yearold roan appaloosa mare, and canters across the campus in search of crimes or accidents.

title: Indoor Soccer
description: MAJOR INDOOR LEAGUE

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Jimmy Butts Leads Quartet In Jazz to Pop
description: Jimmy Butts is a footnote in jazz history. He was the bassist in the Tiny Grimes group with which Charlie Parker made his first small combo recordings in 1944 (just reissued as part of a fiverecord set on the Savoy label, Charlie Parker, The Complete Savoy Studio Sessions). He recorded again with Mr. Parker in 1945 and with Teddy Wilson, Helen Humes and Buck Clayton in 1947. But Mr. Butts gave up jazz in the late40's (When bebop came in, he says, they played such long solos that it was too hard work for a bassist). And, for the last three decades, he has worked primarily in duos as a singing bassist and entertainer.

title: Scientists Seek Added Efficiency To End Confusion in Food Laws
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  A select panel of scientists offered Congress a series of recommendations today that would, if carried out, effect the biggest overhaul in Federal food regulation in 40 years.

title: HEARING IS ORDERED ON SHIPYARD BALLOT
description: RICHMOND, Va., March 2  A Federal appeals court here today ordered a hearing on the validity of a union election 13 months ago at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, where several thousand production and maintenance workers are on strike.

title: Japanese Resist Cut In Air Fares
description: TOKYO, March 2 An aerial dogfight is in the making between Japan and the United States over a proposal by Northwest Airlines to slash air fares on transPacific routes as much as 35 percent, beginning April 1.

title: A Brooklyn Filling Station Is Cited For Selling Gas Mixed With Water
description: Fill er up. motorists called out as they pulled into the H & Y Mobil Service Station at 950 Coney Island Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Boys High, Franklin Are Old Playoff Foes
description: Boys and Girls High and Franklin will meet today in a Public Schools Athletic League basketball semifinal playoff at St. John's Alumni Hall in Queens. The meeting brings back the two former schoolboy powers who met for the P.S.A.L. championship in 1964. Boys won the game, 7059, before 12,000 fans, and the P.S.A.L. lost the use of Madison Square Garden after five whisky bottles crashed to the Garden floor after the game.

title: Hanoi Proposes China Talks
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, March 2 (AP) Vietnam, after rejecting a Chinese proposal for negotiations, made its own proposal today for peace talks on the condition that Peking first withdraw its forces.

title: Ma Bell's $9Billion Captive
description: One place where telephones are made is along Shadeland Avenue in a dank industrial corner of Indianapohs. The Western Electric plant there is so big That people use golf carts and threewheel bicycles to get around it. Millions of telephones mar off the manufacturing lines there  Trimlines, Mickey Mouse phones, Snoopy phonec, phones for patios, phones for coal mines.

title: Police Candidate Sues Over Job Allegedly Denied on Moral Issue
description: LONGVIEW, Wash., March 3 (UPI) Randy Hood, a 24yearold Cowlitz County corrections officer, has filed a suit against the City of Longview, saying that he was denied a job on the city's police force because he was not married to the woman he lived with.

title: Tanker and Yacht Collide
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 (AP)  A yacht from Oregon and a British oil tanker collided in the Pacific last night, but no one was injured seriously, the Coast Guard said. All eight persons aboard the 87foot Vaurna from Portland were taken aboard the 670foot tanker Cyclops and were reported safe. A Coast Guard cutter took the power yacht under tow toward San Francisco, 20 miles to the north.

title: 12 NATIONS APPROVE BIG NUCLEAR DEVICE
description: Plans are being drafted for what would be the world's largest experimental device  a machine 20 miles in circumference, partly buried beneath the Jura Mountains north of Geneva. Within it, beams of electrons and positrons, their antimatter twins, circling the huge ring in opposite directions, would collide head on.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Topics Of Rites and Rights
description: With the Yankees owner. George Steinbrenner, and erstwhile managnr, Billy Martin, having at each other again, can spring be far behind? The word from training camp in Ft. Lauderdale is that Martin is on trial to see if he can live up to hallowed Yankee standards of good behavior, and so return as manager in 1980. But a jury of Steinbrenner and club president Al Rosen is stacked against him. They should stop the playacting and, with all due respect and gratitude, tell Martin that the job will never be his.

title: food
description: The moment has arrived. Fabulous food, wonderful wine, solicitous service, discreet decor  a magnificent meal induces a warm glow of wellbeing. You ask for the chef and out trots a pinkcheeked. cherubic person who doesn't look old enough to shave. He is one of the new breed of chefs, a group of young (many are in their 20's), intrepid, creative cooks shaking up the French restaurant scene with their audacity, irreverence and originality. Unlike the chefs of yesteryear, they thumb their noses at tradition, pretention and the haute cuisine. And they are not staunch advo cates of nouvelle cuisine either though some of them incorporate it in their work. By and large, their cooking simply defies neat categories.

title: Singles Weekends in the Catskills: More Than Just the Meeting Game
description: Lucille Jacobs, a 45yearold widow from Stamford, Conn., went to a Singles Weekend at the Concord Hotel recently to take up crosscountry skiing. Her friend, Adele Lewis, 46, an Oceanside divorcee, went for a rest.

title: Turkey, Splintered and Broke, Remains Sick Man of Europe
description: ANKARA, TurkeyThe Islamic revolution in Iran has spawned a new set of domino theorists and some of them believe that Turkey will be next. For a number of reasons, however, it seems unlikely that Turkey will follow the Iranian pattern, although the stress of serious political and economic instability is becoming more obvious day by day.

title: Broadcasting
description: Tomorrow, five weeks of hearings on television advertising aimed at children will begin at the Federal Trade Commission in Washington, picking up where the commission left off after taking testimony for two weeks in San Francisco earlier this year.

title: LANG SON CAPTURED; CHINA IS REPORTED READY TO PULL OUT
description: Chinese forces have seized the strategic Vietnamese town of Lang Son after a week of heavy fighting, Western intelligence analysts said yesterday, and are now reported willing to withdraw.

title: Carolyn A. Patterson, Nurse, Betrothed to Richard J. Sidd
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Haro1d Patterson cf Roswell, N.M., and Quitman, Tex., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Ann Patterson, to Richard Jonathan Sidd. son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gene Sidd Of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: SPORTS
description: WORLD Cup tennis has become a crashing bore, and all the Aetna insurance actuaries combined don't seem able to breathe new life into the antiquated concept. There, I said it, knowing full well that the New Haven Coliseum will be jammed with excited spectators for four days starting next Thursday, despite only a fairtomiddling United States team taking on a notoriously weak Australian squad.

title: Chinese Pronunciation: The New System
description: Following is the Pinyin system alphabet showing the pronunciation with approximate English equivalents. In parentheses, for reference, are the corresponding characters that were used in a modified WadeGiles system.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS
description: WHAT is an untried Broadwaybound musical doing in a dinner theater accustomed to feeding its patrons theatrical fare that has been tried so often it almost comes out predigested? At the Northstage Theater Restaurant in Glen Cove, the producers, Bob Funking and William Stutler, are trying to develop a new philosophy about producing musicals for assumedly unadventurous theatergoers.

title: Connecticut/ThisWeek
description: ART

title: Williams Among the Artists
description: THE new, in American verse in the 1920's, was by William Carlos Williams, Wallace Stevens and Marianne Moore. That the three of them looked intently, independently at visual artifacts is a closely related fact: painting carried, in those years, the DNA messages of new forms.

title: Stalin
description: We live. We are not sure our land is under us. Ten feet away, no one hears us.

title: BONN IS HESITATING ON ATOMPLANT DEAL
description: BONN, March 3  The West German Government is weighing approval of an export license for construction of a nuclear power plant in Argentina, a move thdt could once again strain American relations with Bonn over nuclear exports.

title: Steamboat Charter Trips
description: The 1908 Sabino, one of the last coalfired steamboats in the United States, which is now undergoing repairs at her home base, the Mystic seaport Museum in Connecticut, will be put to greater use than ever before this year. In addition to her usual program of daytime and evening cruises on the Mystic River, the Sabino will be available for evening charters for groups of up to 100 passengers and will make musical cruises on Saturday nights.

title: Fishermen Say Rules Snag Them
description: BOSTON, March 3 (AP)  The schools of cod and haddock have grown since foreign fishermen were chased from New England's rich fishing waters two years ago, but so have the complaints from American fishermen.

title: The Nation
description: When Jane M. Byrne knocked off the Democratic machine in Chicago last week it was like the Rock of Gilbraltar falling into the ocean said Senator Charles M. Percy, a Republican noncombatant.

title: Soviet Prisoner
description: Menachem Begins story about his arrest. interrogation and confinement in a Soviet prison camp first appeared in English in 1957. I doubt that it sold many copies at the time or received more than a few perfunctory reviews. Books on such experiences were a dime a dozen in those years. Nor was this literature considered quite respectable, even in the socalled cold war climate: One could understand the bitterness of the former inmates, it was said, but surely they exaggerated. And even if they were reporting the truth and nothing but the truth, these accounts nevertheless made depressing reading, not the stuff of which best sellers are made. It was Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn who made the prisoncamp genre popular, even though The Gulag Archipelago contains hardly anything that was not known to students of Soviet affairs.

title: What's Doing in WARSAW
description: What is immediately apparent to even a casual visitor to Warsaw is the omnipresence of the Roman Catholic Church. More than any other institution, more, even, than the Communist Party, the church influences the spirit and quality of Polish life. It commands the loyalty of more than 90 per cent of Poland's 35 million people.

title: PEOPLE
description: One more casualty of the bitter and violent antiAmerican attitude prevalent in fran today. That's how David E. Lilienthal described the Development and Resources Corporation, from which Mr. Lilienthal and John W. Macy resigned as chairman and president, respectively, last week. They also recommended the dissolution of the development company, which was founded in 1955 and had a lengthy involvement with development in Iran notably in the construction of the huge Pahlevi Dam on the Dez River. The resignations, the announcement said, were inspired by the cancellation of Iranian contracts and a lapse in current and outofdate payments for services.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: The establishment of a new series of book awards to augment the National Book Awards is being considered by the Association of American Publishers for implementation in the spring of 1980. The new awards, which have grown out of dissatisfaction with the N.B.A., will be broaderbased and will involve massmarket publishers, acccording to Franklyn L. Rodgers, president of Charles Scribner's Sons and head of the A.A.P. committee working on the problem. And there is a distinct likelihood that paperbacks will be candidates in certain categories in the new program. The publishing world has changed, Mr. Rodgers said, and the awards should change with it.

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball Tourney: 40 Teams Get Chance to Be No. 1
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball championship, which started with only eight teams in 1939, has bulged to a 40team field for the 91st annual tournament, which starts Friday. One of every 6.4 of the 257 major college basketball teams will play in the national championship, by far the richest of the N.C.A.A.'s many championship events.

title: Cynthia White Wed To R.G. Whiteman
description: Cynthia Vail White and Robert Gordon Whiteman were married yesterday in Palma de Mallorca, Spain. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of San Francisco by the Rev. Guillermo Payeras.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts of County Chiefs Meeting
description: Following are excerpts from a roundtable discussion with the top officials of Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Bergen and Essex Counties and reporters and editors of The New York Times. The County leaders were Sam Colman, Rockland; Alfred D. DelBello, Westchester; John V. N. Klein, Suffolk; Jeremiah F. O'Connor, Bergen; Francis T. Purcell, Nassau, and Peter Shapiro, Essex. The discussion was held in the Manhattan offices of The Times.

title: CALENDAR
description: Today. Greenwich Antiques Show. Civic Center. Take Exit 5 from 195. 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Furniture, china, glass, collectibles.

title: J.E. Meyer 3d Weds Patricia Ann Reese
description: Patricia Ann Reese, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard L. Reese of St. Petersburg, Fla., was married at the Pleasantville (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church yesterday to J. Edward Meyer 3d of Chappaqua, N.Y., a partner in the New York law firm of Spengler Carlson Gubar Churchill 8c Brodsky.

title: Mark Zeidel Fianc Of Susan Freedman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Freedman of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Dee Freedman, to Mark Lawrence Zeidel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Zeidel of Waitsfield. Vt.

title: The Postal Dispute: An Imbalance of Forces
description: THE controversy over the proposed move of the administrative offices of the United States Postal Service from New York City to New Rochelle has underscored the dynamic issues city versus suburbs, big city versus small city, and decisions based on public policy as opposed to economic factors.

title: U. S. Official Says Much of Asia Is Faced by Permanent Poverty
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (Reuters)  Swift population growth and low food production are threatening to trap much of Asia in permanent poverty, a State Department official said this week.

title: Rangers Tie Sabres; Islanders Score, 42
description: It is better to come from behind and tie than to lose a lead and be tied. With that hockey axiom in mind, the Rangers might have been a bit happy about their 22 deadlock yesterday with the Buffalo Sabres at Madison Square Garden.

title: Chicago Businessmen Expecting Usual Alliance With New Mayor
description: CHICAGO, March 3  Business leaders are hastening to reassure everyone that their traditional partnership with City Hall will continue intact, despite the mayoral primary upset here, and that Chicago will remain the city that works.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: CITY people don't know about outside fire sirens. They pull a handle on a red box or phone 911 and the engines appear. To suburban parents, the wail of a siren from a firehouse roof can chill the blood when their children are not at home.

title: U.S. Office of Education Forming Bureau to Combine 23 Programs
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)  The Federal Office of Education is combining 23 of its smallest programs into a Bureau of School Improvement, which will have a budget of $110 million.

title: Two Police Officers Plead Guilty to Felony Charges
description: Two New York City police officers pleaded guilty to felony charges last week in separate cases brought by the rackets bureau of the Manhattan District Attorney's office. They were automatically discharged from the department and deprived of their pensions.

title: Icebreaker Test on Lakes Is Surpassing Expectations
description: SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., March 3  The first icebreakertug that uses air bubbles forced from holes in the hull to lubricate her passage is surpassing all expectations in comprehensive testing on the Great Lakes, Coast Guardsmen and scientists aboard agreed.

title: Calendars
description: Today  Drag racing season opens at Madison Township Raceway Park, Pension Road. Englishtown, N.J. Gates open 9 A.M.; eliminations2 P.M.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: I read with interest the frontpage article by Andree Brooks, Report Cards for Teachers [Dec. 3]. Implicitly, if not explicitly, the article suggests that teachers do not employ basic skills with precision, thereby contributing to an already exaggerated issue. Curiously, the article does not adhere to the demands of precise reporting.

title: Jane Auld Linker Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joe Burton Linker Jr. of Lynchburg. Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Auld Linker to John Harvey Halbrook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Noah J. Halbrook of Venice, Fla. Miss Linker is a nurse at St. Luke's Hospital in New York, where her fianc, is an industrial psychologistpastoral counselor with the Consolidated Edison Company. An April 7 wedding is planned.

description: Today

title: Many French Cite Lack Of Contraception Data
description: PARIS, March 3 (UPI)  Fiftysix percent of French men and 46 percent of French women consider themselves insufficiently informed on contraception, according to an opinion poll.

title: CARTER REASSURES CANADA ON PIPELINE
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  President Carter affirmed today the strong commitment of the United States to the construction of the multibilliondollar natural gas pipeline to bring Alaskan gas to the lower 48 states through Canada.

description: OAKVILLE, Ontario  Sale! screamed the sign in the store window. Only $4.499 for a swimming pool l

description: WASHINGTON, March 3  President Carter has authorized the formation of a campaign committee to raise money for his reelection and begin the task of building a Carter organization around the country, according to Democratic Party leaders around the country.

description: The engagement of Laura Whitney Mali, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Mali of Pennington, N.J., and Bethel, Vt., to Michael James Astrue, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Astrue of Milton, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: WASHINGTON  Listen for a while to Charles J. DiBona, the new president of the American Petroleum Institute, and it soon becomes clear that one of his favorite words is analysis. Indeed, Mr. DiBona, who took over on Jan. 1, has traveled far on his analytical skills  from the Navy, to a think tank, to the White House and thence to the A.P.I., the oil industry's trade association of 350 corporate and 7,500 individual members.

title: Geological Survey, at 100 Years, Still Fills in Maps Blank Spaces
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)  How much oil is under the Atlantic or how much silver in Montana?

description: AGATHA ILLAVA pulled into her driveway in Westport. Carefully, she got out of her car, steadied herself on her two canes and walked up the three stone stens to her door.

title: GARDENING
description: LAST week iceberg lettuce was 89 cents at the superinarket. That price put a salad essential in the luxury class and made the arrival of spring seem even more urgent. At least then the vegetable patch can be planted and a nearlyfree supply of fresh salad greens will be a reality.

title: A Redefinition of Farms Leaves New York State With 20% Fewer
description: ALBANY Because of a change in the official definition of the word farm, New York State lost about 20 percent of its farms on Jan. 1, with the number dropping from 56,000 to 45,000, according to statistics issued by the State Crop Reporting Service.

title: Cutbacks Will Hurt, County Officials Warn
description: NOW that everyone has got the message  that the public demands tax cuts  the people in charge of spending the money are having to search for areas where reductions can be made with the least amount of pain.

title: 12 Vie in House Election on Coast For Seat of Ryan, Guyana Victim
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 3  While leading Democratic candidates to succeed the late Representative Leo J. Ryan are arguing over who was closest to him, the Republican campaigners in Tuesday's special election are hoping to regain the 11th Congressional District seat that Mr. Ryan held.

title: Adviser to Corporations
description: SCHOOL is out. Corporate management, it seems, has for the present been sufficiently advised by its favorite counselor; now Peter Drucker is at the corner cafe, delightedly regaling anyone who will listen with tales of what must be one of the more varied  and for a practitioner of such a narrow skill as that of management counseling, astonishing  of contemporary professional lives.

title: Some Stories From The Cowboy
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.  As a singing cowboy, he appeared in nearly 100 motion pictures and his recording of Rudolph the RedNosed Reindeer has sold more than 11 million copies. He is a genuine American folk hero. But now Gene Autry owns six radio stations and two television stations. He also owns the

title: Can Women Succeed as Commuters?
description: MORE than a few raised eyebrows and dropped jaws greet my mild announcement that I am returning to the fulltime work force and will be toiling not in the familiar vineyards of Fairfield County, crossroads of half a hundred corporate headouarters, but in the Big Apple, focus of my youthful dreams albeit less shiny than in those days. From now on it will be, out of the secluded study and into the Madison Avenue mainstream and all those millions of private lives flowing through Grand Central Terminal.

title: BANK PANEL ADOPTS RULES ON REDLINING
description: ALBANY, March 3The state's Banking Board this week adopted regulations designed to combat redlining by banks, fulfilling a birgain Governor Carey made with legislators three months ago.

title: Susan P. Robben to Be a Bride
description: Susan Patricia Robben and George Eugene Gwozdecky, 78 alumni of the University of Wisconsin, plan to be married in August. Mr. and Mrs. John Robben of Old Greenwich, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Dr. and Mrs. George Gwozdecky of Thunder Bay, Ontario.

description: Earplay, a radio showcase for largely original dramas, has begun new season on National Public Radio.

title: Spain's Winning Party Is Mapping Its Strategy For Municipal Election
description: MADRID, March 3  Savoring their victory in Thursday's Parliament elections, Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez, his Cabinet ministers and close aides met today to map strategy for next month's municipal elections.

title: FILM VIEW
description: There are several times in any one year when it's apparent that film critics should abdicate in favor of sociologists and psychologists, who are better trained to read human behavior. Criticism seems beside the point when a film like Walter Hill's dreamy, showwindowpretty The Warriors comes along and not only makes a mint of money from its very first days in national release, but also is reportedly responsible for three deaths in or near the theaters where the film is playing.

title: DINING OUT Hibachis on the Miracle Mile
description: BENIHANA of Tokyo has been elaborately installed on a sizable chunk of Miracle Mile real estate. This Benihana of Manhasset is no miracle. It's hardly even a happening.

title: More Bones and a Gun Found at Gacy's Home
description: CHICAGO, March 3 (UPI)  New bones and a gun were found Friday at the home of John Wayne Gacy, the suspected killer of 32 young men and boys.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: One of the more arresting recent characters is a fleshcolored bodysuit personage, Slim Goodbody. John Burstein, the creator of the droll guise that outlines the muscles, organs and skeletal system, appeared in his garb before nail a million school children after publishing the first book slim Goodbody Presents the Inside Story. In his newest project, expressive color photos of Slim accompany cartoons, forced rhymes and explicit advice on handling a potpourri of the most common aches and pains. Sections on dental care and vision are well devised, whereas others, relaxation information or love (yourself), promise more than they deliver.

title: Attempts Being Made In Iran to Ease Strains Between Ruling Units
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 3  Quiet efforts were under way today to ease the tensions between the Government of Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan and the parallel religious government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Maine Considers Relaxing Its Strict Air Quality Standards
description: AUGUSTA, Me., March 3  Maine, whose air quality standards are more stringent than those imposed by the Federal Government, will allow air to become dirtier if proposals by the state's Bureau of Air Quality Control are approved.

title: Middle East Countdown
description: This is a tense, probably fateful moment in the careers of Menachem Begin, Anwar Sadat and Jimmy Carter. They stand at the edge of a historic alliance that could enhance the security of their nations and reassert their joint power in a dangerously unstable Middle East. But they are held back by mutual suspicions. The time for accommodation, if it has not already passed, is about to run out.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: PEOPLE want to know about a diesel's performance, said Paul May. That's the main thing that they ask, and we tell them the truth. A diesel doesn't have the pickup that a gas engine does, but the mileage they'll be getting will more than make up for the disadvantage.

title: Carter to Address Publishers
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) President Carter will address the 93d annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in New York City on April 25, the association has announced.

title: Queen of the Poor
description: Angela BurdettCoutts inherited the modern equivalent of 4 million when she was 23. She was friends with Disraeli, Dickens, Dr. David Livingstone and Gen. Charles George Gordon. She nearly married the Duke of Wellington when she was 33 and he was 78. She did marrY an obscure American named William Ashmead Bartlett when she was 67 and he was 30. Her life spanned that of Queen Victoria, who was another friend. Her acts of charity were both imaginative and generous  E7,000 for a drinking fountain in London's East End, for example  and earned her the title of Queen of the Poor. Later the other Queen gave her a more dignified epithet by making her the first female baron: Baroness BurdettCoutts of Highgate and Brookfield.

title: Corsica
description: To Joseph Heller, death has always been a laughing matter. He was 5 when his father died suddenly, and he remembers the day of the funeral as a party. He was petted and crooned to and fed cake and candy. He was considered too young to understand grief, and for

title: A Film Actress Aims at TV Oomph
description: Los ANGELES

title: With a Dash of Chlorine
description: The following article was written by Julian Kane, a geology professor at Hofstra University who also teaches at Garden City High School, and by Shane O'Neill and John Peterson, Garden City High School students involved in water studies. Mr. Kane is a member of the Citizens Advisory Committee of the Long Island Regional Planning Board's Water Management Study.

title: TIMES REVISES STYLE OF CHINESE SPELLING
description: Under New System Teng Becomes, Deng and Nanking Is Nanjing

title: THE MARKETS
description: While stocks bounced around nervously last week and the Dow Jones industrials fell 7.53 points to $.15.75, two men working in a quiet corner office at 30 Rockefeller Plaza asserted that they have no qualms about calling the nearterm direction of the market: It is headed up.

title: At Aspen, Scooter Makes You Believe It's All Downhill
description: ASPEN, Colo. Most major ski resorts have one: A handsome, hotshot ski instructor with a big reputation and a tan that won't quit, whom all the money moguls and expert skiers feel they Simply Must Hire. At glittery Aspen, that person is Scooter LaCouter.

title: A Kaleidoscope of Dance Styles, Starring the Last Isadorable
description: THE differences between the Royal Danish Ballet and the New York City Ballet are often considered stylistic ones. Where Auguste Bournonville, the father of 19thcentury romantic ballet, reuea on tectinical restraint and delicacy of motion to produce a joyful, pastoral sensibility, George Balanchine filters the 19thcentury Russian classic tradition of Marius Petipa to produce strong, cleanedged modernist forms.

title: Births
description: REINHOLD

title: Jennifer Forrest, Caterer, Wed to David Sonenshein
description: Jennifer Nan Forrest, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold William Forrest of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Guilford, Conn., was married in Boston yesterday to David Aaron Sonenshein, son of Celia Sonenshein of Passaic, N.J., and the late Israel Sonenshein. Rabbi Ronald Weiss performed the ceremony at the Parker House.

title: Engagements
description: RUDESVLAMIS Mr & Mrs Peter Vlanes of New York City arrource the engagement of their daughter Katherine to Jeffrev Rudes. Son of David Rudes of New York and Hallandale. Fia. and the tate Elaine Rudes.

title: Don Cherry's Rare Jazz
description: Jazz at Entermedia, a threenight festival at the Entermedia Theater, Second Avenue and 12th Street, got off to an auspicious if decidedly unconventional start Thursday. Granted, at this point in the development of jazz what is conventional or unconventional is a relative matter. But the firm night of the festival began with an unaccompanied vocalist, Jeanne Lee, and ended with Don Cherry and his trio, who used an Indian sitar, a harpguitar from Mali, a musical bow from Brazil and other nonWestern instruments almost exclusively.

title: IN BRIEF
description: The $1 billion takeover bid by the American Express Company for McGrawHill Inc., the publishing giant, expired. I misread the reaction of Harold McGraw, James D. Robinson 3d, chairman of American Express, said, commenting on the acrimonious battle waged between himself and Mr. McGraw, the chairman of the publishing concern. . . . The Ticor Corporation, the nation's largest title insurer, announced an agreement in principle for a takeover by the Southern Pacific Company, which controls the nation's thirdlargest railroad.

title: Letters: The Oldest Library
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Farmers Ever See Parity?
description: THE farmers have returned to Washington, and I have been thinking about their plea for 100 percent of parity.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: TRANSATLANTIC BLUES, by Wilfrid Sheed. (Avon, $2.25.) During a transAtlantic flight Monty Chatsworth, awardwinning television commentator and personality, turns his tape recorder into a confessional box. The result is a fictional autobiography that throws dark comic light on the contrasting ways of British and American society since World War II and on the spiritual torments of a modern Catholic.

title: Virginia Neaher Sets May Bridal
description: Announcement has been made by United States District Court Judge and Mrs. Edward R. Neaher of Garden City, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Ann Neaher, to Stephen Kahn Gardner, son of Mrs. Irvin B. Gardner of Hillsborough, Calif., and the late Dr. Gardner.

title: A PRESIDENT NAMED BY AUDUBON SOCIETY
description: Russell W. Peterson, director of the Federal Office of Technology Assessment, will leave his post April 1 to become the seventh president of the National Audubon Society, the two organizations have announced.

title: Chamber Society Offers Revival and 2 Favorites
description: Like many bestlaid plans, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center concert Friday night at Alice Tully Hall went a bit awry when Gunther Schuller could not deliver the octet that the society had commissioned from him for the group's 10th anniversary (it will be completed in time to be performed next season). Since the requisite eight players were primed and ready, another octet was substituted, the wellknown one by Schubert.

title: Grace Richardson of Con Ed Bride of Ralph Henderson
description: The marriage of Grace Richardson, director of consumer affairs for Consolidated Edison, to Ralph B. Henderson, vice president and director of catalogue operations for the J.C. Penney Company, took place yesterday at Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church. Msgr. Austin J. Holland performed the ceremony.

description: Following are excerpts from tne  county officials discussion:

title: Photos Revealing New Details on Jupiter's Moons
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 3  New pkotographs from the Voyager 1 spacecraft are showing the moons of Jupiter in increasing detail, revealing for the first time long dark streaks that could be fault lines on Europa and a huge bull'seye feature on Io that mystifies scientists.

title: Men's Fashion
description: It is no accident that Italianbased designers and manufacturers influence the cut of men's clothes everywhere in the world today. Italian men have always understood how to dress. Take a walk down any street in Milan or Rome and watch the men. Even the most humble waiter has a jacket a bit different from the next wailer. The cut is perfect, as is the flair. The Italians understand English tailoring hut use softer fabrics and a lessstructured cut to pull oft a look that is unique.

title: Art and Anthropology Wedded in The Hidden Valley And Two Worlds of Peru Exhibitions Blend Art and Anthropology
description: CHATHAM

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: Competing Versions of Le Spectre de la Rose
description: Both Rudolf Nureyev and Judith Jamison will dance the role of the Spectre to the familiar Weber score this week. Mr. Nureyev will perform Michael Fokine's original choreography in the Homage to Diaghilev at the Mark Hellinger Theater; Miss Jamison will dance Maurice Bejart's recent version with the Ballet of the 20th Century at the Minskoff Theater.

title: It's a New Scene At Seaside Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY

title: Hitchcock  His True Power Is Emotion
description: The career of Alfred Hitchcock, who will receive the American Film Institute Life Achievement Award on Wednesday, proves that a film director can be successful while remaining true to himself, while choosing his own subjects, treating them in his own way, and making his obsessions accepted by the entire world. The Lady Vanishes, Notorious and Rear Window would have been enough to assure the glory of any director, but if you add The ThirtyNine Steps, Rebecca, Suspicion, Shadow of a Doubt, Strangers on a Train, The Man Who Knew Too Much, Vertigo, North by Northwest, Psycho, The Birds and Marnie, you will have listed merely onefourth of a staggering body of work  the richest, longest, and most complete filmography of the directors who began in silent film.

title: Wagner in a Bold New Style
description: In JeanPierre Ponnelle's production of Wagner's The Flying Dutclunan, to be given for the first time by the Metropolitan Opera Thursday night, the main drama takes place entirely in the mind of the Steersman, a minor character who turns up near the beginning of the opera to post watch, but promptly falls asleep instead. The Dutchman, a surreal presence in a black, jewelencrusted cape, is a mere image in a dream. So is Senta, who wears a white, embroidered wedding dress. The Steersman himself appears in his dream as Erik, Senta's thwarted suitor.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE Trenton boy has come home. He sits with a blanket over his knees. The face, once full and ruddy, is now sculpted sparingly, and the ivory skin is smooth.

title: Neediest Cases Appeal Closes With $1,103,189, a Record
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended its 66th annual appeal last week with a total of $1,103,189, a record, in contributions from 10,313 donors.

title: Fall of Dong Khe to China Recalls a French Defeat
description: HONG KONG, March 3 In the summer of 1950, Vo Nguyen Giap, the commander of the Communist Vietminh forces, constructed  in China  a lifesize replica of the French Indochina border outpost of Dong Khe.

title: Wilson's Latest Is in Grand Line of Theater Pieces
description: WEST BERLIN  Robert Wilson's Death, Destruction and Detroit, which will be playing most nights into early April at the Schaubhne am Halleschen Ufer here, is the latest in that grand line of major Wilson theater pieces that includes Deafman Glance, The Life and Times of Josef Stalin and Einstein on the Beach.

title: A Cuban Envoy Pledges All the Aid Hanoi Need
description: MEXICO CITY, March 3 (UPI)  The Cuban Ambassador to Mexico has said it an interview that his country would give Vietnam all needed assistance, including troops if necessary, to fight the Chinese.

title: Deaths
description: SCHICKERTHilde. On February 24, 1979. Sister of Kurt and Adolf. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Memorial service at Grace Church Chantry, Broadway and 10th St., Tuesday March 6 at 11 AM.

title: CAMERA
description: Having your first book published is an exciting experience, but many photographers who would love to have their pictures published in book form haven't the faintest idea about hew to go about it.

title: Why Are the New Stars of Disco Mostly Women?
description: If you spend any time dancing in discos, or if you listen to WKTUFM or any radio station that plays a lot of disco music, you've probably noticed the preponderance of female voices among the stars who have emerged in the disco era. Think of a disco song and what you're likely to hear in your mind, above the thumping regularity of the beat and whatever novelty effects the producer has inserted, are one or more chirping women's voices. The new stars of disco are mostly women  Donna Summer, Gloria Gaynor and such newcomers as Cheryl Lynn, Madleen Kane, Grace Jones, the women in Chic and Sister Sledge and many, many more.

title: Condominium Concept: Vacation at Home
description: CORAM

title: Pegasus at the Starting Gate
description: EAST RUTHERFORD

title: GARDENING
description: THERE are those who still extol the virtues of the old New York International Flower Show. Each spring the Coliseum in Manhattan was transformed into a wonderland of gardens and floral displays, and such was the demand for perfection that a single misplaced plant might result in the loss of a trophy.

title: COURT CLEARS WAY FOR CARVEL INQUIRY
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice has cleared the way for the State Attorney General's office to move ahead on an investigation into allegations that the Carvel Corporation is guilty of restraint of trade, but he said that the ice cream company need not disclose its secret formula.

title: Chic Milieus
description: OWA BOMB explosion at Bloomingdale's! (It's called Abingdon's, and it has been moved a few blocks north, but it's all there, from Housewares to Polo to Underground Gourmet Shop.) But the bomb is just the beginning. There's also a foot fetishist, a pickpocket, a compulsive gambler, a mugger eating a Hostess Twinkle, a Psychotically vengeful exwile, a live Prime Minister and a murderous male model, just for starters. In fact the novel seems to have been put together like Abingdon's merchandising policy, or like a cake made by a child: how about some of this? and this and this and that too? Pile it on and hope it works.

title: ISRAELIS CITE BASIS FOR DEFENSE FEARS
description: TEL AVIV  A ranking Israeli Army officer, seated in his office at the Ministry of Defense, leaned forward, clenched his fist and said, There is, you see, a philosophical difference, a fundamental difference, between us and the United States as to what is the bottom line of damage, of penalty that we can take in a war.

title: Management Tools
description: In battling the growing problem of employee theft, business is in no mood to scoff at any stratagem. Some of the latest:

title: A TINY TOWN BA A MINING GIANT
description: Crested Butte sweeps its rocky ridge into the Colorado sky, high above the tiny hamlet which has taken its name. More than a butte, it is a 12,000foot peak with a sawtoothed crest, a miniMatterhorn challenged only by the supine Mount Emmons across the valley. The two mountains stand like bookends above the plain.

title: ANTIQUES
description: MURIEL JACOBS and Doris Ballard provide a real service to those interested In buying or selling antiques in New Jersey. All one has to do is read their book, Antiquing in New Jersey and Bucks County, Penna.

title: Misses Lundquist, Little Share Lead at 211
description: SARASOTA. Fla., March 3  Dale Lundquist, a littleknown professional from Tampa. Fla., with four years on the tour, and Sally Little of South Africa took the lead after 54 holes today in the Ladies Professional Golf Association Bent Tree Classic.

description: Today: Leading Events

title: This Week in Sports
description: Boxing

title: Singers on Disks, From Ameling To von Stade
description: Singers are among the busiest musicians in the recording studios and there are always a flock of new vocal disks on hand. The following alphabetical survey takes a look at what some of today's most popular concert and opera personalities have produced over the past month or two to satisfy their record, collecting admirers.

title: Figuring Angles;	Washington Seeks Equidistance in the BigPower Triangle
description: WASHINGTON  Government officials rarely admit that the pace of events has left them dazed, but enough things happened last week in American relations with the Soviet Union and China to leave anyone confused. As Chinese troops fought Moscow's ally, Vietnam, Washington and Peking formally established diplomatic relations. And as Washington and Moscow continued their lowlevel quarrels over the Middle East and Iran, the two sides moved closer completing a new treaty limiting strategic arms. Thus, the threecornered relationship between the two Communist powers and the United States seemed a lot more dynamic and a lot more complicated than ever before.

description: Theater

title: News Summary
description: International

title: U.S. Exports: A New Hard Sell
description: John Rennie, president of Pacer Systems Inc. of Burlington, Mass., made his first sales trip abroad in the fall of 1977. He went to West Germany, lugging i.long one of his 40pound flight simulators, a schoolroom training device for student pilots. Mr. Rennie started out in Dusseldorf, and ovr a period of a week, he drove a rented Merci:des over 1,000 miles to Cologne, Bonn, Hanovar, Hamburg and Frankfurt, visiting potential customers. Mr. Rennie doesn't speak Gernmn, but the road signs were helpful enough in n ost places, and when he came to a big city, he would look for a taxi. I'd tell the driver the name of the hotel and just follow him in, he said.

title: Notes: A Quick Guide to Music City
description: Nashville, once a medium size, moderately well known Southern city, has acquired a national identity as the capital of country music. It is the home of the Grand Ole Opry, the nation's oldest continuous radio show, the amusement park called Opryland, dozens of recording and television studios and many of the leading country music entertainers. By tradition, Tennessee's capital is the Athens of the South. Today it is better known as Music City.

title: Marine in Hanoi May Face Inquiry in Return to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  Marine Corps officials at the Pentagon say they will soon go to Vietnam to bring home Pfc. Robert Russell Garwood, who was captured by the Vietcong in 1965 and who reappeared last month when he flipped a message to an anonymous traveler in Hanoi asking that the State Department be informed that he wished to return to the United States.

title: Track Title to Tech
description: Brooklyn Tech, scoring in six of the 13 events, gained the second leg of the triple crown of Public Schools Athletic League track and field titles yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Caring for Our Neighbors
description: I am enclosing a small check to help you close your 1978 campaign with a slightly higher total, wrote a donor to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund last week. That contribution, along with 10,313 others, brought the total of the fund's 67th appeal to $1,103,189.13  $58,000 above last year's, and the highest in the fund's history. For the ninth consecutive year, contributions exceeded the milliondollar mark.

title: VIEWS OF SPORT
description: IWISH someone had told me when I was 14 years old that I was all washed up. I am not sure what would have done about it, but according to the latest reports, young women in Easternbloc countries are doing something. The word is that many of them are taking hormones to delay the onset of puberty. The idea is to keep them lithe and unwomanly enough to be good athletes.

title: Children's Programming Without Commercials
description: The new network does not go by initials but by the name Nickelodeon. Since it carries no advertising, it is liberated from the tyranny of audience headcounts. Instead of being designed by specialists in the art of riveting the great mass of viewers to the set, its programming is assembled by an authority in children's education, Dr. Vivian Homer, who helped develop The Electric Company for the Children's Television Workshop.

title: SEYMOUR MARCUS
description: Seymour Marcus, a former newspaper art director, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92 years old.

title: Mexican Party Marks 50 Year of Uninterrupted Power
description: MEXICO CITY, March 3  The sound of backs being slapped in warm embraces announced the end of the meeting, doors swung open and out marched Mexico's top labor leaders, laughing and joking as they straightened their ties and adjusted the pistols in their belts.

title: Iran's Central Bank Devalues Rial
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 3 (Reuters) The Government of Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan devalued its currency today and pledged that Iran would repay all its foreign debts.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Do you ever have the feeling that you're about 12 years old again, and so are the people producing the shows you see? I don't mean a nice, bright, dawnlike feeling. I think that disappears after six. I mean a terrible sensation of deja vu, with the vu anything but prepossessing.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 3  Players views on the existing basic agreement and future negotiations took up much of the Yankee session today as Marvin Miller, executive director of the Players Association, began his tour of spring baseball camps.

title: Sally Chesson Sets Nuptials on June 23
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Chesson of Gladstone, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Sally Chesson, to Ronald Duffus Sutherland 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Sutherland of Los Angeles. formerly of Princeton, N.J.

title: Nada J.Skerly Married To William R. Arnold
description: Nada J. Skerly, a lecturer in gerontology at the University of Cincinnati, was married yesterday to William R. Arnold of Pittsburgh, a consultant with Alcoa.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Today

title: McCarter Recalling The Blues
description: ONTO the stage step three downandout women, as beaten as the walls of the dilapidated flophouse, as de pressed as the stock market.

title: Newsy Novels
description: NOBODY IS SAFE from the novel these days. It's open season on politicians, of course, and even the celebrated dead, like Agatha Christie, turn up in potboilers that violate taste but not libel law. Neal Travis's book zeros in on the New York journalistic scene.

title: What the County Executives Said
description: Following are excerpts from a round table discussion with the ??to s of Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Bergen and Essex Counties and editors of The New York Times. The County Executives were Francis T. Purcell, Nassau; John V. N. Klein, Suffolk; Alfred D. DelBello, Westchester; Sam Colman, Rockland; Jeremiah F. O'Connor, Bergen, and Peter Shapiro, Essex. The discussion was held in the Manhattan offices of The Times.

title: Once Again, The Restless Kurds Seek Autonomy
description: As Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's revolutionary regime struggles to revive a shattered economy, rebuild a demoralized army and bring armed leftwingers under control, Iran's mosaic of nationalities and ethnic groups showing signs of coming unstuck. The two most worrisome restive groups are the Kurds in the west and the Baluchis in the southeast. Either could easily enmesh Iran in dangerous entanglements with its neighbors. Government spokesmen last week insisted that secessionists would not be tolerated. Delegations were dispatched to mountainous, northwestern Kurdistan to treat with Kurdish leaders who have emerged as the real rulers of their remote region.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The Museum of Modern Art has begun the celebration of its 50th anniversary with a major new show on a subject it introduced to the American public shortly after the museum was founded modern architecture. The exhibition, called Transformations in Modern Architecture, will run throueh April 24.

title: Two Directors
description: When John Ford came home to Hollywood after four adventurous years serving with the Office of Strategic Services during World War II, he cajoled Louis 13. Mayer into paying him a quarter of a million dollars to direct They Were Expendable and shamed him into contributing an equal amount as conscience money for making movies and money in Hollywood while Ford fought Nazis. The entire halfmillion went to found the Field Photo Farm. a rest home and clubhouse for the 300 veterans of Ford's personal wartime reconnaissance and espionage unit.

title: New Setbacks in the Inflation War
description: America's economic picture plunged further into gloom last week, as the Government released a barrage of data nearly all of it indicating that the nation appears to be fighting a losing battle against inflation.

title: An Urban Designer Who Weds Land to Ocean Lays
description: At least 30 new glass and concrete hotels with names like Caesar's World, the Golden Nugget, the Dunes, M.G.M. Grand, Playboy and Penthouse, more than 20 of them in a flashy, highrise strip along the Boardwalk. Elevated, glassenclosed, climatecontrolled skyways linking hotels with a giant shooping pavillion called The Megastructure. Moving walkways, trafficfree malls. Parisian sidewalk kiosks. Inland waterways, channels, basins and lagoons. Marinas, with recreational stone bulkheading and construction linking the water with the land.

title: The Welsh Rejected Limited Autonomy, the Scots Split on the Issue
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland  During the seemingly endless controversy over the question of Irish home rule, William Ewan Gladstone commented, Making power local makes it congenial. The same conviction brought Britain last week to the climax of one of its great constitutional debates.

title: MURROW vs.McCARTHY: SEE IT NOW
description: On a wall of Joseph McCarthy's Senate office there used to hang a framed quotation. its author unknown!

title: Deaths
description: LIPSKYDaniel. Beloved husband of the late Anne and Minnie. Devoted brotherinlaw of Frances Kera, Jack Cantor, and Paul W. Cantor. Cherished uncle of Daniel. Karl, and David Lipsky, Seth Lawrence, Paul S. and Frederic Cantor, and Beth Ann Matz. Services today, March 4, 1:45 P.M.. The Riverside', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Poll Shows Most Workers in U.S. Prefer Jobs to Early Retirement
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)  For the first time, a majority of Americans indicated they would rather keep working than take an early or full retirement

title: ExG.S.A. Manager Is Convicted in Bribery
description: BALTIMORE, March 2 (AP)  A jury deliberated for more than five hours Friday before convicting a former General Services Administration store manager, Charles E. Phelps, on 13 counts of bribery, filing false claims and consoiracy to defraud the Government.

title: T. G. Harris Weds Ann Roberts
description: Ann R. Roberts, daughter of Mary Clark Rockefeller and the late Nelson A. Rockefeller, Vice President and Governor of New York; was married at her home in New York yesterday to T George Harris of Princeton. N.J., a Journalist and magazine editor. He is the son of Luna Harris of Trenton, Ky., and the late Garland Harris. The Rev. John Canker Jr., rector of Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, performed the private ceremony.

title: ANTIQUES
description: The show Gene London puts on for clients in his Gramercy Park studio is an imaginative mixture of period fashions, frivolity and his own special brand of fantasy. He might use as a curtainraiser, for example, a parade of Victorian costumes, rich in laces and ruffles. Then he might follow it with some flippant flapper fashions  awash with beading and sparkling sequins, and cut to swing free of the sylphlike figures of highstepping ladies. For the grand finale, he might consider presenting the suits from the 1940's  football shoulders, buckled waists and skinny skirts that stop short of the ankles. In between, of course, there would probably be a selection of exotic kimonos, comfortably cool camisoles, ermine capes, slinky crepes and even a host of hats.

title: It's Almost Time To Tap the Maples
description: The curator of the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation, Nicholas A. Shoumatoff leaned into a huge sugar maple, drilling a hole with the diameter he recommmends  sevensixteenths of an inch  to draw the sweet sap. It was too early and too cold for maple sugaring, but he wanted to show visitors how was done.

title: I Can't Afford Not to Play Sinclair Lewis
description: Murder. Bruce Dern muttered the word wearily as he pushed Into the lobby of the SherryNetherlands Hotel where, using the sleeve of his navyblue jogging suit as a sponge, the 42yearold actor swabbed the sweat beading on his angular face. Then he started for the elevator.

title: The nice of Success; THE ART MUSEUM Power, Money, Ethics. A Twentieth Century Fund Report. By Karl E. Meyer. Illustrated 352 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $15.
description: THE American art museum, it is now generally agreed, has entered upon a period of crisis  a crisis of success. It has won the attention of a large, eager, heterogeneous public, and yet it cannot afford to serve this public without large  and ever larger  infusions of money from gov ernment, industry, foundations and private benefactors. Thus, the more it succeeds in fulfilling its recognized functions  to col lect, exhibit and preserve works of art deemed to be of significant quality  the more it invites the scrutiny of outside bodies who, more often than not, know little or nothing about art except what it costs to buy it and show it and keep it in a reasonable state of repair.

title: Pamela L. Fraser Becomes Bride
description: Pamela Lundbeck Fraser and Craig McAllister were married in New York yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Morrison Fraser Jr. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth McAllister of Hilton Head, S.C. The Rev. Thomas Bowers of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Union Club.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The 10 Categories Of Educational Handicaps
description: Following are the categories now used in New Jersey to identify children with educational handicaps:

title: A New Haven Public School Where Pride Is Being Restored
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Chilean Folk Group Sings in a Tribute
description: It's about time somebody did some irrelevant material, the folk singer Steve Goodman remarked shortly before intermission at Friday night's Tribute to Victor Jara. And it was. The concert was organized by the National Chile Center, the Chile Committee for Human Rights and Chile Democranco and dedicated to Mr. Jara, who was the leading songwriter of the Chilean new song movement before his death in 1973 at the hands of the country's military junta.

title: Chrysler Tries to Take a New Tack
