The death sentence was commuted to life imprisonment by the President and in July, Mr. KarliBond was pardoned and released.

title: Islam's Law in Iran, With Death to the Transgressor
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 6  The graybearded mullah works in a partitionedoff corner, signing documents and stamping them with a seal as he talks on the telephone.

title: Fire Kills Woman and 4 Children
description: LEBANON, Ky., March 6 (AP)  A fire raced through a home in Marion County early today, killing a woman and four children, Tommy Smith, a state police investigator, said. The father and a fifth child survived. Mr. Smith identified the victims as Mary Ann Rice, 30 years old, and Richard, 6; Scott, 5; Keith, 2, and Gwynn, 6 months. Surviving was the father, Dennis Rice, and a 9yearold son, Todd.

title: After Thunderous Start, It's a Slow Wet Day
description: Heavy rains yesterday caused minor flooding, scattered power failures; hazardous driving conditions and delays for rail commuters coming into and leaving New York City. The storm, which was accompanied in the early morning by blasts of thunder and flashes of lightning, continued throughout the day, and by 10 P.M. had left 2.41 inches of rain, the National Weather Service said.

title: Argentine Costs Up
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 6 (AP) The cost of living in Argentina rose 7.4 percent in February, the Economy Ministry has reported. The increase, led by rises in the cost of food, medical care and school supplies, put the consumer price index at 20,267.5 compared with 100 in the base year 1974. The index has risen 171.6 percent in the last 12 months. The ministry's report, released last evening, put inflation in the first two months of the year at 21.2 percent and was expected to give new impetus to demands by labor unions seeking wage increases.

title: Citibank Differs On Zaire Loans
description: Testimony before a Congressional committee indicating that Citibank's outstanding loans to the Government of Zaire amounted to twothirds of the total $377 million owed to American banks there greatly overstated the value of those loans, according to Citibank.

title: Blind Get Tips on Filing Taxes
description: Searching hands dug into battered envelopes for the year's receipts, later finding the place to make painstaking signatures between metal guide bars, as blind and nearly blind men and women got help with their incometax returns yesterday.

title: TV: Lonigan on NBC
description: TONIGHT at 9, and for the next two Wednesdays at the same time, NBC 's Novel for Television series is presenting a Reginald Rose adaptation of Studs Lonigan, the acclaimed trilogy by James T. Farrell.

title: FUEL SHORTAGE CUTS FLIGHTS BY UNITED
description: United Airlines, the nation's largest air carrier, said yesterday that it was can celing 429 flights a week for the rest of March because of a jetfuel shortage that it attributed in large measure to the curtailment of oil exports from Iran.

title: John H. Knowles, Leading Medical Figure, Dies at 52
description: Dr. John H. Knowles, the president of the Rockefeller Foundation for the last seven years and an international medical leader, died yesterday at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. His death, at the age of 52, was due to cancer of the pancreas. Dr. Knowles lived in New York City and maintained residences in Massachusetts.

title: Manna From Morocco: Couscous and Spices
description: PEOPLE of taste who dote on Moroccan cooking tend to find it among the most sensual foods on earth. It is without question one of the world's 10 great cuisines. A steaming platter of perfectly ordained couscous, to some palates, is about as close as one need come to feasting on heavenly manna.

title: 4 IN A CULT IN UTAH ON TRIAL IN SLAYING
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 6  The murder trial of four members of a polygamous cult opened here today. The four are followers of Ervil Morel LeBaron, leader of the Church of the Lamb of God, who investigators believe has instigated 20 to 29 murders in Utah, California and Mexico since 1972.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Barnes Engineering Company, Stamford, Conn., a manufacturer of infrared electrooptical systems, has elected to its board of directors Millard H. Pryor Jr., president and chief executive officer of Lydall Inc., a diversified manufacturer.

title: Little Detroit of Italy Faces Labor Problems
description: POMIGLIANO d'ARCO, Italy This motor town, in the flatland east of Naples, with Mount Vesuvius as the dramatic backdrop, has sometimes been called a little Detroit. Right now it is in deep trouble.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Deaths

title: William Valentine, 64
description: William R. Valentine Jr., regional director of the Federal Office for Civil Rights, died of a heart attack Saturday while attending a conference in Denver. He was 64 years old.

title: The Wrong Cure for MitchellLama
description: MitchellLama housing projects, built with New York State and City dollars and largely exempt from real estate taxes, provide good apartment homes for 150,000 middleincome families. But for all other taxpayers, they are an immense headache; the rent does not cover payments on the money borrowed to build them. Governor Carey has asked the Legislature enact a cure. Though it contains some good medicine, his proposal is expensive and habitforming. And it violates a basic tenet of housing finance by offering subsidies to people who have not proved they need them.

title: Where Family Bars Thrive; Family Bars: Where They Still Thrive
description: IT was a typical Sunday at the Galtymore House. At one end of the room, John Doran and his wife, Barbara, were talking with friends about the baby they were expecting any day now. Nearby, two customers were arguing, briefly, over the odds at the track, then, at greater length, about the relative merit of serving mint jelly with lamb. In the back, small crowd played darts.

title: A Nutritionist Assails TV's Ads On Sweets as a Danger to Teeth
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  A leading nutritionist told the Federal Trade Commission today that, among all the food products sold through television advertising directed at children, candy, cookies and presweetened breakfast cereals were the most likely to cause tooth decay.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: JOHN W. TIERNAN

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Regains Ground In New York Trading
description: The dollar scored some late gains in foreign exchange trading in New York yesterday after moving lower earlier in the day on currency markets in Japan and Europe.

title: Gamble Gets a Texas Welcome
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 6 In one corner of the Texas clubhouse, Dock Ellis and Sparky Lyle. Directly across from them, Oscar Gamble. At the other end, Jim Kern. If the Yankees have had the most turbulent clubhouse the last two years, the Rangers this year could have the zaniest.

title: 10 Killed in Turkish Gun Battle
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 6 (Reuters)  Ten people were killed and many wounded when two tribes in the southeastern Turkish town of Siverek fought a gunbattle over a woman yesterday, the Anatolian News Agency said today.

title: Koch Aide to Urge Hiring Striking SchoolBus Drivers
description: The Mayor's director of labor relations intends to ask successful bidders for next year's schoolbus transportion contracts to hire many of the drivers now engaged in a wildcat strike.

title: Rockets 119, Nuggets 118
description: DENVER, March 6 (AP)  Houston's Moses Malone blocked George McGinnis's shot as the final horn sounded tonight, preserving a 119118 victory for the Rockets.

title: Naming the Baby: Encratis Won't Do
description: OUR second child isn't due until June, but my wife and I are already sweating out what to name her, or him, depending. I know there are parents who never give the matter much thought, who whip up something on the spur of the moment in the delivery room, and I admire their serenity. But I suspect theyre the same parents who wind up naming their children after Walter Lantz characters and talk show hosts, or burden their offspring with handles like Iona Dodge and Sissy Rider.

title: New 42d Street Stable to Bring More Mounted Police to Midtown
description: Sgt. Thomas Keefe. left, and Detective John Thomas Farrel showing respective mounts. McDonald and Nolan, Their new home  a converted parking garage at 625 West 42d Street. The new stable, strongly supported by theater organizations, will save mounted division 10.000 man??

title: U.S. Expresses Regret
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 The United States is greatly saddened at the loss of life in Chad, the State Department said today.

title: Market Place
description: SOURCE CAPITAL INC., a closedend investment company, has enjoyed considerable success in recent years, primarily because it has avoided the overpriced darlings of the stock market.

title: U.S. Officials Discouraged
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  State Department officials vowed today to continue working for a United Nations solution in SouthWest Africa, but they said privately that they were deeply discouraged by South Africa's rejection of the cease fire.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: At a recent fashion show, all the hats were made cf fresh flowers. It's an idea that can easily verge on the silly. But in the hands of Renny Reynolds, a clever New York florist, they were surprisingly charming. We particularly liked the model whose long hair was twined with smilax and stephanotis, a suggestion for a spring bride to wear instead of the usual veil. Mr. Reynolds would like to discuss the arrangement with the bride two weeks before the wedding. On the big day, he will work with her hairdresser, arranging the flowers to suit her coiffure. The charge is $55 to $65, depending on the complexity of the headdress. Renny's fresh flower hats start at $55 and go up to $150, if expensive flowers such as orchids are used. The shop is at 27 East 62d Street; telephone is 3715354.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Milk Dealers Study Revised Proposals
description: Negotiators for the striking New York teamsters in the milk industry presented revised proposals to the dairy companies yesterday in the first facetoface bargaining talks since the strike began Feb. 24.

title: WASHINGTON Carter's Major Question
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  On the two major and highly complicated foreign policy problems now facing the United States  the control of strategic arms, and accommodation between Israel and Egypt  President Carter is asking a simple human question: Would the world be better off with an inadequate compromise on both issues or with no agreement at all?

title: Drama Fills Hartford Hearing on Monies No Concrete Answers Given
description: HARTFORD, March 7  Carolyn Helander's voice began to crack and tears fell as she sat before a microphone in a small, overheated hearing room at the State Capitol today.

title: Illinois Governor Asks A Ceiling on Spending And on Property Levy
description: SPRINGFIELD, III., March 7  Gov. James R. Thompson asked the General Assembly today to impose ceilings on state spending and on local property taxes in Illinois.

title: Snoopy Stirs a Court Tempest
description: It's hard to assess me political impact of an unauthorized endorsement by an imaginary dog, but when Assemblyman Armand P. D'Amato circulated campaign buttons and posters coupling the phrase You're a good man D'Amato with a likeness of the Peanuts comic strip character Snoopy, he got more than votes.

title: Municipal Bond Yields Level Off
description: Yields on topquality taxexempt bonds leveled off yesterday after rising for four straight weeks. But rates on housing bolds kept climbing. Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds were tentatively priced to yield as much as 8.675 percent.

title: Union Sq. Plan: A Fresh Image For a Soapbox
description: There are almost no soapbox orators in Union Square anymore. The park benches that were once witness to the activities of Mensheviks. Bolsheviks and Trotskyites have now been taken up by community planners concerned with cleaning the subway stop, rerouting traffic around the park and opening a restaurant within it.

title: Radio and TV to Broadcast Segovia From White House
description: A concert by Andres Segovia this Sunday in the White House will be broadcast live to WNYCFM and about 200 stations by National Public Radio starting at 4 P.M.

title: Billy Carter a Patient at Alcohol Rehabilitation Center
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 7  Billy Carter, President Carter's brother, today began a program of group therapy sessions at the Long Beach Naval Regional Medical Center that are designed to help patients end their dependency on alcohol.

title: 1,770 Students Accepted In Error at Stony Brook
description: As many as 1,770 applicants who sought admission to the State University College at Stony Brook, L.I., for the fall term received premature notices of acceptance from the college because of what was described as human error, a school official said yesterday.

title: West German Is Jailed by East
description: EAST BERLIN, March 7 (Reuters) A West German, KlausDieter Harms of Hamburg, was jailed for eight years today for smuggling East Germans to the West in his car, the official East German press agency reported.

title: Film:'The Promise,' 2 Lovers
description: "THE Promise" is about Michael, a student architect, and Nancy, a painter of great feeling whose style is both vague and familiar. You could put one of her works in any motel room and not even miss it. Michael and Nancy are young, beautiful and in love. Theirs is a mystical sort of union. When they walk along the Massachusetts coast, the scenery is Monterey's. Michael and Nancy have their whole lives ahead of them except for one thing, Michael's mother, the possessive, ambitious Marion.When Michael announces that he is going to marry Nancy, Marion becomes very frosty. She reveals that Nancy was raised "by a passel of nuns," that her mother was an alcoholic and that her father was killed while serving a seven-year jail term for armed robbery. But Michael, who is headstrong as well as rich, will not give up Nancy. He sweeps her off to a justice of the peace. En route, however, they have a ghastly automobile accident.Michael remains unconscious for several days but he is unscarred except for a tiny red line on his forehead that looks like an angel's doodle. Poor Nancy suffers a face so badly smashed that  we are led to believe  toads would turn from her.While she lies in her hospital bed, Nancy is visited by the possessive, ambitious Marion, who offers to pay for Nancy's repair work if Nancy promises never to see Michael again. Nancy agrees. After all, she reasons, she looks such a mess that she has lost Michael anyway. Or has she?The absolutely dry-eyed answer to that question can be found at the Radio City Music Hall, where "The Promise" opens today, probably the last film to play the house under its long-time film-and-stage show policy.I assure you that, though I seem to have relayed a great deal of the plot of "The Promise," there's a lot more where that comes from. My synopsis describes no more than the first 20 to 25 minutes. It's impossible to talk about films like "The Promise" without going into the plots, because they're not really about anything else. This screenplay, which recalls bits and pieces of many other, better films ("A Woman's Face," "Love Story," "Love Affair," "An Affair to Remember," among them), was written by Garry Michael White and directed by Gilbert Cates ("I Never Sang for My Father," "Summer Wishes, Winter Dreams"), who knows better but pretends not to.The members of the cast are undercut by both material and direction. As Marion, Beatrice Straight, who won an Oscar for "Network," is playing a character more at home in daytime television than movie theaters. Kathleen Quinlan, nominated for an Oscar for her extraordinary performance in "I Never Promised You a Rose Garden" and who is now at the Public Theater in "Taken in Marriage," is shortstopped not only by ridiculous lines but also by makeup that gives her the plastic look of a face-lift even before the accident so (I assume) she'll look fairly normal later. Under the various masks that have been imposed on her, there's a recognizable intelligence struggling toward the light.Stephen Collins, who plays Michael, is too idiosyncratic an actor to be overwhelmed by this sort of junk. Though he has the looks and stature of a leading man, he also has the unexpected abilities one associates with a fine, seasoned character actor, as he demonstrated in "All the President's Men" and "Between the Lines." He and Miss Quinlan survive "The Promise" in the only way possible  by playing it straight."The Promise," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains nothing at all, including anything that might be thought obscene or suggestive.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: BACKERS OF REAGAN OPEN HIS CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  Ronald Reagan's supporters launched his Presidential campaign today with the formation of a campaign committee that includes four of former President Gerald R. Ford's Cabinet among its 365 members.

title: Prices Found Rising in the South Faster Than in Rest of the Nation
description: ATLANTA, March 7  A new analysis of regional living costs shows that consumer prices are increasing faster in the South than in any other part of the country.

title: Jewish Groups Split Over Lawsuit on Racial Quotas in Employment
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  Jewish groups that have vigorously opposed racial quotas in higher education have split among themselves over their response to a lawsuit that challenges such quotas in employment.

title: Macchiarola Asserts Bidding Will Cut Cost Of Busing of Disabled
description: School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola announced yesterday that schoolbus transportation costs for 32,000 handicapped children would be much reduced over the next three years as a result of the school system's first competitive bidding on bus contracts in eight years.

title: Dow Up 7.71 as Volume Climbs
description: Stock prices moved briskly higher yesterday as gambling and bluechip issues joined with takeover situations in the advance. More than 1,000 issues rose on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: F.D.A. to Allow Saccharin Sales For Year After Moratorium Ends
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)  Saccharin will be allowed to stay on the market for at least a year after the Congressional moratorium on banning it expires in May, a spokesman for the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: Notes on People
description: Margaret Trudeau has carved out a new life for herself in good part by publicly dissecting her old life, and now she's provided extra slices for mass consumption. Deciding what to make of them, however, is not so easy. There she was, the estranged wife of Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau, liberally offering divergent views of her husband for two British mass circulation newspapers and an American magazine.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Death

title: About Nyack
description: NYACK, N.Y., March 5  Daylight slashed briefly into the Nyack Lounge as an arriving customer closed the door, restoring the special fumy warmth and dingy comfort of a neighborhood bar in its afternoon cycle of serenity. Every neighborhood has its nabes  humble, darkly reliable taverns that dress up a man's spirit like old clothes and let him stare Byronically into a glass.

title: NEW EGYPTIAN ROLE ENVISAGED BY SADAT
description: CAIRO, March 7  Egypt, which President Carter visits tomorrow, is pictured by its leader, Anwar elSadat, as a nation that can assume a significant role in protecting the Middle East from the rising threat of instability.

title: TV: Scared Straight, Documentary
description: IN Scared Straight, an hourlong documentary on WNEW/ Channel 5 at 10 tonight, several convicts confront some juvenile offenders in an attempt to scare the crime right out of these kids. The convicts are real, serving life terms at New Jersey's Rahway State Prison. The juveniles are real, brought in from various correctional centers. The confrontation is searing.

title: The Region
description: Yonkers firemen, angry at stalled contract negotiations, staged a surprise, onehour walkout last night, leaving the state's fourth largest city with virtually no fire protection from 8:45 to 9:45. There were no fires reported during the walkout, according to fire officials, but the head of the firemen's union said a number of false alarms were not answered.

title: The Job of Summer Jobs
description: Armed with a negative appraisal of the Labor Department's $750million summer jobs program for poor youths, Lawton Chiles and other Senate critics of the program are threatening to cut this year's funding by 25 percent. Their concern is understandable; their remedy is not. There is no question that the summer jobs effort, now in its 14th year, can stand improvement. But there should be no doubt of its enduring worth.

title: Lazard, Stung by Koch, Ends M.A.C. Role
description: Lazard Frres & Company, the investment banking concern in which Felix G. Rohatyn is a partner, withdrew yesterday as financial adviser to the Municipal Assistance Corporation because, Lazard said, Mayor Koch had impugned its integrity.

title: Market Place
description: THE Japanese, who have aggressively marketed consumer goods in the United States, have shown little desire to enter this country's corporate takeover wars. Now that the dollar is stabililzing relative to the yen, however, some analysts believe the Japanese will find American companies increasingly tempting.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Deaths.

title: School Drug Use Called Extensive
description: NEWARK, March 7  An Essex County grand jury today reported that the use of marijuana, cocaine, Quaaludes and other drugs had increased sharply in schools across the county and that even youngsters in the fourth and fifth grades were using many of the drugs.

title: Talking Business with Kelmenson of Kenyon &
description: The advertising and auto industries were rocked by the news last Friday that Lee A. Iacocca, ousted as president of the Ford Motor Company and now president of the Chrysler Corporation, was pulling some $120 million in Chrysler, Plymouth and Dodge auto and truck advertising out of three ad agencies that have had the business for years, and was assigning it all to Kenyon & Eckhardt Inc., a Ford agency for 34 years.

title: Pakistan's High Court Asks Bhutto Defense To Expand on Its Case
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 7  A deeply divided Supreme Court called today for further argument on a defense plea to commute the death sentence imposed on Zulfikar Ali Bhutto in connection with a 1974 political murder.

title: U.S Highway Beautification Program Is in Trouble
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)  Along the nation's interstate and primary highways there are 197,791 signs and billboards that the Government would like to get rid of and 10,608 junkyards it would like to see screened. But some states are not cooperating and, even if they did, the Federal Government does not have the money to pay for the removal.

title: Koch Puts Off Closing of 5 Clinics
description: Responding to opposition from municipal physicians and health officers as well as a national civilrights organization, Mayor Koch yesterday postponed until July 1 the scheduled March 16 closing of five city clinics at which 50,000 teenagers can get free physical examinations required for summer working papers.

title: U.S. Military Support for Thailand Symbolic Rather Than Substantive
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 7 Each morning, in a huge creamcolored compound on Sathorn Road in downtown Bangkok, the flags of the United States and Thailand are raised together to symbolize the commitment of both nations to the defense of Thai soil.

title: Funding of Abortions By Medicaid Declines, Califano Tells Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)  The number of abortions financed under the Medicaid program dropped sharply last year as tighter restrictions on payments were put into force, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A. Califano Jr. said today.

title: Israel Bars a Khomeini Street
description: TEL AVIV, March 7 (Reuters)  Israel's military governor in the occupied West Bank ordered the Mayor of Kalkilia this week to reverse a decision to name throughfare Khomeini Street, in honor of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran.

title: Malaysian Center Working to Save the Orangutan
description: SANDAKAN, Malaysia  Saving an endangered species may not have been part of the original script for Peace Corps volunteers, but Arthur H. Mitchell, who is 27 years old, tall, bearded and serious, has found helping to save the orangutan more satisfying than teaching general science to Borneo youngsters  and more important as well.

title: ABROAD AT HOME The Risks Of Peace
description: BOSTON, March 7  The drama of President Carter's trip, however it turns out, makes clear how extraordinarily personal the diplomacy of the Middle East has become. The search for peace between Israel and Egypt, over the last eighteen months, has turned largely on the personalities of Anwar Sadat, Menachem Begin and Jimmy Carter.

title: EARNINGS CocaCola Profits Up 14% in Fourth Quarter
description: The CocaCola Company, the world's largest softdrink maker, said yesterday that its profits in the fourth quarter rose 14 percent, while earnings for the year jumped 19.4 percent.

title: First TeasebyTV Ad Campaign?; It's Not About China
description: LOS ANGELES, March 7 What one Columbia executive calls the first teasebytelevision campaign in movie history has begun.

title: 3 Airlines Seek Fare Increases
description: Three of the nation's largest air carriers, American Airlines, Trans World Airlines and United Air Lines, asked Government permission yesterday to raise all fares on May 15, and warned that additional increases might soon be needed because of soaring jetfuel prices.

title: PRESIDENT SETS OFF ON MIDEAST MISSION, CAUTIOUSLY HOPEFUL
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  President Carter, described by aides as optimistic but still uncertain about his prospects for resolving the differences between Israel and Egypt, set off this evening on a personal peacemaking mission to the Middle East

title: Home Improvement
description: THE success of many wood or furniture refinishing jobs depends on completely removing the old finish before applying the new one. This also holds true with many paint jobs where the surface is covered with layers of old paint that is badly cracked or alligatored. In these cases stripping off all of the old paint is often required so that the new finish will not crack or peel, and will be smooth and even in appearance.

title: Carey Proposes Plan to Aid Brooklyn Jewish Hospital
description: ALBANY, March 7  Governor Carey today proposed a plan that would provide the bankrupt Brooklyn Jewish Hospital with extra state help to keep the facility open.

title: OilPricing Guilty Plea Aids Inquiry
description: A wealthy Texas oilman, Albert B. Alkek, pleaded guilty in Houston yesterday to charges of concealing oilpricing schemes. He agreed, as part of his plea, to refund $3.2 million to the Government.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: FRANKLIN M. DOOLITTLE

title: More Couples Adopting Victims of Genetic Defect
description: The social worker told Janet and Louis Marchese that she had an emergency. A baby had been born with Down's syndrome, or Mongolism, and his parents did not want him. Would they take in the baby temporarily, the social worker pleaded, until a permanent home could be found?

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE MUSIC MEN Since 1965, when Jazz at Noon was organized, 150 doctors, lawyers, teachers and executives in advertising and public relations and other business figures have played at informal sessions during lunch at various midtown spots. The Jam at Noon unit now holds forth Fridays during lunch at StoryTowne, the music club at 41 East 58th Street, with 100 diners usually in attendance.

title: COMMODITIES Silver Prices Off Sharply, Reflecting Gold Concern
description: Another wave of selling hit silver fu tures yesterday on the Commodity Exchahere, erasing Tuesday's gains in move similar to the big losses recorded Monday. Prices at the end of trading w ere off 19 cents in most positions, barel v above the daily limit of 20 cents.

title: ExCORE Leader Injured in Crash
description: DURHAM, N.C., March 7 (AP) Floyd McKissick, former national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, was listed in stable condition today after surgery for injuries received in an automobile accident, the authorities said. The police said the accident occured last night on Interstate 85 about four miles north of Durham. The 56yearold civil rights leader was pinned in his car for about 45 minutes after it went off a bridge and landed on a road below.

title: Iranian Komiteti Has Final Say Over Oranges, Brothels and Life
description: ABADAN, Iran, March 6  People walk up to the whitewashed building and stop at the small iron gate that leads into the courtyard of Police Station 2. which is now in the hands of the armed men from the Islamic Revolutinary Committee of Abadan, or the Komiteh, as it is known here.

title: S.E.C. Simplifying Funds Ad Rules
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a proposal designed to simplify the agency's rules governing mutual fund advertising.

title: Dolly Parton's City Place
description: IT was dusk as Dolly Parton stared from the window of her new apartment high above Fifth Avenue, talking in a flat twang about how the big city skyscrapers put her in mind of the mountains of Tennessee. Like mountains with lights on them . . . See down there? She pointed to Central Park in the snow. It's like country.

title: U.S. Bond. Prices Up By  Point
description: The credit markets, supported by what some dealers described as fairly decent demand for bonds from investors, rose moderately in price yesterday. Government and corporate bonds rose as much as a quarterpoint.

title: Nostalgia Comes To Garden Furniture
description: THIS spring, when New Yorkers take to their terraces, city gardens or country homes, they might find themselves in a Proustian frame of mind. Curved wooden deck chairs, ornate love seats. Parisian cafe tables and Swedishbenches will recall memories of pleinair romances of springs and summers past. Nostalgic images of transAtlantic ocean passages, croquet on a Hertfordshire lawn or an afternoon drink at the Cafe Fiore  will all vividly be brought to life by this season's crop of new /old outdoor furniture.

title: Trudeau Party Now Leads Poll
description: TORONTO, March 7 (Reuters)Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's governing Liberal Party, facing imminent general elections, has edged ahead of the opposition Progressive Conservatives for the first time since October, according to a Gallup Poll published today

title: CITY PUPILS REMAIN BEHIND IN READING
description: Nearly six out of ten pupils in New York City's public elementary and junior high schools continue to read below the national standard for their grade, according to readingtest scores released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: Francis B. Molloy, ExManager Of The Times Photo Laboratory
description: Francis B. Molloy, who retired in 1976 as manager of The New York Times's photography laboratory, died Saturday at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 68 years old and lived in New Hyde Park. L.I.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: STORAGE units can be expensive to buy or construct. But heavy cardboard and fiberboard storage units offer a cheap alternative to drawers, files and bins made of wood, plastic or metal. Though not very attractive, cardboard units are well suited for situations where unobtrusive storage is needed.

title: Periplaneta
description: LEEDS, England  I withdrew my patronge from what had been a favorite restaurant when I heard that a cockroach had plopped from the ceiling into a diner's minestrone. The story may well have been pure fiction  malicious legends do tend to get spread around about successful eateries  but I couldn't take the chance. If I'd seen bats flitting around the kitchen, I might have retained the place as my supping venue. But roaches were altogether too shuddersome to contemplate. It's an allergy I share with most people.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Little Rise Seen in Gas Supply
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)  The decision by Congress to lift price controls from natural gas is a gamble that has not yet paid off despite sharply rising consumer prices, the nation's top Federal energy regulator said today.

title: Rodney Adair, 57, Vice President Of a ContainerLeasing Company
description: Rodney P. Adair, vice president for finance of Interpool Ltd. of New York, an international containerleasing company, died of lung cancer Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 57 years old.

title: Cooper Offer Oversubscribed
description: Cooper Industries said that in response to its offer to buy up to 8.6 million common shares of the GardnerDenver Company at $33 a share, it had received tenders for more than 14.7 million shares before the expiration date on Tuesday.

title: Advertising
description: IN a sevenminute sales film created by Case & McGrath for National Distillers, a monk at a festive fete says with a heavy German accent: Before long that blue nun is going to be black and blue.

title: City Hall Lowers Lighting and Raises Tempers
description: The consensus in City Hall this week is that those who liked the blackout of 1977 will love the building's new lighting plan.

title: Dayan Says Treaty Is Near if Sadat Supports Proposals
description: JERUSALEM, March 7  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan said today that an IsraeliEgyptian peace treaty was imminent if President Anwar elSadat of Egypt approved the proposals worked out by President Carter and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel in Washington a few days ago.

title: Khomeini Terms Cabinet Weak, Too Westernized
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 7 (AP)Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who led the. revolution that toppled Shah Mo. lammed Rise Pahlevi, criticized Iran's provisional Government today, calling its ministers weak and deriding them for beliming that everthing should be copied from the West.

title: Begin Tells U.S. Jews His Visit Was Success
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin received an ovation here yesterday when he told more than 2,000 members of American Jewish organizations: Sisters and brothers, I bring you good tidings. Our visit to Washington has been successful.

title: Wilson, Giles Voted Into Hall
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 7 (UPI) Lewis (Hack) Wilson, an awesome slugger whose life had been troubled by drinking, was voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame today with Warren C. Giles, for 50 years a model of decorum and executive ability.

title: Word of a Hurried Meeting in Paris Inflames a South African Scandal
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 7  What were two of South Africa's bestknown men doing in a Paris hotel yesterday, and what could it mean for the future of the nation?

title: George Bamberger, the Brewers Ph.D. in Pitching
description: SUN CITY, Ariz.  George Bamberger had been summoned to Milwaukee early last year by Harry Dalton to discuss managing the Brewers and he was sitting in the general manager's office when Allan (Bud) Selig, the Brewers owner, walked in.

title: Vietnam Charges Chinese Continue Barbarous Acts
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 7  Vietnam charged today that Chinese troops were continuing barbarous acts of war despite Peking's announcement two days ago that it was withdrawing its troops from Vietnam.

title: New Method Sought For TV Rating System
description: Sentiment is growing at the television networks, major advertising agencies and Hollywood production companies to alter the system of audience ratings that causes highpowered programs to be concentrated in three months of the year: November, February and May.

title: CTI in Accord to Build Container Plant in China
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 7  CTI Container Transport. International, a major container leasing company, said today that it has signed a $125 million agreement with China to build that nation's first marine container factory in Canton. A similar pact for a plant in Tianjin is expected to be completed in several weeks.

title: Newspaper Drivers Set Deadline In Bargaining With Wholesalers
description: Douglas LaChance, the head of the newspaper deliverers union, last night set a March 31 strike deadline against 16 wholesalers that distribute much of the circulation of New York City's three major dailies.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Europe's Monetary Plans Drive Dollar Lower
description: Worries over a realignment of European currencies and over the price of oil drove the dollar lower on foreign exchange markets in Europe and New York yesterday after the United States currency had posted early gains in Tokyo.

title: Boos Greet Landlords' Plea For Rent Rise, Fuel Charge
description: Over the boos, clapping, catcalls and chairthumping of some of the 200 tenants in attendance, the owners of rentstabilized apartments in New York City yesterday formally recommended that rent limits be raised substantially and that landlords be permitted to charge tenants 33 additional per room a month to cover rising fuel costs.

title: China Showing Interest in Buying U.S. Warplanes
description: HONG KONG, March 7  China has quietly expressed interest in buying American military planes and associated technology, and may make a foruial request to Washington within a few months, knowledgeable sources in the aircraft industry have disclosed.

title: Talks Called Off By Union Chief In Milk Walkout
description: William Whelan, leader of the striking milk industry workers, broke off negotiations with metropolitan area dealers late yesterday and abruptly left a mediation session following management's rejection of revised union demands.

title: Home Run Cost Wilson a $500 Fine
description: MARTINSBURG, W. Va.  Lewis R. (Hack) Wilson was born in Ellwood City, Pa., April 14, 1900. After the death of his mother, when he was just a baby, his father took him to Chester. Pa., where they lived until Hack was 16 years old. Then they moved to a boarding house in Leiperville, Pa. Hack's older sister stayed in Chester, where she died some years later.

title: Yanks Plan To Wait on Contracts
description: The Yankees, who have played the free agent game better than any other team, could lose a fifth or more of their team to free agency at the end of this season. If they do, though, they plan to do it in the same calculated and astute way they have gained other teams free agents.

title: Two Carter Aides Defend Rhodesia Policy to Senators
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  Two high Administration officials concerned with Africa tried today to halt an erosion of Congressional support for President Carter's Rhodesian policy.

title: Rider Still Uncertain For Spectacular Bid
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 7 Despite his errorfilled ride aboard the victorious Spectacular Hid in yesterday's Florida Derby, 10yearold Ron Franklin was still the colt's regular jockey as of tonight.

title: Give the Guideposts a Chance
description: There are actually those who want President Carter's wage and price guideposts to fail. Some think voluntary controls cannot contain inflation and the nation needs mandatory restraints fast. Others are so fearful of mandatory controls that they want the Administration to concede that any controls are bad. But the President's fourmonth campaign against inflation is not a failure  not yet, at least. The awesome rise food prices, which helped produce doubledigit inflation in January, was not a fair test of the program. Also misleading is the unexpected jump in oil prices caused by disruption in Iran.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Your Feb. 25 editorial Paying for Oil is indicative of the fallacy so prevalent in our thinking on energy matters.

title: Time Bombs Placed on 3 Buses in Jerusalem
description: TEL AVIV, March 7  Three Arabowned tourist buses operating out of Jerusalem this morning had time bombs hidden on board,

title: How New Linkup Works
description: Introduction of the European NIor.etary System is an attempt to expand to eight from five the number of European nations determined to create a stable relationship among their respective currencies.

title: Changes Sought In Trade Pact
description: GENEVA, March 7  Common Market negotiators said today that they would be seeking a better agreement on farm products in the final drive to bring the world trade talks to a successful conclusion next month.

title: LIBYA SENDS UGANDA TONS OF WEAPONS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 7 (AP) Libya was sending tons of military equipment to Uganda as President Idi Amin took command of his armies today in preparation for a promised counterattack against invading Tanzanians and Ugandan exi:es, diplomats and the Ugandan radio reported.

title: Ballet. Nureyev Dances Petrouchka
description: THE Joffrey Ballet, with Rudolf Nureyev as guest artist, opened last night at the Mark Hellinger theater for a fourweek run in a program that will be repeated every night, entitled Homage to Diaghilev.

title: 3 Colleges Advance on Late Goals
description: Boston University, New Hampshire, Cornell and Dartmouth advanced, as expected, into the semifinals of the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference hockey tournament Tuesday night. But only New Hampshire did it smoothly.

title: 2 Restaurants Added To Michelin's Top List
description: PARIS, March 5  This year's Guide Michelin, the bible of French gourmets, is adding two restaurants to its threestar list: Boyer of Reims in Champagne and Lameloise of Chagny in Burgundy.

title: Puerto Rican Terrorist Seeking Exemption From Trial as P.O.W.
description: A lawyer for William G. Morales, Puerto Rican terrorist, asked a State Supreme Court jury in Queens yesterday to classify his Puerto Rican freedom fighter client, as a prisoner of war, and thereby exempt him from the jurisdiction of state courts on weapons and explosive charges.

title: U.S. Submarine Drags a Trawler Through Seas Off West Scotland
description: LONDON. March 7 (AP)  A fishing trawler got its nets entangled with a submerged United States nuclear submarine off western Scotland today and was dragged through the water for about 45 minutes, the British Coast Guard and United States Navy reported.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: AFORD FOUNDATION official recently called Charles E. Silberman's study of crime in America, Criminal Violence, Criminal Justice, seminal, but a book doesn't have to shoulder all of that burden to justify the $540.000 that the foundation invested in research for the project. In a field as beset by emotion, mythology and fear as crime is, honest reporting, earnest analysis and honorable speculation can surely serve the republic well, and that is what this book does  and more.

title: A PLAN ON UNIFYING CLERGY IS ENDORSED
description: CINCINNATI, March 7  A proposal that could soon pave the way for a common ordained clergy among 10 of the nation's largest Protestant denominations was received enthusiastically today by many delegates from the participating churches who are meeting here.

title: City Hospitals Told to Be Friendlier
description: The head of the city's municipal hospital system is undertaking what he calls a behavior modification program aimed at better grooming for staff and hospital workers and increased politeness and responsiveness to patients.

title: I.M.F. Leaders See Growth Lag
description: WASHINGTON. March 7  Higher oil prices and rampant inflation are pushing the world into an extended period of slow economic growth with slim chances of reducing still high unemployment.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Julian Goodman, a champion of freedom in broadcasting, is signing off the air  at least for the current season. Mr. Goodman, the 56yearold chairman of the executive committee of the National Broadcasting Company, has elected to retire on May 31 when his present contract expires.

title: jersey Ruling Broadens Warranties for Homeowners
description: Builders are coming under increasing consumer pressure to provide purchasers with reasonably habitable homes.

title: Further Ethanol Price Rise
description: Publicker Industries, which announced on Feb. 28 a 6centagallon price increase for ethanol, an alcohol, effective April I, said yesterday that it would raise the price by a further 3 cents, for a total increase of 10 cents, because of a new round of price increases by ethylene suppliers. Its new prices will be $1.285 a gallon for 190 proof and $1.385 a gallon for 200 proof.

title: Calculating the Savings
description: Calculating energy savings and the payback period for a solarassisted hot water system is very complex because it involves many variables, including a system's efficiency, location, utility rates and even a homeowner's income tax bracket.

title: Senate Rejects, 5738, A Move to Strengthen U.S. Links to Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  The Senate today rejected a proposal by conservative members to raise the formal United States presence in Taiwan to the level of a liaison office, more than President Carter and the Chinese Government in Peking had agreed on

title: Hershey Debentures Sell Fast
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation yesterday sold $75 million of debentures that were priced to yield almost 9.54 percent, the highest rate of return on new mediumgrade industrialcorn pony bond issue since 1974. Investors gobbled them up as if they were milk chocolate bars.

title: 3 EXPERTS IDENTIFY HUGE SPIRAL GALAXY
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)  Astronomers have identified a giant spiral galaxy of billions of stars that they say is the largest, most massive so far sighted in the universe.

title: A TreasureTrove Of Jukeboxes
description: THE year was 1945 and in most watering holes from New York to California, the Glenn Miller orchestra was beating out the rhythms of Tuxedo Junction, I've Got a Gal in Kalamazoo and Elmer's Tune, all on coinoperated wonder of the day  the bubbling Wurlitzer 1080 jukebox. The Wurlitzer had been the rage since 1937. when the first model appeared with its brightly colored lights and floating bubblesan effect obtained simply by floating a liquid solution through a plastic encasement. Unfortunately, the bubbles started to burst  in most cases from rough treatment in public bars  and in 1946 the bubbling jukebox was banned. It was soon worthless, often seen discarded in empty lots. But in this Retro Age, when everything that was out is back in, the Wurlitzer bubbling jukebox is especially cherished  this time in the gentler confines of homes and executive offices, as a collector's item. And Alan Luchnick, owner of Back Pages Antiques at 389 Second Avenue (near 22d Street), has traveled across the United States, picking up any model in any condition for his clients (including one of the Beatles).

title: Disks: Mozart by Alicia de Larrocha
description: THIS is not a pairing of artists that leaps instantly to mind when the question of ideal Mozart collaborators is raised. The Solti approach to music can often be more muscular and broad than Mozart requires, while Miss de Larrocha goes in the opposite direction, toward understatement and patrician restraint. But so much for expectations: The fact is that you will look a long time to find more enthralling recorded performances of these two concertos.

title: Top Aide at Pentagon Is Quitting in Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  A major Carter Administration effort to reorganize the Pentagon has been jolted by the abrupt resignation of the Defense Department's thirdranking official, who had clashed with the Pentagon's powerful bureaucracy.

title: A Quarrel Over Architecture
description: EARLIER this week, with virtually no fanfare, the Museum of Modern Art opened a small exhibition of the work of Gaetano Pesce, an Italian architect known for his visionary schemes. The circumstances of the show were curious: Mr. Pesce's work was to have been included in the museum's vast survey, Transformations in Modern Architecture, which opened Feb. 22, but it was cut out so late that the architect had already arrived in New York from Italy for the opening before he ioarned that his work, which had been curamissioned especially for that show, was to be omitted. He protested violently, and the museum, acutely embarrassed, agreed to display the work in a separate exhibition, Project for a Skyscraper.

title: ESSAY U.S. Versus Carter?
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  Political appointees who run the Carter Justice Department are staring glumly at a report put together by a dozen agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that raises questions about the honesty of President Carter's family business.

title: More Cubans Arrive in Caracas
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 7 (Reuters)  A group of 75 Cubans, 27 of them political prisoners, arrived here yesterday as part of an agreement reached by Cuban exiles and the Cuban Government. Venezuela has offered to accept more than 1,000 Cuban refugees.

title: NEW MONETARY LINK TO START IN EUROPE AS FRANCE ACCEDES
description: PARIS, March 7  France cleared the way for a new and potentially farreaching effort at European monetary cooperation today by announcing that it had ended its resistance to linking its currency with that of seven other nations.

title: A Thaw at the Polls
description: Last week's mayoral primary election in Chicago brought a ray of spring cheer to students of American politics. Many are in despair over how few people now turn out to vote. In last fall's elections around the coun try, only 38 percent of those eligible to vote in fact did so. That was one point less than the percentage who voted in the previous offyear election, in 1979, and ten points less than in 1962.

title: Stealing A March On Spring
description: EVERY hint of spring brings a bit of hope these days while we wait for winter to depart. But there is an old trick that the winterweary have been practicing for years: snitching a few branches from the garden's trees and shrubs and forcing them to bloom indoors. The respite, though brief, is welcome during March's inconsistencies.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 8, 1979

title: G.A.O. Questions Use Of Energy Dept. Labs By Nuclear Regulator
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  Congressional auditors said today that the Federal agency responsible for promoting increased use of nuclear energy did virtually all the outside research for the commission responsible for guaranteeing nuclear safety.

title: Design Notebook
description: SEA RANCH, CALIF WHEN a style of architecture becomes so recognizable that it is virtually a part of the landscape, to go back to its beginnings can be surprising. The buildings in which a style developed often nave a quaint, almost delicate air to them; they can seem surprisingly modest. We tend to build up seminal works to monumental proportions in our mind's eye, and when we arrive at the real thing we are often startled to find that it is plain and simple.

title: Caberet: Sterling Silver
description: STERLING Silver, a collection of songs by Frederick Silver that opened at the Village Gate on last night, introduces itself with an admirable premise.

title: Plan to Cut Social Security Loses
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)  The House Ways and Means Committee today dealt a probable fatal blow to President Carter's proposal to cut $600 million in Social Security benefits this year.

title: A List of Key Findings of Reading Tests Given New York City Pupils
description: The following tables summarize some of the key findings of the reading achievement tests given in March 1978 as reported by the New York City Board of Education.

title: American ReInsurance Target of Offer by Aetna
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the largest publicly owned insurer in the nation, offered yesterday to pay $62 a share, or $340 million in cash, for the American ReInsurance Company.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN.. Forlorn Hope Fancy, Dowland; Hungarian Dance No. 6, Brahms; Polonaise in A, Chopin; Sonata in C minor, Edelman; Toccata and Fugue in C, Bach; Album for the Young, Nos. 26, 1, 15, and 5. Schumann.

title: 42d Street, You Ain't No Sodom
description: Every few years a plan is announced by a consortium of merchants and lawyers and bankers to transform 42d Street into a squeakyclean block. This time there are to be two glassenclosed atriums (the Ford Foundation, sponsoring the project, is big on atriums), bridges crisscrossing 42d Street, and escalators moving through a complex set of spaces making up the display area that would include a ride that would simulate movement through the layers of a slice of New York from underground to a skyscraper top.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The brick on the front of my house was painted with a latex paint that was applied over a coat of chalking outdoor paint. The paint is now blistering and badly chipped. I have tried to remove as much of this paint as possible by scraping with a putty knife and by use of a hose, but a good deal of the paint remains. Before I can repaint successfully, does all of the old paint have to be removed, even where it seems to be adhering well and if so, is there a better method of removal that a doityourselfer can do?  M.S., Glen Rock, N.J.

title: I. T. T.Chile Case Closed
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  The Department of Justice today dropped perjury charges against an official of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation on the ground that a public trial in the case would risk exposure of classified national security information.

title: Amtrak Costs Seen Rising
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) Amtrak's top official raised doubts today about new cost estimates for building a highspeed passenger train system in the Northeast and told Congress not to be surprised if more money were needed.

title: Dow Chemical Asks Court to Bar U.S. From Banning a Herbicide
description: FLINT, Mich., March 7 (AP)  The Dow Chemical Company and 10 other plaintiffs have asked a Federal court to issue an injunction barring the Federal Government from banning the herbicide 2.4.5T.

title: Entertainment Events
description: THE PROMISE. directed by Gilbert Cates, Radio city Music Hall.

title: How Popular An Option Is Solar Energy?; Are Homeowners Exercising The Solar Energy Option?
description: ALTHOUGH 94 percent of the persons polled by Louis Harris last June said harnessing solar energy might ease national energy problems. very few threestatearea homeowners committed any cash to this belief. Sales figures are sketchy, but solar energy equipment installers who managed to stay in business report that 1978 was a disaster. Ironically manufacturers blame President Carter's April 1977 announcement that tax credits of up to $2,200 would be available, pending Congressional approval, for homeowners who installed solar energy absorbing equipment.

title: Jacobs, Injured, Out of N.C.A.A.
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 7 (AP)  Franklin Jacobs. the Fairleigh Dickinson University high jumper, will miss this weekend's National Collegiate indoor track and field championships in Detroit because of strained ligaments in his left ankle.

title: Khalil Voices Optimism
description: CAIRO, March 7  Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil, after meeting with President Anwar elSadat on the eve of President Carter's visit, told reporters today that he thinks the chances for peace are rather good.

title: World News Briefs
description: Special to the New York Times

title: Bugged Skis Proving A Deterrent to Thieves
description: KILLINGTON, Vt., March 7  Resorts that adopted a variety of methods for catching ski thieves this winter report that the oncepervasive thefts are down as much as 50 percent in some areas.

title: U. of Colorado President Quits in Budget Dispute
description: DENVER, March 7  The unexpected resignation last night of Roland Rautenstraus, president of the University of Colorado, is expected to add new controversy to the Colorado Legislature's proposed financial cuts for the state's major universities.

title: Wagner Loses to Old Dominion in N.I.T.
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 7 (AP)Ronnie McAdoo grabbed a rebound and dropped in a layup with three seconds left tonight to give Old Dominion an 8381 victory over Wagner College in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: A Chad Official Is Reported Killed As Fighting Continues in Capital
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 7 (UPI)  Sporadic fighting continued today in Chad's capital of Ndjamena between forces loyal to President Flix Malloum and those of his rival, Prime Minister Hissen Habr, the Sudan news agency said.

title: Sympathy and Skepticism at Passman's Trial in Louisiana
description: MONROE, La., March 7  One of Otto E, Passman's supporters offered him a red rose and another called for divine blessings as the 78yearold former Congressman shuffled feebly into the Federal Courthouse here to stand trial on charges of bribery and tax evasion.

title: Andres Figueroa Cordero, 54, Was Jailed After House Shootings
description: SAN JUAN , P.R., March 7 (AP) Andres Figueroa Cordero, a Puerto Rican nationalist who served 23 years in Federal prison for his part in a shooting attack on the United States House of Representatives in 1954, died today, doctors said. He was 54 years old.

title: Thin, Dark Debris Ring Is Found to Circle Jupiter
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 7  A thin, faint ring of dark rocky debris has been discovered circling the giant planet Jupiter in its equatorial plane, scientists announced today.

title: Roots II Strikes Personal Chords
description: Although Roots: The Next Generations drew fewer viewers last month than its predecessor two years ago, blacks and whites interviewed in several communities around the country said they felt it was the more important presentation.

title: Scores May Quit High U.S. Posts Over Ethics Law
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  Scores of toplevel Federal executives are considering resigning within the next four months to escape provisions of a new law that forbids former employees to do business with the Government for two years after leaving their public jobs.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: France said it was now willing to join the European Monetary System, clearing the way fora closer linkage between the currencies of eight Western European countries. [Page A1.]

title: Armco Adds Surcharge, Citing High Cost of Scrap
description: Armco Inc., the nation's fifthlargest steel company, said yesterday it had imposed a surcharge of $20 a ton on about onefifth of its products. The company said the soaring price of scrap metal had greatly increased the cost of proaucuig steel in plants using electric arc furnaces. Armco is the biggest purchaser of scrap in the United States.

title: Spain's Middle Class Seems to Find Rallying Point in Surez's Party
description: MADRID, March 7  A longtime tragedy of Spanish politics has been the incapacity of the right to organize itself and govern the nation without igniting a sharp, sometimes violent reaction from a volatile left. The antagonism between fight and left during the tumultuous Second Republic led in 1936 to civil war, a chapter of Spanish history that to this day conditions political behavior here.

title: Piano: Boris Bloch at Y
description: BORIS BLOCH's spectacular performance of the LisztBusoni Fantasy on Themes from The Marriage of Figaro at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association on Tuesday night proved that he is one of the foremost keyboard athletes of the day, and the massive showpiece may keep him in concert engagements for a long time. He played it at the end of a Young Concert Artists recital, his first New York appearance since he won first prize last fall in the Busoni Piano Competition in Italy.

title: Galante, Released After Apparent Misunderstanding, Goes Back to Jail
description: Carmine Galante, a reputed leader of organized crime, went back to jail yesterday because he was released last week as a result of an apparent misunderstanding.

title: Around the Nation
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 7 (UPI) The attorney for the heirs of Karen G. Silkwood said today that she had enough plutonium in her body to cause cancer at the time she died in an automobile accident, but the lawyer for the defendants in the $11.5 million lawsuit said her contamination was minimal.

title: Dance: Showcase for 10
description: TUESDAY evening's Choreographers Showcase concert at the American Theater Laboratory consisted of seven dances. Because two were collaborations, 10 cnoreographers were represented. Given so many dances by so many people, one feared that the result would be a choreographic blur. Fortunately, each dance had its own personality.

title: Home Beat
description: ONE day, friends and painters Laura Rizkin, above left, and Deborah Almeida formed a company, Brazen Bags, to sell vinyl shopping bags  for carrying groceries, gym clothes, beachwear or laundry. The bags will brighten up the city streets, say their creators, who offer them in 30 Fauve color combinations or solids. The colors, they say include azalea, slicker yellow, Cadillac black, hot pink, spearmint green and grape. The bags are $10 each at Bloomingdale's, Henri Bendel, Broomes (170 Spring Street) and Design Observations (282 Columbus Avenue).

title: Ruby Downs Morrow, ExTeacher And a RealEstate Agent, Was 80
description: Ruby Downs Morrow, a former New York City schoolteacher and a realestate agent, died Tuesday at Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Roosevelt Island. She was 80 years old and lived at 11604 Merrick boulevard, St. Albans, Queens.

title: Old Quilts: Tender Loving Care (by Hand)
description: IF a quilt you treasure is in poor condition, learn to enjoy it just as it is. Rang it or lay it across the foot of the bed (but don't sit on it). Restoring the whole thing is senseless; it doesn't enhance the guilt, and the repairs will be very expensive.

title: Merger Curb Testimony Due
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  While President Carter has yet to decide whether to support a proposal limiting corporate mergers, he has authorized John H. Shenefield, the Government's chief antitrust officer, to testify in favor of the concept, a senior Administration official said today.

title: MannesManhattan Music Schools Merger Is Off
description: The Mannes College of Music and the Manhattan School of Music, whose boards of trustees had conditionally approved a merger, yesterday called off Plans for the consolidation. Mrs. Ruth S. Widder, chairman of the Mannes board, said the trustees decided that Manhattan's proposal did not offer the best possible terms with respect to students and faculty, and voted to reject it.

title: The City
description: It was 4:30 A.M. last July 8 when the airline stewardess arrived at the IND subway station at 96th Street and Central Park West. Within minutes, she had been robbed, hurled from the platform to the tracks and kicked by a knifewielding man as she tried to climb back up. The man fled with her wallet and keys and left her in the path of an incoming train.

title: Bucks Control Boards, Turn Back Nets, 13398
description: MILWAUKEE, March 7  The Milwaukee Bucks spotted the New Jersey Nets a 72 lead tongiht, then roared to a 23point lead after one period on the way to a 13398 National Basketball Association triumph.

title: F.A.A. Bans a Battery Used on Some Aircraft
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)Operators of onethird of all the private airplanes in the United States have been ordered to remove a type of battery that has caused explosions, vented harmful gases and corroded wiring.

title: I.M.F. Gold Brings $241.68
description: WASHINGTON. March 7 (AP)  The International Monetary Fund sold 470.000 ounces of gold for an average bid price of $241.68 an ounce at its monthly gold auction today. The I .M F.said successful bids ranged from $241.28 to $243.26 an ounce and that bids were received for 1.53 million ounces. The auction raised an additional $92 million for the I.M.F.'s trust fund to benefit poor nations. The total raised for the fund from the gold auctions to date is about S2.3 billion.

title: 2 ASPIRANTS CHOSEN TO SEEK RYAN'S SEAT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 7  The players were in place today for the start of a fourweek campaign in northern San Mateo County that is expected to be one of those widely watched byelections in which national and state Republican and Democratic committees go allout for Congressional candidates unknown outside the district.

title: Rangers Win, 53
description: ST. LOUIS, March 7  The New York Islanders, who had lost three of their last five games, squandered a 31 lead late in the second period, then had to rally for two goals in the final 20 minutes to earn a 55 tie with the St. Louis Blues in the Checkerdome tonight.

title: Armco Sues E.P.A. Officials
description: Armco Inc., the nation's fifthlargest steel company, filed suit yesterday against officials of the United States Environmental Protection Agency, contending that the agency's complaints against its steelmaking operations in Middletown, Ohio, were arbitrary and capricious.

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY. MARCH 7, 1979

title: G.A.O. Predicts OilPrice Jump
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, predicted today that the price of imported oil would go up much more than the 10 percent increase already planned by the exporting nations for this year, thus causing higher inflation and more unemployment.

title: Fed Reports Massive Dollar Aid
description: The United States intervened massively in the foreignexchange markets between November and the end of January, spending $6.86 billion to put teeth into the dollarsupport program that president Carter announced last Nov. 1, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: F.T.C. Presses Car Study
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it would go ahead with its antitrust investigation of America's automobile manufacturers, one of this country's largest and most concentrated industries.

title: Study on Small Radiation Doses Defended by Head of U.S. Team
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)  The head of a Carter Administration study team today defended his group's conclusion that the scientific evidence on the possible dangers of repeated small doses of manmade radiation was inconclusive.

title: Text of Carter Departure Speech
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI)  Following is the text, as released by the White House, of President Carter's remarks on his departure for the Middle East:

title: Proposals to Gut Subway Crime Are Offered by Councilman Stern.
description: Closer contact between the transit police and the regular police force, installation of silent alarms in token booths and tougher criminal sentencing were among the subway crimefighting proposals offered yesterday by City Councilman at Lame Henry J. Stern.

title: Mahre's Ankle Fracture Is Worse Than Believed
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., March 7 (AP)  Phil Mahre was injured more seriously in last Sunday's fall on the slopes at Lake Placid, N.Y., than was first thought, according to his doctor.

title: New Program to Aid Fisherman
description: SEATTLE, March 7 (UPI)  The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced yesterday a new pro gram under which fishermen who suffer torn nets, cut line, lost gear or other damage by foreign vessels operating in the United States's 200mile zone will be reimbursed by the Federal Government for their losses.

title: South Africa to Mine More Oil
description: SECUNDA, South Africa, March 5South Africa, cut off from its principal oil supplier by the revolution in Iran, is rushing to expand its future capacity to convert coal into oil.

title: Bridge:
description: The habit of most bridge teachers is to give their students practice deals that are slightly too difficult, in the hope that they will learn from failure. Once in a while, however, to convince them that they have a lot to learn, they are presented with a deal that is much too difficult.

title: G.M. Sets Spending On Foreign Business
description: DETROIT, March 7  The General Motors Corporation plans to spend from $10 billion to $13 billion over the next decade expanding its overseas operations, Elliott M. Estes, president and chief operating officer, said today.

title: Sound
description: OWNERS of fine stereo systems have been complaining for years about the dearth of recordings good enough to bring out the best in their equipment. Sound and surface among major record labels  especially those manufactured in the United States  are exasperatingly variable, ranging from ragged to splendid. Prerecorded cassettes have been even less predictable. While cassette releases from Advent, London and DG have earned a reputation for consistent quality, many available cassettes still lack highfrequency definition and dynamic range and suffer noticeably from background noise.

title: Reliance Subsidiary Buys Imperial Stock
description: The Reliance Insurance Company, subsidiary of the Reliance Group, said it had purchased one million common shares of the Imperial Corporation of America, thus bringing its total holdings in Imperial to slightly more than 20 percent. Reliance formerly held about 1.8 million shares, or 13 percent, of Imperial.

title: A Woman in Coma Since Feb. 27 Gives Birth to Girl in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY, March 7 (AP)  A woman who has been in a coma since Feb. 27 gave birth to a healthy, fivepound girl, officials at the Jersey City Medical Center said today.

title: New Hearing Is Ordered For Ryan Death Suspect
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, March 7 (AP)  A judge dismissed murder charges today against Larry Layton, the People's Temple member who was accused of murdering Representative Leo J. Ryan and four other people, and ordered that a new preliminary hearing be held

title: U.S. OFFERS TO SEND ITS F15'S TO SAUDIS
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  The Carter Administration has offered to send a squadron of Air Force fighters to Saudi Arabia, a move that officials said today was designed to facilitate possible Saudi involvement in the fighting between Yemen and Southern Yemen.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DETROIT, March 7  In a move that could save the company millions of dollars, the financially troubled Chrysler Corporation is soliciting its thousands of suppliers for midyear price rollbacks of up to 2 percent.

title: Walkout at Paris Bourse
description: PARIS, March 7  A strike by personnel of the Paris Bourse, this capital's stock exchange, has shut down all trading here in securities for nearly two weeks, but the impact on the national economy is reported negligible and is likely to remain so.

title: Action Is Promised To Slow Food Rise
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 Administration economists today pinpointed food as a principal and growing inflation problem and promised some action within two weeks aimed at slowing the rate of increase in its price.

title: The Editorial Notebook The Invasion of the Experts
description: Our culture is dominated by professionals who call us clients and tell us of our needs.  So charges Michael Pertschuk, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission. In a recent talk, he took to task an array of professions  doctors, lawyers, pharmacists, architects. stockbrokers, dentists, auto mechanics, psychiatrists, interior decorators, family planners, morticians and more  for intimidating the American public, depriving it of confidence in our unprofessional abilities to diagnose our private needs from personal experience.them with a superabundance of conflicting advice, itself subject to constant changes in psychiatric and medical fashion.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, March 7, 1979

title: Clubs Firm On Umpire Demands
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7The presidents of the two major leagues said today that the baseball season would open on schedule in one month with or without the 52 regular umpires, none of whom has signed a contract for 1979.

title: Maryland Aides Pressed On Allegation of Racism
description: TOWSON, Md., March 7 (AP)  A local civil rights leader says Baltimore County officials tried to cover up allegations that a county public works supervisor chained a black worker to his bench and put a rove around a Jewish worker's neck.

title: Paper Workers Reject Contracts
description: PORTLAND, Ore., March 7 (AP)The Association of Pulp and Paper Workers announced yesterday that striking members had rejected contract offers for five mills of the Weyerhaeuser Company and for the North Bend mill of the Menasha Corporation. Farris Bryson, the union's president, said more than 76 percent of the 2,260 Weyerhaeuser employees who voted Monday at five mills in Washington and Oregon were against the proposal. The mills were struck on Dec. 16. Union members in North Bend voted yesterday, 93 to 29, against the Menasha offer. The plant was struck July 19.

title: Hers
description: SHE wants to join A.A., Phyllis tells me. But why, I ask. One vermouth on the rocks and she falls asleep. But if she belonged to A.A., Phyllis explains, she'd have a community. A network to break her falls. Easyover gregariousness, instead of her actual social life: three weeks lead time to plan a dinner party during which she's too dithery to play with her guests. She could seek asylum in a substitute family. In life's black holes they'd be there.

title: Price Rise Seen For Mexican Oil
description: MEXICO CITY, March 7 (AP)  A spokesman for Petroleos Mexicance, the national oil company known as Pemex, said today that Mexico will almost certainly increase its export prices for oil at the end of March, reflecting increases in world prices. Mexico now charges $14.10 a barrel delivered at Mexican ports.

title: 2 Kidnapped and Freed in Spain
description: BILBAO, Spain, March 7 (Reuters)Suspected Basque separatist guerrillas kidnapped an industrialist and his son today and then freed them after payment of a $38,500 ransom, the police said. Carmelo Pico Garcia, 48 years old, and his son Fernando, 21, were abducted from their borne in Algona, eight miles northwest of Bilbao, by four masked men and were driven away in two cars. The father was then forced to go to a bank and withdraw all his money.

title: Letelier Killer'ss Link to Other Plots Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 F.B.I. summaries of secret interviews with the Chilean agent who admitted killing Orlando Letelier in Washington and the agent's travel records show that he was in three other countries at times when prominent opponents of the present Chilean regime were assassinated or attacked.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 8, 1979

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Ski Conditions
description: Figures in parentheses show total trails and number open at each area. Skiarea forecasts appear on the weather page. For information: New York, (212) 7558100; New Jersey, (609) 2928456 Thursdays and Fridays from 2 to 4 P.M.; Pennsylvania, (717) 4215791; New Hampshire, (603 ) 2242525; Vermont, (802 )2290531, and Massachusetts, (800) 6285030.

title: Majestic Set For Debut Of Mama
description: I Remember Mama, the Richard RodgersMartin CharninThomas Meehan musical starring Liv Ullmann, will have its premiere at the Majestic on May 3. The theater, considered one of the most desirable for a musical because of its seating capacity of 1,714 and its location on West 44th Street, will become available with the closing of Ballroom on March 24.

title: Backgammon:
description: The Los Angeles Spring Classics Backgammon Tournament, sponsored by the American Backgammon Championships, was held last weekend at the Pacifica Hotel in Culver City. Calif. Elliot Winslow took first place in a field of 200 by defeating Todd Van der Plum. Gaby Horowitz overcame Alan Martin to win the consolation. In the intermediate section. Bill Granoff was the victor, and David Hershleder triumphed in the beginners group.

title: EXTREMISM GROWING IN SLUMS OF TURKEY
description: ABIDINPASA. Turkey, March 5 Three weeks ago, a squad of military police burst into the home of Suleyman Ayten, the leader of this shantytown on the fringe of Ankara, confiscated books and papers and arrested him.

title: Mayer to Head U.S. Arts Council
description: ALBANY, March 7 Robert A. Mayer has resigned as executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts to become pesident of the American Council for the ArtS. M. Mayer win assume ?? new post on May 1. The American Council for the Arts, a private nonprofit organization, serves as an information resource on the growth and development of the arts.

title: SavingsLoan Sales a Concern
description: WASHINGTON, March7 (AP) The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that he was concerned with moves by national industries to purchase savings and loan associations.

title: Borg, Under Close Guard, Defeats McEnroe in 3 Sets
description: VIENNA, March 7 (UPI)  Bjorn Borg left Vienna today after cashing in $52,000 in prize money for defeating John McEnroe in the final of a local exhibition tournament.

title: Calendar of Events: Glass Art to Antiques
description: Seven nationally recognized contemporary glass artists from California will exhibit their new collections at the Jorice Gallery, near 56th Street, beginning Saturday and continuing through April 10.

title: Stage: Foot in the Door By Bruce Jay Friedman
description: THERE is a genial, selfmocking tone to Bruce Jay Friedman's humor in his plays as well as in his prose  that makes one respond in empathy and with laughter. Often he makes fun of us by making fun of himself, which is to say that he does not abuse his relationship with the reader or with the audience.

title: Vote in Virgin Islands Is Viewed as Setback For More Home Rule
description: CHRISTIANSTAD, V.I., March 7 The defeat of the proposed constitution for the United States Virgin Islands yesterday by 56 percent of voters in the territory was termed by some political leaders today as a major setback to more home rule.

title: Libya Plans To Reduce Oil Output
description: In a move that may add serious new strain to the world oil market, Libya told its oil customers yesterday that it would reduce production at all of its major fields by 12 to 18 percent, according to trade sources in New York.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY. MARCH 7, 1979
