title: Pennzoil to Retire Debt to Aid Unit
description: The Pennzoil Company said planned to retire $123 million of convertible debentures and provide credit assistance to its 63percentowned subsidiary, Pennzoil Louisiana and Texas Offshore Inc.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 9, 1979

title: U.S. Considering Plan To Create a New Fleet For the Indian Ocean
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  The Carter Administration, worried about stability in the Middle East and protecting oil routes from Persian Gulf, is considering the creation of an Indian Ocean fleet in an effort to bolster American influence in the region.

title: Issue and Debate Should N.H.L. Act on Fighting?; The Background
description: The players stand in the center of the arena, toe to toe, swinging wildly, slipping and sliding on the ice, while thousands of fans roar. When it is over, the people grudgingly take their seats for the game to continue.

title: Auctions
description: THE number of old masters sales has more than doubled in recent seasons, with spectacular prices establishing records for works by scores of artists from the 15th through the 18th centuries. What sometimes goes unnoticed, however, are the conventional works that bring modest to moderate prices. In most old masters sales these paintings outnumber the stars. And in some sales, as in next week's auctions at Christie Manson & Woods, Park Avenue at 59th Street, Thursday at 2 P.M., and at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, Friday at 2 P.M., only lesser artists are being offered. Even paintings deaccessioned by major museums in these sales tend to be canvases or panels of the school of, studio of or attributed to variety, works rarely, if ever, exhibited. The auction houses emphasize how affordable these art works are, but bidders should be aware that a mediocre painting does not improve with age nor does its value increase.

title: Italian Skier Still In a Coma
description: BURLINGTON. Vt., March 8  Leonardo David, the 18yearold Alpine skiing star from Italy who suffered brain injury is last Saturday's World Cup downhill race at Whiteface Mountain in New York, was still in a coma today in the intensive care unit of the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont

title: To Relief of Passengers, Retires SteamHeated Cars That Date From 30's
description: The steamheated passenger coach, an unloved breed of car in the Long Island Rail Road fleet, was on its way to joining the steam engine in obscurity as it made its last run yesterday. The last of 127 L.I.R.R. coaches were replaced by refurbished cars with electric heat

title: One Rail Era Ends Unlamented While Another Is Hailed
description: The New York City ,subway system took a ride into history yesterday; and, for a brief while, it was possible to forget the crime, graffiti, inoperative doors and other traviails that distress so many of today's riders.

title: Citibank Fund Role At Issue
description: The Investment Company Institute. the mutual fund trade association, charged yesterday that Citibank had violated the law prohibiting banks from entering the mutual fund business.

title: Dutch Will Not Investigate Luns On Nazi Membership in the 30's
description: THE HAGUE, March 8 (AP)  The Dutch Parliament voted today not to investigate the truthfulness of statements made by Joseph M. A. H. Luns, the secretary general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, after it was disclosed a week ago that he was a member of a Dutch Nazi organization in the 1930's.

title: An Invitation  To the Dance
description: This is a weekend for dance novelties, with BatDor, the Israeli modern dance company, leading the list. New York will have its first full view of the company on Saturday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Parents Charged With Homicide In Baby's Death
description: The parents of a 6monthold baby who died last month in a heatless house in Queens and was found to have been malnourished and maltreated have been indicted for criminally negligent homicide, District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens said yesterday.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2.30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUN DAY EDITION IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4.30 P.M MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY. NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33903. WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITEPLAINS ??5300: NASSAU CO (516) 7470500: SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Mikita Gets Two Goals As Hawks Rout Flyers
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 8 (AP) Stan Mikita scored two goals and assisted on a third as the Chicago Black Hawks scored a 51 National Hockey League victory over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight.

title: Ski Conditions
description: Figures in parentheses show total trails and number open at each area. Skiarea forecasts appear on the weather page. For information: New York, (212) 7558100; New Jersey, (609) 2928456 Thursdays and Fridays from 2 to 4 P.M.; Pennsylvania, (717) 4215791; New Hampshire, (603) 2242525; Vermont, (802)2290531, and Massachusetts, (800 )6285030.

title: New York Court Bars Ford Suit
description: A suit by dissident stockholders of the Ford Motor Company charging Henry Ford 2d with the misuse of corporate funds and other improprieties was thrown out yesterday on jurisdictional grounds by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Out of the Ranks of Volunteers and Into a Demanding City Job
description: Jewelle W. Bickford who for 14 years was a volunteer in such community organizations as the Legal Aid Society, the Citizens for Clearn Air and the Community Service Society believes that volunteerism can be a training ground for significant, paid managerial work. And she's in the position to prove it.

title: Fire Hits German Monastery
description: BENEDIKTBEUERN, West Germany, March 8 (AP)  Fire destroyed a large part of one of West Germany's oldest monasteries today. The police estimated damage to the Benedictine cloister here at $6.5 million. Its valuable library escaped damage. Benedictine monks founded it in 732 near what is now the Bavarian Alpine resort of Bad Tlz.

title: Miss Kinshofer Wins Fourth Giant Slalom
description: ASPEN, Colo., March 8 (UPI) Christa Kinshofer of West Germany continued her mastery of the women's giant slalom today at Buttermilk Mountain, winning her fourth World Cup race.

title: A.T.&T. Asks Rise in Profits Ceilings
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked the Federal Communications Commission today for permission to earn more profits from its interstate and overseas service.

title: EARNINGS Dutch/Shell Profits Rose 32% in Quarter
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the world's secondlargest oil company, reported yesterday that fourthquarter profits rose 32 percent, while income for the year fell 21 percent because of currency losses and inventory factors.

title: Judge OrdersContempt Hearing For Teachers in Capital Strike
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)  A Superior Court Judge told attorneys for the Washington Teachers Union today that they must show her by tomorrow morning why unito leaders should not be held in contempt in connection with a threedayold strike by teachers.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: DR. ARNOLD KOFFLER

title: About Real Estate Buying a House in Suffolk Via MIddle Class Subsidy
description: RONKONKOMA, L.I.  Off and on for 10 years, Robert and Anne Collins had been trying to buy a house. Not a new house; necessarily. They were living in a garden apartment in Queens and feeling the squeeze as their three children grew. They wanted space. and they wanted ownership. But on Mr. Collins's pay as a steamfitter, they could not afford the down payment and carrying costs of anything they wanted to buy.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Lewis W. Foy, the chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said yesterday that unless the company could get higher productivity from workers and greater subsidies from the Federal Government it would have to consider later this year whether to phase out its shipyard in Sparrows Point, Md.

title: Shaken New York Agency Lags In Enforcing AirPollution Code
description: Smoke from the incinerator, an excited caller told a complaint operator at New York City's air and water pollution communications center on Feb. 23. It's been happening for more than a month, the woman went on. I called before. People are very sick. People vomit from this, Spanish people in the building.

title: For Carters, a Royal Palace
description: CAIRO, March 8  In the middle of 200 acres of formal gardens and treelined boulevards, isolated from the din of this overcrowded city by stone walls 20 feet high, stands the 116yearold ivorycolored palace that is being used this week by President Carter.

title: Syrian Says U.S.Arranged Pact Will Not Bring Peace to Mideast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 8  President Hafez alAssad of Syria warned today that an Americansponsored treaty between Egypt and Israel would not bring peace to the Middle East.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Music: Polish Violinist
description: WANDA WILKOMIRSKA is an artist very much of these times. The violinist, in presenting a conventional program at the 92d Street Y.M. Y.W.H.A. on Wednesday night, was never less than a searching interpreter of the music. Yet it was not until she came to Prokofiev's F minor Sonata (Op. 80) after the intermission that her playing was ideally attuned to the work at hand. The performance, with Tadeusz Chtnielewski as her accomplished pianist, was quite spectacular.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Wholesale prices rose 1 percent in February, the second consecutive month of sharp increases, throwing doubt on the progress of the Government's antiinflation program. The Administration said that it would step up its policing of prices and threatened to identify companies not obeying the voluntary guidelines. [Page A1.]

title: Art People
description: IT started on the West Coast, the notion that women artists could study to be  well, women artists. And now it's spread East. On March 30, a big benefit at the World Trade Center will salute the New York Feminist Art Institute, an alternative art school, whose twoyear program will teach the visual arts in a new and decidedly womenoriented way.

title: Teamster Demands Reported to Exceed Guidelines
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  Initial wage and price demands by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in contract talks with the trucking industry substantially exceed President Carter's antiinflation guidelines, sources close to the negotiators said today.

title: Notes on People
description: After Kevin Fagan wrote to Charles Schulz, creator of the Peanuts comic strip, asking for advice on how to become a syndicated cartoonist, Mr. Schulz suggested that he send samples of his work to the dozens of syndicates that distribute comic strips. Mr. Fagan, a student at Saddleback Community College, in Mission Viejo, Calif., took his advice.

title: 2 Take $5,000 From Nathan's, Assault Women
description: Two gunmen took over the Nathan's restaurant just off Fifth Avenue on East 58th Street for an hour late Wednesday night. They sexually assaulted two women and emptied cash registers and money boxes of $5,000.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, March 8, 1979

title: Iran to Halve Its Oil Output
description: TEHERAN, Iran. March 8 (AP)The Iranian oil industry, the world's secondlargest exporter, will restrict its output to half what it produced under the Shah, the Government announced today. The decision means the loss of 6 percent of the world's oil production.

title: Giscard Visiting Rumania
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 8 (Reuters)  President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France began a threeday official visit here today that is aimed at furthering dtente and promoting closer cooperation with Rumania. He conferred with President Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: Midnights at Rocky Horror'
description: THE narrow snack bar area at the Eighth Street Playhouse on a Saturday night looks just like backstage at a highschool play. There is the frantic feeling, the tote bags filled with cosmetics and costumes, the lastminute jitters, the bad wigs, the actors dressed and made up and lionized, the pep talks, the preyers.

title: Spotting Hitchcock Is No Trick as Hollywood  Salutes Director
description: , LOS ANGELES, March 8  The opening moments of the American Film Institute's tribute to Alfred Hitchcock last night reinforced his reputation for being the only director who is as big a celebrity as the stars of his movies.

title: New Director In Carter Drive
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 Mr. President, I'd like you to meet the first of your many campaign managers, said John C. White, the Democratic national chairman, as he reintroduced Evan Dobelle to President Carter last week. The President was preoccupied with news from the Middle East, and chuckled, without reacting to Mr. White's point, an allusion to the fact that President Ford had gone through a succession of managers in his bid to win election in 1976.

title: Kennedy Introduces Bill to Curb Mergers Among Biggest Companies
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  A bill that would severely limit mergers among the nation's largest businesses was introduced today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, but the Carter Administration is known to be divided on whether to support it.

title: SAVING CERTIFICATES FACING INTEREST CUT
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  The Carter Administration announced new rules tonight to reduce the interest payments on the popular, highinterest savings certificates being issued by commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations.

title: China Quitting Vietnam, Leaving a Trail of Debris
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 8  Chinese troops are withdrawing from Vietnam and are destroying bridges, rail and road facilities and other installations as they niove toward the border, Western intellience analysts said today.

title: A Forgotten Staten Island Concentrates on Its Future
description: Cornelius Vanderbilt was born on Staten Island. His first home appears to have been a Stapleton farmhouse later torn down to make way for the Paramount Theater. Now boarded up, the theater is showing only graffiti from the street artists of the projects nearby.

title: Tax ExemptiOns of MailOrder Ministers's Nullified
description: ALBANY, March 8  The tax assessors of four small upstate towns were ordered today to restore the property of hundreds of mailorder ministers to the tax rolls, voiding the prowrtytax exemptions the ministers have been granted for two and a half years.

title: Con Ed Loses Permits To Dig in City Streets
description: Consolidated Edison had its digging permits turned off for nonpayment of bills this week, and has been trying to get them turned back on.

title: Gambling Issues Lead Market Up
description: Gambling issues were the handsdown winners yesterday in a soaring stock market that saw the Dow Jones industrials jump more than 10 points to reach their highest level since late January.

title: W.T.T. Finished for 1979, With Hope of 80 Revival
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 8 (UPI)Joseph Heitzler, the president of World Team Tennis, said from his Los Angeles office today that the league was officially finished for the year but that there were hopes for its revival in 1980.

title: For Children
description: THE BERCIERFOLK CONCERT FOR CHILDREN, a program of folk songs by a family of singers. Saturday of 3 P.M., In the Heckscher Oval at Uncoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue. Free. Reservations. 7192200. extension 237.

title: Money
description: THURSDAY. MARCH 8, 1979

title: Rep. Mikva and Justice Official Nominated for U.S. Judgeships
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)  Representative Abner J. Mikva, Democrat of Illinois, confirmed today that he and Assistant Attorney General Patricia Wald had been chosen by President Carter for judgeships on the United States Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia.

title: Bazargan Goes to See Khomeini as Iran Rift Grows
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 8  Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan left Teheran today to meet with Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini after several days in which the camps of the two leaders have crackled with dissatisfaction with each other.

title: PushExcel in the Classroom
description: The early returns are in on Push for Excellence, the Rev. Jesse Jackson's crusade to instill a passion for learning and achievement in black students. Some people dismiss the civil rights leader's campaign as a publicity stunt but schools in Chicago, Los Angeles. Kansas City and elsewhere have welcomed it. Experience so far suggests the obvious: no evangelist, however captivating and concerned, can rescue a city's schools. Only educators can.

title: New York's Tax Cut, If You Find It
description: New York State's higherincome taxpayers have found sympathy. The Comptroller, Edward Regan, shares their bafflement over why the state income tax table calculates rates up to 15 percent even though the Legislature ostentatiously set the maximum at 12 percent. The Tax Commission has an explanation, but it merely proves that the state's income tax system is too complicated for ordinary citizens and too costly for ordinary administration.

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: Deaths

title: U.S. Moves to Bar Article on Bomb
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, March 9 (AP)  The. Justice Department announced early this morning that it had filed a civil suit in Federal court in Madison, Wis., to prevent a magazine from publishing an article entitled How a Hydrogen Bomb Works.

title: City of Yonkers And Its Firemen In Negotiations,
description: YONKERS, March 8  The City of Yonkers resumed contract talks with the firemen's union todayafter its members, angry over stalled negotiations, followed up a surprise hourlong walkout last night with the threat of a full strike unless talks began immediately.

title: Obituary 10  No Title
description: O'NEILLAlice (nee Farmer) Former resident of 247 Wadsworth Ave, NYC, retired member NYC school system, on March 8, 1979. Loving wife at the late Edward F. O'Neill. Reposing at Wallace Funeral Home. 1543 St. Nicholas Ave (187 st) until 10:15AM Saturday. Mass of the Resurrection at SI. Elizabeth Church, 187 St Wadsworth Ave 10:45AM. interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Badillo and Ward Clash on Antipoverty Unit's Fate
description: An unusual controversy flared yesterday between two of Mayor Koch's top aides, with Herman Badillo, Deputy Mayor for Policy, accusing Haskell G. Ward, Deputy Mayor for Human Services, of having ordered the closing of a Puerto Rican antipoverty program without regard for the services it provided or the people who worked there.

title: Around the Nation
description: DENVER, March 8 (AP)  Colorado health officials seeking the buried remains of Denver's oncethriving radium industry have located another radioactive dump here, but the discovery dates only to the 1950's.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  New Jersey Attorney General John J. Degnan made public yesterday detailed new regulations designed to cut the cost of alcoholic beverages,in New Jersey by lifting most controls on liquor pricing.

title: Those Shrinking Violets
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 8 (AP)  The Fairleigh Dickinson women's basketball team ended its season Wednesday night with the most onesided victory in the school's history beating New York University by 1015. Fairleigh, which wound up with a 176 wonlost record, scored the first 20 points of the game and led by 443 at halftime

title: Adam L. Starr, Manager, Marries Judith Kopecky
description: The marriage of Judith Kopecky, a student at the Columbia University School of Social Work, to Adam L. Starr, a portfolio manager for E.M. Warburg, Pincus & Company, New York investment concern, took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's mother, Manya Garbat Starr of New York. Rabbi Judah Calm performed the ceremony.

title: BusShelter Company Says Unit of Citibank Blocks Building Plans
description: A participant in the struggle over the franchise to build bus shelters in New York City yesterday accused a subsidiary of Citibank of using improper delaying tactics to block the construction of 4,100 shelters in the five boroughs.

title: Yanks Look at Reserve Players, Umpires
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 8 Jim Umbarger of the Texas Rangers went into a lefthanded windup and fired his third pitch at Greg Jemison, the leadoff batter for the New York Yankees in today's game at Municipal Stadium.

title: Oregon Governor Sets Voluntary FuelSaving Plan
description: SALEM, Ore., March 8 (AP)  You do not have to tell Oregonians how to save, Gov. Vic Atiyeh said in announcing a voluntary fuel conservation plan that he hopes will spur state residents to conserve fuel without Federal intervention

title: Music: Russian Program
description: RUSSIAN music  and lots of it  is being served up rather luxuriantly by the New York Philharmonic in its concerts of this weekend, the first of which was given at Avery Fisher Hall last night.

title: Guiornar Novaes, Leading Brazilian Concert Pianist, Dies
description: Guiomar Novaes, the Brazilian who was known as one the foremost pianists of her tittle, died Wednesday in Sao Paulo after a heart attack. She had been ill since suffering a stroke Jan.31. She was believed to be about 83 years old, although standard music reference books differ as to the year of her birth

title: 10 Protestant Churches Take Step Toward a Membership in Common
description: CINCINNATI, March 8  A set of policies designed to foster mutual acceptance of members among 10 major Protestent denominations won approval today from the Consultation on Church Union, an ecumenical body sponsored by the churches.

title: 3 Airlines Join Cuts In Flights
description: The number of airlines canceling flights because of jet fuel shortages grew yesterday as Allegheny Airlines, Lufthansa German Airlines and the Flying Tiger Line cargo carrier announced that they were curtailing their schedules.

title: Obituary 9  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Conflict Over Forest Spray and Childbirth
description: ALSEA, Ore., March 7  The land falls off sharply beyond the edge of the blacktop  down, down, down to the thin ribbon of water in the creek at the bottom of the canyon's notch  and then climbs just as steeply back up the other side where the logging crews are cutting the 100foot tall Douglas firs.

title: U.S. Ends Broadcasts to Group in Soviet and China
description: A United States Government radio station transmitting to countries of the Soviet bloc has canceled its programs broadcast in the language of the Uighurs, a Central Asian people living mainly in China but also in the Soviet Union.

title: Restaurants
description: GOOD Spanish cooking is not easy to come by in this city; but some of the best we've found during the last few years has been served at El Rincn de Espaa on Thompson Street in Greenwich Village. Although not strictly a seafood restaurant, El Rincon's best dishes are based primarily on an abundance of seafresh shellfish such as clams, mussels, shrimp, lobster and scallops.

title: Giants Add Two Coaches
description: The new Giant coaching staff continued to build its Southern accent yesterday with the appointment of Kentuckyborn Jim Stanley as defensive line coach and Tennesseeborn Bill Belichick as special teams coach.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Courier Corporation, Lowell, Mass., a commercial printer, has named G. Neal Ryland vice president and chief financial officer, and Dennis J. Zimmerman vice president and general manager of its Directory division.

title: The Pop Life
description: NOT all 1960's rock stars have survived the 1970's, but in a rather roundabout way Carlos Santana, who will be at Madison Square Garden next Thursday night, has managed to. His route has been roundabout because of his continual shifts of band personnel and his decidedly uncommercial involvement with his guru, Sri Chinmoy. But he's still kept working and putting out records, and he's still capable of drawing an audience and giving a fine show.

title: Pop: Peter Tosh Band
description: PETER TOSH brought the tightest, most powerful reggae show that has yet played in the United States into the Bottom Line on Wednesday for a twonight run.Considerable excitement surrounded the event, much of it due to the fact that the Rolling Stones have signed Mr. Tosh to their record label and are supporting his United States tour, the most extensive yet attempted by a Jamaican reggae artist. But not even Keith Richards's presence at the second show of the evening detracted from the impression Mr. Tosh and his band made on their own terms. They were simply overwhelming.

title: Swiss Inflation Climbs in Month
description: GENEVA, March 8  Switierland 's costofliving index in February jumped 1.1 percent from January, and was up more than 2 percent from yearearlier levels, the Federal Bureau of Statistics said today.

title: Sweden's Wassberg Wins CrossCountry Ski Race
description: OSLO. March 8 (AP)  Thomas Wassberg of Sweden put on a furious finish and won the men's 15kilometer crosscountry race at the opening of the 100th anniversary Holmenkollen Ski Festival today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The planned retirement late this year of Joachim Zahn, one of the principal architects of the strong postwar resurgence and overseas growth of DaimlerBenz, has kicked off an intracompany tussle over succession.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 9, 1979

title: Money Linkup Due in a Week
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)  Finance ministers from the members of the European Economic Community have recommended that their governments put the new European Monetary System into effect next week, Hans Matthoefer, West Germany's Finance miniver, said today.

title: Publishing: Capital Made Of Washington Life
description: GWEN DAVIS, a naturally ebullient woman and author of a forthcoming novel, Ladies in Waiting, (Macmillan), knew right away that what the reporter wanted to know was why a Beverly Hillsbased writer out of New York writes a novel about the postNixon washineton scene.

title: TV Weekend Lillie Begins, 3 Men Set Off in Stoppard Boat
description: WHAT with public television, in the middle of a moneyraising festival, devoting numerous hours to pop, countrywestern and gospel music, Channel 13 is displaying distressing signs of becoming a giant jukebox. But, between bouts of namethattune orgies, there are patches of substance, and two can be found this Sunday. Masterpiece Theater starts a new series with Lillie at 9 P.M., and Three Men in a Boat, with a script by playwright Torn Stoppard, at 10:45. Both, perhaps needless to say, are imports from Britain.

title: 3 Lead L.P.G.A. by 2 Shots at 68
description: RANCHO PARK, Calif., March 8 Nancy Lopez went into the Sunstar Classic today determined to repeat as winner over the Rancho Park golf course. She won here a year ago with a threeunderpar score of 285 on the way to nine 1978 victories that included the Ladies Professional Golf Association championship.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Guard Held in Death

title: Bill Lee: Pot Not My Pitch
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 8 (UPI)  Bill Lee, the Montreal Expos unconventional lefthanded pitcher, said today that reports that he smoked marijuana regularly since his pro career began were erroneous. I've never smoked the stuff, Lee told Art Fust of major league baseball's security staff, who was sent here by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn to investigate the following quotes attributed to the lefthander: I've used it on my buckwheat pancakes and other health foods. I used to run five miles to the ball park in Boston and that killed the poison that I'd inhale along the road.

title: Inez Andrews Sings A Gospel Tribute
description: 'WE have a lot of rockandroll singers out in the audience, the gospel singer Inez Andrews said over the telephone from New Orleans last Sunday. They come purposely to see what they can learn  or what they can steal. They'll come backstage and say, Hey, girl, I've got to know what you did on those last eight bars. Rockandroll singers steal even worse than the gospel singers. Because we had something to steal from the very beginning, while they had nothing.

title: Screen: 'Passage' in the Pyrenees:Pursued by the SS
description: WHEN a film has three times as many producers as it has directors and writers you can usually be sure the film is of less importance than the deals by which it was made."The Passage," which opens at a number of theaters in New York today, was directed by J. Lee Thompson and written by Bruce Nicolaysen, who are clearly outnumbered. It was produced "by John Quested in association with Maurice Binder and Lester Goldsmith," with John Daly and Derek Dawson credited as "executive producers," and Geoffrey Hellman as "associate producer." In addition no less than six companies are involved in the film's production, "presentation" and release."The Passage" is so awful you must suspect it was designed to be someone's tax write-off. As such it should be a smashing success.The film stars Anthony Quinn as a Basque guide who, during the Nazi occupation of France during World War II, attempts to save a famous scientist (James Mason), his wife (Patricia Neal) and their two dreadful children by shepherding them over the Pyrenees into Spain. In pursuit is Malcolm McDowell as a German SS officer who wears a swastika on his athletic supporter, dreams unconvincingly of the 1,000-year Reich and says such things as, "You think we conquered France for her recipes?" when it's obvious no one is thinking anything.The performances are very, very bad, and the mountains boring."The Passage," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains one rape, one scene in which a French Resistance leader has his fingers chopped off with a carving knife and one immolation, among other atrocities.

title: Indecisive Fed Keeps Lot Empty 10 Years
description: A gray wooden wall, too high to see over, runs along a block of Nassau Street in the financial district downtown and turns the corner into Maiden Lane. Its fading murals, painted by the Boys Club of New York, celebrate baseball, dinosaurs and trips to the moon. A makeshift opening at one end says, Door to the future. The future is a sad and empty lot of groundup brick and mortar.

title: Film Retrospective of Andrzej Wajda, Polish Iconoclast, at Hunter
description: A rare gift from Poland: the major films of Andrzej W'ajda in the first retrospective ever held in the United States of this great movie director, will be on display this weekend and next at Hunter College.

title: Congress Receives Bill For Increasing Quota Of Refugees to 50,000
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  The Carter Administration sent to Congress today a bill that would increase the normal flow of refugees to the United States from 17,400 a year to 50,000 and would provide for additional admissions when the President deemed it necessary.

title: SENATE REJECTS BID ON TAIWAN SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  The Senate today narrowly defeated an attempt to write a stronger commitment to Taiwan into legislation designed to carry out the opening of full relations with China.

title: Bluegrass Festival At Brooklyn Academy
description: Two of the bestknown women singers on the folkbluegrass circuit, Delia Bell and Hazel Dickens, will be performing this weekend as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's OldTime Country Music Festival, a rollicking series of concerts devoted to Cajun, Bluegrass, Appalachian and Canadian music.

title: Loan Demand Growing As Money Supply Falls
description: Loan demand is continuing to rise while the nation's money supply continues to decline, according to statistics released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Japanese Banks Near $2 Billion China Loan
description: TOKYO. March 8  Japan and China reached basic agreement here today on a $2 billion loan that Peking plans to use to pay for imports from this country

title: Bigger Business in Smaller Sizes
description: Pat Torbit is 40 years old and 5 feet 2 inches tall. She weighs less than 110 pounds and is thus classified a petite size by stores. However, she found that most of what is called petite clothing was too big for her. She could fit into some of the socalled junior petite apparel, designed for teenagers of collegeage customers, but these clothes often looked too youthful for her.

title: February Wholesale Prices Up 1% As Food Again Leads the Advance
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  The Government's index of producers prices for finished goods at the wholesale level, which anticipates what consumers will pay later in stores, rose 1 percent in Feb. ruary. The unsually sharp monthly increase was the second in succession and indicated that the Carter Administration's antiinflation program has yet to take hold.

title: 6 New Series in NBC Spring Cleaning
description: NBCTV, running third in audience ratings; yesterday put its primetime schedule through another revision, deleting such recently installed entries as Little Women, Brothers and Sisters, Sweepstakes, Turnabout and BJ and the Bear.

title: For a Special Prosecutor
description: The Justice Department's reluctance to have a special prosecutor investigate irregularities in the Carter family peanut business is understandable but misguided. Justice lawyers always resist putting politically sensitive cases in the hands of outsiders. They feel that impugns their ability or probity  and they still believe that even a special Watergate prosecutor was justified only for unique reasons.

title: Her RighttotheHeart of It Style Brought Sheer Pleasure and Delight to Audiences
description: There have been more monumental pianists, more intellectual pianists, but it is hard to think of a pianist whose playing gave as much sheer pleasure as that of Guiomar Novaes. The great artist, who died Wednesday in her native Brazil, had a style that changed very little through the years. It was a style that represented limpidity in finger work, naturalism in internretation, solid rhythm and a purely instinctive quality that went right to the heart of the music.

title: Broadway
description: THERE are no natural candidates. for musical biographies; Cow Chanel was as unlikely as Fiorello La Guardia. There is also no rule that says a Broadway producer must live within walking distance of Sardi's. Therefore, we shall have Carver, which is about George Washington Carver, and which is being produced by Arline Cone of Houston. Loften Mitchell is doing the book, H. B. Barnum is doing the music and lyrics, and Donald MclCayle is doing the directing and choreography. Moreover, Theoni V. Aldridge is to do the costumes, and Jules Fisher the lights. Yes, these people have all done Broadway shows; no, Mrs. Cone has not. Neither did Ken Harper before he produced The Wiz,  Mrs. Cone says, and besides, you have to start somewhere.

title: Exuberant Egyptians Give Carter a Heartening Salute
description: CAIRO, March 8  They chanted, they clapped, they tootled on flutes and thumped drums. They jumped up and down and waved flapping cloth banners that linked the visitor to love, Justice and peace.

title: Recruiters Besieging Schoolgirl
description: She can sink a 12foot Jumper with either hand, hardly ever misses from the line and averages 38 points and 20 rebounds a game. But she can't dunk, at least not yet.

title: Ali Didn't Really Need the Mike
description: The telephone rang at an hour when stiffs are going to work and fighters are running on the road but guys on morning newspapers are deep in the sack. It was Muhammad Ali calling. The evening before, he had driven a harness horse in a nonbetting race at Maywood Park outside Chicago against four of the track's top drivers, Daryl Busse, Walter Paisley, Jim Dalbee and Stan Banks. The heavyweight halfchampion of the world (World Boxing Association but not World Boxing Council) was up behind a steed named, for this occasion.

title: Dr. Cherkasky to Step Down Today As Koch Adviser on Public Health
description: Dr. Martin Cherkasky, Mayor Koch's outspoken health adviser and a strong critic of the city's municipal hospital system, will resign today from his unsalaried City Hall position.

title: Scope of China Imports Scaled Down in Study
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  A new study by the Commerce Department reaffirms earlier, tentative conclusions that China's ability to import goods from the United States, although it will grow, will be limited despite that nation's ambitious development plans.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE economic consequences of the oil crisis stemming from the revolution in Iran are coming into focus, and the outlook is grave. Oil industry experts now expect the world price of a barrel of crude oil to rise by about 50 percent to $18 to $20 by the end of the year.

title: Big Bronx Flower Show Is Harbinger of Spring
description: Wan from hibernation, depressed by all the rain, New Yorkers can find renewal in the Bronx tomorrow regardless of the weather. There, in the New York Botanical Garden, 12,000 plants bearing 100,000 flowers will proclaim the start of spring. They'll mingle with the permanent plant displays in the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, the grand tturnofthecentury greenhouse complex that was restored and renamed after its benefactor just a year ago.

title: Young Volcano Found on Io, Jupiter Moon
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 8 Voyager,1 phOtography has revealed the existence of a large, young volcanic mountain on Io, Jupiter's innermost major satellite. This indicated to project scientists that Io, like Earth, is still an active body with a molten interior.

title: COMMODITIES Cattle Futures Continue At RecordSetting Pace
description: Strength in cattle futures continued yesterday, with some contracts setting historic highs.

title: WaterHeater Makers Fined
description: PHILADEPHIA, March 8 (AP) Two of the six major waterheater manufacturers indicted in connection with an alleged pricefixing conspiracy have pleaded no contest and have been fined by United States District Judge Charles Weiner.

title: Mets Chances Fade. On Deal for Hebner
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 The New York Mets best chance to strengthen themselves  through a trade with the Philadelphia Phillies for the powerhitting Richie Hebner  appeared to be dead or dying today because the Phillies were being besieged with offers from eight or nine other clubs

title: Opera: Met Unfurls Flying Dutchman The Cast
description: THE assault on Wagner continues. last night the Metropolitan Opera staged Der Fliegende Holln der as conceived by JeanPierre Ponelle, who directed the production and provided the sets. This originally was created by the San Francisco Opera, and was intended to be shared by the Metropolitan.

title: After Iran, Iraq Approaches Modernization Warily
description: BAGHDAD, March 3  To the north and south stretch neat new stone villages with television antennas, schools and clinics, new highways with long lines of Mercedes trucks, new factories with Japanese and West European machinery, new farm projects with American and East European equipment.

title: Obituary 7  No Title
description: CEMETARY PLOTS

title: Study of Sleep Reports Men Stop Breathing Longer
description: Healthy men often stop breathing for periods ranging from 10 to 54 seconds when they sleep, according to the results of a research study reported yesterday.

title: At the Movies
description: MOST actresses shy away from playing parts in which they must pretend to be older than they in factare. (Of course, most actresses are older than they pretend to be. but that's another matter.) Not so Lauren Bacall, who has taken on the role of an 83yearold woman in Health, Robert Altman's seriocomedy about the naturalfoods movement.

title: Police Sergeants Will Ride Alone
description: In an extension of the one officer radiocar concept, the Police Department will have sergeants ride alone while on supevisory patrol in some precincts, rather than be driven by a police officer

title: Begin, Back Home, Voices Confidence; Countermoves Viewed as Possible Some in Parliament Complain Motion Is Rejected Where Is Mount Sinai? Money for the Negev Move
description: JERUSALEM, March 8  Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that a peace treaty would be signed with Egypt if President Carter, now in Cairo, received Egyptian approval of proposals worked out between the Israeli and American leaders in Washington earlier this week.

title: Obituary 11  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Mutual Funds for Moslems
description: The man who wanted to bring icebergs to Saudi Arabia as a source of water is now offering mutual funds in the Middle East.

title: Art: 2 Ways to See Robert Morris
description: ROBERT MORRIS is not like any other artist, and he is by any count one of our most valuable and provocative human. beings. He first came to notice with sculptures that were metaphors either for an almost unbearable tension or for the kind of cryptic situation that we all get into from time to time and so rarely know how to get out of. In his prints, he employs a kind of industrial draftsmanship that effectively discards what was once called the fineart bit; and in his occasional writings he employs a prose style that derives in equal degree from Tacitus and Franz Kafka.

title: Blacks and Hispanics Critical of Census
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  Less than 13 months before the 1980 census, the Census Bureau is at loggerheads with local officials and leaders of minority groups over whether innovations in censustaking methods will be adequate to reduce the undercount of ppor people and membens of minority groups, a problem that has plagued previous headcounts of the American populaton.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: IN 1958 Flannery O 'Connor and her widowed mother were about to go to Europe, specifically to Lourdes, for the first and only time. The trip had to be postponed. Miss O 'Connor explained to her friend Maryat Lee:

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Carbide in Price Rise
description: The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday a 2centapound increase in the price of its linear alkyl benzene. effective April 1. The products are used in the formulation of detergents.

title: First Boston Reports Loss
description: First Boston Inc., the holding company for the First Boston Corporation, an investmentbanking concern, had a loss of 4.3 million for the fourth quarter of its 1978 fiscal year, it reported yesterday.

title: Artificial Insemination of Single Women Poses Difficult Questions
description: She worked in a beauty shop in a small New Jersey town. He taught elementary school. Both were young and single and, although they had talked of marrying some day, she did not want to wait to have a child. Nor was she willing to have sexual relations with him before marriage. Accordingly, he agreed to donate the sperm necessary for artificial insemination.

title: Bridge:
description: Bridge players have all heard of Blackwood  but hardly any of them know anything about him. At the age of 75, the inventor of the world 's most popular bridge convention is alive and well and living in Indianapolis.

title: Decision Delayed On Rider for `Bid
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 8  The trainer and owners of Spectacular Bid apparently are still undecided over whether to replace Ron Franklin as the 3yearold colt's jockey.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in The Times yes terday erroneously described a photograph showing the planet Jupiter with a ring. It should have said that while the photograph showed the planet, the ring was an artist's rendering.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: New York City, which took over Yankee Stadium in 1973 at a total cost of almost $100 million, will undertake $80,000 in concrete repair work to seal cracks found near expansion joints, Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Day is said yesterday.

title: Soviet Said to Enter Yemen Conflict
description: KUWAIT, March 8 (AP)  A Kuwaiti newspaper reported today that the Soviet Union and Cuba had rushed troops and advisers to Southern Yemen.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 8, 1979

title: Dayton Eliminates Holy Cross
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 8 (AP)  Led by Jim Paxson's 2 points, Dayton scored its highest total in its 38 National Invitation Tournament basketball games tonight in crushing Holy Cross, 10581, in a firstround game.

title: UNRESOLVED ISSUES
description: CAIRO, March 8  President Carter and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt conferred for two and a half hours tonight, but afterward both sides said that there still were unresolved issues holding up the conclusion of an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: Art: New Drawins By Gene Davis
description: PAINTERS drawings often resemble confidential diaries. They disclose the essential natune of a sensibility. Certain entries have more interest than others, of course, but it is the impact of the whole that commands attention. We are taken behind the scenes, so to speak, and shown not so much the development of a style but the thinking and experience that results in style.

title: Jackson Deplores Loss Of Iran Listening Posts
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, contends that the loss of American listening posts in Iran has done irreparable harm to the ability of the United States to verify a new strategic arms treaty with Moscow and he is criti cizing the Carter Administration for suggesting otherwise.

title: Levi and Aaron, at 66, Tied For Lead in Inverrary Golf
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla., March 8 (AP)  Wayne Levi carded a sixunderpar 66 and tied Tommy Aaron for the firstround lead today in the $300,000 Inverrary Classic.

title: Amin Foes, Renewing Drive, Seem Headed for Capital
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 8 An offensive by Tanzanian troops and Ugandan exiles that is aimed at toppling President Idi Amin has regained momentum and is meeting little resistance as it moves toward the capital of Kampala, according to reports reaching here.

title: American Stores Studies A Merger With Skaggs
description: The American Stores Company, acting after a sharp runup in the price of its stock, disclosed yesterday that it was in the process of considering a merger proposal involving American Stores and Skaggs Companies.

title: Music: Winchester Choir
description: THE great cathedral of Winchester in Hampshire, England, is currently observing its 900th anniversary and, at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, its choir of men and boys ended a North American concert arranged as part of the anniversary Celebration. Performing under the direction of Martin Neary, the ensemble has made 22 appearances in this country and Canada under the sponsorship of Barclays Bank.

title: Flynt Freed of Some Charges
description: CINCINNATI, March 8 (AP) Charges against the publisher of Hustler magazine. Larry Flynt, and two codefendants were dismissed yesterday by Common Pleas Judge Robert S. Kraft.

title: Arco Nears Divestiture Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  The Atlantic Richfield Company announced today that it had reached a provisional settlement with the staff of the Federal Trade Commission concerning its divestiture of the Anaconda Company, a major copper producer.

title: SAMUEL E. GATES, 63, AIRLINELAW EXPERT
description: Samuel E. Gates, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Debevoise. Plimpton, Lyons & Gates and presidentelect of the American College of Trial Lawyers, died yesterday at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia, where he was stricken several days ago with a ruptured aorta.

title: Life Without Mother
description: It was your average homicide. An argument between two people who had lived together for the last three years.

title: House Panel Struggles On WageInsuring Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  The House Ways and Means Committee voted by a slim majority today to earmark budget money for the President's realwage insurance program, but the plan still faces an uphill battle.

title: REA Official Is Indicted
description: Eugene B. Kania, former vice president of finance of REA Express Inc., was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges that he had approved corrupt REA payments to avoid property taxes that the company should have paid in Chicago.

title: Koopmans Stops Italian After 6 for European Title
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 8 (UPI)  Rudi Koopmans of the Netherlands scored a knockout over Aldo Traversaro of Italy today whenTraversaro failed to answer the bell for the seventh round of their European lightheavyweight championship bout.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics
description: Fighting Words

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Closes Mixed
description: The dollar had a mixed day on the world's foreign exchange markets yesterday, achieving some slight gains in New York after retreating in Japan and Europe.

title: C.I.A. Papers Indicate Broader Surveillance Than Was Admitted
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  Formerly classified documents released by the Central Intelligence Agency show that its Office of Security conducted far more extensive surveillance activities inside the United States in the period of the Vietnam war than was previously known.

title: Unkind Cuts
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  President Carter presented his budget as if with great reluctance the Administration was forced to cut social programs to stop inflation. After more than a decade of rapidly growing programs, no one can object to a debate about their intrinsic merits and everyone can believe that some programs ought to be cut, but whatever the demerits of social expenditures they neither cause nor cure inflation. Regardless of whether these programs are cut, inflation will be high.

title: Basis for Accord Is Reached In Times of London Strike
description: LONDON, March 8  In a major breakthrough, negotiators in the dispute that has closed The Times and its sister publications for more than three months have agreed on a formula that could lead to the reappearance of the paper on April 17.

title: Layoff Bill Gains in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, March 8  A bill requiring Connecticut businesses to warn the state before they move or lay off employees was approved today by the General Assembly 's Labor Committee. Supporters said it may be the first time that such a bill has won committee backing in any state legislature.

title: Market Place
description: INVESTORS who have watched Federal courts knock down takeover statutes in Delaware, Idaho. Indiana and Illinois may have concluded that these deterrents to rapidfire takeovers are essentially dead letters.

title: Alcorn State Posts N.I.T. Upset
description: STARKVILLE, Miss. , March 8 (AP)  Larry Smith hit a short jump shot at the buzzer tonight to give unbeaten Alcorn State an 8078 upset victory over Mississippi State in a firstround game of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Business and the Law
description: IT is one measure of how much MudgeRose Guthrie & Alexander, once the bestknown law firm in the country. has receded from the public mind that a potentially embarrassing decision affecting, the firm recently passed by without much notice.

title: The City
description: The Board of Education announced yesterday plans to take over Mayor Koch's KiddieLift program as a wildcat strike by school bus drivers entered its fourth week and efforts to settle the dispute moved slowly. The Kiddie Lift now transports 633 physically handicapped children, to public schools throughout the city.

title: An Indictment Of Child Care
description: A report on children in outofhome care issued this week by the Children's Defense Fund opens with the following remarkable paragraph: Almost everyone agrees that families are vital to the healthy development of children. Professionals and researchers confirm the conventional wisdom: children need to feel wanted and accepted, they need continuity in their relationships with biological or psychological parents; they need guidance to cope with the demands of growing up; and they need to have some sense that there is a regular, dependable quality to the world.

title: SENATORS POSTPONE EXTRAINCOME LIMIT IN QUICK VOICE VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  After quiet lobbying campaign and only a few minutes of debate today, the Senate rushed through a fouryear postponement of its rule to limit strictly the amount of outside income that members may add to their annual salaries of $57,500.

title: World News Briefs
description: DENAIN, France, March 9 (Reuters)  Steelworkers protesting the Government's modernization plans for their industry battled riot policemen today for the second day in this northern steel town.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: HARRY HAUSKNECHT

title: Bankers Trust Sets Major Reorganization
description: The Bankers Trust Company is undergoing a major reorganization in an effort to sharpen its competitive position in wholesale banking. The nation's eighthlargest hank, which announced plans last November to sell most of its New York area branches to the Bank of Montreal, will disclose the changes to its entire staff and to the public today.

title: Hospital Agency Sued By Family of a Patient In Coma After Surgery
description: Charging gross negligence and a cover up, a Queens Village family yesterday filed a $5 million suit against the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation on be; half of a family member, a 26yearold I schoolteacher who it said was in a coma following brain surgery at Queens Hospi tal Center.

title: Restaurant Posts Aid for Choking
description: Last year, 32 people in New York City choked to death on food lodged in their throats. Nationwide, 4,000 choked to death.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: TextileWorker Photos Go on Show on 43d St.
description: A free exhibition of photographs by Earl Dotter of textile workers from the southern United States will be on display through April 27 at District 1199, National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees, 310 West 43d Street. The show coincides with the publication of Rise Gonna Rise: A Portrait of Southern Textile Workers. a book by Mimi Conway, which chronicles the life of textile workers.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bond Prices Up 3d Day Out of 4
description: The credit markets, undeterred by news of sharply rising prices of finished goods, made a fairsized advance yesterday  their third gain in the last four days.

title: Vachon, Detroit Goalie, Is Unclaimed on Waivers
description: DETROIT, March 8 (AP)  No National Hockey League team claimed Rogie Vachon, the Detroit Red Wings goalie who was put on waivers Monday.

title: Mexicans Lack Health Care, but Doctors Can't Find Work
description: MEXICO CITY, March 8  On a wall of the school of medicine at Mexico's National University, students have painted a seemingly obvious message for a country in which half the population receives no medical attention: We demand the right to work. Medicine for the people.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  The critical foreign policy question in Washington now is whether the United States, so soon after its disappointing experience. n Vietnam, is prepared to commit itself politically and militarily to some kind of economic and military defense of the Middle East.

title: Theater: Joe Orton Double Bill
description: DESPITE the eccentricity of his theatrical vision. Joe Orton wrote in the AngloIrish tradition of biting stage comedy. which extends from Oscar Wilde through Harold Pinter. Since his death, with the revival in England of his small but consequential body of work and the publication this season of John Lahr's biography, Prick Up Your Ears, Orton is being treated with an increasing seriousness and respect.

title: Ogden Unit to Buy United Tanker Ships

title: TV: The Child Stealer
description: THE chilling and unexpected thing about The Child Stealer, an ABCTV movie to be shown at 9 this evening, is that it's a thriller with too many victims and not a villain in sight. A divorced couple. played by the enormously likable actors Beau Bridges and Blair Brown, love their children at least as much as they detest each other, but they haven't yet hit upon a successful way of sharing their two daughters affections. The mother, who has custody, is engaged in constant squabbling with her exhusband about his visitation rights, and the father complains that he doesn't have enough of the children's time. The girls wish their parents could live together again, and the parents respective new mates wish the kids were a little less hostile. No one is ahead of the game.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Screen: 'Bright and Beautiful':House Calls
description: IF "All Things Bright and Beautiful" is a hard movie to dislike, it's also hard to pay attention to or remember in any detail. A happy veterinarian, played genially by John Alderton, wanders around the Yorkshire countryside, visiting the cats and dogs and budgies who make up his clientele. His manner is friendly and a bit lackadaisical, so the movie proceeds with a corresponding languor, as if it were out for a stroll on a summer's day. There are no highs or lows, just an endless stream of sick pets and miracle cures. Of these, my favorite was a cute little terrier with indigestion.The closest thing to a dramatic climax occurs when a cow gives birth, on-camera, near the end of the story. Mr. Alderton, it should be noted, took a two-day veterinary crash course and actually delivered the calf. Eric Till, the director, then cuts to a shot of the veterinarian's wife, who has been pregnant and who has been giving birth herself while the cow was doing likewise. Even if Mr. Till's intentions seem good, the net effect is anything but flattering."All Things Bright And Beautiful," set in the late 1930's and based on James Herriot's best-selling memoirs, purports to be the kind of good, old-fashioned family movie they just don't make any more. In fact, they don't make such films very often, but this one, for all its sweeping niceness, hasn't got much pizazz. The average family can have just as much fun clustered in front of its television set, or romping with a furry little friend of its own. And the Yorkshire countryside, which ought to be engaging even when the action is not, is poorly photographed in muddy hues of red and brown.The film opens today at the Guild, the RKO 86th Street and other theaters.

title: Four Old Padres Talk Pitching
description: YUMA, Ariz.  In the San Diego Padres clubhouse, the pitchers lockers are side by side along one wall. Gaylord Perry dresses next to Randy Jones, who dresses next to Rollie Fingers, who is not far from Mickey Lolich  four pitchers who have accumulated a total of 641 major league victories in their careers, not to mention Rollie Fingers's 208 saves. If the Padres are to climb out of fourth place in the National League West, these are the pitchers who must produce. And Quickly. When the season opens. the Padres first 14 games are with the Los Angeles Dodgers, Cincinnati Reds and San Francisco Giants, the three clubs above them last year. And here in the sunny southwest corner of the Arizona desert not far from the Mexico border, those four Padre pitchers are preparing for the twoweek stretch that will influence the Padres season. Of the four, Gaylord Perry is the dean, the 40yearold righthander with an opportunity to attain 300 victories.

Joining what has to be a celebrity trend, Miss Swanson has signed a contract with Randon House calling for the publication of her memoirs in late 1980.

title: Sunset, Sunrise
description: The city is like poetry, wrote E. B. White, the greatest human concentrate on earth, the poeni whose magic is comprehensible to millions of residents, but whose full meaning will always remain illusive. At dusk Thursday and dawn yesterday, the city flaunted some of its most illusive beauty. From the Brooklyn end of the Manhattan Bridge, the silhouetted towers of Manhattan, wreathed in flames of sunset, glittered in the twilight as an outbound freighter slid silently under necklaces of lights on the Brooklyn Bridge. The sounds: muted homebound traffic on the distant bridge, a symphony of evening winds sighing over the East River, a tugboat's farewell in basso profundo. And at 6:20 A.M. yesterday, from the vantage of Governor's Island in the upper harbor, dawn's sunburst mushroomed through the haze of Brooklyn's darkened, ragged skyline. The sounds: baywaters lapping at bulkheads, wheeling seagulls screeching overhead, factory smokestacks whispering soot, and the promising rumble of an awakening giant  the city.

title: 3 in Attempt to Rob Restaurant

The robbery occurred only four: doors away from a Nathan's Restaurant, where two women were sexually assaulted and $5,000 was stolen Wednesday night.

title: Rearrangements, Skits About Love, at La Mama
description: There are two kinds of absurd theater. One plays games with itself; the other, much rarer, and the only kind worth watching, plays games with us. Sometimes they are terrible and piercing games, and sometimes they are playful games, but with real penalties.

title: MAGAZINE HAS HAD A STORMY HISTORY

title: Ingersoll Plastics Unit Sold
description: The IngersollRand Company announced yesterday the sale of its domestic plasticsinjection and blowmolding machinery business to the Goodman Equipment Corporation of Chicago. The purchase was for an undIsclosed amount of cash and notes. The plastics machinery business was a product line of IngersollRand's IMPCO division, based in Nashua, N.H. The sale did not involve the Nashua plant and equipment, which will continue to be used in the production of its expanding business for pulpprocessing machinery and liquidssolids separation equipment.

title: Koch Reiterates He Plans to Shut Some Hospitals

title: Space Shuttle Problem Delays Trip to Florida
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., March 9 (UPI)  The space shuttle Columbia's crosscountry flight to Cape Canaveral atop a 747 jet has been postponed until next week.

title: Dyson Is Reportedly Offered Power Authority Post
description: ALBANY, March 9  Governor Carey has informally offered John S. Dyson, his outspoken Commerce Commissioner, a new post as chairman of the State Power Authority, executive and legislative sources said today.

title: Ship Gets Approval for Dumping
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., March 9 (AP) An Italian freighter anchored off Chesapeake Bay was granted a permit today day to unload 1,500 tons of water contaminated by a pesticide so that it may be dumped off the coast of New Jersey.

title: By Jove
description: Now more than 400 million miles from Earth, Voyager I has begun its journey from Jupiter to Saturn, where it is scheduled to arrive in November 1980. Voyager's close encounter with Jupiter and five of its satellites has already added greatly to our knowledge of the heavens. The Jovian satellites, mere points of light in the most powerful telescopes, were photographed up close for the first time last week. Now we know them as moons with fascinating characteristics of their own. As for Jupiter itself, the enormous quantity of new information makes all existing books on the solar system obsolescent.

title: Israelis Warn Egypt on Any Revision of Proposals
description: JERUSALEM, March 9  Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel expressed the hope today that Egypt would not reject the new American proposals because, he said, the negotiations for a peace treaty cannot continue forever.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Unemployment dropped slightly to 5.7 percent of the work force in February from January's 5.8 percent, the Labor Department reported. The department noted, however, that the decrease was because of rounding and represented no actual decline. This is the lowest figure since August 1974, when the rate was 5.4 percent. The number of persons holding jobs increased by 347,000 in February, slightly less than January's gain of 445,000. The department said that the rate of the number of teenagers without jobs increased to 16.1 percent, while unemployment among blacks rose to 11.9 percent. [Page 1.]

title: France Seems to Soften on Steel Industry Cutbacks
description: PARIS. March 9  The French Government, faced with increasingly violent opposition to its plan to cut back inefficent industries in a bid to modernize the national economy, now appears to be wavering slightly in its previously rockhard resolve.

title: Progressive Magazine: New Court Test
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  With the order by a Federal judge in Milwaukee today forbidding The Progressive magazine to publish an article about hydrogen bomb technology, the stage is set for the first court battle in nearly eight years over the Federal Governmenr's power to prevent publication in a magazine or newspaper of what it calls national security secrets.

title: VW Seeks A Litton Subsidiary
