title: The U.N. Today
description: March 10, 1979

title: INVADERS IN UGANDA ARE SAID TO ADVANCE
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 9  The Ugandan Government said today that it was repulsing a Tanzanianbacked invasion. But wellinformed Western diplomats said that the invaders were rapidly advancing upon Kampala, the capital, with no sign of Ugandan troops to block their path.

title: SAMUEL E. GATES, 73, AIRLINELAW EXPERT
description: Samuel E. Gates, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Debevoise, Plimpton, Lyons & Gates and presidentelect of the American College of Trial Lawyers, died Thursday at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia, where he was stricken several days ago with a ruptured aorta.

title: Even the Dissidents Are Divided In the Divided Episcopal Church
description: While the Episcopal Church continues to be troubled by policies and practices adopted in recent years, its dissidents seem unable to find an organization or beliefs that can unite them.

title: Hyman Nemser, 79
description: Hyman Nemser, a labor lawyer and a former president of the former Brooklyn Women's Hospital, died Tr:tin:day of a heart attack. Mr. Nemser, Who lived in Manhattan, Was 79 years old.

title: Messages to Moscow
description: The inability of Americans to do more than expostulate about the lack of political freedom in the Soviet Union can sometimes lead to a feeling of futility. But Soviet dissenters have made clear that campaigns on their behalf are important, that every effort to keep their cause alive serves to protect them and to restrain their rulers. So three such efforts in recent weeks are noteworthy and welcome.

title: Help for Cities That Need It Most
description: In a welcome display of perseverance, President Carter intends to resubmit an urban aid bill that Congress rejected last year. He is asking for $400 million over two years for communities in economic distress. The new bill deserves a better fate on Capitol Hill,than last year's request for $1 billion.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: DODGE PARKER

title: Khomeini Is Reported To Refuse Resignation Offered by Bazargan
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 9  Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan offered his resignation to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini last night, but the Ayatollah rejected it, a source close to the Prime Minister said today.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: ANNOUCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONE? TO 3543900 ?? 5:30 P.M FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS UNTIL 2:30 P.M ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M TO 4:30 P.M MONDAY ?? FRIDAY; NEW JEPS?? (201) MARKET 33900 WESTCHESTER CO AND ?? NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHTE PLAINS 95300 ?? CO (516) ?? SUFFOLK CO (516) 6691800 CONNECTICUT I ?? 3467757

title: The Ambitious Dance Sequences of Albert Reid
description: At almost any given moment, the dances that Albert Reid presented Thursday night at the American Theater Laboratory were attractive to watch. But only rarely were they satisfying from beginning to end.

title: Southern Justice
description: CULLMAN, Ala.  Breaking precedent with the Alabama law he unabashedly venerates, Judge Jack C. Riley of Cullman County Circuit Court last week removed from his jurisdiction any future criminal proceedings against Tommy Lee Hines, a young retarded black man whose arrest in May in Decatur, Ala. together with his conviction and sentencing in Cullman to 30 years in prison for the rape of a white woman have caused nearly 10 months of bitter racial protest in northern Alabama.

title: Irwin, on 62135, Ties Aaron for Shot Lead
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla.. March 9 (AP)  With no wind to hamper him, Hale Irwin shot a courserecord, 10underpar 62 today and surged into a tie with Tommy Aaron for the secondround lead in $300.000 Inverrary Golf Classic.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 10, 1979

title: Algerian Bank Gets Loan
description: LONDON, March 9 (UPI)  A syndicate of 25 banks signed a credit agreement today to provide $150 million for the Banque Exterieure d'Algerie, the largest of three stateowned commercial banks in Algeria, the Chase Manhattan Bank said. The syndication was well received in the Euromarket and participants in the loan included banks from the United States, France, Canada, Britain, Saudi Arabia, Belgium, West Germany, Japan, Abu Dhabi, Austria, Sweden, Luxembourg and Singapore.

title: Parental Pride Spurs Bidders at Spence School
description: Ordinarily, the atmosphere of the Spence School is far from combative. But with parental pride loosening purse strings the other evening at an auction fundraiser, the bidding became frankly fierce.

title: Bridge:
description: A preemptive bidder sometimes has one firstround control, but often none at all. So for his partner to consider a slam he needs a strong hand with three firstround controls. The funniest, or saddest, bridge story of the year so far, depending on one's point of view, hinged on the action of a player who disregarded this principle and leaped into slam without a single firstround control to his name.

title: Doug Sahm, Rocker From Texas
description: Doug Sahm, who was at the Lone Star Cafe Thursday night, has had a long and colorful career in rockandroll. He first emerged nationally in the mid1960's in San Francisco as the leader of the Sir Douglas Quintet, then made a few records in the early 1970's under his own name, and finally gravitated to the Austin, Tex., region and became a leader of that area's wild and woolly rock /rockabilly scene. Now he seems to have moved to New York, or at least he's spending a lot of time here, and his sets Thursday were part of a continuing series of engagements at the Texasflavored club on Fifth Avenue.

title: Oscar Rittenhouse, Jersey Aide, Dies of Injuries in a Plane Crash
description: Oscar W. Rittenhouse of Milford, N.J., president of the New Jersey County Prosecutors Association, died Thursday in Gulfport. Miss., where he was critically injured in the crash of a commercial airliner on March 1. He was 48 years old.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: In One Egyptian Village, Any American Is a Hero
description: DISOUNIS UM DINAR, Egypt, March 9  Khalid AbdeJ Aziz, a lively 9yearold in a greenstriped outfit, couldn't see the special train carrying the Presidents of the United States and Egypt because too many grownups were standing in front of him. But he shouted Long live President Carter! anyway.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON ASAFE mercuryvapor lamp, which avoids the dangerous ultraviolet radiation ordinarily emitted when a globe is fractured, has been invented for the DuroTest Corporation, North Bergen, N.J. The lamp quickly turns itself off when air enters, even from a small crack.

title: COMMODITIES
description: CHICAGO. March 9 (AP)  Speculation that continuing inflation has prompted the nation's central bank to tighten credit further sent interest rate futures lower today in trading on the commodities markets.

title: Books of The Times Spies From Yesteryear
description: Although it is heresy to say it, the novels written by the imitators of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle may be more fun to read than those of the master himself. Sherlock Holmes's pedantic style probably appealed to the desire of detectivcstory fans to rationalize their light reading as adventures in ratiocination. Holmes's insufferable condescension to Dr. Watson may well have been another projected wish of those same persons.

title: United Will Seek 4% Rise in Fares
description: United Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, will ask the Civil Aeronautics Board to approve a basic fare rise of 4 percent on all its flights within the 48 states to match an American Airlines request for a 4 percent increase, a United spokesman said yesterday.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: And so we say goodbye to Teng Hsiaoping and hello to Deng Xiaoping. Why? The change in the transliteration of Chinese names, adopted this week by The Times, is not meant as a Berlitzlike move to instruct Americans in Chinese. It is in fact the result of a program well over half a century old to help the Chinese understand Chinese as well as each other.

title: Striking Drivers Confront Mayor On Bus Dispute
description: Mayor Koch, confronted by an angry crowd of 400 striking schoolbus drivers in Brooklyn yesterday, urged the drivers to return to work and he pledged to help find a way to insure their job security.

title: Rifle Association Poll Says Majority Oppose More Gun Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  A new poll on gun control that appears to conflict with decades of previous polling on the subject was released yesterday by the National Rifle Association and reported that a majority of Americans saw no need for more laws governing firearms.

title: Sadat as Political Dramatist
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, March 9 There was great political theater in the triumphal train ride that President Anwar elSadat and President Carter took through the Nile Delta today and for hours it overshadowed and delaved the more significant private drama of their delicate negotiations over the precise terms of a peace agreement.

title: New Harnpshire Advances In E.C.A.C. Hockey, 52
description: BOSTON, March 9  The University of New Hampshire advanced to the championship game of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I hockey playoffs with a 52 victory over Cornell at Boston Garden tonight.

title: Music consort on Severity
description: Germanic severity was the theme of the evening at the concert Thursday at Carnegie Recital Hall presented by the New Music Consort. The program was devoted not only to German and Austrian music, but also to a particularly severe sort concerned with the applications of the Serialist idea to every corner of music.

title: U.S. Seeks to End Mortgage Barriers Facing Women
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  The Federal Government began an intensive campaign today to remove the remaining barriers facing women who apply for mortgage loans to buy homes.

title: Rate Rise For Small Saver Seen
description: The Carter Administration will soon allow the nation's thrift institutions to offer small savers interest rates that are more in line with the higher rates that are available to wealthier individuals and corporations, Robert H. McKinney, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said yesterday.

title: Consumer Debt Heavy In January
description: WASHINGTON. March 9  Consumer; contamed to borrow heavily in January. but the increase in their installment debt was smaller than in December, the Federal Reserve Board reported today

title: Miss Weinstein Now a Stein Aide
description: Helene Weinstein, who helped topple former Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut in last year's Democratic primary, has gone to work for Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan, Mr. Steingut's longtime political opponent.

title: Nets Lose 3d in Row As Seattle Triumphs
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., March 9 The Seattle SuperSonics played defense in the second half tonight the way Coach Lenny Wilkens would have it played.

title: Retail Sales in Area Soar
description: New York City's largest retailers experienced an exceptionally strong February, reporting an aggregate sales gain of 10.5 percent over the yearearlier month. It was the third consecutive month of gains exceeding the inflation rate.

title: In Iraq, a Quest for Tower of Babel and Hanging Gardens
description: BABYLON, Iraq  Iraqis are working feverishly to salvage the remains of this ancient center of the arts, science and trade, which has been laid waste by water, winds and man.

title: GARDENING
description: NOW that each day is a trifle longer than the one before, house plants are waking up. More daylight stimulates moreefficient photosynthesis , the manufacture of food within the leaves  and morerapid growth. During this period, from now through April, plants respond best to repotting.

title: The Face of Spring
description: JUST as everyone was coasting along with neutralcolored clothes and neutral makeup, fashion designers threw the cosmetics people a curve with some of the brightest spring colors and vivid color mixes in years. Who would have dreamed purple and red together or blue and yellow last year? Obviously, if a woman is not to look faceless, she will soon find herself at a cosmetics counter pleading for something new.

title: Reducing the Odds on Lost Luggage
description: At some airports, you cannot leave the baggageclaim area until a guard has matched the numbers on your ticket stub against those on the tags attached to your suitcases. At others, a chaotic honor system seems to prevail  or is it that some lines go not care?

title: Sarah E. Jones Is Married to Colin Cuskley
description: Sarah Elizabeth Jones, an assistant manager in international operations at the Chemical Bank, and Colin Bernard Cuskley, a manager for New York City's Financial Information Services Agency, were married yesterday in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Ernest Gordon performed the Protestant ceremony in the Princeton University Chapel, of which he is dean.

title: Histories to Trace Leadership in U.S.
description: James MacGregor Burns, the Williams College political scientist, is embarked on an ambitious historical undertaking: a threevolume history that will tell the story of the United States from the 1770's to the 1980's.

title: As a Fashion Model
description: Despite a hectic life that consists of preparing for shows and a good deal of traveling, Mrs. Pearce feels that her family has not suffered. Her children are Tracy, 21, Pamela, 19, and Tommy, 13.

title: IN THE NATION
description: National security is a magic phrase behind which dubious deeds and policies have long been hidden, as the nation should have learned in the Pentagon Papers and Watergate cases. Now these marvelously adaptable words are being used in a kind of graymail to enable Government officials and others to avoid prosecution on criminal charges.

title: The Nation
description: ATLANTA How to count the nation's poor has become the touchiest issue in the debate over plans for the 1980 census, as testimony in Washington pointed up again last week. It may also be the issue most prone to misunderstanding, as a recent study in the South illustrates.

title: Winston E. Theriot Fianc of Susan Bell
description: Susan Jane Bell and Winston Eames Theriot plan to be married April 21. Pauline W. Bell of Old Greenwich, Corm., and Alan W. Bell of Dix Hills, L.I., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor N. Theriot of Greenwich, Conn.

title: U.S. EFFORT ASSAILED BY GREEK CYPRIOTS
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 10  Washington's efforts to bring the feuding Cypriot communities to the conference table have caused considerable anger in the Greek part of this divided Mediterranean island.

title: Hartford Ranks Towns Wealth
description: HARIFORD MEMBERS of the General Assembly's Education Committee gave Yorke Allen Jr., a freshman Republican, a mock ovation when the new calculation of town wealth was released last week. Mr. Allen's hometown, New Canaan. turned out to be the richest community in the state.

title: A OneWoman Show About Women
description: HUNTINGTON STATION THE 40 or so selections in Viveca Lindfors's onewoman show, I Am a Woman, at the PAF / McDonald's Theater through April 28, were all written by or for women. The show is as simple, as redundant as that, from title to conclusion  the inevitable Helen Reddy song, I Am Woman.

title: Chase Film From Rouen:The Cast
description: If it were a paperback book you might pick it up to read on a short train ride. However, "The French Detective" is a movie  you can't take it with you. You have to go to it, and this presents the potential patron with the need to decide whether it's worth it. I think not, but I also realize that it may be just the kind of think mild anesthetic that some people call entertainment."The French Detective," which opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse, is not a whodunit, but a chase film about a tough, veteran Rouen cop (Lino Venture) and his younger sidekick (Patrick Dewaere), who must break all sorts of rules in their pursuit of a murderer working for a political candidate (Victor Lanoux).The film is not about politics, but about physical movement, about getting into and out of automobiles, about climbing stairs, about entering rooms and leaving them, and sometimes about walking on rooftops in the middle of the night  all the while seeking people who can put one in touch with someone else who may or may not know the whereabouts of still another person. It makes no difference that you have often forgotten who the people are or why they are being sought.Pursuit is the game and the performances by Mr. Ventura and Mr. Lanoux are satisfactory, but Mr. Dewaere, who plays a man who's supposed to be in his mid-30's, behaves as if he hadn't yet made his first communion. I think he means to be cute.Pierre Granier-Deferre, the director, has been represented here by one good film. "The Cat," and one terrible film, "A Woman at Her Window." "The French Detective" is somewhere in between. The exterior shots of Rouen are a nice change from the familiar views of Paris we usually see in other, very similar French films.

title: Mailbox: Joe Torre Charged With Error
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mendez at Sebring: Promoter and Driver
description: In the 1960's, the 12 Hours of Sebring sportscar race was a happening for thousands of college kids from across the country. They would leave books and studies behind and flock to Florida to soak up sun and beer, attend parties into the wee hours and watch the sleek racing cars drone into the night.

title: Vacationing on Hispaniola, Troubled Island in the Sun
description: The idea had been to find a small, quiet spot beside a beach with nothing between us and the Caribbean sun but an occasional coconut palm. If that's what you want, our travel agent said disapprovingly, try Jacmel. Nobody has ever heard of it. You'll be out of your skull in three days.

title: The Face of Spring Is Vividly Different
description: JUST as everyone was coasting along with neutralcolored clothes and neutral makeup, fashion designers threw the cosmetics people a curve with some of the brightest spring colors and vivid color mixes in years. Who would have dreamed purple and red together or blue and yellow last year? Obviously, a woman is not to look faceless, she will soon find herself at a cosmetics counter pleading for something new.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Morris L. West's novel Proteus is about modern terrorism and bow reasonable men can combat it. But as one of the more popular philosophical novelists, his story isn't simply a caper or a kneecapper. (The newly invented slang verb, to kneecap  shooting a man in the legs without killing him  is about the only interesting linguistic contribution of Italy's Red Brigades.) Mr. West is known for his theological thrillers that pose hard, frequently unanswerable questions about today's turbulent world  including the constraints on liberty imposed by democratic societies.

title: Judith H. Bashover Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Bashover of Massapequa Park, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Hannah Bashover, to Ronald I. Rubinstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Noel Rubinstein of Riverdale.

title: Westchester Fights Robin Hood Budget
description: ALBANY THE fight between Governor Carey and county officials around the state has become almost as much a part of life in this capital as the bonechilling weather or latenight camaraderie.

title: Ed Ball at 91: Embattled, Implacable
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  I suppose some people might call me tight with a dollar, Edward Ball was saying the other day as the late winter sun cut through the blinds on his office windows and fell in warm rails on a lush oriental rug beneath his feet.

title: Birth Control Urged To Cut Relief Costs
description: SHOULD ??wed mothers who are ?? welfare be required to p??a?? control? This sugge?? at the heart of welfare reco??tions urged by a committee of businessmen that is advising Governor Byrne on ways to make government mere businesslike.

title: Route 1 Cuts Through Many Worlds
description: FORTY years ago the Federal Writers Project's American Guide suggested that motcrists who wish to test their skill on a modern highway should follow U.S.I. Today the famous old MainetoKeyWest route is hardly a highway at all, and where it dips and jughandles through the metropolitan region, U.S.I changes names and character again and again. It cuts across the Connecticut, New York and New Jersey suburbs, mirroring their economic and social conditions.

title: Jogging Suits, Too, Are Off and Running In a Race for Style
description: THE brilliantly colored velour tops with the tiny images of polo players, attesting to the tact that they were designed by Ralph Lauren, are as pure in design as sweatshirts. But instead of battleship gray, they are in such colors as yellow, red. green or cyclamen pink, set off by white bands.

title: Police Seeking Diamond Dealer, Missing With $500,000 in Gems
description: The police continued their search yesterday for Martin Paretzky, a 71yearold diamond dealer who has been missing since last Wednesday and was believed to have been carrying up to $500,000 worth of precious stones when he disappeared.

title: Yankees Lose, but John Excels
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 10  Tommy John pitched three stong innings today against the Baltimore Orioles in his debut as a New York Yankee.

title: Richard White Is Fianc Of Karen Jill Newman
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Newman of North Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Jill Newman to Richard D. White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome B. White of Valley Stream, L.I., and Philadelphia. A November wedding is planned.

title: Police Act to Improve Phone Replies to Trim Errors Found in Study
description: The New York Police Department is taking steps to improve its responses to telephone requests for information following a department study that found that nearly a third of those who called were given incorrect or inadequate answers.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Is your 78record of Chattanooga ChooChoo so scratchy it sounds more like the 8:10 to New York? The slick new big band reproductions in stereo just aren't the same, are they? Not to worry. Pace University is holding its third annual 1940's danceband bash from 9 P.M. to 1 A.M. Friday.

title: Fallout From China Syndrome Has Already Begun
description: Los ANGELES  The China Syndrome has nothing to do with China. It is a $6million movie, starring Jane Fonda, Jack Lemmon and Michael Douglas that opens Friday at the Loews State and Tower East, whose subject matter  an accident in a nuclear power plant  is as explosive as the metaphor of its title. In nuclear slang, the China syndrome could theoretically occur if the radioactive core of a nuclear plant were uncovered, allowing the searing heat of the core to melt through the steel pressure vessel, through the concrete bottom of the building, through the earth and into China. (More likely, if it did melt into the ground, the core would send jets of deadly radioactive steam into the atmosphere.) Whether such an accident is a real and present danger or a possibility as remote as a meteor landing in Times Square is a question the film does rat answer.

title: C.I.A. Sought to Put Wiretap on Aide to Ayatollah
description: WASHINGTON, March 10  The Central Intelligence Agency wanted last autumn to wiretap the telephone of Dr. Ibrahim Yandi, a principal aide of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian religious leader, but was barred from the covert operation because Dr. Yazdi is an American citizen, Administration officials say. Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian religious leader, but was barred from the covert operation because Dr. Yazdi is an American citizen, Administration officials say.

title: 54 Needless Years in Institutions Created a Mental Cripple, Suit Says
description: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., March 9Jack Smith was born in the State Hospital for the mentally ill here 54 years ago and was institutionalized until recently.

title: Warehouseman Is Said to Admit Altering Records for Billy Carter
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 A 31yearold Georgia warehouseman has said that on the instructions of President Carter's brother, Billy, he manipulated records to hide the movement of collateral for part of nearly $3 million in bank loans to the Carter family warehouse, The Washington Post has reported.

title: Mamaroneck Woman Found Slain In a Men's Store in Washington
description: A 19yearold Georgetown University student from Mamaroneck, N.Y., was beaten and strangled yesterday afternoon while working alone in a clothing store in the Georgetown section of Washington, D.C., according to police in the capitol.

title: Lewis Tops Wagner for Girls' Title
description: The third quarter told the story yesterday at the Public Schools Athletic League girls' basketball championship game at St. John's University. where Francis Lewis High School defeated Susan Wagner, 6141. Lewis led at halftime, 2925, and the game looked as if it was going to De close. Four minutes into the third quarter, Lewis settled the issue, running off 17 straight points and establishing a lead it never lost.

title: Dr. S.A. Levy, Veterinarian, Will Marry Bonnie McGow
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. McGow of Pine Orchard, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Bonnie McGow. to Dr. Steven A. Levy. a veterinarian in Guilford, Conn.

title: Koch's Offer Woos Puerto Ricans
description: Mayor Koch offered yesterday to place qualified employees of the discontinued Puerto Rican Community Development Project in supervisory positions in the city's Summer Youth Employment Project.

title: Root of All Evil (Insufficient Funds Dept.)
description: LAST Tuesday, voters in Bradley Beach soundly rejected a referendum that would have allowed borough officials to spend $80,000 more than state budget limits permit. The money was earmarked for pay increases for policemen and other municipal employees and for a new police car.

title: Tracing Discarded Poisons
description: HARTFORD IN the seemingly pristine woodlands of snowcovered Plainfield, a father and son out on a winter hunting trip stumbled on a secluded nesting scene of an unexpected sort  55gallon barrels being surreptitiously transferred from a truck into a gravel pit. The father sent his son home to get a camera, and the resulting photographs, which were detailed enough to show the licenseplate numbers on the truck, gave the state its first evidence of a major illegal dump site for industrial chemical wastes.

title: Peter George Heytler Jr. Fianc of Ellen S. Rieser
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Willy Rieser of Avon, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Sue Rieser, to Peter George Heytler Jr., son of Dr. Heytler of Wilmington, Del., and the late Marilyn M. Heytler.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Boris Goldovsky has this fierce interest in opera and will travel. Today at 2:30 P.M. the entertaining virtuoso, who used to emcee the Metropolitan Opera News of the Air, will proselytize at Coe Hall in Oyster Bay, lecturing on the musical form and making pertinent points with demonstrations by members of his company of singers. Coe Hall is at Planting Fields Arboretum, Planting Fields Road. Admission is $6. 7591399.

title: Auto Club Reports Travel Rise
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)  The American Automobile Association has reported figures indicating that travel throughout the United States increased by 2.2 percent in 1978 over the preceding year. The association cited a survey that measured travel by counting requests from its members for individually prepared packets of maps and route information.

title: Allfson Gets Spot Near Yarborough
description: RICHMOND, March 10 (AP)Donnie Allison locked up the 11th position today as 20 cars qualified in time trials to round out the 30car field in tomorrow's Richmond 400 NASCAR Grand National stock car race.

title: On the Corporate Treadmill
description: WHAT in the world are those men and women doing running through the corridors of the Emhart Corporation in Farmington at 7 o'clock in the morning?

title: A Career by Design And by Accident
description: JEWELRY was big and heavy six years ago, so when you wore something it was noticed, said Muriel Rosmarin, explaining the start of her career as a jewelry designer.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Death to Despotism Under Any Cover, Was the Cry Last Week
description: TEHERAN, Iran  I'll never wear a veil. I'll never wear a chador. I'll never put on a scarf. No man  not the Shah, not Khomeini, and not anyone else  will ever make me dress as he pleases. The women of Iran have been unveiled for three generations, and we will fight anyone who bars our way.

title: Nettles: Making Case For More Pay
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla March 10 Ninety feet from home plate, baseball's best third baseman taps his glove with a fist and crouches in anticipation.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Realty News
description: Deloitte Haskins & Sells, the account ing concern, and the AddressographMultigraph Corporation are taking space at the World Trade Center.

title: The Dominican Republic
description: We had wanted to try a different kind of lowcost vacation. As fugitives from the frost belt, we. needed a warm and sunny land, but scenic stretches of beach were not enough. Could we find a retreat that was also interesting politically and historically, that would tell us something about the problems of a developing society? When we decided on the Dominican Republic, which along with Haiti forms the island of Hispaniola, we did not anticipate that its problems would limit our time in the sun.

title: Miss Van Norden To Be Wed June 6 To J.A. Anderson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Montagnie Van Norden of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kristina Van Norden, to John Andrew Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Willam Anderson of Kenosha, Wis. A June 6 wedding is planned.

title: The World
description: The will of Allah can sit hard on mortal man. Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan, his authority frequently superseded by Islamic committees that answer only to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, drove in a snowstorm last week to the Ayatollah's headquarters in the holy city of Qum and offered his resignation. The Ayatollah rejected the offer, telling Mr. Bazargan that it was his religious duty to say on. Mr. Bazargan agreed.

title: Mary McCabe, Teacher, Fiance of John H.K. Belt
description: The engagement of Mary Jane McCabe to John Hewlett Keyes Belt has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Thomas McCabe of Riverdale, the Bronx. Mr. Belt is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Banks Belt of Glen Cove and Southampton, L.I.

title: World News Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Marth 10 (AP) The Tanzanians and Ugandan exiles invading Uganda are advancing slowly and carefully toward Kampala, according to Ugandan exile sources here. They said the invading forces had not been repulsed as reported by Uganda's President, Idi Amin.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE LIGHTHOUSE, on the Hudson in West New York, has a tower, a beacon and a spectacular view of the Manhattan skyline. Although difficult for an outoftowner to spot along River Road, the place was a sailors hangout for 150 years and dates almost to the time when Aaron Burr killed Alexander Hamilton on the cliffs nearby.

title: Tolstoy Staged In Piscator Style
description: TO Maria Lei Piscator, the ti me is ripe for a revival of the stage adaptation of Tolstoy's War and Peace by her late husband. Erwin Piscator. The production that the theater arts department at the State University at Stony Brook is staging couldn't have come at a better time. according to the gidow of The director who was, with l;ertit Bloch!, founder of the Epic Theater style of dramaturgy.

title: The Region
description: Mayor Koch's travails with the black and Hispanic communities continued last week when he showed the flag in Harlem. He held the 17th of his constituent hours at Intermediate School 10 and spoke individually to people who had taken numbers for an audience with him. After an hour, though, hecklers took over and the Mayor had to leave  by the front door, as he had vowed to do but under heavy guard.

title: LODEWYK J. JISKOOT
description: Dodewyk J. Jisk?? ?? president of Thomson ?? ties Inc., a New york ?? ny, died Thursday at ?? in Manhattan. He was 63 years ?? resident of Manhattan and W?? R.I.

title: 4 Top Inspectors Named To Curb Waste by U.S
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) President Carter has selected inspectors general for the Commerce and Transportation Departments, the space agency and the Small Business Administration, the White House has announced.

title: What's Doing in PORTLAND, OREGON
description: CITY OF ROSES  Raindrops and tourists are facts of life in Portland, and residents have adjusted well to steady streams of both. All that rain keeps Oregon green, and all those tourists give Portlanders a chance to show off their City of Roses. The name arises from the community's rose culture, which is practiced in its gardens and celebrated in its annual 10day Rose Festival in June.

title: Getting Stuck on Bumpers
description: I WAS driving home on Interstate 80 when, all of a sudden, a car swerved into my lane, coming frighteningly close to hitting me. I am an easygoing guy, but I get angry, to say the least, when someone nearly kills me, and so I hit the horn with all the force that fear and anger can muster.

title: After Years Out of Favor, Suits Come Striding Back

title: Montana House Upholds Vote
description: HELENA, Mont., March 10 (AP) The Montana House of Representatives killed today a resolution reaffirming a March 22 deadline for state ratification of the proposed equal rights amendment. The ratification will stand for two years.

title: SALT, In Perspective
description: WASHINGTON  In the jargon of the journalist, the question of ratifying the SALT II agreement is often shortened to ratifying SALT. A failure to ratify the projected agreement with the Soviet Union is considered a defeat for SALT, whereas a twothirds majority for the agreement is hailed as victory for SALT.

title: Pakistan Airlines Leases the Roosevelt
description: Pakistan International Airlines has agreed to lease the Roosevelt Hotel on Madison Avenue from a partnership headed by Paul Milstein, the developer.

title: The Festival's the Thing at Hofstra
description: The plays of Sha??Spe??

title: THEATER
description: SOME jobs come with assumptions about them built in. For example, truck drivers know the good places to eat along the highways. Minimal thought will reveal how ridiculous that is. In my line of work, it is assumed that all theater critics like and will defend the works of all major playwrights. That is a falsehood too, or r ft is in my case. I am always hoping to like the plays of Bertolt Brecht, and I rarely if ever do. I have somewhat better time at those plays he wrote to be accompanied by the music of Kurt Weill, whom I do admire. Unfortunately, Galileo is not one of these.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE CULTURE OF NARCISSISM, by Christopher Lasch. (Norton, $11.95.) Civilized hellfire sermon on the decay permeating modern American life.

title: N.F.L. Is Basking in Its Income
description: The National Football League's annual meeting begins tomorrow in Honolulu and the thin agenda reflects the tranquil times this sport is enjoying. Pete Rozelle, the commissioner, said recently that the problems facing the league as to quantity and quality were the fewest he had known since taking office 19 years ago.

title: DINING OUT; It's the Only Game in Town
description: WHEN it comes to food, novelty for its own sake is never advisable. So it often is with the preparation of wild game by chefs who treat such exotics as curiosities or seasonal specialties and prepare them with no particular artistry at all.

title: Alice Baldridge Wed to Banker
description: The marriage of Alice Elizabeth Baldridge, an interior designer, to Delos Walker Wainwright, an assistant treasurer of the J. Henry Schroder Bank and Trust Company, took place yesterday in Hewlett, L.I.

title: Sharp Cut in Illegal Heroin Trade Is Reported by 2 Federal Officials
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)There has been a sharp decline in the availability of heroin in the United States as a result of international efforts to reduce illegal trafficking in the drug, according to two Administration officials.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Einstein's Theories Are Remote From Everyday Experience  but They Work
description: Question. Why has Einstein become a folk hero? all the fuss over his hundredth birthday next Wednesday justified?

title: Letters: Taormina  Blue Sky, Blue Sea and Etna, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: STAMPS
description: One of the most prestigious yearly sales in the realm of philately, the Rarities of the World sale comes up shortly. It not only lives up to its name with annual offerings of stamps that make collectors drool with desire, but they are sold at prices that make dealers drool. What is even rarer  in fact unique  it is the only stamp auction to create its own collectible.

title: A Street of Dreams That's Worth a Trek
description: CEDAPHURST IN Beverly Hills, it's Rodeo Drive. In Chicago, it's North Michigan Avenue. In Manhattan, the shopping streets are Madison Al.'nup and Fifth Avenue. In Cedarhurst, it's Central Avenue.

title: The World
description: PEKING  The Guoguang porcelain plant in Hunan Province, which specializes in dinnerware, tea services, and painted vases for the export market, no longer books its orders through a state trading corporation. The plant now deals directly with its customers in the United States and other countries. This represents a step forward in the campaign to boost hard currency earnings, the New China News Agency explained, because previously red tape often hampered production and the plant, out of direct touch with its markets, built up large stockpiles of products not in demand. The businesslike switch illustrates China's high priority on foreign earnings in its drive to modernize and underscores new flexibility in the economy.

title: Bob Hope Is Subject Of Tribute
description: Between 1938 and 1972, Bob Hope was in, by his own count, 60 films. Though lucrative, none of them ever brought him even a nomination for an Academy Award. This failure has, of course, long been a mainstay of his jokebag. Now, seven years after his most recent film, the 75yearold Mr. Hope's contribution to the American cinema will be 4cknowledged, not by Hollywood, but by the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: Authorities in Ontario Reject Quebec's Plan To Attain Sovereignty
description: OTTAWA, March 10  Canada's two largest provinces went off in opposite political directions this week, leaving hitle prospect for a compromise that wold keep them in the same country.

title: They'll Turn Up, She Said
description: When a goodnatured Aspen Airways ticket agent asked whether I wanted to check my bags through to New York, turned to my fianc and asked: Should we take a chance?

title: Within the Limits, Estonians Showed Their Resentment Last Week
description: RIGA, U.S.S.R.  Ever since the Soviet Army invited itself into Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia at the beginning of World War II, many Americans have regarded the Baltic states as captive nations held in Soviet bondage, in the words of the New Yorkbased Supreme Committee for the Liberation of Lithuania.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY Another Day, Another Dollar (Maybe)
description: IT WAS a great relief to hear from President Carter a few weeks ago that his next national budget, while lean and austere, will be nonetheless compassionate. And even though all that money kept being deducted from my salary check, I had continued to feel fine  that is, until I opened my mail the other day.

title: Opponents of Rights Proposal Say That It Will Soon Die in 30 States
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)  The original time limit for ratifying the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution ends in 12 days and opponents argue that the amendment will expire with it in at least 30 states.

title: S.A. Sterling Fianc Of Susan F. Fisher
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Blaine Fisher of Shaker Heights, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Faith Fisher, to Scott Andrew Sterling, son of Morton A. Sterling of Beverly Hills, Calif., and the late Marian Kenton Sterling. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Older Artists Show They Aren't the Retiring Kind
description: GREAT NECK RETIREMENT is a, term not often heard in connection with a career in art. Artists may retire from supplementary jobs, such as teaching, design or museum work, but they often do so with relief and the anticipiation of more time to devote to their true calling. They usually work until they drop, and, like Monet, may produce their most visionary work toward the end of their careers.

title: Palestinian Guerrillas Slain by Israeli Army In a West Bank Clash
description: JERUSALEM, March 10  An Israeli army force killed four Palestinian guerrillas in a clash today on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River, a military spokesman said. There were no Israeli casualties, he said.

title: Turnbull, Wade in Net Final
description: PHILADELPHIA. March 10  After a sleepless night and a pain wracked day. Wendy Turnbull, who was, unable to get her first point for 35 minutes, fought her way into the final of a $125,000 women's pro tournamont tonight by defeating Rosie Casals, 06, 62, 62.

title: Credit Cards for Parking Tickets
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)  District of Columbia officials said yesterday that they planned to allow motorists to use credit cards to pay their parking tickets and towing fees.

title: Integrating a New Group: The Old
description: IN Danbury a former motor inn has just been turned into 98 apartments for the elderly. In Vernon the old U.S. Envelope factory is undergoing similar recycling for senior citizens. In New Britain two schools are being refurbished for the sam purpose, as is the historic Mohican Hotel in New London.

title: John Endicott, Lawyer, Marries Jane McMahon
description: Jane Scott McMahon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald McMahon of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday afternoon to John Endicott, son of Mrs. Robert Rantoul Endicott of Washington Depot, Conn., and the late Mr. Endicott. Msgr. Edward M. Connors performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary.

title: Restitution Plan Seeks to Cut Juveniles' Jail Terms
description: GREENVALE, L.I., March 10  A $2.5 million program to increase the use of restitution as an alternative to jail for juvenile offenders in nonviolent crimes was started by New York State this week.

title: TV VIEW
description: With the passing of another Sweeps month  one of those periodic bouts of ratings madness that determine advertising rates for the next fiscal quarter  television has returned to its weekly series. And the landscape is indeed bleak.

title: Marijuana Crops Revive California Town
description: GARBERVILLE, Calif., March 9 Spring has come early to the coastal mountains. Already people in this rugged backwoods area are buying fertilizer and trading seeds for planting.

title: City U. Faculty Gets Larger Role In Selection of College Presidents
description: The Board of Higher Education ended a dispute with the faculty of the City University of New york over the selection of college presidents last week, voting to allow faculty members greater participation on search committees.

title: Paul S. Wissel Plans to Wed Barbara Luke
description: Barbara Joan Luke of New York, a clinical specialist in nutrition at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, and Paul Stephen Wissel, who is in his fourth year at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, plan to be married May 26 at the Greenville Community Reformed Church in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: A Cairo Crowd At Coffeehouse Dotes on Carter
description: CAIRO, March 10The repeated applause that interrupted President Carter's speech to the Egyptian Parliament today worried the men who had crowded around the small television set in the Zahrit Bab elLouq coffeehouse.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: Accessories Add the Accents In Blue, Red, Yellow and Purple
description: ACCESSORIES play a vital part in accenting a wardrobe. Good jewelry such as rings and watches may be seasonless, but shoes, hats, belts and the like are usually changed along with the pages of the calendar.

title: Barbara Moore Vested Fiance of William Oliver
description: Barbara Moore Vested of New York, an account supervisor with Wells, Rich, Greene Advertising Inc., and William Thomas Oliver, also of New York, plan to be married May 11.

title: WHAT THEY'RE DOING TOGETHER
description: We are a family, says Eugenia Zukerman, that shares as much together as we can Pinchas was with me when each of our two daughtern was born, and happily involved himself in the changing, feeding and bathing routines. Arianna is now 6 and Natalie 3  totally different in looks and personalities, but both able to constantly surprise us with their ability to understand and accept the very structured life of performing musicians. They see us practice every day, want to come to all our concerts, and while the pain of leaving them when one or both of us performs out of town is very real, we hope that by letting them share our career  not only our accomplishments but our joy in our music  they will have the security children need. My husband and I knew that any children of ours would either love or hate music there would be no middle ground Fortunately, Arianna and Natalia love it. And our daily rituals or storytelling and playtime now include some allfamily concerts.

title: Macero Plays Tribute to Mingus
description: The Duke Ellington Composers Series, 12 weekly programs presented by the St. Peter's Church Jazz Ministry, in which a composer in the modern idiom will perform and, at times, discuss his work, began Thursday at the church with an evening by Teo Macero, who dedicated the program to the memory of Charles Mingus, the jazz bassist and composer.

title: Avery Moore Plans To Be Wed May 19
description: Mr. and Mrs. James E. Moore of Atlanta have announced the engagement of their daughter, Avery Ashburn Moore, to Carl Roerig Hartrampf 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hartrampf, also of Atlanta.

title: Miss Gibson, Walter Brown Plan Nuptials
description: Henry van Dyke Gibson of Washington, Conn., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Patricia Rae Gibson, to Walter Emerson Brown, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Emerson Brown of Hackensack, N.J. Miss Gibson also is a daughter of the late Barbara Housh Gibson.

title: Academic Words to Fill Marshall Field Mansion
description: LLOYD HARBOR, L.I.  After more than two decades of silence and darkness, the Marshall Field mansion in Caumsett State Park will again be filled with words and light.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ALTROUGH he is at least two years away from running for Governor, John J. Degnan, the state's Attorney General, has had a taste of the minus side of public life.

title: ART VIEW
description: An American who exhibited in the Armory Show of 1913, who then became one of the first painters of any nationality to be represented in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modem Art after its founding in 1929, and who had the additional distinction of being one of the leading teachers of his day, does not sound like a candidate for historical oblivion. Yet who today ever speaks of Kenneth Hayes Miller (18761952)? His is now one of those names known only to students and dealers of American art, and to certain curators and collectors perhaps, but it is no longer a name one needs to know in order to speak with influence and authority about American art in the 20th century.

title: GARCIA ASKS CARTER TO FREE 4 PRISONERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 10  Many people remember the day in 1950 when two Puerto Rican nationalists tried to shoot their way into Blair House, the temporary residence of President Harry S. Truman, in an attempt to assassinate the President. Representative Robert Garcia of the Bronx remembers it more than most.

title: Iranian Oil Returns, Up to a Point, But More Price Rises Due
description: Iran turned the oil spigot back on last week. Hassan Nazih, chairman of the National Iranian Oil Company, switched on a valve at Kharg Island, sending a flow of oil through a 48inch pipe to a Japanese tanker as the loading platform shook with the rush.

title: Florence Brobeck, at 84, Food Writer and Editor
description: Florence Brobeck, former women's editor of The New York Herald Tribune. onetime food columnist for The New York Times Magazine and a bestselling cookbook author, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 84 years old.

title: Letters TO THE EDITOR
description: To me the quote of the year is by Elia Kazan in The View From a Turkish Prison (Feb. 4): I hope . . . I can bring Turkey and Greece a little closer together. As a native of Lesbos, I know that in Greece. and I imagine it is the same in Turkey, the national paranoia is so keen and pervasive that even the thought of trying to bring Turkey and Greece a little closer is considered close to treason. (I heard of an English teacher in Athens who was deported within 24 hours because he had suggested that his students, as an exercise, discuss the merits of the Turkish position in the oilrights controversy.

title: Job Loss Linked to Abortion
description: GREENBRAE, Calif., March 10 (AP) A former clerk for Assemblyman William Filante has filed a sex discriminalion complaint with the state contending that she was dismissed because she asked for a day off for an abortion. Mr. Filante replied yesterday that Bella Julie Bernard, 24 years old, had been dismissed because she didn't have the skills we thought she had. He said the decision to end her $675amonth job in his Marin County office was made a week before anyone knew she was pregnant.

title: Calf Trapped In Cold Ravine Is Doing Well
description: REDWOOD FALLS, Minn., March 10 (AP)  The Arctic Calf of Delhi, Minn., has spent almost half his life alone, confined to a narrow ravine along Rice Creek west of Redwood Falls.

title: A Guide to Bargains Can Be a Good Buy
description: JOY and Tony de Chiara of Old Greenwich had long been interested in recycling, but little realized that concern over wastefulness and an instinct for bargain hunting would bring Mrs. de Chiara, Brownie leader and P.T.A. member, back into the job market after a hiatus of 15 years.

title: After Years Out of Favor, Suits Come Striding Back

Diane Von Furstenberg frequently slipped a tweed jacket over her printed jersey dress. Giorgio Armani's meticulously tailored jackets became the status symbols of the moment.

But instead of battleship gray, they are in such colors as yellow, red, green or cyclamen pink, set off by white bands.

As the conversation ended, he said, If you're ever out here, stop by. When a visitor to the California Angels training camp phoned him, he growled, I don't

title: Spring's Slim and Colorful Silhouette
description: IF you want to be in fashion, you'll have to be in shape. Those big loose clothes of last year that hid a few extra pounds around the middle have been replaced by slim, bodyconscious silhouettes that are pulled in at the waist and narrow across the hips.

title: Eclectic Is Electric, Musical Brothers Find
description: NEW HYDE PARK WE call ourselves Jekyll and Hyde sometimes, Don Gabis said, referring to the fact that he and his brother Jack perform two somewhat disparate types of music. We're always asking ourselves, What are we going to do now, rock or bluegrass? But it's all strains of the same thing.

title: Route 1 Cuts Through Many Worlds
description: FORTY years ago the Federal Writers Project's American Guide suggested that motorists who wish to test their skill on a modem highway should follow U.S. 1. Today the famous old MainetoKeyWest route is hardly a highway at all, and where it dips and jughandles through the metropolitan region, u.b. changes names and character again and again. It cuts across the Connecticut, New York and New Jersey suburbs, mirroring their economic and social conditions.

title: Bernadette Castro Bride of Physician
description: St. Patrick's Cathedral was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Bernadette Castro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Castro of Lloyd Harbor. L.I., and Ocala, Fla., to Dr. Peter Matthew Guida, a widower of Searingtown, L.I., son of Mrs. Thomas Guida of Long Island City, Queens, and the late Mr. Guida.

title: Miss Hearst and Fiance Get a Marriage License
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 (UPI)  Patricia Hearst, the newspaper heiress, and a nervous Bernard Shaw obtained a marriage license yesterday after paying $6 and presenting blood test information.

title: A Port Project Goes Awry in Italy
description: GIOIA TAURO, Italy, March 6  Many thousands of olive and orange trees were cut in this fertile southern plain between the harsh mountains of Calabria and the deep blue sea. An entire fishing village of 160 families was relocated. Chartered dredgers sailed here from the Netherlands and giant bulldozers and cranes came from northern Italy.

title: Susanna Freed Married To Robert S. Vavasour
description: Susanna Freed, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Freed of Lafayette Hill, Pa., was married yesterday to Robert Shanley Vavasour, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Vavasour of Rye, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University by the Rev. James Poisson, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: Meeting last week in Cincinnati, representatives of 10 Protestant denominations came close to endorsing a proposal that would lead to a common clergy. A revised version of the proposal is to be considered in January.

title: SPORTS
description: I DON'T KNOW if you noticed it,  but Joel Schiavone bought the New Haven Nighthawks Hockey Club the other day. And he did it in style, too. Invited hundreds of fans and hockey notables to a champagne party at centerice of the New Haven Coliseum, gave away the champagne

title: A 15YearOld, Who Gets Around
description: IT'S 5:15 in the morning and a biting winter wind whips around 15yearold Rick Carey as he walks up the entrance to the swimmingpool complex of Manhattanville College in Purchase. Inside, he changes into a bathing suit under a dim light and then saunters onto the cold tile deck of the pool area for the first of his two daily practice sessions.

title: Fashion
description: Fashion

title: Space
description: PASADENA, Calif.  There was a time when the other planets and their moons were little more than points of light in the night sky. Now, they are being discovered as distinctive worlds, their images etched on the mind through that electronic extension of the human eye, the spacecraftborne camera.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Behind the cover. Now a superb TV drama! exclaims a banner across the top. Below it, a small color photograph shows a couple eyeing each other pensive. ly, obviously a scene from the television show. At the bottom, a block of type promises the haunting story of a marriage. . . . Behind this cover, quite like those on dozens of other paperbacks currently on display in the massmarket racks, is an extraordinary book: Too Far to Go: The Maples Stories, the work John Updike, whom many critics consider the most gifted writer of his generation. Its publication is certainly one of the season's literary events.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: THERMOSTATS may go down in Westchester apartments and rents go up because of a shortage of heating oil and a rise in costs. This month the Rent Guidelines Board will hold public hearings to decide on rent levels to go into erect July 1, and apartment owners will cite a 27 percent increase in fueloil prices since summer to support their claim for higher rents.

title: A Position Report on Corporate Wives
description: Diane is the 40yearold, collegeeducated wife of a successful executive at a large Midwest corporation. Her own needs and happiness come second to those of her husband, and third and fourth to those of their two children. Each time the company has moved her husband to another location, she has smiled bravely and talked about the great opportunity. She accepts gracefully the need to entertain people she often dislikes and takes great pains to make a good impression on her husband's superiors. She has recently taken a parttime job, but she carefully arranges her hours and vacations to coincide with her husband's.

title: Stamford Is Crowded Enough Already
description: STAMFORD

title: When Running Shows, It's a Woman's World, Too.
description: PARAMUS THE antiques field has become an increasingly popular one with women, not only as buyers but also as dealers. But their role does not stop there. One of the biggest managers of antiques shows in New Jersey is a woman, too.

title: From Brick to Glass In Grand Central Area
description: The city's recent surge of realestate activity in the Grand Central Terminal area, some community leaders and preservationists maintain, is jeopardizing the survival of many examples of an early generation of skyscrapers and threatening to substantially alter the architectural character of this important commercial neighborhood.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The bestwatched holeintheground in the world has probably been Le Trou, the excavation on the site of Les Hanes, the demolished produce market in the heart of Paris. It has also been the most controversial holeintheground, first for the international protest that accompanied the destruction of Victor Baltard's 19thcentury glassandiron pavilion when the belly of Paris was moved to suburban Rungis; and after, for the equally widespread debate over what would fill it, in the plans for the future use of the land.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Wednesday  Motorsports Club of North Jersey meeting. at Barcelona's Restaurant, 39 Harrison Avenue, Garfield, N.J., at 8:30 P.M. All interested welcome. Information: (201) 3850862.

title: Headliners
description: Turn of the Screw

title: Volunteer Units Respond to Social Change
description: RESPONDING to changing marriage, birth and work patterns among suburban women, Westchester's volunteer organizations have altered their meeting hours, decreased membership responsibilities, and begun offering alternative membership plans to area residents.

title: Glass's Einstein Is Aural Magic
description: Einstein on the Beach, which will be released as a fourdisk album on the Tomato label this week, comes just in time for the Einstein centenary and is a landmark in the recorded history of recent American music. It should be of interest to several different and usually disparate audiences, and its ability to attract such diversity is itself one of the strongest signs of its success.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Claudio Arrau, one of the world's foremost pianists, will peform at the Plaza for the Performing Arts, 30 Van Brunt Street, Englewood. The concert starts at 3 P.M.

title: The Things That Go Buzz! in the Night
description: PERTH AMBOY THE noise began late one November afternoon in 1977. All of a sudden, Adele Wesley remembers, she heard a loud screech from somewhere over the water behind her home here.

title: Douglas MacKay Fianc Of Katherine S. White
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Blunt White of Stonington. Conn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Shelton White, to Douglas W MacKay, son of William E. MacKay, also of Stonington, and the late Jane MacKay. The wedding is planned for September.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: COPENHAGEN Nothing and nobody had prepared me for the absolute hilarity of Kermesse in Bruges, an 1851 ballet by August Bournonville that was just revived in a new production in Copenhagen by the Royal Danish Ballet. At the first night, which recently attended, the number of children in the audience made it clear that the Danes consider it a ballet for adults and children alike. The Queen of Denmark came with her consort and two young sons. Yet Kermesse Bruges (The Fair in Bruges) is also that rarity in the international ballet repertory  a perfect and trice comic work of art, serious in purpose and unforced in the consistent thread of humour that weaves in so naturally with such dramatic logic through its entirety.

title: E.P.A. Unit Alters Name
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 Federal agencies that run hundreds of programs in thousands of places often employ public relations staffs to tell the taxpayers what they are doing. At the Pentagon, for example, public relations work is conducted by the Public Affairs Office, and at the Department of Justice it is done by the Public Information Office.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: I am writing on behalf of, and at the express request of, the Executive Committee of the New Jersey Coalition of Penal Reform, of which I am a member.

title: Route 1 Cuts Through Many Worlds
description: FORTY years ago the Federal Writers Project's American Guide suggested that motorists who wish to test their skill on a modern highway should follow U.S. 1. Today the famous old MainetoKeyWest route is hardly a highway at all, and where it dips and jughandles through the metropolitan region, U.S. changes names and character again and again. It cuts across the Connecticut, New York and New Jersey suburbs, mirroring their economic and social conditions.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The excellent article by Douglas Fleisher and Jonathan Salant titled If Suffolk Abolished its Legislature ...was marred only by inaccurate information about Nassau County's struggle to achieve a county legislature. Since the adoption of the Nassau County Charter in 1938, political scientists have recognized that the system of weighted voting imposed on Nassau was inequitable and unworkable because 56 percent of the county's population is in the Town of Hempstead and the charter states that no town may cast more than 50 percent of the weighted vote on the Board of Supervisors

title: Pinky and Itzhak Hit the Concert Trail Together
description: He is frequently called the foremost violinist of his generation. Born in Israel of Eastern European Jewish parentage, he came to the United States as a teenager, studied with Ivan Galamian and Dorothy Delay, won first prize in the International Leventritt Competition and went on to worldwide acclaim while still in his early 20's. This season alone he will give more than 120 concerts, a dozen or so in New York City, and will appear with the major orchestras of the United States and Europe. The subject of an hourlong documentary on PBS earlier this year, he has dark curly hair, a burly physique, large expressive eyes and a ready laugh. He is an avid sports fan, likes to cook and his first name is unpronounceably guttural.

title: CONNALLY WINS POLL AT G.O.P. GATHERING
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 10  Middle Western Republicans from precinct workers to state chairmen touched, heard, squinted at and judged a pack of Presidential hopefuls today and decided that John B. Connally was the best speaker in the group.

title: TalentLaden Cosmos Seek Midfield Help
description: Incredible as it may seem, the talentladen Cosmos  the North American Soccer League champions in 1977 and 1978 and the favorites for the 1979 title are looking for still more stars.

title: Glorious Minics  The Tuberous Begonias
description: Tuberous begonias have to be seen to be believed. Their blossoms are even more beautiful than their catalogue pictures because the colors are so vivid and the foliage is rich and green.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Ethnics Quarrel in Toronto
description: TORONTO  Property tax assessments for 1979 were recently mailed to homeowners in this city. They went out six tongues  English, French, Spanish, Italian, Greek and Chinese. While many in the United States think of Canada as a pale New World Britain, this country of 23.5 million people has become a polyglot of ethnic communities whose tastes and cultures have a significant impact on national life.

title: A Runner Finds Respect in Europe
description: Once, while attending a cocktail party in Germany, people stopped me throughout the evening to say:

title: Old Planes Don't Die, They Just Fly Away
description: FAIRFIELD TEN years ago, an old B25 plopped onto one of the milelong runways here at CurtissWright. Airport. The World War II bomber, its turret guns long since replaced by cameras, had just flown the North Atlantic after being Used to film the aircombat scenes in The Battle of Britain.

title: In New Jersey, Investigations Raise Questions About Insurers
description: After more than 50 people died in suspicious fires in New Jersey late last year and early this year, authorities launched broad investigations, concentrating on the possible involvement of slumlords. The Passaic County prosecutor's office last week began looking into charges that some Paterson police officers collected big insurance payments after tenements they owned were destroyed in suspicious tires.

title: Shows and Events.
description: Tuesday and Wednesday Annual antiques show and sale at Grace Church, Five Corners, Westwood. Hours: Tuesday, 11 A.M.10 P.M.: Wednesday, 11 A.M.9 P.M. Donation $1.25. Sponsored by St. Martha's Guild:

title: ART; Illustradun as Illumination
description: BRIDGEPORT ALMOST 20 years old. the Museum of Art, Science and Industry is blending nicely into the wooded landscape along Bridgeport's Park Avenue. But its modernist concrete and glass forms still seem at odds with its name, which resounds with an optimism that is more 19th century than 20th. And sharpening this contrast is a display of work there now by an artist who matured during the golden reign of Teddy Roosevelt.

title: Posthumous Stories
description: THE WOMAN WHO WAS CHANGED And Other Stories. By Pearl S. Buck. A John Day Book. 192 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $8.95.

title: Spurs Rally and Overtake Knicks, 111110
description: Billy Paultz's layup and free throw with four seconds remaining last night gave the San Antonio Spurs a 111110 victory over the Knicks at Madison Square Garden.

title: DINING OUT
description: THINGS have changed since we last visited La Cisterna in Mineola, but, happily, they're still the same. Almost a year ago the restaurant moved to more spacious and elegant quarters across the street from its old location. Typical Italian restaurant red was traded for cool beige accented by stylish, very 70's dark brown, against which the restaurant's charmingly naive pastoral wall paintings are shown to advantage. The bar is lovely, highceilinged area hung with baskets.

title: After Years Out of Favor, Suits Come Striding Back
description: COLLEGE girls went back to school last fall with a Perry Ellis broadshouldered jacket to toss over their blue jeans. Diane Von Furstenberg frequently slipped a tweed jacket over her printed jersey dress. Giorgio Armani's meticulously tailored jackets became the status symbols of the moment.

title: Bangladesh Losing Skilled Workers by Thousands
description: DACCA, Bangladesh  The other day, the Bangladeshi lifeguard at the American Club swimming pool here proudly announced that it was his last day on the job. Tomorrow, he said, he was off to Saudi Arabia.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Gambling issues went wild on Wall Street last week, thereby suggesting in retrospect that it might have proven more profitable to invest in the publicly traded shares than to patronize the establishments chance.

title: Court Rules the Swiss May Extradite Maker Of Movies Over Fraud
description: A judge has ruled that Sergio Locatelli, a European journalist and film producer, can be extradited from the United States to Switzerland to face businessfraud charges involving millions of dollars.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: Something in the Air . . . All Aboard the Kamikaze

title: Jogging Is Fine, But Rx Is Caution
description: ON a clear day, or rainy for that matter, people are running up and down inclines, through the streets, on country roads running, allegedly, for their lives. Swaying buttocks, bouncing breasts. People of all ages, sizes and sexes sweating, groaning, faces flushed, wildeyed  have rediscovered the ancient sport of running. Window displays are cluttered with proper running shoes and garments, and bookshelves are crowded with tendentious writings on the salutary effects of the jog.

title: Kibbee Offers New Plan For Community Colleges
description: Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee, asserting that the nine community colleges of the City University of New York have been brought to the edge of educational bankruptcy, has proposed a new financing formula for all public community colleges in New York State.

title: Sideswiped by China
description: IFINALLY finished reading John Emmerson's memoirs on a Yangtze River steamer between Chongqing and Wuhan. I had begun the book America, returned to it during a Tokyo stopover and completed it in China. At the moment of completion, churning down a wide section of that great muddy artery, it struck me that the linkages were just right: The book and this reviewer had passed through the three cultures that have so shaped, enriched and damaged John Emmerson's life. They were also three cultures that had recently, mysteriously, arrived at startling interval of common amity.

title: Scott, Prisoner, Is Victor
description: RAHWAY, N.J., March 10  For Richie Kates, a prison official, there was no escape at Rahway State Prison today.

title: A Hamptons Hub
description: HAMPTON BAYS HAMPTON BAYS, the least celebrated of the Hamptons, is a hub of activity on the South Fork even in the dead of winter. The majority of the stores are open year round, offering merchandise at reasonable prices to the area's allseason population.

title: Tax Referendum Is Far From Ballot
description: SUFFOLK County Executive John V. N. Klein's proposed referendum on cut t .ng property taxes, which received wide attention when he introdLced it two months ago, appears unlikely to make it to the bailot, at least in the immediate future.

title: D.A. Lowry Fianc Of Judith E. Mills
description: The Rev. Dr. Gerald Spencer Mills, senior pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Red Bank, N.J., and Mrs. Mills of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Elizabeth Mills, to David Alan Lowry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence D. Lowry of Pittsburgh. A Sept. 15 wedding is planned.

title: Playing God Over Food
description: The Food and Drug Commissioner, Donald Kennedy, says he does not want to play God in regulating the nation's food supply. That passionate expression is prompted by recent suggestions that the F.D.A. should be given more discretion to weigh the benefits of food chemicals against their risks. His reluctance is understandable: Who would want the responsibliity for deciding who will gain and who will pay, and for deciding what a human life is worth? But unless someone plays God, the public will suffer.

title: GARDENING
description: EVERY sunny day lifts the gardener's heart. Spring is not far off. When it arrives, so will the outdoor projects, and there never seem to be enough hours in a weekend to get them all done.

title: ART
description: PRINCETON THERE was a time when many people believed that science and art could not be mixed successfully. Science was one discipline, precise in its methods, systematic and rational. Art was another, often indirect and imprecise. It depended on irrational imagination and an ambiguous spirit.

title: Jogging Suits, Too, Are Off and Running In a Race for Style
description: THE brilliantly colored velour tops with the tiny images of polo players, attesting to the fact that they were designed by Ralph Lauren, are as pure in design as sweatshirts. But instead of battleship gray, they are in such colors as yellow, red, green or cyclamen pink, set off by white bands.

title: Men's Wear: The American Look Is Casual and Comfortable
description: WHEN all is said and done, when all the gimmicks and fads have been tried, what it comes down to is this: American men prefer the Americanlook suit.

title: Jogging Suits, Too, Are Off and Running In a Race for Style
description: THE brilliantly colored velour tops with the tiny images of polo players, attesting to the fact that they were designed by Ralph Lauren, are as pure in design as sweatshirts. But instead of battle ship gray, they are in such colors a: yellow, red, green or cyclamen pink. set off by white bands.

title: A Budget Amendment Could Be the Wrong Easy Answer
description: The nation's No. 1 problem, the doubledigit inflation that last week's 1 percent wholesale price rise dramatized, is fast becoming a national neurosis, breeding a revolt against higher taxes, rising government spending and big budget deficits. The most recent, and most popular, solution the middleclass rebels have Drowsed is a constitutional convention to mandate a balanced Federal budget. Twenty. eight states have already voted for it, and such Presidential hopefuls as the Democratic Governor of California, Jerry Brown, and Republicans Senator Robert Dole, Senator How. and H. Baker Jr. and Representative Philip M. Crane have endorsed it.

title: On Language
description: Nobody resents language change that comes about naturally; for example, people who once said of their mental state, I'm hurting. now say. I'm in pain, and we accept this as a normal turnover of vogue terms. But resentment and resistance set in when language change is dictated or promoted by government.

title: Poor Senators
description: One of the inspiring aspects of Congressional politics is how conscientiously the members keep their word to each other. It is the very stuff of legend: once a member shakes on a political bargain, he will keep his end of it, no matter what the later peril. Now legend needs tailoring. Senators may keep their promises to each other. It is, as they demonstrated the other day, the public they welch on.

title: Accessories Add the Accents In Blue, Red, Yellow and Purple
description: ACCESSORIES play a vital part in accenting a wardrobe. Good jewelry such as rings and watches may be seasonless, but shoes, hats, belts and the like are usually changed along with the pages of the calendar.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDON  Are Britain and the United States determined to drive Rhodesia into civil war?

title: ANTIQUES
description: WETHERSFIELD ASAMPLER, according to Samuel Johnson's mid18thcentury definition, is a piece worked by young girls for improvement. Usually stitched by youngsters when they were 8 to 12 years old, these proofs or samples of skill were worked on rectangles of linen in embroidery designed for the embellishing of linens and clothing.

title: WASHINGTON 60 Years Later
description: WASHINGTON, March 10  In the next 12 months, the Senate of the United States will have to vote on the defense of the Middle East and on control, with the Soviet Union, of military arms  particularly nuclear weapons.

title: Islanders Triumph; Rangers Score, 63
description: MONTREAL, March 10The Rangers kept alive their fantastic record against the Montreal Canadiens tonight by defeating the National Hockey League champions, 63, for the fourth straight time over a span of two seasons. Not only that, but the victory in the Forum was New York's second in row, the first time that has happened here since the 197475 season when Toronto and Buffalo accomplished the rare feat.

title: Long Island Store Owner Shoots 6, Slaying 2, and Then Kills Himself
description: ELWOOD. L I., March 10  A 43yearold store owner, apparently angry at his partner over the failing finances of their business, shot and killed his partner's stepson in the store late last night and wounded three of his partner's friends. He then went home, killed his daughter, shot his son in the head and killed himself.

title: ChinaTaiwan Meeting
description: The International Olympic Committee announced in Switzerland that China and Taiwan had agreed to meet to discuss Olympic membership. Page 10.

title: Is College Teaching Worth It?
description: COLLEGE teaching has many intrinsic rewards, but the most practical and necessary one is monetary. While this may not be a current problem for full professors at the top of the salary scale, most college faculty members are ranked at the lower professorial levels.

title: Bruce Gold's American Experience
description: IN his diary Kafka asks, What have I in common with Jews? Immediately he answers, I have hardly anything in common with myself and should stand very quietly in a corner, content that 1 can breathe. Thus, failure to identify with his people inspires a joke about failure to identify with himself. The same failure, and the same joke extremely elaborated, describes much of Joseph Heller's third novel, Good as Gold.

title: FOOD
description: NORTHPORT JOE VERDERAME calls pasta with vegetables a peasant concept. As prepared at Pane & Pasta, his restaurant and takeout shop in Northport, it's just as likely to please more sophisticated contemporary palates. Since November, Pane & Pasta has offered an everexpanding array of fresh, madeonthepremises pasta, especially ravioli with enticing and unusual vegetable fillings to eat in or take out.

title: Diane Gail Lipton Sets June 3 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey L. Lipton of East Rockaway, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Gail Lipton, to Monte Jonathan Gollub, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gollub of Brooklyn. A June 3 wedding is planned.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Oil Giants Are Worrying All the Way to the Bank
description: Five years ago, the Arab embargo created a shortage of oil, prices soared as did profitsand the public loosed a barrage of flak that the industry still smarts from. Now, turmoil in Iran has created another shortage, prices are climbing fast and, yes, company earnings are about to zoom again.

title: U.S. Seeks New Talks to Revive U.N. Namibia Peace Plan
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 9 If all had gone according to plan, the first members of a new United Nations peacekeeping force would have arrived in SouthWest Africa yesterday to supervise a ceasefire in a 10year bush war. They would also have helped monitor a oneman, onevote election guiding a million inhabitants to independence in a new black nation named Namibia.

title: New York City Given $33 Million By U.S. for 50,000 Summer Jobs
description: New York City has received an initial Federal allocation of $33,298,843 for summer jobs for disadvantaged youths aged 14 to 21, enough money to provide 50,000 jobs, the city says.
