title: SPOTLIGHT
description: CHICAGO  We're going back to the key person at Sears being the buyer, the chairman of Sears Roebuck & Company remarked after a November meeting with security analysts.

title: Jane E. Garfinkel Will Marry May 20
description: Rita Garfinkel of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jane E. Garfinkel, to Louis F. Solimine, son of Col. Eugene M. Solimine, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Solimine of Dayton, Ohio. Plans have been made for a May 20 wedding at the St. RegisSheraton.

title: Riders to Appeal Fare Increase
description: TRENTON COMMUTER organizations representing riders on the North Jersey Coast division of Conrail have decided to appeal to theState Supreme Court a lowercourt decision upholding a recent 10 percent fare increase.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: AVON  A Sense of Community, exhibition of photographs by Claire Brett Smith. Friday through April 15. Farmington Valley Arts Center. Phone 6781867.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Readers of this journal may have been a bit puzzled, even startled, by the appearance on the Best Seller List  out of the blue and in the number six spot  of a new title from Doubleday: Ruth Beebe Hill's Hanta Yo. What is it? It is a multigenerational chronicle of two families of the Teton Sioux from the late 1700's to the 1830's. Doubleday is call ing the book fiction, but Mrs. Hill has been working on the Indian material used in the book for 30 years. A West Coast newspaperwoman who numbers among her ancestors one who came over on the Mayflower, Mrs. Hill has long studied and been fascinated by Indian customs, ceremonies and ways of thought. According to her publisher, she has read much of the available literature and spoken to hundreds of Indians about their lives and customs. Hanta Yo has a style of its own. After the manuscript was completed, it was translated  every word says Doubleday  into the Dakotah /Lakotah dialect by Chunksa Yuba, fullblooded Dakotah, who has worked with Mrs. Hill since 1963. It was then translated back into an English based on an 1806 Webster dictionary so that the English would be free of modern locutions.

title: Irving Howe's Steady Work
description: CELEBRATION AND ATTACKS Thirty Years of Literary and Cultural Cornmentary. By lrving Howe. 256 pp. New York: Horizon Press. $14.95.

title: Meeting Ground For Art and Print
description: TYLER GRAPHICS Ltd. is obscured by a white picket fence in Bedford Village. In a clapboard and fieldstone carriage house, artists and craftsmen collaborate to create multiple rainbows of contemporary art: Frank Stella silkscreen prints measuring five by seven feet, Ellsworth Kelly's lithographs of leaves and flowers, Stanley Boxer's dreamlike etchings based on SaintSan's The Carnival of the Animals and David Hockney's colored paper pulp pieces entitled Paper Pools.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: What's holding up the construction of new Route 7 from Norwalk on north?

title: Forged Checks Net $8,000
description: GREAT FALLS, Mont., March 10 (AP)  The police say that not one of the 23 local businessmen who reported that a 17 yearold boy wrote them forged checks had asked him for identification. The police say the youth's biggest check was written to a car dealer for $4,725 and the dealer did not even ask for a driver's license. The teenager, who was not identified, was arrested this week and placed in the custody of juvenile officers pending filing of forgery charges. The authorities said the twomonth buying spree involved more than $8,000.

title: Olympic Group Says China and Taiwan Plan Meeting
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, March 10 The International Olympic Committee announced here today that China and Taiwan had agreed to meet to dicucs what the committee president characterized as the Chinese problem. th: Chinese puzzle of Olympic membership.

title: South Africa Scandal's Key Figure Hints Bribery Was a Part of Policy
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 10  The central figure in South Africa's Information Ministry scandal has hinted for the first time that bribery of influential foreigners, including Americans, was a major part of the Government's secret plan to promote its policy of a partheid.

title: The Face of Spring Is Vividly Different
description: JUST as everyone was coasting along with neutralcolored clothes and neutral makeup, fashion designers threw the cosmetics people a curve with some of the brightest spring colors and vivid color mixes in years. Who would have dreamed purple and red together or blue and yellow last year? Obviously, a woman is not to look faceless, she will soon find herself at a cosmetics counter pleading for something new.

title: Mrs. Carter Plans Trips To 3 States in 2 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) Rosalynn Carter has scheduled separate trips to New York, Connecticut and Florida in the next several weeks, the White House has announced.

title: Russian Reported Slain At a Roadblock in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 10 (Reuters)  A Soviet engineer was shot to death by Iranian revolutionary militiamen while driving through Teheran Thursday night, diplomatic sources reported today.

title: Around the Nation
description: EL PASO, Tex., March 10  Several hundred Mexican protesters blocked three of the four bridges between;this city and Mexico today, and a 10yearold Mexican girl was fatally injured in an accident involving an American motorist, an immigration official said.

title: Janet Resnick Plans June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Res?? or Milwaukee have announeed the engagement of their daughter, Janet Resnick, to James Richard Nelkin, ?? of Dr. and Mrs. Morton of New York. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Bellport Captures Suffolk Title
description: SETALIKET. L.I., March 10  Bellport High School, the Suffolk AA basketball champion, defeated Central Islip, the AAA champion, 7564, today to win the overall Suffolk County scholastic basketball championship at Ward Melville High School.

title: Researchers Assert Estuaries, While Undoubtedly. Beneficial, Are Not Vital to Marine and Human Life
description: A new study suggests that estuaries, while unquestionably beneficial to life on land and sea, are not despite a belief to the contrary by some scientistsvital to the exlstence of marine and human life.

title: Budget Convention Drive Appears to Be Faltering
description: WASHINGTON, March 10  The national movement for a constitutional convention to consider a mandatory balanced Federal budget appears likely to fall short of its goal.

title: New Planning Chief Entering Furious Battle in Dallas
description: DALLAS, March 10  I understand you've been a long time waiting, said E. Jack Schoop after being named to head the Dallas Planning Department, a position that had been vacant since October 1977.

title: T.M. Michel Fianc Of Virginia Pender
description: Mr. and Mrs. James C. O'Shea of Barneveld and Rome, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. O'Shea's daughter, Virginia Culpepper Pender, to Timothy Mattheus Michel, son of Mrs. Lincoln Mattheus Michel of Sarasota, Fla., and Wayne, Pa., and the late Mr. Michel. A July 7 wedding is planned.

title: DINING OUT
description: STAMFORD IN an era of theme restaurants, the Stock Exchange in Norwalk is a modest example of the trend. There is a Trans Lux moving tape along the wall, with a constantly changing listing market quotations, and the menu is printed in booklet form on green paper of the type used for checks and other financial documents.

title: Smoked Fish You Can't Carp At
description: AFICI ONADOS of smoked salmon can now skip the trek to Zabars in Manhattan. Tucked away in Mount Kisco is the source, a smokehouse that supplies trout and salmon to the best restaurants in New York City and Westchester. The smokehouse is open for retail sales the first and third Saturdays of each month, and the products are worth scheduling a party around these dates, especially at less than half the price normally charged for smoked salmon.

title: Merrimack College Raises Fees
description: NORTH ANDOVER, Mass., March 10  Merrimack College announced today that its tuition will rise $300 and its room and board charges $200, effective this fall. The increases will bring yearly tuition to $3,200 and housing fees to $2,050. The Rev. John A. Coughlan, president of the Roman Catholic college, said the increases were made necessary by salary increases, higher energy costs, dormitory renovation and general inflation.

title: Jane Wilson Makes the Still Life Come Alive
description: PORT WASHINGTON MANY modern artists have shunned the still life as subject for their paintings. Perhaps a bowl of apples, a vase or a pear have not seemed congenial to certain intellectual or expressive approaches to art. Or maybe artists felt that everything that was to be done with such objects had already been done.

title: Police Petitioning City To Prosecute Hasidirn For Station Takeover
description: Police officers from Brooklyn's 60th Precinct who were summoned to help when a station house in the Borough Park section was taken over last December by hundreds of Hasidic Jews, petitioned the Police Commissioner yesterday to press for strong enforcement of the law against those involved in the takeover.

title: Accessories Add the Accents In Blue, Red, Yellow and Purple
description: ACCESSORIES play a vital part in accenting a wardrobe. Good jewelry such as rings and watches may be seasonless, but shoes, hats, belts and the like are usually changed along with the pages of the calendar.

title: P.S.A.L. Crown To Boys
description: Boys and Girls High School put the icing on the cake yesterday, defeating DeWitt Clinton, 6155, for the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship at St. John's Alumni Hall in Queens.

title: Iowa Wrestlers Capture Title
description: AMES, Iowa, March 10 (AP)  The University of Iowa wrestlers capped a masterly performance in the National Collegiate wrestling tournament tonight by winning two individual titles and nearly breaking the record for most team points in the 45 years of the event.

title: HARM TO NORTHEAST SEEN IN TRADE PACT
description: WASHINGTON, March 10  An authoritative research arm of Congress has concluded that a liberalized world trade agreement being negotiated in Geneva would bring significant rewards to the United States but would result in lost jobs in the urban manufacturing areas of the Northeast.

title: Amor di Poeta of Bjart Given Its Local Premiere
description: In Amor di Poeta, (A Poet's Love), a two and a halfhour ballet that mixes the identically titled Robert Schumann 1840 song cycle, set to Heinrich Heine's love poems, with other texts and popular music, the French choreographer Maurice Bjart has created his most personal work.

title: U.S. Journals Have Printed Atom Bomb Directions
description: In the last five years, two small publications  an underground newspaper in Madison, Wis., and a feminist newspaper in New York  have published detailed articles with diagrams on how to build an atomic bomb, using a coffee can and explosives.

title: Charge of Entrapment in 3 Prisons Under Inquiry by Albany and U.S.
description: Charges that white prison officials attempted to entrap black guards at three state prisons on bribery and narcotics sales are being investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the New York State Commission of Correction.

title: The Horses of Fantasy and Reality
description: IVAN DRACH, born in 1936 near Kiev and widely regarded as one of the Ukraine's leading contemporary poets, writes an ecstatic and colorful poem that readers of contemporary American verse will find readily accessible. Mr. Drach, as represented in this modest selection of generally readable translations by a number of poets, uses the conventional lyric subject matter of domestic, local and folk topics to draw an affectionate if often sad portrait of a still largely rural culture; and there are also some elements of political protest, most notably in the long and ambitious final poem in the book, Knife in the Sun, a powerful collage of personal and historical themes.

title: Dr. Karen G. Kelly To Wed March 18
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vilar F. Kelly of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Karen Grace Kelly, to Dr. William Kramer Levy, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward D. Levy of Norfolk, Va.

title: Men's Wear: The American Look Is Casual and Comfortable
description: WHEN all is said and done, when all the gimmicks and fads have been tried, what it comes down to is this: American men prefer the Americanlook suit.

title: Mets Reassured by Owners. Then Triumph
description: ST. PETERSBURG. Fla., March 10  The New York M??s opended their 23game exhbinon season today after hearing an unusual appeal from their owners to make a winning effort that would effectively silence the rumors that the team was for sale.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: Karen James, Richard D. Hill Have Nuptials
description: The Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Karen Lee James, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney Lee James of West Hartford, Conn., to Richard Dixon Hill, son of Mrs. Claude Dixon Hill of Rock Hill, S.C., and the late Mr. Hill.

title: New Jersey Symphony Split By Discord Over Personnel
description: NEWARK BARELY three months after a musicians strike was settled, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra is embroiled again in a bitter conflict, this time over changes in personnel made by Thomas Michalak, the music director and conductor. Three players, including the associate conductor and principal clarinet, were dismissed or allowed to resign, and 16 string players were demoted.

title: GARDENING; Using Oil Sprays Against Insects
description: EVERY sunny day lifts the gardener's heart. Spring is not far off. When it arrives, so will the outdoor projects, and there never seem to be enough hours in weekend to get them all done.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Iam afraid that what Sweeney Todd most wants to is impressive. It succeeds in that. From the time that we enter the Uris we are all but overwhelmed by the vast industrial warehouse, complete with moving cranes, descending catwalks, and an organist hunched over his keyboard beneath rippling Victorian pipes, that is going to serve as everything from lovenest to slaughterhouse before the determined evening is done. The sootstained skylight that casts a rusty glow over steel stairwells and chattering fanbelts lets us know that industrialism is here, and is corrosive. When the corrugated back wall finally rises to give us a warehouseandriver view, the effect is breathtak ing. The spectacle does not so much let in light as invite despair: the whitewashed mercantile structures are regularly pockmarked with windows so deeply recessed that they seem sockets from which eyes have very recently been plucked. Small wonder that foul deeds will be done here.

title: More and More Suburban Men Are Finding Clothes That Suit Them Close to Home
description: GERALD CASPER, a lawyer who lives and works in Commack, L.I., never travels into New York City to purchase his clothes. He buys his suits and sport coats at a nearby Syms store, while his wife picks up his shirts, ties and other furnishings at local branches of Macy's and Abraham & Strauss.

title: Adrienne L. Weiss Betrothed To Andrew Harrison, Lawyer,
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Weiss of Valley Stream, L.I., have announced theengagement of their daughter, Adrienne L. Weiss, to Andrew M. Harrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard, Harrison of Cranbury, N.J.

title: Design
description: Once the lot of students and the disadvantaged, oneroom living is now a fact of middleclass life. Much of the dreaded discomfort, however, can be eliminated though imaginative design.

title: Louisville and Okla. Fives Gain
description: DALLAS, March 10 (AP)  The clutch secondhalf shooting of Darrell Griffith propelled Louisville to a 6966 victory over South Alabama today in the second round of the National Collegiate Midwest Regional basketball tournament.

title: What Makes Companies Work? Huddling?
description: Organizations are more akin to ruckus than to a wellengineered system  tangled bureaucracies that don't work well and frustrate almost everybody involved. Some people, however, employ an effective, if mostoften unconscious, solution for this disorder. I call it huddling.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The critical reception to the world premiere of Alban Berg's Lulu, which had its first performance in its threeact version at the Paris Opera on Feb. 24, was predictable. At least, that is what the old Paris hands are saying. They had predicted that most of the press in Paris would go crazy over the staging by Patrice Chereau. They also predicted that foreign critics would take a sterner view. French critics, they said, were always inclined to be chic. And so it worked out, exactly according to the predictions. There were one or two adverse comments about the staging in the papers, but for the most part the key word was triomphe.

title: Environment
description: Washington  A decade after the environmental movement captured the public imagination, legal and illegal traffic in wildlife and wildlife products seems to be rising sharply. Although the United States and a growing number of foreign countries are taking steps to tighten protection of threatened species, some conservationists fear that exploitation is outrunning protection.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarker paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Air Force to Assign Women as Noncombat Pilots
description: WASHINGTON. March 10  The Air Force has quietly decided to assign women pilots to big C141 cargo planes around the world and on refueling tankers for all tactical aircraft.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Ask a few questions about a set of 18thcentury American chairs and you may end up writing a book. In the process, you may also pose some basic inquiries about how antiques dealers deal, curators collect, auctioneers acquire what they sell and reporters report.

title: NEW YORK TO CLOSE 4 FISH HATCHERIES
description: ALBANY, March 8  The State Department of Environmental Conservation is closing four of New York's fish hatcheries, including one on Long Island, because, it said, it does not have the funds needed to operate them properly.

title: Inverrary Leader Hits 5Under 67
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla., March 10 (AP)  Larry Nelson, gunning for his first victory in six years on the pro golf tour, birdied three holes in a row on the way to a fiveunderpar 67 that lifted him into a fourstroke lead today in the third round of the $300,000 Inverrary Classic.

title: WILL HE BE THE FIRST?; This month, capital punishment may become legal again  and 40 people on death row will be slated to die in 1979.
description: The electric chair at Florida State Prison is an unimposing machine. Standing empty, unconnected to the heavy black cables snaking behind it from an innocuous white power box, it appears almost antisepticallv benign.

title: Peking Paper Reports Party Rifts
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, March 10 (AP)  Peking's most important newspaper revealed a major breach today in the Chinese Communist Party leadership, and Vietnam said it was caused by internal opposition to the Chinese invasion.

title: Seagrams With Moxie
description: Bronfman was a Canadian businessman who in the course of building the Seagram liquor empire left behind a series of mysteries that are as complicated and intriguing as the empire itself. The mysteries swirl around Prohibition, when Bronfman and his brothers sold liquor to American bootleggers: there were whorehouses; there was a murder; there were threats of kidnapping and an actual kidnapping of a Bronfman cousin; there were bitter family fights over who would run the company. It would be a fascinating story, Sam Bronfman once said, if I could ever tell the truth of what happened....

title: A FAMILY WORKS A MIRACLE
description: The doctors were not making any predictions after Chester Vogel suffered a massive stroke that left him paralyzed. But his family staunchly believed he would recover  and they made sure that he did.

title: Other National Events
description: To avoid prosecution after being indicted last year on 36 counts of influencepeddling in high Washington places, Korean businessman Tongsun Park agreed name names. One of them was former Representative Richard T. Hanna of California, now serving 16 months for conspiracy, another, Otto Passman, a Representative for 30 years until his defeat in a 1976 Louisiana primary. Last week, Mr. Park was in Monroe, La., for the start Mr. Passman's trial, on charges of receiving $98,000 bribes and illegal gifts. Jury selection occupied the week.

title: FILM VIEW
description: There's a fine, achingly honest scene early in Norma Rae, Martin Ritt's new movie about the politicization of a Southern hillbilly woman, when Sally Field, in the title role, and Beau Bridges, as Sonny, whom she eventually marries, are becoming sweetly drunk in a local tavern on their first date. It is Friday night, the end of a long week at the cotton mill where they both work. They are exhausted, awash in beer and very happy. It's at that hour in the evening when the lyrics of even the corniest laments on the juke box speak directly to the listener.

title: Births
description: ANSIS

title: Italian Party Rejects Conditions For Red Support of Government
description: ROME, March 10 (Reuters)  Italy's Christian Democratic Party tonight rejected Communist conditions for supporting a new government, making new elections the most likely solution to the country's sixweekold Government crisis.

title: Hearst Newspapers Try for Comeback
description: The Hearst newspapers, once the most flamboyant group of papers in American journalism but more recently in a quiet period of declining circulation, are making an effort to stage a comeback.

title: Children's Fashions
description: Children's Fashion

title: An OffYear Issue: Rules for Primaries
description: HARTFORD THE second thoughts of some politicians about scrapping Connecticut's convention system for nominating candidates and replacing it with direct primary elections have been summed up by legislative study committee, which has concluded that maybe the present system is not so bad after all.

title: Late TV Listings
description: Noon (Channel 2) Newsmaker New York State Energy Comissioner James Lancca

title: Segovia Gives a Recital
description: The stage and auditorium of Avery Fisher Hall were, as usual, packed to capacity Friday night for Andres Segovia's annual New York recital. In a way, the event might have been consid, ered a warmup for Mr. Segovia's appearance today at the White House. No doubt the attendance at this special occasion will be many times larger, since the concert is to be televised beginning at 4 P.M.

title: Ottilie Rosina King, Spiros C. Droggitis Plan June 23 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Brazell King of Spring Lake, N.J., and Washington have made known the engagement of their daughter, Ottilie Rosina King, to Spires Charles Droggitis. son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Droggitis of Biddeford. Me.

title: A Marathon at Marathon
description: The Greeks are getting a leg up on next year's Olympics in Moscow by staging a modern marathon in Athens this spring over the same course covered by the Grecian hero Pheidippides in 490 B.C. in carrying home the news of an Athenian victory over the invading Persians.

title: Reds Are Still a Tough Team, but Different
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 10  The Big Red Machine, invincible as fate, has vanished into history like the Wehrmacht.

title: In Europe and the U.S., Moves to Stabilize Currencies
description: Moves to stabilize the world's major currencies were in the news last week: the much ballyhooed European won final acceptance and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York released details of its massive support efforts on behalf of the dollar, which has gained more than 4 percent in value since December.

title: Accessories Add the Accents In Blue, Red, Yellow and Purple
description: ACCESSORIES play a vital part in accenting a wardrobe. Good jewelry such as rings and watches may be seasonless, but shoes, hats, belts and the like are usually changed along with the naves of the calendar.

title: Can Women Succeed as Commuters?
description: MORE than a few raised eyebrows and dropped jaws greet my mild announcement that I am returning to the fulltime work force and will be toiling not in the familiar vineyards of the suburbs, but in the Big Apple, locus of my youthful dreams albeit less shiny than in those days. From now on, it will be out of the secluded study and into the Madison Avenue mainstream and all those millions of private lives flowing through Grand Central Terminal.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater

title: The First Century  of Albert Einstein
description: THIS year we are celebrating the 100th anniversary of the birth of Albert Einstein. He was born on March 14, 1879, in the German city of Ulm. The event is being commemorated with speeches, symposiums, television specials, postage stamps and, no doubt, banners and balloons. It is just this sort of homage that Einstein, who saw in his science an escape from the

title: Hamilton Fish Sees No End to Vietnamese Refugees
description: WASHINGTON ON his return from a twoweek trip to Asia as ranking Republican member of a House subcommittee on immigration and refugees, Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. has a sobering message for Americans long accustomed to offering a haven to the world's oppressed.

title: Swagger or Stagger: On Buying a Shillelagh in Shillelagh
description: Practically every traveler worth his salt knows it is difficult to buy a Panama hat in Panama, a canary in the Canary Islands or a turkey in Turkey. But how about a shillelagh in Shillelagh?

title: Soviet Prime Minister, in India, Promises Aid to Hanoi
description: NEW DELHI, March 10  The visiting Soviet Prime Minister, Aleksei N. Kosygin, chose an ancient imperial setting today for a warning to Peking that the Vietnamese could expect the same kind of aid from Moscow in the conflict with China that they received in the hostilities with the United States.

title: IRAN: HEART OF THE MATTER
description: Now that the revolution has reached its climax, if not its denouement, now that the old order has disintegrated, to be replaced by no one yet knows what, we can look back and see why almost everything that has happened so far had to happen more or less the way it did.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: TRINITRON SIDNEY was just where I'd left him the last time, sitting in the den of his Smithtown home, staring at the three television sets stacked on top of one another. CBS on top. NBC in the middle. ABC on the bottom.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THERE is nothing more annoying than a window shade that keeps unrolling by itself, or will not go up under its own power when you give it the usual tug.

title: Men's Wear: The American Look Is Casual and Comfortable
description: WHEN all is said and done, when all the gimmicks and fads have been tried, what it comes down to is this: American men prefer the Americanlook suit.

title: Governor Again Seeks Financial Disclosures
description: ALBANY, March 10 (AP)  Apparently laying the groundwork for payraise requests expected later next week, Governor Carey has renewed his effort to make top state employees disclose their financial interests.

title: Sarah Jane Braun Is Married To James F. Carey in Jersey
description: Sarah Jane Braun, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Braun of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to James Francis Carey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Carey of Reading, Mass.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THERE is nothing more annoying than a window shade that keeps unrolling by itself, or will not go up under its own power when you give it the usual tug.

title: May Wedding Set By Carol Littlefield, Angus McIntyre Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. David M. Payne of Old Lyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Payne's daughter, Carol Littlefield of Palo Alto, Calif., to Angus P. McIntyre Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McIntyre of Huntington L.I.

title: Her Own Heroine
description: AT the age of 28, George Sand published her first novel, Indiana, its subject not a Middle Western state but a passionate Creole girl. Indiana, unawakened to love although married to an autocratic army officer, pursues a career of impeccable virtue enlivened by frequent compromising situations. Although a dashing young Frenchman pursues her. she manages to preserve her chastity. Finally convinced of her lover's unworthiness, Indiana accompanies her husband to a tropical island. On the point of fleeing back to her Frenchman (he has written a persuasive letter), she discovers her true love for faithful Sir Ralph, her longdevoted cousin. The two them leap over a cliff but survive to dedicate themselves to love in a cottage, the inconvenient husband having died in the nick of time.

title: Notes: Off Season in the Caribbean
description: The balmy breezes and swaying palms of the Caribbean never seem so appealing as when the snow is flying up North, but if your index finger is worn out from dialing for hotel and plane reservations during the busy winter season, why not wait until the rush is over and plan your trip in the off season? The sun, the sea and the sand are the same, the experts maintain, but the savings are considerable.

title: A Man of Many Hats To Doff One of Them
description: HACICENSACK UNTIL Jeremiah F. O'Connor was elected to the Bergen County Board of Chosen Freeholders in 1974, the position of Freeholder Director had been rotated each year, with an incumbent seeking reelection usually filling the role as a publicrelations device to stay before the public.

title: PEOPLE
description: Alexander P. Butterfield, a former Presidential aide whose testimony before the Senate Watergate Committee resulted in the discovery of the White House tapes, switched jobs last week, going from aviation to insurance. After two years as executive vice president and chief operating officer of the International Air Service Company Ltd., he has joined the California Life Corporation, a holding company mainly in insurance and computers.

title: Tennis...er, ah...Racquetball, Anyone?
description: CLOSTER FOR the last few winteis, Ray Jacobs. Allen Bell and Patrick Quirk have been playing tennis once a week at a local racquet club. Next season, they are switching to racquetball.

title: Casino Job Picture Brightening
description: ATLANTIC CITY IN A move designed to insure equal employment opportunity in New Jersey's new casino industry, the state's Casino Control Commission more than a year ago established minimum goals for the casinohotels. They called for at least 20 percent of the jobs to be held by members of racial minorities and at least 43 percent to be held by women.

title: A DYNAMO NAMED GORDON DAVIDSON
description: A few weeks ago in Los Angeles, the weather was miserable  soggy, gray, snow falling on the shoulders of surfers at Malibu. But on two theater stages, miles apart, the climate was ice and fire. In both instances, a dynamo named Gordon Davidson was responsible. Born in Brooklyn 45 years ago, he went out West in 1964 and stayed to transform Southern Californiaonce a cultural Sahara  into an oasis of theatrical nourishment. In fact, in more than a decade of innovation such as that place had not seen before, Davidson has become what one Los Angeles politician calls our true cultural czar.

title: Task Gets Harder for Redmen
description: RALEIGH, N.C., March 10  St. John's, which still considers itself lucky just to be in the 41st National Collegiate basketball championship tournament. and Pennsylvania, whose coach said we were very fortunate last night, will probably find things considerably more difficult when they play secondround games tomorrow afternoon.

title: Man's Body Found in Bronx
description: The body of a man who had been slain gangland style was found lying on the service road of the New England Thruway near Coop City in the Bronx, early yesterday, the police reported. A Police Department spokesman could not immediately identify the victim, but said he was in his 30's. The man had been shot in the back of the head. The body wasfound between Hunter Avenue and Reeds Mill Lane about 2:15 A.M. The police speculated that he had been shot elsewhere and then dumped on the roadway.

title: A Freewheeling Play About Irish History
description: The Irish literary tradition. is a wonderful one, but working under the shadows of Yeats, Synge, Joyce, O'Casey and Behan can be a pretty heavy, oppressive burden. I've tried hard not to be swamped by it, because wanted to find a way of my own. I was determined that I was never going to write the 473d version of Juno and the Paycock.

title: TollFree Help for Travelers
description: There it is, on the cover of the 1979 editions of Fielding's Europe, Fielding's Favorites, Fielding's Selective Shopping Guide and Fielding's LowCost Europe, a big gold sticker proclaiming The Living Guide. The smaller print continues: Have your travel questions personally answered free! Oh, come on, the cynic mumbles. They cant mean it.

title: Emergency Room: The Neighborhood Doctor
description: EAST PATCHOGUE IT'S 8 o'clock on a Saturday night. A young mother is holding a feverish child on her lap in the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital emergency room here. Across the way, a group of teenagers are huddled close together. Minutes before, they brought in a friend, unconscious. He had taken 30 Quaaludes.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A public forum on school finance reform will take place in the Cole Auditorium of Greenwich Library at 8 P.M. Tuesday, under the auspices of the 22yearold educational watchdog agency, the Greenwich Association for the Public Schools. Gene Wilhelm, president of the association, said, We are concerned about what is going to happen to the quality of education when state funds are channeled away from our schools and local taxes cannot make up the difference.

title: Rutgers, Syracuse Fives Advance
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 10 When last seen in the National Collegiate basketball tournament, the Scarlet Knights of Rutgers were moving in slow motion, during an embarrassing two games in the 1976 Final Four. Since then there have been two firstround losses in the Eastern Eight tournament. There has not been an outstanding recruit since James Bailey arrived in 1975, and there was the defection this year of Rodney Duncan, once a starting guard.

title: Eve Hilpert, Student, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Hilpert of Huntington Bay, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eve Etherington Hilpert, to Raymond Bankert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Bankert of Scotia, N.Y. Miss Hilpert a student at ColbySawyer College. Her fiance is an alumnus of Dartmouth College.

title: Entertainers Testify for Lee Marvin in Former Companion's Lawsuit
description: LOS ANGELES, March 10  Some of the most successful entertainers in Hollywood have turned out to testify in support of Lee Marvin, the actor who is defending himself against a suit in which the woman he lived with for six years is seeking more than $1 million.

title: A City Couple Brings Ireland to Mantic
description: NIANTIC may seem an unlikely location for a shop specializing in topquality Irish Imports, and Catherine and Frederic Irwin cheerfully admit that they can find no rational reason for opening their shop, Enniskerry West Ltd.. three years alto.

title: Women Executives: View From the Top
description: To some people, the woman who has really made it in America is the woman who is a director of a major corporation. She belongs to a small but growing sorority: In 1969, only 46 women served on boards, and they were often company moguls wives or daughters or sisters. Today there are 278, and achievement seems to have replaced nepotism as the major qualification.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: PAT RAVO, the City Manager of Yonkers, reached into a lower drawer of his desk and removed a small manila folder: In here are the results of months of work that included a series of town hall meetings, the mailing of 3,000 questionnaires, the phoning of hundreds of community and civic leaders and several radio and newspaper advertisements to solicit citizen input on the proposes 197980 budget, he said holding up the felder and slapping it against his right palm. We tried to give residents a chance to speak out on the proposed budget before it is presented to the Mayor and the City Council, and this is how they respond.

title: POLITICS
description: NEW ROCHELLE THE chairman of the Assembly's Committee on Cities was here last week trying to drum up support for a plan to expand the state's current $28 million taxoverburden bill for Albany, Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and Yonkers to a $70 million program aiding all of the state's 60 cities.

title: Anne L. O'Connell And John E. Oliver Plan May Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Francis O'Connell of Harrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Louise O'Connell to John Elser Oliver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry William Oliver of Williamstown and Wellfleet, Mass.

title: The Small Investor Back in Real Estate
description: Is there a place for the small investor in the real estate market? Or should he, once bit by the fall from grace of the real estate investment trusts (REITs), forever be shy? During the past year, growing numbers of small investors have been combining their capital with that of other investors in such vehicles as REITs and limited partnerships. But there are many factors to weigh, summed up in these questions David Hewitt, president of Winthrop Financial Corporation of Boston, urges on the wouldbe investor: How much money is he getting, when is he getting it, what is its source, and how certain is he of ever receiving it?

title: Barbara J. Sullivan, Lawyer, to Wed May 19
description: Barbara Janet Sullivan and Wallace Carmichael Murchison Jr., lawyers, in Washington, will be married May 19 in Princeton, N.J. Their engagement has been announced by the bridetobe's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Sullivan of Princeton. Mr. Murchison is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murchison of Wilmington, N.C.

title: A Photographer's Life: Selected Frames
description: He didn't get started until he was 10, but ever since Bruce Davidson has used a camera as a guide, both to himself and to the world beyond. He is now 44 and his celebrated photographs, ranging over many countries, probing the shadows and a little of the sunlightof many lives, convey his own journey through three decades. This week, a major show of his work goes on view at the International Center of Photography and a book of his photographs will be published by Agrinde/Summit. The book tells of his life with the camera; excerpts from his essay begin on Page 34.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The Year of the Goat began on Jan. 28. The Chinese Lunar Calendar counts the years as a revolving cycle of 12 animals.. Next year will be the Monkey; then follows the Cockerel, the Dog, Pig, Rat, Ox, Tiger, Rabbit, Dragon, Snake and then the Horse againand in 1991 another Year of the Goat.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: Text of' Addresses by Presidents Sadat and Carter
description: CAIRO, March 20 (AP)  Following are the text of an unofficial translation from the Arabic of President Anwar elSadat's address and the text of President Carter's address to the People's Assembly of Egypt today:

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE PLAGUE DOGS, by Richard. Adams. (Fawcett/Crest, $2.75.) Two dogs escape from a laboratory where they've been confined for experimental purposes and raise a great hue and cry as they range over the English Lake countryside. Our reviewer William Safire described Richard Adams as an original artist, his book so redolent of moral dilemmas that you want to trot back and sniff it again. A best seller in hardcover.

title: CRIME
description: The struggles of Israel, a small country surrounded by big enemies, have inevitably provided material for books, and the last several years have seen quite a few espionage and suspense novels on the subject. Latest to join the procession of Israel vs. the World are these two novels  THE ALEPH SOLUTION by Sandor Frankel and Webster Mews (Stein and Day, $8.95) and CABAL by Norman Garbo (Norton, $10.95).

title: CALENDAR
description: Wednesday through Friday. Antiques Show, Old Wethersfield, 300 Main Street. 12 noon to 9 P.M. Take Marsh Street exit from 191. 18th  and early19thcentury American furniture and accessories.

title: First the Ice Cream, Then the History
description: WHEN David B.(for Bird) Burner was a graduate student in history at Columbia University, a professor gave him some advice: Always assume that the opposite of received truth might in fact be the case.

title: The Immortal Mr. Wilson
description: Pending the inevitable flood of protests from electioneers for John Mize, Glenn Wright, Arky Vaughan, Chuck Klein and other legitimate candidates, that was a nice pair of choices the veterans committee made for the Baseball Hall of Fame.and never made an enemy. Chances are he would have been voted into the Cooperstown shrine while he was alive.

title: Iris Greenberg Sets June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Greenberg of Long Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Iris Greenberg, to Gary Udasin, son of Sylvia Udasin of Flushing, Queens, and the late Herbert Udasin. The couple, students at the Downstate Medical Center at Brooklyn, were graduated summa cum laude last year from the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Insurance and Hidden Patronage
description: F?? the State In?? commission dis?? ce brokers who ?? nearly $400.00 ?? p??emiums, the ?? regulations de ??

title: Carolyn D. Aufses Sets August Bridal
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Aufses Jr. of New York and Old Field, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Diane Aufses, to Robert David Blashek 3d, son of Mrs. Lawrence P. Stein of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Robert D. Blashek of Greenwich, Conn.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: KUWAIT  When Queen Elizabeth visited here on her goodwill tour of the Persian Gulf last month, she complimented the nation's ruler, Sheik Jaber alAhmad alSabab, on his lavish welfare and development spending.

title: Ruling on School Policy Delayed
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., March 10 (UPI)  Superior Court Judge Sherwin Lester has reserved decision on the constitutionality of a Teaneck Board of Education policy banning extracurricular high school activities on the Jewish and Christian sabbaths except for sports. He said Friday he would make a ruling after Education Commissioner Fred Burke decided whether the action violated New Jersey's equaleducation policy.

title: Diversification Bids
description: Diversification has become a major theme in the steel industry since the severe business downturn of the mid1910's. Last week, the National Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest producer, announced an agreement to acquire for $290 million the United Financial Corporation of California.

title: Welfare Housing: Officials at Odds
description: YONKERS ALTHOUGH their concerns stem from the same problem  deteriorating housing resulting from the failure of landlords to provide essential services in buildings with welfare tenants  officials of this city and of the county's Social Services Department have appeared to be on a collision course, with each side accusing the other of handicapping any solution.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Carter Sends a Carrier to Show Concern at Yemen's War
description: The Marines have landed and have the situation well in hand.

title: CRUCIAL TALKS AHEAD
description: JERUSALEM, March 10  President Carter said upon arrival in Israel tonight that after three days of talks with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, I have good reason to hope that the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty can now be concluded.

title: Neighbors Relish Hanoi's Discomfort
description: SINGAPORE  Southeast Asian leaders have been slow to comment on the apparent winding down of the ChinaVietnam war, but there are signs that nonCommunist Asians are reasonably content with the outcome although nervously cautious about the future.

title: IRAN WOMEN MARCH AGAINST RESTRAINTS ON DRESS AND RIGHTS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 10  Thousands of women left their jobs and university classrooms and thousands of girls left their schools here today to protest the oppression they feel Islamic rule has brought them.

title: A Welsh Center That Looks at an EnergyShort Future
description: I have been over into the future, and it works, Lincoln Steffans reported enthvciastically after a visit to the infant Soviet Union in 1919. Last summer I got a look at what may be our future, and I have to report that it was not working too well.

title: Milk Drivers Told Outlook Has improved
description: Five hundred striking milkindustry workers held a peaceful rally yesterday on the doorstep of a major bottling plant in Jamaica, Queens, to mark the completion of the second week of their strike.

title: 12 Pick Scores at Aqueduct
description: New York may have a modest challenger er tu the muchheralded Spectacular Bid in this year's glamour races for 3yearolds.

title: Richard Seaver, Publisher
description: RICHARD SEAVER was recently appointed publisher of trade books at Holt, Rinehart and Winston, a subsidiary of CBS, a post that on the surface would seem to conflict with his lifelong devotion to avantgarde literature. Why Seaver? I asked a topranking CBS official. Frankly, he said, to add a touch of class to a house currently steeped in commercialism and nothing very much else. The one writer on Holt's backlist we're proud to have is Robert Frost. We want to start publishing many Robert Frosts.

title: Ban the Bomb  and the Press?
description: Should a magazine be free to publish an article on how to make a hydrogen bomb?

title: Spring's Slim and Colorful Silhouette
description: IF you want to be in fashion, you'll have to be in shape. Those big loose clothes of last year that hid few extra pounds around the middle have been replaced by slim, bodyconscious silhouettes that are pulled in at the waist and narrow across the hips.

title: New Group Combines Evangelism and Orthodoxy
description: A new Christian denomination has been formed, combining some of the personal zeal of the evangelical movement and the traditional ritual of Eastern Orthodoxy, two forms of Christianity that do not easily overlap.

title: What a Food Critic Does Between Meals in Lyons
description: It is doubtful that any serious eater planning a gastronomic tour of France would omit Lyons. France's largest city after Paris and Marseilles is generally acknowledged to be its second culinary capital and there are some who would argue it well may be its first. Paris may seem to deserve that accolade on the basis of the variety, finesse and innovation of its restaurants, but Lyons is regarded as the protector of la vraie cuisine franaise  good, solid bourgeois cooking at its most traditional. The city is not only the stronghold of mre restaurants, where the tradition of woman cooking is still upheld with pride, but also the central jumpingoff point for five of the 18 restaurants in France that possess the highly prized threestar rating from the Guide Michelin.

title: Gloria Vanderbilt and Others
description: WOMAN TO WOMAN By Gloria Vanderbilt. 305 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95.

title: Changes in Society Holding Black Youth in Jobless Web
description: The extraordinary growth in unemployment among black youths, a trend that has persisted through both recession and prosperity and through more than a decade of civil rights enforcement and minority job programs, is largely a result of major changes in the nation's economy, in the structure of its society and in its political climate.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Among forms of rejection, one of the more damaging is Yes, but he wouldn't fit in. It's a killer, in fact. It doesn't come on like an insult. It may even be spoken with overtones of regret, feigned or otherwise. But in its longterm effect it is more hurtful than many a forthright Drop dead!, and none of us would like to have it said of ourselves.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: THERE is nothing more annoying than a window shade that keeps unrolling by itself, or will not go up under its own power when you give it the usual tug.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: In the article Charity Groups in Bitter Feud [Feb. 18], this statement, attributed to Dennis Murphy of United Way, needs to be addressed: The decision to cut off funds [to the Westchester Community Service Council] came after a study found shortcomings in the Council's services.

title: A Ranking of Towns by Wealth
description: The following is a ranking of Connecticut towns according to wealth prepared by the State Department of Education. The rankings are based on each community's propertytax base and percapita income. The number in parenthesis indicates where a town stood in the rankings based primarily on town assessment figuresbefore the state conducted its new study. The first column of dollar figures is the percapita property wealth of the town, as estimated by the State Department of Revenue Services. The second column shows the percapita income of the town, based on 1974 Census estimates.

title: Deaths
description: ACHERMANMar?? (nee Pal mer) On march 8. Devoted wife ?? ??. Nat Acherman in accordance with her wishes she has made ?? of her body to medical research Memorial service to be held at a later ?? Memorical gifts to Ana?? cal Gift Fegistry Lid. Po Box 1644 ??C ?? would be appreciated

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The winter woods that so delight crosscountry skiers and photographers can be a white hell for deer.

title: The City and the State Soon May Formalize a Prison Swap
description: A year ago, Herbert J. Sturz had a devastatingly simple idea. He would have New York State take over from the city the prison complex on Rikers Island. By the end of this month, that idea probably will be translated into reality.

title: Ticket to U.S. Film a Coveted Item for Soviet Elite
description: MOSCOW, March 10  At 1:15 P.M. every Thursday, a select crowd of several hundred, holding special tickets, files into the Illurion theater on the Moscow River for a closed showing of an old American or British film, usually Late Late Show material from the 30's or early 90's, and much of it captured from Hitler's archives at the end of World War II.

title: Crandall Bailey Fiance Of Earl Alun Rogers 3d
description: The Rev, Mead Miner Bailey of New York and Gail Phillips Bailey of Libertyville, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Crandall Elizabeth Bailey, to Earl Alun Rogers 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rogers Jr. of Utica, N.Y.

title: 31 Enter Bids to Run 13 Short Freight Lines Conrail Now Operates
description: ALBANY, March 9  Thirtyone wouldbe railroad magnates have stepped forward, eager to take over 13 small branch freight lines in the state that are now being operated on a temporary basis by Conrail with the help of Federal and state subsidies.

title: Number of Doctors Is Declining in the Rural West
description: HELENA, Mont., March 10 (UPI) Concern is growing over the disappearance of the country doctor from the many rural communities of the West.

title: Guard Is Held at Knifepoint
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., March 10 (UPI)  A disabled Vietnam veteran held a security guard hostage at knifepoint for two hours in the offices of Representative Don Clausen yesterday, but later surrendered without a struggle. The police said the suspect, Charles Pettibone, 30 years old, apparently had wanted to talk over personal problems with the California Republican, who was not in his office. The guard was cut slightly.

title: A Correction
description: In Headliners in The Week in Review of March 4. 1979, the name of Abraham Goldstein, the provost of Yale University, was incorrectly reported as Abraham Goldman.

title: IN BRIEF
description: In an unusual and dramatic move designed to ease its financial troubles, the Chrysler Corporation asked thousands of its suppliers to make midyear price rollbacks of 2 percent. Chrylser buys much larger percentage of its materials and components from outside suppliers than its larger competitors, and over the years that has raised the cost of producing a vehicle $100 or more above that of General Motors Corporation or the Ford Motor Company.... The Federal Trade Commission plans to going ahead with its antitrust investigation of the nation's automobile manufacturers. The decision to continue the nearly threeyearold inquiry was made when the commission refused a series of motions filed by Ford. General Motors, Chrysler and the American Motors Corporation are already challenging the legality of the investigation in court.. .. A suit by dissident stockholders of Ford, charging Henry Ford 2d with misuse of corporate funds, was dismissed on jurisdictional grounds by the Appellate Divislon of State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Lawyers for the shareholders said they would appeal the decision.

title: Winter's Tale Sings of Spring For Hofstra U.
description: HEMPSTEAD L.I.  The plays of Shakespeare have inspired and survived an incalculable range of directorial interpretations and conceits, from Peter Brook's absurdist Lear to Joseph Papp's rockandroll Hamlet. But who is the director who envisions Shakespeare as a Flo Ziegfeld spectacle?

title: Soviet Police Film U.S. Reporters Seeing Dissidents
description: MOSCOW March 10  Soviet security men stationed outside a Moscow apartment building today photographed and filmed American correspondents who were leaving a news conference with Jewish dissidents. The authorities had prevented other dissidents from coming to the gathering from Leningrad, Vilnius, Kiev and Kharkov, the organizers said.

title: Government Clamps Down on Booming 6month Certificates
description: The Carter Administration announced a dramatic move last week to trim the sails of the popular yet troublesome sixmonth savings certificates by reducing the interest payments on them.

title: Policemen: No Margin for Error
description: I'VE BEEN kicked, bitten, punched and shot at, and it's not at all like the television shows, said a police officer with 12 years' experience as he explained a few of his occupational hazards. Last year, when I was getting stitched up in the hospital, I thought, God, I could be in the morgue!

title: The Six Days of Gerard Rinaldi
description: BY his own admission, Gerard Rinaldi has for 20 years been studYing the structure of thinking and the structure of language, psycholinguistics, Samuel Beckett's works, Marcel Duchamp's works and those of his followers, the Theater of the Absurd, language structure as a cultural influence on behavioral patterhs, and classification and order.

title: Gov. Brown Supporting Projects That Aid a Mexican Contributor
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, attempting to persuade Mexico to sell its energy products to California companies, has in the process been lending the weight of his office to proposed projects that would benefit Carlos Bustamante, a Mexican friend who has contributed to his campaign, interviews with Mr. Bustamante and some Brown aides show.

title: Research Management Stifles Innovation
description: By nature, as LeoArthur Kelmenson wrote in this space on Feb. 4, the innovator and the regulator are diametrically opposed. But he limited his arguments to the Government regulator: They can and should be extended to include research management.

title: PEKING IS TROUBLED ABOUT YOUTH CRIMES
description: HONG KONG, March 10  Two high school students, miffed that a classmate had been chastised by his teacher for being a hoodlum. broke into the teacher's room and began attacking him with sticks and stones. When he tried to run for help, they shot him in the chest with a homemade zip gun.

title: Andrea Dale Kent Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Andrea Dale Kent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Kent of Massapequa, L.I., to Seth Martin Wax. son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Wax of East Meadow, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents. The couple, 1977 graduates of the State University College at Buffalo, plan to be married in July. Mr. Wax attends the New York College of Podiatric Medicine. His father is president of the BedfordRobbins Corporation, paper box manufacturer in Brooklyn. Miss Kent's father is senior vice president of Greenstone & Rabasca Advertising Inc. of Melville, L.I.

title: The Face of Spring Is Vividly Different
description: JUST as everyone was coasting along with neutralcolored clothes and neutral makeup, fashion designers threw the cosmetics people a curve with some of the brightest spring colors and vivid color mixes in years. Who would have dreamed purple and red together or blue and yellow last year? Obviously, if a woman is not to look faceless, she will soon find herself at a cosmetics counter pleading for something new.

title: U.S. Worried Over Deterioration And Instability in Southern Asia
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) The United States is worried that a deterioration in relations among nations on the Asian subcontinent could lead to new conflicts and divert attention from economic progress, the State Department's second, ranking official said this week.

title: St. Thomas's Prices: Not All Cheaper Than New York's
description: In a deserted subway tunnel at Dyckman Street in upper Manhattan, a freshly pasted advertisement for a midtown camera shop caught my eye: Why buy a camera in the Caribbean when I can give you the best deal under the sun?

title: CHESS
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil Apowerful center is a strategic weapon that is extraordinarily difficult tc, counteract. It cramps the defense, depriving it of the mobility necessary to shift forces from one wing to the other. In thus isolating the opponent's wing, it creates chances for a decisive attack against either one.

title: New York Groups Support Plans For Voters to Initiate State Laws
description: ALBANY, March 9  A proposed amendment to the State Constitution to allow the electorate to place new laws directly on the ballot or to order the Legislature to consider an issue drew a surge of support here this week.

Goldstein, seeded third, will meet the topseeded Sharif Khan in the final tomorrow.

title: BRIDGE
description: When two people of similar but distinct linguistic backgrounds, such as a German and Dutchman or a Spaniard and a Portuguese, attempt to communicate, the results are likely to fall well short of satisfactory. And the same is true at the bridgetable, when players of vastly different training face each other.

title: James. G. Murray Jr. And Mary S. Hinkle To Be Wed June 23

Miss Grodd, senior at the University of Pennsylvania, and her fianc, a student at its Wharton School, plan to be married July 28.

title: Scavenging for Metal and Fixtures In Deserted New York Buildings
description: Henry walks the streets of New York City almost every day, surveying old buildings. He is keenly interested in the city's older real estate and, more particularly, in its vacant buildings. But Henry is not a buyer or a developer, and when he carefully studies a building it is not with an eye for rehabilitation, renovation or adaptive reuse.

In the anecdote, peasants are told that Communism is on the horizon only to find that the horizon is an imaginary line which as you get closer to it, continually recedes.

title: U.S. Completes Environmental Regulations on Strip Mining
description: WASHINGTON  The completion last week of Federal environmental regulations on strip mining was, like the publication of Euclid's geometry, an event little noted in its time. The rules will be Greek to most: a thousand pages of engineering formulas and bureaucratic legalese, a volume of such numbing bulk that even the Government Printing Office, accustomed to rolling out forgettable tomes in small type, cannot finish the press run until this week.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Now that tennis and jogging have become old hat, everybody is taking up thinking. I advise against it. description: THERE have been many books about the great warcrimes trial of 194546 at Nuremberg technical, analytical, emotional, critical. After 35 years the event still evokes listless debate among the middleaged. None of those records suggests the sense of personal identification that Airey Neave provides in his account. It is strange that he has taken so long to produce it.

title: Green Empire State Building

Excavation for the site was completed on March 6, 1930, and ironworkers were ready to start construction of the skyscraper's skeleton two days later. But Alfred E. Smith, the former Governor and first president of Empire State Inc., looked to his Irish heritage and ordered that work on the building start on St. Patrick's Day, March 17.

title: GARDENING; As Ye Sow, So Shall Ye Plant Out
description: MARCH is the biggest month for indoor seeding to have plants ready for planting outdoors in the spring. It is, in fact, too late for some plants and too early for others, but for most it is just right. The secret of knowing when to sow each kind requires understanding of its rate of growth and development and the date when it can safely be planted out.

title: New Zealand: English and Maori Traditions
description: In the midst of a blustery winter, many dream of flying of to a vacation respite on some sunny South Seas island. This winter I did just that, choosing New Zealand, a country on two islands. I found not only wide solitary beaches and brilliant blue green seas, but also mountains, lakes, fiords, oldworld cities and newworld people, lush green countryside, hot springs and 60 million sheep.

title: Beauty

Often better than tranquilizers and certainly cheaper than a trip to the Caribbean, a good massage can relax muscles, help circulation and leave the subject in a state approaching euphoria.

title: Culture in Carter's White House
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. Vladimir Horowitz's appearance last winter in the East Room of the White House evoked for some of the 100 invited couples present the brief season when Jack and Jackie Kennedy held sway there  the last time when high art and power seemed truly at ease with one another in the nation's capital. The guest list was drawn for Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter mostly from the upper strata of four worlds: political, corporate, artistic and journalistic. After an hourlong recital by the famed pianist, they mingled easily as waiters in black tie circulated among them, bearing silver trays laden with glasses of white wine, hot fennel sausage puffs and strawberry tarts.

If there is validity to these theories, then only those teachers who can consistently maintain a positive, productive classroom atmosphere should continue to teach children. To insure that only competent teachers remain in the classroom, the State Legislature has attempted to provide a means of disciplining tenured teachers who do not measure up to standard.

title: This New Gamble for a Treaty Actually Began at Camp David
description: CAIRO  In the pursuit of peace in the Middle East, Jimmy Carter has given new meaning to that old term brinkmanship, coined in the fifties to describe how former Secretary of State John Foster Dulles confronted the Russians and other Cold War rivals. At a moment when his critics carped that he lacked boldness, Mr. Carter has dared to tie up more of his personal prestige, stake more of his political fortunes and commit more American influence in this region than any previous American chief executive in his effort to grasp the elusive chalice of peace.

title: 'Remember My Name,' Film by Alan Rudolph:The Cast
description: Alan Rudolph is just talented enough to be maddening. In his first film, "Welcome to L.A."  and now in "Remember My Name," which opens today at the Cinema StudioMr. Rudolph has devised sketchy, insufferably pretentious material and then mounted it with an elegance that is undeniable. Mr. Rudolph is the kind of screenwriter whose best lines are the ones he leaves unfinished. But his characters remain curiously watchable even when they spout gibberish, and spout it very slowly and knowingly at that. Both his films are furiously contemplative, yet neither offers any indication that the director knows the difference between catatonia and anomie.But as thematically barren as Mr. Rudolph's work may beand his ideas about the spiritual poverty of modern life in Los Angeles seem pretty threadbare, to the extent that they're intelligible at all  they have a cool physical beauty that very nearly outweighs the foolishness. "Remember My Name" doesn't aspire to the self-congratulatory glamour of "Welcome to L.A.," but the cinematography this time (by Tak Fujimoto) is crisply handsome, and more helpful for being less showy.And Mr. Rudolph has once again attracted actors who are intrinsically interesting even when their material is not, notably Geraldine Chaplin, Anthony Perkins, Jeff Goldblum, Moses Gunn and Alfre Woodard. Also, Mr. Rudolph's recruiting of the blues singer Alberta Hunter, expertly recorded by John Hammond, to write and perform the score amounts to a marvelous coup.The story is very simple, although Mr. Rudolph goes to great pains to make it seem otherwise. Miss Chaplin plays a woman who has just completed a 12-year prison term for killing her husband's lover. When she is released, she tracks down her husband, played by Mr. Perkins, and his new wife, played by Berry Berenson.The first hour of the film is devoted to her efforts to annoy these happy newlyweds, who apparently aren't so happy, by tearing up their marigolds and throwing rocks through their windows. Miss Berenson, whose expressionlessness deadens this angle of the story, doesn't register much shock or surprise at these antics. Mr. Perkins looks puzzled and later explains that he didn't recognize his ex-wife because she used to be a blonde.Miss Chaplin's plans for revenge also involve her getting a job as a cashier at a five-and-ten, because, as one character explains it, "the best way to learn about anything is to learn how much it costs." Mr. Rudolph is at his most implausible in trying to deal with this kind of workaday locale; indeed, he seemed far more at home with the privileged "Welcome to L.A." characters. When he casts Mr. Perkins as a blue-collar construction worker, it's just a matter of poor judgment. But Moses Gunn's role, as a sad black security guard whom Miss Chaplin manages somehow to enslave and turn into her own personal handyman, is markedly unpleasant in its implications.In addition to calling attention to the film's class condescension, Mr. Gunn's character also pinpoints a big problem with Miss Chaplin's performance: As a woman whose sexuality is meant to seem all-consuming and irresistible, she's simply too chilly most of the time. During the final half hour, when her plans for Mr. Perkins take shape, Mr. Rudolph shoots her in reddish light and lets the two actors loosen up considerably, achieving his desired effect. Until then, though, Miss Chaplin's walking-wounded manner is too remote to allow the story much momentum.Like the other players, she has been too cooperative with a screenplay that feels incomplete. Throughout "Remember My Name," the actors work hard to fulfill the surface requirements of scenes that have no dramatic foundation, and the results are often skittish and baffling.There is also a running thread of commentary on various television news broadcasts in the background, about an earthquake in Budapest, that should have been unraveled. When a movie has to rely on television reports, newspaper headlines, billboards, floods or thunderstorms to make its points about the human condition, it might as well drop the message in the mail.

title: In a Neighborhood Luncheonette, Food for Body and Soul
description: I HAD been stumped once too often. Hadn't I told them at the Woodbox, Why, growing up in Brooklyn, we slept with baseball record books under our pillows. And they believed me. Why, wasn't it 505 feet to deepest center field in the old Polo Grounds. Phil Rizzuto did have a higher lifetime batting average than Pee Wee Reese.

title: Hitler in England 1912
description: BERYL BAINBRIDGE is in a situation that most novelists don't even have the luck to know about. Young Adolf is her seventh novel; the previous six have been a continuous success story in her own country (though she may still be a minority taste in America). Her novels have all been written in the same highly original tone of voice; they are short, quirky, funny and horrifying, and exploit the memories and fantasies of her own girlhood and youth. The bestfilled purses become empty in the end; and even if she had more of this sinister gold to concoct from her very ordinary Liverpool past and her early experiences in love and work, there would be critics who would say: Is this the only kind of thing she can do? And yet, when a novelist in this position suddenly changes tune and tone, there will be confusion among the faithful, who miss the anticipated voice, the expected chills and heats.

title: Carol L. Mast To Wed May 5
description: The engagement of Carol L. Mast, a secondyear student at the Catholic University Law School, to Bennett H. Beach, a 1978 graduate of the school, has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. David Mast of Washington, parents of the future bride.
