title: Lake Placid Passes Its PreOlympic Tests.
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., March 10 When this colorful Adirondack village received the goahead in 1975 from the International Olympic Committee to stage the 1980 Winter Games, there were many who insisted it could not be done.

title: Food
description: It has always seemed to me that one of the most curious customs in the world of eating is the British tradition of serving savouries at the end of a meal. A savoury or savory, to give it its American spelling, is a nonsweet, often salty food that is served in small portions after the dessert to conclude a meal.

title: The Search for a Settlement Follows a WellTrodden Path
Man vs. Beast in Kenya
description: The Government of Kenya, a country that increasingly begins to resemble the fabled peaceable kingdom when viewed against the troubled background of the rest of East Africa, is striving to solve its tourism squabble with neighboring Tanzania, but the outlook is not promising.

title: Brookhaven's Emergency Room: the Burden of Providing a Mix of Crisis Care and Routine Treatment
description: EAST PATCHOGUE. L.I.  Its 8 o'clock on a Saturday night. A young mother is holding a feverish child on her lap in the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital emergency room here. Across the way, a group of teenagers are huddled close together. Minutes before, they brought in a friend unconscious. He had taken 30 Quaaludes.

title: Carter Gets a Muted Greeting in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, March 10  The crowds greeting President Carter here tonight were sparse and far less enthusiastic than those who greeted him in Cairo and Alexandria.

title: Rutgers Women Advance
description: TOWSON, Md., March 10  Rutgers, using the fastbreak offense that helped it qualify for the final, defeated Maryland, 8075, tonight to win the Middle Atlantic region championship and advance to the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women sectional tournament.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 11, 1979

title: Miss Lopez Gaining at Sunstar Classic
description: RANCHO PARK, Calif., March 10There are only 18 holes remaining in the 72hole, $100,000 Sunstar Classic and the final round looks as if it will be a showdown tomorrow between Hollis Stacy, the leader by two strokes, and Nancy Lopez, the closest pursuer, for the $15.000 top prize money.

title: St Lawrence Picks Talley
description: CANTON, N.Y. (AP)  St. Lawrence University has chosen Andy Talley, offensive coordinator at Brown, as its head football coach. Talley succeeds Ted Stratford, who resigned last fall to become coach at Hamilton College.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Knoll Farms, Suffolk Avenue, Brentwood. L. I. Regular working hunters, open jumpers, equitation. 9 A. M.

title: Where the Best of TV Is Being Preserved
description: When it appeared several years ago that no copies existed of his longrunning series, You'll Never Get Rich, Phil Silvers, television's Ernie Bilko, couldn't quite believe it. He was shocked, and it took his daughter to revive him. She told her father that over a hundred of the shows were stashed away in a garage. Shortly afterward, he donated them to the Academy of Television Arts and SciencesUCLA Television Archives, which now handles them with the kind of care Sergeant Bilko always felt he deserved.

title: The Arts: Gateway To Love of Learning
description: YOUNG people learn if they are interested, Jean Haddock said with conviction. The problem is to get them interested.

title: No Mea Culpas
description: 25yearold bon vivant in Paris in 1928, William S. Paley fell in love with a highstyle, oneofakind Hispano Suiza and cashed in his stocks to buy the automobile for $16,000. But he quickly found he didn't enjoy having it, because it drew crowds of people wherever he went. I wanted an attentiongetting object without the attention, Mr. Paley observes in his autobiography, As It Happened. and he adds: It may be that haven't changed much in that respect in the last fifty years. the attention, Mr. Paley observes in his autobiography, As It Happened. and he adds: It may be that haven't changed much in that respect in the last fifty years.

title: City P.S.A.L. Wins State Track
description: ITHACA, N.Y. March 10  The P?? ?? Schools Athletic League of New York City, scoring in 10 of the 17 event?? and winning five of them ea??y captured the title today with 36 points ??n the New York State Public High Schools Athletic Assocation indoor track and field championships at Co??nell' Barton Hall. It was only the second year the P.S.A.L. had comp??ted in the meet.

title: Sporting Gear
description: More and more, seasons for coldweather sports are overlapping with warmweather seasons. And more and more, sporting customs of one section of the country are combining with those of another. The result? Some new concepts in participant athletics. Take skiing and surfing. Now you can do both on a snowy slope. A number of manufacturers have combined the surfboard with the snow ski and corne up with an exciting pastime, monoskiing.

title: News Summary
description: Israel's Cabinet approved some of the newly revised language proposed by the United States for a peace treaty with Egypt and left other parts open for further consideration. Details of the Cabinet decision were not disclosed, but a Foreign Ministry spokesman said it should provide enought encouragement for Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance to go to Cairo today to get a response from President Anwar elSadat. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: SiltPolluted Streams Found Surprisingly Resilient
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 11 Streams polluted with silt running off from coal strip mines can recover in decades, much more quickly than had been thought, according to a recent study by the University of Tennessee.

title: F.D.A Panel Urges Curb On Some Vitamin Sales
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)  A Government advisory panel recommended today that curbs be imposed on sales of some vitamins and minerals as nonprescription drugs and that labels mentioning super potency, natural or stress be banned.

title: Restaurant Tipping: The Captain, the Waiter, The Sommelier...
description: In the nottoodistant future, if things go according to plan, patrons at the 21 Club will get a discreet little card along with their bill suggesting what the gratuity should be.

title: DONALD POWER DIES; RETIRED G.T.E. CHIEF
description: Donald C. Power, under whose leadership the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation grew to become one of the nation's largest companies, died of cancer yesterday in his home at Galloway, Ohio, a suburb of Columbus. He was 79 years old.

title: Piano: Arthur Fennimore
description: ARTHUR FENNIMORE's piano recital Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was a basically pleasing affair. Mr. Fennimore likes to play things fast and fleet. Yet unlike so many speed demons of the keyboard, he generally manages to invest the music with idiomatic feeling and convincing musicality. His is hardly the only way to play, to be sure. But it's one way, and an honorable one.

title: DEGUSTIBUS
description: In a recent column I listed (at the request of t reader) the spices I would have on my spice ??helf if storage space was at a premium. My noccs were thyme and bay leaf, cloves, nu; m ??g rtnd oregano. Next in order: dried basil. ??ayenne pepper, chili powder, ??tuder, cinnamon and tarragon.

title: School That Disciplines Retarded Fails 2d State Test
description: ALBANY, March 9  A Rhode Island institution attended by severely retarded and autistic children has sharply reduced its use of controversial physical punishments as part of its treatment for the children, but has still failed to meet New York State standards, according to a followup report by the State Education Department.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Legal Subcommittee on Outer Space: 3 P.M.

title: Taiwan Denies Plan To Meet With Peking On Issue of Olympics
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March H  The president of Taiwan's Olympic committee said today that contrary to reports from Switzerland, sports representatives of Taiwan had not agreed to meet facetoface with China's sports officials to discuss the issue of representation in the international Olympic organization.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Commodities
description: LUMBER futures contracts for May delivery closed down $5 at $218 for each thousand board feet on Friday, a price that will be charted by quite a few economic trend watchers. A week ago, the closing price was $223.80.

title: TV's Blues Brothers Moving to Films
description: LOS ANGELES, March 11  John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd will move their Blues Brothers act from television's Saturday Night Live into the movies next summer. The Blues Brothers will be written by Mr. Aykroyd and directed by John Landis for Universal Pictures.

title: Notes on People
description: She had hoped to be in New York over the weekend to promote a television movie, Bette Davis said by telephone, But while visiting friends in Connecticut, I had this stupid, unnecessary accident  slipped and fell on the ice and broke two ribs. And now I'm in bed. You can't do anything about ribs ex cept want.

title: 12YearOld Steals Gymnastics Show
description: A 12yearold ntmed Tracee Talavera, the youngest person on the floor of Madison Square Garden, became an instant celebrity yesterday by almost capturing the women's championship in the American Cup gymnastics tournament.

title: Racing: Con Celia Scores
description: Con Celia, a 5yearold Argentinebred mare, took over at the top of the stretch and won the $53,550 Correction Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Tanzanian Force in Uganda Is Reported to Fall Back
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 11  A Taazanianbacked invasion force that had been moving toward Kampala, the Ugandan capital, was reported today to have fallen back, but the military situation remained confused.

title: 2d Gem Merchant in Two Days Vanishes With Precious Stones
description: A 27yearold gem dealer carrying as much as $250,000 in precious stones to a customer was reported to have disappeared on Friday, just two days after another New York City dealer was reported missing with up to $500,000 in diamonds.

title: Books of The Times
description: EINSTEIN'S UNIVERSE. By Nigel Calder. 154 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $10.

description: Partial List of schectuted meetings for week follows:

title: Colombia Army Said to Torture Leftist Suspects
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 11  A repressive campaign by the Colombian armed forces against the principal urban guerrilla organization has produced widespread charges of violations of human rights and concern over the military's role in this country's democracy.

title: Song: Clancy Brothers
description: INASMUCH as so many of the Clancy Brothers songs are paeans to strong drink, it seemed poeticallyust that their concert at Carnegie Halton Saturday night was disrupted at one point by altercations among a cluster of rowdy, apparently arunken young men and the listeners they had been annoying all evening. An onlooker in the second balcony subsequently egged the brawlers on by bellowing, Stand up and fight like a man if you re Irish!

title: Szerying In Recital At the Y
description: THERE were no surprises at Henryk Szerying's recital Saturday night at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association. The program was an oldfashioned one  sonatas by Mozart  (K. 454 in Bflat) and Brahms (No. 3 in D minor), plus series of short, lighter pieces, beginning with Bloch's Nigun' and closing with a couple of Kreisler selections. As for the performance, Mr. Szerying is, and remains, both a master violinist and a refined musician.

title: McGovern Urges Orter Dismiss Schlesinger for Energy Policies
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) Senator George S; McGovern called on President Carter today to dismiss Energy Secretary James R. Schles. He accused Mr. Schlesinger of off g. Mexico, increasing the nation's dependence on imported oil, delaying coal development and deliberately causing oil prices to rise.

title: The Region
description: PRINCETON (UPI)  The state's Higher Education Chancellor, T. Edward Hollander, will ask Governor Byrne to seek a court injunction if faculty members at eight state colleges carry out their threat to strike on March 19.

title: Dance: BatDor Company of Israel
description: HE BatDor Dance Company of Israel; which is making its United States debut during its current national tour, attracted some of this country's leading dance figures to the opening of its brief engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Saturday night.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TONIGHT

title: Melinda Young Bride of R.D. Rosengarten
description: In the clubhouse at the Gipsy Trail Club in Carmel, N.Y., yesterday afternoon, Melinda Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Young of HastingsonHudson, N.Y., became the bride of Richard D. Rosengarten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rosengarten of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Robinson of CrotononHudson, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: 51 Caline Takes Santa Susana
description: ARCADIA. Calif., March 11 (AP) Caline, ridden by Bill Shoemaker, won a racelong duel with favored Terlingua to capture Santa Anita's 3yearold filly championship with a onelength victory in the $114,000 Santa Susana Stakes today.

title: MunicipalsSlate Full
description: A huge volume of taxexempt bond financing is scheduled in the credit markets this week, but few corporate bond sales and no Treasury or Federal agency financings are planned.

title: Abortion and the 99 Percent
description: For opponents of abortion rights, there's good news from Washington: Restrictions on Medicaid funding have nearly eliminated Federal financing of abortion. The new data confirm what old data suggested: that the current law is proving dramatically effective. In the last 11 months of last year, Federally funded abortions plummeted to 2,421 from an average of 250,000 to 300,000 a year before the law was tightened  a reduction of 99 percent.

title: Student Wants Parents to Learn About Nutrition to Help Children
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI)  A South Carolina 10thgrader, one of the first two students ever named to the Agriculture Department's child nutrition advisory council, says that teaching parents about nutrition is a key to better eating by children.

title: Advertising
description: THE first thing that Richard K. Mariff Inc., an ad agency, wanted to do for the National Car Rental System, its client, was to increase its public recognition. That assignment went to the abrasive comedian Don Rickles, who became the company's spokesman in its television commercials.

title: Pennsylvania Vehicles Are Killing More Deer
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., March 11 (AP) Nearly six times more deer died an Pennsylvania highways in 1978 than were killed by archers.

title: Letter: On Juvenile Justice
description: To the Editor: The March 3 editonal Due Process for Juveniles highlights issues crucial not only to the future of New York City, but to the nature of society in the United States in the next generation.idea of what works. The reality is much more shocking. We can document over and over again that where there has been a commitment to systematic comprehensive services. there are records of success with young people who have transgressed.

title: Study Outlines Shift of Berkeley To Laboratory of Radical Politics
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 11  Taking what he called a leadership role in the international movement against apartheid, Mayor Warren Widener has endorsed two initiatives on the April 17 city ballot that call tor the withdrawal of fan estimated $10 million in city funds from banks that make loans to the Republic of South Africa.

title: Recital: Enid Katahn at Piano
description: END KATAIIN gave a very ne;,t, precise and correctly plated piano recital in Alice Tui'y H.AII Saturday afternoon. She is an e.ceptionally polished technician. especially when it comes to articulating rapid scalar passagework, and her program was on the whole sensibly devised to accent her strong points in this respect

title: ESSAY Forward to Death
description: WASHINGTON  Mullah Mustapha alBarzani, veteran leader of the Kurdish people, received me for the last time a couple of months ago in his small but wellguarded house in Virginia. Since we shared a fondness for pistachio nuts, he put a large bowl of the Iranian nuts between us, and as we shelled, he talked.

title: The City
description: Mayor Koch has again defended the police investigation into last December's takeover of a police station house in Borough Park by members of a Hasidic group. He commented amid accusations by police officers from Brooklyn who contended they did not receive support from their superior officers after the riot, but were threatened with suspension instead.

title: Herbert Johnson, 68, First Head Of Jamaica Bay's Wildlife Refuge
description: Herbert A. Johnson, the first director of the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge and superintendent of the 12,000acre sanctuary, died Thursday at his home in Rocky Point, L.I. He was 68 years old and had retired in 1972.

title: Auto Racing: Yarborough Wins
description: RICHMOND, March II (AP)  Cale Yarborough gunned his Oldsmobile past Bobby Allison into the lead on the 25th lap today and slowly pulled away to win the Richmond 400 Grand National stockcar race at Fairgrounds Raceway.

title: STATE WIDENS AUDIT OF CITY INCOME TAX
description: ALBANY, March 11  New York State plans to step up its audits of tax returns filed by New York City taxpayers in an effort to raise $10 million a year for the city.

title: Around the Nation
description: ST. LOUIS, March 11 (UPI)  Prodded by a court order, striking teachers and the Board of Education reached tentative agreement today in the strike that has closed public schools to 73,000 students since Jan. 16.

title: ForeignersTakeovers Irk Banks
description: With a number of major foreign takeovers pending, the American banking industry is discreetly mobilizing a defense effort, asking state and Federal authorities to take the campaign to the public.

title: WSB Is SeekingWashington Steel.
description: Blount Inc. and the Washington Steel Corporation announced that WSB Inc., a wholly owned subs:diary of Blount. had commenced an offer to buy for cash all the outstanding common shares of Washington Steel at $40 a share net to the seller. Based on the 1.44 million common shares outstanding of Washington Steel the transaction is valued at $57.6 million.

title: New Orleans Sanitation Workers Reject City's Contract Proposal
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 11 (AP)  Apparently afraid of losing their jobs to private contractors, sanitation workers voted today to reject a proposed threeyear contract with the city.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: SocialService Leaders Dispute Carey Budget And Ask Welfare Rise
description: Predicting that the state's revenue will be $180 million more than Governor Carey's budget expects, a 26member task force of socialservice leaders has called for an increase in welfare grants and other spending.

title: Auto Industry Prepares for Clash With U.S. Over Fuel Standards
description: DETROIT, March 11  The Federal Government and the nation's automobile industry are going into battle over key Federal programs aimed at reducing fuel consumption and pollution from automobiles, and there are indications from both sides that the auto makers may win concessions.

title: Golf: Nelson Posts First Victory
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla., March 11 (AP)  Larry Nelson, undisturbed by the gusty winds, protected his lead with a frontrunning 71 and scored the first victory of his professional career by a comfortable three strokes today in the Inverrary Golf Classic.

title: A Bustamante Formulafor Business and Politics
description: The political and economie power of the Bustamante family can be traced back to friendships formed in the 1940's at a Tijuana bank, where Allonso Bustamante Sr. was an accountant.

title: DATA BACK THEORY ON JUPITER MOON 10
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 11 A couple of months ago three California scientists wrote a paper explaining why some strange things might be happening to heat up Io, the innermost of Jupiter's major moons. The paper was published in the March 2 issue of the journal Science, three days before Voyager 1's rendezvous with Io, and it may well have been prophetic.

title: St. John's, Penn Upset A.C.C. Fives
description: RALEIGH. N.C., March 11  The University of Pennsylvania, champions of the lightly regarded Ivy League, and St. John's Univers'ty, the 40th and last team picked for this year's National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, posted two of the biggest upsets in the 41year history of the tournament today.

title: Reporter's Notebook
description: JERUSALEM, March 11  On this sunny, early spring day, Jerusalem was going through another of those moments of high drama in which Israelis so often find themselves and on which so many of them seem to thrive.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: B. John Mackin, a Houston lawyer, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Zapata Corporation, the company announced. He succeeds William H. Flynn, who was placed on a leave of absence on Feb. 5, according to the Zapata announcement.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Hollywood Report

title: Irish Ballet to Make U.S. Debut April 4
description: The Irish Ballet Company, under the auspices of Noel Pearson, will make its American debut during a twoweek engagement beginning April 4 at the City Center55th Street Theater. There will be a single preview on April 3. Performing in consort with the Chieftains, a group of virtuoso performers of traditional Irish music, the company will present the American premiere of The Playboy of the Western World, twoact, fulllength dance version of the J.M. Synge comedy, which has been choreographed by Joan Denise Moriarity, artistic director of the Irish Ballet.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Trusting In Illusions
description: BOSTON, March 11  Shortly before Ayatollah Khomeini returned to Iran, he was visited in Paris by an American group that included Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, and Richard Falk, Professor of International Law at Princeton. The Americans carne away from the meeting with reassuring words about the Ayatollah's moderation and fairness.

title: Arab Criticism Intensifies Over Carter's Role in Treaty
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 11  Arab criticism of President. Carter's mission and warxings against a peace treaty between Egypt and Israel gained in intensity today.

title: City Opera: Rigoleitck
description: THE most exciting part of Saturday afternoon's Rigoletto at the New York City Opera was the opening scene. Eugene Holmes, singing the title role for the first time in New York, excelled in his exchange with Monterone, using his dark, throaty baritone to create a truly threatening caricature of the stuffy count. After the curse, he curdled his exclamations of Orrore! with withering sarcasm, while gleefully twitching and hopping all over the stage.

title: Deadline Near for Umpires
description: ST. PETERSSURG, Fla., March 11  The first full week of baseball exhibition games began today with all 52 umpires still absent And three, local umpires, hired through the Sunshine Officials Association, were working the game When the St. Louis Cardinals scored twice in the 11th inning and defeated the NewYork Mets. 42.

title: David S. Brenner, 72, Founder. Of Brenner Income Tax Service
description: David S. Brenner, founder of the Brenner Income Tax Service, with offices in the New York metropolitan area and the Catskills, died Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital. Mr. Brenner, who lived at 295 Central Park West and was in retirement at his home in Grahamsville. N.Y., was 72 years old.

title: Study Calls for Testing Of Alternatives to Trials
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)  A federally funded study has proposed that European alternatives to criminal trials, such as onthespot fines and administrative courts, be tried on an experimental basis in the United States.

title: A Chemical in the Balance
description: It took 10 years after Rachel Carson, in her book Silent Spring, called DDT an elixir of death before the Federal Government in mid1972 banned the pesticide. Since then, Congress has passed the Pesticide Control Act (1972), substantial News Analysis amendments to the act (1975) and the Toxic Substances Control Act (1976).

title: New En vironm en tat Fight Looms Over Developing CoalRich Utah Area
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 11  What may be the largest energy project since the Alaska pipeline is threatening to bring on Round Two of a fierce fight over the Kaiparowits Plateau in southern Utah.

title: Conservatives Seek Tie With Right to Life Party
description: The leadership of the Conservative Party and the new Right to Life Party met quietly in Hicksville, L.I., last week. But as is common with politicians of the major parties, the two sides disagreed on the import and sie

title: Albany Moves Toward DivorceLaw Change
description: Major reform of the law governing distribution of property upon divorce, stalled in the New York State Senate for several years, may have been given new impetus by a decision of the United States Supreme Court last Monday that declared unconstitutional a law restricting eligibility for alimony to women.

title: Using a Mexican Middleman
description: TIJUANA, Mexico  The dealings of two California companies with a powerful Mexican family are under investigation by United States Government authorities. In one case, alleged kickbacks of more than $10 million are being investigated by a Federal grand jury, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Quake Jolts Northwest Area
description: KELSO, Wash., March II (UPI)  A small earthquake struck southwestern Washington today, shaking buildings and houses but causing no damage or injuries. A spokesman for the United States Geological Survey in Boulder, Colo., said the quake, which measured 3.8 on the Richter scale, occurred at 9:39 A.M. Eastern standard time and was centered northeast of Kelso.

title: Tiger Wins Court Battle In Bid for Seaboard Stock
description: Since midOctober a feroc ou5 tut largely unheralded battle has been under way between Tiger International Inc. and Seaboard World Airline Inc which Tiger is seeking to take over.

title: Audit Finds $2 Million City Waste on Seized Property
description: New York City wasted nearly $2 million in the 1976.77 fiscal year through nonproductive or unnecessary expenditures in the maintenance of residential properties taken over for tax delinquency, an audit report by the City Comptroller declared yesterday.

title: Arbour Satisfied As Islanders Tie
description: BOSTON, March 11  The New York Islanders and the Boston Bruins played to a 44 tie in a rambunctious National Hockey League game tonight in the Boston Garden.

title: Party Paper Says Mao, Not Radicals, Caused China's Lag
description: HONG KONG, March 11  When the Chinese Communist Party decreed in December that it would henceforth shift the focus of its work from political struggle to economic development, many Chinese must have welcomed the

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has there ever been a switchpitcher in either the major or the minor leagues?

title: Tennis: Turnbull Triumphs
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 11  Midway in the third set, a hoarse voice echoed throughout the Spectrum, imploring Virginia Wade to get her game together. The cry of deefense, by a tennis fancier who perhaps also attends Flyer hockey games, went unheeded by Miss Wade.

title: Washington Watch
description: Washington

title: New Hampshire Six Takes E.C.A.C. Title
description: BOSTON, March 11  The New Hampshire captain, Bob Gould, scored on a rising slap shot with 2 minutes 43 seconds left Saturday night to give the Wildcats their first Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I hockey title with a 32 triumph over Dartmouth.

title: White House Aides Seek to Raise Efficiency of Regulatory Boards
description: WASHINGTON, March 11  Quietly but with gathering force, a group of White House economists opposed to established methods of regulation has set itself up as a counterweight to the agencies charged with regulating the nation's health, safety and environment.

title: New Yorkers Catch Movie Rehearsal and a Bit of Morning Snow
description: Ali McGraw ran along Fifth Avenue yesterday during rehearsal for scene of a new movie, Just Tell Me What You Want, to the delight of a crowd of pass ersby walking in the snow. Snow quickly changed to rain, and skies later cleared. Today is expected to stay sunny, with temperatures in the 30's.

title: Presidential Bid In 1980 Election Denied by Carey
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that he had no intention of running for President in 1980 and that he would support President Carter if he sought reelection.

title: 16 Hurt in High Japanese Winds
description: TOKYO, March 11 (AP)  Winds that gusted up to 76 miles an hour swept across Tokyo and northern Japan today caused 16 injuries and left 6 fishermen missing in rough Pacific seas, authorities reported.

title: Aspin Criticizes 7 NATO Nations
description: WASHINGTON, March 11  Some nalions of the North Atlantic Treaty Organiration are ignoring the alliance's pledge to raise defense spending 3 percent this year, after inflation, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: Panel Investimting Chrysler Efforts on Emission Rules
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 A House Government Operations subcommittee is investigating the Chrysler Crporation's efforts to weaken clean air standards during the 1977 session of Congress.

title: Chicken Delight
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Music: Evening of Bartok
description: THE Performers Committee for 20thCentury Music ended its threeconcert Continuum series at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night with a program entitled Bela BartokThe Later Years.

title: 7 Prisoners Escape From Rikers, but 5 Are Recaptured
description: Seven prisoners escaped from the House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island last night, but five were recaptured shortly afterward, authorities reported.

title: Peking Accuses Hanoi Of Enslaving Laotians In Drive in Indochina
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 11 (AP)  The Chinese Government said today that Soviet and Vietnamese pressure had caused Laos to expel Chinese advisers from that country, and it accused Hanoi of tightening its hold on Laos as part of a drive to dominate Indochina.

title: Weekiy Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 5,19,16, 29, 7 and 12. The supplementary number was 13.

title: Reno Incident Big Obstacle Between Martin and Yanks
description: Four months after Billy Martin's fight with a Reno sportswriter, Martin has not been served with an arrest warrant on the criminal charge stemming from the fight, nor has he been served with papers in the civil suit filed against him.

title: Flawed Argument for Cutting City Services
description: Letters

title: Wrestling: Kinseth And Iowa on Top
description: AMES, Iowa, March 11 (UPI) Bruce Kinseth of Iowa, named as the outstanding wrestler of the 1979 National Collegiate tournament, said he was not thinking about individual awards but was more concerned with making sure the Hawkeyes won the team title.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: U.C.L.A. and DePaulTriumphant in West
description: LOS ANGELES, March 11  Pepperdine attempted to accomplish the near impossible todaybeat the University of California, Los Angeles on the Bruins home floor. For a while it seemed as if the Waves might have a chance, but the Bruins prevailed, 7671 before a partisan crowd of 12.181 at Pauley Pavilion in a secondround game of the National Collegiate baskethall tournament.

title: Tongsun Park Testifies Today
description: MONROE, La March 11 (AP)  The jury that must decide whether former Representative Otto E. Passman accepted bribes will begin hearing testimony tomorrow  with the leadoff witness expected to be Tongsun Park. the South Korean businessman. Mr. Pass. man is accused of taking $213,000 from Mr. Park. including $98,000 in bribes, to get American rice sold to South Korea, and of failing to report $143,000 of the money to the Internal Revenue Service to get out of paying $77.000 in taxes.

title: Motives Are Tangled in the War in Uganda
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 11  The fighting now going on in Uganda is one more example of how rarely conflicts in Africa remain simple, straightforward wars, devoid of deception and uncomplicated by outside interference.

title: The Price of Fur
description: With the recent boom in fun furs  longhaired, wildcaught furs  prices paid to the trapper have gone up as much as 50 percent over last year, when they were al ready In the cold country of Glover, Vt., 20 miles south of Canada, for example, the local buyer has paid $38 for a top raccoon skin, versus $25 a year ago. Red foxes now range from $15, for a poor pelt, up to $77, versus $15 to $58 last year. Top eastern coyotes have gone to $50 and fisher to a high of $165.

title: Pentagon Spending Seen Helping Western Cities
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)  An analysis of military spending and tax payments in the nation's 40 largest metropolitan areas indicates that Eastern and Middle Western cities underwrite a flood of Defense Department money headed for Western cities.

title: Nets Squeak Past 76ers, 104103
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., March 11 Bernard King's layup with two seconds left to play today gave the New Jersey Nets a 104403 victory over the slumping Philadelphia 76ers at the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: Halted Flights Raise Concern
description: WASHINGTON, March 11  Expressing concem that airlines may use the recent shortage of aviation fuel as an excuse to cancel lightly traveled or unprofitable routes, Representative Peter H. Kostmayer today called on the Civil Aeronautics Board to monitor flight cancellations and to consider establishing guidelines for determining which flights should be canceled because of the oil shortage.

title: China AdvertisesCola Drink on TV
description: TOKYO, March 11, (AP) China has broadcast its first television commercial, one that promotes a soft drink called Happiness Cola, Radio Peking said Sunday. It said that the cola was plugged by members of a popular men's basketball team.

title: 3d Party Hopeful Buying TV Time to Assail Carter
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche, the United States Labor Party's 1980 Presidential candidate, is buying television time to accuse President Carter of taking the country to the brink of nuclear war with proChinese and antiSoviet policies.

title: Good Thing for a Horse
description: THERE was a wire service dispatch out of Glyndon, Md., the other day reporting the death of the thoroughbred gelding Find at the advanced age of 29. When he was racing, Find won $803,615, then and now the biggest bankroll ever earned by a horse foaled in Maryland.

title: Daily Routine Near Normal For Teheran
description: TEHERAN, March 11  There is no such thing as an empty street in Teheran on Sunday, which in the Moslem world is a normal working day. An accepted theory has it that if you could somehow straighten the network of streets here into one long road, and then line up all the vehicles in the city on it bumper to bumper, the road would accommodate only half the vehicles in town. The theory is gospel.

title: Segovia Gives Recital at the White House
description: WASHINGTON, March 11  Andres Segovia concluded a series of five Sunday afternoon concerts at the White House today with a 40minute recital. His appearance not only served to honor a distinguished artist, as all these events have done, but it also had an impact that went far beyond the. East Room. The recital was televised live in the Washington area and nationwide on tape tonight.

title: Turkish Leaders Start Campaign To Head Off Religious Violence
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 10  Turkey's supreme religious leader appeared on national television last night to urge an end to intrigues designed to shatter the unity of our country.

title: Bad Day for Jackson, Yanks
description: MIAMI, March 11  Reggie Jackson was involved in a minor car accident today while driving here from Fort Lauderdale for a game between the New York Yankees and Baltimore Orioles. The Yankees, with Jackson in the lineup, suffered their fourth straight loss of the spring training season, this time by a score of 73.

title: Events
description: Music

title: Harvard Is Warned on Activism
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11  Harvard University's academic and financial independence could be threatened if the university took political stands on issues that did not directly involve it, according to Harvard's president, Derek C. Bok.

title: Irish, Mich. StateScore in Mideast
description: MURFREESBORO, Tenn., March 11  The proud citizens of the state of Tennessee who had hoped for a victory by their. Volunteers over Notre Dame were disappointed today. The Irish pressed and trapped Tennessee and won, 73.67, in the second round of the National Collegiate Mideast Regional basketball tournament.

title: Begin, With a Dinner Comment, Turns Carter Grim and Ashen
description: JERUSALEM, March 11  Isaac Stern set a lyrical opening tone for Israel's state banquet Air Carter at the Parliament building tonight, choosing to open it with Beethoven's Spring Sonata for violin and piano because we all hope this may offer the beginning of a fresh new season.

title: Protecting Alaska
description: WASHINGTON  The debate over Alaska National Interest Lands has been portrayed as a contest between developers and conservationists. That portrayal misses the point: at least twothirds of Alaska will be open for development. The real issue: How much of the rest will be protected for all Americans?

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ABOUT TIME The name of Harry Warren comes up often these nostalgic evenings at piano bars around town, as do the ballads of Mr. Warren, one of Hollywood's most esteemed and prolific composers. Down at the Village Green, for instance, a pianist like Murray Grand can play his music by the hour. Surprised listeners invariably ask, He wrote that?

title: Arthur Belkin Marries Beth Glustrom in Jersey
description: Beth Ora Glustrom, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Simon Glustrom of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married there yesterday to Arthur Belkin, son of Mrs. Moms Smolen, also of Fair Lawn, and the late Abraham Belkin. The bride's father performed the ceremony at the Fair Lawn Jewish Center, of which he is the rabbi. Rabbi Marshall Maltzman of Philadelphia assisted.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Goldblatt Brothers Inc., ?? a ?? department store chain, ?? that Hareld Smith, President, ????

title: Three More Babies Die in Naples; Victims of Virus Now Number 76
description: NAPLES, March 11 (UPI)  Three infants, two boys and a girl, died here today, bringing to 76 the number of victims killed by a mysterious respiratory disease during the last year.

title: To DePaul's Ray Meyer, Final Goal Is the Final 4
description: CHICAGO

title: New York State Agrees to 7% Rise And New Merit Setup for 105,000
description: New York State and its largest public employee union reached tentative agreement yesterday on a threeyear contract for 105,000 clerical, institutional and bluecollar workers, providing for a 7 percent pay increase in the first year.

title: Earthquake Shakes Colombians
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 11 (AP) An earthquake that registered 5 on the Richter scale shook mach of Colombia this morning. Authorities said there were no immediate reports of casualties or major damage. The epicenter was near Lebrija, 260 miles east of Bogota.

title: Digest Digest
description: Industry

title: Paper Output for 1978 Set a Record
description: The paper industry produced a record 61.5 million tons of paper and paperboard in 1978, 3 percent more than the 1977 total and 2.7 percent more than the previous record of 59.9 million tons set in 1973, according to figures compiled by the American Paper Institute, the industry trade group.

title: BLACKS ARE LEAVING TOP FEDERAL POSTS
description: With the Carter Administration barely into its third year, the departure of a numb& of black appointees from the Administration and the demotion of a number of others have begun to cause alarm among some civil rights spokesmen and blacks remaining in Government posts.

title: Bridge:
description: Many of the leading players in the metropolitan area were cheering last week, having heard the news that one popular expert is in line for high office. Amalya Hearse, a partner in the law firm of Hughes, Hubbard & Reed, is one of a group of eight people recommended for two vacant judgeships on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Norwalk Seeks To Be the SoHo Of Connecticut
description: NORWALK, Conn., March 11A sprucedup movie house with freshly painted murals of Humphrey Bogart, Marilyn Monroe and Charlie Chaplin opened here Friday night, and some residents and city officials hailed it as another small step toward the rejuvenation of South Norwalk, a decaying waterfront area here, left behind in Fairfield County's rush toward prosperity.

title: Cost of Black Joblessness Measured in Crime, Fear and Urban Decay
description: The parade had been organized by black churchmen to bonor the birth of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Thousands of blacks and whites marched solemnly through the downtown business district of the paradefamous city of New Orleans last Jan. 15.

title: Louis Falk, 83, Headed Jersey Packing Concern
description: Louis A. Falk, former president of the Union Packing Company of Jersey City, died Saturday in Bergen Pines County Hospital, Paramus, N.J. He was 83 years old and a resident of Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Violin: Jacques Verdon
description: BRAHMS composed his three violin sonatas between 1879 and 1888, the years of his ripe maturity. Taken as a group these works add up to a logical, fulllength program of music, although they are seldom performed in tandem. Jacques Verdon and Lise Boucher, a violin and piano duo from Montreal, elected to do so at their New York debut late Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall, and with mixed results as it turned out.

title: Facing Up to Failure in Rhodesia
description: There is to be an election of sorts in Rhodesia next month by which the white minority regime hopes to make itself appear a black regime, thus finding acceptance in the West but running things pretty much as before. This cozy arrangement between Prime Minister Ian Smith and some cooperative black leaders is being challenged by two separate guerrilla forces. With the help of neighboring African states and Sovietbloc arms, the guerrillas have undermined the Government's control over much of the land and people.

title: PneumaticHennessy Deal
description: The Chicago Pneumatic Tool Corn pany said it had entered into an agreement to purchase the assets and liabilities of Hennessy Industries Inc for $30 million in cash. Hennessy is a privately held company that manufactures automotive wheel service equipment. It had worldwide sales of $46 million in its fiscal year ended Sept 30, 1978.

title: Carter Aide Asks Georgia Senate To Reject 9% Teacher Pay Rise
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) President Carter's top inflation fighter has appealed to officials in the President's home state to reject a 9 percent teacher pay increase as too high.

title: Closer BritishU.S. Intelligence Links Fostered by Loss of Iran Posts
description: LONDON, March 11  The loss by the United States of its Iranian listening posts is likely to result in still closer intelligence links with Britain, links that are already far closer than is generally recognized.

title: Refugees: Making It
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  Nearly four years have passed since the first evacuees from Vietnam began arriving at refugee centers in the United States. Having survived the trauma of years of warfare, flight from their homeland and separation from loved ones, they faced an uncertain future.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)  The strategic arms limitation treaty being negotiated by the Soviet Union and the United States was attacked today by senators representing opposing views.

title: Key Figure in South African Scandal
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, March 11  Throughout his career as South Africa's chief propagandist for apartheid, Eschel M. Rhoodie displayed extraordinary reserves of a quality known among Afrikaners as astrant something between cockiness and chutzpah. something between cockiness and chutzpah.

title: Recital: Berman Turns to a More Refined Style
description: PERHAPS Lazar Berman is becoming a bit weary of his reputation as a fireeating virtuoso of the keyboard. Certainly his concert programs and recordings of late seem to be concentrating on the less showy side of the repertory  and who can blame him for wanting to be regarded as thoughtful musician as well as a flamboyant pianist with a barnstorming technique.

title: Mexicans Protest an Intensification Of Inspections at Border in El Paso
description: EL PASO, March 11  Mayor Ray Salazar castigated the Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday for having created a potentially dangerous international situation along the United StatesMexico border here by stepping up its inspections.

title: Stage: Winter Signs, Drama by John Bishop
description: MOST of the time, John Bishop's Winter Signs, which opened yesterday at the Circle Repertory, is a play about civilized recriminations, but there is an extraneous element of suspense hanging over it.

title: Nancy Lopez Wins by Stroke
description: RANCHO PARK, Calif., March 11 Nancy Lopez breathed a sigh of relief after shooting a 69 for a oneshot victory today in the Sunstar Classic.

title: Amherst College to Sell Stock
description: AMHERST. Mass., March 11 (AP) The board of trustees of Hampshire College voted yesterday to sell its stock in companies that operate in South Africa and to instruct its brokers not to buy any more. Peter Gluckler, a spokesman for the fouryear liberal arts college, said the college would sell $30.000 in securities. He said that the decision was made in accordance with guidelines that were set up to prevent the college from investing in corporations that may do grave social injustice.

title: TV: A South African Black's Struggle
description: NELSON MANDELA's courageous 30year fight for freedom for his fellow blacks in South Africa is illuminated on Bill Moyers Journal on WNETTV from 9 to 10 o'clock tonight.

title: PaperWork Gap In City Hospitals Cutting U.S. Aid
description: A failure to perform the necessary paper work has cost New York City's municipal hospitals an estimated $10 million over seven years in Federal reimbursements for kidney machine treatments, dtv officials said yesterday.

title: TV Syndication by Satellite Is Set Up
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 11  In move to harness commercial television to the new satellite technology, three major broadcast concerns jointly announced over the weekend the creation of a satellite distribution system for syndicated programming, one that would deliver shows to stations more ecopomically and at far greater speed than the present postal method.

title: TV: Drama Of Updike's Sad Couple
description: EVERY once in a great while, the potential of both the madefortelevision movie and television itself is realized with a sudden fullness that leaves the spectator blinking in astonishment. The form and the medium, it seems, needn't be limited to silly Fantasy Island capers or calculating lifeanddeath crises exploiting fatal illnesses and assorted social diseases.

title: W.A.Spivack Weds Carole Fern Halpert
description: Carole Fern Halpert, a certified public accountant; was married yesterday at the Park Avenue Synogogue to William Allen Spivack, first vice president of Loeb Rhoades, Hornblower & Company. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony.

title: T.P.R.: Bullets Hang On, Spurs and Hawks Soar
description: The computerized team power ratings show plenty of movement this week. While the Washington Bullets have maintained their No. I ranking among National Basketball Association clubs, the next 13 spots have changed hands.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: UNIONDA LE, L.I., March 11  Fvier goals in the First 3 minutes 38 seconds of play enahled the New York Arrows to roll to a 124 victory over the Cleveland Force today in a Major Indoor Soccer League game at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Shah's Son Said to Leave U.S.
description: LUBBOCK, Texas, March 11 (Reuters)  The Shah of Iran's eldest son reportedly left here today to join his family in Morocco after completing flight training and receiving his pilot's wings at Reese Air Force Base.

title: Soviet Refugees Learn About Purim at a Brooklyn Party
description: I knew all about Brezhnev, I was always cheering Brezhnev, said Aleksei Stern, shaking his fist in a mock salute. But I never knew about Purim.

title: Arkansas AdvancesWith Indiana State
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., March 11 (AP)  Sidney Moncrief scored 19 points and Steve Schall added 18 to pace a patient Arkansas attack and lead the Razorbacks to a 7463 victory over Weber State in the second round of the National Collegiate Midwest Regional basketball tournament today.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Boston Symphony Off On China Tour Today
description: BOSTON, March 11  The 104 members of the Boston Symphony, accompanied by 11 tons of musical instruments, a press crew of about 20, officials of the orchestra and a handful of corporate sponsors, are poised for their flight to China tomorrow morning. Takeoff is scheduled for 9:30 from Logan Airport, and the group of 160 is expected to arrive in Shanghai tomorrow at 4 P.M.

title: Fashion His Fresh View
description: Frederick Zlotkin, cellist, played Bach as background music. If nothing else, that was sign that no ordinary fashion show was taking place on the second floor of 860 Madison Avenue, near 70th Street.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: For the first time since midDecember, the Federal Reserve has decided to raise shortterm interest rates to a slightly higher level.

title: ELSE KAUFMANN CHWAT
description: Else Kaufmann Chwat, a European cabaret performer of the 1920's and 30's, died Sunday at her home in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens. She was 83 years old.

title: Chess
description: There are few players  the world champions Emanuel Lasker and Bobby Fischer come to mind  who have ever been successful in playing into an opponent's strength. For  the rest, the challenge may be fun or ??erting but it surely is pet profiteble.

title: ISRAEL ACCEPTD SOME CHANGES SUGGESTED BY U.S. FOR TREATY; VANCE TRIP TO CAIRO EXPECTED
description: JERUSALEM, Monday, March 12 The Israeli Cabinet concluded a dramatic, allnight session at dawn today, approving some of the newly revised language proposed by the United States for a peace treaty with Egypt and leaving other aspects of the pact open for further consideration.

title: Bell Labs to Introduce New Computer Memory
description: In an innovation that for?shadows a major sinft in the market for computer memories, the Bell Telephone La?oratories has developed a new type of ma?? ?etic bubble memory device.

title: West Bank's Arab Leaders Disavow Autonomy Concept of Camp David
description: HEBRON, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, March 11  Mayor Fahad Kawasmeh's desk was piled high with papers. Outside his office, older Arabs wearing robes and checked kaffiyehs, the traditional cloth headdress, smoked pungent handrolled cigarettes as they awaited an audience

title: FOES OF KHOMEINIFOCUSING ON ISSUEOF WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 11  Theconfrontation between Islamic leaders under Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and their secular opponents grew more intense today around the issue of women's rights.

title: Outdoors: Getting Started in FlyFishing
description: TIME was when catching a fish  by whatever means that worked: clubs, spears, nets, traps and even the pounded roots of toxic plants was all that mattered. But the advent of fishing for fun as well as meat changed all that.

title: Greek Orthodox Celebrate Lent With Procession of Icons
description: Archbishop Iakovos officiated at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in Manhattan yesterday, for the Orthodox celebration of Lent. The service and pageantry traditionally include a procession of icons, or paintings of religious figures, such as the one below. Prayers and hymns are offered to commemorate the restoration of the icons to the church in an ancient ceremony in which the paintings are carried by members of the congregation.

title: Rangers, After a Lapse, Win by 52
description: You have to excuse the Rangers. Though playing excellent hockey these days, for more than half the game last night against the Chicago Black Hawks they seemed to be still savoring their Saturday night victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Norwalk AT A GLANCE
description: An area of 27.7 square miles, divided by the Norwalk. River and ranging from the harbor and shorefront along Long Island Sound to rolling and wooded hills near the Merritt Parkway, 42 miles from midtown Manhattan.

title: A Shorter, MoreEfficient Term Promised for Manhattan Jurors
description: Recent changes in law and procedures have dramatically increased Manhattan's jury pool, court officials say, and the increase may allow jurors not selected for a trial to be dismissed after one week instead of two.

title: Music: Country Players
description: THE word bluegrass brings to mind flashy mandolin, banjo and fiddle playing and male harmony singing, but on Friday and Saturday nights the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Country Musiq Series presented two women who sing bluegrass, Delia Bell and Hazel Dickens. Miss Bell and Miss Dickens both have strong voices, and the groups that backed them were deferential, keeping the instrumental grandstanding typical of most bluegrass groups to a minimum. Otherwise, their styles and philosophies seemed very different.

title: For Young People on a Street Corner in Harlem, Jobs Seem Few and Far Away
description: Trash fires burned in rusty oil drums on Harlem's street corners, and men circled the flames, looking for warmth in the bitter wind.

title: Kirbo Contests Report on Carter Loans
description: WASHINGTON, March 11  Charles H. Kirbo, trustee of President Carter's share of the family peanut business, sharply contested today an allegation that Billy Carter falsified warehouse records to hide a $500,000 bank loan deficit.

title: Sears Net Up 31% as Sales Drop
description: CHICAGO, March 12  Sears, Roebuck & Company announced today the strong results for its most recent fiscal quarter that a number of security analysts had said might accrue from a new corporate strategy  a 31 percent increase in net income despite a 1.3 percent dip in sales.

title: Some Drugs Found to Alter Fetal Brains
description: SOME drugs taken by pregnant women as treatment for serious mental illness might cause permanent changes in the brains of their children, according to scientists whose conclusions are based on new experiments with animals.

title: The Region
description: FORKED RIVER, N.J. (AP)  A construction worker was killed and at least two others were injured yesterday when gusty winds blew over three steel foundation forms at a nucleargeneratingstation turbine house. The 63foot columns were bundles of steel reinforcing rods used to form the base of a turbine building under construction at the Jersey Central Power & Light Company's Forked River station, said Sandy Levin, supervisor of site engineering.

title: Corporations Report Their Quarterly Sales and Earnings Results
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Woman Is Shot 3 Times at Bank After Reportedly Stabbing Guard
description: A woman in her late 20's tried to force her way into a Washington Heights savings bank at knifepoint yesterday morning, stabbing a guard before being shot three times, the police reported.

title: Russian Jalled in Army Evasion
description: MOSCOW, March 12 (Reuters)  A Soviet court today sentenced a 19yearold Pentecostal Christian to a year in a labor camp for evading army service, dissident sources said. The youth, Aleksandr Orlik, was said to have been convicted in the Pacific Coast city of Nakhodka. The Pentecostal community, mainly in Siberia and the Far East, has been in frequent conflict with authorities. Seven Pentocostalists seeking to go abroad took asyulum in the American Embassy here last June.

title: U.F.T. Plans to Seek Arbitration On Paraprofessionals Contract
description: The United Federation of Teachers decided last night to seek binding arbitration to resolve a contract dispute over yearround salaries and pension rights for the city's 10,000 paraprofessionals.

title: 2d Texaco Well Is Dry Hole
description: Texaco Inc., so far the only company to have come across a potential oil or gas discovery in the Baltimore Canyon off New Jersey, said yesterday that second well drilled near its initial find was a dry hole. The company said the well had been completed and fully tested without encountering oil or gas in producible quantities.

title: Man Accused of Raping 3 Central Park Joggers
description: A 27yearold Manhattan man was indicted yesterday on charges of raping three women joggers in Central Park in the last four months.

title: OBSERVER
description: In Middletown, Conn., Wesleyan University scientists have unwrapped a mummy to extract four cigarshaped objects which Xrays had located in the abdominal cavity. The deceased is thought to be from 2,500 to 3,000 years old and to have died as a teenager.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 13, 1979

title: Taxes
description: FOR years, the Internal Revenue Service has used statistical sampling techniques to select tax returns for audit. Within the last few months, however. it has been quietly expanding the technique and applying it to the actual tax audits of the country's biggest corporations.

title: Steel Output Up 4% in Week
description: Steel production for the week ended March 10 rose to 2.8 million tons, up 4 percent from the previous week's total of 2.7 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Top U.S. Mediator to Join Teamster Contract Talks
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  The Government's top labor mediator announced today that he would join the crucial contract negotiations between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the trucking industry tomorrow amid reports that the talks had ground to a standstill.

title: Even in Best Times, True Picture Of Amin's Uganda Stays Hidden
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 12  At the most critical moment in President Amin's eightyear dictatorship, it is always difficult and sometimes impossible to obtain information from Uganda or to make sense out of the little there is.

title: Rhodesian Planes Raid Camps in Mozambique
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Maron 12 (Reuters)  Rhodesian planes attacked uerrilla targets in Mozambique today, military headquarters reported.

title: Dainippon Extends Polychrome Offer
description: Dainippon Ink and Chemicals America Inc. said it was extending its offer to purchase any and all outstanding common shares of the Polychrome Corporation to 5 P.M. on April 11. Dainippon is a wholly owned subsidiary of Dainippon Ink and Chemicals of Tokyo.

title: Ghosts of U.S. Still Haunting A City in Iran
description: ISFAHAN, Iran, March 12  This used to be a company town.

title: Jobless Rate of Blacks Still Rising Despite a 25Year Federal Effort
description: There is no shortage of programs aimed at helping the unemployed particularly the poor, the black and the young.

title: Recital: Novel Clarinetist
description: THERE were some novel goingson at Richard Stoltzman's clarinet recitalSunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall. Bill Douglas, Mr. Stoltzman's pianist. supplied a set of jazzy, quasi-improvisatory pieces brimming with oppor- tunities for vocalizing, clapping, foot tapping and heelkicking. Later, Mr. Douglas switched to the bassoon, and he and Mr. Stoltzman offered three of Bach's TwoPart Inventions. On hir. own, Mr. Stoltzman presented William. McKinley's For One, a sevenminute solo workout embracing an assortment of dynamic and registeral extremes.

title: TaxFree Bond List Half Sold
description: Almost $500 million of new taxexempt bonds were tentatively priced yesterday as this week's heavy schedule of state and city bond sales got under way. As investment bankers set terms on new issues, some yields were raised and some were lowered, but there was no overall trend in the level of interest rates.

title: Hopes Dim for fob Seekers Counting on an Airline Plan
description: Shortly before Thanksgiving Lamar McMillan, a 21yearold black resident of Jersey City who had never had a permanent job, borrowed car fare from his girlfriend, shaved his beard, dressed in a business suit and headed excitedly for the Madison Avenue offices of the National Urban League. United Airlines, under the pressure of a Federal consent decree to increase nonwhite employment, was to be there interviewing dozens of job applicants.

title: Governor Announces ThreeYear Wage Pact With State's Workers
description: ALBANY, March 12  Governor Carey and William L. McGowan, president of the Civil Service Employees Association, formally announced an agreement on a threeyear contract with 105,000 state employees in a Capitol news conference today.

title: F.A.A. Improving New York Radar In Face of Midair Collision Danger
description: Alarmed by a recent run of near midair collisions following last year's San Diego disaster, the Federal Aviation Administration decided yesterday to speed the improvement of radar scopes at New York's three main airports so the towers will receive data on plane altitudes.

title: Pope Meets With Jews And Calls for Dialogue
description: ROME, March 12  Pope John Paul II, meeting today with leaders of world Jewish organizations, called for a fraternal dialogue and fruitful cooperation between the Roman Catholic Church and Jews.

title: Two Biochemists Did Pioneering Work the Hard Way
description: FROM one perspective, it could be said that James and Elizabeth Miller have wasted much of their professional lives. At the least, they were born before their time.

title: Chemical's Florida Office
description: The Chemical Bank announced yesterday that it had received approval from the State of Florida for its trust and investment division to open an investor adviser representative office in Palm Beach. The new office will service existing trust and investment division clients in the state and offer services such as investment counseling, personal custody, and tax and estate planning services, the hank said.

title: Canadian Inquiry On Dumping by U.S.
description: The Canadian Department of National Revenue, Customs and Excise said it had initiated an antidumping inquiry into imports of American made plastic or steel tank compressedair sprayers and disposable syringes.

title: Two Mideast Sticking Points
description: JERUSALEM, March 12  President Carter's drive to obtain an EgyptianIsraeli peace agreement appears to be foundering not on delicate semantics but on substantive issues: the Israelis' demand for a guaranteed oil supply from Egypt, and the Egyptians' demand that Israel agree to go ahead with selfrule in the Gaza Strip even if the Palestinians on the West Bank refuse to take part in such a plan.

title: Swenson, in 15 Days, Wins Alaskan SledDog Race
description: NOME, Alaska, March 12 (Reuters)  Rick Swenson ended a twoweek, ordeal here last night to become winner of the 1949 mile lnternJtional SledDug race. His time was 15 days 10 hours 19 minutes 7 seconds

title: Leaking Dam Is Called Safe
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 12 (AP)  City officials expressed confidence today that the Leeds Reservoir Dam was in no danger of bursting, despite two massive horizontal cracks and some smaller fissures. An aroundthe clock watch was being kept over the 85yearold granite and concrete dam, which began to show cracks last week. One of the huge stone blocks had fallen out and thousands of gallons of water minute were shooting through most of the stones.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, March 12. 1979

title: Radiation Standard May Endanger Thousands, a Lobby Group Warns
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  A public affairs lobbying group reported today that more than 9,000 atomic power plant workers in the United States are exposed each year to levels of radiation found by a British study to damage chromosomes, the genetic material in human cells.

title: Harriet Dragiff Gluck, Former Music Teacher
description: Harriet Dragiff Gluck, a retired high school teacher and administrator with the New York City schools for 42 years, died of cancer Sunday at her home in West Hempstead, L.I. She was 64 years old.

title: Schlesinger Says He Offered to Quit
description: WASHINGTON. March 12 (UPI)  Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger told senators today that he had offered to resign several times, although President Carter has never taken him up on it.

title: U.S. Plans to Send Advisers to Yemen
description: WASHINGTON. March 12  The United States plans to expand its military presence in Yemen by 200 to 300 people over the next two to three years, a top State Department official said today.

title: Market Place
description: IS it possible that Caesars New Jersey, which is 86 percent owned by Caesars World, is worth more than its parent?

title: U.S. Gypsum Offer
description: The U.S. Gypsum Company said its offer to buy up to 1.25 million shares of its common stock at $30.50 a share was oversubscribed. It said stockholders had tendered in excess of 4 million shares. The company said it would purchase no less than one million shares. The tender offer expired on Friday.

title: PEOPLE IN BUSINESS
description: If any company has an ax to grind at the current Federal Trade Commission hearings on limiting television advertising aimed at children, it is General Mills Inc. The giant Minneapolisbased company is an important producer of breakfast foods and toys  two heavily advertised categories on children's TV programs  and it is scheduled to testify at the hearings in Washington later this month.

title: Israelis Listen Silently to Carter, Then Heckle and Shout at Begin
description: JERUSALEM, March 12  Like an embarrassed guest helplessly witnessing a family quarrel, President Carter sat stoically today through a raucous session of the Israeli Parliament. A dozen members heckled and shouted angrily against peace talks, Prime Minister Menachem Begin; President Anwar elSadat and President Carter himself.

title: Deaths
description: MAHLERM. Shephard. The Brotherhood Synagogue expresses its condolences to Evelyn Mahier on the passing of her dear husband who served on our Board of Trustees and whose life was committed to service to his country and his Jewish brethern.

title: The Slippery Case of Jim Todd
description: SCOTTSDALE, ArizJim Todd is not one of baseball's household names. But suddenly he is one of baseball's most important names. Jim Todd is a 31yearold righthanded pitcher who has cone out of big league bull pens 213 times over the last five years with reasonable success  a 2318 wonlost record, 22 saves, a 3.79 earnedrun average. Six weeks ago he thought he would be coming out of the Seattle Mariner bull pen again this season. He had received a contract offer of $80,000 from the Mariners. the same salary he had last year. But he requested $100,000, not an unreasonable figure in today's marketplace. When the Mariners would not budge, he filed for arbitration. If the Federal arbiter agreed with him, he would get $100,000; if not, he would get $80,000  he was willing to risk the difference. But the Mariners apparently were not. Two days after Jim Todd had formally filed for arbitration, the Mariners put him on waiers. No other major league team claimed him, then the Oakland A's signed him. Now to has filed a labor grievance against the Mariners an the case that, if not dishonorable, is certainly as slippery is a Puget Sound mist.

title: New Talks on Namibia Sought at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 12 The United States and four other Western countries, trying to resolve the problems blocking a United Nations plan for the independence of SouthWest Africa, have invited all concerned parties to meet here next Monday and Tuesday.

title: Two Fires, One of Suspicious Origin, Damage Yeshivas in Brooklyn
description: Outside the Yeshiva School at 176 DeGraw Street, in Carroll Gardens section Brooklyn, a boy and his dog climbed over maze of hoses used by 90 firefighters battling a blaze that nearly gutted school shortly after classes let out early observance of the Jewish holiday of Purim. Fire Department officials declared the fire, which began in a secondfloor classroom, to be of suspicious origin. In the Williamsburg section, a second fire began in a firstfloor kitchen of Yeshiva B'nai Yesoshor at 274 Keap Street. A stove pilot light was blamed for igniting a combustible material. Damage was confined to a small area.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: CONCORDlA LAGO (Concordia LineBoiseDriffin Steamship Company). Barcelona march 28, Genoa 29, Naples April 3, Cyprus 5, Beirut 6, Lattakia 8 and Piraeus 10; sails from Port New ark, N.J.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Stenmark Rallies to Win 9th Giant Slalom in Row
description: HEAVENLY VALLEY, Calif., March 12 (AP)  Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden captured his ninth consecutive giant slalom event today on the World Cup tour.

title: The City
description: Assemblyman Charles E. Schumer yesterday called for an end to the us of voter rolls in selecting jurors, saying that the practice was the main reason people did not register to vote.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger told a Senate commit tee that record oil consumption levels in recent weeks demonstrated that the call for voluntary conservation isn't working. But Mr. Schlesinger's testimony failed to explain how a shortfall that energy officials put at less than 2.5 percent of domestic use has caused such havoc. [Page 1.)

title: Ali Is the Same Until He Enters Ring
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 12 Muhammad Ali, on tour with his heavyweight championship, was in what he called this onehorse town today for one of my last final goodbyes to the world. That world will not include South Africa.

title: About Education
description: AGOVERNMENT survey to be published later this month shows that 27 percent of high school seniors believe Golda Meir was president of Egypt, 90 percent think Israelis an Arab nation and 17 percent estimate that the United States population is larger than that of either China or the Soviet Union.

title: Travel With Carter: Diplomacy and Baggage Calls
description: JERUSALEM, March 12  It was a day of ceaseless confusion. The President's travel schedule remained a major mystery, and constant changes in the time for putting baggage in the hallway for departure seemed as good a clue as any to the tortuous nature of the negotiations on an IsraeliEgyptian peace treaty.

title: Congress Told of 2Year Decline In Heroin Quantity and Strength
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) United States intelligence estimates show a steady, significant decline in the quantity and strength of heroin entering the United States over the last two years, a State Department official told Congress today.

title: Mrs. Byrne Endorsed by Democrats13 Days After Her Chicago Victory
description: CHICAGO, March 12  On this 13th day after her upset victory in the Democratic mayoral,.primary election, Jane M. Byrne Was finally granted the two things the had most avidly sought from members of the political machine she had embarrassedi a meeting with the man she had defeated and the endorsement of the party's central committee.

title: U.S. Boxing Unit Returns With Some Lofty Goals
description: After 2 years of lying dormant, the United States Boning Association abandoned its low profile yesterday and pledged to get pro boxing in this country back into shape for another attempt at determining United States champions.

title: Dance: BatDor and the Israeli World
description: DELVING deeply into the Israeli experience, the second program presented Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by the BatDor Dance Company of Israel offered several powerful works that moved and disturbed an audience as most dance companies usually do not.

title: Notes on People
description: Because he will be hospitalized for two weeks, Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. may miss all arguments heard by the Supreme Court in March, including a potentially historic one involving socalled reverse discrimination. Justices often excuse themselves from cases when prolonged absences force them to miss oral arguments. On March 28, the Court is scheduled to hear the case of Brian F. Weber, a Louisiana man who charges that a special program aimed at moving blacks into better jobs made him a victim of racial bias.

title: City Gem Dealer Found Murdered In the Poconos
description: The body of a Manhattan gem dealer reported missing last Friday with as much as $250,000 in precious stones was found yesterday bound and gagged in a sleeping bag along a road in Pennsylvania's Pocono Mountains.

title: Arrows Defeat Fever, 52, After Segota, 17, Is Barred
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 12  Five Arrows scored goals tonight as New York beat the Philadelphia Fever, 52, in a Major Indoor Soccer League game at the Spectrum.

title: Strangers Play Closes
description: Strangers, the play about the marriage of Sinclair Lewis and Dorothy Thompson, closed after Sunday's matinee at the Golden Theater.

title: Iran Oil Chief's Job: Pacify the Workers
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 12  Just one week ago Hassan Nazih, the new chairman and managing director of the National Iranian Oil Company, stood on a jetty extending into the Persian Gulf off Kharg Island. He was presiding over the loading of the first tanker carrying Iranian oil abroad since oil exports were suspended 69 days earlier.

title: Gospel: Dixie Hummingbirds, 51 Harmonic Years
description: JAMES DAVIS was explaining that he and his colleagues had recently performed at a Southern college that was observing Black History Week I told the people, he said with softspoken pride, that they were looking at black history when they were looking at the Birds. That they were, and so were those who attended An Evening in the Gospel Tradition Sunday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, where the headliners were the Dixie Hummingbirds, the gospel group that Mr. Davis founded in 192S.

title: Christian  Church Aides Oppose Tight Rein
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 12  Despite the tragedy involving its member church, the People's Temple, in Guyana last November, the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) should not impose tighter membership policies, several denomination leaders said at the annual meeting of the administrative committee here.

title: Victor Kilian, Actor, Found Beaten Fatally In Hollywood Home
description: LOS ANGELES, March 12  Victor Kilian, a veteran character actor on stage and screen who became best known at the end of his career for his portrayal as the father of the heroine in television's Mary Hartman. Mary Hartman, in 1976, was found beaten to death in his Hollywood apartment yesterday. He was 88 years old. The police said the apartment had been ransacked.

title: Black America's Needs
description: WASHINGTON  A recent National Urban League report, The State of Black America. indicates that black America borders on the brink of disaster. Besides demonstrating the worsening economic and social conditions of most blacks, shattering the dangerous myth that this problem may safely be relegated to the bottom of the national publicpolicy priorities, it proves that blacks' gains are situationally dependent and thus more tenuous than those of other groups.

title: Voyager Finds Io Alive With Volcanoes
description: VOYAGER 1 has sighted active volcanoes spewing gas and ash high above the surface of Io. The discovery has convinced project scientists that the moon of Jupiter must be churning with internal heat and more alive with volcanism than any other world in the solar system that has been explored by spacecraft.

title: Carey Urges Legal Steps By State on Love Canal
description: ALBANY, March 12  Governor Carey has called on Attorney General Robert Abrams to pursue legal action to protect public health in the Love Canal area of Niagara Falls, where hundreds of residents have complained of the dumping of chemical wastes.

title: Lyricists: Oscar Hammerstein 2d
description: THE problem that has under mined the first two program in this season's Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 9nd Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association  a hollowness a the core, a lack of focus because the lyricists (Lorenz Hart in one case, Cole Porter in the other) were not present and the efforts to evoke them was superficial  was solved with considerable success in Sunday night's program on Oscar Hammerstein 2d which was repeated last night.

title: Reliance Purchases Provident Stock
description: The Provident National Corporation disclosed that it had been advised by the Reliance Insurance Company that Reliance had purchased 10 percent, or about 400,000 shares, of the outstanding common stock of Provident, a bank holding company with headquarters in Philadelphia, for about $11 million.

title: SCIILESINGER WARNSOF RECORD OIL USEAS INVENTORY SLIPS
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger warned today that oil consumption in the United States has been running at record levels in recent weeks. The call for voluntary conservation isn't working, he said.

title: Yank LeftHanders Impressive
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 12  One of these days, the New York Yankees are going to find a majorleague rival they can beat in spring training. But it didn't happen today at Fort Lauderdale Stadium, where the Yankees lost a 20 decision to the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Blind Students Touch Way Through Art at a Museum
description: Nobody said Don't touch to a group of Queens high school students visiting the Museum of Modern Art yesterday. Twentyone of the students were blind and handicapped, and they were touring the sculpture galleries and garden. They were learning about art by touching it.

title: Swiss Studying Citibank Data
description: BERN, March 12 (Reuters)  The Swiss tax authorities are investigating the foreign operations in Zurich of Citibank, the Swiss Government said today.
