title: Tanker Is Adrift Off Cape Town
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 12 (AP) An Iraqi oil tanker en route from the Persian Gulf to France was reported adrift off Cape Town today and in danger of running aground, the South African Press Association said.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: THE NEON SCENE Who or what is the Scialapopolo? They are a group of Italian singers and dancers who regularly tour the world as goodwill ambassadors, performing in costume and promoting the folkloric melodies of their native isle of Capri.

title: Scientists, Looking Ahead, Mark Einstein's Centennial
description: To mark tomorrow's centenary of Albert Einstein's birth, scientists throughout the world are celebrating a profound revolution in human understanding of nature  the formulation of theorie accounting for the release of nuclear energy and the slowing of time one warping of space by gravity.

title: Franklin Still Spectacular Bid's Rider
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 12 win or lose, the owners of Spectacular Bid have decided to stick with Ron Franklin as the regular jockey for their champion 3yearold colt in his Triple Crown campaign.

title: Jazz: Lewis Quartet Draws on 2 Modes
description: THE George Lewis Quartet does not give a concert very often, and the audience for its appearance at the Public Theater on Friday night was relatively small. But the music it played erased any doubts this reviewer might have had, after having heard the quartet at Studio Rivbea more than a year ago, that this is one of the most original and important improvising units of the present period.

title: N.F.L. Attendance Report 12 Million for First Time
description: HONOLULU, March 12 (AP)  In opening its annual meeting today, the National Football League reported its 1978 attendance exceeded 12 million for the first time, with an average per game of 57,017.

title: Text of the President's Address and Excerpts From the Prime Minister's Reply
description: JERUSALEM, March 12 (Reuters)  Following are the text of the address made by President Carter today before the Isrueli Knesset, or Parliament, and excerpts from the official translation of the response in Hebrew by Prime Minister Menachem Begin. Mr. Begin was interrupted frequently from the floor and occasionally responded to this in English.

title: Players Are Arbitration Winners Over All
description: Charlle Finley, a loser in the freeagent market and a loser in his attempt to sell his Oakland A's, was the big loser this year in salary arbitration, an offthefield financial game that has been eclipsed by free agency.

title: Last 2 Prisoners In Rikers Escape Back in Custody
description: Two men walked along Hazen Street, the main street of Rikers Island, yesterday morning, with coils of telephone wire draped over their shoulders. They appeared to be repairmen  except that both lacked the identification card that everyone on New York City's prison island is supposed to wear.

title: President Will Confer With Sadat at Airport During Cairo Stopover
description: CAIRO, March 12  A spokesman for President Anwar elSadat said today that President Carter had telephoned the Egyptian leader this evening to say that he wanted to stop over on his way back to Washington. The two leaders will hold discussions at the Cairo airport, the spokesman said.

title: Music: PianistComposer
description: MORRIS MOSHE COTEL, a young composerpianist who teaches at the Peabody Conservatory, performed an allAmerican program at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night.

title: Music: Guitar Works Played By Karpienia
description: OSEPH KARPIENIA presented an unusual, and unusually entertaining, program of guitar music at Carnegie Recital Hall Friday night. The second half consisted entirely of compositions by Mr. Karpienia himself. The first half included the New York premiere of Alan Hovhaness's Sonata for Guitar (Op.316, No. 1), a recent work that is dedicated to Mr. Karpienia.

title: Charleston College Slated To Pick Kresse as Coach
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.. March 12 (UPI)  the College of Charleston will formally announced a successor for its head basketball coach. Alan LeForce, tomorrow, arid it is expected to he John Kresse, a longtime St. John's assistant coach.

title: Canadiens Tie Red Wings On Goal by Lambert, 33
description: MONTREAL, March 12 (AP) Yvon Lambert of Montreal tipped in a shot by Jacques Lemaire with 6 minutes 52 seconds left in the game tonight as the Canadiens gained a 33 tie with the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League contest. The Candiens have won only two of their last seven games.

title: Medical Schools Face Cuts in Aid Over Specialists
description: In an effort to cut what they regard as excessive hospital costs by specialists and to encourage more familycare physicians in New York, state health officials have proposed cutting state aid to medical schools and teaching hospitals that they say are training too, many highpriced specialists. They have also proposed paying family practitioners higher Medicaid office fee.

title: New Trustees Say They Will Drop Head of Harlem School District 5
description: Trustee's appointed by the city's School Chancellor to run cetral Harlem's troubleridden School District 5 have infornied the district's superintendent that he will not be rehired when his contract expires this June.

title: Iranian Assails Israel in U Talk
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 12 In its first official statement to the United Nations, the new Iranian Government called on the Security Council today to bring pressure on Israel to compel it to restore the human rights of the Palestinian people in the occupied territories.

title: 10 Meet Records Broken In 5th Women's Games
description: Ten meet records were broken and four equaled last night at Madison Square Garden in the fifth Women's Games. where 200 survivors of an original opening field of 18.000 girls and women battled in the finals before a crowd of 13,500 that was admitted for free.

title: The Rising Beef Prices
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  Barry Bosworth, chairman of the President's Council on Wage and Price Stability, said today that consumers held the only tool for checking increases in beef prices but that they were not using it.

title: 35 Food Establishments Are Cited for Violations
description: The New York City Health Department released yesterday the names of 35 food establishments it says have violated the Health Code and two it closed for failing final inspection. The department also cited four establishments that corrected earlier violations, one of which was reopened after doing so. The businesses listed were:

title: A 3Week Strike At FM Station In Boston Ends
description: BOSTON, March 12  A threeweek strike to save the personality of an FM radio station, known nationally for its trendsetting programming and locally for its role in providing a sense of community to the youth of this youthoriented city, ended today in victory.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Federal Reserve, acting quickly yesterday morning, appeared to dispel the notion that it had decided to raise shortterm interest rates decisively.

title: Rising Food Prices Provoke Discussion as Consumers and Industry Spokesmen Meet
description: With doubledigit inflation in food prices distressing more and more shoppers, foodindustry representatives and consumer advocates gathered in lower Manhattan yesterday to seek the causes and suggest and possible remedies.

title: City to Penalize Drivers as Judge Rejects Bus Case
description: A judge in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday returned the city's school bus case to the State Supreme Court, and school officials promptly said they would now move to hold 150 striking schoolbus drivers in contempt of court.

title: Polish Chief Begins Soviet Visit
description: MOSCOW, March 12 (Reuters)  Poland's leader, Edward Gierek, arrived today for talks with Soviet officials, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency.

title: Federal Judge Herbert P. Sorg; Ended Walkout by Steelworkers
description: PITTSBURGH, March 12  Judge Herbert P. Sorg of the Federal District Court for Western Pennsylvania, died yesterday at his home in suburban Mount Lebanon. He was 67 years old.

title: VEICKER JOINS RACE FOR THE PRESIDENCY
description: HARTFORD, March 12  Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the maverick Senator from Connecticut who gained national recognition five years ago as one of the most outspoker, inquisitors on the Senate Watergate committee, declared his candidacy for President today.

title: Congress Takes Up Constitution Amendment Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  Congress I officially took up today one of the most pressing national political issues in sight amending the Constitution to require a balanced Federal budget  and gave every indication that it would proceed with considerable caution.

title: Europe's Currency Ties to Start
description: PARIS, March 12  A new monetary system for Europe will begin operation at the start of business tomorrow, leaders of the European Economic Cornmunity announced today at the outset of a twoday summit meeting here.

title: Opera: Marisa Galvany In Met Debut as Norma
description: THE title role of Bellini's Norma attracts sopranos the way Mt. Everest attracts mountain climbers. The challenge lures them on. This season the work is being revived at the Metropolitan Opera for Shirley Verrett, who was supposed to have sung it with the company for the first time last night. Unfortunately, she came down with a cold and was unable to go on. Her place was taken by her standby, Marisa Galvany, who had at least had the benefit of one orchestral rehearsal.

title: COMPANY EARNINGS
description: The Dana Corportion, makers of quipment for vehicles and the industrial market, reported record earnings yesterday for the quarter ended, Feb. 28, with sharp increases over the same period a year earlier. At the same time, directors raised the company's quarterly dividend to 36 cents a share from 32 cents, payable June 15 to shareholders of record May 29.

title: CARTERLOAN REPORT DENIED BY EXCLERK
description: BAINBRIDGE, Ga., March 12 Jimmy Hayes, a former warehouseman who Worked at the Carter family peanut business, said angrily today that information from him about the handling of collateral on loans to the Carter family's warehouse had been distorted and misrepresented.

title: Antiboycott Law Gains Support
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  After months of quiet discussions, businessmen and Jewish leaders have agreed to support an extension, without modifications, of the controversial law that prohibits Americans from participating in the Arabs economic boycott of Israel.

title: In Media's Rays
description: Nowhere is the skill of governmental imagemakers more evident than in the titles they have invented for themselves. Years ago, one spoke of press agent, publicist or the slightly derogatory flack. But before long, the business had become elevated to a profession and its name was elevated to public relations. In time, even that term lost its sheen and the shorthand version  p.r.  came to imply, well, exaggeration.

title: TV: The Ropers Arrive
description: THE Ropers, which will be shown on ABCTV this evening at 9:30, is a spinoff from Three's Company, featuring two of the same actors and a lot of the same attitude. Norman Fell and Audra Lindley, the couple of the title, decide, at the beginning of their new series, to leave the house they once rented to the Three's Company regulars and move to a place of their own. The first episode of The Ropers occupies itself with their efforts to buy a new house, where Stanley (Mr. Fell) keeps tripping over the front step and Helen (Miss Lindley) makes a lot of jokes about the bedroom.

title: Fiat Credit Unit Is Formed in U.S.
description: Fiat S.p.A., the Italian car manufacturer, said it had formed its own credit company in the United States called the Fiat Credit Corporation. It said Fiat Credit was the first United Statesbased credit company formed by a foreign corporation to finance sales of its products in this country.

title: Bridge:
description: Bridge players are substantial contributors to the profits of telephone companies. Every morning there are stories to be told about the night before  about a great bid, a skillful play, an ingenious defense, about a comedy or a tragedy. Most such calls are local, but one player regularly calls from Mexico City to New York.

title: About New York
description: It's good to see the Irish in the old neighborhoods wise up. When you hear of a new restaurant named Hell's Kitchen on a. block in Hell's Kitchen that is on the rebound, it seems likely that the place would be started by a migrant publicist from Des Moines, newly agog over the city, and a Harvard Business School graduate putting his money in gentrification instead of pork bellies.

title: Judge Denies Plea of Teamsters For Magazine Reporter's Notes
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)  A Federal judge today rejected an attempt by the teamsters union to subpoena a magazine reporter's notes in connection with a lawsuit filed by a dissident union group.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: VENEZUELA INSTALLS HERRERA AS LEADER
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 12 Luis Herrera Campins assumed the presidency of Venezuela today in a peaceful transition of power that consolidates the democratic tradition of this oilproducing country.

title: Fluor Issue: Its South Africa Ties
description: LOS ANGELES, March 12  The Fluor Corporation's South African business  a coal conversion project that accunted for about 13 percent of Fluor's worldwide revenues last year of $2.9 billion  came under attack today at the company's annual shareholders meeting in Costa Mesa, Calif.

title: Forum: Why Is Einstein Widely Regardd as the Century's Greatest Genius?
description: At the centennial of Einstein's birth, several leading scientists were asked by The Times to comment upon the man, his work and the legend that grew around him. Why is Einstein so widely regarded as the greatest scientific genius of the century? Does his reputation rest solely on his work, or does it result in part from the widespread attention his personalitrattracted? What follows are the responses in interviews conducted by Richard Flaste:

title: How Many Shirttails in China?
description: Half a century ago, a businessman calculated the heights to which textile sales could soar if the shirttails of 400 million customers in China could be lengthened by an inch. Even before that, enterprising Western traders dreamed about the vast China market. Standard Oil gave away kerosene lamps, then sold the Chinese the oil to refill them. But, as Eugene Theroux, vice president of the National Council for U.S.China Trade, observed recently, China as a market for Western goods has proved over the last century to be essentially an illusion. Is that experience now going tobe reversed?

title: South Africa Paper, on Court's Order, Suppresses Report on Scandal
description: JOHANNESBERG, March 12  Over the weekend. the editor of one of the newspapers investigating South Africa's Information Ministry senndal posted a note in the news?? congratulating the staff on a server of art?? last week that contained several star?? ?? including the assertion ?? tigure in the affair that he had auth?? in bribe influential forergners

title: Music: Debut Made By Glorietta Allison, A Texas Soprano
description: GLORIETTA ALLISON's voice was at once an asset and a liability in the debut recital she sang in Carnegie Recital Hall last Tuesday. The Texas soprano, whose extensive performing experience showed in her poise, has a very pretty instrument. A bright sheen, growing more sparkling as the voice gets higher, made it particularly attractive. On the other hand, it seemed incapable of much coloration. When tenderness or softness was required, the voice remained impersonally shining.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Fluor Studying Chinese Project
description: IRVINE, Calif., March 12The Fluor Corporation, which get, about onetenth of its revenues from such ventures as offshore drilling service, oil and gas explo ration and mine construction, announced today that it was undertaking a $400.000 engineeringfinancial study for a large copper complex in Jiangxi Province, China.

title: Japan to Buy More U.S. Leather
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  Japan will increase its quotas for imports of American leather under an agreement expected to help the industrially depressed Northedst, especially the tanneries of Salem and Plymouth in Massachusetts, Gloversville and Johnstown in New York and Newark.

title: Holding Down Hospital Costs
description: President Carter's attempt last year to impose a lid on hospital costs was blocked in Congress by opposition from the hospital lobby. Now the President is urging passage of a weaker version of the costcontrol measure. It would impose mandatory limits on a standby basis, to take effect only if hospitals fail to meet specified goals on a voluntary basis.

title: Networks Try to Assuage Affiliates
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 12  Top executives of NBCTV and CBSTV, in separate meetings here with representatives of their affiliated stations, defended the repeated revamping of their program schedules this season as a necessity born of the heightened competition for audience ratings.

title: Debut Recital: Haskell Small, Pianist
description: HASKELL SMALL, a pianist and composer whose fascinating background includes studying to be an engineer and a fling as a rock musician, made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall. As a pianist, Mr. Small displayed the willingness and digital ability to investigate composers as diverse as Scarlatti and Alkan. His own compositions, represented by A Small Suite and Introduction and Fugue, were agreeable in a conservatively tonal vein. The suite was concise enough to sound like Satie's laconic vignettes, and the Introduction to a Fugue had many echoes of Prokofiev, including light sarcasm and a motordriven keyboard style.

title: Stocks Overcome Lag, Close Higher
description: With investors keeping a wary eye on the Middle East peace talks, the stock market overcame early weakness yesterday to finish on an even keel. The best performers included Canadian oilandgas issues, as well as glamour and casino stocks.

title: Kreeger Camps on Easy Street
description: I made just about every mistake that it's possible to make, said Douglas Kreeger. If it wasn't stupidity, it was probably plain ignorance.

title: Dartmouth, Minnesota Get N.C.A.A. Hockey Berths
description: MISSION, Kan march 12 (AP) Minntesota. Dartinouth and Bowlung Green have been selected as at large teams for the National Collegrate Drvision I hockey championship, the N.C.A.A. announced today.

title: World News Briefs
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan. March 12 (Reuters)  Pakistan withdrew today from the Central Treaty Organization, or CENTO. in a move that could hasten disintegration of the largely inactive defense alliance.

title: New OTB Chief Sought by Koch in Rift
description: Furious that his Offtrack Betting Corporation chairman has challenged his support of casino gambling, Mayor Koch began looking for a replacement yesterday.

title: Union Rejects New Orleans Pact
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 12 (AP) Garbage collectors voted down a proposed contract, 113 to 17, then resumed work today as they waited for negotiations to continue. A spokesman for Teamsters Local 270, which represents the 325 garbage collectors, said the men would remain on the job pending the outcome of new talks with the city.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, MARCH 12, 1979

title: EDUCATION
description: SCHOOLS in New York State face some major problems in getting their students through the country's stiffest minimum competency tests  beginning with the fact that educators know relatively little about how to provide the remedial education on which they hinge.

title: Deaths
description: ELSTEINBeatrice, on Mo???? Befored wife of Bernard De???? mother or Susanne Gottied and Gerald Elstein. Loving grandmoth er of Catherine and Tony Scheinmon, David and Michael Listein. Dear sister of Arnold Wirtel. Service Tuesday, March 13. 10 Sem. The Riverside 76 51 & Amsterdam Avenue in lie of flowers, contributtoms may be made to Young Israel of the Concourse

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Huey Newton Defense Contends A Key Witness Was Real Killer
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 12  An alibi buttressed by identification of the real killer unfolded in court today as Huey P. Newton's defense to the charge that he shot and killed a 17yearold prostitute who was working her street corner.

title: A Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a letter by A.H. Boultbee published in the March 9 Times implied erroneously that Pemex; Mexico's national oil company, had had to pay for rights to drill offshore.

title: Frances Gray Godwin, Teacher And Specialist in Medieval Art
description: Frances Gray Godwin, a specialist in medieval art, died of a heart attack Sunday in New York Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived in New York City.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The Administration's inflation fighters have discovered what any supermarket customer could have told them all along, that the rising price of food is one of the principal problems of inflation. But it's not clear that they're prepared to do anything about it that would make a. real difference at the checkout counter.

title: Ruling on Brooklyn Expressway
description: Long Isialid College Hospital group of civic associations representing Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill and other historic Brooklyn neighborhoods yesterday lost the first round of what appeared to be a major fight developing over state plans to reconstruct one mile of the BrooklynQueens Expressway skirting Brooklyn's northwestern edge.

title: Indiana Five Deals Alcorn State First Defeat, Advances in N.I.T.
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 12 (AP)  Indiana's Mike Woodson scored 19 points before fouling out tonight, and the Hoosiers held off a strong rally in the closing minutes to edge previously unbeaten Alcorn State, 7369, in the second round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Anna W. Schneider, 83, Pioneer Labor Mediator
description: Anna Weinstock Schneider, the first woman to serve in the Federal mediation service, died Sunday in a hospital at Hollywood, Fla. She was 83 years old and had lived in Hallandale, Fla., and in Westboro, Mass.

title: Major New G.S.A. Leases Frozen
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)  A Senate committee, upset by corruption in the General Services Administration, today froze all new agency construction or leasing arrangements of $500,000 or more.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE soloists in Chamber Music are Caroline Mclaren, very young and very old; her husband, the American composer Robert Mclaren; Robert's friend Churchill Weeks, a student and teacher of music, and Caroline's friend Anna Baehr, who comes to nurse Robert during his long and painful descent into death and who stays to love Caroline. They are all stringed instruments. The music we hear occurs in the chamber of Caroline's heart. It is quite beautiful.

title: Treasury Bills Bring 9.475%
description: The average rate on threemonth Treasury bills in the Government's weekly sale of these shortterm securities rose yesterday to 9.475 percent the secondhighest rate on record, topped only by the 9.908 percent peak rate set on Aug. 26, 1974. Last week, the rate was 9.364 percent.

title: Langharn Will Direct Juilhiard Theater Center
description: Michael Langham, the prominent British director, has been named head of the Juilliard Theater Center, replacing Alan Schneider. Mr. Langham's appointment as director was announced yesterday by Peter Mennin, president of the Juilliard School.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 13, 1979

title: An IrishAmerican Tribute at City Hall
description: Mayor Koch joined James F. Regan, right, of the Board of Education in singing When Irish Eyes Are Smiling, during ceremony yesterday to proclaim Irish American Heritage Week in New York City. Joining the festivities were Jane Ryan, an Aer Lingus hostess  who presented the Mayor with shamrocks flown in from Ireland  and Frank J. Macchiarola Jr., son of the School Chancellor, who was an honorary IrishAmerican for the festivities.

title: Garter's Woes And New York
description: It the President does not show significant alteration in policy and accomplishment, I would be very anxious to know whether or not Senator Kennedy would contemplate seeking the nomination, said Attorney General Robert Abrams, who has played key rotes in the last two Presidential campaigns in New York State.

title: Congress Opens Debate on a New Draft
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  Several Congressmen called today for the resumption of a limited military draft and for compulsory registration for all 18yearolds as Congress began its first fullscale debate on the issues since the endof the Vietnam war.

title: First Chicago Lifts Prime to 11%
description: The First National Bank of Chicago raised its prime rate yesterday by onequarter of a percentage point to 11 percent. A spokesman for the bank attributed the increase to strong loan demand and continuing high levels of inflation.

title: Meeting Arrives Early on Broadway
description: A Meeting by the River, a play by Christopher Isherwood and Don Sachardy based on Mr. Isherwood's 1967 novel of the same name, will begin previews at the Palace next Tuesday, three weeks before itsproducers had intended to start them. It will have its official opening on March 26.

title: 43 N.B.A. Players to Try For FreeAgency Dollars
description: Bill Walton and Larry Kenon are among the top names on a list of 43 players who will become free agents a day after the completion of the National Basketball Association playoffs. The list was prepared by the National Basketball Players Association, which has estimated that the eligible group is earning more than $6 million in salaries this season.

title: TV: Two Einstein Tributes on PBS
description: TOMORROW marks the 100th anniversary of Albert Einstein's birth. With its special and rather charming knack for being slightly off target, the Public Broadcasting Service will offer Einstein tributes tonight and the day after tomorrow. Einstein's Universe, coproduced by the BBC and WGBHTV of Boston, will be on Channel 13 this evening from 9 o'clock to 11. Einstein, part of WGBH's Nova series, can be seen Thursday at 9 P.M.

title: CARTER, NEARING END OF VISIT, TO SEE BEGINAND SADAT AGAIN; OBSTACLES STILL BLOCK A PACT
description: JERUSALEM, March 12  President Carter neared the end of his Middle East mission today, unable to reconcile all the difficult issues holding up the conclusion of an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Wagner's Der Fliegende Hollander, 8

title: State's Counties Fighting Albany For $33 Million
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 12  Officials of New York State's 62 county welfare departments are involved in a tugofwar with Albany over who should get an additional $33 million in Federal socialservices grants.

title: Ballet: Bjart's Verdi
description: MAURICE BEJART likes to cram his ballets with significance. Because too many other choreographers appear willing to seem addlebrained, Mr. Bjart's devotion to serious principles is admirable. Yet sometimes the significance of his ballets exists largely in their themes, while their actual movement falls expressively short of Mr. Bjart's intentions.

title: 3d Spoleto U.S.A. Opens May 25
description: The Spoleto Festival U.S.A. will present its third annual season in Charleston, S.C., from May 25 to June 10. The festival of music, dance and theater will open with a new production of Il Marito Disperator, a rarely seen work by the 18thcentury composer Domenico Cimarosa. The second major operatic presentation will be new production of The Medium by Gian Carlo Menotti, founder and artistic director of the festival.

title: Electron Microscopes Speeding Diagnoses
description: THE electron microscope, for decades almost exclusively a research tool, is now being used to provide rapid diagnoses of several viral diseases that affect children and that often occur as complications of cancer and transplant surgery.

title: Young White Rhodesians Are Streaming to Britain
description: LONDON, March 12  Like many other 23yearold, newly married men, Barry Walton is looking for a job. But Mr. Walton, a native of Rhodesia who immigrated to Britain almost three months ago, is also looking for a whole new life at the same time.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Superior Oil Company andrana dian Superior Oil Ltd. announced yesterday that they would undertake studies for a possible merger of the two companies. Superior Oil already owns about 51 percent of the 9.17 million common shares outstanding of Canadian Superior.

title: Woman Is Wounded By a Subway Gunman Before Helpless Police
description: As two Transit Authority policemen with drawn guns stood by helplessly yesterday in a crowded Bronx subway station, a gunman suddenly seized a woman who had sought protection from the officers and then, using the woman as a shield, opened fire, wounding the womae in the arm and the hip with a wild shot. the police said.

title: Thomson Buys Publisher
description: The International Thomson Organization of Toronto, with large interests in publishing, said yesterday that it had purchased Callaghan & Company, a private legal publisher in Chicago. Neither company would disclose the sale price.

title: Wall St. Lawyer and a U.S. Judge In Line for Federal Appeals Bench
description: Jon O. Newman, a Federal trial judge in Hartford, and Amalya L. Kearse; partner in a major Wall Street law firm, have been recommended by Attorney General Griffin B. Bell to fill two vacancies on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Retail Sales Rose 0.6% In February
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) Retail sales rose a modest 0.6 percent in February, another indication that last year's consumer spending boom may be tapering off, the Commerce Department said today.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Some brokers are still muttering bitterly about the liquidation of the April and May potato futures contracts last Friday by the New. York Mercantile Exchange. They had to tell their cus tomers that they were sold out at a tune when the holders of long positions thought they might have a good run for their money.

title: The Leisure of the Theory Clasp
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Exotic travel and elegant hostelries no longer are the unique preserve of Arab oil sheiks, Greek shipping magnates and Hollywood personalities. Now, a thriving growth industry of international seminars and conferences bestows these same privileges on the vangua rd of the American intelligentsia.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deathes

title: China Reported Planning to Keep Some Border Areas
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 12 (AP)  Chinese officials were reported today to have told diplomats here that while most soldiers were being withdrawn from Vietnam, some bases would be retained in areas from which Vietnamese had raided China.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF MATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543800 UNITE. 5.30 F.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITORS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. 011 SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY E0RTTOM REGIONAL OFFICES 9-00 AM TO 4. 30 F.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33503 WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW MONK STATE COUNTIES ($14) METE FIRMS 56300 NASSAU CO. (516) 747.0000; SUFFOL CO. (516) 6651600; ? (203) 3457767.

title: Rangers Acquire New Defenseman
description: The New York Rangers, weakened by injuries on defense, obtamed 28year old Jocelyn Guevremont from the Buffalo Sabres yesterday in exchange for future consideration

title: Opera: Kavrakos, Greek Bass
description: The Grand Inquisitor in Verdi's Don Carlo is a short role, but it is an important one, and challenging. Ideally, it calls for a singer of commanding presence who can make awesome sounds throughout a twooctave span.

title: Whither Kennecott's Wendel?
description: For sure, says William H. Wendel, when you ask him if he really will retire next Jan. 1 as president of the Kennecott Conner Corporation.

title: Deaths
description: GLEASON, Phillip Patrick on March 10, 1979. Beloved husband of Francine, father of Dennis, Phillip, Shelis. Moira and Eileen. Resposing of Walter B. Cooke. Funeral Home 117 West 72 St. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10AM. Corpus Christi Church. interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Topics
description: Hindsighters

title: New Regime in Iran Executes 11, 2 Apparently for Political Crimes
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Tuesday, March 13Revolutionary firing squads executed 11 men today, Including 2 former Government spokesman from the national Iranian radio and television organization. The two broadcasting officials were apparently the first persons to be executed since the revolution earlier this year for political crimes, although this could not be confirmed.

title: Science Watch
description: A new report from the University of Michigan's School of Public Health suggests that a longstanding controversy over a synthetic drug known to be effective in preventing at least one kind of flu should be ended so that the drug can be used.

title: Decades of Black Rhodesian Gains Being Wiped Out by Guerrilla War
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia  Even if the guerrilla war ended immediately, it would have wiped out decades of progress for the five million blacks  80 percent of the population  who live in the tribal reserves.

title: Around the Nation
description: ST. LOUIS, March 12 (UPI)  Striking public school teachers here voted tonight to approve a new twoyear contract, ending the longest teacher strike in Missouri history.

title: Commodity Fund Talks Start Again
description: GENEVA, March 12  Industrialized and developing countries met here today in a fourth attempt to agree on an international fund to  stabilize the prices of raw materials. However, prospects for a breakthrough at the scheduled weeklong session became dim, according to some Western sources, when the tocalled Group of 77 developing countries showed no sign of compromise in its opening statement.

title: Scaasi's Spring Confections
description: They don't give fashion shows like that very much anymore. Intimate affairs where it's so quiet you can hear the photographers snapping their shutters. Where the applause indicates that some woman has decided the style being modeled fits into her life.

title: Bigger Tax Is Sought If Heirs Sell
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  The Treasury Department, bracing itself for another bruising fight over tax reform, urged Congress today to put into effect a 1976 change in the law that would increase capital gains taxes when inherited property is sold.

title: Grumman Won't Bid On Bus
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  The Grumman Flxible Corporation, one of the last two bidders for a contract to make the Transbus, which is specially designed to meet the needs of the elderly and handicapped, announced today that it was withdrawing.

title: Carey Favors State Casinos But With Private Operators
description: ALBANY, March 12  Governor Carey said today that he would support participation under careful controls by private casino operators if gambling is legalized in New York State.

title: Castles and Rainbows  She Designs Furniture to Fit Children's Fantasies
description: EAGLE BRIDGE, N.Y.  Like Pinocchio's creator, Geppetto, Annie Hatcher works magic in wood  fashioning a storybook world of rainbows, stars, peaks capped with snowlike sundae topping, enchanting knights, fair damsels, dancing piglets and capering mice.

title: Advertising
description: THE GLENLIVET, which says it is the most expensive Scotch whisky from the oldest distillery (licensed in 1824), is having a rebirth, courtesy of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, its owner for the last year.

title: Norfolk State Five Gains In N.A.I.A. Tourney
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 12 (UPI)  Kenny Evans scored 21 points today to lead Norfolk (Va.) State into the second round of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball tournament with a 6457 victory over St. John Fisher of Rochester. N.Y.

title: The City's DayCare System: Resilient in Difficult Times
description: In the midst of the debate in recent years over its consequences whether it meant the salvation of working women or the erosion of family life  day care in New York appeared on the brink of making the argument moot. Like the city, it was in deep financial trouble.

title: Guilty Plea in TheaterFraud Case
description: Gregory J. DePalma. a major defendant in the Westchester Premier Theater case, pleaded guilty yesterday to fraud charges in Federal District Court in Man. hattan.

title: Duo Stoyanov, ViolinPiano, Makes Debut
description: The Duo Stoyanov, a violinandpiano team, made a New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall on March 5. The Stoyanovs are brothers, born in the Soviet Union, who have been living in Denver since they emigrated to this country five years ago. Robert Stoyanov, the violinist, is a member of the Denver Symphony and Artur Stoyanov, the pianist, is a professor of music at Arapahoe Community College.

title: Larvae Found in Easter Baskets
description: DETROIT, March 12 (AP)  K Mart Corporation has ordered store managers to burn 650,000 imported Easter baskets because spider larvae were found in some of them, the company said today. A company spokesman said the larvae were discovered when the shipment from Taiwan was unpacked Thursday and that none of the baskets had bean sold.

title: Dutt: Next Chief At Beatrice Foods
description: A changing of the guard at the top level was announced yesterday by the Beatrice Foods Company, perhaps not a household word outside the investment community but nevertheless the source of some 9,000 products, including Dannon yogurt, Louis Sherry ice cream and Samsonite luggage. The changes take effect July H.

title: Money
description: Primers ate 11 11

title: Tanglewood Signs Philharmonic
description: For the final weekend of next summer's Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., the New York Philharmonic will replace the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which will be taking off for a tour of European festivals. It will be the first time the New York ensemble has played there, although in the initial concerts at Tanglewood in 1934, Henry Hadley led 65 members of the New York orchestra.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY, MARCH 12, 1979

title: Theater: Ralph Pape's Say Goodnight, Gracie
description: ONE of the characters in Ralph Pape's Say Goodnight, Gracie (at the 78th Street Theater) dreams about writing a Norman Lear situation comedy dealing with the first television generation, who see themselves as hopeless failures. This could serve as a description of the subject of Mr. Pape's new play.

title: Music: Hindemith by Yale Orchestra
description: AT one time considered to be a key figure of early 20thcentury composition, along with Stravinsky, Schoenberg and Bartok, Paul Hindemith has pretty much vanished from the concert scene since his death a little over 15 years ago. Save for a handful of instrumental sonatas, little of his music is performed nowadays. Even oncepopular orchestral works such as the Symphonic Metamorphoses on Themes by Weber and the Mathis der Maler Symphony turn up less often than they used to.

title: Housing Starts Rose 6% in 1978
description: New housing starts in 1978 rose 6 percent to 1.96 million units from 1.85 million units the year before, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: Yastrzemski on Red Sox: If We'd Won one More
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 12 The New York Mets took a twohour bus ride into central Florida today to check out the Boston Red Sox, baseball's leading lostcause of 1978, and found a few haunting memories but no disabling hangups.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar rose to its highest level in eight and onehalf months against the Japanese yen and then posted marginal gains against major European currencies yesterday on the eve of a new currency linkup among Common Market countries.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: U.S. Inflation Policies Draw I.M.F. Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The gap between actual and potential output in the manufacturing sector in the United States was virtually nonexistent in the second half of 1978, one of the factors behind the present virulence of inflation, according to a confidential staff study by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Asians Appear to Side With Peking Against Hanoi
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 13  The dust has not yet settled on the field of battle, and Vietnam continues to accuse China of keeping up the war despite Peking's announcement that its soldiers are withdrawing, but the consensus among Asian and Western observers here is that the border fighting is substantially over.

title: Ground Broken For a Skyscraper On Park Avenue
description: A new skyscraper that will not be completed until late next year had its groundbreaking yesterday and promptly gained its first three tenants who, according to sources in the trade, have made rental commitments of more than $450 million.

title: Dainippon Purchase
description: Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc., Japan's largest printing ink maker, said it had purchased 1.95 million shares of the Polychrome Corporation under its recently proposed tender offer of $26 a share. This represents Si percent of Polychrome's 2.4 million common shares outstanding. The tender offer was extended on Monday to April 11 by Dainippon's American subsidiary, Dainippon Ink and Chemicals America Inc.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Even people who swear that they could never become members of a cult are not immune to regimentation. writes Yvonne Hirth. I recently had dinner at posh East Side restaurant. As I glanced at the tables around me, I was surprised to see that everyone was eating the same thing. I questioned the waiter, wondering why the menu appeared to be so limited.

title: EINSTEIN EVOLVING YET ANOTHER THEORY
description: GENEVA, July 26.  Calculating, jotting down figures and symbols, checking equations, smoking his pipe when he has not forgotten to light it, figuring while the translators are turning into French and English his viewson the necessity for improving the education of children. Professor Albert Einstein, even during the sessions hereof the League of Nations Committee on Intellectual Cooperation, of which he is one of the illustrious members, is working in a field of study still more vast than those in which he has already pioneered.

title: Cairo Awaits Israeli Treaty Action
description: CAIRO, March 13  Egypt waited tonight to see whether the Israeli Cabinet would endorse the latest American proposals to remove what appeared to be one of the last obstacles to a peace treaty.

title: Mets, Lacking Pitchers, Tie in Exhibition Game
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 13  The Mets settled for a 33, 11inning standoff with the Pittsburgh Pirates in an exhibition today when the New York manager, Joe Torre, ran out of pitchers after employing five.

title: Judge Denies Suit to Stop Waterway Construction
description: ATLANTA, March 13  A Federal judge in Mississippi has denied a civil suit that would have stopped construction of the huge Tennessee Tombigbee waterway for lack of clear Congressional authorization.

title: Of God, Baseball And Dodger Blue
description: FORT LAUDERDALE. Fla.  Tommy Lasorda was breathing. It follows as the night the day that he was talking about God, about the Dodgers, about his mother and father and four brothers. About the Dodgers, about loyalty, about jogging. You know what jogging's done for America? Now when a jogger drops dead on the road, he's in shape. Guy at the wake says, He looks good. He oughta, the widows says, he ran three miles every morning.  Everybody knows about Tommy Lasorda, who bleeds Dodger blue, who puts his trust in the Great Dodger in the Sky. This is his 30th year in the Dodger organization, his third spring as manager. His predecessor, Walter Alston, managed the team for 23 years, always on oneyear contracts because Walter O'Malley. the Great Dodger in Los Angeles, doesn't believe in multiyear contracts. Not many know it, Lasorda said, but I got a multicontract multimonths.

title: W.H.A. Plans Expansion, Despite New Merger Move
description: TORONTO, March 13 (UPI)  The World Hockey Association is planning to expand to several American cities, despite the National Hockey League's promise to reconsider its refusal to merge the two leagues, Harold Baldwin said today.

title: Notes on People
description: To drive home a point, Dr. John C. Sawhill, the president of New York University, has invited Anatoly Shcharansky to speak at the school's commencement exercises in June. Presumably, N.Y.U. will take the precaution of also lining up someone else. Mr. Shcharansky, a prominent Soviet dissident, is not likely to come since he is serving a 13year prison sentence on an espionage conviction that drew a good deal of international protest.

title: F.C.C. Warns On Postal Fee
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  The Federal Communications Commission warned the United States Postal Service today that its proposal to treat private electronic messages as mail they were handdelivered might be illegal.

title: South Carolina Golf Team Quitting AllWhite Club
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., March 13 (UPI) The University of South Carolina golf team has been ordered to move its headquarters from an allwhite country club.

title: Exxon Rebuffs Canada On Venezuela Oil Bid
description: OTTAWA, March 13The Canadian Government angrily reported today that it had been rebuffed by Exxon International in its demand that Exxon allow its Canadian subsidiary, Imperial Oil Ltd., to buy its oil directly from Venezuela.

title: MiddleIncome Families Facing Housing Barriers
description: What Barbara and John Smith want for themselves and their daughter does not seem unreasonable: a twobedroom apartment with a rent they can afford in a safe neighborhood. But they have been unable to find one, so they are stuck with their rat and roachinfested, onebedroom apartment in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: City Names Landmark Strictures
description: Six town houses tucked away between apartment buildings on 89th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, were among buildings designated New York City landmarks yesterday. Also named were two historic churches in Jamaica, Queens: Monica's Roman Catholic Church and the First Reformed Church of Jamaica, both erected in the 1850's. The Manhattan town houses, completed in 1887, were designed in Queen Anne style by the firm Hubert, Pirsson & Co. for William Rhinelander, a Yorkville landowner.

title: Sohio Move Affects Alaskan Oil Flow
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The announced shelving of the proposed crudeoil pipeline from southern California to Texas was another in a long series of frustrations experienced by the United States in its effort to become less dependent on foreign oil.

title: Sohio Cancels a Pipeline to Carry Alaskan Oil From Coast to Texas
description: CLEVELAND, March 13  The Standard Oil Company of Ohio announced today that it was abandoning its attempt to build a $1 billion pipeline to pump Alaskan crude oil from Long Beach, Calif., to Midland, Tex.

title: Police Deny Officer On Skates Is Theirs
description: A man wearing what appeared to be a policeman's uniform whirled around Fifth Avenue on roller skates for a couple of hours yesterday afternoon, stopping long enough for a cadre of cameramen to take his picture.

title: Screen: 'Voices,' a Deaf Teacher's Love Story:They Shall Overcome
description: "VOICES" is yet another love story about a young woman with a disability and a dream, plus a handsome and extremely patient suitor who helps make that dream come true. In this case, she (Amy Irving) is a deaf teacher who'd like to dance, although other recent variations on this theme have dealt with a blind ice skater who'd like to become a champion (Lynn-Holly Johnson in "Ice Castles") and an about-to-be-crippled ballerina who hopes to give one last great performance (Anne Ditchburn in "Slow Dancing in the Big City").In each of these movies  and "Voices," which opens today at the Baronet, is about the best of a very lackluster bunch  the situation takes the place of a plot. His optimism and her infirmity are the only well-established signs of character, and the action creeps inexorably toward a happy ending that is at least as tired as it is triumphant. "Voices" is full of details about the young man, played by Michael Ontkean, and his family (three generations of contentious men) and their house (in Hoboken) and their business (dry cleaning). But it all manages to seem either trumped-up or extraneous, as does the fact that he has a dream, too. (He wants to be a rock singer.)Movies in this mold tend to be so preoccupied with pie-in-the-sky that they scant the everyday activities that might hold an audience's attention. (Perhaps the most powerful surprise in "Coming Home" was its matter-of-fact depiction of how a paraplegic might accomplish simple household or hygienic chores.)"Voices" includes one very effective scene of Miss Irving conducting a telephone conversation  using a kind of typewriter keyboard  with a deaf friend, and it devotes some attention to sign language. But the director, Robert Markowitz, is so poorly equipped to render his deaf heroine's experience inventively that the best he can do is simply shut off the soundtrack from time to time. The screenplay, by John Herzfeld, is equally insensitive, particularly when it means to be funny. Someone in hero's family: "Is she deaf and dumb?" Hero: "She is not dumb. She's smarter than all of us. She's a teacher."Mr. Ontkean is considerably more likable than his material. But the character is so nebulous  and so noisy and frantic, as a clumsy counterpoint to the silent, demure heroine  that his performance never takes shape; "Slap Shot," in which he was cast as a funny, disillusioned hockey player, provided a much better indication of what he can do.Miss Irving's role is just as ill-defined, but she is agile and interesting even when the screenplay merely calls for her to look shy. And in the last part of the film, when a frustrated and embarrassed Miss Irving  who has made a dramatically convenient secret of her deafness  auditions with a dance company, though she can't hear the music or the directions, she is given a welcome opportunity to be something other than an ingnue. She has an appealing uneasiness that might work better in less sugary roles.Alex Rocco, Herbert Berghof, Viveca Lindfors and the city of Hoboken also appear in the film, although only Hoboken accomplishes this with any success. Mr. Markowitz has also recruited some emphatically disagreeable bit players (one of them throws his false teeth on a table, to emphasize something he has been hollering about).And the script, which is mysteriously full of references to meat, is also overloaded with unlikely coincidences. Mr. Ontkean first spies Miss Irving, for instance, in a train station where she has been playing with one of those machines that engrave a name on a little good-luck charm, and tracks her down after she leaves the charm behind. Speaking of unlikely, her name is Rosemarie Lemon."Voices" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It includes one very mild love scene and a little bit of angry language.

title: Revised Figures Point to Rise in New York City's Jobs
description: Jobs in New York City are growing faster than at any time since the boom period of the late 1960's, a Chemical Bank analysis said yesterday. The bank lined up with other suggestions that a nearly eightyear decline has been at least partly reversed.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Energy

title: How Sohio Plan Went Awry
description: LOS ANGELES, March 13  Two years ago, Charles Spahr's optimism was running high. During a speech at the National Press Club, the former chairman of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio outlined how the company's plan for a 500millionbarrel tanker terminal in Long Beach, Calif., to move 500,000 barrels of Alaskan oil a day to the Middle West would get quick approval from California and Federal officials.

title: Mater Christi's Five, Tolentine Gain Final
description: Mater Christi routed Rice, 10367, last night in the semifinal round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball championships at Fordham University.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, Mar. 5, to Sunday, Mar. 11), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Littoral Society to Stage A Symposium on the Sea
description: A delightful excursion into the rich lore of the sea and its creatures awaits those who attend the American Littoral Society's ninth annual symposium, Your Future in the Sea, at the American Museum of Natural History on March 24.

title: Campus at St. John's Glows Quietly
description: There were no banners, parades, pep rallies or demonstrations at St. John's University yesterday. But all over the campus in Jamaica, Queens, there was an undercurrent of excitement over the two stunning upset victories by the Redmen's basketball team last weekend in the National Collegiate tournament.

title: Flames and Hawks In 8Player Trade
description: ATLANTA, March 13 (AP) The Atlanta Flames completed the biggest trade in their sevenyear National Hockey League history today by sending five players, including Tom Lysiak, to the Chicago Black Hawks for Ivan Boldirev, a center; Phil Russell, a defenseman, andDarcy Rota, a left wing.

title: ACCORD IS REACIIED ON CONVENTION SITE FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: ALBANY, March 13  Governor Carey, Mayor Koch and legislative leaders reached agreement today on a plan to construct a $375 million Convention and Exhibition Center in New York City, ending months of erratic and sometimes bitter negotiations.

title: Canadians Fight Against Sealing Hampered by Winds Off Labrador
description: ST. ANTHONY, Newfoundland, March 13 (UPI)  Strong winds frustrated pro. tests against sealing today and worked in favor of 300 hunters closing in on a herd of baby seals on the second day of the annual pelt harvest.

title: Artillery Duels Are Waged Across the Lebanese Border
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 13  Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon and Israeli forces waged artillery duels today as Israeli planes crisscrossed the skies.

title: The Theater of Peace
description: Thanks to Jimmy Carter, the making of a peace treaty has become as exciting for Americans as the waging of war. That alone is a singular achievement in a nation so obviously searching for dreams to dream. It is especially welcome to a nation struggling to regain its confidence and to resist the desperate counsel that only displays of force command respect abroad. Had the President failed in Cairo and Jerusalem, this would have been a noble failure, certainly a worthier response to Iran than some Bay of Pigs or Mayagez. Now that he appears to have been successful, we rejoice particularly for that aspect of Mr. Carter's performance. It may be more important than the treaty itself.

title: Begin Hails Egyptian Acceptance, Calls Treaty Possible Within Week
description: JERUSALEM, March 13  Prime Minister Menachem Begin tonight welcomed Egypt's acceptance of the proposals taken to Cairo by President Carter and suggested that a treaty might be approved by Israel within a week.

title: Myslik Succeeds Flippin As Princeton Athletic Head
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 13Princeton University appointed Robert J. Myslik, a 1961 graduate, as athletic director today. He succeeded Royce N. Flippin Jr., who resigned in December.

title: The Region
description: JERSEY CITY (UPI)  An arrest warrant was issued yesterday for Kibby Kevelson, a landlord with extensive slum properties in Jersey City and Newark, who failed to show tip in court to answer complaints of violating city housing codes. Officials said the action was part of a general crackdown.

title: Kahn Chides Business on Rules
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) The head of the Carter Administration's drive against inflation sharply criticized the business community today for not doing its share in holding down wages and prices.

title: Canadian Jobless Down
description: OTTAWA, March 13 (Reuters) Canadian unemployment, seasonally adjusted, dropped below 8 percent in February for the first time since June 1977, the Government statistics agency said today. The rate was 7.9 percent, compared with 8.1 percent in January, with the largest drop coming In the manufacturing centers of Quebec and Ontario, Statistics Canada said.

title: Market Place
description: THE oncetroubled Texas International Company, an oil and gas producer and energy equipment manufacturer, is restructuring to emphasize its prospects as an oil and gas concern and has apparently improved its position enough to qualify as a takeover candidate.

title: Katharine Taylor, 90, A Figure in Education In U.S. and Overseas
description: Katharine Taylor, a teacher and for many years principal of the Shady Hill School in Cambridge, Mass., died Monday at her home in Cambridge. She was 90 years old.

title: PEOPLE IN BUSINESS
description: Like his peers at similar firms, Carl W. Menk, president of Boyden Associates, one of the large search concerns that finds management personnel for industry, keeps his finger on the pulse of trends in hiring for the executive suite. And he feels that one of the most meaningful trends is the increasing difficulty in convincing businessmen to relocate from one part of the country to another.

title: Film: 1969 Relived in 'Hair':A Show Remembered
description: ONE might think that because "Hair" was so much the contemporary artifact when it opened on Broadway 10 years ago, its time as a movie would have come and gone. Lifetimes of life styles have been junked in the interim. We all know people who for years wore their hair in the modified Medusa-bob of Gerome Ragni but who now look as neat as Otto Preminger, or who experimented with grass and then quietly returned to the known pleasures of booze, or who once marched on the Pentagon with the enthusiasm they now display in Central Park, jogging around the Reservoir. "Hair" should be old hat, but the good news this morning is that it's not.Milos Forman's screen version, which opens today at the Ziegfeld Theater, is a rollicking musical memoir, as much a recollection of the show as of the period, a film that has the charm of a fable and the slickness of Broadway show biz at its breathless best.This "Hair" is not to us what the original Joseph Papp and the Broadway productions were to their audiences. There's no pretense that it has anything to do with today except to antecede it. It no longer feels the need to shock us with the once highly publicized curtain scene in which the cast stripped down to the buff to confront the audience in lights so dim we could have been watching Julia Child on a bum picture tube.The Galt MacDermot score, with lyrics by Mr. Ragni and James Rado (who wrote the book for the stage show and starred in it), is as sweet as an album of golden oldies but far livelier and wittier than most. You may think you can't listen to "Aquarius" even once more without doing yourself damage, but give it a chance. It frames the film with good feelings that include a dozen other numbers that still have the power to surprise and amuse us.Most important, Mr. Forman and Michael Weller, who wrote the script, have found an easy, loose, very winning screen equivalent to the show's illusive narrative about a naif named Claude who, en route to Vietnam, shares a few halcyon days with a group of hippies in Central Park. Mr. Weller's inventions make this "Hair" seem much funnier than I remember the show's having been. They also provide time and space for the development of characters who, on the stage, had to express themselves almost entirely in song.The film moves in and out of its principal Central Park location  to Wall Street (for Claude's induction in the Army), to the suburbs (for a classic low-comedy confrontation between the hippies and society's stuffed shirts), and to an Army base in Nevada (where the hippies follow Claude to say goodbye but, instead, effect an unwitting change in the plans of the United States Government).Mr. Forman, who won an Oscar for his direction of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," has long had an affection for the American counterculture of the 60's. In "Hair" he has been able to express it with an exuberance that was never completely convincing in "Taking Off." He also manages to keep the fantasy aloft so that we accept the music and the dancing (choreography by Twyla Tharp) without worrying about the realism that so often keeps film musicals earthbound.The contributions of Miroslav Ondricek, a fellow Czechoslovak who was Mr. Forman's cameraman here, and of the members of the cast are of immense value. John Savage, so good in "The Deer Hunter," is very funny as the nave Claude, but then the entire cast is superb, especially Treat Williams as Berger, the hippie leader, and Beverly D'Angelo as Sheila, the society girl who joins the tribe.The film has several things that are not super. The big production number based on the title song  staged in a jailis total confusion, and there are times when the itchy fingers of the editor prevent us from getting the full effect of what the dancers are doing. Mostly, though, the film is a delight."Hair," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some partial nudity, some vulgar slang and some words that are obscene if one understands their meanings.

title: Auto Dealers: The Hard Sell
description: DETROIT, March 13  Twentyfive years ago, when James V. Mancuso left the General Motors Corporation to open a new car dealership of his own in Skokie, Ill., the auto business was relatively simple, he recalls.

title: J. EUGENE BUSHER
description: J. Eugene Busher, president of the realestate brokerage concern of Eugene J. Busher Company, died yesterday at his country home in Barryville, N.Y. He was 84 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y

title: Technology
description: THE Westinghouse Electric Corporation has developed a meter that could help ease the load problems of utilities with an improved method of monitoring peaks and valleys of electricity use. The Pittsburghbased company says its register unit records consumption of electricity by timeofday use, and when coupled with a watthour meter, it provides a complete timeofday watthour system.

title: Stage: Marquis of Keith
description: IN presenting Frank Wedekind's The Marquis of Keith, the Classical Stage Company announces that it is the first American production of this play by the precursor of German Expressionist Theater.

title: Islanders Romp, 72; Westfall Is Retiring
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 13  In ways that Eddie Westfall could only dream about, the remarkable Mike Bossy had another threegoal game tonight  sharing the drama of Westfall's decision to retire at season's end  as the Islanders crushed the Boston Bruins by 72.

title: Seller of Hitler Portraits Fined
description: ESSEN, West Germany, March 13 (Reuters)  A court fined a salesman 600 marks ($324) today for selling portraits of Adolf Hitler and Hermann Gring, the Nazi air force chief. The court ruled that the portraits were Nazi symbols. It is illegal to distribute or sell such symbols in West Germany.

title: Jazz: Jackson, Alexander
description: THE combination of Milt Jackson and Monty Alexander in a concert on Monday night at the Symphony Space. Broadway at 95th Street  the first in a series of six benefits there for the Consortium of Jazz Organizations and Artists  not only reiterated Mr. Jackson's position as the wellspring of the Jazz Vibraharp that he has maintained for three decades, but it also gave Mr. Alexander the kind of jazz exposure that he needs and deserves.

title: Wine Talk
description: WHEN winter comes, can the Heublein auction be tar behind? Well, about . couple of months, if you want to get technical. This year it will be held on May 24 in Chicago and, for this, the 11th running of wine's lopline media event, some fascinating wines have been lined up.

title: Earthquake Shakes Athens
description: ATHENS, March 13 (AP)  An earthquake measuring 5 on the openended Richter scale jostled Athens today but there were no immediate reports of damages or casualties, the Seismological Institute said. The institute said the epicenter was 53 miles northeast of Athens near the town of Chalkis.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 14, 1979

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: THE world of food has such broad horizons, it is as amusing as it astonishing how deeply exercised food enthusiasts can become over one recipe or another. That is not to say that I myself will abide transgressions against classic French cooking and will not protest misnomers, in the name of Escoffier, as loud as possible. What have in mind are the supposed purists who are opposed to variances from what their palates are accustomed to. Some months ago, for example, reader wrote to say that he was vehemently against putting any kind sauce on fresh bay scallops because they suffered from any but simplest methods of preparation: broiling or sauteeing.

title: Elizabeth Bartlett, Excivic Aide
description: Elizabeth M. Bartlett, former president of the Women's City Club of New York, died Monday at her borne in New York City. She was 81 years old.

title: From Out of the West: Caviar
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Israeli Deal on Captives Reported
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 13 (AP) Israel has agreed for the first time to exchange prisoners with a Palestinian guerrilla group, a Palestinian official said here today.

title: Supermarkets in Transition: Shaping a Positive Image
description: SUPERMARKETS are worried. Faced with consumer hostility brought on by relentlessly rising food prices, many of them are experimenting with ways to appease and please their customers. The new approaches include streamlined store design and unusual techniques for providing more services, raising efficiency and offering a friendlier ambiance.

title: For the Peacemakers, a Hopeful Turn on a Twisting Road
description: CAIRO, March 13  President Carter's Middle East mission ended today on the same note of surprise and elation that broght the Camp David summit meeting to a close six months ago. It was that meeting that started the long, often frustrating negotiations over an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty that now seems close to conclusion.

title: Philippine Rebels Ask Ransom for U.S. Missionary
description: MANILA, March 13  An American missionary teacher is being held for $71,000 ransom by an armed band believed to be Moslem rebels, Bishop Estanislao Abainza of the United Church of Christ disclosed tonight.

title: Prospects for Overhaul of Federal Communications Law Brighten
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Prospects for a sweeping overhaul of Federal communications law during the current Congress have suddenly brightened.

title: Job Programs for Black Youths Need Coordination, Experts Say
description: I've been at this for a long time, Garth L. Magnum was saying. There are no real answers. A lot of things have helped. But all you can expect is to make some marginal improvements.

title: Minority Preference May End
description: WASHINGTON. March 13  The Carter Administration, in an effort to conclude a multilateral trade pact with European governments and Japan, has offered to overturn a longstanding policy that gives small and minority businesses a preference in bidding for Federal contracts.

title: ANGUS G. WYNNE JR.; BUILT THEME PARKS
description: DALLAS, March 13 Angus G. Wynne Jr., developer of several of America's biggest amusement parks, died last night at Baylor Hospital here after suffering a heart attack at his Dallas home. He was 65 years old and had been in poor health for some time.

description: WASHINGTON, March 14  The Defense Department said today that American military instructors now in Yemen and others being sent there would play a strictly limited training role.

title: A Victorian Breakfast: Late and Great
description: IT was always a late meal, you see, John Tovey was saying, explaining why Victorians breakfasted later and more hugely than most of us. The gentry would go out early, riding, shooting or fishing. They would inspect their smallgame traps. Then it was back to the country house for breakfast.

title: Careers
description: FOR years high school and college students have been indoctrinated with the idea that high grades are everything, but now the pendulum may be swinging the other way.

title: TV: Pearl Bailey Saluted
description: THERE'S something to be saidTHERE'S something to be saidfor singlesponsorship television shows. The sacred corporate image is fused with the production. The result, frequently, is somewhat better than presentations that reflect only the taste and budget of the network and the packager, and on which several advertisers buy .30 seconds or a minute or two of commercial time, with no feeling of responsibility.

title: Spanish Police Say a Leftist Plot To Kill Prime Minister Is Crushed
description: MADRID, March 13 (Reuters)  The Spanish police have uncovered what they believe was a leftist plot to assassinate Prime Minister Adolfo Surez during last month's general election campaign, police sources said today.

title: Pfizer Will Sell Scanners to China
description: Pfizer Inc. announced the signing of a contract with the China National Chemicals Import and Export Corporation in Peking for the sale and installation this year in China of its models 0450 and 0200 body scanners. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: A.C.L.U. Challenges a Plan for Surveillance Abroad
description: WASHINGTON. March 13  The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday challenged a proposed law that would authorize United States intelligence agencies to place Americans living abroad under electronic surveillance in noncriminal cases.

title: The City
description: Milk prices, which rose sharply in the first days of the strike of drivers and dairyplant employes, have now dropped to a level 3.5 cents above pricesbefore the walkout, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

title: Hanoi Reports Fierce Fighting
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 13 (Routers)  Vietnam said today that its forces had wiped out two Chinese infantry batallions and three artillery companies yesterday in what it described as fierce fighting in northeastern Lang Son Province.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Chess:
description: The seconds in a world championship match, while present for the benefit of their principal, also reap longterm benefits for themselves. Only a small fraction of the opening analyses they work out ever get a chance to appear in the match itself; the rest is theirs to use in subsequent events.

title: Malavasi in Hospital
description: HONOLULU, March 13 (UPI)  Ray Malavasi, 48-year-old coach of the Los Angeles Rams, was listed in satisfactory condition in a hospital today. He was admitted last night with symptoms of high blood pressure, after attending the National Football League owners meeting.

title: Members Begin SitIn At the Church of God After Receiver Named
description: PASADENA. Calif., March 13 (UPI)The treasurer of the Worldwide Church of God, speaking as several hundred members began the second sitin of their prolonged dispute with California officials, vowed today not to let the state rape and pillage the church any longer.

description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Following is how senators said they would have voted on the measure to suspend the limit on senators outside earnings:

description: With oil stocks and blue chips leading the way, the stock market pushed higher yesterday on expanding volume.

description: Too Far to Go, the widely praised television adaptation of eight short stones by John Updike that was presented on NBC on Monday night, had its inception when Robert Geller realized that, although he was happily married, a lot of people weren't.

title: Personal Health
description: HALF century ago, when jet travel was not even an aviator's dream, Wiley Post, who piloted his monoplane around the world in eight days, had already discovered what we now call jet lag. Mr. Post recognized the disruption of body rhythms caused by rapidly changing time zones and worked out a program to counter the deleterious effects of altered sleepwake cycles on flying efficiency.

title: Brooklyn Fire Kills 2 Young Sisters
description: Two young sisters were killed and three other members of their family and a neighbor were slightly injured early yesterday after a fire believed to be arson raged through their Brooklyn house and an adjoining familyrun grocery store.

description: International

title: Miller Hints Fed Opposes Hostile Bank Takeovers
description: The Federal Reserve Board probably would oppose unfriendly takeovers of American banks by foreigners. G. William Miller said yesterday at a news conference in New York.

title: Rent Board Postpones Hearing
description: The Rent Guidelines Board, which was scheduled to meet today to review the increases it allowed for rentstabilized apartments, has rescheduled the meeting for Wednesday at 1:30 P.M. in the Police Headquarters building.

title: 6 Oil Companies Agree to Comply In Part with Albany Price Inquiry
description: ALBANY, March 13  Six major oil companies have agreed to partial compliance with subpoenas issued by the State Energy Office in an investigation of their pricing and supply policies, New York State's Energy Commissioner, James L. Larocca, announced today.

title: City Announces Plan For the Improvement Of Subway Stations
description: The Department of City Planning made public a series of prototype plans yesterday for modernization of the 456 subway and elevated stations.

title: Paper Deliverers Warn of a Shift On Wholesalers Strike Deadline
description: The Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, which set a March 31 deadline last week for a strike against 16 wholesalers who deliver newspapers and magazines to retailers in the metropolitan New York area, warned yesterday that it may have to move it up.

description: NEW ORLEANS, March 13 (AP) Lindy Infante, who spent the last two years as a receiver coach with the Giants of the National Football League, has returned to Tulane University as offensive coordinator, a post he previously held.

title: Amin Says Palestinians Assist Uganda's Cause
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 13 (AP) President Idi Amin said today that Palestinian soldiers were helping Uganda in the battle to drive out the Tanzanians.

title: Best Buys
description: WHEN President Carter announced wage and price control guidelines last fall, New York City consumers were paying $1.36 for a fivepound bag of sugar. 86 cents for a dozen eggs, 61 cents for a head of lettuce. $1.69 for a pound of butter and $1.39 for a pound of ground chuck. Then, the total for those five staples was $5.91. Today, shoppers will pay $6.79 for those same food items.

description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, March 15 GUGLIELMO MARCONI (Italian Line Cruises International). Lett St. Thomas March 11; doe 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that it would irreparably impair the national security if The Progressive magazine were allowed to publish an article that supposedly details secrets on building a hydrogen bomb.

title: Mercator Atlas Is Auctioned In London for $680,000
description: LONDON, March 13  An atlas of Europe by Mercator, the 16thcentury cartographer, was sold at Sotheby's auction here today for 5680.000.

description: The dollar soared against the Japanese yen in foreignexchange trading in Europe and New York yesterday, after Exxon's announcement that it was cutting supplies of crude oil to Japan.

description: Morning

description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Mayor Koch told a Congressional panel today that he favored an increase in President Carter's projected Federal budget deficit next year in order to allow grants of more aid to urban areas.

title: Jersey Squanders 17Point Lead
description: CHICAGO, March 13 (AP)  Anis Gilmore scored on a stuff shot with minute 8 seconds remaining, and Reggie Theus and John Brown followed with baskets on unorthodox shots that enabled the Chicago Bulls to defeat the New Jersey Nets. 105102.

title: FIVE ATOMIC PLANTS ORDERED SHUT DOWN
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today ordered that five electrical generating plants powered by nuclear energy be closed down within 48 hours because of a deficient analysis of their ability to withstand earthquakes.
