title: Antiabortion Amendment Gains
description: NASHVILLE, March 13 (AP)  After an hour's debate and viewing of color photographs of human fetuses, the Tennessee Senate approved a resolution urging an amendment to the United States Constitution outlawing most abortions. The 23to5 vote last night sends the resolution to the House. If it passes that chamber, Tennessee will become the 15th state to endorse the resolution.

title: Exxon Sets CrudeOil Sales Curb
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it would soon stop selling crude oil to all other oil companies.

title: Carter's Return Draws a Crowd To Hail Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, March 14  A very tired but exuberant President Carter slowly descended the ramp from Air Force One early this morning and told a Jubilant crowd, Our work has had a happy result.

title: Frank Stops Casale in 10, Keeps Title
description: TOTOWA, N.J., March 13  In a bout as pretty as a Secaucus pig farm but as rugged as a Hoboken dock brawl, Scott Frank retained the New Jersey heavyweight boxing title tonight when Guy (The Rock) Casale was unable to answer the bell for the 10th round because of a closed right eye.

title: Citicorp Notes at 10.152%
description: Citicorp reported that it sold its weekly issue of 91day auction paper yesterday at an average rate of 10.152 percent. up from 10.095 percent last week. The bankholding company, parent of Citibank, received $641.5 million of bids and accepted $100 million at rates ranging from 10.05 percent to 10.169 percent. It accepted 37 percent at the high rate and it also announced it would sell $100 million more notes next Tuesday.

title: Economic Scene
description: HOW can the United States best handle the economic problems  intensified inflation, threatened recession and a worsening of the international balance of payments  set off by the Iranian explosion now reverberating throughout the Middle East? And if President Carter succeeds in winning a peace treaty between Egypt and Israel, as he appears to be on the verge of doing, will this ease or aggravate this country's energy and financial problems?

title: Dollar Continues to Gain Against Japan's Currency
description: TOKYO, March 13  The dollar continued to rise sharply in relation to the yen today, despite intervention by the Bank of Japan. The United States currency closed at 205.975 yen, its highest level in more than eight months. Currency dealers here said Japan's central bank, which sold some $150 million worth of dollars yesterday to support the intervened again today by selling $60 million to $70 million.

title: TWO CHURCHES TAKE STEP TOWARD UNION
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 13  Two major Protestant denominations, the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) and the United Church of Christ, have taken a firm step toward some form of union by separately approving further discussions.

title: Park, at Trial, Describes Meeting Passman in 70
description: MONROE, La., March 13 (UPI) Tongsun Park, the South Korean businessman, testified today that former Representative Otto E. Passman was introduced to him by Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana in 1970 as someone who would be very helpful if I would become his friend.

title: For the British in Northern Ireland, No End in Sight
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 8  Nearly a decade after British troops began patrolling the streets of this troubled province, their mission shows few signs of ending.

title: Opera: Unplanned Debut
description: THE title role of Bellini's Norma attracts sopranos the way Mount Everest attracts mountain climbers. The challenge lures them on. This season the work is being revived at the Metropolitan Opera fir Shirley Verrett, who was supposed to have sung it with the company for the first time Monday night. Unfortunately, she came down with a cold and was unable to go on. Her place was taken by her standby, Marisa Galvany, who had, at least had, the benefit of one orchestral rehearsal.

title: 3.5% Growth Seen in Europe
description: GENEVA, March 13  Western Europe's economic growth rate should attain the 3.5 percent projected by national planners for 1979, against the 2.8 percent recorded in 1978, according to a United Nations survey released today.

title: Beware the Blizzard of 88
description: Let no one be deceived by the latest run of lamblike weather, sunny days and temperatures in the 50's. March, which the early Britons called hyldmonath, or a loud and stormy month, is with us still, and as last weekend's sharp reversion to winter attests, it deserves no trust.

title: A Brooklyn Jail Escapee Seized in San Francisco
description: A convicted murderer who escaped from the Brooklyn House of Detention two weeks ago has been arrested by the F.B.I. in San Francisco.

title: Court to Hear BusStrike Motions
description: Two legal actions aimed at ending the wildcat strike by schoolbus drivers and matrons in New York City are expected to be heard in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn by the end of the week. The strike is nearly a month old.

title: Unofficial U.S. Links To Taiwan Approved By House and Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Both houses of Congress approved legislation today enabling the United States to maintain unofficial relations with Taiwan while giving diplomatic recognition to China.

title: Library Trustees Bridling At a Performance Audit
description: City auditors have started to investigate, for the first time, how wisely a host of private agencies  hospitals, museums, libraries, childcare institutions  are spending city money.

title: Quiet Start For Europe Money Plan
description: PARIS, March 13  Western Europe's experiment with fixed exchange rates opened quietly today without any tension among the eight participating currencies and no pressure on the dollar.

title: COMMODITIES
description: News that an American company had made a copper sale to China bolstered copper futures yesterday, following their recent decline. In addition, some buying by bargain hunters helped prires as well.

title: Advertising
description: THE chances are that Scientific American, already published in five languages besides English, could next be distributed in the Soviet Union in Russian. That seemed to be the gist of the hints being given off vesterday by C. John Kirby, vice president, advertising, and others at the first seminar on international publishing given by the Magazine Publishers Association, at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Ulster Town a Combat Zone
description: CROSSMAGLEN, Northern Ireland, March 8  Paddy Short, whose bright blue cinderblock tavern is one of the few cheerful spots in this otherwise grim little border town, wiped off the shiny bar and then used his damp cloth to gesture toward the heavily armed British soldiers patrolling outside his door.

title: Private Lives
description: WHEN the word went out from every editor of every newspaper and magazine on the Eastern Seaboard to bag Otto, nobody called me. I was at home alone, reading The New York Review of Books. I would have preferred chasing around the Poconos in the black of night in search of the restaurant whose name John McPhee refused to mention in The New Yorker. Although all food, in my opinion, is overrated, I'd rather be searching for a scoop on frozen turbot than be reading about cannibalism.

title: Bostonians Arrive in Shanghai
description: SHANGHAI, March 13  The tired, disheveled but happy Boston Symphony Orchestra touched down in Shanghai shortly after 6 o'clock tonight, after a 20hour flight. Here in China to give a series of concerts and master classes in Shanghai and Peking, the members of the orchestra had just enough time to get to the hotel, spruce up a bit and get to a banquet in their honor at the Peace Hotel.

title: Music: Orpheus Players
description: THE Orpheus Chamber Ensemble's concert Monday night at Carnegie Hall was a gratifying success  gratifying because all good music performed well becomes a gratifying experience, but also because there is something inherently satisfying about a conductorless chamber orchestra.

title: U.S. Report Clears Cleveland Bank In Dispute Involving City's Default
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  A Federal Reserve staff report has concluded that the Cleveland Trust Company did not violate banking laws or sound practices when it increased its trust holdings in private utility company at the same time it was supporting a demand that Cleveland sell a competing municipal power system.

title: Three Top Scorers Miss 10491 Loss
description: Frustration showed on Coach Elgin Baylor's face last night after the New Orleans Jazz lost to the Knicks, 10491, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Lear to Make Own Films
description: LOS ANGELES, March 13  Norman Lear, creator of television's All in the Family, Sanford and Son and Maude, will write, direct and produce an unspecified number of original motion pictures for Universal.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 13, 1979

title: Murder Trial Goes On For a Nurse Who Says She Halted Aspirators
description: BALTIMORE, March 13 (AP)  Colleagues say that Mary Rose Robaczynski is a compassionate woman who expressed a belief in euthanasia. Now the fanner nurse is midway through a murder trial, accused of killing a man in a coma by unplugging his respirator.

title: Statements by Carter and Begin on Talks
description: Mr. President, Mr. Prime Minister and friends, as we depart for Cairo and then for my own country. I want to express on behalf of Rosalyn my wife, myself and all the American party, our gratitude to the Government and to the

title: Iran's Oil Output Nears New Goal
description: Iranian oil production has reached 2.5 million barrels a day, the National Iranian Oil Company said in Teheran yesterday, up from the 1.6 million barrels a day that the company produced when it resumed oil production last week, but still well below the million barrels it turned out daily before the revolution.

title: News of the Theater
description: MURDER at the Howard Johnson's has found theater. It will go into previews at the Golden on May 15 and then open there two nights later. The mysterycomedy by Sam Bobrick and Ron Clark stars Bob Dishy, Tony Roberts and Marcia Rodd, and until this week it was one of a number of productions that faced the possibility of an endless life on the road because of the theater shortage in New York. Last Sunday night, however, Strangers closed, freeing the Golden.

title: TV: Romeo and Juliet
description: NO, the British Broadcasting Corporation's Romeo and Juliet does not have the gorgeous energy, the sheer vivacity of the Franco Zeffirelli film produced a decade or so ago.

title: Mugger Who Pushed Woman Onto Tracks Indicted in a 2d Case
description: A 20-year-old convicted mugger, serving time for robbing an airline stewardess and pushing her in the path of an oncoming subway train last July, was indicted yesterday by a grand jury in Manhattan in the robbery less than a month earlier of another woman who had also been pushed onto subway tracks by her assailant.

title: 45 Reported Killed in Crash Of Jordanian Plane in Qatar
description: DOHA, Qatar, Wednesday, March 14 (Reuters)  More than 45 passengers on a Jordanian Boeing 727 airliner were killed when the plane crashed in a thunderstorm at Doha airport today, airport officials said.

title: Stage: Shepard Suicide
description: SUICIDE in B Flat (at the Impossible Ragtime Theater) is the third new play by Sam Shepard to be introduced in New York so far this season. Each of the works demonstrates a different aspect of this adventurous playwright.

title: Brock Praises Carter's Peace Efforts in Middle East
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Bill Brock, the Republican National chairman, praised President Carter's peacemaking efforts in the Middle East today but said the President would need other successes before the public believed he had a capacity for leadership.

title: Northern Ireland Child Wounded
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 13 (AP)  Gunmen firing from ambush seriously wounded an 8-year-old girl today in Stewartstown, 35 miles west of here, the police said. The girl's father, police reservist, was driving her and her brother to school when the gunmen opened fire. The father and son were unhurt.

title: Bridge:
description: Bastions of male exclusivity are few and far between these days, but there is one notable survival in New York. It is the Interclub Contract League, now in its 45th year, which conducts a monthly tournament during the winter with the dignity and comfort of a bygone era. Feminist complaints of discrimination can be countered with the argument that women have their own leagues, conducted during the summer in country clubs.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amex Commodities Exchange has named Michael A. Mullan director, market development.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PERSPECTIVES Free exhibitions in art and photography are opening in two of midtown's more picturesque showcases. Starting today, at the northeast building of Rockefeller Plaza, Nikon House this month is combining two picture exhibitions in the gallery. Frank Wilcox's Light is a Jewel includes a series of color photographs stressing the importance of light to the images, while Terry Gruber's Colorborne features color images of abstracts, prism images, people and patterns.

title: Hunter Consoles Yankees
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13On an afternoon when the Yankees finally scored, but still lost their sixth straight exhibition game, Catfish Hunter provided some consolation for New York today.

title: Derry F. Daly, 52
description: Derry F. Daly, manager of the J. Walter Thompson Company's directresponse group, died Sunday of a heart attack in his home at 36 East 10th Street. He was 52 years old.

The voluntary longterm care facility, one of the nation's largest, serves 1,800 elderly people. Residents ranging from 69 to 98 participated in celebration.

title: Army Secretary Rebuffs General For Seeking a Draft for Reserves
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Gen. Bernard Rogers, Army Chief of Staff, said today that he would like to begin drafting Americans this year into a reserve force, but he was sharply rebuked by his superior, Army Secretary Clifford L. Alexander, who said in a statement tonight, There is no necessity for the resumption of the draft.

title: Seoul Pessimistic on Its Talks With North
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 12  For the first time since 1973, a series of highlevel political meetings between South and North Korea are taking place at Panmunjom, but the South Korean Government doubts that the conferences will achieve results, officials said last weekend.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: WHEN a recipe instructs you to pound a piece of meat until it is flat, be careful. A fine cut of veal does not call for a sledgehammer approach; it requires a cook armed with an appropriate meat pounder and enough sensitivity to flatten the meat without pulverizing it.

title: Officer Fined $20,000 And Made To Resign In a New Crackdown
description: A New York City police officer has been fined $20,000 and forced to resign for associating with narcotics peddlers, and two other officers have been given lesser fines for taking bribes from gamblers, the department reported yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday stated incorrectly that a committee of the National Academy of Sciences had recommended that the exposure level for workers to radiation be lowered from 5 reins a year to 0.5. The recommendation was made not by the committee but by Dr. Edward Radford, chairman of the academy's committee on biclogical effects of iorizing radation.

title: ExAide to Tim Tones Kills Himself at News Briefing
description: MODESTO, Calif., March 13 (AP)  A former People's Temple leader killed himself with a single gunshot to the head tonight minutes after complaining to reporters of Federal harassment in connection with the cult's murdersuicide ritual in Guyana.

title: REBELS IN GRENADA SAID TO STAGE COUP
description: Armed rebels reportedly led by an opposition leader on the Caribbean island of Grenada took over the radio station, the airfield and a military barracks early yesterday morning and announced in broadcasts monitored in nearby Barbados that they had overthrown the Government of Sir Eric M. Gairy.

title: $705 Million Tenneco Bid Made for General Crude
description: The International Paper Company, in a move that took the Gulf Oil Corporation by surprise, disclosed yesterday that it had broken a tentative agreement to sell Gulf its General Crude Oil Company and had reached a new sales agreement with the Tenneco Oil Company and the Southland Royalty Company.

title: Per Haekkerup Dies at Age of 63; Danish Leader and U.N. Diplomat
description: Per Haekkerup, a leading figure in Danish politics since the end of World War II, died yesterday in Copenhagen at the age of 63.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Marry of your recipes call for shallots. Here in Alaska they are not, to my knowledge, available anywhere. Can anything be substituted for shallots; onions, perhaps?

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Sites for 3 Super Bowls Are Awarded by N.F.L.
description: HONOLULU, March 13 (AP)  The National Football League's Super Bowl games for I981, 82 and 83 were awarded today to New Orleans; Pontiac, Mich., and Pasadena, Calif., respectively.

title: Books of The Times
description: DAVID LADD, the actor's younger son, is quoted in Beverly Linet's biography. Ladd as saying: Perhaps my father will become a cult figure. Maybe this book will revive him. It isn't likely to, because Alan Ladd made few movies that have aged well, or that show him off as anything more than a handsome. laconic cipher.

title: White House Challenged on Plan To Limit the Costs of Hospitals
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)  The White House was challenged on its hospital cost control bill today by critics who said the proposal would punish small, efficient hospitals and reward mismanaged, highly profitable institutions.

title: Around the Nation
description: DENVER, March 13 (AP)  Colorado's method of financing public schools is unconstitutional because it does not provide equal financing for rich and poor districts, a judge ruled today.

title: European Leaders Upset Over Big Food Surpluses
description: PARIS, March 13  The Common Market voiced concern today over the mountains of surplus food resulting from its farmprice subsidy system. These same stockpiles, the United States argues, are seriously threatening American agricultural exports just as the Carter Administration is trying to narrow the country's trade gap.

title: Ferris Irks Broadcasters Over Pay TV
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 13 Charies. D. Ferris, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, predicted today that quality children's programming would be produced profitably in the new television marketplace that is growing around cable television, pay television, satellites, video cassettes and video disks. These technological innovations, he said, will not be constricted by the economic considerations that make excellent programming for children seem beyond the capacity of the existing commercial television system.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: EARNINGS
description: J.C. Penney Company Inc., the nation's thirdlargest retailer of general merchandise, had profit declines of 13.1 percent in the fourth quarter and 4.8 percent for the 52 weeks to Jan. 27, despite record sales, according to the company's preliminary unaudited statement issued yesterday.

title: Carol Bellamy Endorses a Liberal Party Candidate
description: The New York City Council President, Carol Bellamy, together with Robert F. Wagner Jr., the chairman of f the City Planning Commission, and nine other Democratic officials have bolted their party's line and endorsed the Liberal Party candidate in a special election for the Assembly next Tuesday. The election will be in the 62d Assembly District, which covers lower Manhattan and the northeastern corner of Staten Island.

title: Gas Cost Rise Cleared
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)  The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission reversed an earlier ruling today and gave naturalgas producers a $1 billion bonus by saying they can charge top prices for gas sold under old contracts.

title: It's Time For the Eating Of the Greens
description: ST. PATRICK's DAY, just three days away, is the first, and perhaps the most exuberant, holiday what well may be called the long green season springtime. And if the wearin' of the green is the traditional requirement of that Irish festival, the eating the green is equally important to most of the observances that follow.

title: Regents Chairs Draw the Eminent in a Bargain for State
description: When he won his sevenyear struggle to emigrate from the Soviet Union three months ago, Veniamin Levich became one of the most soughtafter luminaries of the academic world. and Columbia University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and other prestigious schools bid for his services.

title: BREAKTHROUGH SEEN
description: CAIRO, March 13  President Carter won Egyptian approval today on all points of a proposed peace treaty between Israel and Egypt and said that Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel had agreed to submit to his Cabinet as soon as possible the few remaining issues that Israel had yet to endorse.

title: Labor SuesOn FederalPay Guide
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  The nation's largest labor organization, as previously threatened, filed suit today against the Administration's wagerestraint standard, asking a Federal court to declare unlawful the Administration's plan to withhold contracts from companies violating the guideline.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, March 13, 1979

title: City to Give Transit Police $500,000 for Overtime
description: As a way to increase the presence of uniformed transit police officers in the subway system, the city has agreed to provide $500,000 to the Transit Authority for overtime payments during the next three and a half months.

title: U.S. Speaks Out for 22 Detained in Soviet Union
description: GENEVA, March 13 (Reuters)  The United States accused the Soviet Union today of abusing the fundamental freedoms of its citizens and identified 22 people said to be detained for trying to promote human rights.

title: Japan Allows Ads Of U.S. Cigarettes
description: Foreign cigarette makers are going to be able to advertise their wares in Japan for the first time since World War II, Ippei Kaneko, the Japanese Finance Minister, announced in Tokyo yesterday.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Sportswear in SoHo

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: At a Party for Hair, No Tears for the 60's
description: The prevailing hair styles were short enough to please even a boot camp sergeant, and the attire was black tie rather than flower child fantasia. A decade has undeniably passed, and the 1,000 partygoers who gathered to celebrate the 1960's on Monday night seemed far more interested in having a good time than in mourning a bygone era.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (Reuters)  China has purchased copper from the United States for the first time in 30 years, the Government said today.

title: 4 New Casinos Predicted in Jersey
description: TRENTON, March 13  Joseph P. Lordi, chairman of the New Jersey Casino Control Commission, told a legislative committee today he expected to see four new gambling casinos operating in Atlantic City within 15 months.

title: Jersey Is Preparing to Spend 600 Million in Transit Plan
description: TRENTON, March 13  The state's .Department of Transportation proposed today to spend $600 million to improve New Jersey's bus and rail system. Commissioner Louis J. Gambaccini said $120 million would come from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and $480 million from Federal matching funds.

title: A Baldness Remedy Is Assailed
description: LURED by the dream of a full head of luxuriantly thick, permanent hair, thousands of bald or balding men are falling victim to a new Implantation process now widely seen as dangerous  the sewing of synthetic wig fibers directly into the scalp.

title: Tickner Falters in Skating
description: VIENNA, March 13 (AP)  A disastrous third round in the compulsory figures put Charlie Tickner of Littleton, Colo., the defending champion, in fourth place on the opening day at the world figure skating championships today.

title: TaxFree Yields Dip Some what
description: The taxexempt securities market, working to underwrite an unusually big volume of new issues this week, set terms on more than $1.5 billion of notes and bonds yesterday. Yields on some of the largest issues were lowered modestly.

title: Protecting U.S. Companies Abroad
description: In the early days of United States commercial imperialism, which were not all that long ago, American companies operating overseas would be offended when they became targets of nationalist demonstrations. The sudden realization that some saw them as Ugly Americans caused pain and damaged their selfimage.

title: Jailed Sweepstakes Winner Still Fighting I.R.S. Bill
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 Frank McNulty has apparently won a round with the Internal Revenue Service  and he has spent four years and one month in jail so far to do it  but he may never get to spend the money.

title: St. Louis Teachers Resume Work After Adopting Pact
description: ST. LOUIS, March 13  The city's 4,100 schoolteachers returned to their classrooms today, ending a bitter strike that has kept students out of classes for the last eight weeks.

title: Indiana and Ohio State Get N.I.T. Byes
description: Indiana and Ohio State, Big Ten rivals, gained byes yesterday into the semifinal round of the National Invitation Tournament in a blind draw made necessary because six teams had survived the first two rounds.

title: Real Estate
description: I'VE learned two things, said Samuel Silberberg, who rarely misses the opportunity to draw lessons from experience. The first thing is you're better off owning your own building. The second thing is I'm better off closer to the sources of my business.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  This column really should be signed by former Secretary of State. Henry Kissinger because, with his permission, it contains his reflections on President Caiter's mission to the Middle East.

title: Winking at the Senate
description: We expressed incredulity the other day when the Senate voted itself a backdoor raise by lifting the limit on the outside earnings of senators. The new limit was what Speaker O'Neill has described as the heart and soul of the new ethical codes Congress adopted in 1977. Members of Congress used to receive fat fees from interest groups for speeches or professional services  leaving them open to suspicion of influencepeddling or greed. To remove a limit on such earnings now, a mere 67 days after it took effect, seemed to us unhealthy, for obvious reasons.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Soviet Reported To Add to Load Missile Can Fire
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  American arms negotiators have been shaken by intelligence information indicating that the Soviet Union's most powerful missile is being adapted to carry more warheads than would be permitted under the projected armslimitation treaty.

title: U.S. Indian Ocean Plans Assailed
description: NEW DELHI, March 13  Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin, touring India, lashed out at Washington today over reports that the United States was considering establishing a permanent naval presence in the Indian Ocean and the Persian Gulf.

title: Safe Nuclear Waste Disposal Held as Still Unsolved
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  A special committee of the Federal Government reported to President Carter today that the safety of disposing of highlevel radioactive wastes in underground repositories could be determined only after specific investigations at particular sites. The committee's assessment conflicted with the broad assertions of Federal officials over the years about the relative ease of handling radiactive wastes created by nuclear power reactors and the manufacture of nuclear weapons.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Federal Reserve continued to pump temporary reserves into the banking system yesterday in an apparent effort to keep the Federal funds rate  the basic shortterm interest rate in the credit markets  below 103/16 percent.

title: ONE MORE SPY CASE REPORTED BY BONN
description: BONN, March 13  A sevenweeklong series of espionage disclosures about East German penetration of West German Government and industry reached a high point today with the announcement that the secretary of one of Bonn's most important political figures had disappeared and was suspected of being a spy.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LOS ANGELES  The oil cutoff at Suez in 1956 led to abortive schemes for digging canals with nuclear explosives and to premature plans for nuclear electricity. especially in Europe. European hopes were soon dashed. And no one has found an economic use for peaceful nuclear explosives. But their military implications are evident in India and Brazil and Argentina.

title: Deaths
description: BARTLETTJuliet M. Suddenly on March 12. 1979 in her 81st year. Sister of Sarah Bartlett Finley& Philip G. Bartlett. Noticed memorial service later.

title: 5 Senators Bid Energy Chief Leave
description: WASHINGTON. March 14  Five Democratic Senators took the floor today to call for the resignation of James R. Schlesinger as Secretary of Energy, contending he had mismanaged his department and favored industry over consumers.

title: It's Business as Usual in Grenada One Day After Regime Is Ousted
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, March 19 (AP)  Stores on this little Caribbean island opened for business as usual today and supporters of the rebel civilians who toppled the Government yesterday danced in the streets. One death was reported in the coup. .

title: Ozawa Conducts Class in Shanghai
description: SHANGHAI, March 14  Seiji Ozawa worked hard today, but not with his Boston Symphony. He had an afternoon date with the Shanghai Philharmonic and put the orchestra through the Pathetique Symphony by Tchaikovskv. Part of the reason the Boston Svm- phony has come to China is pedagogical - conductor and musicians are to work with their Chinese counterparts, indoctrinating them into performance prac tices of Western music.

title: Kresse Hired at Charleston
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., March 14 (UPI)  John Kresse, formerly an assistant at St. John's University, was named head basketball coach at the College of Charleston. He will succeed Alan LeForce, who announced his resignation in January.

title: I.T.T. Travel Service Unit
description: The formation of a new company. ITT Electronic Travel Services, was announced yesterday by George F. Knapp, vice president of the International Tele- phone and Telegraph Corporation and chief executive of I.T.T.'s Telecommunications operating companies. Mr. Knapp said the new company had developed computerized multiaccess reservation service, which is called Mars, for travel agencies throughout the country. The new service will provide direct connections with the computerized reservation networks of participating airlines, hotels, carrental agencies, cruise lines and other related travel services, Mr. Knapp said.

title: Ripped Off By Aliens
description: ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands was 6 A.M. when I dropped off my son, Richard, at Belmont Park in Elmont, N.Y. He joined about 20 others, mostly young, outside the racetrack employment booth. They hoped to find work as hotwalkers  people who walk horses around  the lowest paid job on the backstretch. They knew that hotwalkers were needed now that racing was in full swing. What they didn't know was this: While they were waiting for hours each morning for trainers to hire new men, most openings were being filled by illegal aliens who didn't find it necessary to fill out forms or wait on lines.

title: The Milwaukee Cites 1978 Loss
description: CHICAGO, March 14 (UPI)  Effects of the winter were disastrousfor the Milwaukee Road, the railroad's bankruptcy trustee has reported, and the railroad needs about $10 million in additional funds in April to sustain operations until early summer.

title: Ballesteros's Golf Swing Rated Incomparable by Henry Cooper
description: MIAMI, March 14  Severiano Ballesteros looks like a bullfighter. Even his followthrough on a golf swing has the grace of .the matador, for the 21yearold SpAniard moves with a fluidity that belies his constant pain.

title: 2 Agencies Win Spots With Sony
description: Waritig & LaRosa and Ammirati Purls AvRutick both won pieces of business from Sony Industries, a unit of the Sony Corporation of America. Yesterday.

title: About Little Ferry
description: LITTLE FERRY, N.J., March 13 It was more than 40 years ago, when Ralph Corrado was a little boy, that his father had the neatest green diner hauled right down the main road of Hoboken, parading it wondrously, as if it were a railroad car from Mars. He had it hooked up to its foundation on Madison Street and the first customers came, and thoyate and stared.

title: Bill Jorgensen Quits As WNEWTV Newsman
description: Bill Jorgensen, for 13 years the anchor man on WNEWTV's nightly newscasts, has quit his job to pursue other interests, according to a statement issued by WNEW and Mr. Jorgensen. The station said: Bill Jorgensen played a major role in establishing Channel 5's 10 o'clock news as the most successful primetime news in America. We wish him well.

title: Clark to Lease Westchester Theater
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 14  The Westchester Theater, whose former operation was marred by bankruptcy and criminal indictments, will be leased by the entertainer Dick Clark, who is to reopen it in June under his name, it was announced today.

title: American Is Among 45 Who Died In Airliner Crash on Persian Gulf
description: DOHA, Qatar, March 19 (AP)  An American was identified today among the 45 persons killed earlier today when Jordanian airliner crashed and bumed

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRI VINO TODAY. Match 11 OUCILIELMO MARCONI (Ifallen Una Cruises International) Let St. Thomas March 11; is S AM. at W. um Street.

title: Mexican Quake Kills 1, Injures 32,
description: MEXICO CITY, March 19 (AP) major earthquake and 18 aftershocks jolted vast areas of .Mexico before dawn today, killing one person and destroying or damaging bUdings in the capital.

description: Music

title: Deaths
description: GANLYJohn BernardMarch 4.1979 in Capitoia. California in his 76th year. Beloved Brother of James. Raymond, band the late Laurette. Reposing at Conner Funeral Home. 4955 Broadway. N.Y. Thursday. Visiting hours 110PM. Mass Christian Burial, 10AM Friday at Elizabeth's R. C. Church2268 Wads. worth Ave, NYC. Interment Gate Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of Rowers, contributions to Mount Monresa Retreat House. Fingerboard Rd. Staten island will be appreciated.

title: DISBELIEVER: Manuel Gonzalez was already celebrating victory in Tokyo yesterday when officials announced he had narrowly lost W.B.A. bout to junior middleweight champion Masashi Kudo of Japan.

title: U.S. IsSaid to. Accept a Direct. Role In Talks on Palestinian Home Rule
description: CAIRO, March 19  The United States has agreed to participate directly in the negotiations between Egypt and Israel aimed at bringing Palestinian home rule to the West Bank and Gaza Strip, a ranking Egyptian official said today.

title: Irrepressible New York State Appeals Judge
description: David Ross

title: St. Louis Pupils Return, Talking Of Vacations. That Are Not to Be
description: ST. LOUIS, March 14  Uncertain about their academic standing and unhappy that they will have to spend much of the summer in the classroom, most of the city's 73,000 students returned to their classes today after the longest teachers strike in the city's history.

title: Palestinians Demonstrate
description: JERUSALEM, March 14  There were demonstrations today in eastern Jerusalem and on the West Bank against the projected treaty, and political leaders there, most of them elected with the support of the P.L.O.. denounced the accord.

title: South Africa Strike Ebbs
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 14 nationwide strike by white miners appeared to have collapsed today, apparently giving a major lift to efforts to end racial discrimination in South African industry.

title: MANY ARAB NATIONS ASSAIL CAIRO PACT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 14  Arabs, from hardline opponents of peace with Israel to financial backers of Egypt, joined today in denouncing Egyptian and Israeli moves toward a treaty.

title: Bill Would Delay Law On ExU.S. Aides
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)  Representative George E. Danielson, Democrat of California, has introduced legislation that would postpone for six months a new ethics law designed to eliminate the socalled revolving door between Government officials and the companies they regulate.

title: Advertising
description: IF you think nobody would be interested in a publication that is made up totally of paid advertising you don't know. about the Physicians Desk Reference.

title: Golden Nugget's $21 Million Issue
description: Golden Nugget Inc., a company that owns a gambling casino in Los Vegas, Nev., and intends to build one in Atlantic City, is selling $21 million of securities today in a combined package of common stock and 12 percent debentures.

title: Howard L. Bern, Vice President Of Grossinger Hotel, Dies at 54
description: Howard L. Bern, general manager and vice president of the Grossinger Hotel and Country Club, died yesterday in the Community General Hospital in Harris, N.Y., following a long illness. He was 59 and lived in Liberty, N.Y.

title: Regan a Skeptic On Plan to Build Convention Hall
description: ALBANY, March 14  Comptroller Edward V. Regan expressed serious reservations today about the methods that will be used to finance the New York City convention center and about its potential financial effects on the State of New York. But he said he doubted if be could legally stop

title: Norman Macbeth, 62, Chairman Of an ElectroOptical Corporation
description: Norman Macbeth, chairman of the Kollmorgen Corporation, died Tuesday of a heart attack while vacationing in Rio de Janeiro. He was 62 years old and lived at 20 Horseshoe Road in Darien. Conn.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times March stated incorrectly that no one who lost a Presidential primary in New Hemp shire had ever gone on to win the nom'. nation. In 1964 Remy Cabot Lodge defeated Senator Barry Goldwater, who won the Republican nomination. In 1972 Senator Edmund S. Muslde defeated Senator George McGovern, who won the Democratic nomination.

title: Coast Phone Refunds Ordered
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 14  Two California telephone companies were ordered today to draw up plans for refunding $363 million to their customers and reducing rates by more than $70 million a year.

title: Appeals Court Reserves Decision on a Challenge to SchoolBus Pact
description: Three members of a state appeals court yesterday sharply questioned the New York City School Chancellor's decision to change job security and other labor provisions for new schoolbus contracts.

title: ANEW DISTRIBUTION IN WORLD OIL SALES PERILS U.S. IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  The United States is facing almost twice the reduction in oil imports that it suffered at the outset of the Iranian crisis because the international petroleum companies have begun to change the way they distribute their available oil.

title: Illusion of Prosperity Masking Southern Italy's Problems
description: PALERMO, Sicily  Yes, we have some outward signs of wellbeing here, the southern union leader said, but we have no wellbeing.

title: Black Hole
description: Astronomers who have aimed the Haystack radio telescope near Westford, Mass., at the core of the Milky Way Waxy in the last year have concluded that there is an object there five million times as massive as the Sun  a black hole whose gravity is so strong that it sucks in everything within reach, including light.

title: Ktel Tones Down TV Shouting
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba  NOW! WOW! Ktell It is the company best known as the sponsor of latenight television movies interrupted by noisy commercials. Many very noisy commercials, selling the likes of Miracle Brush, DialeX knife sharpener, Salad Queen and hit records.

title: Market Place
description: NOW that Sohio has dropped plans for a pipeline to transport Alaskan crude from West Coast to East Coast refineries, fans of tanker companies are becoming enthusiastic.

title: U.S. Constitution Shields 2 East German Hijackers
description: WEST BERLIN, March 14  A special American court ruled here today that two East Germans who seized a Polish plane last year and diverted it here had the full protection of the United States Constitution and therefore were entitled to a trial by jury.

title: Letters
description: To THE HOME SECTION:

title: Sound
description: LET me continue the mostly good news about cassettes. The occasion is a friend's recent departure for a sabbatical sojourn on Crete  an island that, he says, has everything except opera. He considers the latter a serious lack.

title: The New York Times/William E. Sawa
description: As they waited for awards ceremony to begin, some of the 64 New Yorkers who were honored yesterday for going to the aid of subway passengers or transit police, created a microcosm of the city's population. The award winners, 21

title: North Stars
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 14 (AP)  Glen Sharpley and Tom Younghans scored goals 12 seconds apart in the third period tonight to help the Minnesota North Stars rally from a 31 deficit and register a 43 National Hockey League victory over Montreal.

title: Behind the Veil of Iran
description: It is in the nature of revolution that people who unite against a set of grievances will rarely agree on how to wield power once it is won. The women of Iran, marching determinedly against Ayatollah Khomeini, reaffirm that lesson of history. They also offer hope for Iran's future.

title: Dance: 3 by Viola Farber
description: WITH their lean, fast, pivoting and fragmented pure movement, the more abstract dances of Viola Farber bear the clear influence of Merce Cunningham, with whom she performed for 10 years. They are also funny and humane, but of late the choreographer has seemed most interested in rather

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The United States faces nearly twice the reduction in oil imports that it suffered at the start of the Iranian turmoil, because of new tribution methods being adopted by international oil ministration and industry officials said. As a result, upward sure on prices might intensify. [Page Al.]

title: Nonsteel Operations Aid U.S. Steel's Net
description: The United States Steel Corporation said in its annual report that nonsteel operations accounted for 86 percent of its operating income in 1978 while contributing only 27 percent to its sales.

title: Rear Adm. Paul Lee Dead at 82;  Helped Build World War II Fleet
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., March 14 (AP) Rear Adm. Paul Lee, retired, a naval engineer who played a key role in creation of the Navy's fleet in World War II, is dead at the age of 82.

title: GARDENING
description: THE wrong time to prune is spring, when the sap has begun to energize the trees for new growth. Nor is slimmer a good time, because the new growth following pruning might not be hardy enough to survive the winter. Fall pruning re- moves the new growth and is too hard on the trees. Prune in winter, and the bark will heave, letting all sorts of nasty insects into the wounds come spring.

title: Dr. Martin Rush, 67 A Cytology Specialist And Professor, Dead
description: Dr. Martin R. Rush, a pioneer in the field of cytology, the branch of biology dealing with the structure, function,.pathology and life history of cells, died Tuesday of a heart attack at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 67 years old and lived in Red Bank.

title: Pennsylvania Backs Wheeling Steel Loan
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 14 (UPI) The Pennsylvania Industrial Development Authority board voted unanimously today to reaffirm its Jan. 29 approval of a crucial $10 million lowin serest loan to the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Editor of HBomb Article Says U.S. Acts to Stifle Press
description: MADISON, Wis., March 14  The editor of The Progressive magazine today accused the Department of Justice of having made a sweeping attack on the First Amendment rights of the American people. .

title: Asia Parley Approves Cooperation in Search For Mineral Resources
description: MANILA, March 14  The Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific approved a resolution today defining areas of cooperation in searching for oil and other mineral resources.

title: Violinists: Zukerman And Perlman Team Up.
description: THE stage and auditorium of Carnegie Hall were packed last night to hear Itzhak Perlman and Pinchas. Zukerman in duoviolin recital. The audience was obviously there to get its share of thrills from a display of virtuosity by two of the best young violinists around. This they got, but there was a handsome byproduct involved: the chance to hear music that rarely turns upin the concert hall and, when it does, is played by adventurous but less-than-expert performers.

title: Stock Is Offered In Federal Express
description: A public offering of about 1.3 shares of common stock of the Federal Express Corporation at $25.25 a sharp was announced by an underwriting group managed by Kidder, Peabody & Company; Merrill Lynch, White Weld Capital Markets Group, and the New Court Securities Corporation.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Penalty Helps Alligood Win U.S. Biathlon Crown
description: OLYMPIC VALLEY, Calif., March 14 (AP)  Ken Alligood of Anchorage, Alaska, won the national 20kilometer biathlon championship today when Glenn Jobe of Kirkwood, Calif., was penalized four minutes for shooting at another competitor's target in the rifle phase of the crosscountry ski event

title: Sights and Sounds Of Ceramics
description: WE have all seen clay flowerpots are clay  and we have all touched clay porcelain dishes are clay. But Martha Holt's Clay Prep-Orations allows us to listen to clay as we sit enclosed on three sides by 50pound bags of clay while a tape plays the sounds of a ceramic artist at work.

title: The Painted Wall: Architecture Comes Indoors
description: WHEN we moved in here just after ive were married, was clear that we were in a little corner of some past grandeur, explained Nancy Blac kwood, a freelance curator, referring to the fourand a-half-room apartment in the landmark building that she shares with Michael Blackwood, a documentary film maker.

title: Lost $200,000 Violin Returned to Schneider
description: The Gliarnerius violin valued at $200,000 that the violinistconductor Alexander Schneider left in a New York City taxicab last month was returned to him yesterday by a trumpet player and a singer from Detroit who found it when they hailed the same taxi on.fhe day it was lost.

title: Tribunal Interrogates Former Iran Premier, Key Adviser of Shah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 14  Former Prime Minister Amir Abbas Hoveida, for 13 years the righthand man of the Shah, is being interrogated by a secret revolutionary tribunal here.

title: Home Beat
description: IT all started about three years ago when Nancy Wykstra, above, wanted an allcotton mattress but couldn't find one. Someone told her about the futon traditional Oriental mattress, made up of layers of cotton batting and covered with a cotton fabric. She made one for herself, then started making them other people and was asked to teach a course in futonmaking at New York's East West Center for Holistic Health. Now the 31-year-old Miss Wykstra, who grew up Michigan and learned to sew from her mother, is making more futons in a loft lower Manhattan. She sews them herself, using allcotton batting for the mattress filling, and unbleached muslin for the cover. Japanese futons are different from Chinese ones, Miss Wykstra explained., The Japanese ones are thin and matlike, while the Chinese ones are more like our mattresses. She will make futons in either thickness. Although they are heavy, she said, the futons fold easily, are good for bad backs and can be rolled un and used as guest beds or couches. To order r a naturalfiber futon, telephone Miss Wykstra at 799 5383; when your mattress is ready, she will call you back and you will have to arrange to pick it up yourself. But remember that even the thinner Japanesetype futons weigh approximately 20 pounds each; the thicker Chinese ones weigh between 50 and 60 pounds apiece, so don't expect to be able to pick one up and take it home with you on the subway. Depending on their thicknesses, twinsized futons are $55 or $50 each, doubles are $65 or $60, and the queensized ones are $75 or $70. Miss Wykstra also makes the small, crackly traditional Oriental buckwheat hull pillows for $11.

The airport, 40 miles from Tokyo, opened last May after 12 years of sporadic protests and fighting between radicals and riot police.

title: Hers
description: HOW hard it is to get a fix on certain people. I say X is a prince; others say he's a swine. Some feel Y is rude; others find her agreeable. So who is right? Sometimes, I recently decided, we're all right. What we're respond- ing to is the phenomenon of selective niceness: Since many people dispense niceness with discrimination, our perception of them is likely to depend on whether or not we've been the recipient of it. These discriminating individuals assume they have at their disposal a limited quantity of niceness which, if not husbanded, becomes depleted, like other natural resources, such as oil or gas. So they allocate it frugally a dollop here, a smidgen there  assessing where it will get results.

title: Education Could Pay

The best estimates are that when the new tests are put into use in 1981, some 10 percent of the seniors in New York City will fail: Beyond that, there is concern that marginal students will assume that they will not be able to earn a diploma and will drop out of school, thus being sentenced to lifelong poverty.

title: Subtracting From Reactor Safety
description: The dramatic order that five large nuclear reactors be shut off within 48 hours obviously raises new doubts about the safety of these complex power plants. It is the second blow of the year to public confidence reactors. In January, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission repudiated the conclusions of a major study that found the likelihood of an accident to be extremely remote; reactors were not thereby condemned as dangerous but they were deprived of a theoretical certification of safety. Now the commission has been forced to question the safety of five plants operating along the East Coast. This episode adds ground for concern but, oddly, for some confidence, too.

title: Bonn Said to Plan Release of Accused War Criminals
description: BONN, March 14  The prosecution in West Germany's last major concentration camp trial will recommend the acquittal next week of four former Nazi SS guards accused of participating in the murder of 250,000 Jews, an authoritative court source reported today.

title: A WEARY PRESIDENT THANKS LEGISLATORS
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  Weary after six days of shuttle diplomacy, President Carter expressed deep gratitude late today to a group of Democratic and Republican members of Congress for their bipartisan support during his peace mission to Egypt and Israel.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Skaggs Companies, the large drugstore and food chain, announced yesterday an agreement in principle for the takeover of the American Stores Company, operator of Acme supermarkets, for $58 a share, or V09 million in cash and stock.

title: Guitar: jumez Plays Contemporaries
description: jEAN PIERRE JUMEZ is French guitarist with a passion for enlarging and publicizing the contemporary repertory of the instrument he plays so well. So it was that in the recital he gave at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night under the sponsorship of Savarez Strings he played only 20thcentury music, most  perhaps all  of it composed within the last quarter of a century.

title: Energy Issues Up in Quiet Day
description: Takeover situations and the domestic energy sector provided some of Wall Street's best performers yesterday, while the stock market in general retreated slightly after its recent sharp advance.

title: Mobil Oil Said to Prepare Offer for General Crude
description: A threeway bidding war over valuable oil holdings of the International Paper Company appears to be developing, with the Mobil Oil Corporation actively preparing to make a bid for the General Crude Oil Company, industry sources said yesterday.

title: U.S. Is Investizating Alleged Embezzlement at NBC
description: Federal prosecutors in New York City and Washington are investigating allegations that expenseaccount managers of NBC embezzled large sums from the network over a period of years.

title: Brazil Chief Takes Office Today
description: BRASILIA, March 14 (Reuters)Gen. JoAo Baptista Flgueiredo will be sworn in tomorrow as Brazil's President, raising hopes of a new democratic era. The former intelligence chief has pledged to continue the cautious political reforms introduced by his predecessor, Ernesto Geisel, and ease the way for a return of democratic institutions.

title: EARNINGS
description: Favorable foreign currency translations and strong performances in most of its businesses lifted profits of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation by 49 percent in the fourth quarter and 17.4 percent for all of last year, the company reported yesterday. Sales and earnings for both periods were described as records.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 14, 1979

description: IT has been downhill for the Celts for at least 2,500 years. Once upon a time we talked to trees and birds. We wore beards and antlers. We forged iron. We threw salt over our shoulders. We kissed under

description: BEVERLY HILLS. CAL

title: Italian Skier, Still in Coma, Shows Signs of Responding
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., March 14 (UPI) - Leonardo David, Italian downhill skier, may be moved tomorrow from the intensivecare unit at the Vermont Medical Center Hospital, according to Dr. Henry Sclunidek.

title: Notes on People
description: He was a very eccentric, but harmless man, I thought, but it now appears he really wasn't my friend, and it took his murder to reveal this to me, Tennessee Williams said yesterday. He was referring to Frank Fontis, manager of a small museum in Key West, Fla., who until he was shot three times in the head Jan. 5, was the caretaker of Mr. Williams's Duncan Street home. When Mr. Fontis's safe was opened bylis executor, it was found to be stuffed with interesting items that Mr. Williams maintains are his property and wants returner!

title: Greatest Pair of Hands
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Mara 14  The greatest pair of hands in the New York Yankee training camp belong to a newcomer who isn't even listed on the roster.

title: Violent Klan Group Gaining Members
description: ATLANTA, March 14  Amid a campaign of professed nonviolence by most Ku Klux Klan leaders, one major Klan group has taken a pronounced turn toward armed defiance, publicly brandishing sawedoff shotguns and submachine guns, harassing and beating activist blacks and intimidating public officials.

title: Chinese Plane's Crash Is Said to Have Killed Around 200 in Peking
description: PEKING, Thursday, March 15 large Chinese plane, evidently on a military training flight, crashed into a residential and factory district in northwest Peking early yesterday, killing all 12 passengers believed to have been aboard and as many as 200 people working in a prefabrication plant.

title: Mount Vernon Five Gains In Regional Tournament
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 19 Mount Vernon defeated Uniondale, 7258, tonight in a semifinal game of the New York State regional Class AAA scholastic basketball tournament at Nassau Community College.

title: Consumers Rush to Buy PeakRate Certificates
description: There was something of a flurry yesterday in moneymarket certificates as customers rushed to savings institutions to buy the last ones permitted under old rules, allowing higher interest rates.

title: U.S. Duo Takes World Skate Crown
description: VIENNA, March 14 (AP)  Tai Babilonia and Randy Gardner of Los Angeles became world pairs champions in figure skating tonight, the first Americans to win the title in 29 years.

title: Reasons for Exchange
description: TEL AVIV, March 14  There was speculation here today that the exchange of prisoners in Geneva might be a response to a request by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt for an Israeli gesture of good will in connection with the negotiations for a peace treaty, but officials said the timing was merely a coincidence.

title: Letter. On Sugar Price Supports
description: To the Editor:

title: Uniroyal Sells Plant
description: NAUGATUCK, Conn., March 14 (AP)  Uniroyal Inc. announced the sale today of its former fooimear manufacturing facilities to Equities Holding, an industrial development group in Stamford.

title: Two Legal Aid Officials Nominated as Judges
description: Two officials of the Legal Aid Society were among seven persons whom Mayor Koch said yesterday he intended to name to terms of up to 10 years on the Family and Criminal Courts.

title: TeenAgers Without a Future
description: If ever a problem has earned the adjective intractable, it is the chronic unemployment of teenage blacks.. In good times and bad, their jobless rate has been frozen at many times the rate of total unemployment and more than twice that of young whites. More- over, the rates have risen despite increasing Federal spending on youth job programs. As our colleagues reported in a series of articles in The Times this week, the explanations for the phenomenon are legion, but the remedies are elusive. Yet far more is known about training and employing teenagers than the nation's grim record suggests. The problem is how to apply this knowledge.

title: Hayes Admits Guilt on Drugs
description: DALLAS, March 14 (AP)  Bob Hayes, an Olympic gold medal Vi kfa.e.; in track and former allPro wide receiver for the Dallas Cowboys, pleaded guilty to narcotics charges today in state court here.

title: Illegal Trash Builds MileLong Ridge in
description: Somewhere in the city, in the middle of the night, a large green private garbage truck hisses to a stop at the edge of a vacant lot. With a whirring whine of the hydraulic system, the back opens and 10 tons of mixed garbage spills out.

title: Gilbert Kanter, 62, Lawyer, Dies; Headed Jewish Groups in Queens
description: Gilbert Kanter, a lawyer, died Thesday of cancer at Long Island Jewish Hital. He was 62 years old and lived in Flus Oueens.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Chicago Bridge & Iron Company, Oak Brook, Ill.based worldwide builder of metal plate structures and related systems, has formed a wholly owned marine construction subsidiary, SeaCon Services Inc., and named D.M. Herring its president.

title: Scouting Mission Looms for Martin
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 14  Billy Martin, the former and possible future manager of the Yankees, will leave here in a day or two on a threeweek scouting mission to Arizona.

title: Ballet: Bjart Wayfarer
description: DISCONCERTINGLY often, Maurice Bejart can seem merely pretentious choreographer. Yet just as one is ready to dismiss him as a choreographic windbag, he can turn surprisingly eloouent.

title: Atomic Closing to Lift Oil Use
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)  The unexpected shutdown of five East Coast atomic power plants will raise United States oil demand at least 100,000 barrels a day, pushing the nation closer to serious shortages and to mandatory conservation, Energy Department officials said today.

title: Music: Parnassian Ives
description: WITH its raucous dissonances, gritty humor and disjointed rhythms, Charles Ives's Second Sonata for Violin and Piano was ahead of its time when it was finished in 1910.

title: HOUSE BACKS A RISE IN DEBT LIMIT OF U.S. AFTER BUDGET FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  The House of Representatives approved another rise in the public debt limit today, but only after narrowly beating back a strong challenge from increasingly confident supporters of a balanced budget.

title: WASHINGTON Footnote To History
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  The Carter Administration is naturally pleased with the outcome of the President's mission to the Middle East, and is now pressing its diplomatic momentum abroad and its political advantage at home.

title: Approaches to the Problem Of Jobs for Young Blacks
description: The unemployed young man took drag on a joint, then passed it to a friend as he looked out from the roof of a tall building in northern Harlem down across the valley to the east and the broad Harlem plain to the south, down past mid- town, toward the World Trade Center and beyond.

title: United Press International
description: SEAL HUNT GOES ON IN CANADA: In St. Anthony, Newfoundland, hunters hauled a bundle of 50 seal skins back to their ship after the morning hunt on Wednesday.

title: To Fuel Investment in Business
description: WASHINGTON  In 1940, Frank Perdue joined his father's chicken business on Maryland's Eastern Shore. They had one employee but many good ideas and a lot of drive. Today, that family operation employs 3,800 people and markets millions of tender chickens. But Frank says that if he were starting out in business now, he'd never make it: A fledgling operation stalls before it can shift out of first near.

title: A Step Toward Parity on Garment Alterations
description: Unisex is altering the economics of men's and women's clothing.

title: Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk

title: Rumsfeld's Remedy for Searle
description: CHICAGO, March 15  Donald Rumsfeld is out of politics and into the healthcare business these days and he thinks he has found a cure for a nagging corporate ailment  in this case a lingering bout of indigestion at G.D. Searle & Company.

title: Search Goes On at Peking Plant For Those Killed in Jet Crash
description: TOKYO, March 15 (AP)  Soldiers in Peking continued searching today for victims of a plane crash yesterday that killed about 200 people, most of them workers in a factory struck by the Britishbuilt Trident jet transport. Western diplomats in the Chinese capital reported.

title: Art People
description: Within displays favorite photos.

title: ISRAELIS KILL TWO IN WEST BANK CLASH
description: JERUSALEM, March 15  Israeli se.curity forces and armed Jewish settlers fired upon rockthrowing Arab demonstrators on the Israelioccupied West Bank today, killing two Arabs, one of them a teenage girl.

title: Full Inquiry Set In City's Action On Bus Shelters
description: Stanley N. Lupkin, the City Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday that he would carry out a fullscale investigation of all the events leading to the Board of Estimate's decision to grant the city's busshelter franchise to Convenience and Safety Inc_

title: United Airlines Employees Reject Pact and Set Deadline for Strike
description: CHICAGO, March 15 (AP)  Mechanics, ground crewmen and other employees of United Airlines rejected a contract offer today and set a strike deadline that could shutdown the nation's largest domestic air carrier.

title: Homecoming for a Yankee Fan
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  When Paul Mirabella was pitching for the Texas Rangers last year, he and Diane Polizzi chose Oct. 24. 1979, as their wedding date. Then he was traded to the Yankees, so they postponed the ceremony a month.

title: About Real Estate
description: As the inventory of residential properties that the city takes over for nampayment of taxes grows and grows, the longterm questions remain unanswered but grow more pressing: How can they be managed? Who will pay the bill?

title: Muscling In on Yemen
description: The American game now in the Middle East is to make Saudi Arabia at least a silent partner in the budding alliance of Egypt, Israel and the United States.

title: Munch Show At the Modern Is a Small Gem
description: THERE are two things to be said straightaway about the exhibition called The Masterworks of Edvard Munch, which opened yesterday at the Museum Modern Art. The first is, it is an excellent small exhibition that affords an unusual opportunity to see some the greatest paintings ever produced by one of the masters of modern art in Europe. The second is, it is not the show called Edvard Munch: Symbols and Images, recently seen at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: New Miss Marker's Small Town Girl
description: A 6-year-old girl from Helotes, Tex. tpopulation 25), who has never acted in her life, has been chosen from 5,000 girls throughout the country to play the title role in a remake of Little Miss Marker, the 1939 movie that made Shirley Temple America's darling.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation, Mountain View, Calif., has elected Edward H. Browder and Andrew A. Procassini corporate vice presidents.

title: Market Up As Energy Issues Star
description: Oil and gas stocks moved higher yesterday as the undisputed current stars of Wall Street, outdistancing such other recent favorites as the glamours and the gambling issues.

title: The Pop Life
description: `Nicolette, a first album from the West.

title: A Calypso Rhythm On the Piano Keys
description: The rhythmic lilt of Monty Alexander's speech is a ready identification of his home in Kingston, Jamaica. But until recently, his origins were not as evident in his piano playing, even though he started out as a prodigious recorder of Jamaica ska, the music that preceded reggae in the Caribbean.

title: Japan's Trade Back in Surplus
description: TOKYO, March 15 (AP)  Japan posted a trade surplus of $375.6 million last month, compared with a deficit of $1.4 billion in January and a surplus of $1.6 billion in February 1978, the Finance Ministry announced today in a preliminary report.

title: Spring Tour by Rock Stars Planned to Begin April 24
description: A tour of rock stars featuring an ad hoc group called the Barbarians may take place this spring, although spokes. men close to the musicians involved say nothing final has been determined.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bond Traders Marking Time
description: The credit markets moved very little yesterday, and trading activity dwindled nearly to a standstill as bond traders and their customers found little new in the continuing debate about the strength of the economy and the latest nuances of monetary policy.

title: Connecticut Banks Fight Out-of-State Incursion
description: HARTFORD, March 15  Connecticut commercial bankers, concerned about competition from big New York City banks, have initiated a strong effort in the legislature to stop the incursion of nonbank subsidiaries of large out-of-state bank holding companies with activities ranging from leasing equipment to secondmortgage loans.

title: Marooned in Alaska Cold: 4 Who Lost Hope Return
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, March 15 (AP) Their boots lost and with only a few apples and onions and some Tang breakfast drink, a man and his three teenage children survived in subfreezing temperatures for more than a month after their sailboat ran aground on an island.

title: Citibank Lifting Checking Fees
description: Effective May 1, Citibank will raise the monthly fee on its special checking accounts by 50 cents to $1.25 and the percheck fee by 5 cents to 20 cents, the bank announced yesterday.

title: Stein Urges Dropping HomeRelief Program To Save $286 Million
description: Andrew J. Stein, the Manhattan Borough President, yesterday urged the abolition of the home relief category of public assistance, covering more than 125,000 people in New York State and costing $286 million a year in state and local funds.

title: One Man Is Killed When Derelict, Deaf Group Clash in Subway Train
description: A 63-year-old derelict whose only home is the New York City subway system was arrested on a Queens train early yesterday morning after he drew a hunting knife and fatally stabbed a severely handicapped passenger. However, the circumstances are so sharply in dispute that the District Attorney refused to render a judgment and referred the case to a grand jury.

title: Jersey to Open Courtrooms to TV
description: TRENTON, March 15  The State Supreme Court today agreed to open New Jersey courtrooms to teevision, radio and stillphotographers on an experimental basis. beeinninp May 1.

title: DR. RALPH EMERSON
description: Dr. Ralph Emerson, Distinguished Professor of Botany at the University of California at Berkeley, died Monday at Kaiser Permanenti Hospital in Oakland, Calif. He was 66 years old and a resident of Berkeley.

title: Mobil Confirms MergerBid Plan
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation, confirming reports that it was planning to make a multimilliondollar offer to purchase the General Crude Oil Company, announced yesterday that it was studying the situation but has made no decision when to proceed.

title: City Will Spend Million a Week On Pupils'
description: Frank J. Macchiarola, the New York City Schools Chancellor, plans to spend about $1 million a week for taxis to transport to school thousands of handicapped children stranded by a wildcat bus drivers strike.

title: Concert: Musica Sacra
description: ON paper  even with some curious scramblings of plans  the Musica Sacra concert Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall (which was broadcast live on WNYC), should have been a magical experience. In reality, it was a fine concert, but not quite magical.

description: Both leading money supply indicators, M1 and M2, showed hefty increases in the week ended March 7, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

description: Child proteges down from Boston.

title: Celebrating St. Patrickand His Cathedral
description: AS if anyone needed another reason for good cheer on St. Patrick's Day, the celebration this weekend will be doubled. The Fifth Avenue parade will be stepping off at noon tomorrow, rich with 193 marching bands from 10 states, sprinkled with highstepping girls and anxious to maintain its reputation as the grandest parade anywhere. But there is a secona ceienration going on, too, MU Ulat can found in the domed cathedral that was named for Patrick, the patron saint of the Irish.

description: The first pleadings in the cases of alleged embezzlement by expenseaccount managers at NBC are expected in a matter of days, according to sources close to the continuing investigation.

title: Congressional Move Challenges Panama Canal Treaties on Cost ,
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  Congressional opponentg of the Panama Canal treaties accused the Administration today of concealing the costs of carrying out the basic pact and demanded that President Carter take back the ratification documents that he deposited in Panama last June.

description: A series of science workshops for children will be held tomorrow and the next three Saturdays at the Hall of Science in Flushing MeadowsCorona Park, Queens.

description: The Department of Commerce plans to intensify its efforts to attract more United States apparel and textile manufacturers to the world export market, a department official said yesterday.

title: Art: Sculptural Trips  Into Built
description: AMORE than faintly discernible trend in sculpture today is what might be called architectural fantasy, a predilection for built forms and environments, sometimes whimsical in their expression, that refer to other than purely sculptural ideas.

Passman, the former Representative, $98,000 in 1973. The Government contends this was a bribe to influence Mr. Passman to help Mr. Park retain his job as sole agent for U.S. rice sales to South Korea. Mr. Park testified for the third day in the trial of Mr.

title: Music: Renaissance Jazz
description: AS everybody must know by now, jazz began as an improvisatory way of making music and, although much of it is now planned in advance and written out like any other music, there is still considerable leeway for improvisation. But the concept of improvisation did not originate with jazz musicians. It has always been a factor in musicmaking of all degrees of sophistication  a must in most if not all of the Oriental musics and in primitive and folkmusic performance, and an option in composed music of the Western world of at least the last six centuries or so.

title: Pentagon Weapons Data Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  Despite law requiring accurate reports to Congress on results of tests on new weapons, the Defense Department continues to provide inaccurate, sometimes misleading reports that have led to the purchase of flawed weapons systems, according to partly classified report by the General Accounting Office.

title: Screen: 'East End Hustle':Prostitutes Redeemed
description: "EAST End Hustle," which opens today at the Liberty Theater, looks like an attempt by some talented young Canadian film makers to break into the market for exploitation films. The movie, about a group of pretty, young Montreal prostitutes who try to escape their pimp, features a lot of rather gratuitous but tame nudity, some violence and, ultimately, a not very persuasive redemption.More interesting than the film are the people who made it. Frank Vitale, who produced and directed it, was represented in New York several years ago by the far more ambitious "Montreal Main." He was also the cameraman for "Rubber Gun," the funny, nervy melodrama about a group of Montreal dropouts that was shown in New York last year. Allan Moyle, the director of "Rubber Gun," appears in "East End Hustle" and wrote the screenplay with Mr. Vitale and Steve Lack, who was the flamboyant star of "Rubber Gun." They're all capable of much better things.

title: Face of the City Stares Out in 130 Years of Photos
description: The Museum of the City of New York, that treasuretrove of colorful city memories, began collecting photographs of New York and its faces and preoccupations more than a half-century ago. It now has a quartermillion original prints and negatives, many of which have not been seen since the early 1950's. This weekend, New Yorkers have a rare chance to study 200 black-and-white photographs from the collection, including two daguerreotypes, that cover 130 years of city history, in New York Seen, a new exhibition in the museum's new photo galleries.

title: Price Guideline Tightened
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  The Carter Administration tightened its price standard today in a manner calculated to force some companies to defer part of the price increases they had announced for spring.

title: TV Weekend
description: AHONG the more prominent of this weekend's offerings are two new television movies. both on ABC. Tonight's, at 9, is called The Cracker Factory. Sunday's, also at 9, is The Jericho Mile.

description: Morning

title: Jewish Rep Stages Loyalties,
description: The Saturday curtain at the Jewish Repertory Theater was 15 minutes late because 90 members of a Brooklyn chapter of the Orthodox Jewish group Mizrachi couldn't start out on the trek to East 14th Street until the sun went down. When they finally settled into their seats in the Milton Weill Audi- torium at the EmanuEl Midtown Y.M.Y.W.H.A., the play was not, as one might perhaps have thought, a Yiddish classic, but a revival of Loyalties, a drama about the British upper crust by John Galsworthy.

title: On CatcherRich Yankees, Munson Still King
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 15  Three months ago, the New York Yankees were so worried about their catching that they asked Fran Healy, one of their radio broadcasters, if he could eet into Shane.

description: Tom Goldstein

title: Net Outlook For CBS A Surprise
description: The announcement that CBS Inc.'s firstquarter earnings are expected to be down as much as 50 percent took much of Wall Street by surprise  not because earnings are likely to be lower, but because they are likely to be dorm by much more than the company had nrevinuslv sue2ested.

title: Baker, to Show Leadership, Plans to Keep Senate Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. will not give up his minority leader's post in the foreseeable future, even though he is expected to formally announce his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination by July, the Senator's new campaign chairman said today.

title: Off Off Broadway Gdzeteer
description: Camille: One Shendan Square Theater. at Barrow Street (between Washington Place and West Fourth Street (260 7137). Show times: Tonight, tomorrow and Sunday, 8 P.M. Tickets: S5, S7 and $10.

title: Dayan Predicts a Key Role for U.S. In Negotiating Palestinian Solution
description: JERUSALEM, March 15  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan predicted today that the United States would take an active role in negotiation to establish Palestinian autonomy on the West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip, and would then seek to draw Jordan, and later Syria, into a comprehensive peace agreement.

title: BUDGET OFFICE SEES RISE IN U.S. OUTLAYS
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  Driven in part by events in the Middle East, the Government's spending this year and next year will be higher than the sums forecast by President Carter in his January budget, the Administration said today.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 15 (AP)  Rhodesian warplanes bombed a black nationalist guerrilla arms dump in Mozambique in the second strike across Rhodesia's eastern border this week, the military command announced today.

title: Detroit Hands Knicks 7th Straight Road Loss
description: PONTIAC, Mich., March 15 (AP)The Detroit Pistons dissipated a big lead early then rallied behind Bob Lanier's 13 points in the fourth quarter to defeat the New York Knicks, 8883, in National Basketball Association action tonight at the Pontiac Silverdome.

title: CARTER AIDES TO FLY TO ARAB LANDS IN BID FOR TREATY SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  President Carter is sending a highlevel delegation to Saudi Arabia and Jordan to seek their support of the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty and to try to discourage Arab action against Egypt for agreeing to sign the pact.
