title: Doctors Instruct Begin To Stay in Bed for Flu
description: JERUSALEM, March 15 (Reuters) Prime Minister Menachem Begin's doctors have ordered him to stay in bed for a few days because of influenza, his spokesman said today.

title: U.S. Suing Citibank
description: The Federal Government filed three lawsuits against Citibank yesterday in a complex dispute concerning $18.5 million in contracts to construct public buildings. The suits are seeking $3 million in damages.

title: IN THE NATION Statehouse Fever
description: ATLANTA Gov. George Eusbec is sitting pretty. Owing to constitutional reform, he's the first Georgia governor in modern times to have a second fouryear term. His $2.7billion budget will be balanced and largely unchanged by the Legislature. The state has a surplus in the Treasury, the percent sales tax hasn't been raised since 1949 and there's no taxcutting drive to upset state priorities.

title: Publishing: A New Leaf For Small Press Fair
description: THE New York Book Fair, the annual meeting ground for small press publishers here and abroad that has provided New York with a lively series of gatherings in the last five years, has postponed its 1979 autumn fair until next spring. The postponement will give the fair people extra time to plan.

title: The Region
description: Two men allegedly involved in series of kidnappings, robbery and auto theft in New York City, New Jersey and two suburban New York counties are being sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the police in both states.

title: Alabama, PurdueWin, Reach N.I.T. Semifinal
description: HOUSTON, March 15 (AP)  Alabama overcame a 17point deficit and defeated Texas A & M., 7268, tonight. Reggie King's timely baskets and the clutch play of Eddie Phillips helped the Crimson Tide gain the semifinals of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: An Unwelcome Alabama Guest: Radioactive Gas in Many Homes
description: ATHENS, Ala., March 14  It just mars on, the 36yearold housewife said resignedly as she pointed at the white cylinder that the Alabama Department of Public Health had installed in her tasement to determine if her new dream house concealed a radioactive nightmare.

title: Killer of Sal Mineo Is Sentenced To 10 Consecutive 5Year Terms!
description: LOS ANGELES, March 15 (AP)  A pizza deliveryman, Lionel Williams, was sentenced today to at least 50 years in prison for killing Sal Mineo, the actor, and committing 10 robberies.

description: The bestlaid plans for coping with energy problems have been bedeviled by political deadlock, administrative incompetence and bad luck. Consider:

title: Baroque Ensemble in the Village Tomorrow
description: Works by Telemann, Bach, Vivaldi, Scarlatti and Riccio will be played on Baroque instruments by the New York Baroque Ensemble tomorrow at 8 P.M. in St. Joseph's Church, Avenue of the Americas and West Fourth Street.

title: American Symphony Lives Up To Its Name
description: The American Symphony Orchestra doesn't need to justify its name, but it will do so anyway Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall with a program exclusively native in content. It was the creation of Richard Dufallo, the guest conductor, who has long been a proponent of 20thcentury music, whether it orizinated here or abroad.

title: Macy's Spendings Plans
description: R. H Macy & Company plans to spend $390 million over the next three years for opening 16 new stores, refurbishing existing stores, increasing inventory and consumer receivables not otherwise financed, paying off existing debt and paying dividends,

title: Court Delays Hearing On Call to Ban Article On Hydrogen Bombs
description: MILWAUKEE, March 15  A Federal District judge today postponed a hearing scheduled here for tomorrow on the Department of Justice's request for a preliminary injunction to prohibit The Progressive magazine from publishing an article on the hydrogen bomb.

title: A Wine List Fit for a DodinBouffant
description: FOR a new restaurant, DodinBouffant has an interesting wine list. Only two years are represented on the Bordeaux list, 1967 and 1971, with one exception, a 1964 Carruades de Lafite, the discontinued second wine of Chteau Lafite Rothschild. We had the Carruades the other rtioht and it was excellent. It is risky to offer 1964's, and DodinBouffant has to be complimented for bringing it off. The restaurant deserves a nod, too, for offering only vintages that are ready to drink. There are no 1970's, for instance. Presumably, there will be when the management thinks they are ready.

title: Art: Ben Nicholson In Sum in Brooklyn
description: THE case of Ben Nicholson, whose retrospective exhibition has just opened at the Brooklyn Museum, is one of the most remarkable in modern British art. Nicholson was born in 1894 into a family that had associations with money and power, success and high Bohemia. His father, William Nicholson, and his uncle, Tarbes Pryde, were painters who made their mark without fuss or contrivance. Their work sang in tune with the times. If Winston Churchill could have painted like William Nicholson. he would have done it ; and a whole generation of Londoners grew up in gratitude for the posters with which Pryde and Nicholson jointly (and under the name of the Beggarstaff Brothers) gave a new elegance to the notion of publicity.

description: Corinne Griffith

title: Messing Under Contract To Rochester of N.A.S.L.
description: ROCHESTER, March 15 (UPI) Shen Messing, the former New cork Cosmos goalkeeper, signed a twoyear contract with the Rochester Lancers of the North American Soccer League today.

title: Carter Campaign Unit To Use Mondale Name
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  Vice President Mondale's name will be a part of the name of President Carter's reelection committee when the group's papers are filed tomorrow with the Federal Election Commission, Evan S. Dobelle, the committee chairman, announced today.

title: Around the Nation
description: HARLAN, Ky., March 15 (AP)  One man was killed and two were injured today when shots were fired into a bus carrying about 35 nonunion miners home from work, the state police said.

title: Campaigns for Car Pools Falter in Tristate Region
description: The threat of a nationwide gasoline and fueloil shortage has prompted the Federal and local governments to step up promotion of car and van pools and other ridesharing systems of transportation. But despite their renewed commitment, officials in the New YorkNew JerseyConnecticut region ad:nit their efforts have been generally unsuccessful.

title: Brown Disputes Sohio Oil Move

It is caused by a new Federal law that aims to prevent alumni of Government from exploiting their recent positions and subordinates for private gain in private jobs. No such stampede is likely to occur and certainly Congress should not be stampeded into abandoning a worthy measure. But the law is loosely worded and could use clarification.

title: Music: Abbado Conducts Mahler's 6th
description: THE symphonies of Gustav Mahler continue to be as popular as ever, at least with conductors and probably with audiences, too or conductors wouldn't bother to keep them in their repertories. Even so, few of them tackle the Sixth Symphony, which is extraordi- narily savage in its overall aspect and not a work that is easy to like. Its power rests in none of the congenial and optimistic spirit of the more popular Mahler symphonies but in its almost demonic character and its gloomily enigmatic ending.

title: Film: Nuclear Plant Is Villain in 'China Syndrome':A Question of Ethics
description: THERE'S probably never been an era when some of the people living in it did not believe that things had gone as far as they should go. When the wheel was invented, there was someone, I'm sure, who groaned and said that now everyone could roll toward disaster just that much more quickly. Evolution is scary. Few of us like to acknowledge that we don't represent the perfect end of the process.In the atomic age, technology has been accelerating at a rate that leaves many of us exhausted, if not fearful. For someone who hasn't yet learned how to dominate a high-spirited electric typewriter, the thought of nuclear energywith its potential for good as well as for destruction  turns the imagination into a nervous heap.It's these apprehensions that are called forth by "The China Syndrome," James Bridges's smashingly effective, very stylish suspense melodrama that opens today at the Loews State 2 and other theaters."The China Syndrome," written by Mr. Bridges with Mike Gray and T.S. Cook, evokes the spectacle of the terrifying things that might happen should there be a lapse in the safety procedures at an electrical generating plant powered by nuclear energy. The time is now and the place is southern California. The film is as topical as this morning's weather report, as full of threat of hellfire as an old-fashioned Sunday sermon and as bright and shiny and new-looking as the fanciest science-fiction film.It stars Jane Fonda as a clever, ambitious television news reporter named Kimberly Wells, a woman who keeps a turtle for a pet, who doesn't let her private life take precedence over her public image and who knows she is not going to make big-time network news by doing chatty features about singing messengers. It also stars Michael Douglas as Richard Adams, Kimberly's cameraman, a 60's radical turned into a 70's skeptic, a fellow who sees conspiracies everywhere, who wants to be a part of the establishment but keeps biting the hand that would feed him.In the best role he's had in a long time, Jack Lemmon appears as Jack Godell, a key official in the nuclear-energy station where Kimberly and her television crew, on a routine story assignment, happen to witness what the public-relations man blithely calls "a routine turbine trip."On further investigation, the reporters learn that what they saw was, in fact, far from routine and was, instead, in the jargon of the trade, "a potentially costly event." In this case, "event" means a malfunctioning that could have resulted in a "meltdown"called the China syndromeleading in turn to the destruction of the plant and the creation of a radioactive cloud capable of laying waste to half of Southern California.Could this happen? I've no idea, but the film makes a compelling case based on man's not-so-rare predisposition to cut corners, to take the easy way out, to make a fast buck, to be lazy about responsibility and to be awed by the authority representing vested interests."The China Syndrome" is less about laws of physics than about public and private ethics. The film isn't only concerned with safety procedures, but also with the ethics of a certain kind of journalism that packages news that won't offend. Also, in the course of the story, both Kimberly Wells, woman reporter, and Jack Godell, who has dedicated his life to the priesthood of technology, must make decisions that have the effect of denying all they've done before.However, "The China Syndrome" doesn't keep us on the edges of our seats because it's so uplifting. Mr. Bridges, who wrote the screenplay for a fine little sci-fi film called "The Forbin Project" and most recently directed the James Dean elegy, "September 30, 1955," is a gifted and witty melodramaticist. There is suspense almost from the film's start in a television newsroom, and it builds without much letup until the finale. He has an ear for the way people talk, an eye for the pressed-plastic look of our transistorized world and sympathy for minor dishonesties that can suddenly shape the way people behave when faced with major problems.The three stars are splendid, but maybe Miss Fonda is just a bit more than that. Her performance is not that of an actress in a star's role, but that of an actress creating a character that happens to be major within the film. She keeps getting better and better."The China Syndrome," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some mildly vulgar language.

title: 11 Are Taken In by Dream Apartment
description: After a month of searching, Eric Anderson found his dream apartment, a spacious, partly furnished studio on a charming little street in Greenwich Village that rented for only $275 a month.

title: Studying With the TV On: Tuning In More Than the Basics
description: The members of Helen Kolsky's high school English class can effortlessly lift 2,000 pounds, walk on ceilings and go flying through the air  or at least that is the image they are trying to project.

title: ST. PATRICK's PARADE
description: The St. Patrick's Day Parade on Fifth Avenue will begin at noon today at 44th Street. At 86th Street the line of march will turn east, ending at Third Avenue.

title: SubwayCrime Statistics Up, Transit Agency Confirms
description: The Transit Authority acknowledged yesterday that there had been substantial and, in some categories, huge increases recently in statistics reflecting crime in New York City's sprawling subway sys tem, but it ascribed much of the rise to better crimereporting methods and con tended that a media focus on the subject had served to heighten public fears.

title: Torture of Ulster Prisoners Indicated in British Report
description: LONDON, March 16  A judicial cornmission that investigated Ncirthem Ireland's prisons concluded today that there were indications that an unspecified number of suspected terrorists there had been tortured during police questioning.

title: Congo Recognizes Cambodians
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo, March 16 (Reuters)  The Congo Government announced today that it had recognized the Hanoibacked regime in Cambodia. Congo is the fourth African country to recognize the new Phnom Penh leaders, after Angola, Ethiopia and Mozambique.

title: Writer Says ExPremier on Trial Helped Free Iranian Intellectuals
description: The release of Reza Baraheni, an Iranian poet and scholar imprisoned and tortured try the Shah's secret police, and of at least 10 other Iranian intellectuals, was made possible through the influence of former Prime Minister Amir Abbas Hoveida and his brother, formerly Iran's delegate to the United Nations, according to JerzY ltosittski, the author.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: School Bus Bids and Stakes
description: In our comment last month about New York City's school bus problem, we chided the bus drivers for outrageous acts of violence that threatened children. The drivers were seeking to block the return to competitive bidding in the awarding of bus contracts. Happily, the violence has stopped, but the use of bids is clearly more difficult than we had expected and evidently more difficult than the Board of Education expected, too.

title: SINAI PULLOUT COST PUT NEAR $4 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman of Israel told Defense Secretary Harold Brown today that the cost of withdrawing from the Sinai Peninsula would be $3.5 to $4 billion. United States officials said later it was unlikely that the Carter Administration would ask Congress for that much.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: Van Brocklin Satisfactory After a Second Operation
description: ATLANTA, March 16 (AP)  Norm Van Brocklin, former star quarterback and Atlanta Flames coach, was in satisfactory condition but remained in intensive care today after his second operation in two weeks.

title: Group Plans Challenge in Court To New York State Alimony Law
description: Sidney Siller, general counsel for the Committee for Fair Divorce and Alimony Laws, said at a news conference yesterday that his organization was planning to file suit to have sections of New York State's divorce law declared unconstitutional in light of a ruling on March 5 by the United States Supreme Court in the case of Orr v. Orr.

title: Oil Issues Lead Gains In Market
description: Profit Outlook Lures Investors

title: Warriors Turn Back Nets by 117102
description: OAKLAND, March 16 (AP)  Sonny Parker came out of a scoring slump witn 22 points, and Tom Abernethy had 2,) for the Golden State Warriors as they beat the New Jersey Nets, 117102, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Fed Lets Foreigners Buy Banks
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  The Federal Reserve Board today announced approval of the foreign takeover of three American banks, including the Marine Midland Bank of New York, in action expected to stir further controversy over foreign penetration of American business.

title: Books of The Times Falling Into Love
description: A full apprehension of the human condition would drive us mad, according to Ernest Becker. It seems to me that, in Too Far to Go, Joan and Richard Maple arrive at something similar, and it drives them to divorce.

title: A.T.&T. vs. the Regulators
description: Unlike other corporate giants, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company cannot set its own prices. It cannot dream up a new service and just go ahead and bring it out. As a regu- laced monopoly, it must plead its case for what it wants and needs before Government regulators, the people appointed as the public's guardian angels against steep phone rates and shoddy service.

title: United Press International
description: ALDO MORO REMEMBERED: Residents of Rome placing flowers at the site where Aldo Moro, former leader Italy's Christian Democrats, was kidnapped one year ago yesterday. Health Minister Tina Anselmi is second from right. Mr. Moro's body was found on May 9, 1978. Red Brigades terrorists took responsibility for the slaying.

title: Green Traditions, Old and New
description: Some St. Patrick's Day traditions have changed the past few years. The Friendly Sons qo longer gather in the Astor Hotel to celebrate on the eve of the Great Day, a lonely dish of boiled bacon and kale tucked for remembrance in the midst of a banquet starting with terrapin and ending in a blaze of pistachio ice cream.

title: New York State Bars Burning of Dirty Oil By Con Ed and Others
description: Consolidated Edison's application to burn lessexpensive but dirtier highsulfur fuel was denied yesterday after State Energy Commissioner James J. Larocca concluded that supplies of lowsulfur fuel were ample in the New York metropolitan area and looking better every day.

title: Patrick
description: BOSTONThe yellow light hurt my eyes. My cousin Margaret Kellett was standing in the doorway saying, Your mother wants you to come downstairs. At the other bed my brother Gerard was putting on his clothes.

title: Aid Rise Urged For Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (Reuters)  The Senate was urged today to more than double the Carter Administration's proposed economic aid to Turkey from $98 million to $200 million and to make it a grant instead of a loan.

title: U.S. District Judge Fixes June 4 As Date of Retrial for Rep. Flood
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)  The retrial of Representative Daniel 3. Flood, Democrat of Pennsylvania, on bribery, perjury and conspiracy charges was set for June 4 today.

title: Your Money
description: MILLIONS of people who are not covered by company pension plans can make tax-deductible contributions to individual retirement accounts, and much of the onerous paperwork that used to accompany the process has been eliminated.

title: Fertilization of a Human In Laboratory Is Backed
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  Concluding that research into laboratory fertilization and artificial implantation of human embryos can be ethically acceptable, a national advisory board took an important step today toward permitting Federal financing for such work.

title: Mondale Reschedules Trip
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (Reuters) Vice President Mondale will visit Brazil and Venezuela from Wednesday to Saturday, the White House announced today. He had been scheduled to make the trip this week to attend the presidential inagurations in both countries but postponed it to rvnain in Washington while President Carter went to Israel and Egypt.

title: 2 Women Named to U.S. Posts
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) President Carter announced today that he was nominating Patricia A. Goldman, a Republican and women's rights activist, to be a member of the National Transportation Safety Board. Miss Goldman, who lives here, would fill a term expiring Dec. 31, 1983. Mr. Carter also said he was appointing Rebecca R. Pollard of Philadelphia to the Board for International Food and Agricultural Development for threeyear term.

title: PetroCanada Takes On Exxon, Stirring Debate
description: OTTAWA, March 16  The Canadian Government's controversial oil company, PetroCanada, has been given more responsibility than ever before for obtaining secure oil supplies from abroad with only a short time until an election that could very well result in its demise.

title: Anticipating a Great Day for the Irish
description: Lifting their glasses in a toast, patrons of McCann's Bar on West 42d Street joined Bob McDonough, bartender, in an early celebration of St. Patrick's Day. About 120,000 marchers  wearing the green, of muse  are expected to take part in today's 217th annual St. Patrick's Day Parade, the oldest continuous parade in the United States.

title: Japan Regains Funds Surplus
description: TOKYO, March 16 (AP)  Japan recorded a currentaccount surplus of $300 million last month, reversing balance-of-payments deficit, which was $1.42 billion in January, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: Notes on People
description: Carey Isn't Planning Any Adirondacks Honeymoon

title: McEnroe, Stockton Triumph
description: CLEVELAND, March 16 (AP) John McEnroe beat Alvaro Betancur by 62, 61, 61 and Dick Stockton defeated Ivan Molina by 62, 63, 64 in opening singles matches to give the United States a 20 lead over Colombia in the North American zone final of the Davis Cup competition today.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: F.A.A. Announces a Plan To Strengthen Air Safety
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  The Federal Aviation Administration announced today that it would move to toughen airsafety rules by increasing fines, permitting criminal prosecution and eliminating a loophole that gives immunity to violators who turn themselves in.

title: Moscow Vetoes U. N. Peace Call For Both Vietnam and Cambodia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Mar. 16 The Soviet Union tonight vetoed a Security Council resolution calling for an end to Vietnam's armed intervention in Cambodia and China's invasion of Vietnam.

title: A Changed Santana Band Presents Its New Sound
description: Santana achieved mass popularity 10 years ago with a fresh style that combined Latin rhythms, highnote blues guitar and moody, minorkey instrumentals that build to rousing percussive climaxes. There was a raw. street feeling to the band's music then; the original Santana sounded like a rock group jamming with some conga drummers in Central Park.

title: Buddy Rich And His Band In Jazz Series
description: From year to year, Buddy Rich's band just keeps rolling along, riding on the consistent and persuasive drumming of its leader. But there are some nights when it rolls better than others. One of those nights was Thursday evening, when it gave two performances at New York University's Loeb Student Center as part of Jack Kleinsinger's Highlights in Jazz series.

title: Building Block at Mahwah
description: In its celebrated Mount Laurel decision in 1975, the New Jersey Supreme Court struck down exclusionary zoning and called on developing communities to promote adequate housing for all categories of people. The court assumed that state and Federal subsidies would enable communities to heed its mandate. Then, in 1977, the court went further. In a case from Madison Township, it said the goal could be met even without public funds and that developing communities must zone their open land to promote private housing moderate costwhat it called leastcost housing.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: John S. Morris Is Named Union College President
description: Dr. John Selwyn Morris, the 53-yearord Orovost and dean of the faculty of Colgate University, has been named president of Union College in Schenectady,

title: SCM Votes Plant Outlay
description: The SCM Corporation, the officeequipment and chemical company, announced yesterday that its board of directors had approved an outlay of more than $20 million for the next phase of construction of a chemical plant now being built near Brunswick, Ga. The plant will refine sulfate turpentine. Construction is scheduled forcompletion in December 1981'.

title: Problem for a. Seashelling Mecca: Too Many Visitors With Shovels
description: SANIBEL ISLAND, Fla.  A longtime resident of this Gulf Coast shelling mecca swears her story is true.

title: Associated Press
description: ON GUARD IN GRENADA: A supporter of the new Government patrolling St. Georges, capital of the Caribbean island where Sir Eric M. Gairy was overthrown this week. Yesterday, in a demonstration opposite the United Nations in New York, 300 people celebrated the coup and a spokesman for the new Prime Minister, Maurice Bishop, assured the crowd that everything normal at home and that elections would soon be scheduled.

title: CORRECTION
description: CORRECTION

title: Toledo Within Point Before Irish Rally L.S.U. Ousted
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 16  Those pesky little leprechauns did not come out from under theit toadstools until it was almost too late to be of any help to the Fighting Irish tonight. Maybe the Wee People felt Notre Dame would not need assistance against the University of Toledo.

title: Braila
description: ASCarelli, Beulah Lamy, Harry

title: The Don Redlich Dancers Span His Range of Concern
description: As a choreographer, Don Redlich continues on in his own offbeat wayward path. Thursday's concert by the Don Redlich Dance Company at the Kaufmann Concert Hall 'spanned the range of his concerns  a zany comedy of manners to a deeper, even lyrical, examination of the human condition.

title: World News Briefs
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 16 (AP) The Chief of Staff of Southern Yemen, Lieut. Col. Saleh Abu Bak Husseinoon, arrived from Aden for peace talks today in Sana, capital of neighboring Yemen, the official Iraqi press agency reported.

title: Amin's Ugandan Foes Set Talks For a Campaign Against Regime
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  Ugandan opponents of President Idi Amin will try next week in Tanzania to bury their dif, ferences and form a united front for a drive to bring down the Amin regime and restore democratic government, a prominent Ugandan exile said today.

title: Judge Upholds Revocation Of Kallie Knoetze's Visa
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 16 (AP)  United States District Judge Norman C. Roettger today upheld the State Department's revocation of Kallie Knoetze's visa, dealing a blow to the South African heavyweight's boxing career.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Surges 64 an Ounce; Dollar Advances Broadly
description: The price of gold surged $4 an ounce on bullion markets yesterday while the United States dollar continued to gain against major currencies in Europe and New York.

title: Syracuse Eliminated Shot by McKoy Thwarts Rutgers
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 16 The code was passed on, from Joe Lapchick to Lou Carnesecca, and it will be passed on again.

title: Concert to Memorialize City School Music Aide
description: A concert to honor the memory of Peter J. Wilhousky, former director of music for the New York City Board of Education and a wellknown choral director, will be presented at St. Patrick's Cathedral on March 25 at 2:30 P.M.

title: Deaths

title: Capital of Brazil, All Grown Up but With No Place to Go
description: BRASILIA, March 16 This is a city with more than a million people, addresses like Individual Habitation Sector South, Internal Quadrant 20, Group 9, House 4, no visible pollution, about 200,000 cars but hardly any traffic

title: ExLegislator Is Selected For Chief Justice in Jersey
description: TRENTON, March 16  Robert N. Wilentz, a 52yearold former state legislator, was nominated by Governor Byrne today to succeed Richard J. Hughes as Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court upon his mandatory retirement in August at aee 70.

title: 4 of 5 Golden Gloves Champions Keep Their Titles
description: The New York Golden Gloves, where amateur boxers throw punches and show heart in equal amounts, started slowly at Madison Square Garden last night. But the 53d annual boxing show ended with a bang.

title: Dodgers Shut Out Mets
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16  Five months after they blew a twogame lead in the World Series to the Yankees, the Los Angeles Dodgers crossed paths today with New York's other team, the Mets. And the twotime National League champions betrayed no damage to their psyche or their pitching.

title: Soviet Maneuvers Reported Near the China Border
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  Administration intelligence analysts said today that the Soviet Union was conducting largescale military maneuvers near its southern border with China.

description: Among the state regulatory agencies, one of the toughest is the Louisiana Public Service Cornmission. It has clamped on South Central Bell one of the lowest rates of return in the telephone in-

title: Inquiry at NBC Focuses on Role of Unit Managers
description: The unfolding scandal at NBCTV over alleged embezzlement and expenseaccount fraud by some executives, which has led to a grand jury investigation in Washington, has put a focus on a rarely noticed official of the networks, the unit manager.

title: Jean Monnet, 90, Architect of European Unity, Dies
description: Jean Monnet, the Frenchman widely acclaimed as the spiritual father of the European Economic Community, died yesterday at his country home west of Paris. He was 90 years old.

title: Resentment Growing in Nigeria's North, a World Away From South
description: KANO, Nigeria, March 11 Trumpets blare as a sleek silver RollsRoyce glides serenely to a halt, discharging His Highness the Emir of Kano.

title: Wajda's 'Man of Marble' Delineates Heroic Laborer:The Cast
description: Andrzej Wajda, Poland's greatest film maker, is quoted as having said that one cannot commit heroic acts if they are useless. Such an act is a tree falling in the middle of the forest where there is no one to hear. A heroic act that accomplishes nothing is as abstract as the gesture of a gymnast. This is something to keep in mind if you can possibly get to see Mr. Wajda's extraordinary 1977 film "Man of Marble," which is being shown today at 3:15 P.M. and 9 P.M. at the Hunter College Assembly Hall. "Man of Marble" is one of nine films being screened in the eight-day Wajda retrospective that will end tomorrow.In "Man of Marble," Mr. Wajda, best known here for "Kanal" (1957) and "Ashes and Diamonds" (1958), explores the course of Polish Communism from the late, paranoid 40's, before Stalin's death (1953) and the political thaw (1956) to the present, when many Communists are virtually indistinguishable from the members of the new bourgeoisie. The movie is a political epic, compassionate and as bitterly funny as a cartoon."Man of Marble" is about the attempts of a film maker, a woman with the busily self-important manner of the young fanatic, to make a documentary about a certain Mateusz Birkut, a bricklayer who, in the early days of the Communist revolution, was hailed as a national hero for his productivity feats and became as famous as any film star, only to disappear from the record books in 1952.Mr. Wajda's efforts to come to terms with Stalinism, as well as with the contradictions and lapses within subsequent Polish regimes, are even more courageous than the actions of his surrogate film maker within the film. But though Mr. Wajda's film often has the tone of satire, especially in the films-within-the-film he shows us, the sense of the movie, at least to the outsider, is that of loss, of promises broken, of great ambitions grown flabby, of dreams distorted to small purpose.This is apparently because the film, as it was released in Poland and as we are seeing it here, is missing a penultimate sequence that would have emphasized Mr. Wajda's concept of the continuing nature of the social struggle. In removing references to the workers' strike in the port of Gdansk in 1970, the Polish censors have  unintentionally, I assume  undercut and neutralized Mr. Wajda and made the movie seem far more bleak and pessimistic than he probably intended. The movie that we see is about a heroic life that failed.In form, "Man of Marble" is a mystery story as Agnieszka (Krystyna Janda), the film maker, seeks the truth about Birkut (Jerzy Radziwilowicz), whom she first gets to know through newsreels and propaganda films ("Birth of a City" and "Architects of Our Happiness") and then through interviews with his former wife, his best friend and others, friends and enemies, who knew him. Like Charles Foster Kane, Birkut always remains at one remove from the investigating reporter and from the audience.When Birkut is initially picked to be the centerpiece of a documentary designed to call attention to "the noble art of bricklaying," he is hardly more than a sweet-natured, Marxist Candide. Later, when he understands the machinations of the Stalinist system, he rebels and pays the price for his knowledge by being packed off to prison as the leader of a terrorist gang called the Gypsy Band. In fact, he had gotten drunk one night, hired a carriage and a gypsy band to serenade him, and gone to police headquarters, where he threw a brick through the front door.Unlike many of his colleagues, Birkut refuses, later, after he has been rehabilitated, to forgive and forget. He disappears in the crowd to become  in effect  the unrelenting conscience of the revolution."Man of Marble" is not, I think, a film that many revolutionary societies could tolerate. Its picture of young radicals growing into smug, self-serving middle-age is not the sort of thing that draws recruits to a cause. But Mr. Wajda is a humanist who refuses to restrict himself to the short view that sees only what is currently acceptable.Unfortunately, when "Man of Marble" is screened without its key sequence, it has the look of something unfinished  and, indeed, it now makes no sense without the help of program notes. Yet it is a big, fascinating, risky film that testifies not only to Mr. Wajda's remarkable vision, but also to the vitality of contemporary Polish life.

title: The Region
description: State Plans to Shelve NuclearPower Plan

title: Alexandre Parodi, de Gaulle Aide in Occupied France
description: PARIS, March 16  Alexandre Parodi, who was Charles de Gaulle's chief representive in Germanoccupied France, died yesterday at his home here. He was 77 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed.

title: Leonide Massine Dies
description: Leonide Massine, one of the great 20thcentury ballet choreographers and the creator of Parade and Gaiete Parisienne, died at the age of 83. Page 24.

title: Canada Retail Index Up
description: OTTAWA, March 16 (Reuters) Canada's consumer prices rose by 0.9 percent in February after a rise of 0.8 percent in January, Statistics Canada reported today. The increase over the last 12 months was 9.2 percent, compared with 8.9 percent recorded for the year ended in January, the Government agency said. Judged by the 1971 base figure of 100, the Consumer Price Index now stands at 168.9.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: OTB Panel Split On Koch's Move To Oust Director
description: The members of the Offtrack Betting Corporation were divided yesterday on what position to take regarding a move by Mayor Koch to oust Bernard Rome as the corporation's chairman.

title: Sadat Says He Wants Just One Pact Ceremony, Not
description: CAIRO, March 16  President Anwar elSadat said today that he hoped all three copies of the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty, in English, Arabic and Hebrew, would be signed at a single ceremony in Washington, omitting proposed signings in Egypt and Israel.

title: Turkey Announces Austerity Plan But Won't Devalue Currency Now
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 16 The Turkish Government disclosed tonight the first stage of what it called a comprehensive economic rescue program designed to satisfy a host of competing interest groups at home and abroad and set Turkey on the road to economic recovery.

title: Boston Symphony Moves on to Peking
description: PEKING, March 16  The Boston Symphony Orchestra arrived in Peking today on the second half of its weeklong tour of China. Three concerts here are on the agenda before the group leaves next Thesday. There will also be master classes with musicians from the Pe- king Conservatory and elsewhere. At yesterday's master classes in Shanghai, musicians were brought in from all over China. The final concert, next Monday, will include Beethoven's Fifth Symphony played by the combined forces of the Boston Symphony and the Central Philharmonic of Peking.

title: Park Testifies He Lied Repeatedly to Protect Passman
description: MONROE, La., March 16  Tongsun Park, the Government's key witness in the bribery trial of former Representative Otto E. Passman, testified today that he had lied repeatedly to Justice Department investigators in an effort to protect Mr. Passman from prosecution for his alleged role in a plan to sell surplus rice to the South Korean Government.

title: AYATOLLAH ORDERS HALT TO EXECUTIONS AND CLOSED TRIALS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 16  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered a halt today to the closed trials and summary executions that have gone unchecked here for the last month, resulting in the deaths of more than 60 men.

title: Assistance Sought for Carey Oil
description: A $500 million plan to rescue Edward M. Carey, the oil executive, from severe financial difficulties is under active negotiation, oil industry sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Report Proposes Top State Aides Get a 14% Raise
description: ALBANY, March 16  A special panel studying the question of pay increases for public officials recommended today that highranking state executives and judges be given raises of 14 percent by Oct. 1. Legislators salaries would rise 40. percent by 1983, but they would not begin receiving any of that increase until 1981.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MATTER OF TIME Remember the movie Deadline at Dawn from 1946? In this neatly suspenseful drama, a Manhattan dancehall hostess, played by Susan Hayward, and a taxi driver, Paul Lukas, race the clock to vindicate a sailor, Bill Williams, who has been framed for murder. The film drew good notices, with praise for Harold Clurman's lowkeyed direction and the scenario written by Clifford Odets, his associate in Broadway's Group Theater.

title: Justice Agency Reportedly Seeking Prosecutor for Carter Loan Inquiry
description: ATLANTA, March 16  The Department of Justice has begun seeking candidates for an appointment as a special prosecutor to conduct an investigation of bank loans provided to President Carter's family's peanut business by the Na tional Bank of Georgia, wellplaced pri- vate legal and Administration sources said today.

title: 2 REAFFIRM A 2D GUN WAS SHOT AT KENNEDY
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)  In a draft of the House assassination committee's final report, two acoustics experts stand by their assertion of a 95 percent likelihood that a second gunman fired at President Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963.

title: Swiss Couple Is Indicted in Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, March 16A Federal grand jury here has issued a 30count mail fraud indictment against a couple from Zurich, Switzerland, charging them with fraudulently obtaining more than $500,000 from the Internal Revenue Service over an eightyear period.

title: United Airlines Workers Agree to Resume Talks
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers agreed today to resume contract talks with United Airlines, thereby averting for the time being a possible strike of 18,000 United workers.

title: Kratzert Up by 1 At Doral
description: MIAMI, March 16  Alan Tapie hardly ever thinks about baseball any more, even though some of the major league teams are training nearby. Golf is his life and his livelihood, but there are times when his fantasy returns.

title: Trading Terminated In Wheat Contract
description: CHICAGO, March 16  The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, in a highly unusual action designed to prevent market manipulation, ordered termination today of trading in March wheat futures.

title: South Africa Scandal's Key Figure Is Accused of Theft of Secret Funds
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 16 Prime Minister P.W. Botha announced today that charges of theft and fraud involving secret Government funds had been brought against Eschel M. Rhoodie, the central figure in South Africa's widening influencebuying scandaL Mr. Botha said an arrest warrant for the former official would be issued.

description: An Appreciation

title: Barre Wins A Test on Steel Cut
description: PARIS, March 16The French Government's bitterly contested plans to close down nearly half the country's steel industry as part of its campaign to modernize the economy easily survived a major parliamentary assault today by the divided opposition parties.

title: Ali's $1 Million Exhibition
description: Perhaps some day, some year, or some century, ]'.7uhammad Ali actually will retire from boxing. But until then, he apparently plans to continue displaying his inimitable identity in exhibitions  a euphemism meaning for enough money, I'm always available.
