title: Brewery Plan Splits Mennonite Area
description: HARRISONBURG, Va., March 19 A plan to build a multimilliondollar brewery near here, in a richly endowed farming area of the Shenandoah Valley settled in the 18th century by Mennonites of deeply conservative and dry persuasion, has aroused a wide dispute.

title: A Little Assembly Race on S.I. Draws Big Attention
description: With a gaudy green St. Patrick's Day carnation in his left lapel, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan visited Borough Hall on Staten Island yesterday in support of Paul Viggiano, the Democratic nominee in next Tuesday's special election in the 62d Assembly District.

title: Superior Oil Net Drops
description: The Superior Oil Company, principally a producer of crude oil and natural gas, reported yesterday a 34.6 percent drop in net income for 1978 despite  record revenues that were 34 percent higher than the year before.Although the drop in annual earnings was the sharpest in many years, the company's stock rose 5 points yesterday to close at $361 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Patents
description: Car Phone Service Widened

title: Con Ed Ordered To Set Up a Rate For Its Big Users
description: ALBANY, March 16  The Public Service Commission ordered the Consolidated Edison Company today to prepare a new rate structure that would involve charging 224 large commercial and industrial customers more for electricity used during the day and during the summer, when electricity is more expensive to produce.

title: Issue and Debate Right of Professionals to Advertise Their Services
description: In the Middle Ages, professional people were walking advertisements. You could tell them by their clothes. Doctors, wrote Barbara Richman in A Distant Mirror, wore purple or red gowns with furred hoods, silver belts, embroidered gloves and golden spurs. Boccaccio's Doctor Simon, she recalled, went further, advertising his specialty  proctology  by having chamber over his door.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)  The NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. asked a Federal judge yesterday to hold Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, in contempt for failing to meet a court deadline in a North Carolina college desegregation case.

title: POLICEMEN TO RIDE ALL SUBWAY TRAINS ON NIGHTTIME RUNS
description: A sweeping program to combat subway crime, including the posting of police officers on all trains during evening hours and the use of shorter trains at night, was announced yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Corral Rule Irks Horse Owners on L.I.
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., March 16  The backyard barns of this affluent community on the North Shore of Long Island are under attack, particularly those belonging to horse fanciers, in the view of some of its 2,300 residents..

title: Housing And Output Show Lags
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) Construction of new homes plunged in February for the second consecutive month to the lowest level in nearly two and a half years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Bringing the Irish Together
description: DUBLIN  The political stalemate in Northern Ireland has now persisted for nearly five years, and it is a cause of grave concern to the Irish Government.

title: Appraisals Are Mixed in Yankee Bull Pen
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 16  Ken Clay and Goose Gossage, the long and the short of this season's bull pen, offered sharply different appraisals of their progress today.

title: Belgian Growth Cut Seen
description: BRUSSELS, March 16 (AP)  The Iranian revolution will probably cut Belgium's economic growth this year from 2.9 percent to 2.5 percent, according to a Chase Econometric Associates study published today by the Belgian financial daily Financieel Economische Tiid. The reasons were a drop in Iranian orders in Belgium and higher Iranian oil prices. The study included consequences of the revolution on the 13 leading industrial countries that supplied 90 percent of Iran's imports. Belgium and the Netherlands would be less affected than West Germany, France, Italy and Britain, all big exporters to Iran.

title: Hair for Spring: Keeping It Simple
description: A woman who is still bemoaning the fact that she can't manage her own hairdo is probably trying for tortured effects. Particularly the recent fling at retro hairdos: all those pompadours and puffs looking like breakfast rolls perched on the head, which only professionals could manage. Many hairdressers are already tired of them. I never really liked them, says Xavier. But designers thought they went with their clothes, so everybody did them. I think retro dresses and retro hairdos are too much.

title: U.S. Speeds Pumps for Oil Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 The Department of Energy announced today that it had begun installing temporary pumps to retrieve cmde oil from the muchcriticized and lagging strategic petroleum reserve.

title: Bridge:
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 16  The world's biggest bridge contest ended here last night in a victory for two young New York experts who now live in New England. The first Grand Na-

title: Americans
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  Fewer patents were issued to residents of the United States last year than in any other year since 1964, according to statistics in the annual report now being prepared by the Patent and Trademark Office.

title: The Yukon, Fabled Land of Brawling Men, Now Has a Woman in Charge
description: VHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, March 10  The Yukon government building here is dominated by five huge hanging tapestries depicting the many roles of women in the territory's 81 colorful years of history. The tapesroes, mace oy 10Cal women in a territorywide round robin, show a wide range of typical frontier activities, including cooking, milking, plowing, caring for children and sewing.

title: Coal Mine Strike Ended
description: INDIANA, Pa., March 16 (UPI) strike that at its peak idled more than 3,000 coal miners in three counties ended today when miners at the Rochester and Pittsburgh Coal Company's Urling mines 1, 2 and 3 returned to work. The United Mine Workers members agreed to iron out problems over wet working conditions through grievance procedures.

title: Laos Says That Chinese Troops Have Crossed Into Its Territory
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 16 Laos today broadcast a long and detailed protest against what it said were Chinese incursions and other hostile activities.

title: Military Leaves By City Workers To Be Checked
description: Investigation Is Broadened After Abuses Are Found

title: Mater Christi Retains Title
description: Raffaele Mungin sunk a foul shot with 13 seconds remaining in overtime to give Mater Christi a 6059 victory over St. Nicholas of Tolentine in the Catholic High Schoois Athletic Association championship game before a noisy capacity crowd at St. John's Alumni Hall in Queens.

title: The City
description: Acknowledging that efforts to prosecute persons who committed welfare fraud had been largely ineffective, city officials announced plans to seek more criminal indictments and other disciplinary measures, particularly against public employees who receive pay:nents to which they are not entitled.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday. March 16, 1979

title: LOUIS M. LOEB, 80; WAS TIMES COUNSEL
description: Louis M. Loeb, a former president of the City Bar Association in New York and retired general counsel for The New York Times, died yesterday in a San Diego Hospital after a heart attack. He was 80 years old.

title: Carter to Confer At Camp David On Energy Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  President Carter has summoned his key Cabinet and economic advisers to a special meeting at Camp David Monday to deal with the projected shortfall in the nation's energy supplies.

title: Tennessee and For ciham In A.I.A.W. East Final
description: COOKEVILLE, Tenn, March 16 (AP)  Kris Kirchner scored 18 points and grabbed 12 rebounds tonight to lead Maryland's Lady Terrapins past Valdosta State, 7366, in the opening game of the A.I.A.W. South regional tournament.

title: Key Rates
description: Key Rates

title: Complaints Against Police Rise
description: Complaints about the New York City police received by the Civilian Complaint Review Board jumped 21 percent last year, to 10,335, according to the. board's annual report. Most were forwarded to the Police Department's chief of opera- tions, but the board completed investigations of 3,727 cases. Of those, 960 were settled informally by the board's conciliation unit and 2,091 were ruled unsubstantiated because of a lack of evidence or noncooperating complainants.

title: Allegheny Lifts Prices of Steel
description: PITTSBURGH, March 16  The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation today announced price increases on stainless steel sheet, strip and plate.

title: Woman, 25, Arrested In Robbery of a Bank
description: A 25-year-old woman believed to be the lady bomber bank robber was taken into custody on a Bronx street yesterday and charged with last week's $6,900 robbery of a Queens Citibank branch in which railroad flares were used to simulate sticks of dynamite, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported.

title: `In Trousers Is Fantasies Of a Boy, 14
description: In Trousers is 18 songs and a few barely suggested sketches setting out the fantasies and worries of a 14-yearold boy named Marvin.

title: Man Freed in Unreported Death
description: A charge that a Queens man failed to report the death of his mothef for six months was dropped yesterday in Criminal Court at the request of the Queens District Attorney. The defendant, Robert Lesterwick, about 65 years old, was charged after the discovery of the body of Irene Lesterwick, 80, on Feb. 12.

title: Letter: On Alaskan Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 16, 1979

title: Subject of U.S. Criticism Assails Shutdown of 5 Nuclear Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  The head of the engineering company whose simple arithmetic error the Government has blamed for requiring the shutdown of five nuclear power reactors said today that the shutdown was without justification.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 43.

title: OBSERVER State With Five Sides
description: The military embodies most of the features Americans usually think of as disagreeable in the socialist state. Wages are fixed by law. Bureaucracy governs every aspect of daily life.

title: Porcelain Theft Ring Broken
description: CHICAGO, March 16 (Reuters)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had broken a steal-to-order ring that took collections of valuable Porcelain Hummel figurines. Agents recovered $60,000 woth of more than 300 of the Germanmade figurines valed at $75 to $2,700. The F.B.I. said the ringleader, Alton Sanders, 45 years old, a Chicago building contractor, was arrested on Tuesday and the police were seeking four other men who carried out the robberies for him.

title: Thomas J. Bly, Executive Editor Of Register in Shrewsbury, NJ.
description: Thomas J. Bly, executive editor of The Daily and The Sunday Register in Shrewsbury, N.J., died Thursday at the Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 61 years old and lived in Red Bank.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 16, 19711

title: City Faces Suit Over the Issue Of Bus Shelters
description: The Convenience and Safety Company announced yesterday that it would file suit to compel Mayor Koch and the Board of Estimate to divulge what went on during a closed meeting of the board last Thursday, when the future of the city's busshelter franchise was discussed.

title: Shetlands Warn On Oil Spills
description: EDINBURGH, March 16 (AP)  The authorities in the Shetland Islands are threatening to close the giant Sullom Voe oil terminal, crucial to the development of Britain's North Sea oil bonanza, after a string of oil spills that are killing rare sheep and thousands of birds.

title: American Moves Up In Skating
description: VIENNA, March 16 (AP)  Linda Fratianne of the United States led the field in the short program today and closed ground behind her chief rival, Anett Poetzsch of East Germany, in the competition for the world figure skating title.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: TORONTO, March 16 (AP)  The Hudson's Bay Company, the giant Canadian retail chain that this month became the subject of a takeover bid, said today that it recorded a 378 percent gain in profits in the year ended Jan. 31, primarily because of its sale of an oil and gas subsidiary.

title: Laurie Hathaway Is Wed in Jamaica
description: Laurie Ann Hathaway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Holmes Hathaway of Cincinnati, was married yesterday afternoon in Reading, Jamaica, to Henry Williams Sage Jr., son of Mrs. Sage of Hobe Sound, Fla., and the late Mr. Sage. Percival L. Thompson, civil registrar of marriages in Montego Bay, Jamaica, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's brotherinlaw and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Herrlinger 2d.

title: Long Island Stories
description: THE biographical notes on Everett T. Rattray are brief, announcing little more than that he has lived his life in East Hampton, with absences for attendance at Dartmouth College, the Navy and the Columbia University School of Journalism.

title: Penn Identity Mixup: It Is Not Penn State
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 17 Even this week, after the University of Pennsylvania had recorded two of its greatest basketball victories, the Quakers had been reminded of Penn's pet peeve. These are students of the oldest university in America, the home of the Wharton School, the Palestra and Smokey Joe's, and not necessarily in that order of importance. It is also the home of an Ivycovered identity crisis.

title: Consultant Fianc Of Susan E. Gibson
description: Prof. and Mrs. George Briggs Collins of Blacksburg, Va., and Bellport, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Collins's daughter, Susan Elisabeth Gibson, to Brian Winthrop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Winthrop of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Deng Indicates Early Talks
description: PEKING, March 17 (AP)  Deputy Prime Minister Deng Xiaoping indicated today that negotiations with Vietnam over the two countries disputed border could begin within a week.

title: GARDENING
description: NO GROUP of house plants can equal begonias for beauty of flower and foliage. Basically, they are shade plants, although they welcome some sun, too.

title: State to Get Major Food Center
description: SECAUCUS AMAJOR wholesale fooddistribution center for Northern New Jersey  something that Phillip Alampi, the state's Secretary of Agriculture, has dreamed of for 20 years  has been moved out of the uncertain realm of feasibility studies and into the first stages of actual planning.

title: Laurie Brown Sets Marriage for May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fred Inness Brown Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Douglas Brown, to Robert Wallace Tranchin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Tranchin of Dallas. A May wedding is planned.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: Q. I have a 1968 sixcylinder Plymouth with 140,000 miles to. its credit. Until the car is thoroughly warmed up, the transmission is reluctant to move from one speed to another. When it does shift, it does so with a thud. The transmission fluid has never been changed. Would changing the fluid at this point lead to any other problems? LILLY CLARVIT Fresh Meadows, Queens

title: Fresh Rumors on Closing Fort Dix, With Its $100 Million Yearly Payroll, Cause CorIcem
description: FORT DIX, N.J. (AP)  Conversation here about reports that the Army is considering the closing of this 62yearold military installation quickly gets down to basics..

title: STATE LOBBY OFFICE IN CITY MAY BE SHUT
description: ALBANY, March 15  The state office in New York City that oversees the regulation of lobbyists will have to close its doors under a plan worked out by legislative leaders here this week.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: With the thaw finally in, the Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts in Rosyln Harbor is resuming its Sunday nature programs today. Visiturs to the former Frick estate off Northern Boulevard will be treated to a brief photographic history of the mansion, see a 45minute multimedia presentation by Richard P. Meyer depicting the beauty and wonders of the natural environment and, then, be invited to walk  or hike  through the 175acre preserve. The free program starts at 8 P.M. 4849333.

title: Inflation's Ahead
description: From the frying pan of Middle East diplomacy, President Carter is plunging this week into the fires of inflation.

title: Interior Dept. Maps Plan To Save Barrier Islands
description: WASHINGTON, March 17  An extensive effort to protect the chain of fragile barrier islands stretching along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts from Maine to Texas has been prepared by the Department of the Interior.

title: Almost 10,000 Birds Found Dead Upstate; Cause Is Being Sought
description: Thousands of birds  estimated by some officials at nearly 10,000  have been found dead on a farm near Newburgh, N.Y., and Federal and state authorities said yesterday that the cause of the deaths was a mystery.

title: Conservative Activism Is Growing at Israel's Universities
description: JERUSALEM, March 17  It was a crisp, clear night, and the stars flickered as brightly as the lights from Jerusalem and the surrounding Arab villages when Ruth Cohen began guard duty around the Hebrew University dormitories straddling Mount Scopus.

title: State Plans to Raise Boat Owners Fees
description: Boat registration fees in New York State are expected to rise as much as 10 times the present rate as part of a planned omnibus bill to increase the state's total revenue.

title: Uncertainty Grows On Nuclear Safety
description: Advocates of nuclear power often call it a vital energy source because it could dramatically lessen the country's dependence on oil, but ambivalence inside and outside the Government has slowed its development. Several events last week seemed certain to increase the doubts.

title: Privileged Guest Tells Of Carter's Frugality
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) Vice President Mondale said in an interview released today that although he was hurt by rising prices he was privileged to pay the cost of his lunch when he dined with President Carter.

title: Mount Pleasant Faces Double SecessionTuesday
description: IT is not exactly a Proposition 13 movement, says Phillip Zegarelli, a North Tarrytown Trustee. bat the political effectiveness of another approach in the drive to cut taxes will be tested Tuesday when the voters of his village and the illage 01Pleasantville will be asked to decidi, whether they want to secede from the town of Mount Pleasant.

title: The Beneficiaries of blic Transportation
description: SIX years ago, my husband and moved out of New York City, primarily due to the poorly run, filthy and noisy subways, as well as the school system. Today, we would give our eye teeth to plop a token or 50 cents into a bus coin collector in order to reach our destination.

title: Howard Ganson 3d Weds Miss Haight
description: St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church in New York was the setting yesterda evening for the marriage of Donna Jo Haight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Bradley Haight of Tucson, Ariz., for. merly of New York, to Howard Hutchinson Ganson 3d, son of Mrs. Allen Lemmon of Downingtown, Pa., and the late Mr. Ganson Jr., a mechanical engineer of Brookings, Ore. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. Richard Sullivan.

title: SHOP TALK
description: SMITHTOWN IF you're shopping Smithtown's Main Street, the first place to stop is at Pier I Imports. It's almost impossible to make your way among the crates, shelves and piles of pillows and straw mats stacked on the floor without hearing shoppers murmur delightedly, Oh, I don't believe it they have everything here.

title: Putting Poetry Into Travel Photos
description: As the taxi makes its way up the mountain, the driver mutters about the loco Americano who wants to take pictures in the moonlight. The vehicle passes through a massive gate, and the stillness of a thousand years envelops the traveler's senses. Suddenly there is the sight of one of the great wonders of the world. Getting out of the cab, the visitor points a camera toward the towers and filigreed walls of the Alhambra, its beauty doubled by the reflecting pool beneath it. The camera records the magic moment.

title: Tapie Leads Doral by a Stroke
description: MIAMI. March 17  Alan Tapie took the lead today after three rounds of the Doral open and then divulged his strategy for winning the $15,000 first prize tomorrow.

title: Oxford Crew Beats Cambridge
description: LONDON, March 17  Disaster struck the Cambridge crew on the eve of the 150th anniversary rowing of the OxfordCambridge boat race and made today's fourth consecutive loss to Oxford almost a foregone conclusion. The Cambridge stroke, John Woodhouse, had the flu.

title: Gag Rule on Board Fans School Dispute
description: NORTHPORT THE debate over the NorthportEast Northport School Board's decision to remove William Sammond as interim principal of the high school here has raised some issues that go beyond the controversy, which has embroiled students, teachers, parents and the board for several weeks.

title: Alydar and His Friends
description: HIALEAH, Fla., March 17  Alydar was rooting in the straw in the rear corner of his stall, a shadowy figure to eyes accustomed to the morning sunlight. From out in the walking ring in front of the Calumet Farm barn. John Veitch, the trainer. called: Hey, Alydar! The colt turned immediately and thrust his head over the stall door. A wisp of straw clung to the tiny star on his forehead. Veitch brought several lumps of sugar from the tack room and Alydar munched them eagerly. John stepped back and they regarded each other, the young trainer, prematurely bald, and the 4yearold horse with ears pricked alertly.

title: Miss Urban Bride Upstate Of D.T. Hunn
description: Florence deMoss Urban, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Zeller Urban of Buffalo, was married there yesterday afternoon to David Thomas Hunn, son of Mrs. David Edward Hunn of Troy, N.Y., and the late Dr. Hunn. The ceremony was performed in Christ Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Robert G. Hetherington.

title: Prisoner Is Under House Arrest In Move to Save Funds on Coast
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 17  In an unusual effort to save tax dollars, a 48yearold nurse is serving a year's house arrest in the fatal shooting of her husband.

title: Sunday Observer
description: What people do together when they feel libidinous is of small concern to me so long as they don't have sex. Sex isn't meant to be had, and people who insist on having it ought to be taken in hand and lectured sternly.

title: Sunflowers Will Stand Out In Any Garden
description: Both showy and practical, sunflowers are versatile prima donnas in a garden plot. These flowers come up center stage no matter where planted. Children love to watch their rapid growth and neighbors appreciate the cheerful view over fence toos.

title: Bridge to the Stars
description: IN his latest novel, Arthur Clarke once again sounds his grand theme  the theme that animated his most popular novel, Childhood's End, and the classic movie he wrote with Stanley Kubrick, 2001. This theme can be stated only in the 261 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $10. form of a paradox: Man is most himself when he strives greatly, when he challenges the very laws the universe; yet man is small and the universe large, and anything he creates must, in the long run, be dwarfed by the works of others.

title: FOOD
description: UPTON SINCE 1965 there has been a lot cooking at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton: Chinese cooking, German cooking, French cooking, Indian cooking and much more. That does not necessarily mean that cooking is all science, but it does indicate that it can be an enjoyable way to spend time and make friends.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: In prose a bit too elevated for youngest readers to tackle on their own. Mr. Greenfeld provides a brief, lucid account of the ancient Jews enslavement by Pharaoh and their miraculous release, as well as an explanation of the traditional Passover celebratory meal  the seder  with its special foods and rituals. For Jewish children, and even some adults, the symbolism of the lamb shankbone, the roasted egg, the bitter herbs and the filled wine cup set out for the prophet Elijah will, at last, be perfectly clear clearer than many a standard Passover haggadah has ever made them. Elaine Grove's blackandwhite scratchboard illustrations are suitably formal and reverent  perhaps too selfconsciously so; but the whole is a commendably earnest and useful work, well worth an annual preseder review by young and old alike.

title: Faulty NuclearStorage Facility Stirs Controversy
description: Four months ago, a small hole was discovered in a catchpan that lies beneath a huge, underground steel storage tank holding more than 600,000 gallons of liquid radioactive waste in the small town of West Valley, N.Y., 30 miles southeast of Buffalo.

title: Bases in Mozambique Hit
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 17 (AP)  Rhodesian jet fighters attacked guerrilla bases in neighboring Mozambique today, the fourth such attack in a week, the military command reported.

title: Islanders Set Back Rangers, 52
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 17 You didn't have to be Irish tonight to appreciate the Irelanders, as many of the greenclad spectators at Nassau Coliseum were calling their team. After jumping off to a 50 lead, the Islanders and Chico Resell turned back most of the 41 Ranger shots to beat their New York rivals, 52.

title: WHEN NOT TO SAVE A LIFE
description: The October 1978 issue of Hospital Physician, a medical journal, presented the case of a suicide attempt by an 80yearold woman who had for two years been living in a nursing home. She suffered from glaucoma, which had almost completely blinded her, and from cancer of the colon, for which she was receiving chemotherapy. Her husband was recently dead. Under these circumstances, I regard her suicide decision as wholly rational.

title: Sports Today
description: World Series, International Race of Champions, final, at Atlanta International Raceway. (TelevisionChannel 7, 3:30 P.M.)

title: The Nation
description: A measure to increase the public debt limit by $32 billion passed the House with difficulty last week, and although the close call was not unusual, the nature of the opposition was.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: PERDIDO, by Jill Robinson. (Pocket. $2.75.) The granddaughter of one of Hollywood's founding fathers struggles to comprehend the differences between the tinsel dreams of her hometown and the vulgar realities of the 1950's. The background of this first novel is rich and authentic, its plot a 1,:. threadbare.

title: ART VIEW
description: The exhibition that Margit Rowell has organized at the Guggenheim Museum under the title of The Planar Dimension: Europe, 19121932 (through May 6) is an important event. It concentrates on one of the most decisive developments in the history of modernist art  the creation of a new form of sculpture based on planes in open space rather than on mass or volume  and gives us a definitive account of it.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IS being put on the dean's list an invasion of a student's privacy? Possibly so, according to the University of Connecticut.

title: Water in Idaho Town Threatened By Sewage Spilling From Lagoon
description: RUPERT, Idaho, March 17 (AP) State health officials have cautioned residents to boil all drinking water after wall of a treatment lagoon washed away, spilling millions of gallons of partly treated sewage over a threemile area.

title: Small and Minority Concerns May Lose Bidding Advantage
description: As part of the international horsetrading looking toward a trade agreement, the United States last week let be known that it was proposing to give foreign exporters a better chance at Federal contracts.

title: Calendars
description: Today  Fairfield County Hunt Club. Long Lots Road, Westport. Conn. Local, junior and children's working hunters; ponies, equitation. 8 A.M.

title: AS VANCE SEES IT
description: On March 6, a day before leaving for the Middle East with President Carter. Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance gave an interview to Bernard Gwertzman. Excerpts from his remarks follow:

title: Toni Allen Kramer To Be Wed June 9
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Hamilton Kramer of New York and Sands Point, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Toni Allen Kramer, to Daniele Damaso Bodini of New York. He is a son of Mrs. Franco Bodini of Rome and the late Mr. Bodini. A June 9 wedding is planned in Sands Point. miss Kramer, an alumna of Sarah Lawrence College, attended the Hewitt School. Her father is executive vice president of Allen & Company, of which her grandfather, Charles Allen, is founding partner. Her father also is on the board of Columbia Pictures Inc. and Teleprompter. Her mother, known professionally as Terry Allen Kramer Is a theatrical producer.

title: THE BOOM IN BLOOMING PLANTS
description: These days almost any plant that blooms indoors is winning new admirers. Orchids are doing it, so are tulips, narcissus, dahlias, ranunculuses, hyacinths, lilies, begonias, even zinnias, to name just a few. As surely as the crocus heralds springtime, these blooming beauties represent a new movement in decorative flora. It is the first major change in the greenhouse and flowershop business since the rise of the indoor jungle in the late 60's.

title: Screen Treatments
description: The heroine of The Idol, a violeteyed movie star with a lot of husbands, bears amazingly little resemblance to any real violeteyed movie star you might name. There are times that Alison Cooper seems familiar, to be sure: when she wins away singer Billy Hunter from his pert and cute actress wife, or when she heads for Rome to make Helen of Troy with the English actor David Osborne, whom she finds attractive  even with his pitted skin. But she's in no danger of being mistaken for anyone authentic when she speaks or thinks. Alison contemplating the 50odd carat diamond on her hand: It had a hardness she could try to emulate. Alison pondering her success: Fame, money, beauty, talent  where did they get anyone, after all? A writer who sets out to sensationalize already lively headlines can be the worst sort of scoundrel, but there's one thing he'd better not be nice. David Benjamin, author of The Idol, is an avid enough Elizabeth Taylor fan to be very, very dainty with his Alison Cooper. She's a sweet young thing when she makes her debut as a child star in that animal movie (not National Velvet, silly Bandit, the story of a raccoon). And she remains sweet until Mr. Benjamin decides that she and Osborne ought to sound, at least marginally, like characters in Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? (Alison: You have the soul of a shoeclerk! Some artist. David: What would you know about art? You've got the culture of a sewer rat!) While he is occasionally highhanded with the facts of his heroine's life, Mr. Benjamin is careful not to commit the ultimate invasion of privacy: trying to figure out what's going on in her pretty little head.

title: BANK PROFIT GUIDES EXPECTED TO BE SET
description: The Carter Administration expects to publish a special profit guideline soon for banks and other financial institutions, according to senior Administration officials.

title: Jean Monnet, 18881979
description: Before he began the most significant quartercentury of his life, at age 61, Jean Monnet had already completed many successful careers  cognac salesman, global financier, reorganizer of Chinese railroads, League of Nations executive, war production coordinator, director of French reconstruction. Then, in 1950, he devoted himself to a single idea: the unification of a fragmented Western Europe.

title: The Problem Had a Name
description: THIS painful story is written with elegant detachment and distance; yet its effect is heartrending and frightening. Even today, 50 years after the identification of the disorder known as dyslexia, millions of children are suffering the isolation and bewilderment, the fear of failure and ridicule experienced by Eileen Simpson, a gifted woman, now a psychotherapist and writer.

title: ART
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE Central Hall Gallery, in former furniture warehous, just off Main Street, is a high light of the lively art scene ii Port Washington. The gallery is a cooperative of 24 women artists of the area, and its stark white walls and generous open space adapted from commercial use are reminiscent of a SoHo showplace. The current exhibition of largescale drawings and notations by Betty Holliday is very much at home in this environment, where the interior's blackandwhite simplicity compliments the monochrome tonality of the works.

title: Transplant Donor Reform Urged
description: ATLANTA, March 17 (AP)  The case of an Idaho woman who contracted rabies and died after she received a corneal transplant has prompted the national Center for Disease Control to push for new donor standards. The victim was the first person to develop rabies from a tissue transplant, the center said. She received the transplant last October and died seven weeks later.

title: Deaths
description: Lodge No. 9,Brith AbrahamZion, is saddendby the death of its cherished mentorand Past President. Our condolence with a mourn ful heart go to hisdeor wifeMildred, our Financial Secretary, and their children. Memorial services 2:00PM, Sunday. March 18. at Parkside Chapel, Queens Blvd. 8.66 Ave., Forest Hills. L.i. Bernard Donefet. President SPOONERLeo S. Como Loyaltown and Loyallown Ladies League mourn the loss of Leo S. Spooner. devoted member of our Board, congenial personality loyal supccrter & contributor. Our heartfelt Sympaathy is extended to his dear wife and family.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Wseem to be running into an odd lot of halfplays lately. What's a halfplay? Well, it's tantalizing piece of work for which a writer has created two or more  though often only two  generally arresting characters, developed them with some honesty and/or affection, and then failed to relate them to any world larger than themselves. It's as though inspiration had galloped along while the first few portraits were being sketched, only to falter at the first knock on the door.

title: Furor Over HBomb Article Astonishes Magazine Editor
description: MADISON, Wis., March 15  Erwin Knoll, bearded and rumpled, sat behind his desk, shaking his head in puzzlement as he contemplated the furor that his small monthly magazine had stirred up.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: It is quite some time since the art of Franz Kline (191062) was considered in depth in a big metropolitan exhibition. A touring show of 92 of his works was seen at the Whitney Museum and elsewhere in 1968, but since then a whole new generation of gallerygoers has come into being. All has been quiet on other fronts. There has been no catalogue raisonne and no fat monograph. There have been no delirious prices at auction and no scandals, financial or emotional, to bring him adventitious publicity. No tyrant of taste has forced him on our attention.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS
description: GREENLAWN IT is not unusual for painters to take music as the point of departure for their compositions Kandinsky, Stuart Davis and Georgia O'Keeffe are only three of the many who have done so. It is rarer to find composers who seek inspiration in the visual arts. This is the challenge accepted by the pianistcomposer Edvard Lieber, whose recital this afternoon at the Harborfields Library will feature 24 preludes based on paintings by Willem de Kooning.

title: William Mackie Weds Annette L. Osborne
description: Annette Lamagna Osborne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Lamagna of New Providence, N.J., was married in Summit, N.J., yesterday to William A. Mackie, an executive vice president of the IngersollRand Company in Woodcliff Lake, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Robert Kelsey performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Central Presbyterian Church. lie was assisted by the ReyJohn Egan of St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Is it really five years since the death of Sol Hurok? Yes, and it is beginning to seem longer. When the Ukrainianborn impresario with the slouch hat and the silvertipped cane disappeared from our midst in March of 1974, we were left wondering who or what would take his place. Pessimists thought nobody or nothing could, or would. Given the directions in which our cultural life was heading, they said, the day of the independent, freewheeling, highprofile impresario in the arts was over It now is clear, unless someone has been hiding contradictory evidence, that these Cassandras were dead right. The future, they predicted, would be in the hands of the foundation screening committee, the endowment panel, the arts council bureaucrat and the nonprofit manager. And, true to forecasts, we have seen the emergence (if it can be called that) of a new race of cultural administrators whose ideal seems to be the faceless but powerful conglomerate executive, the technocratic type whose rise was foretold chillingly generation ago by James Burnham in The Managerial Revolution. Clearly, the species of artistic entrepreneur to which Sol Hurok belonged is either dead or gasping its last, and the day when anyone will flamboyantly risk his own money or reputation on an artist or an artistic venture almost done.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Atmospheric transport of acid aerosols, most notably sulfates and nitrates, over much of the northeastern United States is worrying those monitoring the phenomenon.

title: TV VIEW
description: Never underestimate the persistent yearning for selfrespect. Despite countless indications to the contrary, television executives, too, are human, wanting to believe desperately that their lives are not pointless, are not entirely anchored to the trivia of game shows, a Love Boat or a Flatbush. They can indeed distinguish between quality and junk, even on the level of a situationcomedy or an actionadventure show. Few people, including the more demanding of critics, would argue that television should devote itself exclusively to the uplifting of society. It would be ridiculous to underestimate the value of good entertainment: in sitcoms from I Love Lucy to All in the Family, in action formats from The Defenders to Police Story, in domestic dramas from The Waltons to Family. Only fools would argue against the presence of such programs on the schedule. On the other hand, only fools would fail to notice that such programming is becoming more rare on the schedule as the target audience becomes younger and younger. As new series are being produced more frantically than ever before, the humor becomes more sophomoric, the scenarios more predictable, the formats more tired. There is good reason for their being ripped off the air in record numbers. They are generally dreadful.

title: LAW Religion Astronomy
description: When the late Alexander Bickel argued the Pentagon Papers case for The New York Times eight years ago, he told the Supreme Court that the Constitution forbade prior restraints on the press  with a single exception. The courts could stop a publication, he said, if it would lead directly and unavoidably to a disastrous event.

Concert pianists learned to operate manual elevators. Actors sorted mail. Lawyers, professors and corporate executives carried out garbage and stood watch at the front doors of their buildings.

Few people, it seems, ever took such galleries seriously.

title: A Very Special Place

Mr. Rattray, a 12thgeneration native of the area who is publisher of The East Hampton Star, provides an informal history in The South Fork, The Land and People of Eastern Long Island, published last week by Random House (see today's Book Review, Page 11). Peter Dohanos, art director and producer for films and television, has lived in East Hampton for 24 years. These are some of the penandink illustrations he provided for The South Fork.

title: WASHINGTON

title: DINING OUT
description: FOR reasons more sociological than culinary, many ItalianAmerican restaurateurs deliberately (often erroneously) advertise their cuisine as Northern Italian, as if to suggest the heady, rich, spicy food of Campania, Sicily, Calabria and Apulia are lower in the caste system. So when one finds an Italian restaurant that cooks dishes from all over the peninsula, but takes a special pride in its Neapolitan dishes and does most them extremely well, it makes up for all the dreary Italian food one finds in restaurants with less integrity. The Terrace Club, across the street from Lord & Taylor in Scarsdale, shows that it has enormous respect for good ingredients and careful preparation.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Dr. Arthur Anderson's analysis of the Fairfield resident [A Look at God and Man in Fairfield, Feb. 4] as hostile to the new, using religion for status and exhibiting an ugly racist side, is only part of the tale. We are truly the most privileged of persons, with the largest amount of space, the best of all the New World's dreams. But, we are also realists. We see the world in real terms and notice that our life styles are becoming less rich with all the great goodies of our culture each year.

description: Singles. beware! As a reader cornplained a few weeks ago. a surcharge called a single supplement can sorely inflate vacation costs for a person traveling alone.

title: Chopping Up Women
description: SHAVE STEVENS new novel is an artistically ambitious version of a currently popular species of thriller that attempts to generate excitement by piling up female corpses. Like Jimmy Breslin's and Dick Schaap's .44, Dan Greenburg's Love Kills and Steven Whitney's Singled Out (to name a few), By Reason of Insanity features numerous scenes in which women are sexually mutilated and slowly hacked to pieces by a psychotic murderer who has a rage against women. Because By Reason of Insanity is more than 500 pages long and because Thomas Bishop, the novel's psychopath, is the most resourceful mass murderer of modern times, Mr. Stevens is able to depict considerably more hackings and stranglings than is usual in a misogynist thriller. He also spices the formula with historical personages (Caryl Chessman, Richard M. Nixon) and some hideously explicit necrophilia.

title: To Be Black And Female
description: AT the end of the 1960's, American mass media rolled the cameras away from black life and the quantity of print on the subject became too small to read. As a result, the number of books published by and about black people has been negligible 182 pp. New York:

title: Appreciating a European AvantGardist
description: In some respects, the United States has made commendable strides to escape its musical provincialism in recent decades. On the other hand, the welcome emphasis in the past few years on native composers has had a reverse effect, such that the major works of the European avantgarde are played here with surprising infrequency.

description: Elizabeth Ann Wood of New York was married yesterday to Cleon T. Knapp 3d. a Los Angeles publisher. The ceremony was performed in the Westwood United Methodist Church in West Los Angeles, Calif., by the Rev. Dr. Jerry Larsen.

description: TRADITIONALLY, the virtuoso roles of the classical ballet repertory have been uncharted territory for black dancers. But now, spurred by the accomplishments of such dancers as Arthur Mitchell, founder of the Dance Theater of Harlem, and Paul Russell, a former principal with that company, the ballet stage is broadening its spectrum.

description: GOVERNOR BYRNE has found what might be the perfect wad. to unify divergent and competing groups: Make a proposa: that no one can agree with.

title: A Builder With Nature as Partner
description: ROBERT (Sawdust) Butler is an architect and builder who treats natural materials with respect. A house is a final resting place for wood, stone and brick, Mr. Butler says, and they should be laid to rest in a noble fashion. According to Mr. Butler, each building material should undergo minimum processing and travel minimum distances from source to house. He has put this theory to work in the Lake Mahopac house that he built and lives in with his wife, Suzanne.

title: At Home: A Dog And A Family
description: THIS is a shaggy dog story. It raises certain shaggy questions about love, responsibility, guilt and the sanctity of canine and/or human life. The dog in question belonged to a couple I know. She is a concert pianist, and he is a psychotherapist. They had not planned to have a dog. In fact, their respective careers kept them so busy that they postponed having children.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: The Ars Musica Camerata and Baroque Ensemble will return to Englewood today for the second of its Bach Festival performances. Joyce Keshner will conduct the concert, which begins at 3 P.M.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: In his review of my book, A Season of Youth (Dec. 17), Leo Marx offers two major criticisms. One is that I am surely wrong about the relative impact of the Civil War and of the Revolution on the national imagination. On this matter he is as entitled to his view as I am to mine. We can agree to disagree. I only wish he had indicated that I do take this comparative question into account and deal with it quite seriously on pages 15 and 25659.

title: Louisiana VoteBuying Admitted
description: LAKE CHARLES, La., March 17 (AP)  A Leesville man has admitted paying two women $5 each to vote for Representative Claude Leach in a Congressional election won by the Louisiana Democrat by 266 votes. Federal District Judge Edwin Hunter accepted a guilty plea yesterday from Leon Madria:58 years old, to two of six counts in an indictment accusing him of buying votes in a disputed 4th Congressional District election won by Mr. Leach over Jimmy Wilson, a Republican.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE two young entrepreneurs who head Growth Enterprises have done well in renovating the inn in Chester that Zephaniah Drake built in 1810 to serve passengers traveling by stagecoach between New York and Easton. Pa. The handsome threestory brick building it is now known as The Black River & Raritan Publick House  survived into the automotive age by becoming a preparatory school and, later, a hotel whose guests included such New Jersey residents as Charles A. Lindbergh.

title: SELECTION: Nanles 44
description: LATTARULLO looked even weaker with hunger today than usual, and swayed from the waist, eyes closed, even when sitting down. After our chat I decided to take him for a meal to one of the sidestreet restaurants that have opened in the past few days.

title: Space Shuttle Test Today
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., March 17 (AP)  A test flight was planned for tomorrow to determine if the experimental glue used to repair the space shuttle Columbia will hold for the craft's crosscountry trip. The shuttle's twoday flight to its launching site at Cape Canaveral, Fla., on the back of a jumbo jet had been scheduled for March 9, but was postponed after some of the craft's protective tiles crumbled in a brief test flight.

title: And Now a Treaty for America
description: President Carter has come home triumphant with a peace treaty in his pocket. But it alone will not resolve our main Middle East problem: economic dependence on Arab oil. Now is the time  perhaps the last politically convenient time in many years  to act to reduce our consumption of foreign oil and thus gain a position of strength against the oil cartel.

title: The Democrats Succeeded Here, But Success Has Its Problems
description: AS far as elections go the Town of Brookhaven is one of the Democratic success stories in predominantly Republican Suffolk County.

description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 17 Mount Vernon defeated Central Islip, 7869, today and won the Southeastern regional AAA scholastic basketball championship at Nassau Community College. The victory was Mount Vernon's 24th against only one loss and sent the Westchester team into next week's state championships in Rochester.

title: In the Camps
description: What matters, in novels about the holocaust, is not the line between tact and fiction but the abyss that divides the genuine from the fake. The banality of evil is still with us, spurred on by sales figures and ratings; the wave of meretricious trash that brought us a televised Auschwitz in living color has not yet crested. Its cheap sentiments and mediasized ideas falsify, desecrate and pervert both the reality of what happened and our memory of it. Those with the courage to examine their wounds in pursuit of the truth face a struggle. The unspeakable resists language. Yet in the end their voices are the only ones that matter. We may choose to ignore them, but ignorance will not restore our innocence.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Forty Second Street  from Great White Way and Crossroads of the World to Porn City  a thoroughfare with as many different images as the turns in its fortunes and history. Right now, a problem street, blighting the heart of midtown, the subject of periodic cleanup campaigns and efforts Y renewal.

title: IN BRIEF
description: After the Commodities Futures Trading Commission warned that speculative squeeze threatened to disrupt the wheat futures market, The Chicago Board of Trade last week delayed openings in all wheat futures for nearly three hours, and trading in contracts for March delivery remained suspended throughout the day Friday. The Federal agency said that concentration of the bulk of the March contracts in the hands of a few large speculators created conditions for possible market manipulation.

title: Charanga Bands Perform
description: Charangas  Latin dance orchestras that feature violins, a flute, and rhythm  play a gently cooking brand of music that is just about impossible to resist, and at the festival of charangas, held at Roseland Friday night, little resistance was in evidence.

title: BOLIVIAN EXLEADER RETURNS FOR VOTING
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 17  Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez, who was ousted as President of Bolivia last year, has returned to his country and announced that he will lead a nationalist front in general elections scheduled for July 1.

title: Humanities Books for All
description: A new series of books on the humanities, aimed at nonacademic readers, will be published by W.W. Norton & Company of New York for the National Humanities Center, a private institute of advanced study in Research Triangle Park, N.C. The center has no connection with the National Endowment on the Humanities, the federal agency.

title: WouldBe Acquirers Line Up for Chance at General Crude
description: It seemed to begin as a rather routine albeit highpriced deal. At the beginning of the month, the International Paper Company announced an agreement in principle to sell its General Crude Oil Company to the Gulf Oil Corporation for $650 million. Last week, however, International Paper announced that it had dropped the tentative deal with Gulf and had concluded new agreement, also tentative, to sell the company to the Tenneco Oil Company and the Southland Royalty Company for 5705 million.

title: Notes of a Cultural Marco Polo
description: The scene sunset on Chang An Jie (Street of Perpetual Peace) in Peking, last month. Outside a movie theater, a crowd spills onto the street, halting all traffic Our guide tells us that the theater is playing a new American film, Modern Times, with Charlie Chaplin. A new film? we Degin to understand why we a group of 22 professionals in the arts and especially film under the aegis of the newlyestablished Center for United StatesPeoples Republic of China Arts Exchange of Columbia University's School of the Arts  had been invited by the Chinese to make this trip. They want help and advice in modernizing and updating their performing arts and we have come to do what we can.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Mescal Wilson made a fine impression in the debut program she played in Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday afternoon. The pianist, who hails from Dallas and has earned degrees at the University of Texas and the Juilliard School, worked her way handily through music in a variety of styles, with her technique generally equal to the heavy demands made on it.

Faroe of East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Robert Beringer performed the ceremony. The bride, an alumna of Briarcliff College, is a candidate fora master's at Rutgers University. Her husband, a research engineer with the Electro Magnetic Compatibility Analysis Center in Annapolis, Md., graduated from Princeton University.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The National Invitation Tournament semifinals move into Madison Square Garden tomorrow night with Purdue playing Alabama at 7 P.M. and Indiana meeting Ohio State at 9 P.M. The championship game is 9 P.M. Wednesday. with the consolation game at 7 P.M.

title: GARDENING
description: ADAFFODIL is a daffodil is a daffodil. The daffodils glorious parade of color will begin as soon as the ground dries out from the deluge. The small members of the species are the earliest to show their true colors and somehow they are all the more special for their diminutive size. Some early daffodils are only several inches high and the flowers are just as cunning. When they fade, it will be time for the major displays to begin.

title: The Republicans Bedeviled by the Pelham Affair
description: NO ONE is quite sure what it all means, but it is curious that at least one of the upcoming village elections not only excited local passions but gained the attentions as well of the chairmen of the county's two local parties.

title: Jill Cathryn Kreher Bride Of Dennis Joseph Mayne

Mayne of Malden, Mass. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation by the Rev. Frank Del Prete.

title: GARDENING
description: IN 1959, researchers at the University of Massachusetts shade tree laboratory spread salt over the roots of a sugar maple at a rate comparable to that anticipated in runoff water from a heavily salted road. By spring, all grasses and herbaceous plants had died, and the tree itself was dead within four years.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE is a growing trend on the Island to., ward stylish yet informal eating places where dinner is not a production, but an of fort is made to provide good food. Raisins ii Woodbury is a typical success along these lines.

title: U.S. Symphony Thrills Chinese In Peking Hall
description: PEKING, March 17  A wildly enthusistic audience headed by Deng Xiaoping, the senior Deputy Prime Minister, cheered the opening concert in Peking tonight by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Seiji Ozawa.

title: TV TALE OF TWO WRISORS
description: For seven weeks last November and December, England relived the Abdication Crisis which had amazed, moved and baffled the nation 42 years ago. Edward and Mrs. Simpson, a television series, aroused as much partisan feeling as ever, as though time had stood still and the Duke of Windsor had not been dead these seven years.

title: The Facts of a Life
description: IN the almost 20 years that have passed since he was killed, Albert Camus has been more a cult than a man. His writings have sold prodigiously, the ideas in them have been taken to mark an epoch and have circulated to the ends of the earth, even his Illustrated. 753 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $16.95. rather turgid plays have been played to mystifying acclaim. Legions respect Camus, some go further and reverence him. What he had been missing hitherto was a biographer, but now fie has that too. Herbert Lottman's life is the first to be written, either in French or in Epglish, and it is exhaustive, a labor of love and of wonderful industry. From now on we have the necessary facts of Camus's very uneven life, and the variously flattering myths that have obscured it can be laid to their rest.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: YONKERS wants Amtrak, but does Amtrak want Yonkers? That is the question Amtrak officials in Washington are asking themselves as they consider a request by Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli that the Governmentsubsidized railway system designate his city as a stop on its Empire State runs between Grand Central Terminal and upstate cities.

I have seen the truth of that saying verified over and over again. The main concern of many very remarkable people is to cut a figure and play a role.
