description: NEW DELHI, March 17  Street demonstrations  familiar, often noisy and bloody occurrences since the British moved the capital here over 65 years ago underwent a change of image this week when the city's judges took to the streets to demand higher pay.

title: On Language
description: When this column stumbled on the stage, eyes blinking at the bright lights of Sunday, a question was posed to readers: When you want somebody to call you back in a hurry, but you do not want to alarm them with fears of a medical emergency, what word do you use?

title: Anita Zito Fiancee Of G.T. Hansson
description: The engagement of Anita M. Zito to G. Thomas Hansson has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Zito of Melville, L.I. Mr. Hansson is a son of Mrs. Gunnar T. Hansson of London and the late Mr. Hansson of Darien, Conn., and Goteborg, Sweden.

title: Realty News
description: The architectural firm of Davis, Brody & Associates and the planning firm of Llewelyn Davies Associates have been selected by the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the American Stock Exchange to design the exchange's new headquarters building in lower Manha rtan The new facility, estimated to cost $40 million, will be built by the U.D.C. and financed from a $15 million New York State economic development grant and approximately $25 million in bond proceeds from a consortium of New York institutional investors.

title: Are UTurns Possible Under Proposed Bus Takeover Program?
description: THE Opinion Page of Feb. 25 contained an article by Louis J. Gambaccini, Commissioner of the state's Department of Transportation, extolling what the Commissioner perceives to be the virtues of creating a public transit corporation to acquire and operate bus companies in New Jersey.

title: CAMERA
description: Movies and slides share one thing in common: neither one can be fully appreciated until they are projected. The vibrancy of their colors as seen by transmitted light is unrivaled by the same images when viewed by reflected light, and their display takes on the aura of a performance.

title: Pastor and Professor
description: CAR L RANSOM ROGERS, entering his 78th year rich and full of honors, has been president of the American Psychological Association, the American Asnriation for Applied Psychology and the American Academy of Psychotherapists; he has writIllustrated. 444 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $12.95. ten books read by millions, established a curative procedure for the troubled of soul, received medals for his work as researcher and as practitioner, been acclaimed as a rare light in the darkness of mechanistic psychology. Surely Carl Rogers is not running for another office.

title: Births
description: Mr. & Mrs chares Schwart ??nee Los Leval of seten island and Parks?? N.Y announce the ?? of her son ??mahew David. Princess ??Arr s?? brother. On March 3. 1979 Named ra maternal ??c.rand'ather Maurice Levy Maternal Or andrrven-?? Iv?? Mrs Golde Levy Paterna orandparent's Run & Louis Schwarz A spectal thanks to Dr. Ronald Zoppel.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Twentythree years ago, The New Yorker published a cartoon of a father and son gazing out over the Manhattan skyline. The caption: Someday, my boy, all this will belong to Mr. William Zeckendorf.

title: The New Bipartisans
description: WASHINGTON  If we have learned anything in recent months it is that a President must provide leadership to which the American people can respond. Nowhere is that more true than in foreign policy.

title: Around TheGarden
description: Keep close watch over seedlings indoors. Start feeding at onequarter rate weekly when they have their third pair of true leaves. Use refined oil sprays to control mites and scales while woody plants are dormant. Temperatures must be above 40 degrees. Read and follow label directions.

title: A Singer's 4 Concerts In 10 Days
description: George Wein, the jazz impresario who has based two of his innovative presentations  the Newport Jazz Festival and the New York Jazz Repertory Company  on ideas derived from classicalmusic programming, is trying a third jazz adaptation of a classical formula. Mr. Wein will present Sarah Vaughan, the singer, in a cycle of three different concerts at Carnegie Hall in a period of 10 days: Wednesday, Friday, and Friday, March 30.

title: Therapy for the Credit Cardaholic
description: THE warning signs had been there for some time  the monthly juggling of bills, the phone calls from creditors until finally the teacher from New Rochelle decided to count up his debts. He found that he owed more than $33.000. It was shocking to realize just how much we really owed, he said. And a lot of it had to do with the freedom of the plastic credit card.

title: As Sadat Said, Jimmy Carter Has Done It!
description: Sixteen months after Anwar elSadat set foot in Jerusalem, peace between Israel and Egypt is at the point of paper and pen. Egypt's President was probably right last week when he said that the real test of a peace treaty will come after the signing. But the statement did not detract from an extraordinary achievement, only put it into perspective.

title: Woman Booked as Bank Robber
description: A 25yearold woman believed by the police to be the lady bomber bank robber was arraigned yesterday at the Federal District Courthouse for the Eastern District in Brooklyn. Bail was set at $50,000.

title: Ellen Robin Kaufer Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Saul Kaufer of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Robin Kaufer, to Joel Harris Komisarow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Komisarow of Beechhurst, Queens. Miss Kaufer, a student at Queens College, is in the copyright contracts department of Charles Scribner's Sons, and her fiance, an alumnus of Indiana University, is with HDC Publications, New York trade magazine publishers. His father, a partner in HDC, was formerly a cartoonist for King Features. Miss Kaufer's father is a printer with the Barr Press in New York.

title: IN THE NATION
description: DECATUR, Ala., March 16  Torn West is an amiable, articulate man in his mid30's who looks as if he could shoulder a bale of cotton or blast a hole through the Dallas Cowboys front four. In fact, he's spending less time these days at his homeinsulation business than on his duties as Northwest Alabama Kleagle of the Invisible Empire, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan.

title: VETERAN IS WINNER IN BRIDGE TOURNEY
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 17  One of the world's top bridge players has demonstrated at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals that the young stars cannot expect to have matters all their own way. George Rapee, a sprightly 63yearold New Yorker who won three world team titles more than a quarter of a century ago, headed the field of 112 pairs advancing into the final two sessions of the national men's pair championship today.

title: In Westchester, a Police Merger With National Echoes
description: WHITE PLAINS  When Westchester County Parkway Policemen in dark blue shirts began working next to sheriff's deputies in gray shirts last week at a new communications console in the Parkway force's headquarters north of White Plains, it was the first step in a consolidation of the two departments that some county officials have been promoting for years.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: Readers are invited to submit questions on cars. Mr. Schuon cannot answer letters personally, but those of general interest will be published. Send them to Marshall Schuon, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Opera's Siren Song Calls Elaine Malbin
description: GREAT NECK ELAINE MALBIN would like very much to have a word with Beverly Sills. As the incoming director of the New York City Opera, Miss Sills has said she would like to hire young American singers for the company. But Miss Malbin ha, another suggestion: Think about hiring the older American singer as well.

title: Lee Wolfe Fiancee Of Mark R. Carson
description: The engagement of Lee Ann Wolfe to Mark Reese Carson has been announced by Mr. and Mr. Paul Wolfe of New Canaan, Conn., parents of the future bride. Mr. Carson is a son of Mr and Mrs. Reese Carson of Exton, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: Josephine Mongiardo in Vocal Recital
description: Josephine Mongiardo showed commendable enterprise in assembling an interesting program of vocal music Friday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Not only was the selection entertaining for its quality and offbeat nature, but also the performances, including a variety of instrumental combinations, were consistently sensitive, stylish and engaging.

title: Nuclear Experts Debate The China Syndrome
description: AWASHINGTON, D.C. Anew film depicting a narrowly averted but serious accident at one of America's giant nuclear power plants has generated sharply conflicting responses from experts intimately involved in the current national debate over atomic energy.

title: Lines Harden in College Dispute
description: AS THE deadline neared for strike of about 3,200 faculty members at New Jersey's eight state colleges, both sides hardened their stands because each saw the issues as crucial.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: PublicService Jobs Program Upheld in New Study
description: WASHINGTON, March 17  A new study by the Brookings Institution has concluded that the Federal Government's publicservice jobs program to help the chronically unemployed is working well.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: You don't buy a suit without trying it on; by the same token you can't what a golf club will do for you until you work with it,' says Norman Schaut, owner of GolfORami! on Adams Street in Bedford Hills. where the second annual meiropt,litantirea, equipment show is taking place.

title: APlant Neighbors Held Unafraid
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 17 (AP)  People who live near atomic power plants apparently have little fear that the plants will hurt area property values, a Pennsylvania State University survey suggests.

title: Winning Trust Was Carter's Principal Aim, And He Did It
description: WASHINGTON  In many ways, it was reminiscent of his campaign for the Presidency. Not just because of the hectic schedule, the crowds, the motorcades and the other trappings. It was more than that.

title: Vietnam Suggests to China That Talks Start Friday
description: BANGKOK, Thailand. March 17 (Reuters)  The Vietnamese Government proposed today that talks with China on restoring normal relations should begin Friday either in Hanoi or at a point along their common border.

title: Oil Wealth Has Not Meant an End to All of Venezuela's Troubles
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The new Venezuelan Government of Luis Herrera Campins, an upset winner over the incumbent party's candidate, offers more continuity than change in this booming oil country. Taking office last week, President Herrera attacked corruption, inflation and spendthrift administration. But he seemed to be saying he would do the same things as his predecessor, only better.

title: Around the Nation
description: MADISON, Wis., March 17 (UPI)  A 47yearold Indianapolis woman who had an extra heart placed in her chest was reported in satisfactory condition today at the University of Wisconsin Hospitals.

title: Fiske Hails Industry's Crime Aid
description: The chief Federal prosecutor in the Southern District of New York expressed praise yesterday for companies that originate Federal investigations into wrongdoing by their own executives.

title: DEATHS
description: BURKEThomas P. Reposirvj at WII. hams Funeral Home, 5628 Broad way at 232 St, Bronx until 9:30AM Monday.

title: Ann B. FitzSimons Betrothed to James O. Chamberlain
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John F. FitzSimons of Forest Hills, Queens, and Hague, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Ann Baxter FitzSimons, to James Osborn Chamberlain, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Fitzhugh Chamberlain of Chester, N.Y.

title: Officials Are Heeding Opposition to Mining Uranium in Vermont
description: MONTPELIER, VT., March 17  Confronted with mounting public opposition to proposed mining of uranium, Gov. Richard A. Snelling has recommended that Urangesellschaft U.S.A. Inc. be denied permission to prospect for the radioactive metal on 2,000 acres it has leased in Okemo State Park, near Ludlow.

title: FILM VIEW
description: popular film criticism of the 1930's, 40's and 50's often had a way of confusing art with elevated attitudes. Humane intentions could ennoble a movie. Critics, then as now, equated certain films with community duty, like vaccination. Thus, John Ford's The Grapes of Wrath was automatically considered more important than his My Darling Clementine, William Wellman's The OxBow Incident more arofound than Ernst Lubitsch's To Be or Not to Be, and Elia Kazan's Gentlemen's Agreement more worthy than Vincente Minnelli's The Pirate. It sometimes seemed as if the major function of criticism was the grading of films for social content.

title: Wayne Jordan, 76; A Former Newsman, Teacher and Historian
description: BUFFALO, March 17 Wayne Jordan, a newspaperman who also was a historian and an educator, died last night after suffering a heart attack in his home at 216 Summer Street in Buffalo. He was 76 years old.

title: Daniel McCartney Weds Miss Hines
description: Dorothy Hope Hines, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Hines of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Quogue. L.I., was martied yesterday to Daniel Francis McCartney, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. McCartney of Elmhurst, Queens. The Rev. Dermot Brennan performed the ceremony in the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale.

title: Proud Polish Overcoming Stereotypes
description: A lot of people still say, Yeah, the Polacks, they're stupid or drunks.  said Tina Bobak, who lives in Mount Vernon and is one of more than 19,000 people of Polish descent in Westchester. These people still have visions of someone slumped over a bar. It bothers me because I know all of the good things. For every one Polish person who might fit that image, I know 50 others who don't. But it's very difficult to overcome the old stereotypes.

title: Major Hotel Chains Checking In on L.I.
description: MINEOLA ANEW wave of hotel construction is sweeping the Island from Garden City to Hauppauge, with government and business leaders hopeful that the availability of more than 1,000 new hotel rooms will give a tiost to the Island's economy.

title: Ideas &
description: With the publication of his first encyclical last week. Pope John Paul II provided a comprehensive look at the future concerns of his reign. His papal letter confirmed the picture of the Pontiff that has emerged in the five months since his election and, viewed as a statement of policy, suggested that his main preoccupations may be discipline within the Roman Catholic Church and human suffering throughout the world.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Walter F. Murphy is McCormack Professor of Jurisprudence at Princeton and the author of such serious studies as Congress and the Court, Elements of Judicial Strategy and Wiretapping on Trial.

title: Carol Troy, Author, Has Bridal
description: Carol Troy, author of Cheap Chic Update, was married yesterday to Lucian King Truscott 9th, author of Dress Gray, the bestselling novel about West Point. Tha Rev. Martin Kelly performed the ceremony in St. Anthony of Padua Roman Catholic Church. A reception was held at the Lotos Club.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: A series of concerts at the Alternative Center for International Arts, an experimental enclave on East 4th Street, is further evidence of the increasing interest in Indian music and its growing influence on contemporary musicians. The seven concerts, starting Friday and concluding on June 2, offer a full range of Indian music, from South and North Indian classical music to folk music of Bengal and Indojazz. (See Music)

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: A Podiatrist Presents Another View
description: To the Sports Editor: Your Feb. 27 article (Some Podiatrists Said to Overcharge Runners for Customized Shoe Device) contains clicrted statements and spurious allegations by a minority of individuals who deal with runners and, by doing so, should know better.

title: New Jersey/ This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris, in an Actor'sCaf Theater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. Opens Friday (through April 21). $3.5045.50; students and the elderly, $2.5044.50. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Newton Buckner 3d Will Wed Janet Swartz
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Swartz of Newington, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Janet S. Swartz, to Newton Buckner 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Newton Buckner of Sand Lake, N.Y.

title: INVESTING
description: Back in the mid1960's, a fortunate few got in on the ground floor of McDonald's stock. A purchase of 100 shares cost $2,250 at the initial offering price. By late 1972, as the industry grew and McDonald's prospered, that initial purchase was worth $141,000.

title: Law Puts Mothers Convicted of Crime In Double Jeopardy
description: AWOMAN who gets into trouble with the law in Connecticut may receive what amounts to two sentences. One is uttered aloud by the judge in the courtroom when he orders the woman to spend a period of time in prison. The other is never really spelled out until it is too late to do anything about it: The woman can be deprived of her children, perhaps forever.

title: Shows and Events
description: Today  Meadowlands Antiques Exposition, Meadowlands Race Track (indoors). Access from Route 3 or Exit 16W of the New Jersey Turnpike. Hours: 11 A.M.7 P.M. Admission: $2.50; parking, $1. 250 exhibits. For information, call (201) 2623063.

title: United States Seals Davis Cup Victory
description: CLEVELAND, March 17 (AP) John McEnroe and Peter Fleming led the United States Davis Cup team to victory over Colombia in the Northern zone final today. They defeated Ivan Molina and Orlando Agudelo, 64, 60, 69.

title: BornAgain Mead Paper Leads Revival
description: DAYTON, Ohio  Papermakers to America was the proud slogan of the Mead Corporation over the years as it matched its competitors in every major market from envelopes to cardboard boxes. Family was the byword at Mead  as it was at the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, the Weyerhaeuser Company and the International Paper Companywhere dynamic chips off the old block ran the shop. And when the industry went on an expansion and diversification campaign in the 1960's, Mead was in there with the rest  and suffered with them in the industrywide depression of the 1970's.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: Senator Kassebaum Is Divorced
description: ELDORADO, Kan., March 17 (AP) Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum was granted a divorce today by a Butler County court judge. The Kansas Republican's petition for divorce on the ground of incompatibility was not challenged by her husband, Phil Kassebaum, a Wichita lawyer. The divorce came after 24 years of marriage, four children and two years of separation.

title: A New Chamber Group Takes Shape
description: YOU wouldn't believe the amount of effort and energy that has gone into all this, Marsha Cheraskin Winokur was saying, but we're starting off with the highest hopes. ine scarsaaie pianist was referring to the organization of a new ensemble called the Saxon Wood Chamber Players and to the planning for its first season, which begins next Sunday.

title: Dream Ending Again for Alien and Family
description: PERTH AMBOY, N.J.  Early in May, Cecilio Reyes will quit his $200aweek job as a forklift operator at a chemical plant here and, together with his wife and young son, reluctantly board a plane to return to his native Mexico.

title: A Course in Frustration at UConn Stamford
description: STAMFORD WHEN I started teaching here in 1962, the students in my classes were the usual 18yearolds, said Yakira Frank, director of the Stamford branch of the University of Connecticut. Gradually things began to change, just as they had been predicting, she said. I still teach one class a semester, and now, out of 24 students, 18 are women over 40.

title: Fans Set Ring Afire
description: ROI ET, Thailand, March 17 (AP)  Spectators set fire to the boxing ring tonight after they were told by the promoter that the World Boxing Association junior featherweight championship fight between the champion, Ricardo Cardona of Colombia, and Vichit MuangroiEt, the Thai challenger, had been canceled.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Whirligigs  toys ma??? to whirl in the wi?? and spin in the mindmay well have been invented by the ancients. If they were, these fragile wind. indicators did not survive. We may never know, in fact, whether even at a later date, the Vikings and those who sailed the seven seas in recent centuries, had the will and the wit to chisel these provocative pointers so that mariners could perceive immediately each shift in the direction and the intensity of the winds. Some folk art experts have suggested just that, and it is logical. But where's the proof?

title: Pollution in Great Lakes Is Called Still Critical
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 17 Pollution of the Great Lakes by toxic substances remains a critical problem and serious and effective controls are needed promptly, according to an annual report issued this week by an international commission that monitors water quality in the lakes.

title: Miss Havisham Goes to the Opera
description: There is a line in Tom Stoppard's play Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead which says that every exit off stage is an entrance into another, entirely different arena of action. This tantalizingly existential notion appealed instantly to the composer Dominick Argento when he read the play, and it has, in part, influenced his new opera Miss Havisham's Fire which receives its world premiere Thursday night at the City Opera.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Rosemary Rogers's own story reads like the kind of fantasy that could come only from her pen  six bestselling romantic novels in six years and an annual income reported to be $1 million. Miss Rogers herself, an exoticlooking, 15yearold divorcee, plays down the income, saying only that it amounts to hundreds of thousands of dollars; but that's where her demureness stops.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: APPROXIMATELY 1,500 exasperated condominium owners recently formed an organization to fight what they feel is their disproportionately high level of property taxes and secondclass treatment by Stamford, which, they say, is exacerbating the injustice by failing to provide certain basic municipal services.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: THE turnout in Bedford was so small that a panelist spent the first 15 minutes playing the piano while waiting for people to arriveand only six did.

title: Yale Sports: The RedInk Blues
description: NEW HAVEN TROUBLE on the Yale campus. Money trouble, the worst kind. The university, like many others these inflationary days, is spending more than it has coming in. Next to the library, the worst offender is the athletic department, which is $3.3 million in the red.

title: Tractorcade Demonstrators Go Home, Leaving Mostly Anger Behind
description: WASHINGTON  Dave Bosle left his corn field in Hastings, Neb. on Jan. 18 and drove his tractor here to join hundreds of other farmers in demands for higher farm prices. Last week, as the tractorcade demonstrators were trickling home, he was well aware that many in Washington felt that they had succeeded only in causing damage  an estimated $3.6 million worth to the capital, and untold political damage to themselves.

title: A 747 of One's Own N. Y. to Paris in Solitary Splendor
description: None of my youthful dreams of glory included anything airborne. Though was aware of Charles Lindbergh's epic solo flight across the Atlantic in 1927 as a stirring fact of history, I somehow never felt sufficiently inspired by it to envision myself up there in the clouds, battling the elements without a companion for a distance of 3,000 miles.

title: Fashion
description: This spring, fashion is being vitalized by color  everything from hottedup pastels to strong primaries. Come summer, the color red will predominate in every type of fabric, from silk crepe de chine and taffeta to terry cloth and polyester cotton. And it is the full range of reds, from crimson through poppy to rose that designers are using in their summer collections. Here are just a few of the ways red will run riot.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: One of the exhibits in the Smithsonian's Highlights From the Chase Manhattan Money Collection, that opened last month, is a pattern coin in gilt bronze, designed by William Barber, for a $50 gold piece that almost became regular issue back in the middle 1800's.

title: Furtwngler's Schubert Remains Compelling
description: Wilhelm Furtwangler's 1951 recording of Schubert's Symphony No. 9 is one of the more famous orchestral performances ever committed to disk. Its recent release on DG's halfprice Privilege label marks its fifth appearance in the Schwann catalogue since it first turned up on Decca 27 years ago. In those days.

title: Laurie Beth Litwin Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Litwin of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Beth Litwin, to David Aram Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Idris Thomas of London. A wedding is planned July 8.

title: U.S. AND BRITAIN ASK ALL SIDES TO DISCUSS NEW RHODESIA VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, March 17  The United States and Britain appealed anew today to both sides in the Rhodesian conflict to open negotiations for a peaceful settlement based on elections supervised by the United Nations.

title: Fundamentalist Minister Resigns As Chairman of Oregon's G.O.P.
description: PORTLAND, Ore., March 17  Walter L. Huss, a onetime fundamentalist minister who last August seized control of Oregon's Republican Party, yesterday announced his intention to resign as party chairman.

title: DIKING OUT
description: CHESHIRE RESTAURANTS, like people, deserve a second chance. First impressions can often be incomplete. This was more than a little apparent in two recent experiences at the Pavillion, set back from the road on Route 10.

title: City College and Hunter Victors
description: Oscar Armero of City College captured four medals, three gold and one silver, and led the Beavers to the men's title with 158 points in the City University of New York indoor track and field championships yesterday at Queens College's FitzGerald Memorial Gymnasium.

title: Mt. Kisco Candidates Ignore Assessments
description: MOUNT Kisco THE issue of fullvalue assessment that had appeared last month to be a key issue and the possible undoing of any incumbent seeking reelection here Tuesday has been muted in the last few weeks by the failure of any candidate to make an issue of it.

title: Hope A. Ramsing And Martin Lynn, Broker, Are Wed
description: Hope Antoinette Ramsing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Byron L. Ramsing of Palm Beach, Fla., was married there yesterday to Martin Worthington Lynn, on of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Ferguson Lynn of Watertown, Conn.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: ATLANTIC CITY IN THE midst of an economic boom, it isn't often that a voice of restraint is heard, much less heeded, particularly if the boom is in a place like Atlantic City.

title: HOMOSEXUAL PRIEST DEFENDS HIS ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 17  The Rev. Robert F. Hummel, a Roman Catholic priest suspended from the ministry last week after publicly acknowledging that be was a homosexual, recalls the experience that ultimately prompted him to acknowledge his homosexualtiv.

title: IT PAYS TO BE A GHOST
description: It is only fitting that, in an age of unbridled narcissism, that most selfeffacing of literary figures, the ghostwriter, should come into his own.

title: Oil Prices Hold Steady, for Now
description: Oil Prices Hold Steady, for Now

title: Physicist Challenges Agency
description: MILWAUKEE, March 17  A staff physicist at the Argonne National Labo, ratory in Illinois has challenged, in an affidavit filed yesterday in Federal District Court here, the Department of Justice's contention that an article written for The Progressive on the hydrogen bomb contained information that was not in the public domain.

title: Library of Performing Arts in Capital
description: WASHINGTON  Two major cul turul forces in the capital  the Library of Congress and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Artshave joined forces to establish the first Performing Arts Library here. It resembles, on a modest scale, the Performing Arts Library at Lincoln Center, which is linked to the New York Public Library.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Broken clouds are visible over New England and in the Southeast. Overcast clouds extend from the lake region through the upper Missouri Valley, the Southern Plains States and into the Gulf States. Overcast cloud bands are also visible in the northern Rockies and in most of the Southwest.

title: Banker's Ledger Reported to Differ From Official Carter Loan Records
description: ATLANTA, March 17  The official of the National Bank of Georgia who was responsible for handling the multimilliondollar peanut loans to President Carter's family business kept a private ledger on the loans performance that varied at times from the bank's official records, according to bank and Government officials.

title: What's Doing in RICHMOND
description: RENAISSANCE  Richmond's first tourist was Capt. John Smith, who stepped ashore on a May weekend in 1607, just 11 days after founding Jamestown, 65 miles downstream on the James River. A monument indicates the spot today, one of scores in a city of monuments that link the capital of Virginia with the birth, development, rending and rebirth of the nation. Burned twice (by the turncoat Gen. Benedict Arnold in the Revolution and by rebel looters in the final week of the Civil War), Richmond was twice rebuilt and then fell into a century of sleepy gentility before its renaissance since World War II as a business center for the midSouth and as a crossroads for tourists to the Tidewater.

title: Food
description: If we were asked to name the one dish that is at once the most elegant and the easiest to cook and carve, it would quite likely be a roast saddle of lamb. The saddle is that part of the animal that extends from the last ribs to the hindquarters. It is, in short, where you would place a saddle if, for some curious reason, you decided to ride the beast. The saddle has marvelous strips of flesh on either side of the back or center bone, and the cooking involves little more than roasting the seasoned meat for about 45 minutes. Before serving, the meat is taken from the oven and allowed to rest 15 minutes to redistribute the juices. To slice, simply carve the meat at thin intervals, holding the knife close to the backbone. Saddle of lamb is a dish of such simplicity that vegetable garnishes seem in order, both for color and taste. Recipes for three such garnishes appear below.

title: Iranian Refugees of Middle Class Feel Uneasy and Isolated in U.S.
description: For some families of the Iranian middle class who fled to the United States after the Shah's departure, life as a refugee is an uneasy conflict between memories of prosperity back home and the new poverty facing them as a result of businesses lost and assets frozen by the turmoil in their homeland.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: This is, I rush to report, a lovely book, a gentle, sensitive memoir about Eizabeth Mooney's mother, to whom it is dedicated. Bess Comstock lived with 196 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. S9 95 her husband and two children in Rome, N Y, was afflicted as a young woman with tuberculosis, the disease they called the white plague, and was then exiled 150 miles north to the City of the Sick (Saranac Lake) for her cure. She returned to her family, her illness somewhat arrested, lived as a semiinvalid and died of TB when her daughter Elizabeth was 19.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: Q. I have a 1968 sixcylinder Plymouth with 140,000 miles to its credit. Until the car is thoroughly warmed up, the transmission is reluctant to move from one speed to another. When it does shift, it does so with a thud. The transmission fluid has never been changed. Would changing the fluid at this point lead to any other problems?

title: TRANSIT POLICE ACT ON KOCH'S DIRECTIVE
description: Moving to implement Mayor Koch's program to combat subway crime, the Transit Authority undertook a major realignment of its 2,900member police force yesterday, virtually dissolving its detective division and plainclothes anticrirne and tactical patrol units to provide 550 additional men in uniform for patrol duty in stations and aboard all nighttime trains, starting tomorrow.

title: $131 Million Question For P.U.C.A.
description: HARTFORD THE Public Utilities Control Authority, the centerpiece of a 1974 campaign promise by Governor Grasso to improve utility regulation, is facing what may be the most difficult test of its fouryear existence. The authority will begin hearings next month on the largest proposed rate increase in the state's history  a $131 million rise sought by Northeast Utilities. The action comes at a time when, through a quirk of state law, all five of the agency's commissioners are facing reappointment by the Governor, who has not been pleased with the way the body is handling the case.

title: Umpires Fear Dirty Tricks
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 17  Baseball's umpiring impasse could lead to widespread cheating on the playing field, a retired major league umpire warned today.

title: How to Win at Wimbledon By Scoring as a Spectator
description: The tattered mustardcolored ticket stub that. I have kept like a talisman from 1974 says. The Lawn Tennis Championships period. as if there were on other protennis event of any consequence.

title: Reassessing the Property Tax
description: NEW LONDON THE economic debate that has been part of the state's effort to estaBLish A NEW SchhoolfinancE sys tem may soon enter a new area of controversy  attempts to revise the system of apprasing property for tax purposes.

title: OPTING FOR SUICIDE
description: No doubt, many people who face a lingering death  from cancer, say, or some other disease contemplate suicide. But by the time they are ready to take action, it is often already too late. Closely monitored by family and caretakers, they lack access to any effective means of suicide. They may also be physically or mentally incapacitated. Their lastminute, improvised suicide attempts are quite likely to end in failure, humiliation and, perhaps, additional pain. This is the case history of a patient who firmly believes in advance planning. I am that patient.

title: Rod Layer Heads Field In Legends Tournament
description: ATLANTA, March 17 (AP)  Rod Layer heads a field of eight players competing in the $25,000 Tennis Legends tournament Thursday through next Saturday at the Georgia Tech Coliseum.

title: Wine
description: The 1974 bordeaux were nothing special: hard when they were young,just becoming drinkable now. Still, a single bottle of Chateau LafiteRothschild 1974 sells in New York for $23. Don't gasp  the 1975 sells for $40. So do a couple of the other firstgrowth bordeaux, along with Cheval Blanc from St. Emilion and Petrus from Pomerol.

title: CYRUS VANCE PLAYS IT COOL
description: It is a time to be stoic. Don't overreact. No Marines in Iran. There are limits to what the United States can do. Be calm. The storm will pass. The goals of our foreign policy are sound. They can be realized with patience. Patience. Patience.

title: ISRAEL PRESSING U.S. TO SPEED SHIPMENTS OF TANKS AND JETS
description: WASHINGTON, March 17  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman of Israel, expressing concern that Syria and Iraq will seek to undermine an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty, is pressing the United States to speed delivery of weapons, Administration sources said today.

title: The Fleisher Collection's New Catalogue
description: The Edwin A. Fleisher C,oliec tion of Orchestral Music ii. the Free Library cf Philadelphia, to give it its full dignified title, is one of the most important as well as one of the largest repositories of musical materials in the world. It exists not just for researchers to dig around in. It is for active use. Any ensemble can borrow a particular work (score and parts), perform it and return it for a relatively small handling fee. (When a score calls for an unusual instrument, such as a hurdygurdy, that is supplied, too.) It is a godsend for orchestras with limited budgets, but major organizations use the collection, too. They can find in it works that are not available anywhere else.

title: Beth Labson Is Fiance of William Freeman
description: Beth A. Labson, who expects to graduate from Harvard Law School in June, and William S. Freeman, a lawyer with the Department of Justice in Washington, plan to be married on Aug. 19 in San Mateo, Calif.

title: Rosalyn Elliott Becomes Bride
description: In the First United Methodist Church in Birmingham, Ala., yesterday afternoon. Rosalyn Elliott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt Massey Elliott of Jasper, Ala., became the bride of Allerton Garthwaite Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Garthwaite Smith of Mountain Brook, Ala. The ReV. Dr. Edwin Kimbrough performed the ceremony.

title: Archbishop Thomas Boland, 83, Of Newark Archdiocese Is Dead
description: The Most Rev. Thomas A. Boland, the retired Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, died Friday night in St. Mary's Hospital in Orange, N.J. He was 83 years old and had been hospitalized since June because of severe arthritis.

title: 5 Test Houses on Long Island
description: WADING RIVER, L.I.  The temperature outside the Scharback house here this afternoon is 45 degrees, and the sun is barely visible through the hazy latewinter sky, but the air being forced through the solar panels on the roof and then down to a rock heatstorage bin in the basement, is 103 degrees.

description: Harriet Winslow Wheeler of Irvington, N.Y., and Dr. Charles Hathorn Wheeler of Bear Lake, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Brook Radway Wheeler, to Roger Stuart Berlind, a theatrical and film producer. He is a son of Mrs. Henry M.

title: Legal Rainbow's End: Sweeps Winner Freed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 (AP) This is Frank McNulty's first St. Patrick's Day out of jail in nearly four years because a judge ended a term that Mr. McNulty was serving for refusing to pay taxes on winnings from the Irish Sweepstakes.

title: A Low Rating For Readiness Within NATO
description: Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, NATO's commanderdesignate, will fly to Europe this week to evaluate the military legacy being left by Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., who retires in June. The situation he will find includes both hopeful developments within the alliance and some glaring deficiencies that have not been dealt with.

description: To the Business Editor:

title: MUSIC

title: I Like Playing a Woman in Control of Her Life
description: LONDON The difficulty with this profession is that more often than not, for a woman anyway, the marvelous parts are tragic figures who are just taken over by circumstances. They aren't very often women who are totally in control of their lives. The more I read about Lillie Langtry, the more amazing she seemed  and the more I wanted the opportunity to play a woman who was in control and not intimidated by the society she lived in.

title: Darkness To Dawn
description: PARIS  The peace treaty which now seems definitely ahead for Egypt and Israel represents a stunning breakthrough fur the strained Middle East after 30 years of war between Israel and all its neighbors, and generations of hostility between Arabs and Jews. It doesn't guarantee peace, but if President Carter had failed in his dramatic effort, that could easily have meant another war.

title: Apartheid, Mighty but Doomed
description: Where is South Africa headed in the next five to 10 years?

title: A Not So Happy Holiday In Sunny Acapulco
description: Acapulco means the place where the ieeds died. After a threeweek stay. my wife and I conclud that vacation dreams die there. too.

title: U.S. Chauffeured Cars Are Reported Growing
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) More Federal officials are using chauffeurdriven Government cars now than when President Carter issued his nofrills costcutting edicts in 1977, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: LastSecond Basket Beats Arkansas
description: CINCINNATI, March 17  Yes, Indiana State can play with the big boys and beat them.

title: Mother and Daughter
description: TRAVEL has always had its detractors. D. H. Lawrence wrote to a friend: It only excites the outside. The inside it leaves more isolated and stoic than ever. It is all a form of running away from onself and the great problems. Margaret Logan would not agree, although much in her book would tempt one to argue that she has been influenced by Lawrence's ideas of what is heroic in women. She believes in the primacy of the orgasm. She writes, Take away orgasm and there goes the shape of lovemaking. She believes in the primacy of adventure. She chooses the bicycle over the car and embarks on a 2,000mile cycling tour of France and Italy, a tour she has designed to introduce her sulky, antagonistic 17yearold daughter to the world of ambiguity and uncertainty.

title: INTERVIEW
description: HACKENSACK

title: Other Regional Events
description: Lowell R. Weicker Jr. last week became the fifth candidate to declare formally for the Republican Presidential nomination, although to hear him tell it, Mr. Weicker, who considered leaving the party several years ago, is a Republican in name only. Admitting he was the longest shot in the field  party regulars say he has lacked national exposure since the Senate Watergate hearings  he said: I'm told that all this talk of investment for a future during times of economic difficulty runs against a tide of conservatism [but] that's what I'm going to be all about.

title: Louise BarruCh Engaged To Stephen M. Levene
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Barruch of Valley Stream, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louise Ann Barruch, to Stephen Michael Levene, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Levene of Binghamton, N.Y., and Hollywood, Fla.

title: In Albany, a Good Attitude Paid Off
description: ALBANY  Governor Carey and William L. McGowan, president of the Civil Service Employees Association, stood side by side last week, positively gloating about the precedentsetting labor settlement they had just reached for the state's 105,000 administrative, institutional and operational employees. It was a far cry from the scene two years before, when negotiators averted a statewide strike by hours. And it was an even farther cry from last year's bargaining between Mayor Koch and the municipal unions, a long and vitriolic public tussle that saw the Mayor drop one demand after another in return for union peace.

title: The World
description: In Summary

title: At Home: An Ailing Dog And the Wonders of Science
description: THIS is a shaggydog story. It raises certain shaggy questions about love, responsibility, guilt and the sanctity of canine and/or human life. The dog in question belonged to a couple I know. She is a concert pianist, and he is a psychotherapist. They had not planned to have a dog. In fact, their respective cafeers kept them so busy that they postponed having children.

description: American Jewish leaders who had an rlong audience with Pope John Paul II 1st week said the world Jewish cornimunity should be pleased with his emerging papacy.

description: The openplan office landscape revolution, which began to tumble walls more than a decade ago, continues to gather momentum and controversy.

title: Wearers of the Green Turn Blue As Snow Chills Ireland's Holiday
description: DUBLIN, March 17 (UPI) Ireland celebrated St. Patrick's Day today despite snowstorms that piled up 10foot drifts and curtailed parades in many cities in the coldest wearing of the green in memory.

description: 10:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Lamp Unto My Feet: The Seventh Day, readings based on experiences of Israeli soldiers during the Middle East war of 1967.

title: Intervention in Yemen War Signals Foreign Policy Shift
description: WASHINGTON  An aircraft carrier steaming toward the Arabian Sea; American radar warning planes patrolling the skies of Saudi Arabia; military advisers and arms going to a brushfire war in distant Yemen  Government officials were reluctant to discuss details of these operations, but several acknowledged that the Carter Administration's mostly unexpected military response to the conflict represented a new phase of American foreign policy.

title: An American International
description: EMARKABLY enough, the two elder statesmen of American music were born (four years apart, it is true) on the same street in Brooklyn. There is a 388 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. Cloth, $22.50. Paper, $8.95. whole history of American culture in that coincidence. Aaron Copland, born in 1900, came from the wrong side of the tracks ; by contrast, the stretch of Washington Avenue where Roger Sessions was born in 1896 was known as the most beautiful street in America. Copland, the son of immigrant shopkeepers, went on to become the best known and most American of composers. Sessions, descended from impeccable 17thcentury New England ancestry, became a composer's composer and the most important representative of international symphonic modernism in American music.

title: Overpayments Declining In Federal Welfare Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)  The Government said today that $565 million was misspent in two of its largest welfare programs in the first six months of 1978, but the error rate in the biggest program took a sizable drop.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the first name of the president of Sea Containers Group was given incorrectly in an article on Page 3 of last Sunday's Business/Finance section. His name is James B. Sherwood.

title: U.S. Agriculture Group in China
description: PEKING, March 17 (Reuters)  A delegation from the United States Agriculture Department. is here to discuss technical cooperation in such areas as feed operations and seed technology. The delegation, headed by Deputy Secretary Dale Hathaway, arrived yesterday. The mission is a followup to a visit last November by Secretary Bob Bergland, who reached agreements covering scientific exchanges.

title: CHESS
description: In the average international tournament, the crosstable often makes it appear  or so the sponsors interpret it  as though the grandmaster circuit riders gang up on the local contingent while taking it easy on each other. It iust isn't true.

title: Neil Diamond Has Spine Surgery
description: LOS ANGELES, March 17 (UPI) Neil Diamond, the singer, was reported progressing satisfactorily today after undergoing surgery yesterday for removal of a portion of a vertebra. Mr. Diamond, 38 years old, whose hits include Sweet Caroline, Holly Holy and Beautiful Noise, was admitted Monday for routine tests involving an old back problem, said a spokesman at CedarsSinai Medical Center.

title: New Prestige for Those in the Firing Trade
description: On April Fool's Day, Thomas B. Hubbard will celebrate the 10th anniversary of his company, a pioneer in that branch of management consulting known as outplacement  the care and handling of redundant executives. A man who knows how to fire with a flare, Mr. Hubbard got in on the ground floor of a booming business: no fool he.

title: Capitol Mall Repair Aided
description: TANGENT, Ore., March 17 (UPI) The Oregon Seed Trade Association will donate 7,200 pounds of grass seed to the Federal Government to restore lawn on the Capitol Mall destroyed by tractors during the farmers protest in Washington this winter.

title: The Region
description: In years to come, building New York City's Convention and Exhibition Center may seem to have been less complicated than drafting the legislation, unveiled last week by Governor Carey, that specifies how it will be paid for and who will run it. After nearly a year of bargaining over political tradeoffs, the Governor, Mayor Koch and leaders of the Legislature, including Republicans, agreed on a $375 million bond sale and state control of the center, which, barring hitches, is to be built in the Penn Central yards in the West 30's.

description: WASHINGTON

description: When Isadora Duncan was in her proBolshevik period, her effusive rhetoric on the New Dawn proved too much for one of her good friends, a founding member of the French Communist party. If she persists in giving curtain speeches, then I will dance, he warned.

title: POLL SAYS FEW BACK SOVIET ARMS TREATY
description: WASHINGTON. March 17  An opinion poll released this week suggests that only 20 percent of the American public Support the specific terms of the propoced strategicarms treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: How Things Were Made
description: The great Encyclopedie, ou Dictionnai re des Science, des Arts et des Mtiers began in 1745 with a Paris publisher's intention to translate the twovolume English Cyclopedia of Ephraim Chambers. The project was to take two years. Instead, it ended in 1781, comprised 35 folio volumes, became the major achievement of its editor, Denis Diderot, and had an incalculable effect on Western thought. It was a foreword to the Industrial Revolution.

title: Knick Free Throws Top 76ers
description: Freethrow shooting has been only one problem of the Knicks during this National Basketball Association season. But it was different last night in the final quarter when free throws paved the way for the 103101 victory over the hapless Philadelphia 76ers before a crowd of 18,488 at Madison Square Garden.

title: West Taking South's Place as Most Alienated Area
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo.  State officials like to tell the story of how the Federal Government decreed that the operator of a oneman mine had to acquire stretcher in case he was injured, even though there was no one for miles around to carry it.

description: Susan Joyce Freeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin D. Freeman of Hollis Hills, Queens, and Marvin Jacob Weingarten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Weingarten of Brooklyn, were married yesterday evening at the Freeman home. Rabbi H. Joseph Stmckes performed the ceremony.

description: Linda Fratianne wins world figure skating championship in Vienna. Page 3.

title: CRIME
description: There is no secret about the basic situation in PANDORA MAN by Kerry Newcomb and Frank Schaefer (Morrow, $8.95). We have had books in which The Enemy has his man in high places, even in the White House. But Pandora Man spells out the situation from the beginning, and those who take comfort in the conspiracy theory of history will be happy. A Texan named Matthew Bern has just been elected President. He takes his entire staff to his ranch. A television crew appears, right on schedule  and wipes out everybody but the Presidentelect and his Chicano secretary and adviser, one Tom Salcedo. Both are seriously wounded. After they get out of the hospital and meet, Salcedo realizes that whoever the man is, he is not Matthew Bern. It also turns out that Salcedo is alive by accident. But how much longer will he be permitted to live? He realizes this as well as the next man, and flees.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: ITHOUGHT I would end my days in my house in Stockton, said 79yearold Louise Douglas. But last winter, I had to be plowed out about 20 times, and couldn't face another winter like it.

title: Elise Werner, Designer, Engaged to Ira M. Frost
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Werner of Sharon, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elise Beth Werner, to Ira M. Frost, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack P. Frost of Highland Park, Ill.

title: Pskov: A Journey Into Russia's Past
description: Pskov is a bare 120 miles due west from Novgorod, but, when I suggested that I might go directly from one to the other. I was told that this was impossible. I must go back to square one. in other words back to Moscow. and start again. I knew it was useless to argue. Clearly something unutterably secret must lie between the two towns which I could not be allowed to see. In the end. however, it was agreed after a tussle that, in this neverending game of snakes and ladders. I need only go as far as Leningrad and start again from there. Always glad of a pretext to spend a few hours in Leningrad. I cheerfully agreed and at 11 the following night. after an excellent dinner at the Astoria. featuring some really superb cold sturgeon mayonnaise and a bottle of Tsolikauri. an excellent dry Georgian white wine I had never before tasted, I caught the bright blue Baltika Express. bound for Riga.

title: Margaret S. Bates Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Winthrop Bates of Duxbury, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Sandiford Bates, to Frederic David Lewis, son of Anne M. Lewis of Brooklyn Heights and the late Arthur Lewis.

title: News Summary
description: Israel wants faster delivery of American arms to forestall Iraqi and Syrian action against its peace treaty with Egypt. Administration sources said that Defense Minister Ezer Weizman had stressed Israel's need for earlywarning and other electronic installations in the Negev Desert. He reportedly has told aides that he believes the American contribution remains flexible, and that the Administration might provide more than the $2.5 billion it promised for the Israeli withdrawal from Sinai. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: In Baseball, Calm Before Bargaining Storm
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17  A new economic war appears to be taking shape in baseball, and players and owners are already girding for the end of their collectivebargaining contract later this year.

description: Draths

title: East Title To Tenn. Women
description: Since the beginning of the season, the women's basketball team at Tennessee has worked hard. For three hours daily, the players have gone through strenuous practices, exercising, running. It has all paid off.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: For the first time in weeks, the word on oil from Iran was good. Not terrific, but better than many expected. Production rose to 2.5 million barrels day, with exports nearing 2 million (prerevolutionary levels of 6 milion went with the Shah). Even more encouraging, the National Iranian Oil Company was signing longterm contracts at a more or less normal price of $15 a barrel. And Nigeria, the second largest supplier of crude to the United States after Saudi Arabia, looked to be backing way from an immediate raise in its crude prices.

title: South African Sees Last Chance in Talks On Namibia at U.N.
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 17  Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa left today for New York describing talks that will open at the United Nations on Monday as probably a last chance for the world organization's plan for a peaceful transition to black majority rule in SouthWest Africa.

title: Britain's New Political Playwrights
description: LONDON Aclaywrote the American drama critic, George Jean Nathan, in a summary dismissal of theatrical propagandists, can't hold a pistol against an audience's head and command it to give up. No indeed; but it can sometimes force it to think. And one of the most heartening things about the British theater right now is the existence of a group of dramatists (most notably Trevor Griffiths, David Edgar, David Hare, Howard Barker, Howard Brenton and Stephen Poliakoff) who all believe in the power of the stage as a medium of social and political analysis. Though instinctively left wing, they are not propagandists. Much as they desire social change, they are alert enough to know it is not in the cards; and a lot of their energy goes into exploring the dissolution of radical dreams in postwar Britain.

title: Marriage Groups Encountering Criticism
description: BAY SHORE TEN years ago, seven couples and a Roman Catholic priest met around a kitchen table in Port Washington to form the first Marriage Encounter group in the United States. Now, a decade later, the movement, which has reached 800,000 couples nationwide, 65,000 of them on the Island, is experiencing growing pains.

title: A New Monetary System Launched Last Week Was a Welcome Sign of Progress
description: PARIS  By finally launching their new monetary system last week, the nine nations of the European Common Market embarked irrevocably on the last of three perilous adventures planned for this year. Besides trying to unify their currencies and the widely differing economic policies that underlie them, they also are committed to giving Europe its first directly elected Parliament and to extending community membership to Greece, Portugal and Spain.

title: Mortgage Money: Must We ay Higher Prices for It?
description: TENANTS and homeowners beware: Mortgage bankers and thrift institutions are engaged in a slick publicrelations campaign. If you do not act immediately, your homes are going to cost a lot more money. Let me explain the facts from the consumer's point of view. We are told that an emergency shortage of mortgage money exists and that the state must raise the ceiling on mortgage interest rates to avert a serious housing crisis.

title: GARDENING
description: A DAFFODIL is a daffodil is a daffodil. The daffodils glorious parade of color will begin as soon as the ground dries out from the deluge. The small members of the species are the earliest to show their true colors and somehow they are all the more special for their diminutive size. Some early daffodils are only several inches high and the flowers are just as cunning. When they fade, it will be time for the major displays to begin.

title: Illegal Immigrants Stir a Controversy
description: NEWARK

title: The New York Times /Edward Hausner
description: What do you do for the 217th rendition of a hit that has played for 216 years? You give em gilded glockenspiels and pounding drums, prancing mounts and preening politicians, giggling children and several miles of marchers in brightly colored uniforms  and you call it a St..Patrick's Day Parade.

title: Letter TO THE EDITOR
description: It is good news that William Satire will be doing a weekly stint (On Language, How Do You Do, Feb. 18) with ammadversions on the uses and misuses of language. A felicitous and facile verbalist, he has long enjoyed the affliction of cocoethes scribendi. As a wordsmith in the less erudite environs of Madison Avenue, 1 have myself sought to match my adwords to both product and prospect, writing always under the injunction: Words are like leaves, and where they most abound, much fruit of sense beneath is rarely found.

title: Few Offers Accrue To Actors in Roots
description: Roots: The Next Generations was an actor's dream  a serious, sensitively written television drama with an audience of 110 million. A presold hit, one actor said. Some entertainment people might have expected that the show  which ran for 14 hours over seven nights on ABCTV, ending Feb. 25  would bring a rush of job offers to some of the young black actors and actresses who contributed so largely to its success. How have they actually fared? Although it is still too early for a complete answer, the indications are that things could be better.

title: Hopes Grow in Aqueduct Strike
description: Hope surfaced yesterday for a break in the 32day labor dispute between parimutuel clerks at Aqueduct and the New York Racing Association.

title: 11 Die in Nursing Home Fire
description: OSLO, Norway, March 17 (AP)  Fire swept through a nursing home in northern Norway late Friday, killing 11 elderly persons in their beds with the fumes from burning plastic furniture, the police reported. They said emergency squads had rescued 16 other patients, nine of whom were then hospitalized, two in serious condition. The home is in the village of Sandnassjon in Nordland.

title: ARAB GULF NATIONS WORRIED BY TREATY
description: BAHRAIN, March 17  Some moderate Arab leaders in the Persian Gulf region are deeply uneasy and others outright angry over the prospect of the signing of an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty that they believe represents a serious political danger to the whole area.

title: POL POT CONFIRMED ASSERTION BY NIXON
description: BANGKOK, Thailand  President Nixon's assertion in 1970 that the American invasion of Cambodia was intended to strike at the headquarters for the entire Communist military operation in South Vietnam has received confirmation from an unexpected but authoritative source.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ANEW and perhaps decisive court attack on the form of government in Ocean Grove is under way.

title: At Synagogue, Hope for Peace Brings Prayers
description: It was a usual Fridayevening service at the Stephen S. Wise Free Synagogue, but with a difference. We give thanks for the promise of peace soon to be fulfilled, said Rabbi Sally Pilesand, who went on to pray that Israel and her neighbors truly touch hands in peaceso may it be.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Energy related issues struck pay dirt last week on Wall Street and, in the process, helped the popular stock averages to continue advancing. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.96 points to 852.82 after running ahead 27 points in the previous week.

title: The Sun Rose Differently
description: ERNEST HEMINGWAY used to say that he'd like to live long enough to become a wise old man. This dream ended nearly two decades ago when, ailing in mind and body, he removed himself permanently and tragically from the status of senior citizen. itherwise, astonishingly enough, he would be elebrating his 80th birthday next July.

description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 17  This is a war, this is a revolution, Dr. Ibrahim Yazdi was saying, explaining the secret courts and the firing squads here. We had to show that we mean business.

title: Shift of Funds From L.I.E. to City Stirs Officials Ire
description: THE decision by the Secretary of Transportation to divert most of the $270 million in Federal funds from major improvements for the Long Island Expressway to other uses in New York City has drawn the ire of Long Island officials and the Borough President of Queens.

description: TOO MUCH DEFENSE: Joe Meriweather of the Knicks fouling Julius Erving of the 76ers as he tried to block scoring attempt last night at the Garden. New York V. on 102ICI.

Seaman of Upper Brookville, L.I., and Willard Mellor of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Helen Mellor, to Thomas Caldwell Turner, son of Mrs. Thomas Turner of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Turner. An August wedding is planned.

title: Pearl Primus, Ph.D., Returns
description: Pearl Primus affects surprise whenever anyone asks her she's still dancing. You don't ask a fish if it has stopped swimming. Of course I'm still dancing! But she understands why people ask the question.

title: Approaches to Unity, Maybe
description: As two groups of Protestant kinfolk, the Disciples of Christ (Christian Church) and the United Church of Christ, last week approved a new round of talks aimed at resolving the relatively small differences that separate them, the gesture fit into a pattern of increased ecumenical activity that is a heartening sign to many church leaders.

title: Miss Chadwick Sets Wedding For September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Macy Chadwick of Newburgh, N.Y., and Fenwick, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Caverly Chadwick, to Martin Colden Hoffman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoffman of Ligonier, Pa. A September wedding is planned.

title: Sheryl B. Roller to Be a Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Roller of Millburh, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Sheryl Bonnie Roller, to Neil R. Elsohn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon R. Elsohn of New York.

title: Childless Women Find Hope in New Clinic
description: NORFOLK, March 17  For 24 hours a day, I slept, drank and ate, thinking about nothing but wanting a child, Diana Savasta says. When they told me I probably could never have children, the first thing I wanted to do was hold a baby in my arms. I want a normal life  I want to buy Pampers and milk and have to try to figure out how to pay the bills.

title: Editors Choice
description: CELEBRATIONS AND ATTACKS, by Irving Howe. (Horizon Press, $14.95.) A selection of the literary and cultural critic's writings, mostly reviews, published during the past 30 years.

title: One Couple's Story: We're More in Love
description: COMMACK AFTER 15 years of togetherness, most married couples limit their written sentiments to a shopping list scrawled on the back of an old envelope or an occasional reminder to feed the cat. Not so for Sheila and Lester Meneilly of Commack. Every day they pen love letters to each other; they say it is because of Marriage Encounter.

title: Harriette Ellison Ford Is Wed
description: Harriette Ellison Ford, vice president and director of fashion publicity of Vassarette, a division of Munsingwear, was married yesterday to Ralph J. Wolfe, vice president and general manager of Panasonic in Secaucus, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation by Canon Robert Lewis. The bride is daughter of Mrs. Ralph Littlefield of New Windsor, N.Y. Mr. Wolfe, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph C.Weife of Holyoke, Mass.

title: The Pentagon Club Closed Ranks to Shut Out Resor
description: WASHINGTON  Several months ago, a Pentagon official walked into the office of another official, settled into a chair and made a request. Do me a favor, he said. Give Stan Resor something to do.

title: PEOPLE
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. announced last week that David M. Culver, president of the giant Canadian aluminum ingot producer, will become chief executive on July 1, ending the long years of control by the Davis family.

title: The Tortuous Path to Peace: A Chronology That Began While Egypt and Israel Were Still at War
description: Sadat's Visit, Camp David and Finally Came the Carter Gamble

title: SPORTS
description: TEANECK THE recent announcement of Stan'Wright's appointment as athletic director at Fairleigh Dickinson University is more than a homecoming for the former Englewood product. It is another significant step in the right direction for coilege sports in New Jersey.

title: Receivership Suspended As Church Posts a Bond
description: LOS ANGELES, March 17 (AP)  Officials of the Worldwide Church of God have posted a $2 million bond in Superior Court to suspend, at least temporarily, the power of the receiver appointed to control the church's assets.

title: How a County Company Sealed a. Deal With China
description: It was midDecember in Peking and Frederick M. Gutterson, an American business executive. was being taken through the city's hipyards. His company, CTTContainer Transport Internationnt Inc., was negotiating to build China's first marine container factory.

title: Letter From London
description: LONDON WRITERS have been feeling the cold in London's snowbound, strikebound, rubbishbound winter. The long hibernation of The Sunday Times, The Times and its supplements especially the Times Literary Supplement  is depriving literary journalists of their principal outlets and authors of their publicity and due recognition. The only positive thing to be said is that the national garbage mountain is lower than it would have been had the papers been published. The journalists drift about evilly, like the thousands of children shut out of schools because of the council workers strike. John Gross, editor of the TLS, like the boy on the burning deck, refuses persuasive offers to leave his ship for more obviously seaworthy vessels, works on a long piece about the letters of D.H. Lawrence for The New York Review of Books and compiles an Oxford Book of Aphorisms. Meanwhile, The Observer  most people's alternative to The Sunday Timesgrows fat and confident, both in its literary and political pages: Conor Cruise O'Brien, its troubleshooting editor in chief, has been crossing swords with historian E.P. Thompson and expressing his vivid Celtic contempt for former Premier Harold Wilson.

title: Connecticut/ThisWeek
description: BRIDGEPORT  Exhibitions and sale of watercolors by Suzanne Crossland, Gallery of Easter Seal Rehab Center, 226 Mill Hill Ave. Through March 30. Weekdays 8:30 to 5. 3667551.

title: What They're Saying
description: John Stearns, angry about the Mets situation: I realize we are the laughingstock of the National League. People are laughing at us and that upsets me. I was at one of the local golf tournaments the other day speaking with a guy from anotner team. He's with a championship ball club that was very active over the winter picking up players and he said to me, What's the matter with your ball club? Aren't you guys doing anything at all?

title: A Report Card on The M.B.A.
description: Arjay Miller, the former president of the Ford Motor Company who shifted gears at midcarcer and entered the academic world, has announced that he will retire on July 1 after 10 years as dean of the Graduate School of Business at Stanford Universal. Under his leadership  marked by the same brisk, efficient style that propelled him through the ranks during his 23 years at Ford  Stanford has risen to challenge Harvard and Chicago for the preeminent spot in graduate business education. And not so coincidentally, the school's endowment has increased from $6.4 million to $23.2 million.

title: Captured American Basks in Stardom of a Viennese LookAlike
description: Soccer fans can be generous in their appreciation. Once upon a time, one of them transformed me into an international soccer star, though I have never played the game and until I met him had never touched a soccer ball.

title: Boy Struck by Train Survives
description: CRANSTON, R.I., March 17 (AP)  A 15yearold boy who was struck by a slowmoving freight train was reported in satisfactory condition today at Rhode Island Hospital. Sgt. Ronald Andersen of the Cranston Police Department said the boy. whose name was not released, hopped on the train for a joy ride, fell off and was hit by a box car, suffering a severe cut in the stomach.

title: Privileged System of British Law Is in Public Dock
description: LONDON, March 17  One of Britain's strongest bastions of privilege and tradition, its ancient, closeknit legal establishment, is under siege.

title: Architecture
description: In recent decades architects have shied away from color. Now two famous advocates of white find that color can be a valuable tool.

title: J.J. Fulmer Fianc Of Susan M. Gallo
description: The engagement of Susan Marie Gallo to James J. Fulmer has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Gallo of Manhasset, L.I., parents of the bridetobe. Mr. Fulmer is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh S. Fulmer of Northboro, Mass., and Thousand Islands Park, N.Y.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH it is not always good idea to splice electrical wires together when a longer length is needed, there are occasions when splicing is a more practical and convenient measure than replacing an entire length of wire. There are also times when a splice must be made in a dualconductor electrical cord as part of a repairing job. it the splice is in an electrical extension cord or in the power cord of a lamp or small appliance, it must be sufficiently strong so that it cannot be easily pulled apart. The drawing shows the correct way to make such a splice.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: If I had to count the pictures I've painted I'd commit suicide, said Alice Neel, the exuberant and prolific 79yearold artist whose retrospective exhibition is on view at the Silvermine Guild of Artists in New Canaan and the University of Bridgeport.

title: After School Aid What?
description: SINCE the State Board of Education and the School Finance Advisory Panei issued their plan for school aid a few weeks ago, little has been said about the impact of the recommendations on town finances. In part, this is because of the complexity of the plan itself. Any town's aid depends on its relative standing on 15 separate statistics, some of which cannot be predicted in advance with complete accuracy.

title: Teton Sioux and Other Indians
description: RFADING Banta Yo is like entering a trance. Sensual and emotional order has been rearranged. Beliefs, perceptions, values held by several tribes of Teton Sioux Indians (Mahto, Palani, Okandada and others) have been sunerirmaosed on his834 pp.New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95. 305 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $9.9,5. 477 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $11.95 tory. Happenings take on strange direction and odd meaning. The English language has been purged of words, tenses, moods that might separate these aborigines from their mythic sources. Human motivations as transmitted to us in the legacies of Aristotle or Freud rarely show in these regions. A curtain separates Hanta Yo from the world we know.

title: USAC Revving Up To Outshine CART
description: By almost all standards, Championship Auto Racing Teams first race last Sunday in Phoenix, Ariz., was a success, with Gordon Johncock taking the checkered flag over a field of 21 starters. The race was nationally televised and attendance was reoorted as 18.000.

title: Kennedy Proposes Court to End TaxLaw Conflicts
description: WASHINGTON, March 17  Senator Edward M. Kennedy has proposed the creation of a new United States court of tax appeals designed to eliminate decades of conflict and confusion in the arcane but commercially important field of tax law.

title: Miss Fratianne Regains Crown
description: VIENNA, March 17 (UPI)  Linda Fratianne, the 18yearold Californian, regained the world title in figure skating tonight. heating her archrival, Anett Poetrich of East Germany, the defending champion.

title: U.C.L.A. Rally Falls Short in 9591 Loss
description: PROVO, Utah, March 17  De Paul moved the crowd to its feet and itself to the semifinal round of the National Collegiate basketball tournament today by upsetting the University of California, Los Angeles, 9591.

title: 500 Assail Trap Cruelty At FurTrade Gathering
description: More than 500 people opposed to the use of leghold traps to catch more than 80 million fur animals annually in the United States and Canada staged a noisy but peaceful fourhour demonstration yesterday outside the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, where hundreds of furriers and fur designers gathered for a banquet to open the International Fur Fair.

title: Gain for Conservatives Expected on Eve of Finnish Vote
description: HELSINKI, Finland, March 17  Finland will choose a new Parliament tomorrow and Monday, and once again the Soviet Union will be looking balefully over the Finns shoulders.

title: Striking Baton Rouge Teachers, At Stores, Seek Public Support
description: BATON ROUGE, La., March 17 ( ?????)  Striking teachers, who want the school board to negotiate with their union, lobbied for public support in shopping centers today and predicted that their numbers would swell Monday.

title: Crafts Jury Stresses Quality In Selecting for Show
description: IN a darkened room, five slide projectors advanced simultaneously, presenting for the jury five pieces of work by each craftsman hoping to participate in Spring Market 79, a New Haven crafts fair sponsored by the Connecticut Craft Professionals at the Goffe Street Armory.

title: Beth Bond, Student at Post, To Be Married to Scott Levy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin S.J. Bond of Merrick, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth Marci Bond, to Scott David Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Levy of the Bronx.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: There was perhaps the tinge of an Eric Ambler plot in the death of Col. Arthur Finehout, the American Army military adviser to Iran. He was found hanged in his quarters in Teheran last Jan. 16, an apparent suicide. But there was no immediate explanation as to why the colonel, who was chief of staff of the United States Military Assistance Advisory Group in Iran, would have taken his life.

title: Key Role for Florio In Amtrak Hearings
description: WASHINGTON

title: No Signing Date Is Set For a Mideast Accord
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)  A White House official said today that no date had been fixed, even tentatively, for the signing here of the prospective EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: Meeting the Encyclopedist of Rail Travel
description: Have trouble unraveling a railroad timetable? How about a real challenge  a book of timetables covering 60,1)00 trains in 120 countries? The book, known as the Thomas Cook International Railway and Local Shipping Service  the Guide for short is published monthly, has 530 pages and contains information on trains in every corner of the world.

title: PAPEBBACK TALK
description: Book people. Publishing, gloomsayers keep a;serting, is fast becoming an impersonal business, conJed in skyscrapers and superintended by accountAnts whose only interest in books is the bottom line. Maybe. But take a ride or two into the countryside Fiction factory. From Manhattan, drive up the Taconic Parkway for two and a half hours, turning of as if you were going to Tanglewood. Shortly before you reach the Massachusetts line, in a village called Canaan, you'll come upon three Tudorstyle buildings amid snowcovered fields in which a herd of deer roam. This is Book Creations Inc., a fiction factory operated by 63yearold Lyle Kenyon Engel. With the help of his wife, son and a dozen editors and typists from the neighborhood, Mr. Engel will create, before 1979 is out, 75 plump novels for publication by 10 leading paperback houses  Ace, Bantam, Dell, Fawcett, Jove, New American Library, Pinnacle, Playboy Press, Pocket and Warner. Every one will sell in the hundreds of thousands of copies.

title: Suburban Officials Ponder New School Financing
description: PORT CHESTER, N.Y., March 17Representatives of school board associations in counties surrounding New York City  concerned about the effects of a New York State Supreme Court decision requiring the eqiialization of school financing of public education  gathered here today to form an ad hoc panel to establish the financial needs of downstate suburban counties.

title: Deaths
description: KERENBerdie. On March 15, 1979. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Jerry and Arthur. Loving grandmother of Donna, Robert, Philip, Michael and Stuart. Services today 10:45 AM at The Colonial Chapels of I.J. Morris Inc.. 46 Greenwich St.. Hempstead, L.I. Miami and Fort Lauderdale. Fla., Papers please ccpy.

title: Other World Events
description: Procrastination is good electoral policy in the view of Pierre Elliott Trudeau.
