The Canadian Prime Minister, who must call an election by midsummer, is postponing in the evident hope that the threat of Quebec separatism will win back his old popularity among other Canadians. Out west in Alberta, however, that is clearly not the case. In elections for the provincial legislature last week, the opposition Progressive Conservative Party took 74 of seats.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE workout at the bar had been in progress for a half hour, and Lesli Lyon was perspiring along with the other 15 students of the ballet practicing under the watchful eye of Valia Selskaya. All were working hard, and all, from the two 11yearolds to the mature women who were part of the advanced class, showed some ability, good technique or promise of developing it.

title: Innovation at the Forever Bicycle Factory
description: SHANGHAI  What's been happening at the Forever Bicycle Factory reflects much of the recent history  economic and, to a degree, political of China. It is a story of product development, improved productivity, bootstrap automation and a new sense of freedom and nurnose.

title: Tenneco Oil Fined $300,000
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 17 (AP)  A Federal district judge has ordered the maximum fine. $300,000, against the Tenneco Oil Company, convicted of making illegal payments to the sheriff in a New Orleans suburb. Judge Robert F. Collins levied a $10,000 fine on each of 30 counts of mail fraud.

title: Boston Museum to Open Branch Near Faneuil Hall
description: BOSTON, March 17  The Museum of Fine Arts will open a branch at the bustling Faneuil Hall Marketplace on Boston's waterfront this spring in what the museum believes to be the first move by a major art institution into a business development.

title: A GENERATION OF LOST SCHOLARS
description: Not long ago, The Claremont Courier, a smalltown newspaper in California, received this job application: I graduated last month from U.C.L.A. with a Ph.D. in philosophy. I am now looking for a job in the real world since the academic world is apparently closed to me. I would like to write for The Courier. I do not type very fast but I use all 10 fingers.

title: Marriages
description: MARY RHOAD DuJANY of Yonkers, N Y has announced the marriage of her daughter Honorine B DeJany to Willam Powers Bagwell. son of Cath??ine Lennon Bagwell, of Queens. N Y The bride is the daughter also of the late Albert Peter DuJany.

title: New Appeal Is Made to Brezhnev To Let Nureyev's Mother Leave
description: LONDON, March 17 (Reuters)  A group of musicians, actors and playwrights today called on President Leonid I. Brezhnev of the Soviet Union to allow Farida Nureyev, the ailing mother of Rudolf Nureyev, the dancer, to visit her son in the West.

title: THEATER
description: THE 1964 musical Funny Girl is probably better remembered for making a star of Barbra Streisand than for itself. The implication is that Funny Girl wasn't a very good show and wouldn't have made it without the thennew excitement of Miss Streisand's presence and a few songs, such as People and Don't Rain on My Parade, that caught the public's fancy.

title: Oil Supplies Squeezed as Consumption Rises, Inventories Fall
description: If petroleum is, as its purveyors would have it, industrial America's lifeblood, the news last week must have sent leaders scrambling for a transfusion. among the cteveiopments: The nation's consumption of oil has been running at record levels in recent weeks, and inventories are dangerously depleted. A new oilcompany global distribution system, it turns out, will cut imports to the United States twice as much as shipments to other consuming nations. Construction of a $1 billion pipeline that would have moved Alaskan oil to market, and made for maximum Alaskan production, has been canceled.

title: Spring May Be a Little Late Each Year
description: WHEN does a Westchester winter end? Shall we be optimistic and call spring by equality of day and night, by the vernal equinox on March 21? In terms of weather, that date is too early for spring.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: DETROIT  In the five years since the 1973 Arab oil embargo sent shock waves through the American economy. the automobile industry has suffered one of its greatest slumps in sales and employment and staged an amazing rebound. Today it is showing an apparently impressive  but in fact illusory  ability to sustain the momentum of that turnaround.

title: New Rule to Change Lacrosse
description: The lacrosse season is ready to open with a drastic reduction in faceoffs this season. As a result, players are trying to cope with new tactics on offense and defense, new transition flows and new game plans.

title: Letters
description: A U.S. Plan to Aggravate EastWest Tension

title: A Life of Letters
description: 'M AIL is very eventful to me, Flannery O'Connor wrote to a friend in October 1951. This was so because the illness that had been detected earlier in the year, a then incurable disease of the blood vessels called lupus ervthematos.

title: LongBlooming Perennials For the Busy Gardener
description: Any gardener who is busy or perhaps lazy can save time and work by planting longblooming flowers. These are some of my favorite perennials which can be ordered at this time of year and set out as soon as the soil is ready.

title: Emily Sears Lodge to Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Cabot Lodge of Beverly, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily Sears Lodge, to Robert Ren Pingeon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Rene A. Pingeon of Mendham, N.J.

title: Bryan FerryThe Edgar Allan Poe of Rock
description: Bryan Ferry is alive and well and looking for an apartment in Manhattan. America is a great challenge to me, the English rock star explains, as a kind of archseducer. Here there are so many reluctant brides, so many potential ears to seduce? Who could resist?

title: Weicker: Bit of Luck On Time and Place
description: ONE thing you have to remember about Lowell Weicker is that he has had the uncanny, Godgiven ability or maybe just the plain good luck  to be in the right place at the right time, a Greenwich Republican who has watched the Senator's career over the years was saving not limn.

title: Historic lona Island to Be Sold
description: INVERARAY, Scotland, (Reuters) Iona, the island where Saint Columba landed from Ireland in 563 and built his base for the conversion of the Picts and Scots, has been offered for sale. The trustees of the 10th Duke of Argyll were reportedly asking $2 million for the island to raise money to pay death duties for the estate of the duke, who died in 1919.

title: Stenmark Wins, Ties Ski Mark
description: FURANO, Japan, March ]7 (AP) Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden, moving through the gates with precision, won the men's slalom race today and tied the record for the most World Cup ski victories in a season at 12. If he wins the giant slalom tomorrow, he will have 13 victories, including a sweep of the 10 giant slaloms, breaking the mark of 12 set by JeanClaude Killy of France.

title: Arafat and King Hussein Discuss How They Will React to Treaty
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 17  Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization met today to discuss what Palestinian sources said would be their opposition to the Americansponsored EgyptianIsraeli treaty.

title: Health
description: The advent of tranquilizers in the 1950's revolutionized the treatment of the mentally ill. It drastically reduced the number of institutionalized mental patients: In 1955, there were 559.000 patients in the country's state mental hospitals; today, there are fewer than 170,000. In addition, tranquilizers have enabled many people who might otherwise have been incapacitated to lead productive lives. But it is now becoming increasingly apparent that antipsychotic drugs  the major tranquilizers  are creating, as a side effect, a serious and bizarre disorder that has a bizarre name: tardive dyskinesia.

title: Headliners
description: The life of genius, sometimes, is but short. Adela Holzer was a genius at the end of the 1960's, when she claimed a $2 million profit on a $50,000 investment in the hit musical Hair. As a Broadway producer with three shows simultaneously on the boards in 1975, she was still pretty smart, and people who knew how smart she was gave her their money to invest. But last week, a State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan gave her a failing grade at last. The jury found her guilty of five counts of grand larceny in defrauding investors who had given her money for automobile dealerships in Indonesia and realestate deals in Spain. Mrs. Holzer said she could have cleared herself if she had been able to go to Europe and Indonesia for proof.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Zaire defaults on its international obligations  Turkey refuses to accept I.M.F. demands for domestic austerity  Poland agrees to permit Western banks to monitor economic policies in return for a new foreign loan. These events of the last two months are related: They all derive from extensive external borrowing by countries in response to balance of payments deficits. By providing a major portion of these funds, the commercial banks of the United States have become intimately involved in the affairs of the borrowing nations, with implications that extend far beyond the profitability and strength of the commercial banking system to serious foreign policy matters.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: Q. I have a 1968 sixcylinder Plymouth with 140,000 miles to its credit. Until the car is thoroughly warmed up, the transmission is reluctant to move from one speed to another. When it does shift, it does so with a thud. The transmission fluid has never been changed. Would changing the fluid at this point lead to any other problems?

title: Wetlands, Wildlife and Gambling: Do Casinos Endanger Brigantine?
description: OCEANVILLE TEN miles north of Atlantic City lies the Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge, 20,229 acres of woods and fields, salt marsh, tidal bays, freshwater pools and barrier beaches. In November and March, thousands of snow geese stop there to feed on their way to and from their Arctic breeding grounds. In late April, the northbound shorebird migration brings sandpipers.

title: Two Winners
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 17 Twelve hours earlier, Wayne McKoy had banked in the rebound of Reggie Carter's jump shot to put St. John's into tomorrow's Eastern Regional final against Penn in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament. Now they were having breakfast today in a booth at Howard Johnson's, the 6foot8inch sophomore center from Bayside, Queens, and the 63 junior guard from Harlem who have been longtime teammates and friends. Wayne McKoy had demolished his bacon and scrambled eggs, and Reggie Carter was wading through his stack of pancakes when a St. John's rooter in a red sweater hovered above them.

title: Notes: To the Source of Tut's Treasure
description: Although Americans have been flocking to the exhibit of the Treasures of King Tut at museums across the United States, they are seeing only about 2 percent (55 pieces) of the 3,059 items found in the boy pharoah's tomb. The rest remain in Egypt. As a resuit of heightened interest, tourism to Egypt has been increasing 20 percent a year, and many travel organizations are expanding their tour programs.

title: ANTIQUES
description: RIDGEFIELD Just because an object is crude, has a few old paint smears and is older than one's parents, doesn't mean that it is antique or should be called folk art. So says Judy Lenett, who collects and,deals in folk art, an often misundersood categorv of antioues.

title: trails
description: FRESEArnold D. 74. Died yesterday after a short illness. Av. Frese was tom in Bremen. Germany, on March 14. 1905, and came to the USA in 1426. He Joined States Marire Corporation in 1931 and held series of management positions, serving as Financial Vice President and in later years as Chairman of Global Bulk Transport, Inc. He is survived by his wife Ines G. Frese and Mrs. Freae's daughter Mrs. John M. Kingsley. Jr. Funeral Ser. vices and burial will be Private. Please omit flowers.

title: United Airlines and Machinists Called Intent on Reaching Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) Robert O. Harris, a member of the National Mediation Board, said today that negotiators for United Airlines and the Machinists and Aerospace Workers union were intent on reaching an agreement.

title: Kathleen McNeily Plans a June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter W.G. McNeily of Kennett Square, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Collett McNeily, to George Martin Davis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Davis of Franklin Shrines. N.Y.

title: 42d Street, New Dance By Rinker
description: Everyone who was anyone or nearly so in the dance world seemed to be at the American Theater Laboratory on Thursday for Kenneth Rinker's new Forty Second/92d Street Variations. Mr. Rinker's cool impudence and even cooler technical facility brought him special attention in the years he danced with Twyla Tharp, and he has remained a hot item on the chic circuit.

title: South Africa's Angry Press Is in a NoWin Situation
description: JOHANNESBURG  The South African Government and the opposition Englishlanguage press have been at each others throats for more than 30 years. But the dispute has rarely been more acrimonious, or involved issues of greater consequence, than that surrounding the Information Ministry scandal of the past year. Last week, the affair appeared to be moving toward a climax, with investigating newspapers hinting at future revelations that would show some top officials to be liars, cheats and swindlers, and the Government reviving threats to stifle the journalistic assaults on the national interest once and for all.

title: Illegal Aliens in New York: A Life of Fear, Costly to All
description: The instructions were simple: Climb the stairs to the second floor and knock on the only door without a name or a number.

title: Miss O'Donoghue And Pedro Castillo Set April Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul O'Done)ghue of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Estelle O'Donoghue, to Pedro Alejandro Castillo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pedro Antonio Castillo of Darien, Conn.

title: Winning in Sports and Winning in Life
description: Growing up playing sports, all sports, I always wanted to win. I was never pleased with just having played well if I was not a winner.

title: World News Briefs
description: NIAMEY. Niger. March 17 (Reuters)  President Felix MaBoum of Chad will resign and support the leader of the Libyanbacked rebels under an agreement to end the country's civil war, informed sources said here today.

title: Doctors Rebellion Imperils Canadian Health Plan
description: OTTAWA, March 17  A threat by the federal Government to reduce its financial contribution to health care has highlighted developing strains in one of the world's most comprehensive systems of medical insurance.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: PLAINVIEW ONE of the few corners of the Island that can expect a population boom in the next few years is a small section of Plainview surrounded by an unobtrusive cordon of electric and telephone wires, called an eruv.

title: A Wall of Glass in Connecticut
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  When Richard Knabel closes his house at night, he activates a motor that causes a glass wall to fill with styrofoam beads, a process so odd it sometimes stops traffic. Traffic, however, is not one of his concerns  the heavy insulation in his house provides such quiet, he says, that sometimes he cannot even believe traffic is going by.

title: A City Bleeding
description: SOMETIME in 1993, Norman Lewis, a Welsh novelist and journalist, the author of an extraordinary study of the Mafia in Sicily, volunteered for the British Intelligence Corps and was turned down, he says, because of the color of his eyes. The 206 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $8.95. Selection Officer believed that blue was the color of Truth, and Mr. Lewis, along with others whose eyes betrayed them, was tipped into the dust bin of the Field Security Police, an agency that seemed to improvise its missions and whose officers were frequently given to making up alarming rumors to fill in the emptiness of the weekly reports. After service in North Africa, he was posted to Naples, and Naples 44 is a diary  vivid, lucid, eloquent, often funny, more often bitter and melancholy  of his years in and around the stunned and bleeding city, which he came to regard as essentially Oriental in character. He quotes one Scarfoglio, a leading turnofthecentury observer: Naples is the only Eastern city without a residential European quarter.

title: More and More, Jupiter and its Moons Resemble the Solar System in Miniature
description: When, in the early 17th century, Galileo found four moons orbiting Jupiter, he realized that his discovery confirmed the Copernican proposition that the earth and other planets are in orbit around the sun.

title: Gable, Iowa Put Stranglehold on N.C.A.A. Wrestling
description: The 49th National Collegiate wrestling championships at Iowa State University in Ames was  as expected  a homestate brawl between two of college wrestling's country cousins. The Iowa schools have dominated the N.C.A.A. Division I tournament for the last 10 years. Iowa State has won five out of 10; Iowa has won four out of the last five championships, winning this year on the mats of its intrastate rival from the Big Eight.

title: T.P.R.: Islanders Move In on the Canadiens
description: The computerized team power ratings this week show little movement at the top of the National Hockey League since the most recent T.P.R. evaluation of hockey clubs, two weeks ago. This reflects remarkably even play among the 10 toprated clubs during the latest evaluation period, from Feb. 27 through last Monday. In fact the New York Islanders, the New York Rangers and the Boston Bruins, still ranked second, third and fourth, had identical records during that period: three victories, two losses and two ties.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Drilling Vessel Probes Mysteries Of Sunken Island Chain in Pacific
description: A mile beneath the frigid waters of the North Pacific, the deepsea drilling ship Glomar Challenger has bored into a chain of sunken islands that, it has been shown, were a counterpart of today's Hawaii.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, MARCH 19, 1979

title: Digest BUSINESS
description: The Joint Economic Committee has urged the Administration and Congress to combat inflation by encouraging savings and investment, the committee said in its annual report. In an apparent philosophical shift, the committee's report stressed relatively conservative economic means to fight inflation instead of advocating such liberal measures as tax cuts and direct spending. [Page D1.]

title: Toxic Alcohol Kills 20 in India
description: NEW DELHI, March 18 (AP)  Atoxicl batch of homemade alcohol killed 20 of the people who drank it and sent more than 50 others to hospitals, the United News of India reported today.

title: Opera: Met Recasts Flute
description: SATURDAY night's performance of The Magic Flute at the Metropolitan Opera, the eighth of the season, featured an almost entirely different cast than the )ne with which the opera entered the repertory a month ago. Two singers, Dale Duesing as Papageno and John ShirleyQuirk as the High Priest, were heard in roles they had never taken at the Met before this year.

title: United Press International
description: FLOOD FORCES EVACUATION OF COLORADO TOWN: Residents Wheat Ridge taking refuge in the cafeteria of the local high school. An inflatable dam at a reservoir near the Denver suburb gave way unleashing 30 million gallons of water and causing 1,500 persons to flee their homes.

title: Arafat Intends to Seek Embargo of Oil to U.S.
description: Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that he would ask for an oil embargo against the United States at the next Arab summit conference and the next conference of the foreign ministers.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Prudential's Beck Studies Idea of a Big Board Seat Since Robert A. Beck became chairman and chief executive officer of the Prudential Insurance Company of America last September, he has been taking a close look at many of the giant insurer's activities. And one area that is very much on his mind is the possibilty that the Pru  the nation's largest insurance company with $50 billion in assets  will apply for membership on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Gulf Pact Set With Scallop
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said it had reached an agreement with Scallop Nuclear Inc., a unit of the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group, under which the uranium supply and light water reactor fuel fabrication activities of the General Atomic Company would be operated for the account and benefit of Gulf Oil. Gulf and Scallop jointly own General Atomic.

title: A Nominee for Jersey Chief Justice Who Is Direct and Methodical
description: TRENTON, March 16  In 1966, when Robert Nathan Wilentz, the normnee to be New Jersey's new Chief Justice, first rose in the State Assembly to make a speech, everyone saw the son of David T. Wilentz, one of the state's most powerful political figures.

title: Marcos Calls for Freer Debate, But Many Politicians Are Wary
description: MANILA, March 18  President Ferdinand E. Marcos has told members of the National Assembly he created a year ago that they should debate more vigorously, for it is all right to be efficient but it better to be free.

title: Hospital Agency's Head Press for Fiscal Reforms
description: Joseph C. Hoffman, the head of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation, has ordered his top executives to devise and implement within two weeks detailed programs intended to put the beleagured agency's financial house in order.

title: Locker Room Policies Pondered
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 18  Neither the Yankees nor the Mets have made a final decision on the exact procedure by which they will grant female members of the press corps equal access to locker rooms this year.

title: UnItecl Press International
description: FINLAND'S PRESIDENT VOTES IN HELSINKI: Urho Kekkonen, the 78yearold leader of the Social Democrats, casting vote yesterday during the first day of twoday general elections. A gain of about five percent for the Conservative party has been forecast, which would make the party Finland's second largest with about 45 of 200 seats in Parliament.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Angolan issue.

title: Blast at British Mine Kills
description: LONDON, March 18 (AP) methanegas explosion today at a coal mine near Wigan, northeast of Liverpool, killed three miners and badly burned eight others, the National Coal Board reported.

title: Wheat Trade Ban Ends
description: CHICAGO, March 18  A Federal judge, responding to a plea by the Chicago Board of Trade, issued a preliminary injunction tonight. The injunction blocks enforcement of an order by Washington regulators to terminate the commodity exchange's trading in March wheat futures.

title: TURKEY'S RELATIONS WITH U.S. STILL TENSE;
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey. March 12  Five months ago. 26 United States military monitoring stations and support installations across Turkey reopened after a fouryear suspension. The move was supposed to usher in a new era in TurkishAmerican relations. It has not.

title: In crimeRidden Lagos. Public ExecutIons Draw Crowds
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, March 18  On Bar Beach. which is known for its undertow, among other deadly things, two men talked the other day about the crime problem here.

title: Beets
description: MABONMary Frost, on March 16, after a long illness. Wite of the late James Brown Mahon. Survived by her daughter Candida Mators Dixon, her sister Rosamund Frost Lowell and three grandsons. Memorial mass at Church of St. Viecent Ferrer, Wednesday, March 21 at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to American Federation of the Arts.

title: OUTLOOK UNCERTAIN FOR NAMIBIA PARLEY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Mar. 18 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and ministers of Britain, Canada, France and West Germany held private strategy talks this evening in preparation for the start tomorrow of two days of neEotiations aimed a persuading South Africa to cooperate in bringing about a ceasefire) in SouthWest Africa and United Nationssupervised elections leading to independ1 ence for the territory.

title: Rebecca Riger Is Bride Of Yoshihiro Tsurumi
description: The marriage of Rebecca Riger to Prof. Yoshihiro Tsurumi, director of the Pacific Basin Economic Study Center at the University of California at Los Angeles's Graduate School of Management, took place yesterday at the St. Moritz. Rabbi Philip E. Schechter, assisted by Cantor Robert Abelson, performed the ceremony.

title: 3 Die in Crash of Light Plane
description: LOS ANGELES, March 18 (AP)  A pilot and his two teenage passengers were killed when a light plane lost its left wing and plummeted to the ground near the Golden State Freeway, the authorities said. No one on the ground was hurt.

title: Key Legislators See No Increase In Relief Grants
description: An increase in the basic monthly welfare allowance  called for by Mayor Koch and some legislators  will not be part of the new state budget, the chairmen of the Fiscal Committees of both houses of the State Legislature said yesterday.

title: The Rookies to Watch in 79
description: IN the old days they arrived at spring training with no contract, no money and no great shot at a job, and they even had to claw their way into the batting cage to take a few swings. They were called rube or busher, and one of them 65 years ago was called the Babe, because he was General Manager ST. PETERSBURG, FLA. Jack Dunn's baby on the old Baltimore Orioles.

title: Expansion. 4 Years Old, Strong
description: The economic recovery turned years old this month, making it one of the longest business expansions on ecord. But economists who follow business cycles say the unusual length of the current growth phase does not by itself mean that a downturn is near.

title: Pop: Nicolette Larson
description: NICOLETTE LARSON arrived at the Bottom Line last weekend with all the makings of a triumph. She didn't have one. at least at the Friday early show.

title: U.S. BEGINS A REVIEW ON JOBS FOR YOUTHS
description: The White House has begun a review of the arsenal of youth employment programs that constitute, in the words of one Federal manpower official, the largest social experiment the nation has ever undertaken.

title: Redmen Miss Last 3 Shots
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 18 As the clock ticked 08.07.06, St. Jhon's University's last shot for a chance to reach the Final Four became a second and a third shot. But the shots did not go in, and the University of ??? won the National Collegied. East regional basketball final to day, 6462.

title: Jazz Dance: Pepsi Bethel
description: PEPSI BETHEL, a popular dance teacher at New York's Clark Center, brought his Authentic Jazz Dance Theater back to the Theater of the Riverside Church on Saturday. The familiar program covered black dance from the Caribbean to Harlem and from the juba to the mooche, for an afternoon of familiar pleasures and disappointments.

title: Baker First At Atlanta; Crewman Is Killed
description: HAMPTON, Ga., March 18 (AP) Buddy Baker benefited from mechanical problems that slowed his two closest competitors during the final 100 miles and sped on to an 18second victory today in the Atlanta 500 Grand National stock car race.

title: Dr. Karen G. Kelly Bride of Physician
description: Dr. Karen Grace Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vilar F. Kelly of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Dr. William Kramer Levy, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward D. Levy of Norfolk, Va. The Rev. David Dumcombe, chaplain of the Yale Medical School, performed the Protestant ceremony at Waveny House.

title: Deaths
description: BOROCHOWSKYMichel. On Saturday March 17th. of Elizabeth, N.J., Rockville Centre, N.Y., and N.Y.C. and N.YC., beloved husband of Tuba (nee Ravicher), dear father of Claire Angel. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chaoels, at Millburn. 2950 Vauxhall Road,, Union, N.J., Monday March 19th 1979 at 10:30 A.M. Interment Mt. Lebanal Cemetery, Iselin. N.J. Period of Mourning will be observed at the residence at Mr. 8 Mrs. Myron Angel, 625 Willow Grove Road. West field, N.J.

title: ESSAY Four Other Scandals
description: WASHINGTON  Man says: What do you think of Carter? Other man replies: I like him. I like his Mideast policy and I like his forthrightness. The only thing I don't like about him is his brother  the one in the White House.

title: Fight Urged On Inflation By Savings
description: WASHINGTON, March 18  The Joint Economic Committee of Congress, in an annual report that stressed conservative rather than liberal themes, urged Congress and the Administration today to combat inflation and expand employment by encouraging savings and investment.

title: Mrs. Moser Takes 6th World Cup Title
description: FURANO, Japan, Monday, March 19 (AP)  Annemarie Proell Moser of Austria captured her sixth World Cup ski title today. By finishing second in the final race of the season, she overtook Hanni Wenzel of Liechtenstein, the defending champion, in the overall standing.

title: Market Place
description: THE bankruptcy of the Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust two weeks ago may have discouraged many investors who have been attracted to the yields offered by banksponsored real estate investment trusts.

title: Competency Tests in Basic Skills Cost Few Pupils Their Diplomas
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.  Six years ago officials of the Kern High School District, concerned about declining student achievement, installed one of the nation's first minimumcompetency testing programs.

title: Assailant Is Disarmed And Mortally Stabbed By Brooklyn Man, 79
description: A 79yearold Brooklyn man on his way back from buying a bottle of soda Saturday night disarmed and stabbed to death a knifewielding teenage mugger who had him pressed against a basement wall and was reaching for his wallet, the police said yesterday.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 29, 38, 1, 13, 25 and 16. The supplementary number was 26.

title: Plywood Profits Sought By International Paper
description: The International Paper Company, which has spent the last five years fruitlessly looking for riches below the five million acres of forest land it owns in the South, now plans to harvest them from the trees growing above.

title: Abortion Aid Curb Weighed in Albany
description: ALBANY, March 18Legislative leaders and Governor Carey are seeking to resolve a seemingly inevitable deadlock over the emotional issue of public financing of abortions.

title: Notes on People
description: Of all the socalled Iron Curtain nations, the two that remain the most standoffish, even in respect to cultural exchanges, are Albania and East Germany. Occasionally there is a tear in the East German curtain, however, and the latest opening will admit as an honored guest Lee Strasberg, founding father of New York's Actors Studio and guru of the Stanislayskian method school of theater. In late spring, he hopes to accept an invitation to hold a twoweek series of seminars in East Berlin.

title: Stage: English Drama, Ride a Cock Horse
description: DAVID MERCER's Ride a Cock Horse is a play in three arguments and a nervous breakdown.

title: ISRAEL AND EGYPT STILL SEEK ACCORD ON SINAI TIMETABLE
description: WASHINGTON, March 18  The defense ministers of Egypt and Israel were unable today to decide on the exact timetable for Israel's initial troop withdrawals from Sinai, the last unresolved question in the peace treaty that is expected to be signed later this month.

title: Deaths
description: GATESSamuel E. The Board of Directors of Grosvenor Neighborhood House, Inc, records with sorrow the loss of our good friend. Samuel E. Gates. For many years he was a devoted friend who gave unstintingly of his time. We wish to express sympathy to his wife, Philomene A. Gates, Board Member, and to hfs family.

title: A Fresh Face for the Assembly
description: The voters of New York City's 62d Assembly District, which takes in lower Manhattan and the eastern edge of Staten Island, will choose a replacement tomorrow for Louis DeSalvio, who resigned his Assembly post after 38 years to take a job with the State Insurance Fund. The district is split not only by the Upper Bay but by ethnic and economic differences that make this an unusually complicated election.

title: Posting of Transit Policemen Starts On All Nighttime Subways Tonight
description: The keystone of Mayor Koch's $7.5 million crackdown on crime in New York City's subways  the posting of transit police officers on all nighttime trains and in virtually all stationsgoes into effect tonight with a massive transfer of transit detectives and plainclothes officers into uniform to meet the expanded patrol requirements.

title: Israeli Food Up
description: JERUSALEM, March 18 (Reuters)  Food prices in Israel soared overnight after the Finance Ministry announced a $100 million cut yesterday in Government subsidies for basic commodities.

title: ISRAELI PARTY ISSUES THREAT OVER TREATY
description: JERUSALEM, March 18  On the eve of a Cabinet meeting to approve the IsraeliEgyptian peace treaty, a conservative religious party has sparked an uproar by publicly threatening to resign from the Government unless Prime Minister Menachem Begin accepts its demands to insure that the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip remain firmly under Israeli control.

title: Knicks Fade in 2d Half, Bow to 76ers
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 18  The Knickerbockers lost their momentum in the second half this afternoon and dropped a 10690 decision to the Philadelphia 76ers at the Spectrum.

title: Some Sicilian Victims of 1968 Quake Still Homeless
description: GIBELLINA. Sicily  There is little traffic on the new road that winds through the Belice Valley in the stark hills of western Sicily, and few of the tour. ists who ride in orange buses to the Greek ruins at Selinunte know that thousands of people around here who lost their homes in an earthquake 11 years ago are still living in wooden shacks under corrugatediron roofs.

title: Coast Race Goes To Noble Dancer
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 18 (AP)  Noble Dancer won the San Luis Rey Stakes for the second time in a row today, scoring a 2length victory over Tiller in the the $162,800 event.

title: Car Enters Road Exit  4 Killed
description: DALLAS, March 18 (AP)  Four persons were killed and three others were lured yesterday when a car entered the busy Interstate 35 freeway going the wrong way and collided headon with another auto that in turn struck a pickup truck, the police said.

title: Peace Seems Attractive to Cairo Students
description: paused between classes at Cairo University to discuss the pending peace treaty with Israel. At least we will have an advanced country in the neighborhood,

title: Wendy Osinoff Married To Sheldon M. Goldstein
description: Wendy Lynn Osinoff, daughter of Jean Zisser of New York and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Gerald K. Osinoff of New York and Lido Beach, L.I., was married yesterday at the Regency Hotel to Sheldon M. Goldstein, ion of Mr. and Mrs. Morris J. Goldstein of Swampscott, Mass. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW. March 18 (Reuters) Soviet airliner on a flight from Odessa crashed yesterday near Moscow's Vnukovo Airport, causing some casualties, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: Sages And/or Scientists?
description: MANTIC. Conn.  During the 1950's and 1960's, it was the fashion among moral philosophers to spend much of their time demonstrating by rigorous argument that moral terms such as good and bad, right and wrong, and ought and ought not simply express irrational bursts of feeling, having no more significance than Yummie! and Ugh!

title: A China Hand: Young, Witty And Untiring
description: PEKING  When W. Michael Blumenthal, the Secretary of the Treasury, conferred here with Deng Xiaoping, the senior Deputy Prime Minister, and Hua Guotene, the party chairman. the man seated at the Secretary's right hand on both occasions was J. Stapleton Roy, a 43yearold Foreign Service officer who spent much of his boyhood in China.

title: Space Shuttle May Move Today
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE. Calif., March 18 (UPI)  The space shuttle Columbia may get under way for its piggyback flight to Florida atop a Boeing 747 jet tomorrow morning if weather permits, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today. The flight to Cape Canaveral for final outfitting has been held up for a week.

title: City Maintains That Census Undercounts Illegal Aliens
description: Representatives and direct taxes shall be apportioned among the several States which may be included within the Union according to their respective numbers.... The actual enumeration shall be made within three years after the first meeting of the Congress of the United States, and every subsequent term of 10 years in such manner as they shall by law direct. Article 1, Section 2, Constitution of the United States.

title: Trial to Open for Suspect in 3 Oklahoma Girls Deaths
description: PRYOR, Okla., March 18  Testimony is expected to begin here tomorrow in the trial of Gene Leroy Hart, a 35yearold Cherokee charged with the slayings of three young Girl Scouts at a nearby camp two summers ago.

title: Supplementary OTC Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I have been increasingly irritated by editorials, essays, etc. advising Mayor Koch that it is his duty to kowtow to various union bosses, ethnic poohbahs and neighborhood rabblerousers in the interest of some sort of unity or concord. But the final straw is Oscar W. McCrary's letter [March 10] asserting that the Mayor's attitude has an uncanny similarity, especially for blacks, to an American historical experience found during slavery.

title: its
description: SCHWARTZAbraham. The stockholders and Directors of the New Nautilus Hotel regret the loss of our distinguished member.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee will meet tomorrow with four new members and a complex problem  what course to set for monetary policy at a time of soaring inflation and conflicting trends in the economy. The chances seem good that it will decide to tighten a bit.

title: Brzezinski Fails to Get the Backing Of Saudi Arabia or Jordan for Pact
description: RIYADH. Saudi Arabia, March 18 Zb:gniew Brzezinski left here today without winning Saudi support for the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: Islanders Defeat North Stars, 53
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 18 The New York Islanders won their fourth straight game tonight, defeating the Minnesota North Stars, 53, in the Met Sports Center.

title: Ford Race: 3 Agencies Seen Ahead
description: IT looks as if the Ford Motor Companv has ended up considering the three ad agencies that most of Madison Avenue thought they would end up considering to replace Kenyon & Eckhardt on the LincolnMercury account. Besides Ogilvy & Mather, they are Young & Rubicam and Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, the two agencies that lost most of the Chrysler business that K.&E. picked up. None of these three agencies acknowledge being in the running  Ford for some reason is insisting on secrecy  but street talk has it so.

title: Flowers, Fangs, Fear
description: EAST LONGMEADOW, Mass. She carries herself like a lady, but she can't take time to be polite. She interrupts my question with an insistent No! as if. the repetition will make me go away faster. Cataract lenses enlarge the dull alarm in her eves.

title: Ballet: Bernhard Troupe In Rarely Seen Works
description: THE Bernhard Ballet, which performed Saturday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, is a new small company from Connecticut founded in 1977 with Genia Melikova as artistic director and its backers, Van and Diana Bernhard, listed as producersdirectors. At present, it seems to serve as a showcase for young, inexperienced dancers.

title: Mexico Opens Gas Line For Link to U.S. System
description: MEXICO CITY, March 18  President Jose Lopez Portillo inaugurated a 780mile natural gas pipeline today that is to be extended as far as the Texas border, if Mexico and the United States reach agreement on a price for Mexican gas exports.

title: Unrecorded Aliens Cost New York City Millions
description: For more than a year, an employee of New York City studiously logged on wall chart the daily levels of water consumption of a Manhattan lowincome housing project and of Stuyvesant Town, a middleincome development. The chart showed that nearly four times as much water flowed through the pipes of the lowerincome project.

title: Sports Briefs
description: While the labor dispute between the New York Racing Association and the union of parimutuel clerks hung fire yesterday at Aqueduct, a crowd of 17,902 turned out in good weather to watch the horseracing.

title: Free, Clippers Deal Nets 5th Loss in Row, 11098
description: SAN DIEGO, March 18 (AP)  Lloyd Free scored 15 of his gamehigh 31 points in the fourth quarter today, leading the San Diego Clippers to a 11098 National Basket ball Association victory over the New Jersey Nets.

title: Negotiators Fail to Reach Settlement in Washington's School Strike
description: WASHINGTON, March 18  School board representatives and teachers union negotiators failed to reach agreement this weekend in the District of Columbia school strike, sending the walkout over teachers authority into its 14th day tomorrow.

title: The Region
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. (UPI) Contract talks resumed yesterday in an attempt to avert a walkout threatened for tomorrow by faculty members at eight state colleges.

title: Television
description: 5:14(2)Public Hearing (R)

title: Reducing Subway Fares Urged by Citizens Panel
description: Subway fares should be reduced to 25 cents, commuter rail fares should be cut 20 percent and new taxes should be imposed to pay for the reductions, a citizens committee told Governor Carey yesterday. The committee criticized the management of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority as ineffective and inefficient.

title: Dancemagazine Cites 3
description: Erick Hawkins, Aaron Copland and Jorge Donn will be honored today at the 29th annual Dancemagazine Award ceremony at the Regency Hotel.

title: U. S. Links Widen in Pretoria Scandal
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 18  Aliegations that South Africa bribed Amencan politicians widened today with newspaper report suggesting that campaign contributions to proSouth Africa candidates may have included presidential contender.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meeting, for week follows

title: Jerome G. Ambro, 81, 9Term Assemblyman
description: Jerome G. Ambro, a lawyer who served nine terms as a Democratic Assemblyman from Brooklyn, died Saturday at the age of 81.

title: Buckner Signs Pact
description: MESA, Ariz., March 18 (AP)  Bill Buckner, the Chicago Cubs first baseman, signed a fiveyear contract extension today for an estimated $1.3 million. He had been on the final year of a threeyear pact, but now is signed thoough the 1984 season.

title: Ship With 20 Tons of Hashish Is Seized
description: A ship carrying 20 tons of hashish was boarded and seized Saturday night off Sandy Hook, N.J., and her crew of five Americans and three West Germans were arrested, the Coast Guard said yesterday.

title: Former Carter Warehouseman Says He Sent Misleading Data to Bank
description: ATLANTA  A former bonded warehouseman at President Carter's family peanut business says he often sent misleading and exaggerated information tr, the National Bank of Georgia so that his reports would conform to what he thought was the Carter family's payment arrangement.

title: Six Measures Designed To Aid Subway Safety
description: Following are the key measures in Mayor Koch's subway anticrime program:

title: South Africa Tightens Its Control of the Press
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 18  The South African Government has moved beyond the use of threats to tighten controls on the press and has introduced bill in Parliament that could have the effect of stifling much of the reporting in opposition newspapers on the activities of the police.

title: Bridge:
description: NORFOLK, Va.; March 19  A rare sibling victory concluded the women's pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's spring nationals here last night. Edith Kemp of Miami Beach and Anne Burnstein of Las Vegas, Nev., who are sisters, sprinted past the leaders with a 67 percent final section to take the title.

title: 2 Black Rhodesians Reject U.S. Call
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 18 (AP)  Two black Rhodesian Government leaders today rejected a BritishAmerican call for elections here next month to be supervised by the United Nations. One said preelection talks with black guerrillas, as proposed by Washington, would be disastrous.

title: The City
description: John T. McKenna, a fireman critically burned in a twoalarm fire in a Washington Heights apartment building on Feb. 22, died Saturday night in the burn center of New York Hospital, according to the Fire Department.

title: Brewster Quietly Follows Own Road as Envoy to Britain
description: LONDON, March 15  Two years ago this month President Carter telephoned Kingman Brewster Jr., then president of Yale, and asked him to serve as United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James's. He accepted.

title: A Victim of Big Competition
description: AI LANTA, March 18According to Frank W. Hulse, founder and chairman of Southern Airways, his company may accomplish in merger the kind of success it never fully achieved in 30 years as an independent carrier.

title: WALTER BINGER, 91, AIDE TO LA GUARDIA
description: Walter D. Binger, a civil engineer who designed the East River Drive, died Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 180 East 75th Street.

title: St. John's: Three for the Money
description: UNTIL then Ron Plair had not missed. Nine shots from the floor, nine baskets. Three shots from the foul line, three baskets. And now, with St. John's trailing Penn, 6462. and only 17 seconds remaining in the East regional final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament yesterday, the Redmen were listening Lou Carnesecca during a timeout.

title: National Book Awards Announce Nominations
description: John Irving's The World According Garp and John Cheever's The Stories of John Cheever are competing for a major book prize for the second :,me this year. In January, the Nat ional Book Critics Circle declared Mr. Cheever the winner, with Mr. Irving the runnerup in fiction. And on April 23 the winners of the National Book Awards will be named.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN ARROW (U.S. Lines). Rotterdam April and Felixstowe 3; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: Washington Watch
description: IS the bill to resolve the Federal Reserve's problem of dwindling membership dead? The House Banking Committee, which recently tabled the legislation. appears to be saying yes. A number of Carter Administration officials concerned with banking contend it is too early to tell, however.

title: Albert S. McGrouer, 75, A New York State Judge
description: Albert S. McGrover, a New York State Supreme Court justice, died Saturday at Victory Memorial Hospital in Brooklyn He was 75 years old and lived in the Bay Ridge sect ion of Brooklyn.

title: In Suffolk, When It Rains It Floods
description: In the back yard, a vegetable garden is under several inches of water, as is a section of the lawn and an inground swimming pool. At least one of the pool walls has buckled and the brick walk around it is in pieces.

title: Drell!!
description: APTSusan Battle, Chappaqua. N.Y., March 18, 1979, daughter of Lillian Smith Battle, mother of Carol and Josette Apt, sister of Mrs H. Wayne (Warren) Bracken. Service Tuesday, 10 AM. Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, N.Y., where family will receive friends Monday (today), 79 PM. Interment Fair Ridge Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the Chappacrua Ambulance Corps in her memory would tse appreciated.

title: Chess:
description: Lajos Portisch of Hungary topped an elite allgrandmaster field to take first prize in the International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, with a 74 score. He pressed middlegame positional advantage with energetic intensity, extracted points with fine ending play and produced several original nuances in the opening.

title: Dr. Paul N. Carnes Is Dead at 58; A Unitarian Universalist Leader
description: Dr. Paul N. Carnes, president of the Unitarian Universalist Association of North America, died of cancer Saturday in Boston. He was 58 years old.

title: ScottHeron and Band
description: THE line that drew the loudest response during Gil ScottHeron's concert Thursday night at Carnegie Hall was, Democracy's standing on the corner  unemployed. But when Mr. ScottHeron sang this lyric in the early 70's. he was suggesting that the means for effecting political change were available if only his black audience would pull itself together and employ them. In today's era of diminished expectations  if not outright despair the lyric reflects only the grim statistics of black joblessness.

title: Outdoors
description: ANY experienced angler knows that locating fish in a lake or the ocean is often more difficult than catching them once they are found. If, on salt water, hundreds of terns are bunched over A school of bluefish feeding on shoals of sand eels, the problem is instantly solved, but often a shimmering expanse of water stretches for miles, unbroken by feeding birds or fish.

title: New York Life Joins Federal Drive To Eliminate Unnecessary Surgery
description: The New York Life Insurance Company has become the nation's first major private health insurer to join the Federal Government's newly organized drive to eliminate unnecessary surgery.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Can Company, Greenwich, Conn., has appointed Patrick F. Van Keuren to the new position of vice president, legislative affairs.

title: McCumber Golf Winner
description: MIAMI, March 18 Six feet. Enough to bury a person. Mark McCumber knew that if he missed the putt on the 18th hole those six feet could bury his chance to win the Dora, open and cost him his first victory in professional golf.

title: Letter: On Trade Agreements
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of March 6 Lifting the Trade Barriers incorrectly refers to American industries that might be hurt by the trade agreements as inefficient. It also, and just as incorrectly, perpetuates the myth that imported merchandise saves American consumers money. It doesn't.

title: LongJailed Pianist Soloist With Boston
description: PEKING, March 18 There were no special festivities at tonight's Boston Symphony concert in the Red Tower Theater. The program consisted of Tchaikovsky's Pathetique Symphony, the Liszt Piano Concert No. 1 in Eflat and Ravel's Daphnis and Chloe Suite No. 2.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ALONE TOGETHER Purposeful stagings of late classics uptown at Columbia University have already made a marked contribution to the city's drama scene. The latest project of the Teachers College Theater is a new production of William Gibson's comedy,

title: The Certainty of a Cycle
description: While few economists are predicting an imminent recession, there is little doubt that someday there will be another one. Although the length of a cycle may be unpredictable, the working of the cycle itself is still regarded as a certainty akin to the rising of the sun..

title: Golf Show: New Trends Are Par for the Course
description: REMEMBER the aluminum shaft? It's about to be joined in oblivion by graphite and that Still more costly spaceage material, titanium. The investmentcast iron club (that's the one with the back partly hollowed out), on which so many hopeful golfers spent millions of dollars a few years ago, is giving way BEDFORD HILLS. N.Y. to something called the low profile. Forged clubs, now attached to lightweight steel shafts, are coming back. The most significant trend these days is the move to lighter swing weights. Women's clubs, once the orphan of the market, are becoming better, because manufacturers are paying more attention to quality control than to appearance.

title: Growing Number of Colleges Give Credits for Knowledge Gained Outside Classrooms
description: The idea that adult5 ought to get academic credit for what they have learned from life outside the classroom is gaining acceptance at a growing number of colleges and universities.

title: Mrs. Carner Fires 69 For a 3Shot Victory
description: SAN DIEGO, March 18 (AP)JoAnne Carner fired her second successive threeunderpar 69 today to win a $150,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament by three shots.

title: House Freshman Builds Support at Home
description: VINITA. Okla.  At lunchtime the other day, the Pioneer Cafe was serving up fried chicken, chocolate cream pie and Mike Synar.

title: Test for U.S., Bell Issues
description: The Government and corporate bond markets, which have just meandered through a week with no new benchmarks to guide them, face more definitive tests this week. A big Bell System bond issue is scheduled to be priced late this afternoon, and the Treasury will auction twoyear notes Wednesday.

title: Artist Is Slain in Fight With Man Following Friend to Apartment
description: A 34yearold artist was shot to death early Sunday while fighting an armed intruder who followed his woman friend back to the couple's East Village apartment, the police said.

title: Canada Ready to Open Road to the Arctic
description: WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory  After 22 years of construction and nearly $100 million in expenditures, engineers here are about to open North America's first land road to the Arctic, directly linking the population centers of the United States and Canada with the vast, wilderness areas rich in minerals north of the Arctic Circle.

title: Memorial to Roosevelt Is Pressed Despite Federal Rejection of Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 18  Citing its remarkably high cost, the Interior Department decided recently to abandon support for a memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt here. Now Eugene J. Keough, the former Brooklyn Congressman who has been chairman of the FDR Memorial Commission for 10 years, is trying to figure out how to proceed without the support of the department and the National Park Service.

title: Robert Kieffer, 75, Dies; An Insurance Executive
description: Robert Soule Kieffer, a former vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and a past president of the Life Insurance Advertisers Association, died Saturday at his home on Dawn Harbor Lane, Riverside, Conn., following a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Reaching for Southern Markets
description: CHICAGO, March 18North Central Airlines has become a textbook case on what freedom from Government regulation can do fora business.

title: Braila
description: CORDESEmily J. The officers. Board of Directors and members of the U.S. Courthouse Federal Credit Union, NYC, mourn the loss of our esteemed Director and friend of over 20 years. Her devotion to our Credit Union was a pillar of strength and a source of Inspiration. We will always cherish her memory Private graveside services will be held in Cincinnati, Ohio.

title: Steinbrenner Seethes as Mets Top Yanks
description: PORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 18  George Steinbrenner winced today as a chant of Let's go Mets picked up volume in the sixth inning of an exhibition game between New York's two majorleague baseball teams.

title: Ohio State Resurgence Symbolized by N.I.T. Semifinal Berth
description: Ohio State's appearance tonight against Indiana in the semifinal round of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden represents the latest step in the Buckeyes climb back to national respectability.

title: Training for Copywriters
description: Everyone connected with the advertising business will tell you that the heart and soul of it is the copy: what is written for either a print or broadcast ad. And yet, while there are schools for art directors and many agencysponsored training programs for account people, little is done to hone copywriters.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Low level clouds cover New England and middle level clouds extend from the Middle lantic States through the Middle West. High level clouds stretch along the Mississippi Valley and heavy convective clouds are apparent over the Central Plaiis States. Overcast cloudiness covers the central Rockies.

title: 2 Republicans Reported Queried On Heading Carter Loan Inquiry
description: Robert Price, Deputy Mayor of New York in 1966, and Carla A. Hills, a former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, are among those who have been asked if they would consider serving as special prosecutor to investigate bank loans provided to President Carter's family peanut business by the National Bank of Georgia, according to wellplaced private legal and Administration sources.

title: Marshal Hooks a Scofflaw But Tows In a Headache
description: When the dust finally settled Saturday afternoon, Alfred Locasio, a NewYork City marshal, had his $873 and Joseph Ancel, a caterer, still had his station wagon, but almost everything else that happened was in dispute.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Now the Palestinian Question
description: BOSTON. March 18  There has been no pause for contented reflection. Just a few days after President Carter's breakthrough in the Middle East. diplomats are worrying about the next phase of the process. That will be the negotiation about autonomy in the West Bank and Gaza, scheduled to start just a month after the treaty between Israel and Egypt has been signed.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY Or TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9413001 NASSAU CO. (516) 7470600; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 669.1600; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Radio
description: 8 A.M., WNCN. Melody in F, Rubinstein; March and Cortege from Sylvia, Delibes; Toccata. SaintSaens.

title: As You Go Up the Ladder, Pull Other Women Alone
description: The keynote speakers included the president of the New York City Council, a former Deputy Mayor of the city, a representative of the Federal Department of Labor, a mother of five on supplementary assistance and a former convict.

title: Miss Fromhoitz Nips Miss Barker's Streak
description: BOSTON, March 18 (AP)  Dianne Fromholtz defeated Sue Barker, 62, 76, in the final round of a $150,000 women's tennis tournament here today, snapping a winning streak that saw the unseeded Miss Barker topple Chris Evert and Virginia Wade earlier this week.

title: Handicapping Casino Gambling
description: Should New York State welcome casino gambling? If so, where? And who should run the casinos? The questions of where and who have yet to be satisfactorily answered by the advocates of legalized gambling. Too many people, including Governor Carey and Mayor Koch, seem eager to bet on the benefits of gambling without first nrudentiv weiehin2 the odds.

title: Goldsmith's Company Strengthens French Ties
description: PARIS, March 18  In a surprise financial move with political overtones, Sir James Goldsmith, the colorful AngloFrench financier who controls the Grand Union and Colonial Stores supermarket chains in the United States, is allowing the big French electrical group, Compagnie Generale d'Electricite, to buy a major stake in his Frenchbased food empire.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Do the numbers given football players fall within certain ranges for different positions? If so, what are they?

title: Nancy E. Ellison Is Married To Dr. Lewis Lane, Surgeon
description: In Temple Shaarai Shomayim in Lancaster, Pa., yesterday, Nancy E. Ellison, an inflight supervisor for Trans World Airlines in New York, was married to Dr. Lewis B. Lane, a senior resident in orthopedic surgery at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York. Rabbi Stanley Feinston performed the ceremony.

title: Federal Actions Renew Questions On Nuclear Power's Future in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 18  Amid increasing concern over the adequacy of the nation's oil supplies, several recent Government actions have highlighted nagging questions about the longstanding expectation that nuclear power would provide a major source of electricity in the future.

title: DE GUSTIBUS Reed Birds in the Chafing Dish
description: The vast majority of America's aristocracy are the offspring of dynasties founded by immigrants who came to this country and became enormously wealthy through the railroads, gold and silver mines and so on. One wonders if this doesn't account for a number of dining and cooking customs that have been a part of the national culture  customs that could be labeled pretentious and nouveau riche.

title: Opera: Shirley Verrett Sings Norma at the Met
description: SHIRLEY VERRETT sang her first Norma at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday afternoon, an indisposition having prevented her from appearing as Bellini's Druid priestess at last Monday night's Norma. Miss Verrett is a singer of intelligence, beauty and generous vocal endowment, and her accomplishments in this most demanding of bel canto roles were not inconsiderable, although the overall impression she left was a curiously uneven one.

title: Penn Tops St. John's, 6462
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 18  Ear.n Johnson kept finding his Michigan State teammate, Greg Keiser, alone under the basket. Kelser kept dunkinv, Johnson's passes and the Spartans easily defeated Notre Dame, 8068. today in the Mideast regional final of the 41st National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship.

title: Music: The Elysian Trio
description: THE Elysian Trio, heard Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, is composed of the violinist Gary Kosloski, the pianist Robert Mayerovitch and the cellist Regina Mushabac. The group's program, a long and demanding one, consisted of Beethoven's Ghost Trio (Op. 70, No. 1), Shostakovich's Trio in E minor (Op. 67) and Brahms's Trio in B (Op. 8).

title: ExOhio Official Is Said To Get Peace Corps Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 18  Richard N. Celeste, the 41yearold former Lieutenant Governor of Ohio, refused today to confirm a report in Newsweek magazine that he had been approved by President Carter as the new director of the Peace Corps. Spokesmen for the White House and Action, the Peace Corps' parent agency, also would not confirm the report.

title: Pop: Barry White and Gloria Gaynor
description: BARRY WHITE and Gloria Gaynor did four shows at the Felt Forum over the weekend, and although this seems to be Miss Gaynor's moment - she has a No. I record with I Will Survive and a large and fanatical following with the discos - it was clearly Mr. White most of the audience had come to see. During Miss Gaynor's set at the early show on Saturday night the front row of chairs remained halffilled, but by the time Mr. White came on every seat was taken.

title: The Prisoners Who Reject Mercy
description: The pleas for clemency for Puerto Rican nationalists who were imprisoned a generation ago for two violent attacks in Washington raise some vexing questions. Without condoning the 1950 assault that endangered President Truman and killed a Blair House guard, or the 1954 gunplay that wounded five members of the House of Representatives, supporters of the four remaining prisoners say they have paid their penalty and now should be released.

title: India Aids Snowbound Valley
description: NEW DELHI, March 18 (AP)  Indian Air Force helicopters crisscrossed the Lahaul Valley in northern India today ferrying relief supplies to residents cut off since early this month by heavy snows.

title: City Opera: Season's First Coq d'Or
description: EVEN though Tito Capobianco's name has long since been removed from it, his production of RimskyKorsakov's Le Coq d'Or remains one of the brightest adornments of the New York City Opera's repertory.

title: Events
description: Music

title: Piano: Pollini Pairs Usual and Unusual
description: MAURIZIO POLLINI first came to international prominence by winning the Warsaw Chopin competition, but his recital yesterday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall was a long, long way from Chopin. Not that Chopin represents the unchallenged heights of the piano repertory, necessarily: yesterday's recital was an altogether brilliant, thoughtprovoking affair.

title: Fed Ruling Snags Bank Deal
description: The C.I.T. Financial Corporation says it will not proceed with the proposed sale of a controlling interest in its National Bank of North America to Britain's National Westminster Bank unless the Federal Reserve Board agrees to amend its status as a regulated bank holding company.

title: Young, French And Trendy
description: Paul Young. impresario of what came to be known as the Youthquake, or the revolutionary approach to fashion in the 1960's, has something new on his mind for the next decade.

title: Rangers Bow, 51
description: The Rangers lost their second game in a row last night, something they hadn't done since Feb. 3, dropping a 51 decision to the Pittsburgh Penguins at Madison Square Garden.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Pearl Moore, a lithe 5foot7inch sociology major at Francis Marion College in Florence, S.C., plays on the women's basketball team there but also likes to go to a nearby high school playground where boys play pickup games. Winners keep the court, losers sit and watch.

title: Brooklyn Synagogue Vandalized
description: Swastikas were painted on a Brooklyn synagogue over the weekend, and the synagogue's rabbi charged that the vandalism was the work of extremist Jews stung by his criticism of a demonstration last week by Hasidic rabbis protesting Israeli policies on Orthodox Jews in Jerusalem.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN the 1950's, when I went to school, everything, including literature, was poppsychologized. In the 60's, when nobody went to school, everything, including literature, was poppoliticized. Thus in the 50's we were taught that when Meursault, in Albert Camus 's The Strang.

title: Chris O. Stern Wed To Morton Hyman, Shipping Executive
description: Chris Oliphant Stern, daughter of Alfred R. Stern of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Mrs. Frederick E. Wagner of Lyme, N.H., was married yesterday to Morton P. Hyman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving S. Hyman of New York.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Exercise is in these days, but a lot of people don't like going out get it. This has caused manufacturers to devise equipment for use home, where you can trim or build up your body with convenience, privacy and usually for less cost in the long run. Dozens of items arc available, among the latest of which are these:

title: OffDuty Policeman Mugged, Gun Stolen
description: An offduty police officer was clubbed to the ground in the lobby of his Nforningside Heights apartment building last night and his revolver stolen after he fired three shots at his assailant, the police said.

title: Mindy Carol Miller Wed to Elliot C. Lisman
description: Mindy Carol Miller and Elliot Cyril Lisman were married yesterday afternoon at the Sheraton Center in Manhattan. Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik, uncle of the bridegroom, and Rabbi Abner Weiss officiated.

title: Yankee Thing Is Frustrating
description: ALL spring training seasons are the same, and each is different. The pitchers throw well, and the managers percolate cheer, and as you travel from camp to camp you learn that five or possibly six teams will win the World Series in October. This scenario plays against a background of creeping traffic and old people attentively bent at shuffleboard courts in a crowded corner of the state.

title: Charles Stevenson, 71, A Bennington Professor
description: Charles L. Stevenson, a professor at Bennington College, died Wednesday in his campus office, in Bennington, Vt. He was 71 years old and he was a Bennington resident.

title: In Iran, Some Shooting and a Speech by Khomeini
description: TEHERAN. Iran, March 18  The gardeners were watering the lawn around the Prime Minister's palace this morning, preparing the seat of the Provisional Revolutionary Government for the coming spring.

title: Around the Nation
description: DENVER, March 18 (AP)  An airtraffic control computer broke down for 21/2 hours at Stapleton International Airport yesterday, nampering the landing of a Frontier Airlines plane with engine troubles and e.isrupting arrivals and departures.

title: Fertilizer Cited In Upstate Death Of 10,000 Birds
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y., March 18  A state investigator said today that extensive chemical tests have shown that the nearly 10,000 birds found dead here last week were the victims of poisoning from a fertilizer that had been applied on a field in unusually heavy amounts by a farmer.

title: About Education
description: AN academically able but physically handicapped young woman why is about to graduate from high school has been admitted to an elite college in the Northeast. And after her first visit to the campus she wrote: I was not merely shocked but absolutely appalled at what I saw. It appears that the university does not hold a widespread belief in elevators or ramps. . a majority of the houses and classrooms are inaccessible to the physically disabled; the effectual segregation appears to me a form of discrimination.

title: WILLIAM WALZER
description: Until 1977 when he retired, Mr. Walzer was in a partner in the firm of Walzer Walzer, which he operated with his oldest son, Martin. He went into the legal profession in 1917, following service as a lieutenant in the United States Army in World War I.

title: GeorgiaPacific To Buy Polymer
description: The GeorgiaPacific Corporation said that it had agreed in principle to acquire Polymer Materials Inc., a supplier to the plastics industry. The proposed transaction would be on an exchange basis of 0.4042618 share of a new series of voting adjustablerate convertible preferred stock of GeorgiaPacific for each share of Polymer Materials, which has 1.23 million common shares outstanding.

title: Spring Planting on Third Avenue
description: The New York Times/ Paul Hosetros

title: Teamster Locals Told To Take Strike Votes
description: ARLINGTON, Va., March 19 Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, asked leaders of union locals today to begin taking strike authorization votes as contract talks with the trucking industry resumed without any immediate prospect of a settlement.

title: Advertising
description: LILY OF FRANCE MARKETING, the subsidiary of the Bestform Foundations that sells women's undergarments, will be advertising its wares on television for the first time this weekend, taken there by Jack Cassidy, its president for the last six years, and its new agency, Nadler & Larimer.

title: Television
description: 5: 55(4)Aerospace Down to Earth

title: Concert: Dufallo Leads Visions by Wernick
description: RICHARD WERNICK'S Visions of Terror and Wonder for orchestra and mezzosoprano (1976), for which the composer won a Pulitzer Prize in 1977, received its New York premiere at concert by the American Symphony on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The allAmerican program, conducted by Richard Dufallo, also included Carl Ruggles's Men and Mountains, Charles Ives's Decoration Day and Aaron Copland's Piano Concerto.

title: Author of Article About HBomb Gives Affidavit in Magazine Fight
description: MADISON, Wis., March 19 (AP) Howard Morland, the author of an article the Government wants to suppress on the ground that it discloses secret information on thermonuclear bombs, gave the Government his affidavit today in the fight to publish the article in Progressive magazine.

title: Sihanouk Renews Plea For Parley on Indochina
description: PEKING, March 19 (Reuters) Prince Norodom Sihanouk, saying that he was now refusing to represent the ousted regime of Prime Minister Pol Pot of Cambodia, tonight repeated his call for a new Geneva conference on Indochina and an international force to supervise a ceasefire in his country.

title: Survey Finds That Offers of Jobs For Graduates Rose 30% in Year
description: Job prospects for college graduates appear to be better this year than in any year since the recession of the late 1960's and early 1970's.

title: Polls Open at 6 A.M. For 62d A.D. Election
description: The polls in a special election today in the 62d Assembly District, which spans New York Bay to include part of the Lower East Side and a strip along the eastern shore of Staten Island, will be open from 6 A.M. until 9 P.M.

title: COMMODITIES
description: A Government report at the weekend showing a 15 percent decline in new housing starts during February led to moderate selling yesterday in lumber and copper futures, analysts said.

title: Charter to Buy Stake in Carey
description: The Charter Company, confirming reports that it would come to the rescue of the financially troubled Carey Energy Corporation, announced jointly yesterday with Carey that the two had reached agreement in principle for Charter to acquire 80 percent of Carey Energy for cash and convertible preferred stock.

title: CAREY TAX CUT PLAN SEEMS TO BE DEAD AS LAWMAKERS BALK
description: ALBANY, March 19  Governor Carey's plan to cut personal and business taxes by $372 million over the next five years appeared dead today because of a lack of support in both houses of the State Legislature. The administration was reported ready to postpone its fight for the cuts until later in the legislative session.

title: New Afghan Regime, Battling Foes Within, Blames Iranians for Unrest
description: NEW DELHI, March 19  The Afghan Government is accusing Iran of sending thousands of soldiers across the border in disguise to make trouble, and the Iranians are denying the charges. But reports from the area indicate that Moslem dissidents are taking to arms against the proSoviet authorities in Afghanistan.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets on the Angolan complaint 3:30 P.M.

title: TV: 13 Queens Blvd. Begins Tryout on ABC
description: A NEW series beginning a trial run of four weekly episodes on ABCTV tonight at 9:30  13 Queens Blvd.  is a sort of Maude before that Beatrice Arthur character moved to suburbia. In this case, the wisecracking, doubletaking, deadpanning wife, Felicia Winters, is played by Eileen Brennan.

title: Elratlis
description: AN. JERSONCecile 0. of Madison, NJ on March 18, 1979. Wife of Richard A. Anderson. Mother of Richard A, Anderson Jr, Convent Slation. NJ. Mrs Vincent (Michelle) SOdano of Madison. NJ and sister of Thomas O'Connor of Chicago and Mrs Joseph (Helen) Maloney of ChicaPO. Also survived by 4 grandchildren. Liturgy of Christian Burial Wednes day March 21st. 9.30AM at St vin cent's Church. Madison. Friends may call at the Burrcakps & Kohr uneral Horne, 106 Main St. Madison, Tuesday 24 and 7.9PM.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Anglo Company Ltd, a diversified contract driller of oil and gas in Canada, Alaska and the Rocky Mountains, has elected Francis J. Nestor vice president and general counsel, and Richard A. Stratton controller.

title: Dividends
description: Pe 5ts.of day rikn Rale record ado.

title: Violin: Nina Beilina Does Contrasting Concertos
description: NINA BEILINA, the Moscowborn violinist who came to this country to live in 1977, quickly found a place for herself in New York's musical community, and Sunday night's concert at Carnegie Hall showed whv. The small. darkhaired musician played two concertos with an orchestra under the direction of Leon Fleisher, giving an excellent account of herself in each. Miss Beilina, violinist of great technical assurance, moved easily from the closeensemble requirements of Bach's Concerto No. in E to the more patently heroic demands of the Beethoven Concerto in D.

title: Assembly Gets Bill to Allow Sale Of Table Wine in Grocery Stores
description: ALBANY, March 19  At a news conference today that turned into a wine and cheese party and lured legislators out of the Assembly, Assemblyman Rolland E. Kidder announced the introduction of bill that would allow the sale of table wines in grocery stores.

title: Purdue, Sparked by Carroll's 42, And Indiana Reach N.I.T. Final
description: Joe Barry Carroll, Purdue's silent giant, scored a careerhigh 42 points last night in powering the Boilermakers to an 8768 victory over Alabama and a berth in the final round of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: High Court to Rule on Union Liability in Wildcat Strike Losses
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 - The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the national and district levels of a labor union could be held financially liable to an employer for losses resulting from wildcat strikes called by individual locals.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Few are privileged to live 90 years, and no man ever filled that long lifespan with more rich achievement than Jean Monnet. His transcendent purpose was to transform Europe and he quite literally succeeded.

title: In the Subways, Koch Says, Perception of Crime Is Real
description: New York City's assault on subway violence is as much a response to the perception of crime as to the fact of crime, Mayor Koch says. Whether or not the perception is accurate, the Mayor asserts, is widely held, it appears to be influencing people's behavior and it must be dealt with.

title: Peabody College Approves Merger With Vanderbilt, Ending a Debate
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn.. March 19  The trustees of the George Peabody College for Teachers voted today to end the school's 104year existence as a small undergraduate college and become a professional school within adjacent Vanderbilt University.

title: Steel Use Is at 94.6% of Capacity
description: The steel industry achieved one of the highest operating levels last week since it began making production figures public four years ago, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, a trade group.

title: Jesuits Say China Has Not Asked Them to Return
description: Jesuits are ready to return to China but still are awaiting a formal invitation, according to the Rev. Pedro Arrupe, the head of the Society of Jesus.

title: Minnesota Backs D.C. Vote
