description: ST. PAUL, March 19 (AP)  Minnesota today became the fourth state to ratify a constitutional amendment giving Washington, D.C., voting representation in the Senate and House. The final vote was 37 to 29 in the Minnesota Senate. The State House voted 68 to 66 for the amendment March 8. Ohio, New Jersey and Michigan previously approved the amendment.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN ARROW (U.S. Lines). Rotterdam April and Felixstowe 4; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. ( N ) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, March 19, 1979

title: Hunt Extends Offer
description: The Hunt International Resources Corporation announced that it would extend to April 2 its offer to buy any and all shares of Sunshine Mining Company common stock for $15 a share. The offer was to expire yesterday. Sunshine Mining has vigorously opposed the Hunt offer, calling it inadequate. Sunshine has indicated it believes its stock to be worth from $22 to $23 share.

title: E. H. Lindberg and Wife Die in Mexican Accident
description: Edward H. Lindberg and his wife were killed instantly when the car in which they were passengers collided with a tractortrailer on Friday in Mexico. The couple had been vacationing in San Luis de la Paz. Mr. Lindberg was 80 years old and his wife, Rosalie, was 75. They lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Cosmos Perform Poorly In a Colombia Setback
description: MEDELLIN, Colombia, March 19 (AP)  Two Cosmos players were ejected and a third was fined in a 20 loss Sunday to Atletico Nacional. Coach Eddie Firmani called the defeat a disappointing effort.

title: F.C.C. Aide Bars Rate Of A. T.&T.
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  In highly unusual move, a hearing officer for the Federal Communications Commission rejected today a rate application filed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and ordered the company to change the way it calculates rates by adopting an 86page manual that he issued.

title: Appeals Panel Backs Court Wheat Action
description: CHICAGO, March 19  A Federal appeals court panel rejected today a plea by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for a stay that would have once again halted the offagain, onagain trading in March wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Subway Crime, Union Mischief
description: There has been a shocking rise in crime in New York City's subways and it has stimulated an even more worrisome rise in the public's fear that it cannot travel safely. Mayor Koch has moved promptly to try to restore public confidence. But the transit police union seems to be exploiting the situation in negotiating a new contract. Its members deserve praise for making an arrest in every recent subway homicide but their bargaining mischief should not be rewarded.

title: Henry Ford Will Quit His Top Job This Year
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 19 Henry Ford 2d has made it official that he will step down from the top of the secondlargest American automobile manufacturing company before the end of this year.

title: Syracuse Starts Fast In Lacrosse
description: Rutgers and Syracuse, northern lacrosse teams, achieved surprise victories over southern rivals last week surprising to many, but not to their coaches.

title: Resorts Reports $17 Million Profit
description: Reflecting the success of its hotelcasino complex in Atlantic City, Resorts International Inc. had profits of 317 million, or 31.36 share, in the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, the Floridabased company reported yesterday. In the 1977 final quarter, the company operated at a loss of 5415.000.

title: World Cup Skiing Titles To Mrs. Moser, Luescher
description: FURANO, Japan, March 19 (AP) Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden scored record 13th victory by capturing the final World Cup Alpine ski race of the season today, but he had settle for fifth place in the overall Cup standing.

title: CLINIC CALLED FRONT FOR ABORTION FOES.
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 19  The emotional debate that the question of abortion almost inevitably provokes has taken a new twist here with the filing today of administrative and legal action against a clinic in Northeast Philadelphia. Lawyers for a women's health group and a patient at the clinic charge that the clinic is really a front for an organization opposed to abortions.

title: Arab Group Buys Ritz Hotel in Paris
description: PARIS, March 19 (AP)  The luxury Paris hotel, the Ritz, has been sold to an Arab consortium, it was learned today.

title: Mets Defeat Pirates, 54, In Puerto Rico Exhibition
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 19 (AP) Joel Youngblood pinchhit a tworun homer in the seventh inning to give the New York Mets a 54 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates in an exhibition game tonight.

title: 18,000 Hear Bostonians Finale in Peking
description: PEKING. March 19  The final notes that the Boston Symphony Orchestra played tonight at its last concert in China was the peroration of Sousa's Stars and Strives Forever. There were 18,000 listeners in the indoor Capital Stadium, and they went wild. There were yells, rhythmic applause, cheers and demands for the conductor, Seiji Ozawa. Mr. Ozawa obliged, darting around the perimeter of the big arena like a matador who has made a sensational kill and has been awarded both ears.

title: Navy Transforms Quiet Georgia Town
description: ST. MARY'S, Ga.  Kilroy Cook held up a bandaged right hand for the men on the dock to examine. A wild hog he had trapped in the woods behind his home had cored him badly.

title: Bridge:
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 19  In the third round of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship here today, four of the 16 matches pitted New Yorker against New Yorker. A tough battle was expected between Michael Moss, whose team includes Tom Smith and Jim Rosenbloom and Moss's estranged wife, Gail Moss, whose sextet of woman world champions includes Jacqui Mitchell and Dorothy Hayden Truscon.

title: House Votes Stockpile Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)  The House today passed legislation that for the first time would set Congressional guidelines for stockpiling critical national defense materials. The legislation, passed by voice vote, would direct the President to determine the kinds and quantities of materials to be stockpiled to meet national defense needs.

title: The City
description: Several devices that went off in stolen money bag caused two bank robbers to drop the loot on a Brooklyn sidewalk, but most of the money is still missing. It was possibly picked up by passersby, the police said.

title: LAURIVOLPI DIES, FORMER MET TENOR
description: Giacomo LauriYolpi, a former leading tenor of the Metropolitan Opera, died of cerebral blood clot Saturday in a hospital in Valencia, Spain. He was S6 years old and had made his home in Burjasot, a suburb of Valencia, for more than 50 years.

title: Wyeth Art Going to Carolina Museum
description: A littleknown museum in Greenville, S.C., will get the extensive collection of Andrew Wyeth paintings owned by Joseph E. Levine, the motionpicture executive. The collection, bought rrom Mr. Levine for the Greenville County Art Museum by a retired local manufacturer, Arthur Magill, at a cost believed to be between $4 million and $4.5 million, consists of 26 works that will bring to the bustling textile town the largest group of Wyeth works outside of the artist's own holdings.

title: Variety of Sensors Tell Plants It's Spring
description: THE MAGIC of spring has begun, although not until tomorrow does the sun's zenith passage at noon move north of the Equator, marking the official start of the season of renewal in the Northern Hemisphere.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Are there any welldocumented cases of endangered species that need to be preserved not only for philosophical reasons but also because they are valuable to human civilization?

title: 17YearOld Charged in Shootings Of Queens Jeweler and Cabdrivers
description: A 17yearold youth who the police said had escaped from a detention center in Columbus, Ohio, has been charged with the murder of a Queens jeweler Saturday night and the robbery and shooting of two cab drivers in the same area during threehour period yesterday morning.

title: The Duke Of Argyll's Chutzpah
description: WASHINGTON  To the world at large, the Duke of Argyll's decision to sell the island of Iona may represent yet another poignant milestone in the downhill fortunes of the nobility. but I know  and I am confident that he knows I know  that Argyll's move is an act of unmitigated chutzpah.

title: U.S. Agency Reportedly Set Up Suspect in Computer Bank Fraud
description: LOS ANGELES, March 19  Last Oct. 25, a computer consultant named Stanley Mark Rifkin made a single telephone call and thereby stole $10.2 million from a bank, possibly the largest theft ever committed by one person in this country in a single stroke.

title: Notes on People
description: Devotees of opera arcana have been looking forward for more than a year to what's said to be the American premiere of one of Meyerbeer's seldomperformed works, II Crociato in Egitto (The Crusader in Egypt). The Sacred Music Society's concert version of the opera, a truly grand affair that at one point includes an appearance by the West Point marching band, is scheduled for a single performance March 28 in Carnegie Hall, but Frederica von Stade, the American mezzosoprano, has decided to pull out of the allstar cast that includes Justin Diaz, Yvonne Kenny, and Rockwell Blake.

title: Minerva Pious, Played Mrs. Nussbaum Part On Fred Allen Show
description: Minerva Pious, who for nearly two decades tickled the risibilities of radio listeners as Mrs. Nussbaum when she appeared with Fred Allen, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 75 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Jersey Defers Vote on Renaming Education Chief Pending Inquiry
description: TRENTON, March 19  A Senatecornmittee vote on a second fiveyear term for Fred G. Burke as New Jersey Education Commissioner was ordered delayed today until completion of an investigation of rus role in granting a $25,000 contract to a vocationaleducation consultant whom he had recommended for appointment to a state council on vocational education. Senator Martin L. Greenberg, Democrat of East Orange, said no vote would be taken by the Senate Judiciary Cornmittee until Attorney General John J. Degnan had reported on the results of the investigation, probably later this week. Opponents of Dr. Burke appearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee have accused him of covering up circumstances of the transaction.

title: Deaths
description: KENNEDY  David. On March 19.1 1979. Beloved husband of Helen. brother of Robert and Stanley Uncle of Isabelle Sloan. Robert Kennedy and James Kennedy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2.5 and 79PM. Funeral service Thursday 1PM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Bruins Edge Leafs by 43 On 4 Goals in First Period
description: BOSTON, March 19 (AP)  The Boston Bruins did all their scoring in the first period tonight, led by two goals and an assist by Dwight Foster, and then held off the Toronto Maple Leafs for a 43 National Hockey League victory.

title: Koch's Best Bet For City's OTB,
description: SO tar as his friends, associates and wife could recall yesterday, 49yearold John Fontaine Keenan has never indulged in any kind of gambling. but they all insisted that didn't mean that he wouldn't be a superb head of Off.track betting Corporation. He has been a prosecuror most or ;us wonting life, but has demonstrated competence as an admit istrator. too. oresent and Tonner associates declare.

title: Right Gains in Voting in Finland, But Ruling Parties Retain Edge
description: HELSINKI, Finland, March 19 (AP) Finnish voters have apparently taken a Iswing toward the right, with Conservatives making significant gains in the twoday parliamentary elections that ended today.

title: Rock: Steve Reich
description: STEVE REICH became the second composer of trance music to play at the Bottom Line within a month on Sunday, following Philip Glass's two nights there on Feb. 28 and March 1.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar closed mixed against major currencies en the world's foreign exchange markets yesterday as the price of gold dropped by more than $1 an ounce in Europe but then made slight recovery later in New York.

title: Southern Seeking Railroad Properties
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) The Southern Railway Company said today that, if the merger of the Chessie System Inc. and the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad Company was approved, it wanted the merged railroads to sell Southern certain properties so it could remain competitive.

title: Carter Discusses Oil and Inflation With Top Aides
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  President Carter conferred for more than eight hours today with his top economic and political advisers on ways to curb inflation and the nation's consumption of energy while coping with the problem of reduced oil imports from Iran.

title: I.C.C. Backs Tyler Bid
description: The Tyler Corporation announced yesterday that the Interstate Cornmerce Commission had approved the company's application to purchase all of the business and assets of Thurston Inc. for approximately $45 million. Thurston is the parent of Thurston Motor Lines, a generalcommodity common carrier. Tyler provides goods and services to industrial customers and does heavy mulang.

title: Fashion: Living Legends Upstage Spring Styles
description: The fashion show in its pristine form is becoming increasingly rare. Often one is offered musicians or entertainers to admire, in addition to the clothes being keyed to an eminent charity  the good works gambit  and people prominent in fields other than fashion arc given good seats, so they can be scnitinized, too.

title: Yanks Ignore Kuhn and Win
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 19 Bowie Kuhn may not have considered it a representative lineup, but worked for New York today as the Yankees beat Atlanta, 21, with a squad consisting almost entirely of backup men and rookies.

title: Market Place
description: THIS is the story of a brief but dramatic stock market rise. The shares of an emerging company came from nowhere, rose to new heights and then slid into limbo. The story is of Intermedics Inc., a manufacturer and marketer of cardiac pacemakers. This company was formed in 1973, largely with former employees of the industry's leader, Medtronic Inc.

title: B.P. Finds Success Without Iranian Oil
description: LONDON, March 19  The British Petroleum Company, which lost 40 percent of its crude oil supplies in Iran's revolution, is oddly enough doing just fine these days.

title: Mack Sells 20% Stake To Renault
description: Mack Trucks Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 20 percent interest in the company for $115 million to Renault of France, the Governmentowned auto maker, as part of a deal whereby Mack will market Renault trucks in the United States and Canada.

title: Jersey Gets Power On Gasoline Price
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 New Jersey received the authority today to enforce Federal price limits at gasoline pumps. The Department of Energy announced that the authority had been extended on a trial basis oy Secretary James R. Schlesinger at the request of Governor Byrne.

title: Around the Nation
description: OAKLAND, Cal., March 19  Michelle Williams came to Huey Newton's murder [trial today and recanted her identification of the Black Panther Party leader as the man she saw shoot Kathleen Smith, a 17yearold prostitute, on Aug. 6, 1974.

title: Deaths
description: GORDON  4..I.Kile. Beloved sister of Myron, devoted sisterinlaw of Er leen Gorden Devoted Aunt of LC.O. nore and Milton Beckerman. 5ervl (es Dfivair)

title: Land Shortage Alters Old Japanese Burial Practices
description: TOKYO, March 19  Takashi Kaiho led the way up the stairs of the cinerariurn. A quiet man of middle age with eyeglases and a long forehead, he is the superintendent of Tokyo's only locker cinerarium, a threestory concrete building in the Zoshigaya district equipped with 3,950 compartments to hold the ashes of the dead.

title: Bringing Technology to the Third World
description: Ever since the Truman Administration proposed technical assistance to the developing countries with the celebrated Point Four program  the dream has persisted that scientific knowledge could help poor countries catch up with rich ones. But technology has never been fully put to work on the problems of development. An overdue attempt to improve that performance is now to be made, if Congress permits.

title: Clinic to Provide Sterilization Using Simpler Technique
description: A relatively inexpensive, safe and quick method for sterilization developed over the last 20 years in the Far East will be available to women in an outofhospital setting in May at Planned Parenthood of New York City, it was announced yesterday.

title: $750 Million Commodity Fund Set
description: GENEVA, Tuesday, March 20 - Industrialized and developing countries agreed early today on the developing tal principles of a $750 million fund that they are to establish to stabilize thirdworld earnings from raw materials.

title: AN ALIBI IS CLAIMED IN 3 GIRLS KILLINGS
description: PRYOR, Okla., March 19  Lawyers for Gene Leroy Hart disclosed a key element of their defense strategy today when they asserted for the first time that Mr. Hart was nowhere near the rustic camp where three young Girl Scouts were staying when they were murdered two summers ago.

title: Letters
description: To SCIENCE TIMES: I take strong exception to the estimate in the article Computer Says Monkeys Couldn't Write Hamlet  At Least Not So Far [March 6] that would take a trillion monkeys more than a trillion times the age of the universe for one of them to type at random Hamlet's line To be or not to be, that is the question.

title: Can't Rush Bank Plan, State Says
description: Despite the approval by the Federal Reserve Board last week of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation's application to acquire Marine Midland Banks Inc., Muriel Siebert, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, said yesterday that she would not be rushed into approving the takeover of a major United States bank by foreign comnanv.

title: Hypertension Found to Be Two Diverse Conditions
description: THE most prevalent form of high blood pressure, lifethreatening illness that affects many millions Americans, is really a group of diverse maladies rather than a single ailment, scientists have concluded from a large accumulation of evidence.

title: Independence Assured, Rumanians Crave Freedom
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania  The Russians would not be pleased by the Rumanian Communist Party's history museum. In the entire sweep of displays that run through room after room, only a single panel depicts the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917, as if it were a minor footnote.Lenin is dismissed with a lone portrait, one of the few pictures of him to be found in the faded elegance of this East European capital.

title: Telecast Of Lucia Canceled
description: The telecast of Donizetti's Lucia di Lammermoor by the New York City Opera tomorrow night on WNET/ Channel 13 has been canceled because of a dispute over a pay demand by the orchestra musicians. The telecast was to have been part of the Live From Lincoln Center series.

title: BRZEZINSKI REPORTS MIDEAST ASSURANCES
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's assistant for national security, said today that a threeday mission to the Middle East had assured him of the willingness of Saudi Arabia and Jordan to cooperate with American diplomacy in the area.

title: End of Lid On Savings Rate Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stalfility, and Barry P. Bosworth, the staff director, recommended today that the Government ultimately abolish the ceilings it imposes on interest rates on savings deposits.

title: A Heated Holmes Cools Off Ocasio
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 19 (UPI)  Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, and Ossie Ocasio of Puerto Rico, the challenger, exchanged insults at a news conference today that ended with Holmes pouring a glass of water over Ocasio's head.

title: Clouds Over U.S.Saudi Ties
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 19 The United States' relationship with Saudi Arabia, once a model of understanding and close coordination, has become clouded with question marks and, from the Saudi perspective at least, many unpleasant surprises.

title: Spectacular Bid Runs 6 Furlongs In 1:12 35 in Flamingo Tuneup
description: MIAMI, March 19  Spectacular Bid had an outstanding workout this morning, and all he got for his trouble was cinnamon doughnut  not even his preferred creamfilled variety.

title: A Federal Grant To Help Rebuild 126 City Bridges
description: A $244 million program to rehabilitate 126 of the city's bridges was announced yesterday by Mayor Koch, who said that $195 million would be provided by the Federal Government.

title: Shortage Predicted In Unleaded Gas
description: A shortage of unleaded grades of gasoline is a distinct possibility in 1980 and a probability in 1981, even if Iranian exports resume at their prerevolutionary level, according to an industry research group.

title: A.M.A. Calls Figures on Unneeded Surgery Exaggerated
description: The American Medical Association said yesterday that there was a tiny amount of unnecessary surgery performed in the country, but that an estimate by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare that onethird of the total was unnecessary was grossly exaggerated.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P. M. (TelevisionChannel, cable, Manhattan and Teleprompter, 7:30 P. M. RadioWNEW, 7:20 P. M.)

title: Panel Backs Five APlant Closings
description: WASHINGTON, March 19A member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that the occurrence of a significant earthquake near one of the five nuclear reactors that the commission shut down last week was far more likely than suggested by some of the commission's critics.

title: 14 Hospital Officials and Vendors Are Indicted on Kickback Charges
description: The indictments of 19 hospital officials and vendors on kickback charges involving five New York hospitals were ant nounced yesterday by Charles J. Hynes, the Special State Prosecutor for Nursing Homes, Health and Social Services.

title: 4 in a Family Die in Plane Crash Near the Airport in Aspen, Colo.
description: ASPEN, Colo., March 18 (AP)  Four! persons were killed when a twinengine plane crashed and burned yesterday shortly after taking off from the Aspen airport, the authorities said.

title: GRUMBLING IS HEARD IN NICARAGUAN ARMY
description: MANAGAUA Nicaragua, March 15 The National Guard has been loyal to the Somozas for more than 40 years, former Lieut. Col. Guillermo Mendieta Chavez said. Couldn't General Somoza be loyal to the Guard for just one day and leave the country?

title: Indoor Soccer: Losing Money, Gaining Confidence
description: It is 3 months old and, with luck, some of the teams will lose only half a million dollars, but the Major Indoor Soccer League likes to think of itself as the next American pastime.

title: Dance: Asian New Coalition
description: THE Asian New Dance Coalition, which presented a program of new and old works on Sunday at the Sun Ock Lee Studio, was formed last year to project the Asian ancl AsianAmerican cultural identity through dance. The four New Yorkbased choreographers from the Philippines, Japan, Korea and China have obviously been touched by American society and culture, particularly its modern dance. But the pieces closest to Asian cultural traditions were most successful.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING. March 19 (Reuters)  China told Vietnam today that talks on settling the disputes that flared into war between the two nations last month should start in Hanoi about March 28. Vietnam said Saturday that the discussions should begin on March 23, either in Hanoi or at the border.

title: 8 State Colleges In Jersey Facing A Faculty Strike
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Tuesday, March 20  While lastminute negotiations continued between the state and the union representing 3,200 faculty members at eight state colleges, preparations were under way for a strike that would curtail the education of about 65,000 students.

title: Penn Campus Exudes a HoHum Air
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 19  The University of Pennsylvania basketball team arrived today at Philadelphia International Airport after defeating St. John's, 6462, yesterday to gain a berth in the Final Four of the National Collegiate tournament. The triumphant Quakers, who will play Michigan State in the semifinals Saturday at Salt Lake City, were greeted by only about 200 wellwishers.

title: Kurdish Tribesmen Battle Iran Troops
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 19  Heavily armed Kurdish tribesmen battled Iranian troops today in the Kurdistan market city of Sanandaj, according to reports reaching the capital.

title: Contemplative Man's Recreation
description: EVERGLADES CITY, Fla.  Captain Dennis Hancock is 55 years old, and this would be his 40th season as a fishing guide if he hadn't frittered away five years with the Navy in the South Pacific. By now it comes natural to him to talk like a fishing guide, but he waited the better part of an hour before giving his new sports the treatment. The sports  Morris McLemore, a Georgia cracker who has put down roots Miami, and a small Yankee companion  were half an hour late arriving at dockside. Getting McLemore into motion the morning is not the same thing as launching an aircraft carrier, but the difference is negligible. You're starting out, Captain Hancock said cheerfully at 8:30 A.M., about the time we should be coming back. Having remarked on the hour, he also remarked on the date, which he said was about a month too early. If I could afford it, he said, I'd just put the boat up for March. We're trying the impossible today.

title: Bird Top Choice Of N.B.A. Pilots
description: Larry Bird of Indiana State, the outstanding forward who will lead the undefeated Sycamores against DePaul in the semifinal round of the National Collegiate basketball tournament on Saturday at Salt Lake City, was the only unanimous choice for the College AllAmerica team chosen by coaches of the National Basketball Association.

title: Soccer Players Union Sets Strike Deadline
description: CHICAGO, March 19 (AP)  Representatives of the North American Soccer League Players Association voted today that if owners do not recognize the union by March 30 the players should vote to strike.

title: Alvin N. Sarasohn Is Dead at 59; Executive With Grey Advertising
description: Alvin N. Sarasohn, a senior vice presi. dent and group creative director of Grey Advertising Inc., died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. lie was 59 years nlcl.

title: A Reckless Miss Evert?
description: Underneath the sweetness and synchronized strokes that have become her trademarks, there is a touch of the rebel in Chris Evert.

title: Strikes Tie Up Much of Israel in FoodPrice Protest
description: TEL AVIV, March 19  Hundreds of thousands of Israelis stopped work for four hours today to protest the Government's economic policies, especially a decision to raise food prices.

title: U.S. WILL GO AHEAD WITH AID FOR YEMEN
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  The United States plans to go ahead with a $390 million arms shipment to Yemen despite reports that Southern Yemen is withdrawing its troops, American officials said today.

title: PROFITS General Mills Net Off 10.6% in Quarter
description: General Mills Inc., the diversified toad processor and restaurant chain operator, yesterday reported its first quarterly profit drop in many years. Earnings for the third fiscal quarter fell 10.6 percent from a year earlier, the company said.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter conferred with his top aides for more than eight hours about ways to curb inflation and energy consumption. However, the President's spokesman said that no decisions had been taken at the Camp David meeting and that none would be made until there were discussions with Congressional leaders [Page Al.]

title: A Few Drinks May Help Curb Heart Attacks
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 19  Moderate consumption of alcoholic beverages may protect against death from heart disease, according to new evidence presented here today. However, the researchers emphasized the need for further studies before they could recommend a drink or two a day as a way to help prevent heart attacks.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY RE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5.30 P M FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2 30 P.M ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION IN REGIONAL OFFICES 900 A M TO 4.30 P M MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY. NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900. WESTCHESTER CO AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 0.5300, NASSAU CO (516)7470500. SUFFOLK CO (516)6691500 CONNECTICUT (203)3487767

title: Stage: The Deserter, Based on Eddie Slovik
description: NEAR the end of World War II, Pvt. Eddie Slovik was executed, the first American soldier to be shot for desertion since the Civil War. Slovik was the subject of a 1954 book by William Bradford Huie and a 1974 television film starring Martin Sheen. Norman Beim's brief new play, The Deserter, running this week in the Circle Repertory Company's latenight series of oneacters, was inspired by the Slovik story, but, according to the author, it is not an attempt to reproduce the facts of the original case.

title: EDUCATION
description: ALTHOUGH Salt Lake, one of the nation's more conservative communities, might seem an unlikely place to find radical educational innovation, everybody here helps run the schools and everybody seems pleased with the arrangement.

title: Associated Press
description: RETURNING TO COURT: Larry Flynt, the publisher of Hustler magazine, arriving at courthouse in Atlanta yesterday surrounded by bodyguards. Mr. Flynt was shot last March as he left courthouse In Lawrenceville, about miles northeast of Atlanta, where he was on trial on charges of distributing obscene material. Mr. Flynt was left partially paralyzed from attack. Jury selection was expected to continue In open court today. Authorities have not caught gunman, who also wounded Gene Reeves, an attorney, during attack.

title: Taxes
description: RESIDENTS of New York State may not be taking advantage of some new tax benefits approved by the Legislature last year because the basic tax package mailed to taxpayers does not contain the necessary forms. But state tax officials are not concerned, and maintain that taxpayers affected by the new law are either sophisticated enough to ferret out the casual references to the new benefits or affluent enough to hire knowledgeable tax help.

title: BELL'S DECISION DUE IN CARTER LOAN CASE
description: Griffin B. Bell, the Attorney General. will announce today whether he will appoint a special prosecutor to investigate bank loans provided to President Carter's family peanut business by the National Bank of Georgia, a Justice Department source said yesterday.

title: News Summary
description: Washington pledged Mideast aid. The Administration said that after the IsrealiEgyption peace treaty was signed it would provide Egypt with about $2 billion arms and Israel with $3 billion toward the cost of withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula. American officials said that the requests would be sent to Congress, where no major resistance is expected. [Page A1, Colume 6.]

title: Energy Stocks Pace Heavy Trading
description: Energy issues dominated the Wall Street spotlight yesterday as popular stock averages pushed higher to finish just below their peak levels of 1979. The pace of trading, meanwhile, continued to accelerate.

title: Treasury Bills Rise in Yields
description: Yields rose on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182day maturities.

title: Young G.O.P. Opposes Weicker
description: WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., March 19 (AP)  The Connecticut Federation of Young Republicans has voted narrowly to oppose the Presidential bid of Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. Ralph Fabian() of Waterbury, the group's president in 1978, said the resolution against Weicker passed narrowly at a convention Saturday, and then only after most of the delegates had left. I'm sure that if this resolution had been presented to the entire delegation, it would have failed misf:rably, he added.

title: New Jewels in Grenada
description: Coups d'etat are unusual in the Englishspeaking Caribbean, where a tradition of constitutionalism is one of the more positive legacies of British colonial rule. But Sir Eric Gairy, who was ousted as Prime Minister of Grenada last week, was himself an unusual figure, little resembling the leaders of the other Anglophone islands.

title: Max Hayward, a British Scholar On Modern Literature of Russia
description: Max Hayward, a foremost British specialist in contemporary Russian literature, died of cancer on Sunday in Oxford, England. He was 51 years old.

title: Increased Iranian Shortfall Seen
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 John F. O'Leary, Deputy Secretary of Energy, testified today that the United States had not yet experienced a shortage of oil caused directly by the halt in imports from Iran, but warned that the nation might be deficient by 900,000 barrels a day, or 4 percent of current consumption, before long.

title: Gulf Coast Monitored for Cholera
description: CHOLERA, a potentially devastating diarrheal disease that disappeared from the United States earlier this century, has reappeared, and experts at the Center for Disease Control here suspect that is likely to stay.

title: Southampton and Arsenal Draw in Quarterfinals, 11
description: SOUTHAMPTON, England, March 15 (AP)  Southampton shrugged off its defeat in the English League Cup at Wembley last Saturday and battled to 11 draw tonight against Arsenal in the quarterfinals of the Football Association Cup.

title: ExBanker Guilty in Fraud Case
description: NEWARK, March 19  A former official of the New Jersey National Bank pleaded guilty today to charges that he had defrauded the bank out of more than $771,000 and used his bank position to sell stolen securities, United States Attorney Robert J. DelTufo announced. The United States Attorney said that between January 1973 and November 1978 Lawrence Stephens, 37 years old, a vice president at an office of the bank in Long Branch, N.J., gave out more than $771,000 in bank funds to William H. Rodgers, 39, who was the operator of Sonny Acres Farm, in return for cash kickbacks.

title: Those Eroding Guidelines
description: Those Eroding Guidelines The atmosphere surrounding this week's review of the Administration's antiinflation policy is gloomy indeed. With the wage guideposts about to face their first major test in the Teamster negotiations, inflation continues unabated and the antiinflation program seems to be disintegrating on all sides. The President's advisers continue to protest that the guideposts have not yet had a chance to work. But that is not likely to persuade the Teamsters to ignore the recent damage suffered by the Administration's policy.

title: Events
description: ELOCUTION OF BENJAMIN, a play by Steve Spears. Directed by Richard it/barren. At Theater Four, 424 West 55th Street, 6:15.

title: Deaths
description: PIOUsMinerva Died suddenly Fn day. March 16.at Lenox Hill liosp tal She is survived try her niece Barbara Pious Bresler of Fairfield. CT 0. a nephew Dr. Donald Pious of Seatqe,Wathington Funeral sere, cos were held on Sunday March 18 al Fairfield. CT.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FULL LEGACY The name of Louis Comfort Tiffany, son of the founder of Tiffany & Company, has become synonymous with Art Nouveau lamps, stainedglass widows, Favrile vases and silver objects. But Tiffany contributed much more to 19thcentury American art. Today through May 12, some SO Tiffany works in oils, watercolors and pastels, and drawings and photographs will be on display at New York University's Grey Art Gallery and Study Center, 33 Washington Place, at Washington Square East.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Der Opernball, Overture, Heubergcr; Humoresque, Koussevitzky; May Night, Overture, RimskyKorsakov; Sinfnnia in B flat, J. C. Bach.

title: Al Unser Nursing Injuries Suffered in Racing Crash
description: ALBUQUERQUE, March 19 (UPI)  Al Unser, a threetime Indianapolis 500 winner, who was injured Saturday at the International Race of Champions in Hampton, Ga., is recupering in Albuquerque, his wife reported today.

title: State Clears Way for Upstate Man To Sell Windmill Energy to Utility
description: ALBANY, March 19 The state's Public Service Commission today paved the way for an Orange County man to become the first to sell windmillgenerated electricity to a New York State utility.

title: IN THE NATION
description: DECATUR, Ala.  When Tommy Lee Hines, a retarded black, was arrested here last May on charges of raping three white women, the local black community called for help from the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.

title: MusclePowered Channel Flight Is Planned
description: LOS ANGELES, March 19 Human muscles will lift an airplane across the English Channel this spring or summer, say the Californians who in 1977 accomplished the longest sustained, controlled manpowered flight.

title: KOCH TO DISCHARGE ROME AS OTB'S HEAD
description: Mayor Koch plans to dismiss the chairman of the Of ftrack Betting Corporation, Bernard Rome, today for publicly challenging the Mayor's support of casino gambling, and appoint the special state anticorruption prosecutor, John F. Keenan, to take his place. Mr. Rome, learning of the Mayor's plans yesterday afternoon, accused Mr. Koch of playing bad politics.

title: Snow Reassures West On Its Supply of Water
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) Heavy snowfalls have helped alleviate fears of a water supply shortage in some areas of the West later this year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: No Sign of Progress as Talks Start on U.N.'s SouthWest Africa Plan
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 19 A new effort by five Western nations to save the United Nations independence plan for SouthWest Africa began today with no sign of progress in overcoming the objections raised by South Africa.

title: U. S. TO SEND EGYPT $2 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  The United States pledged today that after the the signing of an IsraeliEgyptian peace treaty, it would provide Egypt with about $2 billion in planes, tanks and antiaircraft weapons, and Israel with $3 billion for the costs of its withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Low level clouds cover northern New England while heavy convective clouds stretch along a cold front from the Middle West to Texas. Heavy overcast clouds are apparent from the lake region through the Northern Plains States and from the Southwest Desert region to the Southern Plains States. Broken high level clouds cover the Rockies.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Bechtel Corporation and the Hanna Mining Company announced yesterday that through subsidiaries they had acquired for cash 695,590 common shares of Welltech Inc., an oil and gaswell maintenance and completion services company.

title: About New York
description: The Rev. Baybie Hoover could smell the newsstand, so she knew exactly where to reach and touch the building corner where she sings with her tin cup amid the heavy crowds across from Bloomingdale's. She took the tin cup from her wraithlike layers of clothing and felt it, discovering it was battered and pinched shut.

title: The Region
description: JERSEY CITY (AP)  Six persons died yesterday in a fire in a downtown fourstory brick tenement, officials say. The cause of the fire at 192 Mercer Street was not ithmediately known. Fire officials identified the dead as Susie Colon, 49 years old; Edward Vasquez, 22; Eleanor Clark, 22, and her two children, aged 2 and 3. Authorities had yet to identify the sixth body found in the eightfamily tenement, It was not known if anyone else had been hurt in the fire.

title: 11 Policemen Named On Charges of Having Bogus VehicleCards
description: Eight New York City police officers, detective and two supervisors at Police Headquarters have been brought up on Police Department charges for allegedly possessing fraudulent policevehicle identification cards. The genuine cards are used on civilian cars to allow parking in nonparking areas.

title: Income Up Modest 0.6% In February
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) The personal income of Americans rose only slightly last month, but factories continued to operate at a high rate of capacity, the Government reported today.

title: Cardin Shows Haute Couture Designs in China
description: PEKING, March 19 (UPI)  Pierre Cardin today gave the Chinese their first taste of haute couture in decades when he showed off his collections of spring and summer fashions for women and fall clothes for men.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Bell System's big $450 million issue of 40year bonds scheduled for sale today was priced yesterday to yield 9.65 percent, just slightly lower than the rate of return on a similar financing in February. The yield was regarded as relatively low for the current state of the credit markets, and it helped cause a minor decline in bond prices late yesterday afternoon.

title: Are Car Fuel Rules Too Harsh?
description: DETROIT, March 19  Should the Federal Government relax its tough fuel conservation standards for automobiles?

title: This, Ha, Is Called, Ha, Security. Ha. (Sigh)
description: In February 1978, William P. Kampiles sold to the Russians a secret report from a Central Intelligence Agency file to which he had access from March to November 1977. As a result, they know technical details of our most advanced satellitereconnaissance system, the KH11, and what sort of camouflage is needed to defeat it. Mr. Kampiles was convicted, in November 1978, but how many other secrets leak out without our knowledge no one knows.

title: Science] Watch
description: The risk of cancer to the daughters of women who took the drug DES, or diethylstilberstol, during pregnancy may be less than previously believed, according to the initial results of study sponsored by the National Cancer Institute.

title: Skepticism Tempers Relief Among Subway Passengers
description: If riders fear the subways, their feelings seem to be masked behind blank stares and pervasive silence in the closeness of the crowded cars.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in Business Day on Saturday inaccurately depicted the increases in some telephone rates. Intrastate toll rates rose nearly 51 percent from 1967 to 1978 and interstate toll rates increased almost 10 percent in the same penod.

title: Soviet Extends Power of Navy To All Oceans
description: A boast by Adm. Sergei G. Gorshkov that the Soviet Navy has achieved significantly greater operational capabilities is supported by two recent striking examples of the flexibility of Russian sea power.

title: Deaths
description: SCHWAIDELSONSarah The Oak land Jewish Center of Barak* N mourns the passing of its most es teemed & beloved member. We ex tend our sincere sympathies to her husband Morris and children Ruth, Cynthia and Sidney.

title: Foster Gets Contract
description: The Foster Wheeler Corporation said it had received a contract valued at $74 million from Ireland's Electricity Supply Board for the engineering, manufacture and construction of two 300megawatt boilers at Moneypoint, County Clare, the site of Ireland's first major coalfired generating station.

title: Israeli Cabinet Approves Peace Treaty
description: JERUSALEM. March 19  The Israeli Cabinet voted overwhelmingly today to approve the terms of a draft peace treaty with Egypt.

title: Arrows Messing, Zungul Named Soccer AllStars
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 19 (UPI)  Shep Messing, the flamboyant goalkeeper of the New York Arrows, was named today along with five highpowered goal scorers to the Major Indoor Soccer League's first allstar team.

title: Auctions Follow Society to the Sun
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., March 19 Each winter when society flees the cities, the bidding at auctions wanes. To correct that situation, Sotheby Parke Bernet, the auction house, decided a decade ago to follow the wealthy to their watering places: First to cileneagles for Scotland's summer shooting season, then to Monaco and St. Moritz on the Continent. And now Palm Beach.

title: New Experts Easing The Corporate Move
description: In a quiet, carpeted counseling room 16 floors above Park Avenue, a $25,000ayear lowermanagement executive with Union Carbide hesitantly answers questions about his earnings, his family, his housing, transportation, recreational and cultural needs.

title: United Press International
description: FIREMAN CAUGHT IN EXPLOSION: Terry Bowman and a fellow fireman tried to duck for cover, top, from an explosion at a fire in a high school auditorium in Beaverton, Ore. As his clothing burned, below, Mr. Bowman ceived aid from comrade. He was rushed to a hospital where his condition was listed as critical. Several other firemen were injured in, the blaze at the school. which was unoccupied at the time.

title: A.T.&T.'s Net Up 9% In Quarter
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that earnings for the quarter ended Feb. 28 had risen 9 percent while revenues climbed 10.5 percent.

title: Satellite Offer May Aid TV Stations Programming
description: THE RCA Corporation, in accelerating the use of the new satellite technology, finds itself in the position of breaking up the network structure of broadcasting that it pioneered 50 years ago when it created the National Broadcasting Company.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a prisoner can be allowed to justify a jailbreak on the basis of prison conditions that he contends are onerous'; or intolerable.

title: City Official Reports Progress in SchoolBus Talks
description: New York City's director of labor relations said yesterday that some progress had been made toward settling the 34dayold strike by schoolbus drivers during the first facetoface meeting between Board of Education officials and the drivers union since negotiations broke off early in February.

title: Associated Press
description: NEW JERSEY REFINERY EXPLOSION INJURES SIX: Flames erupt from a processing plant at Exxon's Bayway Refinery in Linden, N.J., early this morning. Explosion rocked houses up to tour miles away. Six persons, including employees and firemen, were injured, two seriously. Page B19.An explosion and fire shook an Exxon refinery in Linden, N.J. at 12:30 A.M. today, sending flames 300 to 500 feet into the air, injuring six plant workers and firefighters, two of them seriously, and bnnging in fire engines and ambulances from nearby towns in northern New Jer sey.

title: Space Shuttle Delayed Again
description: EDWARDS MR FORCE BASE, Calif., March 19 (AP)  Heavy rains today forced space agency officials to postpone again the longdelayed flight of the space shuttle Columbia to its launching pad in Cape Canaveral, Fla. The shuttle and its Boeing 747 ferry were to have taken off on a 30minute test flight before dawn, then headed for Florida, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said.

title: New Books
description: Angela Ambrosia, by Ray Errol Fox (Knopf, $7.95). Young girl tries to lead normal life as she battles leukemia.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: ALTHOUGH it has never much bothered me, it apparently troubles some people that the origins of the Bronfman family fortune do not possess its present trappings of high respectability. So at least one concludes when reading Peter C. Newman's King of the Castle: The Making of a Dynasty: Seagram's and the Bronfman Empire, an attempt by a Canadian journalist to expose the background of the great liquor corporation whose sales are expected to reach $3 billion by 1980. For here is what Mr. Newman does: He begins by dazzling us with the wealth and power of the Bronfman family (Except that they are almost certainly richer and without a doubt more secretive, the Bronfmans have become the Rothschilds of the New World.), and especially with the nearapotheosis to highWASP respectability, or yechus (to use the Yiddish word Mr. Newman employs) of the empire's founding father, Sam Bronfman.

title: Braths
description: De RISO  Charles. The Flask Club re. cords with profound Sorrow the passing of its loyal and devoted member.

title: First TV Broadcast of House Session Isn't High Theater
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  Sam Rayburn, the irascible Texan who served as Speaker of the House of Representatives during most of the 1940's and 1950's, once asserted that the debate and proceedings in that legislative chamber constituted the highest theater on earth.

title: U.S. Indicts Sindona on Bank Role
description: Michele Sindona, an Italian financier wanted on fraud charges in Italy, was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges involving the transfer of $40 million that he used to buy a controlling interest in the Franklin National Bank.

title: Police Force Goes From 500 to 900 As War on Subway Crime Begins
description: Hoping to rout muggers and reassure uneasy riders, the Transit Authority posted a force of 900 uniformed police officers  900 more than previously  on all trains and nearly all stations of the 230mile system last night to begin Mayor Koch's $7.5 million plan to combat subway crime.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Thomas Saunders is a 43yearold black businessman who knows sheet metal fabrication like the back of his hand. A graduate accountant, he first worked for a sheet metal corporation, then became a partner in a sheet metal manufacturing venture.

title: BELL WINS REVERSAL OF CONTEMPT ORDER
description: Attorney General Griffin B. Bell won a reversal yesterday of a court order that held him in contempt for his refusal to release the files on 18 informers who spied on the Socialist Workers Party.

title: Mrs. Carter's Energy Plea: Try Walking
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 19 While her husband grappled with national energy problems at Camp David, Rosalynn Carter today offered a Springfield audience her own formula for coping with gasoline shortages and rising prices.

title: Lima Journalists Begin a Fast
description: LIMA, Peru, March 19  Four Peruvian journalists locked themselves in the crypt of Lima's cathedral today in a hunger strike to protest press censorship and the military Government's closure of their publications. They said the closings had made a farce of the transfer of power to a civilian government.

title: Ripping Off The Police
description: ASPEN, Colo.  The police are getting ripped off. They are getting a thirdrate college education. They are paying for, deserve, and require, a lot better. They receive, at best, training under the guise of higher education training in which courses in judo, first aid and firearms take precedence over such subjects as community organization and power structure.

title: Bankers Trust in China Tie
description: The Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday that it had established a correspondent relationship with the Bank of China. Bankers Trust said the move would enable it to expand business with China that it had conducted through its Hong Kong and London offices.

title: Six Measures Designed To Aid Subway Safety
description: The assignment of officers in uniform on all 600 trains between 6 P.M. and 2 A.M., and in most stations between 4 P.M. and 2 A.M.

title: Progress Reported in Namibia Truce Talks at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 20 Western ministers met today with Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa and said afterward that progress had been made toward achieving a ceasefire in SouthWest Africa and United Nationssupervised elections in the territory.

title: TokenBooth Killings Echo in Broad Channel
description: Like the bridge of a ship, or a watchtower on an atoll, the Broad Channel station of the IND subway (elevated at that point in Queens) looks out on the encompassing waters of Jamaica Bay and beyond to the wide world, including the faroff towers of Manhattan.

title: U.S. AND NEW YORK AGREE ON DISPOSING OF NUCLEAR WASTES
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  After more than a year of negotiations, the Federal Energy Department has tentatively agreed to accept responsibility at a possible cost of several hundred million dollars  for eventual disposal outside New York State of huge deposits of I highly radioactive nuclear waste at the West Valley, N.Y., storage facility near Buffalo.

title: Suspect in Oklahoma Slayings Breaks Year of Silence
description: PRYOR, Okla., March 20  After nearly a year of selfimposed silence, Gene Leroy Hart took advantage of a courtroom recess today to answer questions about himself and to discuss some of his thoughts and feelings as he stands trial for his life.

title: Roan Consolidated
description: Rising copper prices helped give Roan Consolidated Mines Ltd. a profit of $11 million, or 37 cents a share, in its second fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31, the company reported. In the earearlier quarter, by contrast, the Zamblabased company (which is 20.4 percent owned by AMAX Inc.) had a loss of $8.1 million.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Bell Names Former U.S. Attorney To Investigate Carter Peanut Loans
description: This is the second time in the history of the United States that a special investigation has been ordered into the affairs of a sitting President. But it was clear, in the scope of the investigation described by Mr. Bell and in the absence of public charges of wrongdoing by President Carter, that today's action did not parallel the appointment of the Watergate special prosecutor to investigate the campaign practices of President Nixon nearly six years ago.

title: Melanie Bartol Is Bride Of John Willard, Lawyer
description: Melanie Smith Bartol of Southport, Conn., a model and actress, was married in Fairfield, Conn., yesterday to John Rockell Willard, a lawyer in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Adam Lewis performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Supreme Court Tightens Protection For Witnesses Granted Immunity
description: WASHINGTON. March 20  The Supreme Court today strengthened the protection afforded a person who testifies before a grand jury under a grant of immurnty.

title: Egypt Calls Begin Remarks Inappropriate
description: CAIRO. March 20  Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil of Egypt said today that remarks by Prime Minister Menachem Begin to the Israeli Parliament, including sharp remarks directed at Mr. Khalil, were an inappropriate start for peace between Israel and Egypt.

title: Caviar Outlook Improves
description: Recent local reports forecasting a shortage of Iranian caviar and resultant price increases were greatly exaggerated, according to wellinformed sources involved in the caviar trade in Europe, the United States and Iran.

title: Year Of The Coast
description: Anyone who mistakenly assumes that the environmental movement is everywhere in retreat  buffeted as it has been by the misleading economic arguments almost daily leveled against it  would gain a different perspective by observing in action a small group of aggressive, knowledgable young environmentalists who have recently launched a brand new crusade to halt the rapid deterioration of one of America's most important natural resources.

title: Monroe Scores 28 as Bucks Fall
description: Streaks of gray are becoming more noticeable in his hair, and he has slowed defensively. But there is a lot of offensive magic left in 34yearold Earl Monroe, and every so often it emerges.

title: Mexico Oil Funds to Go To Industry
description: MEXICO CITY, March 20  After months of heated debate, the Mexiain Government has decided to use its growing oil wealth to finance a huge expansion of the country's industry, giving lessimmediate priority to the creation of muchneeded jobs.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the recent earnings of the Certainteed Corporation. The correct figures are $50.8 million for 1978, $54.1 million for 1977 and $36.6 million for 1976.

title: Notes on People
description: Fifty years is a long time to be playing the piano professionally, and it's even more remarkable that the artist could still be in her prime. That's because Alicia de Larrocha was only 5 years old when she gave her first recital in Barcelona in 1929, too young to even be nervous. I think I was very happy when I was that young, she said. I didn't remember to be nervous until I was an adult.

title: Chess:
description: Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif., who has won the United States champ!. onship three times, finished in the middle of the field in the strong international tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, but the games that he won produced some of the most sparkling, exciting chess of the event. Especially worthy of analysis was his gambit of rook against the British grandmaster Anthony Miles.

title: Woman, 78, Battles for Her Apartment
description: At 10 A.M. yesterday, Celia Goodman, a 78yearold widow, was crying with joy. A locksmith, surrounded by New York City detectives and a lawyer carrying a court order, had just pried open the door to her Manhattan apartment, allowing her access and apparently ending an ordeal that had seen her evicted from a twobedroom, rentcontrolled apartment for which she pays $157 a month. Her belongings were stored in a Brooklyn warehouse.

title: Deaths
description: BE NAJAMAlbert H. On March 20, 1979. Beloved husband of Theodora E. (nee Bender) of Montclair, N J. Father of Albert C., Alan. Charles, Pia and Michael Benalam. Step father of Bethany Hoyle and Grandfather of Jeffrey. Funeral services on Thursday evening at 8:00 PM, at the Scanlan Funeral Home, East 28th Street at 121h Avenue, Pater. son, N.J. Friends may call Wednes. day and Thursday, 79PM In memoriams to favorite charity on medical research.

title: 9 Automatic Stoplights Inaugurated by Peking
description: PEKING, March 20 (Reuters) Peking's first nine automatic traffic lights were turned on today, and officials hoped they would speed traffic.

title: Dominican Republic Is Lent $185 Million
description: LONDON, March 20 (UPI)  The Dominican Republic signed a $185 million loan agreement today with a group of international banks led by the Chase Merchant Banking Group, the Royal Bank of Canada and Banco de Resetvas de la Republica Dominicana, the Chase Manhattan Bank said.

title: Sad Hoffman Tells of Film Suit
description: LOS ANGELES, March 20  A year after he filed a $65million lawsuit against First Artists Productions for taking away his creative control of Straight Time and Agatha, Dustin Hoffman sits in his lawyer's office close to tears. He has tried to give an unemotional account of seizureof both films by Phil Feldman, president of First Artists. But his arms flail the air as the words are not by themselves adequate; and he writhes in his chair. You put in a lifetime of work and training and someone takes your paint brush away.

title: Indiana's Knight Seeking Last Word in NI.T. Final
description: In Bobby Knight's office at Indiana University, there is a poem on the wall:

title: In the Spring
description: In the spring, fewer tankers steam into New York harbor but more cruise ships are seen. The lobstermen set their pots in Gravesend Bay, just seaward of the Verrazano Bridge, and the flounder boats begin going out again. In Hoboken, on the Hudson, boys fish for blue crabs with killifish strung on a bait ring held over a net. The harbor is getting cleaner; there are even rumors that the defunct old oyster beds behind the Statue of Liberty have been showing signs of life.

title: CARTER CONSIDERING GRADUAL DECONTROL OF OIL AND NEW TAX
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  The Carter Administration is considering a new energy program that would combine the phased lifting of price controls on domestic crude oil with an accompanying tax at the wellhead or on oil companies profits, White House officials said today.

title: The City
description: Criminal charges filed against Abraham Hirschfeld, a landlord, by two ot his tenants were dismissed on a technicality in Manhattan Criminal Court. A lawyer for the tenants, Martin Goldman. said he would ask the consumer affairs bureau of the District Attorney's office to file charges against Mr. Hirschfeld, the former mayoral and United State Senate candidate.

description: In percent

title: U.S. and Jersey Investigate Blast At Oil Refinery
description: Federal and state safety officials Joined company investigators yesterday in seeking the cause of a massive early morning explosion and fire at an Exxon refinery in Linden, N.J., that injured seven persons, two seriously, and shook buildings four miles away.

title: Financial Consultant Sentenced For Not Filing U.S. Tax Returns
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 20 (AP)  Irwin Schiff, a financial consultant whose book accused the Federal government of conning the public, was sentenced today to six months in prison for intentionally not filing incometax returns.

title: U.S. Aid Asked Devon Hints In Asian Trade Simplicity Deal
description: MANILA, March 20  Serious concern about the ability of United States business to survive unaided against aggressive foreign competition dominated the semiannual meeting of the AsiaPacific Council of American Chambers of Commerce, which ended here yesterday.

title: Deaths
description: BLUMBERG  Beniarnin Beloved husband of Fay, devoted father of Phiilio, Sherrie Posner and Susan PoIan. Adored brother and greatgrandfather. Services Thurs., 9:45 AM at Schwartz fsrothers Forest Park Chapels duetor Blvd A, 76 Rd., Forest Hills

title: Big Bell Issue Is Offered
description: The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company's $450 million issue of 40year debentures, priced late Monday to yield 9.65 percent, was formally offered to investors yesterday as the corporate market headed into its first billiondollar week since midOctober.

title: Midland to Expand
description: The MidlandRoss Corporation announced it would spend more than $18 million at its Cicero, Ill., foundry to virtually double the plant's capacity for production of steel castings. The expansion will raise the Cicero plant capacity from about 26,000 to 50,000 tons of steel castings a year. The project is scheduled for completion in 1981.

title: 6 Cameras, Faster Film Introduced by Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company today introduced six new cameras plus an instant film that it said was twice as fast as its fastest film now on the market.

title: Text Tied to Khomeini Published by the C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  The Central Intelligence Agency has published an Englishlanguage version of Islamic Government, a book reportedly based on lectures given in Paris by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the revolutionary leader of Iran.

title: $50 Million in Fur on View
description: The New York Coliseum is housing $50 million in fur garments and pelts. and thousands of retailers and wholesalers have passed through the doors of the American International Fur Fair. which opened Sunday.

title: Filmways Sets Merger Accord
description: Filmways Inc., a diversified producer of movies for television, said yesterday that it had signed a merger agreement providing for the takeover of American International Pictures, a producer of motion picture and television programming.

title: Companies' '78 Profits Up by 26%
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  Corporate profits surged by 26 percent last year, fueled by a yearend business boom that approached a 7 percent annual growth rate, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Private Detective Rank Is Backed for Reporters
description: BOSTON, March 20 (UPI)  The Massachusetts House has given preliminary approval to a bill that would force investigative news reporters to register with the state as private detectives.

title: Gardner Murphy Is Dead at 83; Psychologist, Author, Professor
description: Gardner Murphy, an eminent psychologist and pioneer scientist in the field of parapsychology, died Monday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington, D.C., following a protracted illness. He was 83 years old.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Gary L. Seevers, the acting chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, began a longscheduled week's vacation in Clearwater Heath, Fla., last Saturday. But it has not been too restful so far. Since Sunday, the commission has been in court over its unsuccessful attempt to terminate the last three days of trading in March wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade, and Mr. Seevers has been in the middle of the battle via long distance.

title: Italy's Car Exports
description: ROME, March 20 (UPI)  Italy exported fewer automobiles last year but sold them for higher prices, the Central Statistical Institute said today. The value of auto exports in 1978 grew 16 percent to $3.15 billion; the number of cars exported fell 2 percent to 714,000.

title: Oil Output Up In Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 20 (AP)  Venezuela's oil industry continues to increase production to help meet worldwide demand following the cutback of oil exports from Iran.

title: The Worldly Delights of Garlic
description: IT would seem that since the beginning of time the world has been divided into the alliumphiles and the alliumphobes, those who love garlic and those who have a passionate dislike for it. It would also seem that garlic, more than any other herb, has through the ages been considered by many to be a miracle worker, a serious cureall for an extraordinary number of fevers, humors and other ills.

title: JOHN THOMPSON, 61, A STATE FISCAL AIDE
description: John R. Thompson, former first deputy comptroller of New York State, died Monday at his home in Albany. He was 61 years old and also lived in Rensselaerville, N.Y.

title: With an Accord in Chad Conflict, France Is Pulling Out Its Forces
description: PARIS. March 20  The French Government announced today that, since a ceasefire had been signed between warring factions in Chad, the French military forces were being withdrawn.

title: DORIS ROTBERG
description: LIVINGSTON, N.J., March 20 Doris Rotberg, an officer of several philanthropic organizations in the state, died of cancer today at St. Barnabas Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived in Short Hills.

title: Economic Scene
description: THIS is shaping up as a year in which virtually all the economic forecasters are likely to wind up with egg on their chin, if not a custard pie in their face.

title: Sidney Licht, Medical Authority
description: Dr. Sidney Licht, a physician, professor and author, died Sunday at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. He was 71 years old.

title: A Lawyer of Competence and Integrity
description: Paul Jerome Curran is a prominent member of the prosecutors fraternity in New York, and yesterday the brethren, most of them Democrats, cheered the appointment of the Republican to the delicate task of investiegating the business dealings Of a Democratic President and his family.

description: DAYTONA BEACH, FLA.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Viggiano Wins an Assembly Seat In S.I. District in an Easy Victory
description: Paul Viggiano, whose father was a legandary Democratic district leader on Manhattan's Lower East Side, won an Assembly seat with unexpected ease in a special election yesterday.

title: WNETTV Raises $1.1 Million
description: WNETTV's recent twoweek fundraising drive brought the publictelevision station 41,720 new members and $1,166,479 in pledges, according to figures compiled by the station. Harold Holzer, a spokesman for WNET, said that the station usually received about 98 percent of the money pledged. Presently, the Federal Government matches $2 for every dollar raised by publictelevision station.

title: 76 Death of Infant Is Restudied After Brother Dies of Starvation
description: The police said yesterday that the Queens Medical Examiner had reopened the case of the 1976 crib death of a Queens couple's 4monthold child after the death Sunday of the couple's other child, a 15monthold boy, from dehydration and malnutrition.

title: California Bonds Yield 6% In Major Test of Market
description: In the first of two major tests of the taxexempt bond market this week, California sold $125 million of topgrade bonds yesterday in a financing that showed that investors are in no rush to accept lower yields.

title: South African Pilot Links Murder Of Politician and Wife to Scandal
description: JOHANNESBURG. March 20  South Afrim's Information Ministry scandal took a mysterious turn today with a former pilot's assertion that two West Germans were paid $35,400 each to murder a politician and his wife a week before the 1977 general election.

title: Toward An Energy Policy
description: The recent problems in Iran have prompted a new sense of urgency and revived the inevitable questions about our lack of an effective energy policy. Out current dilemma is not due to a lack of energy resources, technology or money. It is an institutional problem.

title: Viking Display Coming
description: What is called the largest and most comprehensive exhibition on the Vikings, the adventurous seafarers of ancient Scandinavia, is scheduled to open at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in October 1980.

title: Malissa Childs Elliott; Author and Journalist Held State Dept. Jobs
description: HANOVER, N.H., March 20 Malissa Childs Elliott, an author and journalist, died of a brain tumor here today at Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital. She was 50 years old and lived in Sorinefield. Vt.

title: Bank Sought to Share Credit Line for Carter Business
description: The National Bank of Georgia sought to get other banks to assume $5 million of a line of credit for President Carter's family peanut business at the same time the business was late in making loan repayments to the Atlanta bank, according to bank reports and documents.

title: Uncountable Aliens Should Count
description: Their number and whereabouts may be unknown, but the presence in New York City of a half million or million or million and a half illegal aliens is no secret. As Howard Blum's two articles in The Times revealed this week, small businesses relish this growing source of cheao labor. City Hall, on the other hand, is Painfully aware of the costs of providing them with municipal services. While local officials try to cope with the burden, national immigration policy muddles along, stuck somewhere between the extremes of blanket amnesty and wholesale deportation.

title: UNC Resources Sells Properties
description: UNC Resources Inc. announced the sale for $37.9 million of its 50 percent interest in a number of uranium properties in the Powder River Basin of Wyoming to the Tennessee Valley Authority, its joint venture partner in development of these properties.

title: Big 8 Is Given Ultimatum In Hearing on Slush Fund
description: KANSAS CITY, March 20 (AP)  The Big Eight Conference was given a choice today of either submitting further evidence against Jim Stanley, the former Oklahoma State football coach, or proceeding against the university and leaving Stanley out of any further action.

title: Mets Are Scheduled for Large Revamping
description: ST. PETERSBURG. Fla.. March 20  An upheaval in the starting lineup of the New York Mets seemed imminent today when Manager Joe Torre flew back to camp from Puerto Rico to begin the annual bloodletting known as cutting the squad.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: Film: 'The Bell Jar':A Would-Be Poet
description: EVEN though Sylvia Plath was substantially older than her college-girl autobiographical heroine when she wrote "The Bell Jar," the book has an adolescent spirit. Its hypersensitivity, its romantic flights of fancy and its seesawing moods are as typically teen-age as they are early signs of the author's illness, which eventually led to her suicide. This is the signal quality of "The Bell Jar," a schoolgirl overstatement that makes the book as amateurish as it is haunting, and it's a quality that the film version doesn't even begin to understand. This is as sane, cheery and level-headed an account of a nervous breakdown as you could ever hope to see."The Bell Jar," which opens today at Cinema I, makes it impossible to believe that its heroine, Esther Greenwood, is a hard-working and extremely driven would-be poet; as played by Marilyn Hassett, Esther is, even at her most hysterical, more like a cheer-leader whose team has just lost a big game. This is disastrous, not because Miss Hassett doesn't make Esther brainy enough but because it is the character's imaginative life that leads her to a collapse, and the movie barely even goes skin-deep. The audience isn't given the slightest clue about Esther's quirks, her fears, her peculiarly distorted notion of herself. She seems to be afraid of sex, and she also seems to be the object of amorous attention from most of the women she knows but, beyond that, the movie doesn't explain a thing.Much of the story is concerned with Esther's experiences in New York, in the 50's, as a guest editor at a women's magazine. Larry Peerce, who directed "Goodbye, Columbus," would seem well equipped to send up the fashion world in these sequences, but there's no satirical edge to any of this, and no dramatic edge either. It all simply plods along, en route to a nervous collapse that manages to seem perfectly unwarranted by the time it finally occurs. The scenes that are supposed to trigger all the trouble  Esther's confrontations with her mother (Julie Harris) and her strangely sadistic editor (Barbara Barrie), a gratuitously sleazy orgy with a disk jockey (Robert Klein)  are appallingly flat, neither explanatory nor disturbing.When Esther finally decides to commit suicide, she does so in a way that's instructively at odds with the suicide attempt in the book. Miss Plath's heroine meant business: She took an overdose of pills and hid in the cellar of her mother's house, where she was found only by accident. Miss Hassett's Esther writes a farewell note on a mirror in lipstick, then slashes one wrist and scrawls something in the sink, writes a farewell message on a notepad and wanders downstairs without really bothering to hide. This sequence, which lasts a long time and isn't affecting in the slightest, is emblematic of the movie's way of spelling things out ad nauseam and still not making them clear.Miss Hassett is unconvincing and, much of the time, unsympathetic; she hasn't a hint of the mystery that might make an audience believe in her madness. The best she can do is to raise her voice unexpectedly to indicate she's disturbed, and also to stop washing her hair. As sweet-faced and appealing as Miss Hassett was in Mr. Peerce's "The Other Side of the Mountain," she's so wrong for "The Bell Jar" that she tries an audience's patience before long. Of the other actors, only Julie Harris breathes any life into the material  although nothing in either her performance or Miss Hassett's makes it possible to understand why Esther hates her mother.The script, by Marjorie Kellogg, is full of overwrought extremes, even though Mr. Peerce directs virtually all of it with an inappropriate evenness. The editing of the film is so choppy it calls constant attention to itself. The music, by Gerald Fried, is pretty, and so are the costumes, by Donald Brooks.

title: Begin Says Israel Will Never Allow Palestinian State in Occupied Area
description: JERUSALEM, March 20  Opening a marathon debate in Parliament on the peace treaty with Egypt, Prime Minister Menachem Begin vowed today that Israel would never permit the establishment of a Palestinian state in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: EARNINGS
description: The K Mart Corporation, the nation's secondlargest retailer, yesterday reported a 23.7 percent jump in earnings for the fiscal fourth quarter, ended Jan. 31, and a 15.4 percent gain for the full fiscal year.

title: Accord Reached In Most Disputes In College Strike
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 20 Tentative agreement was reached late this afternoon on most major disputed issues that resulted in a strike against eight state colleges by a facultyprofessional union this morning.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FRENCH PICTURES Eight films by young French filmmakers will have their United States premieres today, tomorrow and Friday, during a film festival sponsored by Columbia University's French House and the French Cultural Services. A ninth film, Le Rouge de Chine, by Jacques Richard, was previously presented here.

title: Ruth Finney Allen, 81, Journalist for 50 Years
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 Ruth Finney Allen, a journalist who worked for the ScrippsHoward newspaper chain for 50 years, died today at her Georgetown home following a long illness. She was 81 years old.
