title: Affidavits Censored in Bomb Article Case
description: MADISON, Wis., March 20  The United States Attorney's office here suppressed today large portions of affidavits submitted by the author of an article on the hydrogen bomb in connection with The Progressive magazine's defense against a Government attempt to have it enjoined from publishine the article.

title: Got baum Embroiled in Dispute With Council 37 Rival
description: A bitter dispute that could have farreaching ramifications has erupted within the ranks of New York City's powerful publicemployee union.

title: Companies Merge
description: Two public relations concerns, Irving L. Straus Associates and the Haft Group, have merged to become Straus Associates/ Haft Group with headquarters at 655 Third Avenue. Mr. Straus is president and Herbert L. Haft is executive vice president.

title: Stage: 'The Elocution of Benjamin
description: THE Elocution of Benjamin begins with Gordon Chater, the play's entire cast, naked on stage. Mr. Chater is an overweight, aging Australian actor, and in the ripples and folds of his body  soon coverea by a towel and then by clothes  we think we see a man without sham or illusions. As we discover in this new Australian play, which opened last night at Theater Four, the character played by Mr. Chater is a man who has cloaked his life with pretense.

title: Recital: Sephardic Songs
description: THE voice of Victoria de los Angeles, once one of the loveliest soprano sounds this side of heaven, is not what it once was, and there were moments in the early part of her recital at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. last night when one winced at the hard, forced tones the Spanish singer had to resort to in her performances of songs by Ravel, Milhaud and Rodrigo.

title: Careers
description: ALTHOUGH rsums may not produce jobs, they have long been considered a good way to get a foot in the door, at least by most experts in the personnel field. How else, many of them argue, can they know who is out there knocking?

title: Private Lives
description: EITHER he makes me uneasy, or his house does. The house is on a side street in a Southern college town, down among the furniture factories. But the house really belongs Berkeley, Calif., where once upon a time, before anybody had been divorced, we were dolphins together.

title: 2 Villages Vote to Begin Secession
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 20  Residents in two Westchester County villages today overwhelmingly approved separate but identical ballot questions directing local officials to begin the legal process of seceding from the central Westchester Town of Mount Pleasant.

title: Senate's Ethics Panel Finds Brooke Committed Only Minor Violations
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  After a 10month investigation into the financial affairs of former Senator Edward W. Brooke, the Senate ethics committee concluded today that the Massachusetts Republican had committed only minor violations of Congressional conduct rules while serving on Capitol Hill insufficient to warrant punishment even if he were still in the Senate.

title: Recital: Unusual Piano Fare
description: MARYLENE DOSSE is a specialist in the lessorthodox areas of piano literature. She has recorded concertos by Massenet, Lab o and Piern, not to mention the complete piano solos of SaintSans. On Monday night she gave the first of two programs in Alice Tully Hall devoted to just such unusual fare. In this instance the music stemmed from the imperial and postimperial years of Vienna, Budapest and Prague. The pianist calls the programs Nocturnes.

title: Willie Horton's Sharp New Image
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Willie Horton has never looked much like a baseball player, much less a smart baseball player. quatty instead of slim, slow instead of fast, a slugger instead of a schemer, he fit the image of those who vanish into obscurity once pitchers throw the fastball by them. But now Willie Horton has a sharp new image. Frontoffice people suddenly are aware he is worth inspection as a potential manager, or at least as a potential coach. He looms as the Seattle Mariners designated hitter this season, but his new image is more significant. Strangely, it developed accidentally. To enhance his value as a 35yearold free agent after the frustration of wandering from Texas to Cleveland to Oakland to Toronto last season, he joined the Valencia team of the Venezuelan Winter League as its dh. But when Cookie Rojas departed as manager in midseason, Willie Horton suddenly was appointed his successor. And he succeeded as few baseball managers ever have.

title: For 7 Women Contestants, Fairness Is in Eye of Beholder
description: Seven unsuccessful beauty contes:.ints charged yesterday that an affiliate of the Miss Universe organization had misled them about the $750 in sponsor fees required to compete in the New York State finals and that last week's voting had been marred by appearances of favoritism.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Personal Health
description: IN a collision with a cement truck four years ago, Robert T. was severely injured, breaking both arms and legs and many ribs, severing the nose from his face and suffering deep cuts all over his body. The highway patrolman first on the scene noticed Robert was wearing a Medic Alert bracelet that said he was a hemophiliac. If Robert was going to live, he had 20 to 30 minutes to get to a hospital that had the blood constituents needed to stop his bleeding.

title: Fire Razes Old Depot in Bridgeport
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 20  A twoalarm fire, apparently set by arsonists early this morning, destroyed a. vacant 75yearold railroad station that city officials had hoped to renovate as the catalyst for the revitalization of downtown Bridgeport, the state's largest city.

title: GRACE LEWIS HOXTER
description: Grace Lewis Hoxter, an artist and printmaker, died of cancer Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 53 years old.

title: Treasury's 2Year Note Sale Put Off
description: The Treasury, citing the failure of Congress to raise the limit on the national debt, postponed yesterday the sale of $2.88 billion of twoyear notes it had scheduled for this afternoon.

title: Flawed Start for a Major Cookbook Series
description: HAVING exhausted just about all of the viable ethnic approaches to food in their 27volume Foods of the World series, and left with a 24karat mailing list of subscribers as a result, the editors of TimeLife have found yet another form in which to package recipes and string them out into a brandnew collection.

title: TV: Edward the King Still Reigns on Channel 5
description: As Edward the King enters the home stretch, reaching the 10th of 13 episodes tonight 8 on WNEW/Channel 5, the import from British commercial television continues to retain remarkable dramatic strength.

title: Yankees Shelled By Twins
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 20  If the New York Yankees had not acquired Tommy John and Luis Ti ant during the offseason, Jim Beattie probably would have been their No. 4 starting pitcher this year.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: T HIS morning. writes Alex Nazemetz New Jersey. coming in on the Gladstone branch of Conrail (formerly and more beloved Erie Lackawanna) we had standees lammed in the aisles 25 miles out.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: SIMPLY by pressing a piece of meat with his fingertips, a professional chef can tell, with considerable accuracy, whether the meat is done. The clue is in how springy the meat is. Raw meat doesn't bounce back; rare meat does.

title: WCBSTV Bringing Back Lassie and Gentle Ben
description: Starting April 2, WCBSTV/Channel 2 will carry repeats of Lassie and Gentle Ben to replace the weekday talk show Everyday.

title: Taiwan to Discuss Olympic Issue
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 20 The Chinese Nationalists decided today to send a delegation to Switzerland to discuss the question of Chinese representation on the International Olympic Committee.

title: Goldin Accuses Critics In BusShelter Dispute Of Smear Campaign
description: City Comptroller Hairison J. Goldin charged yesterday that he was the victim of a ferocious smear campaign being conducted by officials of Bustop Shelters, which he said had submitted the absolutely worst bid for the city's fantastically lucrative busshelter franchise.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 20  A fivegoal performance by Steve Zungul sparked the New York Arrows to a 94 victory over the Cincinnati Kids tonight at the Nassau Coliseum and put the Arrows into the twoofthree game final of the first Major Indoor Soccer League championship.

title: Market Place
description: FOR a long time now, !lousing bonds have been regarded as stronger credits than hospital bonds in the marketplace, with the result that prices were generally higher, and yields lower, for the housing securities.

title: Rockwell Puts Price On Buying Wilmot
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said it might pay about $40 million to acquire the 20 million outstanding shares of Wilmot Breeden Holdings Ltd., a British maker of automotive devices.

title: Queens CableTV Grant Blocked
description: A State Supreme Court justice enjoined the Board of Estimate yesterday from implementing a franchise given to the operate a cabletelevision system in Oueens.

title: Meeting With Pentagon Set on Status of Fort Dix
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said today that the New Jersey Congressional delegation would meet Thursday with the Secretary of Defense, Harold Brown, to discuss reports that the Defense Department was again considering a plan to deactivate Fort Dix.

title: Clerks at Aqueduct Reject New Proposal
description: The union representing parimutuel clerks at Aqueduct voted overwhelmingly yesterday to reject new proposals by the New York Racing Association to end the 35day labor dispute.

title: Panel Suggests 5 For State Judge In List for Carey
description: ALBANY, March 20  New York State's Commission on Judicial Nomination today sent Governor Carey the names of three sitting judges, a former judge and the dean of Fordham University Law School as candidates to fill the vacancy on the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.

title: Bridge:
description: NORFOLK. Va.. March 20 Almost all the favored teams survived into the fourth round of the Vanderbilt Knock out Team Championship at the Ameri can Contract Bridge League's spring nationals at the Scope Convention Cen ter here today. One exception was the seventhseeded group composed of

title: How Cornell Cot Price Relief
description: Since the beginning of the Carter Administration's guidelines program, only one exemption to its price restraint standard has been granted, although several exemptions from the wage limit have been extended to industries facing shortages of skilled workers.

title: Federal's Expected To Liquidate by '80
description: Federal's Inc., a department store chain that had 54 stores a year ago hut now has only two, will be out of business by the end of the year, according to Stanley Bershad, a lawyer, who is in charge of liqudiating the firm.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: The Region
description: A new program for preserving the scenic beauty of the Hudson River has been presented to Governor Carey and to the State Legislature by the state's Department of Environmental Conservation. Commissioner Robert F. Flacke said his department would would develop new guidelines for enviconmentalimpact statements that would give more importance to the scenic impact of construction projects.

title: T.W.A. Will Seek Atlantic Fare Rise
description: Trans World Airlines said yesterday that, because of surging fuel prices, it soon would ask Government permission to raise transAtlantic fares by 7 percent.

title: Energy Issues Falter
description: Energy stocks faltered yesterday after showing strong gains in recent sessions, and the rest of the market played followtheleader in a moderate retreat.

title: OwensIllinois Purchase
description: OwensIllinois Inc. said yesterday that it had increased its equity interest in the Nippon Glass Company, a major glass container manufacturer in Japan, to 30 percent from 19.5 percent. The purchase price for the increased equity in Nippon Glass was not disclosed. Nippon Glass. sales in 1978 were about $180 million.

title: Around the Nation
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 20 (AP) All four defendants were found not guilty of all charges today in the 1977 slaying of Dr. Rulon Allred, the polygamist leader.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  These are the gentle seductive days in Washington, when the herring begin to run up the Potomac and, by some similar instinct, Senators begin running for the White House.

title: Corporations Report Their Sales and Earnings Results for the Quarter
description: ASA LTD (N)

title: Study Turns Up Surprises on Fiscal Shape of Cities
description: A twoyear study of 66 cities with populations from 50,000 to 900,000 shows some surprising exceptions to the generally known fact that the oldest cities are the most likely to be financially troubled.

title: Rangers Gain 22 Tie In Last Five Seconds
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 29Trailing the Washington Capitals, 21, with time running out, the Rangers salvaged a 22 tie as Phil Esposito scored with just 5 seconds left tonight at Capital Centre.

title: U.S. Would Consolidate Student Aid Plans
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)  The Carter Administration suggested today that the Government consolidate its student assistance programs, make colleges responsible for dispensing student aid and relieve schools of the task of collecting the loans.

title: Koch SubwayCrime Program Passes Its First Test
description: The first test of a new crash program to combat subway crime ran smoothly Monday night, and Transit Police officials said yesterday that they were planning only minor adjustments. Four hundred officers in uniform were put on night duty to supplement the 500 normally on duty.

title: Books of The Times
description: DEREK WALCOTT is a poet and a revolutionary, and what he proposes in The StarApple Kingdom would be, it came true, the first poetic revolution. I mean a political revolution achieved through modifications of consciousness that deserve to be described as poetry.

title: Hammer Victim Dies, Setting Off Inquiry by Jury
description: An Orthodox Jewish teenager died of a cerebral contusion last Friday, five days after he was struck on the head with a hammer by a man who had taunted him with religious slurs as he was shepherding seven children home from a Madison Square Garden hockey game, according to the police.

title: Real Estate
description: THE office market in Manhattan is geographically divided, in the simplest terms, into midtown and downtown. Actually there are geographic submarkets, especially in the midtown area. They are faring quite differently.

title: ABC Sweeps Ratings
description: With Sunday night's television movie The Jericho Mile augmenting the clutch of popular situation comedies that have led the audience ratings all season, ABCTV scored a thumping victory over its rivals last week, one of the largest weekly ratings triumphs ever by a network. NBCTV, meanwhile, testing a raft of new series for their acceptance with the audience, had one of its poorest weeks ever.

title: Finland Begins Search for a New Coalition
description: LONDON, March 20  Finland began today the search for a new coalition government to give expression to the confusing outcome of the parliamentary elections held Sunday and yesterday.

title: Athlete at Syracuse U. Dies
description: SYRACUSE, March 20 (UPI) A Syracuse University freshman collapsed and died while playing intramural basketball at the Archibold gymnasium last night. Edwin Landis, 19 years old, of Bernardsville, N.J., apparently suffered a heart attack during the game. He was pronounced dead on arrival at CrouseIrving Memorial Hospital. Mr. Landis lived on campus at Booth Hall dormitory.

title: U.S. Aide Says Child Care Funds Will Not Increase Substantially
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., March 20 (AP) President Carter's special assistant for women's issues said today that the Federal Government could not afford substantial increases in the financing of day care.

title: Catchings Is Crucial to 117110 Victory
description: PISCATAWAY. N.J. March 29  The gold chain Harvey Catchings wears around his neck has the letters: DEFENSE. Tonight, it was timely in describing the job Catchings did on Bob Lanier, Detroit's star center, in the New Jersey Nets 117110 victory over the Pistons at the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: Two Former Officials of G.S.A. Get Jail Terms in Fraud Scandal
description: BALTIMORE, March 29 (AP)  Citing the need to set an example for Government employees, a United States District Court judge today sentenced two former General Services Administration officials to jail.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The kid's name doesn't matter because it changes all the time. He's a prelirn boy, someone willing to put on a pair of boxing gloves on a moment's notice and get knocked out at some small fight club desperate for a lastminute substitute opponent. On good nights, the kid can make $75 just for risking his brains and body.

title: Citicorp Increases Dividend
description: Citicorp, in announcing a 3cent Increase to 32 cents in its quarterly dividend yesterday, indicated that it did not expect its earnings ratios in 1979 to exceed its averages in the best three of the last five years.

title: U.S. Drug Unit Denies It Plotted a Bank Theft
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration issued a statement today saying that as an organization it did not originate plans for an aborted $50 million bank theft by Stanley Mark Rifkin, a Los Angeles computer consultant, nor did it encourage him to commit the theft.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IF one learns a few basic techniques, the rest of cooking Is only ?? plied logic. There are, astonishingly, few ground rules. If you ?? make a basic mayonnaise, for example, you can make a sau?? remoulade, a sauce tartare and so on with the simple addition of a few ingredients such as chopped anchovy, capers, and pickles. Similarly if you can make a basic hollandaise, the technique of making variatior on it  bearnaise, sauce Choron and so forth  are easy to come by. A basic white sauce becomes a Mornay with the addition of cheese, and d brown sauce becomes a sauce madere with the addition of madeira wine. If hasty cooking is your goal, one of the most basic techniques to lit. learned is a method of sauteeing chicken. If you know the few, easily learned steps involved, your range in flavors is almost limitless. You simply start with the base and add flavors according to your taste and imagination. Your inventiveness can run riot.

title: KURDS PRESS ATTACK ON IRANIAN TROOPS
description: SANANDAJ, Iran, March 20  Kurdish rebels demanding autonomy carried their uprising against the new Iranian Government into a third day here.

title: Prospects for Equal Rights Plan Dim as Drive Fails in Key States
description: A drive to pass the equal rights amendment this winter in four key states has failed in three of them  Oklahoma, North Carolina and Illinois  and is in doubt in the fourth, Florida. As a result, chances for the eventual passage of the amendment look increasingly bleak.

title: Jewish Women: Changing Relationships
description: Mildred Levine, 76 years old, the grandmother of five and president of the sisterhood of the Flatbush Jewish Center, never had any desire to seek fulfillment in a career. I may have had the option, but I simply didn't want it. she said the other evening.

title: El Salvador Blacked Out by Strike
description: SAN SALVADOR, March 20 (UPI) More than 1,200 striking electrical workers virtually paralyzed this Central American nation today.

title: Advertising
description: LEDA SANFORD was president, publisher and editor in chief of American Home magazine. More recently, she was president and publisher of Chief Executive magazine. Now she is publisher and editor in chief of Attenzione, a proposed magazine for ItalianAmericans. She's using a much fuller name, Leda Giovannetti Sanford, but a rose by any other name....

title: Technology
description: IT all looked fairly straightforward in 1976. That was when the microwave cooking products division of Litton Industries petitioned the Federal Communications Commission for permission to operate its microwave ovens at a higher frequency in the radio spectrum.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CALGARY, Alberta, March 20The International Shell Group and its Canadian partners will begin the regulatory process June 19 to obtain an Alberta permit to build and operate the world's third commercial oil sand plant, estimated to cost almost $5 billion (Canadian).

title: Miss Barker Finds Her Groove
description: Two years ago, Sue Barker was the girl with the golden forehand, young, starryeyed and only a shot or two away from challenging Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova for the top spot in women's tennis.

title: Hashish Unloaded From Cargo Ship
description: Dock workers at Port Newark remove bags of hashish from the hold of the Olaug, a Liberian freighter seized Saturday evening off Sandy Hook, N.J., by Federal authorities. Twenty tons of the drug, with a street value of about $40 million, were found aboard. Eight persons have been arrested.

title: Arts Academy Awards Honors
description: The 1979 awards for literature conferred by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters will go to Arlene Croce, critic and journalist; Barry Hannah, novelist; James McConkey, novelist and shortstory writer; Robert M. Pirsig, technical writer; Richard Poirier, teacher and critic, poets, Morris, Philip Schultz and Dave Smith. Each award of $4,000 is to honor and encourage creatine work.

title: Mainline Churches Rediscover Healing
description: WHEN Emily Gardiner Neal was a writer for national magazines in the 1950's, she set out to expose the healing ministries, but instead became one of America's bestknown healers.

title: James M. Long of A.P.; Correspondent Was 71
description: ROME, March 20 (AP)  James M. Long, a foreign correspondent of The Associated Press for 27 years, died today after.a long illness. He was 71.

title: Coalition Cabinet Offered in Italy
description: ROME, March 20  Acting Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti announced today that he had formed a new threeparty coalition Cabinet, but it was being predicted here that he would be defeated in Parliament and that the main task of his Cabinet would be to organize June elections.

title: The Wrong Seal Hunt
description: ARHUS, Greenland  Dog food is expensive these days. Sealskin is not.

title: Nicaragua on Edge as Rebels Prepare
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 15 While Nicaragua awaits a new insurrection aimed at overthrowing President Anastasio Somoza Debayle, the country is slowly being torn apart by common crime, guerrilla action and brutal repression.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, March 20  Emergency legislation was being rushed through the House of Commons today to keep Scottish justice functioning during a strike of court officials. A walkout of clerks and stenographers has brought the administration of justice to a virtual standstill.

title: Grant Will Aid Chicago Study
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  The Chicagobased John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, established by the late John D. MacArthur, who owned the Bankers Life and Casualty Company, announced today its first ma ior erant of uo to $500.000

title: Best Buys
description: Suddenly it's spnning, and almost overnight greengrocer stands all over the city seem to be sprouting with fresh salad greens, tender stalks of asparagus and giant, global artichokes. What's more, the quality is high and the prices are declining, as spring crops from Florida, California, Texas and Arizona arrive in the East.

title: Red Cross Assails Both Sides in Rhodesia Fighting
description: GENEVA, March 20  The International Committee of the Red Cross, departing from its policy of diplomatic circumspection, denounced both sides in the Rhodesian guerrilla war today for their wanton and persistent cruelty.

title: Saudis Said to Restrict Swimming by Women
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, March 20 (Reuters)  Women have been barred from using hotel swimming pools in this city on the Red Sea, the Saudi Gazette, an Englishlanguage newspaper, reported today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Energy and Inflation: A Maze of Paradoxes
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  The debate over energy and the economy has illustrated, once again, that in government, the ideas put forward as solutions are often not solutions at all.

title: Speak Up, Mr. President
description: Jimmy Carter is not to blame for the shadows of Watergate that haunt the investigation of his family's peanut business. But he needs to be just as sensitive to the Nixon scandal now that it momentarily darkens his path as he was when it cleared the way for his climb to the Presidency.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: The AfterTax Tie

title: A DowntoEarth Star Offer
description: Weather permitting, New Yorkers will have a chance this evening to gaze through powerful telescopes at Jupiter and its moons, at the ringed planet Saturn and at other celestial obiects

title: Spring at a Disco: Black Ties and Sneakers
description: SPRING was still two days off, officially, but the fashion designer Hardy Amies didn't let the calendar bother him. On Monday night he gave a dinnerdance for about a thousand people at the trendy New YorkNew York discotheque, and the theme for the evening was The Rites of Snrine.

title: News of the Theater
description: THE Goodbye People will go into previews at the Belasco Theater on April 17 and open on May 1. Actually, it will be a reincarnation for the play by Herb Gardner, one of several, in fact, that it has had. In the beginning, in 1968, it was at the Ethel Barrvrnore. where it got through only seven performances. In the cast then were Milton Berle, Bob Dishy and Brenda Vaccaro. Now, 10 years, a couple of rewrites and a few productions later, it will star Herschel Bernardi, Melanie Mayron and Ron Rifkin. The producer is Joe Kipness, and the director is Jeff Bleckner.

title: Al Hodge, 67, Played Captain Video on TV
description: Al Hodge, who as Captain Video became one of television's earliest and bestknown children's heroes, died on Monday in his room at the George Washington Hotel here.

title: Merger of Firestone And Borg Delayed
description: CHICAGO, March 20 (AP)  The proposed merger of the BorgWarner Corporation and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company has been delayed at least until July to complete and analyze studies, the companies announced today.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: First Charge Filed in NBC ExpenseAccount Case
description: WASHINGTON. March 20  The Government today filed the first for mal charge in the alleged NBCTV ex penseaccount scandal, which Federal investigators say has spread to 20 per sons in and out of the network.

title: Business Records
description: SANK PUPTCY PPOCEEDINCS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Taesday, March 20, 1929

title: New Hope For Sohio Oil Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  There is a good chance to resurrect a pipeline project to move surplus crude oil from California to Texas, where it could be refined and pumped into the nation's distribution system, a spokesman for the Department of Energy said tonight.

title: Monumental Deal By Sun Approved
description: The Sun Life Insurance Company of America said that John C. Neff, the Tennessee insurance commissioner, had granted approval for the company to acquire up to 21 percent of the voting Dower of the securities of the Montimental Corporation and its wholly owned Tennessee subsidiary, the Volunteer State Life Insurance Company. Sun Life is a subsidiary of Kaufman & Broad Inc.

title: Cuomo Proposes Spending Limits For Campaigns
description: ALBANY, March 20  Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed a campaignfinancing law today that would limit spending in state gubernatorial contests to $3.2 million per candidate  roughly half the amount spent by the two major party candidates last year.

title: Wildlife Parley Seeking to Save Periled Species
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 20 More than 200 wildlife experts from some 50 countries began a twoweek conference yesterday in this semitropical city in an atempt to arrest the continuing extinction of animal and plant species and halt the rapid worldwide decline in animal populations.

title: Ida P. Rolf, Developer of Rolfing
description: Dr. Ida P. Rolf, a biochemist who developed a technique known as Rolfing, which involved the manipulation of soft tissues of the body, died Monday at a nursing home in Bryn Mawr. Pa. She was 82 years old and had lived most of her life in New York.

title: Alcoa Price Rise Cut To Meet New Guide
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, yesterday became the first company to reduce the size of a series of price increases due to pressure from the Council on Wage and Price Stability.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Q&A
description: Q. A few weeks ago you printed a recipe calling for raw ground pork. Later on you added salt to taste. Now. I'm not about to taste raw pork for you or anyone else. What do you mean?

title: REQUESTS BY ISRAEL FOR ARMS APPROVED
description: WASHINGTON. March 20 The White House has agreed to Israel's requests for at least 200 tanks, 800 armored personnel carriers and many artillery weapons and 3irtoair and airtoground missiles, Administration officials said today.

title: Keenan Is Appointed To OTB as Chairman And Endorses Casinos
description: Mayor Koch yesterday officially appointed John F. Keenan, the special state prosecutor, as a member and chairman of the board of the Offtrack Betting Corporation and said he had the three votes necessary to install Mr. Keenan as president of the corporation as well.

title: East Germany Says It Has Seized 2 Suspected of Spying for NATO
description: EAST BERLIN, March 20 (Reuters) East Germany announced today that two West Germans had been arrested on charges of having spied for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and said it had foiled a Western intelligence operation.

title: Nastase Is Disqualificd
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 20 (AP)  lie Nastase made abscene gesiture too many tonight and was disqualified in his firstround match against Bob Lutz in the $175,000 New Orleans Tennis Festival.

description: To the Editor:

title: At 80, Still Obsessed By a Grape
description: SOMEONE suggested calling Konstantin Frank the grand old man of New York wine. Governor Carey came close when he issued a proclamation recently calling Dr. Frank a pioneer and congratulating him for his immeasurable contributions to New York's wine industry.

title: Arms Treaty: How to Verify Moscow's Compliance
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  Six months ago, as the White House began building support for a new strategic arms treaty with the Russians, President Carter told an audience at Cape Canaveral that the proposed accord would not rely on trust and that the United States had photographic satellites guarding against possible Soviet cheating.

title: New Yorker Jailed in Swindle
description: ST. LOUIS, March 20 (UM)  A New York roan was sentenced to four years in prison today for trying to swindle a businessman of money to be used in a contrived plot to hijack a nuclear submarine. James w. Cosgrove, 26 years old, of Geneva, N.Y., is the second man to be sentenced in the scheme. Edward.J. Mendenhall, Mr. Cosgrove's codefendant, was sentenced last week to five years, the maximum.

title: PRESIDENT FIGHTING BUDGET CONVENTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 The White House has committed its political power and prestige to trying to block the states from calling a constitutional convention to mandate a balanced Federal bucipet

title: An Accord on Key Points Averts A Strike by Faculty at Boston U
description: BOSTON, March 20 A strike planned for tomorrow and Thursday by faculty members at Boston University was called off tonight after negotiators made what both sides called substantial progress.

title: TaxExemption Bid Lost
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 The Supreme Court ruled today, by a vote of 6 to 3, that an organization made up of owners of Midas Muffler franchises is not eligible for the Federal incometax exemption offered to trade associations, business leagues and chambers of commerce.

title: Indiana State's Bird Has Say: Thank You
description: Larry Bil J. the leading player on the topranked college basketball team in the nation, temporarily returned from his selfimposed exile yesterday and agreed to meet the press. The bandage on his left thumb said more.

title: Dubuffet Sculpture Is a Visitor to Central Park
description: Curious New Yorkers crowded around La Chiffoniere, (The Ragpicker) as she made her debut at the entrance to Central Park, at Fifth Avenue and 60th Street, yesterday. The stainless steel sculpture, standing 22 feet high, is one of the last large pieces to be completed by Jean Dubuffet, the French sculptor. The sculpture will be on view there for three months.

title: Special School Programs Found Spur to Healthier Living Patterns
description: NEWORLEANS, March 20  The major killer diseases that afflict Americans have their roots in childhood and. according to a report here today, children enrolled in special discussion and activity programs in schools can be encouraged to adopt healthier living patterns.

title: Television
description: Television

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Sony Corporation of America announced increases yesterday in suggested retail prices for three product lines imported from Japan, including color television sets. A company spokesman attributed the price rises, effective April 1, to fluctuations in the value of the Japanese yen against the dollar.

title: Q&A
description: Q. A recent inspection of my basement showed evidence of termites not present when we bought the house. The inspector noted that the cement block was cracked in places and said termites follow those faults. He said chemicals alone won't kill the termites, that a compound must be forced into the cracks under pressure with special chemicals that will do the job permanently  with a 25year guarantee. Is this method foolproof, and can I do it myself? R.A.N., Northport, L.I.

title: Guide to Underground Information
description: A sure sign the underground design movement is spreading quickly is that architects are selling hundreds of blueprints for model homes. The firm U'Bahn Earth Homes, 9008 Brandan Street, Granite City, Ill. 62090, sold 260 blueprints of their model homes last year and expects to sell 1.000 this year.

title: House Panel to Consider Charges Against Diggs
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) The House ethics committee will vote next week on bringing formal misconduct charges against Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr., Democrat of Michigan.

title: Soviet Will Raise Prices of Oil 2.3%
description: LONDON, March 21 (AP)The Soviet Union is increasing its crude oil export prices 2.3 percent, industry sources said today. It is the second Soviet crude oil price rise in five weeks.

title: Market Place
description: STANLEY KROLL, a professional commodity trader who recently has been on the sidelines building a fleet of hotel barges in Europe, is about to reenter the market, this time on his own.

title: Argentine Court Rules Army Overstepped Its Powers
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 21  The Argentine Supreme Court, in an apparent move to restore respect for the civilian courts, has ruled that the army command illegally removed a noncommissioned officer from a jail where he was being held on criminal charges.

title: Disabling the Disabled
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J.  Between 1963 and 1965, I was city editor of a small daily paper in nearby Long Branch and, whenever the rear door was unlocked, I rode the dirty, creaky freight elevator to the third floor, where the newsroom was located. So did a reporter with cardiovascular problems. I wear leg braces because I had polio in childhood. The reporter and I were grateful when we didn't have to climb the steep stairway at the front of the newspaper building.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Design Notebook
description: MOST people in the market for a new house make their choices based on such factors as convenience and location  how many bathrooms there are and how close the place is to the train station, for example. Aspects of design are frequently secondaryafter all. how much pleasure will you get out of that neat little Georgian manor house if it hasn't any closets?

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Giants Put Wampfler on Hold
description: The remaining coach from the Giants' old football regime, Jerry Wampfler, has been told not to come into the office any more in what appears to be a test of opposing wills.

title: Of Time, Memory, And a Sin That Isn't
description: THE trouble with going to the theater so much is that plays, jokes, social observations, even the texture of whole centuries all begin to overlap. Where am I tonight? you ask yourself, shaking your head to clear it a little and glancing at your watch (provided your watch has a date on it). Oh, yes, you answer, this play was written in the 17th century and I am looking at it in the 20th, or, this joke was coined in 1928 and I am laughing at it, absurdly, in 1979. Life becomes an echo chamber and the reverberations from the walls  invisible walls get all mixed up.

title: Pontiff, Urging Fasting for Lent, Sees Training of Will to Do Good
description: ROME, March 21 (AP)  Pope John Paul II, speaking today to 30,000 people in three audiences, urged Roman Catholics to mark Lent by fasting, making it sport in an effort to to train the will to do good.

title: Coal Panel Deals Publicly With Issues Behind Strikes
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 Almost a year after the end of the bitter 1978 coal strike, the President's Coal Commission today began grappling publicly for the first time with the issues that many believe lay behind that strike and others before it.

title: U.S. Supreme Court Backs Transit Agency on Refusal to Hire ExAddicts
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  The Supreme Court of the United States ruled today that a refusal by the New York City Transit Authority to hire former heroin addicts enrolled in methadonemaintenance programs neither violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights nor constituted illegal discrimination on the basis of race.

title: Abitare Celebrates Italian Style
description: AGAINST hardedge modern, there was dolce vita last night  and the mood was definitely Italian. Martini & Rossi champagne flowed, music from old Fellini movie scores thrummed, and practically everybody crowding into the party at Abitare, the furniture store at 212 East 57th Street, was shouting Come sta! or Ciao! to friends, Romans, countrymen  and an interested assortment of interior designers.

title: Yemeni Revises Cabinet In Wake of a CeaseFire
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 21 (AP) The President of Yemen announced a reorganization of his Government today in the wake of a ceasefire in the border fighting with Southern Yemen.

title: Music: New Orchestra of 20th Century
description: FOR some years, now, various agents of the New York newmusic establishment have attempted to organize a fullscale symphony orchestra to play the major orchestral works of the 20th century. There can be little doubt that such an ensemble would be welcome. Conventional symphony orchestras perform and even commission such works, to be sure. But they do so grudgingly, their audiences resent it, limited rehearsals often preclude good performances, and the premieres are rarely repeated in subsequent seasons.

title: Talking Business
description: When Maine potatoes did not meet delivery standards some 10 days ago, the New York Mercantile Exchange, of which 29yearold Michel Marks is chairman, promptly halted trading in the March contract and liquidated the April and May contracts before the Commodity Futures Trading Commission could speak out.

title: Fireman Buried With Full Departmental Honors
description: As his mother and other relatives walked behind, the coffin of Fireman John T. McKenna, 30 years old, was bourne to funeral yesterday at Queen of Angels Roman Catholic Church in Long Island City. Mr.,McKenna, of Ladder Company 34, became the first fireman to die in the line of duty this year when he succumbed to injuries suffered Feb. 22 when he fell through the roof of a burning apartment house in Washington Heights. Mayor Koch, Fire Commissioner Augustus Beekman and about 3,000 firemen attended funeral. Burial was at Calvary Cemetery.

title: The Economics Of Building Down
description: ARCHITECTURE should be buried, said Malcolm B. Wells with more conviction than humor. For more than 15 years, the Massachusetts architect has argued that underground structures could ease energy and environmental problems. Now other people are saying the same thing. We're looking at a boom, Mr. Wells said with satisfaction.

title: Jersey Boy's Body Found
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 21 (UPI)  The body of a 7yearold boy who drowned in Rancocas Creek Feb. 11 was found today by his grandfather, who had been walking along the waterway every day searching for the child. The boy, Daniel Anderson of Mount Holly, and a companion, Mark Shim, 9, of Mount Holly, drowned while sledding on the frozen creek near their home. The Shinn boy's body was found the next day.

title: Books: Marina, GlobeTrotter's View
description: MARINA was the wife of C.L. Sulzberger, for many years The New York Times foreignaffairs columnist. As such, she was a frequent partner in the many journeys Mr. Sulzberger made covering his beat, as well as the hostess at the many gatherings at their home in Paris for the illustrious, the famous and the powerful in government and politics. She died in 1976 at 57 years of age, and Marina is a memoir made up of her letters, extracts from her diary and the comments that Mr. Sulzberger wrote to bind the parts together.

title: Topics Misbehaving
description: A fivemonth inquiry by a New Jersey grand jury has reached the conclusion that 90 percent of the students in Essex County try drugs of some kind before leaving high school. The public schools, in the words of the report, have become the main marketplace for drugs.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Inflatable Rubber Dam's Collapse In Colorado Attributed to Vandal
description: WHEAT RIDGE, Colo., March 21 (UPI)  The collapse of an inflatable dam that forced the temporary evacuation of 2,000 homes over the weekend was caused by a vandal who slashed three holes in the rubberized fabric, according to investigators.

title: U.S. Gold Sold at $241.30
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) The Treasury raised $361.4 million from the sale of slightly more than 1.5 million ounces of gold from the United States stockpile at its regular monthly auction, it was announced today.

title: Going Underground
description: MARK SIMON and Don Metz have gone underground. For different reasons, these two young architects decided to build houses below the earth's surface. Mr. Simon wanted to preserve the site's landscape; Mr. Metz designed his house for maximum energy savings. Their finished houses provide two responses the growing interest in underground living.

title: Solomon Quits as Administrator Of the General Services Agency
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)  Jay Solomon resigned today as administrator of the scandalmarked General Service. Administration, effective March 31 President Carter said he had accepted the move with regret.

title: Merrill Lynch Begins a Realty Network
description: Merrill Lynch & Company took its first step toward forming a nationwide retail real estate brokerage network.

title: For Iran, a Pause Before Dealing With Economic Disaster
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 21  Iran closed down today, putting aside its problems for five days of celebration of its traditional New Year's, possibly the first in more than 2,500 years here without an absolute monarch.

title: Appeals Court Rules Snepp Violated Pact With C.I.A.
description: RICHMOND, March 21 (AP)  A Federal appeals court has ruled that Frank W. Snepp 3d broke a contract with his former employer, the Central Intelligence Agency, through publication of his book Decent Interval. But the court held that the Government must file suit if wishes to recover damages.

title: Bullets Beat Knicks As Hayes Dominates
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 21 (AP)Elvin Hayes scored 31 points and hauled down 22 rebounds tonight to lead the injuryriddled Washington Bullets to a 119106 National Basketball Association romp over the New York Knicks. Three of Washington's top four scorers missed the game because of injuries.

title: Pop: Frish berg on 70's
description: DAVE FRISHBERG is a songwriter, singer and pianist who is known best in some quarters because he wrote a hit song several years ago whose lyric was made up entirely of the names of baseball players  it was called Van Lingle Mungo, which gives you an idea of the period he was drawing on. In other quarters, he is held in special esteem for I'm Hip ('Cause I'm Hep), commentary on the confusions of slang that is one of the gems of Blossom Dearie's repertory.

title: Tennessee Favored to Keep Swim Title
description: CLEVELAND, March 21  The 56th annual National Collegiate swimming championships begin tomorrow, and everyone has made the University of Tennessee the favorite except Ray Bussard. Not coincidentally, he is the Tennessee coach.

title: 2 Plead Guilty in Subway Slaying; Shot IRT Victim, 60, in the Back
description: Two Bronx men pleaded guilty to manslaughter yesterday in the robbery slaying of a 60yearold postal worker aboard a subway train last year. The defendants, John Robert Jordan, 18, and Marvin Devonish, 19, were charged with murder but were allowed to plead to the lesser charge after plea bargaining. They face up to 25 years in prison at their sentencing in State Supreme Court on April 27.

title: Study Set on Compensating Distillers
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  The House Ways and Means Committee has asked the Treasury to study ways to compensate domestic distillers of alcoholic beverages for the loss of a preference over foreign bottlers given up in the currrent trade liberalization negotiations.

title: College Strike Ends as Faculties Endorse TwoYear Jersey Pact
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 21Professors and other faculty members at eight state colleges today voted overwhelming approval of a twoyear contract providing acrosstheboard salary increases of 7 percent a year for the 3,200 members of the bargaining unit.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 22, 1979

title: 13 Doctors at Rikers Island Discharged for Pay Abuses
description: Thirteen Health Department doctors assigned to the Rikers Island prison were discharged yesterday, accused of claiming pay for work not performed, and another doctor and three dentists were suspended. A psychiatrist had resigned last December.

title: MOBUTU SAYS I.M.F. WILL GIVE ZAIRE AID
description: PARIS, March 21  President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire said today that his country had completed negotiations with the International Monetary Fund on a package of aid and economic reforms and that he expected to sign an agreement in the next few days.

title: EARNINGS
description: The May Department Stores Company, a large retail chain, reported yesterday profit increases of 7.3 percent for the fourth quarter ended Feb. 3 and 12.3 percent for the full fiscal year.

title: Met Wings Clipped By Sutton
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21  There were 1,200 baseball players in the training camps of Florida and Arizona today, but none of them had a day like Don Sutton of the Los Angeles Dodgers  from the moment he lifted the nose of his Cessna off the runway.

title: Avalanches Trap 2,000 in India
description: NEW DELHI, March 21 (AP)  Nearly 2,000 people have been trapped by avalanches in Pin Valley in the northern state of Himachal Pradesh and at least 230 others are believed dead in the area, a Government spokesman said here today. A number of avalanches swept through the region early this month. Reports from the area said at least one village, Arhat, had been wiped out.

title: Yankees Voice No Concern
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 21  What is wrong with the Yankees?

title: Puerto Rico Bond Sale Delayed
description: An $80 million Puerto Rico bond sale scheduled for next week was delayed yesterday until the week of April 9 to restate the commonwealth's financial statements to show a smaller cash balance.

title: TEAMSTER CHIEF TIES UNION'S WAGE GAINS TO BUSINESS PROFITS
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 The head of the teamsters' union, whose contract negotiations with the trucking industry are in a critical stage, said today that it would not be fair to hold down workers' wages while corporate profits were soaring.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., March 21 (AP)  Duane Thomas, the running back who has not played since 1975, has signed with the Green Bay Packers, the National Football League club announced troday.

title: Mater Christi High: A Producer of Stars
description: The April 15 incometax deadline date that is dreaded by most people is eagerly anticipated by college basketball coaches. For that date is the traditional cutoff for the mostsought schoolboy athletes to declare their choices of college for the fall.

title: France's Quest for Ford Plant Draws Fire
description: PARIS, March 21  A major controversy has erupted over the French Government's efforts to persuade the Ford Motor Company to locate a $1 billion automobile plant in the depressed steelproducing region of Lorraine in eastern France.

title: Justices Uphold State on Paying Striking Workers
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  The New York State law that provides unemployment benefits to strikers was upheld by the Supreme Court of the United States today.

title: Drawing the Line in Alaska
description: Congress is once again taking up the Alaska lands issue, the most important conservation decision of the present generation. The Federal Government, which once owned the entire state, is already transferring 40 percent of the land to the state government and its native peoples, the largest such land grant in the nation's history. The question now is what to do with the residual Federal lands.

title: Calling for Vigor, Connally Makes A Swing Through New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N.H., March 21  John B. Connally came selling his message of a Presidency of optimism, vigor and decisiveness this week, but left today without any certain measure of who was buying among New Hampshire Republicans.

title: Bergland Sees Food Cost Spiral
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland says that further increases in food prices are inevitable and that there is nothing that the Federal Government can do on the farm level to stop them because they are caused by inflation that occurs after raw farm products start toward the supermarket.

title: 2 Albany Aides Play Key Role in State Budget Battle
description: ALBANY, March 21  James L. Biggane, secretary to the New York State Senate Finance Committee, waited impatiently for a legislative news conference to end, his pipe, as always, creating enough smoke to set off a fire alarm

title: Viggiano Vote Cheers Democrats
description: Democrats counted an expected victory yesterday, and the infant Right to Life Party counted an unexpected show of strength in the special election in the 62d Assembly District, which spans New York harbor.

title: Bridge:
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 21  The quarterfinal stage of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship began at the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League today in the Scope Convention Center after close finishes and upsets abounded last night.

title: Deaths
description: BAPPETT Anne or ?? For. m?? of ?? Will be ?? the ?? & Ma guire Funeral Horne. ?? Paul Funeral services Friday with ?? men in R??on Ce?? St Paul

title: Pullman Drops Passenger Car
description: CHICAGO, March 21 (Reuters)  Pullman Inc., whose name became synonymous with railroad sleeping cars, announced today that it would stop making rail passenger cars because of unacceptable contractual conditions and foreign competition.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Intercity Bus Profits Down
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  Although operating revenues of the nation's 10 largest intercity bus companies increased in 1975, earnings declined, the Interstate Commerce Commission reported today.

title: Jane Scheibe, 57, Office Manager Of McDowell Colony for Artists
description: Jane Scheibe, office manager of the McDowell Colony, died of a heart attack Saturday at her home in Peterborough, N.H. She Was 57 years old.

title: Hussein Flies to Meet With Saudis On Response to EgyptIsrael Treaty
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 21 (AP) King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Saudi Arabia today to coordinate policies and actions to be taken after the signing of a peace treaty between Egypt and Israel.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Genovese Slayer Cites Victim's Slur
description: Fifteen years after he stalked a young Queens barmaid and knifed her to death in the full view of 38 witnesses who made no move to intervene, Winston Moseley now says that that he attacked the woman, Catherine Genovese, because she had made a racial slur against him.

title: El Salvador Is Shaken by Violence and No End Is in Sight
description: SAN SALVADOR  In apparent response to mounting domestic and foreign criticism, El Salvador's armybacked Government has rescinded its powe??s of arbitrary arrest, but repression and leftist violence continue to convulse this deeply divided Central American republic.

title: GARDENING
description: HOMEGROWN asparagus what luxury! This elegant springtime treat can never compare with its store. bought relative, because asparagus, like sweet corn and peas, is supreme when picked while the cooking pot is out on the stove to boil.

title: IND Train Derails at 14th St.
description: A cracked wheel derailed a northbound IND local yesterday morning at the 14th Street station of the Eighth Avenue line, the Transit Authority said. The agency said the first car of a CC train derailed just north of the station shortly after A.M. No riders were hurt. The accident interrupted northbound service, with CC locals rerouted to Avenue of Americas from Jay Street in Brooklyn to 59th Street in Manhattan and A and E service using express tracks to 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.

title: Calendar of Events: Porcelain Exhibition
description: Porcelain Exhibition, CooperHewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street.

title: 3 Arrested on L.I. in Lithograph Forgeries
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 21  The Nassau County District Attorney's Office announced the arrest today of three men in a scheme involving the alleged forgery and sale of 200 lithographs attributed to arc Chagall, Joan Mir, Alexander Calder and Salvador Dali. The value of the authentic prints was estimated by experts to be more than $3 million.

title: Duties Cut Supplies Of Imported Cheeses
description: The price of Cheshire cheese, a crumbly, cheddarstyle British import, has climbed from $2.98 to $3.29 a pound since January at Zabar's, the specialty delicatessen on Manhattan's West Side.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Curran Is Confident He Has Power To Investigate Carter Loans Fully
description: In the face of skepticism over the extent of his authority, Paul J. Curran declared yesterday that he was confident he had sufficient power to investigate loans of $7 million to President Carter's family peanut business during his Presidential campaign.

title: U.S. AND ISRAEL PLAN A POLITICAL ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  The United States and Israel expect to sign an accord in a few days that would provide American political support in case the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty is violated, officials of both sides said today

title: LEWIS W. FEICK
description: Lewis W. Feick, a former associate of Riter & Company, a brokerage concern, died of a heart attack at his home in New York City on Thursday. He was 73 yearsold.

title: Payments Deficit for 1978 A High, but Gain Is Cited
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)The United States had a deficit in its balance of payments last year of $16 billion, which was less than expected because of improved trade activity in the final three months of the year, the Government said today.

title: Senate, in Voice Vote, Confirms 7 U.S. Judges
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) The Senate confirmed President Carter's first four nominees to new Federal judgeships and his first appointment of a woman to a Federal appeals court.

title: Disk: Keeping Gems of Revues Alive
description: HAVING collected many of the obscure and some of the not so obscure songs of the more renowned writers of Broadway's show scores in his Revisited series of disks, Ben Bagley has now turned to the not quite so renowned songwriters who have dropped their gems into revues, a musical form that has proved to be more perishable than the book show. One side of this disk is devoted to songs from the 1948 revue Make Mine Manhattan, the other to material from a miscellany of shows including Lend an Ear, Touch and Go, Small Wonder, Bless You All, Angel in the Wings, Tickets Please, Girls Against the Boys and the 1941 edition of Meet the People.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: The City
description: New York City borrowed $125 million from the clearinghouse banks and four pension funds in a private sale of shortterm notes.

title: Sohio Acts To Renew Pipeline Bid
description: CLEVELAND, March 21 (AP)  The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) today formally resubmitted an application for California airquality permits required for construction of a $1 billion oil pipeline from California to Texas, but the company's chairman said no final decision had been made to proceed with the project.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON. March 21 (AP)  The Government announced the recall today of more than 100,000 doses of vaccine designed to protect infants from diptheria, whooping cough and tetanus, following the deaths of four babies within 24 hours after receiving the vaccine.

title: About Great Neck
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., March 20  It the last day of winter, and the widow at 24 Johnstone Street is putting 40 years of possessions up for sale in her house  her clothes, her furniture, her books, her silver.

title: Court Decides Parochial Schools Need Not Bargain With Unions
description: WASHINGTON March 21  The United States Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that because Congress had never intended Federal labor laws to apply to parochial schools, officials of such schools cannot be required to bargain with unions of lay faculty members.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Browne Vintners Company, a division of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc., has named Stanley M. Sheppard president.

title: Umpires, Managers and Drunks
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla.  When Whitey Ford was a youngster with the Yankees he studied pitching under the crafty veteran, Allie Reynolds, who knew his subject so well he threw two nohitters in a single season. The first lesson Professor Reynolds taught: Always miss the Fort Myers trip.

title: ThriftUnit Stock Sales Allowed
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board issued regulations yesterday allowing the conversion of mutual savings and loan associations to the capital stock form of ownership.

title: Polluters Are Prey For Creek Walkers
description: TRENTON, March 21  Shortly after 9 o'clock this bright spring morning, Alford Pfeiffer and Michelle Hayes hitched up their rubber waders and plunged into the muck and brambles alongside Miry Run, a once sparkling little creek in east Mercer County, on another day of searching for polluters.

title: Instructions Are Given On Alternative Means To Transport Students
description: The New York City Board of Education, responding to protests from parents who expressed confusion over how to get their children to school during the wildcat strike by schoolbus drivers, yesterday issued the first detailed instructions on alternative means of transportation.

title: Music: Miss de Larrocha
description: IN the years since Alicia de Larrocha first began playing regularly in this country, the Spanish pianist has grown as an artist, and no doubt her admirers have ripened as listeners. Where once we went to marvel at her incredible keyboard mastery and her easy handling of such pianist's nightmares as Iberia, we have come to realize that she bows to few musicians today in the Parnassian works by which the truly great are always measured. At Avery Fisher Hall last night, Miss de Larrocha hammered home that realization again and again as she performed the first of three concerts in a Beethoven concerto series, with the aid of Andr Previn and the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra.

title: A Hero of the Airwaves Dies, Alone and Forgotten
description: When Al Hodge was the Green Hornet on network radio 40 years ago, performers did three live shows a night one for the East Coast audience, one for the Middle West and one for West Coast listeners. Radio's recording technology was not very good then, and there was no room for gambling on a rebroadcast with so many Americans waiting for the superhero's latest adventure.

title: Czarist Painting in U.S. 75 Years Is Returned to the Soviet Union
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  A 19thcentury Czarist Russian painting sent to the United States for the 1904 St. Louis World's Fair and thereafter remaining on American soil  ended its 75year odyssey today when it was presented to the Soviet Ambassador here.

title: Kurdish Townsmen, Ignoring Iran's Appeals for Truce, Continue Revolt
description: SANANDAJ. Iran, March 21 Kurdish townsmen held to their alleyway and rooftop positions here today, ignoring pleas for a truce while pouring gunfire into an Army barracks for the third day.

title: Books: Art Movements
description: THE noble name of encyclopedia should not be taken lightly. A true encyclopedia has three main characteristics, and every one of them is fundamental. It is majestic in size. It is accurate beyond all argument. And in a roundabout way it is the autobiography of the age that produced it.

title: 9.87% Yield Set on Utility Bonds
description: A $100 million highgrade electric utility bond issue was priced yesterday to yield 9.87 percent, the highest rate of return on such an investment since late 1975, and it proved moderately attractive to investors. Late yesterday, underwriters estimated it to be at least 70 percent sold.

title: MERRILL L. HASSENFELD
description: Merrill L. Hassenfeld, honorary national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, died yesterday of a heart attack in Providence, R.I. He was 61 years old and lived in Providence.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Supreme Court upheld a New York law providing unemployment benefits to strikers. The Court rejected the argument of New York Telephone that the law implicitly favors labor over management and therefore should be overturned. [Page A1.]

title: Screen: The Holocaust
description: SIGHET, SIGHET and Shadow of Doubt, two short films on view at the Film Forum, are attempts to arrive at some understanding of the holocaust. And each is in a sense doomed to failure, since the event so thoroughly defies comprehension that the closer one studies it, the less one really knows. But when the truth is unattainable, the process of inquiry can become an end in itself, and both of these films find sometimes shapely and provocative ways to pose questions, even though the answers remain out of reach.

title: NortonShavers Upstages Holmes Match
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 21 There's a world heavyweight championship fight here in two nights, but for all the suspense of how and when Larry Holmes will beat Osvaldo Ocasio, it might as well be a preliminary bout. The real main event is the 12round elimination contest between two old sluggers, Ken Norton and Earnie Shavers, for the right to be Holmes's next serious challenger.

title: South African Role in Iowa Voting Charged
description: A former official in South Africa's Information Ministry who has been in hiding in Europe reportedly has said that his country interfered in the electoral process in the United States last year with the aim of defeating Senator Dick Clark, a liberal Iowa Democrat.

title: Indoor Pools: A New Approach
description: EVEN people who can afford to build indoor swimming pools, which cost upward of $50,000, are sometimes discouraged by the $1,500 to $3,000 in annual operating expenses. Enter Alphonse Maderna, an Austrian designer of crystal chandeliers, with a competively priced underground pool that costs about $500 a year to heat and cool.

title: U.S. CITIZENS BRIBED, SOUTH AFRICAN SAYS
description: LONDON, March 21  Eschel M. Rhoodie, the central figure in the South African bribery scandal, has declared in an interview that the United States was one of the principal countries where his Government paid opinion formers and decision takers to express proSouth African views.

title: Villages' MayorsElect To Press for Secession From Mount Pleasant
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 21  The Mayorselect of two central Westchester County villages, whose residents yesterday overwhelmingly approved the concept of seceding from the Town of Mount Pleasant, said today that they would immediately begin the necessary legal steps required under state law.

title: Sickout Hits Bermuda Hotel
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 21 (UPI)  About 450 out of 4,500 hotel workers called in sick for the fourth day today, forcing visitors to carry their own bags and make their own beds. A few tourists left. The service staff, including bartenders, bellmen, kitchen workers and desk attendants, is seeking improvements in offseason unemployment insurance. The union has been without a contract for a month, and a full strike is scheduled for April 9.

title: Jove Joins Berkley Books In New House
description: The editorial lines of two paperback houses, Berkley Books and Jove Publications, will be altered as a result of completion of a transaction last week between two conglomerates, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and MCA Inc. HBJ, which could not make a go of it with Jove, sold the house to MCA, Berkley's owner.

title: BEGIN PLANS HIS TRIP
description: By JONATHAN KANDELL Special to The New York TimesJERUSALEM, Thursday, March 22 The Israeli Parliament overwhelmingly endorsed the peace treaty with Egypt today, clearing the way for signing ceremonies in Washington on Monday to end formally a state of war that has existed between the two countries for more than three decades.

title: Stocks Stage 7Point, FinalHour Rally
description: Glamour and bluechip issues staged a spirited, finalhour rally yesterday to lead stock prices higher after the market weathered what some Wall Street brokers called a psychological test. the recovery placed the market just below its 1979 high set in late January

title: Fire in Brooklyn Kills 3 Children; Two Are Injured
description: Three young children were killed yesterday as flames swept through the upper floors of a fourstory apartment house in 1 the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. A 7yearold boy and his grandmother were seriously injured when they leaped to the ground.

title: New England of N.A.S.L. Loses Use of Stadium
description: BOSTON, March 21 (AP)  A Massachusetts Superior Court judge booted the New England Tea Men of the North American Soccer League out of Schaefer Stadium in Foxboro, Mass. today, forcing the team to find a new playing site for 1979 home games.

title: Deaths
description: VEEHA??Francis J ?? ?? ?? on March ?? ?? Beloved husband of Ceraldine nee w?? Beloved father of Dennis, Norcon Sankavich. Joseph, Francis W and Michael Dear son of ?? title: Court Enjoins U.S. Metals
description: A Federal District judge in New York issued a preliminary injunction against the U.S. Metals Depository Corporation and four of its officers to prohibit them from violating Federal commodity laws. The judge also said the court would appoint a receiver to take charge of the firm, lawyers in the case disclosed yesterday.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 21, 1979

title: Home Beat
description: DANIEL E. RICHARDSON, above, graduated from Wesleyan University in 1969, and returned to his hometown of St. Louis to work at the Shure Manufacturing Company, which at the time was mainly producing furnishings for automobile service garages. I felt strongly that the workrooms of these facilities did not have to be dull, Mr. Richardson explained, and that the service technician was a professional who could profit from a wellorganized working environment, much like his counterpart, the office worker. So Mr. Richardson managed to get the Shure workbenches streamlined. He introduced way out colors like orange, bright green and red into the then graygreen line. Some colors took hold, Mr. Richardson said, especially the cardinal red. Over the years, the cornpany has expanded its selection of workbenches, tool carts and service desks, which are primarily used by automobile technicians and mechanics, in service stations, garages and schools. Mr. Richardson, who is now the president of Shure, sees a more practical homerelated use for the workbenches  actually what we would call worktables, in the home. The allsteel tables with bakedenamel finishes come in a variety of heights and can be equipped with drawers or topped with wood. Although they are normally bolted to the floor in service stations, or workrooms, this is not always necessary as the workbenches are heavy and stable enough to stand securely on their own. In New York, you can get the Shure workbenches at Manhattan Ad Hoc Housewares, 842 Lexington Avenue, at 64th Street. Shown above outside the store, Mr. Richardson perches on a 34inchhigh, 48inchlong and 29inchwide table that retails for $135. The drawer is $75. You can order workbenches in other sizes and stackable drawers that can be used as units.

title: Books of The Times
description: ASEBALL? ... It's full of order and disorder, says one of the women in Philip F. O'Connor's first novel, Stealing Home. Incredible things can happen within those nine innings ... and between those foul lines. Marvelous and puzzling things. No game the same and all that. Which partly explains, I guess, why so many American fiction writers have been attracted to the game. Baseball's nearly limitless possibilities for drama. The fact that the game is not shaped by real chronological time. And much more, to judge from the 27 selections in Jerome Holtzman's Fielder's Choice, an anthology of baseball fiction edited by the senior baseball writer for The Chicago SunTimes.

title: ABROAD AT HOME If Arizona Were Rhodesia
description: BOSTON, March 21  Why aren't the blacks of Rhodesia satisfied with the majority rule election being held next month by Ian Smith's internal regime? Why do many of them sympathize with the Patriotic Front guerrillas? Why doesn't the Carter Administration support this election instead of calling for one supervised by the United Nations?

title: Remark on Female Police Denied
description: The head of the Civilian Complaint Review Board denied yesterday that he had accused female police officers of being macho and acting overly tough to prove themselves.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide. cccItYled by Record World. a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets, singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. Ali astensk rndicates an especially fast. selling record.

title: Congress Is Asked for Power to Fight Housing Bias
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  The opening shot was fired today in what promises to be the major civil rights battle of 1979 as the Carter Administration told Congress that it needed broad new powers to enforce Federal laws against discriminaI fion in housing.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: In an unusual public demonstration of displeasure over management succession, two outside directors of the Beatrice Foods Company have resigned from the board of the Chicagoba sed food processor.

title: Sound
description: THE styling of stereo components seems to undergo periodic changes of fashion, much like other items of home furfishing, and from what has been seen at the latest product previews, we seem to be heading for a new look in audio.

title: Advertising
description: THE Newspaper Advertising Bureau, founded 66 years ago to stimulate national advertising in that medium and now active in all categories, is involved in what could well be its greatest effort.

title: TRAVEL ABUSE LAID TO FEDERAL AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)  A Senate Appropriations Committee staff report charged today that there were widespread abuses of business trips by employees of the Environmental Protection Agency, including an assistant administrator who, investigators said, traveled repeatedly with his secretary.

title: Rangers Survive Chicago Rally to Win, 76
description: CHICAGO, March 21  The first day of spring brought no respite to the miseries of the Chicago Black Hawks. In fact, they grew worse tonight as the Rangers handed them their seventh consecutive loss, 76, and Black Hawk

title: Stiffer Pollution Fines Set
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 The Environmental Protection Agency served notice today that, when companies failed to comply with antipollution regulations, they would be fined as much money as they had saved by not complying with the rules.

title: The Impaired Lose
description: If current events really play a role in teaching youngsters about the world, the wildcat strike of schoolbus drivers for the handicapped is an excellent learning tool.

title: Industrialist Is a Victim Of Italy's Red Brigades
description: ROME, March 21  An industrialist was critically injured in the northern Italian town of Cuneo today when his car was demolished by a bomb that went off as he turned on the ignition.

title: Draft May Fill Reserves Gap
description: Gen. Bernard Rogers's proposal to draft men and women into the Army's reserve force should not be interpreted as an admission by the high command that the volunteer army has failed. The pro. posal by General Rogers. the Army Chief of Staff, does not give credence to charges that the professional force is ton black, poorly educated or insufficiently motivated or disciplined.

title: Westchester Businessman Charged With Heading Cocaine Ring of 13
description: A businessman was charged yesterday with heading a Westchester County narcotics ring that allegedly employed his mother, his sister and 11 others, including a policeman, in a scheme to sell millions of dollars of cocaine.

title: Kurt Molzahn, Pardoned as a Spy
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (AP)The Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn, a Germanborn minister who was convicted as a Nazi spy in 1942 but was later pardoned by two Presidents, died Sunday at the age of 83.

title: G.A.O. Says 2 Agencies Refuse Data to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 The General Accounting Office has accused the Attorney General, Griffin B. Bell, and the Director of Central Intelligence, Adm. Stansfield Turner, of blocking the access of Congressional investigators to secret intelligence files without the authority of law.

title: Amoco to Help Boat People
description: CHICAGO, March 21 (Reuters)Amoco said today that it had instructed its 14 tankers to help Vietnamese boat people in distress. Some ships ignore them because of the difficulty of putting them ashore in Asian countries reluctant to receive them.

title: Favorites Triumph In Tennis
description: Chapter Four of the lookingglass war will unfold at Madison Square Garden tonight when Chris Evert and Tracy Austin meet in the second round of the $275,000 women's wintertour tennis championships.

title: Fate of Huey Newton and Black Panthers Hinges on Murder Verdict
description: OAKLAND, March 21  Huey P. Newton shattered the exchange between the others and the reporter. His voice rose to a shout as he said, The minister of defense will answer the questions. Ask your questions of the minister of defense.

title: Grace Completes Purchase of Daylin
description: W.R. Grace & Company said it had completed the nearly $140 million acquisition of Daylin Inc., operators of home improvement centers. Grace said that the offer expired at 5 P.M. on March 19 with more than 90 percent of the outstanding Daylin shares tendered.

title: Glass Artist Embraces Technology
description: THE result of a marriage between commercial technology and artistic skill, 12 pieces blown clear glass designed by James Carpenter and executed by Steuben craftsmen under his direction are now on display at the Steuben Gallery, 56th Street and Fifth Avenue, through April 14.

title: Mercedes Wagon: Hot Item for a Cool $23,900
description: Got four kids, a pair of Weimaraners and a love of camping you just can't shake? You need a station wagon. This one is nice looking. Sleek. Comes in 30 colors. Handles like a dream. Twentyeight miles to the gallon on the road, 23 in the city. And you can drive it away for a tidy $23,900, base price.

title: New York Seeks To Take Over 500 Bus Shelters
description: The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to ask the courts to order Bustop Shelters Inc. to give its 500 bus shelters to New York City immediately, pending completion of the complex and controversial awarding of a new franchise for the shelters.

title: Deaths
description: KELLEY  Solon C. Jr. Age 84 Died at his Hobe Sound. Florida res??dence Tuesday, March 20, 1979 after ?? long Illness ?? Kelley also main??ned home at ?? Park Ave. NYC and in Dor?? Vermont ?? was a graduate of the Ta?? School and of Brown University. For many vears Mr Kelley was associafed with the investment ?? of Blair former Hobe Bush two children Edmund R.C. Kelley and Mrs. Richard S??ey three ?? children Mrs. Henry G Hay, Mr Herbert L. D?? ??on and Mrs. James Ritchie?? grandchildren and 4 greate grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Monday at 10:30AM at Christ Memorial Chapel Jupiter Island. Hobe Sound Florida.

title: Going out Guide
description: THE PIANIST Don Shirley is a leading American pianist. He has played with the major American orchestras, and they have played his compositions. He is a Harvardtrained psychologist, an expert in Ambrosian and Gregorian chants and a linguist.
