Because he also plays modern American music, people often refer to himto his intense consternation  as a jazz pianist.

title: Drops in Spot Oil Prices Confirmed by U.S. Aide
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 A senior official of the Department of Energy confirmed today that prices in the world's spot oil market have declined markedly because of resistance by oil companies, the resumption of Iranian oil exports and prospects of conservation by consuming nations.

title: Prehistoric Footprints of ManLike Creatures Found
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  Footprints of two creatures who appear to have walked exactly as modern human beings do have been uncovered by Dr. Mary D. Leakey in a layer of volcanic ash that blanketed a part of what is now Tanzania more than 3.6 million years ago.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  As predicted, Charles Kirbo's appointees at the Carter Department of Political Justice have found an amiable Republican to be Special Nonprosecutor in the Carter warehouse scandal.

title: Gain Weak For Orders In Durables
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)New orders received by factories for durable goods rose a weak threetenths of 1 percent last month, with high demand for airplanes and parts failing to offset declines in most other industries, the Commerce Department said today

title: John Hoy Kauffmann Dead at 53
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  John Hoy Kauffmann, chief executive of The Washington Star from 1968 to 1974, died yesterday at Washington Hospital Center of cancer of the throat. He was 53 years old.

title: PresidentialCandidate Debates On TV Urged for Every Election
description: Noting that the televised NixonKennedy debates in 1960 and the CarterFord meetings in 1976 were the only time during campaigns that  the two major candidates appeared together side by side and under conditions that they did not control, the Twentieth Century Fund yesterday issued a report advocating the establishment of such debates as a regular electionyear feature.

title: Notes on People
description: The infant first grandson of Richard M. Nixon had his introduction to the outside world yesterday. What can be described only as an unruly mob of shouting television and still photographers, reporters, and curious hangerson swarmed around and engulfed Tricia Nixon Cox, who was carrying her weekold first child, Christopher Nixon Cox, and the baby's father, Edward Cox, as they emerged from New York Hospital. The baby appeared to ignore the din.

title: Indiana Tops Purdue In N.I.T. Final, 5352
description: A 20foot jump shot by Butch Carter with 4 seconds left enabled Indiana to edge Purdue, 5352, in the final round of the National Invitation Tournament last night before a crowd of 14,889 at Madison square Garden.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: 0NE of the most useful items for householders is adhesive tape, but many people are not aware of the wide variety available and the possible sources for these tapes.

title: Dolphins to Join Loch Ness Hunt
description: The search for evidence of the legendary monster of Loch Ness will resume this summer and this time the searchers plan to enlist the services of dolphins to photograph any large creatures in the Scottish lake.

title: Happy Anniversary, E.R.A.
description: In some ways, today's anniversary  the original deadline for ratification  marks a defeat for the Equal Rights Amendment. Seven years after Congress proposed it, the E.R.A. still lacks approval in three of the necessary 38 states. Now the amendment battle moves into an unprecedented extension period. Even if three more states endorse it before the new deadline in June 1982, challenges to the validity of the extension as well as recisions of past endorsements could prevent the amendment's adoption.

title: Amtrak's Fare Increases
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  Amtrak has raised ticket prices on the BostontoWashington rail corridor twice what is allowed under the President's antiinflation guidelines, but the company said today that it was in compliance with the rules.

title: Private Ambulance Strike Is Off
description: A strike of private ambulance drivers in New York City and the Westchester County communities of Yonkers and Mount Vernon has been canceled at the request of mediators in order to permit further talks with New York Medicaid officials. Charles Kranitz, president of Local 531 of the teamsters union, so notified the 200 ambulance drivers and attendants who had voted to strike the three regions, where they also provide municipal ambulance service.

title: Device to Let Deaf Read TV Speech
description: Three of the major television networks next year will begin offering programs that deaf people literally will be able to read with the aid of a specially designed device, a decoder.

title: Indiana Group Approves Takeover
description: Stockholders of the Indiana Group, an insurance holding company, have approved the previously announced $98 million proposal of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation to acquire the company.

title: Portland Tests the Concept Of Governing by the Region
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  This metropolitan area of about one million people has embarked on a unique experiment popularly elected regional government that embraces parts of three counties and that has the power to do things that raise hackles out in the suburbs, things such as scattering lowincome housing and ordering a community to accept garbage dump.

title: Pop Music: Jan Hammer
description: JAN HAMMER stood on the stage of the Bottom Line on Monday evening and pretended to play guitar. There are a lot of guitarists whose instrumental prowess is only pretense, but what made his performance unusual is that he is a noted jazzrock keyboardplayer. No more. Slung over his shoulder was an unwieldy keyboard contraption plugged into a battery of synthesizers that enabled him to mimic quite uncannily the sounds of an electric guitar. Mr. Hammer even aped the cliched gestures of a rock guitarist, writhing and grimacing to beat the band which in this case bore his surname, Hammer.

title: Wisconsin Trust Split by Suit
description: The First Wisconsin Mortgage Trust of Milwaukee, a leading real estate investment company in the early 1970's but now shrunken and struggling, said yesterday that two of its top officers had resigned following an unusual legal dispute. They refused to assist the trust in a suit it brought against the bank that created the trust.

title: Short Interest on Big Board Up by 3.8 Million Shares
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 3.8 million shares in the month ended March 15 to 39.9 million shares. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 33.8 million shares.

title: Issuing Limited On Cash Cards
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)The Federal Reserve Board said today that banks and other financial institutions could issue valid cash cards, only in response to specific requests ors to renew previously issued cards.

title: Rate of Serious Crimes in State Dropped 6.3% in '78
description: ALBANY, March 21  The number of serious crimes reported in New York State declined last year, with 46 of its 62 counties showing a drop in the crime rate, according to statistics released today by the State Division of Criminal Justice Services.

title: U.C.L.A. Coach Said to Resign
description: LOS ANGELES, March 21 (AP)  The University of California, Los Angeles, refused to comment today on reports that its basketball coach, Gary Cunningham, had resigned. But U.C.L.A. called what it termed a major news conference for tomorrow morning at its Pauley Pavilion.

title: Albany Move Seen to End S.C.I.
description: ALBANY, March 21 The Republicanled Senate has recommended the abolition of the State Commission of Investigation, a panel that looks into irregularities in the behavior of state agencies and officials, and is questioning the financing for one scale's special prosecutors, legislative sources said today.

title: Excerpts From High Court Decision on Jobless Pay
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  Follow ing are excerpts from today's Supreme Court decision upholding the New York law that provides unemployment compensation to strikers:

title: Mrs. Carter Sees Political Friends
description: DAVIS, Calif., March 21  Rosalynn Carter calls them Carter friends, politically influential groups that she has met with this week at every stop of her crosscountry tour billed as a salute to community volunteers.

title: Elections Near, Trudeau's Rival Still an Enigma to Many Voters
description: OTTAWA, March 21  Anybody but Trudeau, say bumper stickers in Toronto. In a few weeks, elections will be called in Canada, and disaffection for Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau among the Englishspeaking majority could end 16 years of Liberal Party rule and lead to victory for Charles Joseph Clark of the ProgressiveConservative Party.

title: Gullikson Conquers Connors
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 21 (AP) Tom Gullikson, winner of only two singles matches all year, came up with a big serveandvolley game tonight to upset topseeded Jimmy Connors, 64, 36, 62 in the $175,000 New Orleans Festival of Tennis.

title: Suspected Guerrillas Rob Nicaragua Bank; 15 Hostages Are Held
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 21 (AP)  An armed band believed to be Sandinist guerrillas robbed a bank controlled by the ruling Somoza family today, but ran into the police while trying to escape, the authorities said. At least three ducked back inside and took 15 hostages.

title: Prolific, Perverse Roaches
description: THE good news is that New York City is home to only four of the 55 kinds of cockroaches that roam the United States. The most common roach in the city is the German roach, a brown bug that cherishes dampness and darkness, especially in kitchens and bathrooms. The larger Oriental roach, which occasionally hops out of a sewer pipe, also lives in the New York City area, as does the brownbanded roach.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 22, 1979

title: Egon Schwelb, ExAide Of U.N. Rights Division
description: Egon Schwelb, a retired United Nations official, died Tuesday at New York University Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan..

title: The Region
description: A 70foot fishing vessel carrying 20 to 25 tons of marijuana was seized by a Coast Guard cutter early yesterday evening after the drugs were discovered during a routine boarding, the Coast Guard reported.

title: Sherman Gets Arts Medal for WQXR Work
description: Robert Sherman, program director of WQXR radio, has received the National Arts Club's 1979 Gold Medal of Honor for Music.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Story of Oba: A Tribal Tale From Nigeria
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  It is a nice Nigerian irony that while no one knows precisely when elections for the hopedfor civilian rule here will begin, just about everyone knows that in this country's Benin region the new oba, the. latest link in one of Africa's oldest tribal monarchies, will ascend his throne on March 23.

title: Evolution of a Prosecutor
description: When the office of special prosecutor to investigate corruption in New York City's criminaljustice system was created six and a half years ago, it was called special partly because the office was meant to be temporary.

title: I.T.T. Agrees To Buy Burpee
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has announced an agreement in principle for it to purchase from the General Foods Corporation its wholly owned subsidiary, the W. Atlee Burpee Company of Warminster, Pa.

title: Home Improvement
description: WHEN a toilet tank does not flush properly, or when it is constantly running and dripping so that the handle has to jiggled frequently to make it behave, it's not only annoying, it may also be wasting water. And if the home has its own waste cesspool or septic tank, there is also a strong possibility that the continuous water flow will overload the drainage system.

title: Free Trade's Winners and Losers
description: Freer trade creates losers as well as winners, and the Congressional Budget Office has just given the old cities of the Frost Belt some bad news about the forthcoming trade pact. With greater competition from abroad, they will suffer a further drop in jobs in such industries as textiles, shoes and metal fabrication.

title: 3 Multinational Banks Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (Reuters)  Congressional investigators issued today a report critical of the activities of three multinational development banks.

title: Film: 'Boyfriends' By Joan Tewkesbury
description: "OLD BOYFRIENDS," the first film to be directed by Joan Tewkesbury, who has written screenplays for Robert Altman, is a movie in which the characters are more intelligent and interesting than anything they are required to do. They appear to have an existence outside the story, though I'm not sure how this can happen if, as I assume, the actors are playing the characters written in the screenplay by Paul Schrader and his brother, Leonard.Yet here is a movie in which one remembers as vividly as anything else Buck Henry in a throw-away role, that of a private investigator who is so delighted with his beautiful, statuesque secretary that he beams with helpless pleasure every time she pours a cup of coffee. His fascination with the young woman has nothing at all to do with the rest of the movie, but it is mysterious and surprising, the way life is and "Old Boyfriends" isn't. The film opens today at the Sutton.The movie presents us with the spectacle of Diane Cruise (Talia Shire), a clinical psychologist from Los Angeles, who has fallen into a deep neurotic depression following the loss of her husband. However, the way that Diane behaves doesn't suggest a depressed character as much as it does someone in the throes of a literary conceit. In an attempt to get a fix on herself, Diane sets out to track down three former boyfriends who, at different stages in her life, were crucially important to her. There's Jeff (Richard Jordan), her college love, who is now a film maker separated from his wife and, as he puts it, "a working mother" to his 13-year-old daughter. There are also Eric Katz (John Belushi), the leader of a tacky band, the fellow who humiliated her in high school, and Lewis Van Til, her grammar school boyfriend who was killed in Vietnam, but who left a younger brother, Wayne (Keith Carradine), who looks exactly the way Diane thinks Lewis would have looked if he had lived.Almost as soon as she meets Wayne, Diane starts "transferring" (based on the psychiatric meaning of the word "transference"), which  from the way it's demonstrated in this movie  is a communicable disease.Does Diane straighten herself out? Do movies have endings?There are some nice small moments in the movie, including a funny sequence about the filming of an election campaign commercial, and most of the scenes between Diane and Jeff. There's an unexpectedly affecting encounter between Diane and Wayne's mother (Bethel Leslie), which is then neutralized by a second encounter between them that is terrible.The writing veers back and forth between the good and the appalling. Says Diane, as she attempts to describe her relationship with Jeff: "He reaches inside me and pulls me out. I only wish that I could love me as much as he does." Some of this comes from her schoolgirl diaries, yet she has the unfortunate habit of talking like this in every adult crisis.Miss Tewkesbury's directorial style is loose without being lively. The screenplay doesn't help, but then it looks as if the director began production fondly hoping to discover the center of the film during the shooting. There's a good deal of seemingly unnecessary cross-cutting (between simultaneous actions), which doesn't heighten interest as often as it dissipates it. The performers, including John Houseman, who plays the small role of a psychiatrist, invest much more of themselves in the film than it ever returns to them.

title: Hers
description: MY daughter, Audrey, will be 1 year old next week, and I am trying to decide if seems as if she's been with us forever, if it seems like the day before yesterday when she was born. Both are true. This year has been the longest and the shortest of my life.

title: Space Shuttle Delayed Again
description: EL PASO, Tex., March 21 (UPI)  The flight of the space shuttle Columbia, weathersensitive because of temporary tiling installed to protect its aluminum skin, today was postponed for the fifth time in 12 days because of a spring rainstorm over south Texas. An Air Force spokesman said that, weather permitting, the shuttle  bolted atop a 747 jumbo jet  would take off from Biggs Army Air Field at 9 A.M. tomorrow and arrive 90 minutes later at Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio, Tex., on the first leg of an allday flight to Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: Backgammon:
description: Planning ahead and anticipating problems many rolls in advance is recognized as an essential part of middlegame strategy. It is often overlooked that planning far ahead may still be necessary even in the final stages of the game. Failure to do so can result in costly upsets when one is hit in the bearoff.

title: David Hicks: A Designer's Life Style Is an Auction's Key
description: WATLINGTON, England, March 21  When David Hicks, one of Britain's bestknown interior decorators, decided to open up his palatial country home for a public sale of its art and furnishings, the occasion was, for many, rather like an invitation to a music lover to ruffle through Leonard Bernstein's record collection.

title: Germans Link Woman to Killing
description: KARLSRUHE, West Germany, March 21 (AP)  The West German prosecutor charged a woman with murder and at tempted murder today in the shooting of one policeman and the wounding of another. The prosecutor. Kurt Rebmann. said that the woman, Angelika Speitel, would stand trial in Dusseldorf. A gun fight erupted when Miss Speitel and two companions, all linked to the BaaderMeinhof terrorist gang, were intercepted in a forest near Dortmund last September.

title: Bittersweet Farewell of a Grownup Child
description: MY parents have retired to Florida, and I am suffering an empty nest syndrome. They taught me the value of family, urged me to settle in town, nurtured the love of my children and then they left. I may be 31 years old and a liberated woman, but it still hurts. There are thousands of people like me, experiencing a kind of delayed separation anxiety. Our parents are leaving the old hometown and shaking our roots loose as they go.

title: World News Briefs
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 21 (Reuters)  The proCommunist Afghan Government has advised embassies in Kabul that communications have been cut with the western city of Herat, where Government forces and Moslem rebels have been fighting.

title: Advent of Spring Proves a Cause for Celebration
description: Jack Glattbach beamed through most of yesterday. He had his reasons. Andrew McKinley skipped his college classes. He had his reasons. Lesli Koppelman, Jennifer Blau and Tiffany Greene all had their reasons, too. All, in their way, were celebrating the arrival of spring.

title: Son of America Is Home to Tell About Chinese InLaws
description: Sidney Rittenberg has come home for a vacation after 34 years. I feel, he said yesterday, that I am a son of the American people and a soninlaw of the Chinese people and that I have come home to tell my folks about my inlaws.

title: Rights Group Appeals To Salvadoran Rebels
description: SAN SALVADOR, March 21 (Reuters)  A human rights group here has appealed to guerrillas to extend their deadline for killing four hostages.

title: 2 Seized in Illicit Sale Of 5,000 Quaaludes
description: LINDENHURST, L.I., March 21 (UPI)  Undercover agents posing as drug dealers bought 5,000 Quaalude pills outside a Lindenhurst diner last night and then arrested the two men who had sold. them, the Suffolk County police said

title: Ward Foods Sets Loan Agreement
description: Ward Foods Inc. said the company had entered into a $25 million, sevenyear loan agreement with eight domestic banks, led by the Mellon Bank, N.A. of Pittsburgh. Ward said the loan was unsecured, although the banks may call for security under certain conditions.

title: Pakistan Breaks Hashish Ring
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 21 (Reuters)  About 210 pounds of hashish oil, valued at $7 million, have been seized here after the arrest of an airline attendant and the owner of a pharmacy, the police said today. The male attendant, who worked for Pakistan International Airlines, and his partner were said to have been smuggling hashish to New York and Amsterdam for two years.

title: Attica Figure Free on Parole
description: John Hill, the last man imprisoned for his part in the September 1971 Attica prison uprising, was released on parole yesterday from the Eastern Correctional Facility at Napanock, N.Y. Mr. Hill, now 26 years old, was convicted in April 1975 of beating William Quinn, a guard, to death during the riot.

title: NEWS GROUPS TRIED TO CONFIRM CHARGES
description: The interview with Eschel M. Rhoodie, the principle figure in the South African corruption scandal, that was presented by the British Broadcasting Corporation last night followed a series of secret negotiations involving a number of British and American newspapers and television networks mat were offered access to Mr. Rhoodie's information on a pooled basis for a total of $200,000.

title: U.S. MAY NOT OPPOSE U.N. VOTE ON ISRAEL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21 The United States, which has often vetoed antiIsraeli resolutions in the Security Council, has decided conditionally not to block a plan for a commission to study conditions on the occupied West Bank.

title: JESSE JACKSON OPENS NEW ORLEANS DRIVE
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 21The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson brought his national campaign for student discipline to the Louisiana Superdome tonight with a rally attended by an estimated 50,000 people, cheering and chanting for selfmotivation, selfrespect and hope.

title: TruckingRate Bill Starts Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  Two powerful Senate Democrats reached an agreement today that will allow early consideration of legislation to introduce price competition to the trucking industry.

title: Alcan Cutting Price Of Aluminum Ingot
description: The Alcan Aluminum Corporation, the fourthlargest producer of aluminum in the nation, said it was also reducing the price of aluminum ingot to 58 cents from 59 cents a pound to comply with the newly revised Government price guidelines.

title: Advertising
description: IF you are the parent of one of the college kids currently enjoying the spring thing in Fort Lauderdale or Daytona Beach, Fla., or Padre Island, Tex., you may be interested to learn that they are being inundated with radio commercials from Western Union telling them how easy it is to get money from home. Charming.

title: U.S. Official Sees New OPEC Rise
description: WASHINGTON, March 22A senior American official who spent last weekend conferring in London with representatives of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries says that OPEC will probably decide on new price increases and possibly set production cutbacks when it meets in Geneva on Monday.

title: Tax Revolt May Wipe Out Jersey Hamlet's Entire Staff
description: VICTORY GARDENS, N.J., March 22  A taxpayers' revolt in this poor hilltown of western Morris County has threatened to wipe out the jobs of the entire fulltime municipal work force  all five people.

title: Red Sox Wish It Was 10/2/78
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 22Right from the start, when Willie Randolph was fooled on the first pitch thrown today by Mike Torrez, the customers behaved as if they were back home at Fenway Park in Boston.

title: Corporate Profitability: What Is Best Measure?
description: Corporate profitability has long been a controversial subject. For business leaders, it is a means of measuring the health of their industries. For Government officials, it is a way to take the pulse of the economy and to judge whether investment will be sufficiently high to insure future economic growth. For labor chiefs, it is one way to judge whether workers are getting a fair shake.

title: Screen: 'The Great Bank Hoax':Bumbling Cover-Up
description: "THE Great Bank Hoax," which opens today at the Trans-Lux East and other theaters, is a self-styled "fable," which, in this case, means a homespun comedy with fewer chuckles than a road map. It's about the efforts of the bumbling officers of a small-town bank to fake a robbery to cover up an embezzlement by the bank's chief clerk, a fellow who doesn't want the money, only to test a theory. More than that you need never know.The people involved in this facetious enterprise include Arthur Godfrey, Richard Basehart and Burgess Meredith, all of whom look suspiciously wrinkle-free, as well as Ned Beatty, Michael Murphy,Charlene Dallas and Paul Sand, the young man who won a Tony award in New York some years ago for his performance as a dog in Paul Sills's "Story Theater." In the past, each actor has demonstrated talent that is nowhere to be seen in "The Great Bank Hoax," which was written and directed by Joseph Jacoby."The Great Bank Hoax," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), suggests nothing obscene or suggestive.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Market Place
description: SMALL investors take note: A recent study of all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange indicates that over a 20year period those companies with clean balance sheets, high return on equity and low priceearnings multiples were the stock market winners, and by a wide margin.

title: Moynihan Bids Carter Take a Clear Position On Buildup by Soviet
description: WASHINGTON. March 22  Senator Darnel P. Moynihan warned today that the United States may well be at risk because of a recent military buildup by the Soviet Union, whose international behavior he described as intentionally contemptuous of the United States.

title: The Pop Life
description: ELVIS COSTELLO'S second album was called This Year's Model, and that was, among other things, a comment on the insecurities of the trendy world of popular music, in which this year's commercial hit or critical favorite is next year's forgotten reject.

title: About Real Estate
description: Three years ago the building workers of Local 32B went on strike for 17 days against owners of apartment houses in New York City. Tenants experienced a reduction in services. City sanitation workers, in sympathy with the strikers, refused to pick up the garbage. The resulting litter was tremendous.

title: More Talks Needed for Soviet Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  Senior Administration aides, after an extensive review at the White House of the negotiations with the Soviet Union on limiting strategic arms, have concluded that further talks with Moscow are necessary before a new accord can be reached, Government officials said today.

title: Vendor Gets A Special: 4 Tickets At Full Price
Business Records
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 22, 1979

title: Tracking Drug Industry Sales
description: In the early 1960's, an enterprising advertising man diagnosed a need for an organization to act as scorekeeper for the pharmaceutical industry in much the way the A.C. Nielsen ratings track the broadcast industry.

title: Conoco to Rebuild Damaged Refinery
description: The Continental Oil Company announced plans to rebuild its Commerce City, Colo., refinery at a cost of $22.5 million. The refinery has been out of service since it was damaged by fire and explosion last Oct. 3.

title: Two Million Shares Of Bulova Tendered
description: The Loews Corporation announced that a total of about two million common shares of the Bulova Watch Company had been tendered to its wholly owned subsidiary, the LTR Holding corporation, pursuant to LTR's $10 cash tender offer for any and all outstanding Bulova shares, which expired at 5 P.M. on Wednesday. The shares tendered include shares subject to guarantees of delivery and shares subject to receipt of additional documentation.

title: Publishing: Carole Baron Named Editor of Crown
description: IN a major editorial shift at Crown Publishers, Herbert Michelman will step down as vice president and editor in chief, a post he has held since 1949. He will be replaced by Carose Baron, who will leave Pocket Books where she is executive editor. Mr. Michelman will publish and edit books for Crown under his own imprint.

title: Executing the Death Penalty
description: One of these Mondays the Supreme Court will announce whether it chooses to hear yet another broadside assault on capital punishment. If it answers no to John Spinkellink, the condemned Florida drifter whose petition for review of his death sentence poses the challenge, it may also be condemning the threefourths of the nation's 500 deathrow inmates who are in the Deep South and so under the jurisdiction of the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals. That could mean that executions will resume after a dozen years in which no American prisoner was involuntarily put to death.

title: U.S. Sues On Skil Bid Of Emerson
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) The Government filed suit today to block the impending acquisition by the Emerson Electric Company of more than 50 percent of the stock of the Skil Corporation, a leading manufacturer of portable power tools.

title: Papp's 3d World Troupe To Be Classics Repertory
description: In what he calls the most important move I've made in years, Joseph Papp is expanding his blackHispanic Shakespeare company into an emerging third world repertory classical acting company. It will begin with a budget of $1.2 million a year and is planned to eventually cost $2.5 million to $3 million a year, approximately half of the entire budget of Mr. Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival. budget of $1.2 million a year and is planned to eventually cost $2.5 million to $3 million a year, approximately half of the entire budget of Mr. Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival.

title: At the Movies
description: THE setting was the oakpaneled Recital Room on the mezzanine of the Barbizon Hotel for Women. Seated in front of the golden pipes of a petite organ sat Marilyn Hassett, easing a sprained back, while scores of guests came by to say hello to her and to Larry Peerce, the star and the director, respectively, The Bell Jar.

title: Florida Gas Holds Acquisition Talks
description: The Florida Gas Company said it had held preliminary discussions with two companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange concerning their possible acquisition of Florida Gas.

title: Rights Plan Foes Celebrate Its Difficulties With a Gala
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  With a gala party, musical skits and a blitz of antifeminist pronouncements, opponents of the equal rights amendment marshaled forces here today to celebrate the expiration of the original sevenyear ratification period, to declare the measure moribund and to lampoon its supporters in song. satire and stinging sarcasm.

title: Holmes: Hey, I'm Main Event
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 22 Larry Holmes, slowly emerging from the shadow of the other heavyweight champion of the world, will get paid between $1 million and $1.5 million tomorrow night to defend his World Boxing Council title against a sparring partner he had to take it easy on just two years ago.

title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 22, 1979

title: Shortcut to Grandmother's Proves Otherwise
description: Shawn Robertson, 11 years old, found that shortcuts may be more interesting but not necessarily faster ways getting from one place to another. Taking a detour to his grandmother's house in Bristol, Conn., the boy got stuck in waistdeep mud. A fireman, Rick Lundquist, managed to extricate the youngster from his predicament.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Bridge:
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 22  Two veteran New York stars who used to be one of the world's great partnerships seem headed for a final confrontation in the Vanderbilt knockout team championship here tomorrow. Sam Stayman and George Rapee, who together won three world team titles more than a quarter of a century ago, led separate teams into battle in the semifinals today with high hopes of advancing to the finals tomorrow, and then  as each of them hopes  to a victory that would put them in line for further international honors.

title: Laotian Aide Confirms Stationing of Vietnam Troops
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 22  A Foreign Ministry official acknowledged implicitly today that Vietnamese troops were stationed in Laos and had used it as a base in the invasion of Cambodia.

title: Olivieri Says State Fosters Institutionalizing Aged
description: New York State encourages the elderly to institutionalize themselves by offeting larger payments to residents of adult homes than to those who live by themselves or with family, City Councilman Antonio G. Olivieri said yesterday.

title: Islanders Topple Canadiens, 53
description: MONTREAL, March 22  The New York Islanders, just seven years in the National Hockey League, humbled the mighty Montreal Canadiens in the Forum tonight, 53, before 18,083 fans. In doing so, the Islanders moved 4 points ahead of the Canadiens in the run for the best record in the league and the home advantage throughout the playoffs. Both teams have nine games left.

title: Leftist Leader Is Slain In Guatemalan Capital
description: MEXICO CITY, March 22  Manuel Colom Argueta, former Mayor of Guatemala City and Guatemala's most popular leftist leader, was murdered by unidentified gunmen as he drove to his office in the Guatemalan capital this morning.

title: U.S. Plans $1.5 Billion Bond Sale
description: The Treasury announced yesterday that it planned to sell $1.5 billion of 15year bonds next Thursday to raise new cash, and the news caused a modest decline in bond prices late in the afternoon. Earlier, mediumgrade corporate and highergrade taxexempt bond issues failed to evoke much enthusiasm from investors.

title: Carter Role in '76 Loan Talks Reported
description: ATLANTA, March 22  President Carter took part in discussions and correspondence in 1976 about financial aspects of his family's peanut business that are now the subjects of a special investigation by the Department of Justice, according to interviews with persons who say they were present, and to bank records.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 23,1979

title: Ma Bell Plays Patroness to Orchestras
description: The Bell System American Orchestras on Tour program, which will bring a subsidy of $10 million to seven major ensembles over the next four years, was announced yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. It is believed to be the largest financial commitment made by a company for such a project. The money will help to defray the expenses of national tours made by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Cleveland Orchestra, Los Angeles Philharmonic, New York Philharmonic, Philadelphia Orchestra and Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: EDMUND WILSON thought him the only firstrate comic genius that has appeared in England since Bernard Shaw. George Orwell thought he was about as good a novelist as one can be ... while holding untenable opinions. Harold Acton said of him, He had the sharp eye of a Hogarth alternating with that of the Ancient Manner.

title: Film: 'Boulevard Nights':Coast Gangs
description: RAYMOND (Richard Yniguez) and Chuco (Danny De La Paz) are brothers, two young Mexican-Americans living in East Los Angeles, where virtually every street is at war with the next. Raymond aspires to leave the slum, get married and open his own automobile-repair shop. Chuco, the younger one, has no identity except (or that of his gang, which leads him first to paint-sniffing and then to disaster."Boulevard Nights," which opens today at the Cinerama and other theaters, trivializes the Mexican-American experience by equating it with the melodrama of many other minor movies about gang wars. The film, written by Desmond Nakano and directed by Michael Pressman, is so busy trying to meet the needs of a conventional narrative that it appears to have no point of view about its characters. When we watch them suffer and die in foolish pursuits, the movie is merely sightseeing.With the possible exception of Mr. De La Paz, whose haunted looks suggest someone deeply troubled, the actors are not very good. Mr. Pressman begins one key scene by pointing the camera at the sky and then panning down to the action on the ground. When a director starts a scene by taking pictures of the sky, it usually means he's not got very much on his mind.

title: Deaths
description: FITZGIBBONS  Katherine (nee Kiernan) age 86. On March 21, 1979. Resided at 18B Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn. A Dame in The Order of the Holy Sequicher and widow of John J. Fitzgibbons, a Knight of The British Empire. Funeral services 10AM Monday, Sacred Heart Church, Southbury, Conn. Visiting tours Sunday 24 and 79PM MunsonLovetere Funeral Home, Main St, Southbury.

title: Rare South Indian Music Opens Innovative Series
description: Tonight's concert at the Center for International Arts by Dr. L. Subramaniam, the celebrated Indian violinist, is a doubly auspicious occasion. It marks a rare appearance here by an outstanding exponent of the littleheard classical music of South India, and it inaugurates an ambitious new Music of India series at the center, an art gallery and performing space at 28 East Fourth Street, between Lafayette Street and the Bowery.

title: Option Ruled Out On Monumental
description: Frank Baker Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Monumental Corporation, announced that the Maryland commissioner of insurance had disapproved the proposal of the Sun Life Insurance Company of America to acquire up to 21 percent of the voting securities of Monumental.

title: Mets' Pitching Problems Grow
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22  Things went from bad to worse for the New York Met pitching staff tonight when Bob Apodaca and Bob yrick were placed on the disabled list and Juan Berenguer was farmed out to the Pacific Coast League.

title: Environmental Chief Denies Official Trips Wasted Tax Dollars
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) Douglas M. Costle, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, vowed today to correct any travel abuses by his agency's employees but denied that incidents cited by Senate investigators reflected a widespread waste of tax dollars.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Airlines has named John C. Pope treasurer.

title: Carter's Energy Policies Pose Danger for Him in New England Primaries
description: BOSTON, March 22  President Carter's energy policies have started a degree of regional discontent that brings with it threats of significant opposition in key Presidential primaries next year in New England.

title: Sea Songs and Stories Day on 35th St.
description: Songs and tales of the sea will be presented in a fivehour program tomorrow, beginning at 5:30 P.M. in the Community Church, 40 East 35th Street.

title: U.S. Marine Leaves Vietnam After Nearly 14 Years
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 22  The United States Marine Corps has an informal slogan: First in, last out. Today Pfc. Robert Russell Garwood became the embodiment of that slogan when he left Vietnam after having arrived nearly 14 years ago with the first Marine detachments sent there in 1965.

title: The Region
description: PATERSON, N.J. (UPI)  The police have been questioning relatives and friends of a 9yearold girl, whose partly nude and battered body was found buried under debris on a deserted street about a block from her house. The girl, Latrelle Jones of 59 Paterson Avenue, had been missing since Saturday, and was found beaten to death Wednesday.

title: Oil Companies Sue Alaska
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, March 22 (AP)The major producers of North Slope oil and owners of the transAlaska pipeline filed suit against the state today, charging that a corporate income lax on the industry was unconstitutional.

title: Wind Group of Holland Offers a Dutch Treat
description: If you like surprises you might try the concert bythe Netherlands Wind Ensemble in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night at 8. This crack group of 17 firstdesk players from five Dutch orchestras will play a formal program of works by Rossini, Franz Krommer, Edgard Varese and Mozart, but thereafter it promises something more. What exactly that will be is anyone's guess.

title: Art People
description: WITH the Tutankhamun show nearing the end of its original tour (it closes April 15 at the Metropolitan Museum, the last stop on the sixmuseum circuit organized by the Met then clanks on to new bookings in San Francisco, Canada and West Germany), this seems as good a time as any to check out what's happening with the money earned by the Egyptians, largely from the sale of Tut reproductions in participating museum shops.

title: For Children
description: SPRING NATURE WALK, through the Wadsworth Sanctuary, to view birds and wild flowers, Saturday and 1:30 P.M., at the Nature Center for Environmental Activities, 10 Woodside Lane, Westport, Conn. Free. Call (203) 2277253.

title: Admiral Called Likely G.S.A. Head
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  President Carter will announce soon the appointment of Rear Adm. Rowland G. Freeman 3d as the new head of the scandalplagued General Services Administration, White House officials said tonight.

title: MARGARET ASKWITH
description: Margaret Askwith, a travel executive, died yesteday at her home in Larchmont, N.Y. She was 93 years old.

title: In Changing San Francisco, a Proud Hotel Holds Out
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 22  Seen from the entrance to the alley called Maiden Lane, past the memorial to Mm. George Dewey's victory at Manila Bay, over the beds of primroses and through the clouds of pigeons, the Powell Street front of the St. Francis Hotel towers beyond Union Square like a fortress.

title: Cunningham Gets New Life Style
description: LOS ANGELES, March 22 (UPI)  Gary Cunningham resigned today as head basketball coach at the University of California, Los Angeles, saying he had coped well with the pressures of the job but needed more freedom of time than the position allowed.

title: ArabAmericans Attack Treaty Over Issue of Palestinian Rights
description: DETROIT, March 22 North America's largest Arabspeaking community here in Detroit does not respond to the proposed EgyptianIsraeli peace pact any more favorably than the leaders of Saudi Arabia and Jordan did to the Administration's recent efforts to enlist their support for it.

title: Japan Jails Two In Poisonings
description: TOKYO, March 22 (AP) Two former fertilizer company executives were convicted of professional negligence and sentenced to prison today in connection with the Minamata disease, a mercury poisoning that killed 283 persons.

title: Who's Doing What for Bach, and When
description: 11 A.M. The Bloomingdale Chamber Orchestra. Allan Miller, Pinchas Zukerman David Aks, conductor.

title: Honest Bill Daly Wears a Toupee
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 22  The couple from Sioux Falls were checking into the Las Vegas Hilton today when the registration clerk mentioned tomorrow night's boxing card in the hotel pavilion.

title: Dr. Sidney Alan Rapp Weds Amy J. Liebman, Executive
description: Amy Jane Liebman and Dr. Sidney Alan Rapp were married yesterday at the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre by Rabbi Jerome Davidson of Temple BethEl in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Theater: Rosmersholm
description: NEW HAVEN IN lbsen's Rosmersholm, the powerful momentum of fa'e conjured up by the author is all but choked in a plot that is a mare's nest of moral complications.

title: U.N. GROUP TO STUDY ISRAELI SETTLEMENTS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22The Security Council, overriding Israeli objections, approved a resolution today creating a threemember commission to look into the situation of Israeli settlements on the West Bank of the Jordan.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Hog futures prices declined as far as permitted yesterday after a Government report said that there were largerthanexpected numbers of hogs awaiting slaughter on farms in 14 porkproducing states.

title: Memorial Service for Bill Doll
description: A memorial service for Bill Doll, Broadway press agent who died in Englewood Hospital, Englewood, N.J., on March 2, will be held in the Belasco Room of Sardi's Restaurant, 234 West 44th Street, next Thursdayat 5:30 P.M.

title: Broadway
description: IS it time for a big, smashing Broadway musical about Victoria Woodhull? Miss Woodhull was a dazzler  a candidate for President in 1872, a spiritualist, a stockbroker, a suffragist and a great many other things as well  and various people have considered doing a show about her life. A few, in fact, have tried. Now there is to be Onward Victoria!, which began as a staged reading at the Manhattan Theater Club, but is supposed to be a big, smashing Broadway musical next season. We decided that it cried out to be a musical, says Julianne Boyd, who staged the reading. Miss Boyd, who directed Eubie!, is to direct Onward Victoria! while John Hart is to produce it. He is associate producer of Eubie!

title: IN THE NATION
description: MONTGOMERY. Ala.  The house at 3140 Fitzgerald Drive in this city's new Hillwood section could be any house in suburban America  dark brick, black blinds, brass carriage lamps, a spacious garage in the rear full of gleaming cars.

title: Business and the Law
description: IT is a matter of no small irony that one of the most significant pieces of legislation affecting big business would, if enacted, be called the Small Business Protection Act of 1979.

title: Parents in Suburbs Are Turning Increasingly to Private Schooling
description: Applications for admission to private schools in the counties surrounding New York City are on the rise, largely as a result of dissatisfaction with the public school systems whose advantages had originally lured families to the suburbs.

title: TAXFREE BOND USE IN HOUSING DISPUTED
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  The mounting use of taxexempt bonds by cities to finance lowcost mortgages to middleclass home buyers threatens to have such an impact on the Federal treasury that the Administration warned today it was contemplating strong measures to clamp down on the trend.

title: A Power Play in Wheat
description: CHICAGO, March 22  Leslie W. Rosenthal, a prom inent commodities trader and vice chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, has emerged as a central figure in the scare over possible price manipulation of March wheat contracts, which has shaken the commodities market over the bast week.

title: Escaping the OilImport Trap
description: HONOLULU  Those who were unconvinced at the time of the Arab oil embargo in 1974 that the United States should dramatically decrease its dependence upon imported crude oil may now feel different in the light of the loss of Iranian oil and price increases by the oilexporting Middle Eastern countries. if we had the political will, we could become completely selfsufficient in energy. Our vulnerability to disruptions in crudeoil supplies represents a far more serious threat to national security than any of the alleged imbalances in strategic weapons between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Colombia Cracks Down but the Marijuana Gets Through
description: BARRANQUILLA. Colombia, March 16  The war between the armed forces and drug smugglers on the Atlantic coast of Colombia has produced huge seizures of marijuana and hundreds of arrests, but major shipments continue to move to the East Coast of the United States..

title: Philharmonic: Pollini
description: ANYONE making up lists of the most talented pianists and conductors of the middle generation would have some explaining to do if the names of Maurizio Pollini and Claudio Abbado did not appear somewhere high up there. So last night's New York Philharmonic concert, which brought them together, was one not to be overlooked. Strangely, however, the two young Italians, both from Milan, did not add up to as wonderful a team as the curious listener might have expected. They met on predictably high ground for a performance of Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto, but it was a performance more noteworthy for its polish and unreproachable good taste than for higher matters.

title: New Rule Is Sought On Stocks
description: WASHINGTON. March 22 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced plans today for a new rule that could exempt newly listed securities from stock exchange rules that require trading on the exchange floor.

title: F.B.I. Head at Odds With Congress Over Audit on Use of Informers
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that the bureau and Congress were unable to agree on a Congressional audit of the F.B.I.'s use of informers.

title: Books: Museum Story
description: THE CITY OF NEW YORK History Illustrated from the Collections of the Mueum of the City of New York.Text by Jerry Patterson. Foreword by Locos Auchincloss. Introduction by Joseph Vearh Noble. 252 pages. Harry N.Abram $19.95.

title: Magazine Outlines Its Arguments Against Restraining Bomb Article
description: MADISON, Wis., March 22  Attorneys for the The Progressive magazine will contend in Federal District Court Monday that the Department of Justice's attempt to suppress a report on the hydrogen bomb threatens our national security far more than the publication of a newspaper or magazine article ever could.

title: Around the Nation
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 22 (AP) Utah Gov. Scott Matheson today endorsed the Army's plan to blow up 26 rusting land mines, including some that may contain a deadly nerve gas.

title: A Police Chief Becomes Chief of Patrol Today
description: I'm telling you this: If William Bracey can become a chief in the greatest police department in the world, you can, too.

title: Student Chefs Prove the More Cooks the Better
description: Poached capon smothered in bechamel sauce and garnished with leeks, carrots and truffles is not everyone's idea of a deterrent to unemployment. But Matthew Ryan thinks it has some merit.

title: Deaths
description: SEHEdward Sr., the Officers, Board of Trustees and members of Central Synagogue deeply mourn the passing of an esteemed member of many years. Heartfelt comblences to all members of the family.

title: Proposals on Regulatory Policies Are Expected From Carter Soon
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  President Carter plans a statement in the next few days endorsing regulatory revision and legislation aimed at streamlining the revision process, Administration officials said today.

title: DENG SAID TO WARN CHINA ABOUT LAXITY
description: PEKING. March 22  Deputy Prime Minister Deng Xiaoping has reportedly accused some Chinese of having gone to far with the trend toward greater freedom of expression and democracy.

title: Opera: Eugene Onegin
description: TCHAIKOVSKY'S bittersweet and infinitely touching Eugene Onegin made its seasonal entry into the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday night. The leading roles had been newly cast, two of the singers being from the Soviet Union. Conducting the work, which was sung in Russian, was Naami Yarvi, an Estonian, making his debut with the company. The performance was successful in a curious way, because it was possible to fault it in various details. It provided an overall experience that was quite moving and came not merely from the impact of the endearing score.

title: Ballet: Sleeping Beauty in Roanoke
description: ROANOKE, VA. THE Houston Ballet presented its new production of The Sleeping Beauty at the Roanoke Civic Center here Wednesday night under the auspices of the Thursday Morning Music Club.

title: Notes on People
description: What with the highly publicized fundraising campaign by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to buy bulletproof vests for police officers, much importance was placed yesterday on choosing the first recipient of a vest. Phyllis Newman, the actress, was recruited to draw a name from a wire basket in City Hall ceremonies, and out came the shield number of Al Amadeo, of the Empire Boulevard station house in Brooklyn.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Carter Administration has decided not to lift preferences in Government procurement now given to small businesses and minority enterprises. The Administration had included a relaxation the preferences in concessions it agreed to earlier in the international trade talks. But political pressure apparently prompted a reversal of that stand. [Page Al.]

title: Income Limits Raised For Disability Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)The Department of Health, Education and Welfare raised the limits today on how much income a person can earn without losing Social Security or Supplemental Security Income disability benefits.

title: Cooper Near Accord On GardnerDenver
description: Cooper Industries said it had entered a provisional consent agreement with the staff of the Federal Trade Commission that, if accepted by the commission, would terminate the Government agency's investigation of Cooper's plans to acquire the GardnerDenver Company.

title: What Mr. Carter Can Do About Oil
description: Our dependence on imported oil  now about half of all our consumption  continues to push the American economy toward recession and erode our influence in the Middle East. That view is universal, but there is no consensus on what to do about it.

title: Fran Warren Back With Sunday Kind of Love in Her Voice
description: Fran Warren really has something to sing about for the next three weeks at Michael's Pub. This engagement, in which she sandwiches a tribute to Sammy Calm, the songwriter, between tributes to her own vast. present and future, is the first time Miss Warren has performed since the city of New York made her half a millionaire.

title: Deaths
description: ASKWITHMargaret Long. In her 93rd year at home in Larchmont. Beloved wife of Herbert. Loving mother of Bertram, Jerry (Edna), Jean and Marlory. Cherished grandmother of eleven and great grandmother of five. Service Sunday 2 p.m. at The Westchester Riverside, 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: U.S. Aides Call Afghan Rebellion Challenge to ProSoviet Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  The proSoviet Government of Afghanistan, in fighting against Moslem rebels and tribal dissidents, appears to be facing its first real challenge since it seized power in April 1978, Administration officials said today.

title: The Editorial Notebook The Antinuclear Syndrome
description: Two dramas about the catastrophic potential of nuclear power opened almost simultaneously last week. In movie theaters around the country. Jane Fonda and Jack Lemmon struggled against reckless businessmen to prevent a devastating accident known as The China Syndrome. And in Washington, D.C., regulators ordered five nuclear plants shut down to avert a virtually identical accident. How well did art mirror life?

title: Operators of School Buses Offer To Resume Service if Protected
description: About 35 schoolbus operators met with the Board of Education's Bureau of Pupil Transportation yesterday and offered to resume service in the school bus drivers strike if they were provided police protection for their personnel and equipment.

title: Witter Has Deficit of $886,000
description: The Dean Witter Reynolds Organization Inc., which operates a worldwide securities firm, reported yesterday a loss of $886,000 for the second fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28 and a profit of $2.5 million, or 28 cents a share, for the six months.

title: TV and Radio to Cover Signing of Peace Pact
description: The three commercial television networks and the Public Broadcasting Service said yesterday that they would provide live coverage of the signing of the Middle East peace treaty in Washington Monday.

title: Regents Plan Inquiry Into a Merger Proposed by Two Schools of Music
description: ALBANY, March 22  The New York State Board of Regents today authorized Chancellor Theodore M. Black to investigate the circumstances surrounding the proposed merger of the Manses College of Music and the Manhattan School of Music. The merger was proposed last January and abandoned earlier this month.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The latest chapter in the Bank of America's apparently widening investigation of its officers real estate operations has come to light with the resignations of more executives from the nation's largest bank. These departures follow the puzzling resignation last August of Alvin C. Rice as a vice chairman and the subsequent disclosure of loans made by the bank to a real estate developer with whom he had had dealings.

title: Leesona Adds NegriBossi
description: The Lecsona Corporation announced yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of the IngersollRand Company's Italianbased subsidiary, NegriBossi S.p.A., for $12 million. NegriBossi makes plasticinjectionmolding machinery and had sales last year of about $25 million.

title: Nicklaus Tied at 67, But Zarley 66 Leads
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., March 22Golfers may rest easy. The earth has spun back to its normal orbit now that Jack Nicklaus seems to have recovered his game.

title: Tracy Austin Routs Chris Evert, 63, 61
description: The first two times she played Chris Evert, Tracy Austin said she was awed. Last summer, she wilted from fatigue. But last night at Madison Square Garden, the 16yearold Californian stunned the tennis world with a 63, 61 victory over Miss Evert for a berth in the semifinals of the women's winter tour championships.

title: Steel Concern Extends Tender Bid
description: The PittsburghDes Moines Steel Company said that it had received 198,794 of its common shares following a tender offer that expired Wednesday.

title: North Koreans Assail Maneuvers In South as Prelude to New War
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, March 22 (UPI)  North Korea charged today that the United Nations Command had betrayed its intention to start a war on the Korean Peninsula by holding military exercises in South Korea.

title: TV Weekend
description: MOVIES made for television are uncommonly fond of personal handicaps that afford upbeatuplift endings, and, in this sense, No Other Love is no exception. It is the story of two young people who fall in love and want to get married. The problem: both are mentally retarded. The difference: No Other Love, which can be seen on CBS tomorrow at 9 P.M., has been made with sensitivity, honesty and outstanding acting talent.

title: Hotel Holiday: How Suite It Is
description: THEY come from Scarsdale and Scranton, Princeton and Pittsburgh  some of them travel all the way from Washington, Boston or even Toronto. They are making New York a center for a new kind of tourism: urban weekending.

title: CARTER TO PROPOSE A $10BILLION PLAN ON HEALTH FOR 1983
description: President Carter will ask Congress within the next few months to approve the first phase of a national health plan that would initially cost from $10 billion to $15 billion, beginning in 1983, Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced here yesterday.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Albert W. Hughes, 88, Executive Who Headed the J.C. Penney Co.
description: Albert William Hughes, retired president and chairman of the board of the J. C. Penney Company, died yesterday in the New Rochelle Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Larchmont. N.Y.

title: N.H.L. Approves Plan to Merge With Four Clubs From W.H.A.
description: CHICAGO, March 22 The National Hockey League voted today to merge with its rival, the World Hockey Association. Though many details remain to be negotiated, the agreement by the N.H.L. Board of Governors represented the first step in putting all of North America's major professional players in one league.

title: Chanting Dervishes Move in Ecstatic Circles
description: Not all dervishes are whirling dervishes. There are also chanting dervishes  Sufi Moslems who use their voices as drums during their sabbath eve rituals in the prayer lodges of Turkey.

title: San Francisco Sends a Trove Of French Art
description: ONE or two superfine paintings have just come into town on a visit. They are part of a loan show called Masterpieces of French Art from the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, and they are on view at Wildenstein & Company, 19 East 64th Street, through April 27.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Poverty Label and Funds Spurned in East Flatbush
description: Poverty presses hard on many of the edges of East Flatbush, and in some cases it has come right into the community.

title: REPRIEVE IS SOUGHT FOR DEFENSE BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  This is sad commentary on the influence large corporations and their lobbyists can exert on the legislative process, said Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, the chief architect of America's nuclear fleet.

title: Albany Compromise on School Aid And Revenue Sharing Falls Apart
description: ALBANY, March 22  Negotiators for the Legislature and Governor Carey reached and then lost an agreement today to hold down increases in education aid in return for a new state revenuesharing formula. The new formula would have given local governments almost as much state aid as they had expected for this year, but would have slowed the growth of local aid in the future.

title: U.S JETS WILL KEEP A WATCH OVER SINAI TO ENFORCE TREATY
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  The United States has agreed to continue surveillance flights over Sinai for three years to check on Israeli and Egyptian compliance with the terms of their peace treaty, Administration officials said today.

title: Disabled, He Waits in Vain for School Bus
description: In the quiet moments, Robert stares out the window. He gazes at the street looking at what is left of the familiar, waiting for a sign that things will come back to normal.

title: City Opera: Miss Havisham
description: THE New York City Opera added another statistic to its history last night. With its performance of Dominick Argento's Miss Havisham's Fire, the company now has 17 world premieres and 13 commissions to its credit. The opera was conducted by Julius Rudel, who on June 30 will step down as director of the company he has headed for so many years. Beverly Sills, his successor, was in the audience last night.

title: Dayan Seeks U.S. Security Assurance
description: JERUSALEM, March 22  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan flew to Washington this morning to negotiate final details of a pact specifying what action the United States would be prepared to take if Egypt violated its peace treaty with Israel.

title: Money
description: THURSDAY. MARCH 22, 1979

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 22 (Reuters)  Hanoi accused Peking today of holding on to some of Vietnam's territory in an attempt to provoke a new war.

title: I.R.S. Aide Is Accused of Taking Gratuity From Foundation Head
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)  An auditor for the Internal Revenue Service was charged in an indictment today with accepting a gratuity from Dr. Murdock Head, director of the Airlie Foundation in Warrenton, Va.

title: Events and Openings
description: THE GREAT BANK HOAX, directed by Joseph Jacoby; starring Richard Basehart and Ned Beatty, at the Trans Lux East, Guild. Embassy and other theaters.

title: Toward a Wider Gateway
description: A proposal to increase bus service to the beaches the Gateway National Recreation Area on New York's Rockaway Peninsula has provoked some unpleasant exchanges. Residents of nearby communities complain that traffic on access roads and the Marine Parkway Bridge would reach intolerable levels, cutting them off from police, fire and ambulance assistance and inviting summertime riot if everyone tried to flee the park at once in a rainstorm. Those who want more buses imply that the residents are trying to keep out poor and minority bathers.

title: Sadat Lauds a Great Ally
description: CAIRO, March 22  President Anwar elSadat today welcomed the approval by Israel's Parliament of the peace treaty between Egypt and Israel, and he attributed the vote of approval to a great ally  the Israeli mother.

title: White House Plans Peace Treaty Festival
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  Teams of workmen were busy this afternoon raising a special platform on the rarely used North Lawn of the White House in preparation for the signing ceremony, at 2 P.M. Monday, of the peace treaty between Israel and Egypt.

title: Alcoa Will Restart Texas Smelting Line
description: The Aluminum Company of America announced that it would restart another smelting line at its Point Comfort plant in Texas, which will mean that three out of the seven smelting units at the plant will be in production by early July. The step was taken to meet the high demand for aluminum, the company said.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Dancin' Jazz is the theme of the ondo Dance Theater's program toight and tomorrow at the new Perorning Arts Center of the State Uniersity of New York at Purchase. And ho better could Rondo have chosen as ??e theme's exponent than Daniel Narin, the jazz soloist, who has been aswilding dance audiences with his dra??atic intensity and jazz technique for any a year? Mr. Nagrin will perform tree solos, one of them his Strange ero, a portrait of an American ganger set to a Stan Kenton score. Other tests are Michele RebeaUd, Bonnie rosby and Pat Strauss, a comic, lanky rmer star of Canada's Les Ballets ??zz. Also on the program is Take ve by Elizabeth Rockwell, the com??ny's director, a modernjazz dance telling of the Pied Piper legend. Curin time is 8:30 each night, and tickets ??e $7 tonight, $8 tomorrow. Informa??on: (914) 2535900

title: Holding a Birthday Blowout for J.S. Bach
description: Allan Miller has no idea how many people might show up for WalltoWall Bach II, the free 12hour marathon of J.S. Bach's music to be held at Symphony Space tomorrow from 11 A. M. to 11 P. M., but an estimated 7,000 musiclovers responded to the invitation to Wallto Wall Bach I last year, and so he is prepared for the worst. Tins marathon will celebrate not only Bach's music, but his birthday as well he would have been 294 years old this week.

title: Vorster Rejects Allegations in South Africa's Scandal
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, March 22 President John Vorster broke months of silence today to rebut allegations that as Prime Minister he had approved secret plans in which money was used irregularly. But he did not specifically deny that some of the money was used for bribery and other political machinations in the United States and elsewhere.

title: 117,000 Tires Made in Sweden Are Being Recalled by Firestone
description: AKRON Ohio, March 22 (AP)  The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it was voluntarily recalling about 117,000 steelbelted radial 500 tires manufactured in Sweden before May 1, 1976 for use in the United Stares.

title: McEnroe Triumphs By 64, 62
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 22 (UPI)Thirdseeded John McEnroe avoided the same fate that had stunned Jimmy Connors the night before and instead advanced to the quarterfinals of the $175,000 New Orleans Tennis Festival with a 64, 62 victory over Kim Warwick tonight.

title: Small Business Forces U.S. Shift On Trade Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  The Carter Administration has decided not to withdraw the preferences in Government procurement now given to smallbusiness and minority enterprises. The plan to withdraw the preferences had been strongly opposed by minority anitsmallbusiness leaders and influential members of Congress.

title: Yastrzemski Gets A Sweeter Deal
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 22  Carl Yastrzemski's demands for a little more finacial security were finally answered today by the Boston Red Sox. They gave the 39yearold slugger a twoyear contract extension estimated to be worth $1.2 million.

title: Koch Says Police Reinforcements Curb Subway Crime
description: Mayor Koch declared yesterday that subway crime had dropped since rein. forced transit and city police patrols began last Monday afternoon, and added that the police deployments would be flexible.

title: Two for Seesaw Uptown
description: Two for the Seesaw, William Gibson's romantic play about an unlikely couple, will be performed this weekend at Teachers College at Columbia University, Broadway and 120th Street. Donations accepted. Reservations: 6783748 or 6783777.

title: Allstate Gives Million for Housing
description: CHICAGO, March 22  Robert B. Sheppard, president of Allstate Insurance Company, said today that Allstate would invest El million in Neighborhood Housing Services, a national organization to rehabilitate neighborhoods.

title: U.S. Subpoenas Campaign Data In Sewer Inquiry
description: The books, ledgers and other campaign records of both the Republican and Democratic Parties in Suffolk County have been subpoenaed as part of a widening Federal investigation of Suffolk County's troubled Southwest Sewer District.

title: EARNINGS
description: Profits of N. V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken, known in the United States as the Philips Lamp Works, surged 39.8 percent in the fourth quarter last year, overshadowing the 1.4 percent profit drop in the first nine months of 1978. As a result, the giant diversified electricalelectronics producer, based in Eindhoven, the Netherlands, reported an 11.7 percent increase in earnings for all of last year.

title: Auctions
description: THE abundance of Art Nouveau and Art Deco material that will be dispersed over the next eight days at New York's two leading auction houses may well be the largest representation of these 20thcentury decorative arts styles ever dispersed at public sale in such a short period of time. The action opens tomorrow at Christie, Manson & Woods, Park Avenue at 59th Street, with the sale of 478 lots, and continues next week at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, where more than 900 lots go under the hammer in two sales.

title: Economic Scene
description: AN old folk saying goes, The bride is too beautiful, and that is how different judges are appraising the corporate profit figures released this week by the Government. Pretax profits showed a 26 percent gain for the fourth quarter of 1978 above the figure for the corresponding quarter a year earlier. In the fourth quarter, pretax profits surged $225 billion. After taxes, profits rose to an annual rate of $130.7 billion for a 25 percent gain.

title: Goodell Keeps Swimming Title
description: CLEVELAND. March 22  Brian Goodell of the University of California. Los Angeles, who won three titles in the National Collegiate swimming championships last year took his first step tonight toward another triple.

title: Huey Newton Jury Recesses
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 22 (AP) The jury in the murder trial of Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther Party leader, retired for the night without a verdict atter interrupting its deliberations to rehear a prosecution witness's testimony. Mr. Newton is accused of shooting a 17year old prostitute to death in 1974. Deliberations will resume tomorrow.

title: Ethics Panel Tentatively Agrees On a Hearing Date for Talmadge
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)  The Senate Ethics Committee tentatively agreed today to open hearings April 11 in its investigation of Senator Herman E. Talmadge. The Georgia Democrat's former wife, Betty, was expected to be the first witness.

title: Long Kurdish Struggle Now Focuses on Khomeini
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 22  The Kurds beat back the forces of Xenophon in 401 B.C. They fought the Romans, the Parthians, the ChriStian Crusaders and the Mongols. Both Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and his father knew enough about the Kurdish nature to favor placation whenever possible. Now it falls to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to reckon with the Kurds.

title: Lukens Acts to Bar Aid to Phoenix Steel
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 22 (AP) The Lukens Steel Company has filed suit in an attempt to block Federal aid to a competitor in the steel plate industry.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY. MARCH 22. 1979

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Mexico Treaty Goes to Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (Reuters) President Carter asked the Senate today to ratify a new extradition treaty with Mexico.

title: Anouilh Play Heads Park Slope Arts Fare
description: Theater, music and poetry will be part of the cultural fare served up this weekend in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: Great Canadian Oil To Expand Output
description: Great Canadian Oil Sands Ltd. announced that the Alberta government had approved its application to expand its synthetic crude oil production by 13,000 barrels a day. The current average daily production is 45,000 barrels Great Canadian Oil is 96.1 percent owned by the Sun Company of Radnor, Pa.

title: 8 Senate Republicans Attack Bell For Not Appointing a Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  Eight Republican Senators, including three Presidential candidates, took the Senate floor today to attack Attorney General Griffin B. Bell on his decision to name a special counsel rather than a special prosecutor in the Carter warehouse investigation.

title: Mondale Sees New Brazil Leaders
description: BRASILIA, March 22  Vice President Mondale met today with Brazil's new President, Gen. Joiio Baptista de Oliveira Figueiredo, in an effort to continue the recent improvement in relations, which deteriorated in the early months of the Carter Administration.

title: Music: Corigliano Poem
description: JOHN CORIGLIANO, whose Poem in October was performed by the Endymion Ensemble Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is an awardwinning American composer whose frankly eclectic, frankly tonal music includes concertos for piano, oboe and clarinet heard here over the last few years. Poem in October, written for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in 1970, is a 15minute setting of Dylan Thomas's poem of the same name, scored for tenor, flute, oboe, clarinet, string quartet and harpsichord.

title: Renault to Renovate Plants in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 22 (AP)The French auto maker Renault will invest $100 million over five years to modernize Argentine plants, currently crippled by a weeklong sitdown strike by workers demanding pay increases.

title: Man Seized at Nixon Estate
description: LOS ANGELES, March 22 (AP)  A 33yearold man accused of assaulting a Secret Service agent after he rammed his car through a gate at the estate of former

title: Air Travel Up Across Atlantic
description: GENEVA, March 22 (UPI)  Air traffic across the North Atlantic rose 11.2 percent in 1978 to 16.8 million passengers, the International Air Transport Association reported today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 22 Notre Dame, the twotime defending champion, and Wayne State, the favorite, qualified in all three weapons today at the 35th National Collegiate fencing championships, which are being held this year at Princeton University's Jadwin Gym.

title: 3 Nations Together On Energy
description: LA JOLLA, Calif.  The tinned States has a very high percapita consumption of energy as a result of our rapid industrial growth and a naive belief that supplies of energy would always be available. But this belief has peen shaken by Middle Eastern events.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 23, 1979

title: Hayes: 5 Years In Prison
description: DALLAS, March 22 (AP)  Bob Hayes, an Olympic gold medal winner and a former Dallas Cowboy allpro receiver, was sentenced to five years in prison today for selling cocaine to an undercover agent.

title: The City
description: Three armed men stole a delivery van containing men's and women's apparel valued at $75,000 from a garage on West 37th Street.

title: Money Supply Declines
description: After a fairly strong rise a week earlier, the nation's money supply reverted in the week ended March 19 to the declining trend that has prevailed since the turn of the year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

title: Traditional Italian Music at Casa Galicia
description: Traditional Italian music will be performed by more than 30 ItalianAmerican musicians and singers from the metropolitan area Sunday at 3 P.M. at Casa Galicia, 119 East 11th Street (between Third and Fourth Avenues).

title: WITNESSES DIE OFF, 1950'S SPY CASE ENDS
description: A 22yearold indictment charging Alfred K. Stern and Martha Dodd Stern with conspiracy to spy for the Soviet Union was dismissed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Art: A Perspective On Alfred Gottleib
description: FOR artists once eager to sever the ties that bound their art to the mundane data of the observable world, Freud's pioneering discovery  or should one say. his pioneering invention?  of the unconscious opened up a vast new territory, an unchartered land of infinite promise, mystery and romance. What a boon it proved to be to the artistic mind of the present century!

title: Hotel Plan for Atlantic City
description: An architect's rendering of the plans for the Ritz Hotel and Casino that was unveiled yesterday before the New Jersey Casino Control Commission. Arches and broad terraces above Boardwalk characterize new hotel's facade.

title: Byrne Doubts Pentagon Will Block Fort Dix Cuts
description: After an hourlong meeting with top Defense Department officials, Governor Byrne said this evening that the Army had recommended the transfer of all basic training operations out of Fort Dix in New Jersey and that he was now pessimistic that the Pentagon would reverse that position.

title: Venezuela Spending To Spur Oil Output
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Venezuela's new Christian Democratic Government, with oilexport income booming again, is backing a huge investment plan to increase oil production and refining.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overtheCounter.

title: New Gambling Authority Urged
description: HARTFORD, March 22  After months of growing concern about alleged irregularities in the state's gambling industry, a study was released today calling for a complete restructuring of the commission that regulates gambling.

title: Namibian Criticizes South Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22 A leader of an insurgent group in SouthWest Africa said today that South Africa was trying to wreck the United Nations plan for supervised elections in the territory because it wants to install a regime of quislings under Pretoria's control.

title: Albany Caucus Seeking Proviso On Aid for City
