description: ALBANY, March 22  Members of the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus are pressuring the Assembly's Democratic leadership to require that a proposed $70 million increase in state education aid to New York City be used to improve the city's schools rather than to close the city's budget gap, as Mayor Koch intends.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday incorrectly stated the date of record of a 32cent dividend declared by Citicorp. The dividend is payable May 1 to shareholders of record March 30.

title: Panel Drops Inquiry Into South Africa Bribery Charges
description: The House ethics committee quietly opened and closed a precautionary investigation of the South African bribery reports and found no violations of law by a member of the House of Representatives, according to the committee chairman.

title: No Heart at Economic Talks, Groups Say
description: When President Carter took his economic and energy advisers to Camp David on Monday, there were a lot of people left back in Washington pondering the old capital truism that what comes out of a meeting depends, in large measure on who is invited in the first place.

title: Callaghan Faces Key Test in Commons Next Week
description: LONDON, March 22  The life of the minority Labor Government of Prime Minister James Callaghan hung by a thread tonight after the Conservative Party introduced a motion of no confidence.Edinburgh and Cardiff. In Wales, the proposals were rejected by a margin of more than 4 to 1. and Welsh devolution is considered a dead issue for the immediate future.

title: Bangladeshis Slay Suspects
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 22 (AP) Villagers beat to death 9 of 12 alleged robbers at Keraniganj, three miles from here, the police said today. The police said the 12 opened fire when challenged yesterday, then took shelter in a house. When they exhausted their ammunition, the police said, the villagers beat them. Six died on the spot and three in a hospital. Three were captured.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor

title: For the Record
description: Several wells in North White Plains have been closed, pending tests to determine if the drinking water is contaminated by pesticides from a lawn and garden center that burned down over the weekend. The results are not expected for several days. ... A bulletproof vest saved a Conrail policeman from death or serious injury when he was shot by a gunman in a Jersey City railyard. Ronald Tedford, 25, of Hoboken, was struck in the chest by a gunshot. The slug bounced off the vest, and the officer suffered only a bruise.

title: St. Paul Chamber Group Does Copland and Haydn
description: Appearing at Lincoln Center this weekend with two eminent guests, the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra under Dennis Russell Davies will offer wellknown, rarely heard, recently found and newly fashioned works.

title: Former G.S.A. Aide Sentenced
description: BALTIMORE, March 22 (AP)  A former General Services Administration store manager who admitted accepting gifts from a supplier was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in prison for conspiring to defraud the Federal Government. Charles Carroll Lee, 45 years old, of Woodbridge, Va., former manager of the G.S.A. store in the General Accounting Office Building in Washington, had pleaded guilty in United States District Court to one count of conspiracy.

title: Dolphins Acquire Colzie
description: MIAMI, March 22 (AP) The Miami Dolphins traded a thirdround draft choice to the Oakland Raiders today for Neil Colzie, a cornerback and punt returner. Colzie, a Miami native who was the Raiders' firstround draft choice in 1975 out of Ohio State, set a National Football League record in 1976 for return yards.

title: Dow 861.31, Its Highest In 5 Months
description: With a notable absence of fanfare, the Dow Jones industrial average pushed ahead yesterday to its highest level in five months. It was a market characterized by small price advances rather than any outburst of group strength.

title: Deaths
description: MATTHEWSJean Flagler. The Officers and members of the Westchester Auxiliary of Youth Counseling League (formerly Youth Consultation Service) mourn the passing of their good friend. Jean F. Matthews. Mrs. Matthews was a tireless supporter of our agency and en inspiring leader of our auxiliary for well over 20 years. She will be sorely missed. We extend most heartfelt sympathy to her family.

title: Ruth Heyman, Collector Of Art and Civic Leader
description: Ruth Stein Heyman, a member of the board of the Columbia University Advisory Council, department of art history and archeology, died in her sleep yesterday at her home, 3 East 76th Street. She was 79 years old and also lived at High Hill. Armonk. N.Y.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  One of the paradoxes of this age of endless communications and negotiations that the people and even the negotiators and historians are often left in doubt about what happened.

title: Winton C. Hoch Is Dead at 73; Won 3 Cinematography Oscars
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., March 22 (UPI)  Winton C. Hoch, who won three Academy Awards for his cinematography, died at Santa Monica Hospital Tuesday from the effects of a stroke he suffered at his home. He was 73 years old.

title: Judge Bars Vote on UV By Sharon
description: Justice Arnold Fraiman of New York State Supreme Court ruled last night that the Sharon Steel Corporation may not vote at a UV shareholders meeting on Monday the 1 4 million shares of UV Industries that it purchased March 7 The meeting could result in the liquidation of UV Industries

title: New Zealand Gasoline Ban
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 22 (UPI)  New Zealand's ban on weekend sales of gasoline is resulting in significant savings, the Government announced today. An Energy Department spokesman said that during the third week of the ban, covering the period from 7 P.M. Friday to 6 A.M. Monday, demand for gasoline dropped 16.6 percent. The figures were based on a survey of the country's service stations.

title: Jean Flagler Matthews, Philharmonic Director
description: Jean Flagler Matthews, a member of the New York Philharmonic board of directors, died yesterday while vacationing in Hawaii. She was 68 years old and a resident of Rye, N.Y. and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Restaurants
description: JUST a few days go, a customer was overheard asking Aladar (Ali) Kende if his restaurant, the Green Tree, was a nonprofit enterprise. Considering the copious portions simple, hearty and delicious homestyle Hungarian food sold at Green Tree for incredibly low prices, it's easy to see how someone would get that impression.. But for the last 21 years, this pleasant, informal and lively restaurant on the corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 111th Street has made a profit, serving local residents, among them students and teachers from Columbia University and Barnard College, as well as the staffs of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and St. Luke's Hospital and Church.

title: A.P. and U.P.I. Name Peking Correspondents
description: Within a few days The Associated Press and United Press International will open the first two American news bureaus in Peking since 1949.

title: Mobil Bids $765 Million For General Crude Oil
description: The Mobil Corporation has formally joined the competition to acquire the General Crude Oil Company, offering its parent, the International Paper Company, $765 million.

title: Study Finds U.S. Air Service Grew in Year
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  The Civil Aeronautics Board, in its first major study of the airline indusry since the deregulation bill was passed last year, has found that service to communities of all sizes has grown significantly.

title: In Boston, What Is Quick, Crowded and Indispensable? The Shuttle
description: BOSTON, March 22  The first thing that any recent emigre here from New York acquires, aside from a bad cold, a good goosedown jacket and a trembling fear of Boston drivers, is a sudden appreciation for the BostonNew York air shuttle.

title: Brewer, Teamsters Union Settle
description: A threeyear agreement, announced this week, between Local 46 of the Teamsters Union and Preferred Distributing Corporation, a subsidiary of the F. & M. Schaefer Brewing Company, will provide for a reduction in the distribution crew through the payment of one week's pay for each year of service as an earlyretirement incentive, a spokesman for the union said yesterday. Under terms of the settlement the crew will be reduced from 435 to 350, he said. The pact provides for a $15 a week increase in the first year and $10 additional in both the second and third years. The former base pay rate was $282 a week, the spokesman said.

title: Florida Funds Accused by S.E.C.
description: A mutual fund complex in Coral Gables, Fla., has been accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of securities switching and other transactions that violated antifraud and other provisions of Federal securities laws.

title: Deaths
description: HEYMANRuth S. Congregation ErnanuEl of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member. Ruth S. Heyman. To her family & loved ones, we express our profound sympattry. May her memory be for an eternal blessing. Maxwell M. Rabb. President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Mattel Acquires Two Ice Shows
description: Mattel Inc. announced that its wholly owned subsidiary, Ringling BrothersBarnum & Bailey Combined Shows Inc., had acquired the business and assets of the traveling ice show operations of Shipstads & Johnson Ice Follies Inc. and Holiday on Ice Inc. from Wirtz Productions Ltd. of Chicago.

title: 37 Protesting Campus Employees Seized at Columbia
description: Scores of New York City policemen stormed two Columbia University buildings last night and arrested 37 demonstrators who had seized control of the facilities and disrupted the institution's payroll and computer operations in a labor dispute earlier yesterday.

title: ExCongressman Samuel Friedel; Represented Baltimore District
description: TOWSON, Md., March 22 (UPI)  Former Representative Samuel N. Friedel of Baltimore died of a heart attack in a Towson nursing home yesterday. He was 80 years old.

title: Deaths
description: HASSENFELDMerrIll L. The Counsel of Jewish Federations deeply mourns the death of Merrill L. Hassenteld. His leadership was superb in the quality of his intellect, the depth of his commitment, the maturity & wisdom of his ludgment, & It was universal in the range of his concerns in his own community & worldwide and In his lewish & total community responsibilties. His example, & his personal warmth and compassion, were an Inspiration to all who knew him. To his beloved wife Sylvia, & to his family, we extend our heartfelt condolences.

title: Bowery in Pact For Suburban
description: The New York and Suburban Federal Savings and Loan Association is to be merged into the Bowery Savings Bank under an agreement in principle that was announced yesterday.

title: Suspect in 7 Conrail Slayings Is Charged With Murdering 3 in Michigan
description: JACKSON, Mich., March 2.3  A three month search for the missing shotgun linked to the murder of three Conrail employees here on New Year's Eve has ended with the accidental discovery of the weapon under some park bushes.

title: T.V.A. Condemns Entry Of Oil Concerns Into Coal
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 23 The Tennessee Valley Authority, the nation's largest purchaser of coal, isued a report today condemning continued efforts by major oil companies to enter and dominate the nation's coal and uranium markets.

title: Mexico Screening Investors
description: MEXICO CITY, March 23  In contrast to the open door policy of some major oil producers, Mexico is carefully screening the potential foreign investors who are rushing here with the hope of sharing in the profits of the country's expected economic boom.

title: Oils Strong As Dow Loses 1.56
description: Oil issues pushed higher yesterday and several specialties in other groups produced large gains as the general market showed no decisive overall direction.

title: Deaths
description: HEYMANRuth. Jewish Community Center of White Plains records with sorrow the passing of its cherished member. Maurice Davis, Rabbi Lawrence H. Foster. Pres.

title: Louis Brockway, 82, Rubicam ExOfficer Headed 2 Ad Groups
description: Louis N. Brockway of Greenwich, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla., onetime chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies and of the Advertising Council, died yesterday of a stroke in his Delray Beach apartment. He was 82 years old.

title: Begin Lands at Kennedy, Sees No Delay in Signing
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel arrived in New York yesterday and said he did not expect lastminute details to be a serious obstacle to the peace treaty to be signed with Egypt on Monday.

title: Playoffs a Divorce Problem
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 23  The State Supreme Court, which is frequently called upon to decide weighty issues of law, was asked today to determine which member of a divorced couple had the right to use tickets for the impending New York Islander Stanley Cup playoff games.

title: Foes of Budget Curb See Hope in Montana Vote
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  Opponents of a constitutional convention to require balanced Federal budgets said today that they were encouraged by the surprise defeat of a resolution supporting such a move in the Montana Legislature yesterday.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Mr. Bell Escapes Jail
description: Thanks to a Federal Court of Appeals, Attorney General Griffin Bell will not have to go to jail for his refusal to divulge the files of informants who infiltrated and disrupted the Socialist Workers Party. We never thought he would or should be remanded to the custody of his own Bureau of Prisons for contempt of court, even though we agreed with Federal Judge Thomas Griesa that the files should be turned over to the party. Mr. Bell risked contempt because he saw it as the only way to get a definitive ruling on the underlying issue. There ought to be a better, less dramatic way to test the rights of office.

title: SENTENCE OF DEATH FOR BHUTTO UPHELD
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Saturday, March 24  Pakistan's Supreme Court today rejected an appeal to lift the death sentence against former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto.

title: RIAD QUITS AS HEAD OF THE ARAB LEAGUE
description: CAIRO, March 23  Mahmoud Riad, Secretary General of the Arab League for seven years, has resigned on the ground that the peace treaty to be signed Monday by Egypt and Israel has rendered impossible his efforts for Arab unity.

title: Men's Wear: A Casual Approach To the Rules of Fashion
description: He describes his men's clothes as Ivy League combined with the European sense of fashion. At 31, Alexander Julian is confident enough to strike down shibboleths such as, never break up a suit  you'll wear out the pieces.

title: Peking Exonerates 3 Who Attacked Party
description: HONG KONG, March 23  The three young men in their early 30's are not household names in the West, like Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn. But in China they are among the most celebrated political prisoners, having penned a devas tating wall poster of 77 pages in 1974 in which they denounced the Communist Party as a corrupt new privileged stratum that was governing without law or democracy.

title: Socialist Workers Ask $5 Million Settlement In Suit Against U.S.
description: The Socialist Workers Party announced a proposal yesterday for a $5 million settlement of its fiveyear, $40 million lawsuit charging Government agencies with illegally interrupting the party's activities.

title: Arrows Romp Over Fever, 147
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. March 23  Steve Zungul and Branko Segota set the pace for New York tonight as the Arrows defeated the Philadelphia Fever, 147, in the opening game of the twoofthree Major Indoor Soccer League championship series at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Deaths
description: BENNEYANMrs. Marion (Hall). Of Madison, Coon. Died March 23, 1979 at her home after a long illness. She was born in Plattsburgh, N.Y. and resided in White Plains, N.Y for most of her life before moving to Madison. She leaves her husband Arsen Benneyan, a sister Mrs. George L. Harvey and a brother Edward Hall, both of N.Y.C., a cousin Doris Corbett of Madison, and several nieces and nephews. Memorial services will be held at the First Congregational Church Chapel in Madison, Coon, at 2:00PM, Monday, March 16, 1979. Interment will be in the family plot in Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, N Y. at the convenience of the family. For furthur in. formation contact the Swan Funeral Home, (2031 2452488. Memorial contributions may be made to the Cancer Fund or the Madison NursinoAssociation, Madison, Conn.

title: James Newman Jr. Weds Miss Walker
description: Leslie Hailand Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Garfield Hailand Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill., was married in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church last evening to James Wilson Newman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Newman of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson, assisted by the Rev. Dr. William Hudnut, performed the ceremony.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) Federal judge, ignoring pleas that Cubans opposed to President Fidel Castro had been made scapegoats for the crime, sentenced two men to life imprisonment today for the murder of Orlando Letelier, a former Chilean Ambassador to the United States. Mr. Letelier and an assistant, Ronni Moffitt, died when bomb went off in their car on Sept. 21, 1976.

title: Columbia to Drop Charges Against 35
description: Columbia University announced yesterday afternoon that it would not press charges of criminal trespass against 35 demonstrators who were arrested late Thursday night after they seized the institution's computer and payroll facilities in a labor dispute.

title: Closing of 174 Stores Is Planned by A. & P.
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company announced yesterday that it would close 174 stores over the next two weeks, beginning immediately.

title: Floods, Gales and Snow Plague Midwest and Plains
description: Residents along flooding rivers in Illinois and Iowa yesterday erected sandbag barricades to save their homes while galeforce winds and blinding snows swept the Plains.

title: Kenny Rogers, Singer, Goes Country at Carnegie
description: Kenny Rogers's concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night left this writer mulling over a nagging question: Just what does going country mean? In Mr. Rogers's case, it certainly means money. Around two years ago, Kenny Rogers, pop singer, decided to become Kenny Rogers, country singer, and since that time he has sold millions of records and won numerous awards.

title: New Shops: Spring Tonic for Taste Buds
description: Along with the first budding crocuses and early forsythia, spring brings with it this year a trio of new specialty food shops. They are all on the Upper East Side and represent a wide range of choice and varying degrees of elaborateness.

title: Two Sniper Shootings Spur Someone to Help Police in South Bronx
description: It wasn't a major crime as crimes go in the bombedout heart of the South Bronx, the playground of muggers, arsonists, drug dealers and thugs of all description. A sniper with a gun, holed up in an unknown apartment, had shot a young man and a teenage girl, both in the back, in separate incidents as they they walked along a rubblestrewn, allbutforgotten street yesterday.

title: Winston Tong, Puppeteer, Puts Nijinsky in His La Mama Act
description: The rarefied artistry of Winston Tong is a coalescence of Oriental and Western theater. Mr. Tong, currently performing at La Mama, is a young San Francisco actor, author, director, designer and innovator who creates oneman chamber pieces that are as intimate as a shadow box and as resonant as a myth.

title: ModernArt Museum Reopens in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, March 23  With the motto See and Hear warning visitors not to expect the traditionally hushed atmosphere of a museum retreat, the Museum of Contemporary Art inaugurated its expanded and redesigned quarters this evening with an extravagant display of light and sound.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 24, 1979

title: Pearl Primus Offering Program Of Dance Called Earth Theater
description: Pearl Primus is too wellknown a name in the history of black theatrical dance to need a lengthy introduction. Her reputation as a pioneer in this field, particularly in recreating the dances of Africa from authentic sources, has obviously stood strong despite her own absence as a concert performer for many years.

title: Magazine Overruled in Objections on Bomb Article
description: MILWAUKEE, March 23  A Federal District Court judge today overruled The Progressive magazine's objections to the suppression of a number of affidavits and other documents it had filed to support its contention that all the material in an article it intends to publish on the hydrogen bomb is in the public domain.

title: Your Money
description: WITH the Government's recent clampdown on the amount of interest that banks and savings and loan associations an pay on the popular savings certificates linked to Treasury bill rates, the Treasury bills themselves look more attractive than before.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON JOHN J. MEDICO JR., a professional engineer in Sarasota, Fla., was granted a patent this week for a solar window that both heats and cools, with adjustable veins and pipes for air and water. Many of the windows, and the related system of collecting and dissipating energy, are to be incorporated in a condominium of 176 apartments now under construction in Sarasota.

title: Philip Bourneuf 71
description: Philip Bourneuf, an important character actor who appeared on the Broadway stage, in films and on television, was found dead in his Santa Monica, Calif., apartment yesterday. He was 71 years old and lived alone. The actor was seen on stage as recently as two years ago, in a production of Hamlet staged in Tucson. Ariz.

title: 12Hour Shifts Required Of Most Transit Officers
description: Most of the city's transit police oficers have been working 12hour shifts on mandatory daily overtime, every day since last Monday when the city began crackdown on subway crime.

title: If You've Ever Falsified A Job Rsum, Read This Article
description: After the recent dismissal of The New York Times and WCBSAM weather forecaster because he had misrepresented his academic credentials, friends urged me to write down this far from unique 12yearold story:

title: Sindona Enters Not Guilty Plea
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, pleaded not guilty yesterday to a fraud indictment in the Federal District Court in Manhattan and remained free on bail.

title: Emigrant Absorbs Prudential Savings
description: The Prudential Savings Bank, which suffered a $4.99 m?? last year, was merged, into if?? grant Savings Bank at t?? business yesterday. It was the ?? est merger ever to have taken plac among savings banks.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 23, 1979

title: Edward A. Maher Is Dead at 80; Founded an Oil Company on L.I.
description: Edward A. Maher, the founder of an oil company, died Thursday at his home in Garden City, L.I. He was 80 years old.

title: RETURNING MARINE COULD FACE DEATH
description: NAHA, Okinawa, March 23 (AP) Pfc. Robert R. Garwood, a marine accused of collaborating with the enemy in the war in Vietnam, could be sentenced to death if convicted on preliminary charges pending against him, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

title: Rail Cuts in New England Denounced by Legislators
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 23 State legislators from Massachusetts and Connecticut began a joint effort here today to oppose plans by the Department of Transportation that would curtail passenger rail service throughout New England despite recent efforts to revitalize it.

title: Russian Sets Swimming Mark
description: MOSCOW, March 23 (UPI)  Vladimir Salnikov of Leningrad set a world record in 800meter freestyle swimming today, clocking 7 minutes 56.43 seconds in the first 800 meters of a 1,500meter event in Minsk, according to Tass, the Soviet news agency. The time lowered the record of 8:01.54 set by Bobby Hackett of the United States in 1976.

title: Notes on People
description: It was a lovely spring day, the happy talk of an IsraeliEgyptian peace treaty was in the air, and so yesterday seemed a fitting time for a lunch at Le Perigord marking publication of Peace, Dtente & SovietAmerican Relations, public statements by Leonid Brezhnev, leader of the Soviet Union.

title: Events Today
description: TIPTOES, book by Guy Bolton, music by Mr. Botton and Fred Thompson, lyrics by Ira Gershwin, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, downtown Brooklyn.8.

title: Table Settings, a Comedy Of a Modern Jewish Family
description: In Table Settings, James Lapine plunks down solidly and in stage center his comic stereotypes about the life of a modern Jewish family. Then he proceeds to create some lively variations around them.

title: Mount Vernon Five in Final
description: ROCHESTER, March 23  Mount Vernon, the defending champion, advanced to the New York State AAA scholastic basketball tournament final by defeating Shaker High of Latham, N.Y., 5949, tonight at the War Memorial Auditorium. The victory was the 25th for Coach Tony Fiorentino's ream against only one loss

title: Deaths
description: MELVEN Helen B. Of Bellmore and Florida on March 12, 1979 atter a long illness. Services were held at the C. S. Bartholomew & Son Funeral Home, Inc., Bellmore. Interment Greenfield Cemetery, Hempstead.

title: Race at Aqueduct Provides A Record Quinella Payoff
description: Quinella wagering, one of the subjects of dispute when the parimutuel clerks went on strike at Aqueduct Race Track on Feb. 15, came into particular focus at the Big A yesterday. A payoff of $478.20 for a $2 quinella bet provided a track record for that form of betting since it was introduced in February.

title: Music and Sunshine Enliven a Springtime New York
description: Joan Mondale, top, wife of the Vice President, was serenaded by Conjunto Folkorico as she visited St. Ann's Church in the Bronx yesterday. But the city opened its arms to everyone, with balmy temperatures as high as 68 degrees. A student at Columbia kicked off her shoes and studied outside. And street musicians made Fifth Avenue a more inviting place to sit and bask in the sun. Alas, rain and cooler temperatures are forecast for the weekend.

title: Hudson's Bay Directors Battle Thomson's Bid
description: TORONTO, March 23  Kenneth Thomson, the Canadian newspaper owner, appears to face a fight in his bid for control of the Winnipegbased Hudson's Bay Company, one of Canada's largest departmentstore chains.

title: Chris Evert, Miss Wade Ousted
description: Chris Evert's winter of disarray ended uncermoniously last night with another defeat, this time to Dianne Fromholtz, 62, 63, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Food and Fuel Costs Led Index in New York Area
description: A second straight month of steppedup inflation afflicted New Yorkarea shoppers in February, with sharply rising meat and fuel prices pushing up the Consumer Price Index close to 1 percent last month, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Aluminum Shortfall Seen
description: Roy A. Gentles, president of the Alean Aluminum Corporation, the American subsidiary of Canada's Alean Alumimum Ltd., predieted in a speech yesterday that the demand for alumimum would exceed supple by about million tons in North America by 1983

title: Fuel Bills Hurt Business, L.I. Florist Says
description: BAYVILLE, L.I., March 21  If I had to do it. all over again, I wouldn't open a flower shop with an attached greenhouse, said Alan Tebaldi, searching through the winter fuel bills that he said had come close to putting him out of business.

title: Books of The Times; Through a Bottle Darkly
description: FEMALE COMPLAINTS. By Sarah Stage. Illustrated. 304 pages. W.W. Norton. $10.95

title: High Inflation: Carter Options
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  Once again, the news about prices is bad and both economists and political critics have questioned President Carter's ability to manage the economy. As the Consumer Price Index jump of 1.2 percent for February made painfully plain, inflation has been raging even faster than the President's advisers ex pected, and they did expect some acceleration.

title: Leaders of Uganda Exiles Meeting As Invasion Effort Seems to Wane
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 23  Leaders of Ugandan exile groups, which have repeatedly squabbled and splintered in recent years, were scheduled to meet in northern Tanzania today in an effort to settle their differences and come up with a common strategy for overthrowing President Idi Amin.

title: Bernstein Role as Operating Head Of H.R.A. Is to Be Ended by Koch
description: Blanche Bernstein, the city's Human Resources Administrator, was told by Mayor Koch yesterday that she was being removed as operating head of the agency, but that she could remain in her present position with greatly reduced powers if she wanted to.

title: EXPORT OF URANIUM TO INDIA APPROVED
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted today to approve the export of 18.5 tons of slightly enriched uranium to fuel the Tarapur atomic power station near Bombay, India.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: AMSTERDAM, March 23 (AP) NationaleNederlanden N.V., the largest insurance company in the Netherlands, formally announced today that it would offer to acquire all the stock of the National Life Insurance Company of Georgia for $360 million.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: With Peace, Egyptians Long for Plenty
description: CAIRO, March 23  Abdel Gawad Minshadi, a Cairo streetcleaner in a faded blue tunic, rested for a moment on his long straw broom and daydreamed about better times ahead.

title: Zambian Policeman Turns Thief
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 23 (AP)  A Zambian policeman shot and killed two people, seriously injured two others, there grabbed the $24,300 payroll he was escorting for the Lusaka City Council, authorities said today. The robbery took place yesterday 20 miles south of Lusaka.

title: Canadian Industry Draws Fire in Study
description: OTTAWA, March 23  The conventional view of Canada as an advanced industrial nation has been jolted by one of its most prestigious official bodies, the Science Council, whose latest report talks of a massive failure of the country's industrial systems.

title: U.S. Abandons Rights. Case Against ExPoliceman
description: The Department of Justice announced yesterday that it was abandoning plans to seek another trial for William L. Walker, a former New York City police officer who had been charged with murder in the shooting death of a black college student in Brooklyn in 1973.

title: Focusing on Neighborhoods
description: With a voluminous final report to President Carter, the National Commission on Neighborhoods has completed its mission. Created by Congress in 1977, it was supposed to suggest strategies for reviving urban neighborhoods while preserving a place for the poor and elderly who might otherwise be squeezed out by middleincome homesteaders.

title: Now or Never on a Convention Center
description: Governor Carey and New York's legislative leaders have announced agreement on a plan for financing the New York Convention Center, now priced at $375 million. Comptroller Edward Regan promptly complained that the method would circumvent usual requirements for a referendum of the state's voters. A more basic question is whether the convention center is still a good investment.

title: U.S. Plan Eases Rail Restraints
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The Carter Administration announced legislation today to give more freedom to railroads to merge, to set their own rates and to provide changes in service without the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Two Plead In Trust Case
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 23 (AP) Executives of two major offshore oil construction companies entered no contest pleas to antitrust charges today and agreed to cooperate in the continuing Federal investigation of bid rigging and price fixing.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, the view of Senator Edward M. Kennedy on jurisdiction over trucking deregulation legislation was misstated in Business Day on Thursday. The Senator said the Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation had sole jurisdiction over the substantive subject matter of motor carrier regulation.

title: The City
description: Carmine Galante, the 70yearold reputed organizedcrime leader, was released on $50,000 bail late yesterday from the Metropolitan Correctional Facility at Foley Square after the United States Parole Commission failed to conduct a hearing within the time limit set by a Federal judge.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: POST ANTIQUITIES Mention Greek art and thoughts go back to 5000 and 3000 B.C. and Venus de Milo, the Colossus of Rhodes and Aphrodite of Knidos, for example, come to mind. But living Greek artists are, of course, still producing art  there and here.

title: Deaths
description: Co??Joseph E. Beloved husband of C?? Devoted father of Jerome J., and Ro??ynn Gelles and Susan Scher. Loving grandfather. Services Monday 11:30AM The River??de, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Carter Wants Palestinian Tie, Calls P.L.O. a Problem
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  President Carter said today that the United States wanted direct relations with Palestinians living under Israeli occupation but found it a problem to deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Yankees Defeat Mets, 93
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23  It means nothing now, being two and 12, Reggie Jackson was saying before the game. In the last 10 days of spring training, it'll come together for the Yankees. Bob Lemon will crack the whip. Peer pressure win be felt. We might even get It going tonight.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 23, 1979

title: Election Fever Pushes London Stocks Higher
description: London, March 23 (Reuters)  Investors bought millions of pounds worth of shares in the City of London today as election fever gripped the stock market.

title: The Region
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J.  Police services will continue in Victory Gardens, according to Morris County's Prosecutor, Peter Manahan, even if that tiny borough is forced to dismiss all municipal workers April 1 because voters have rejected any higher taxes to pay for a $50,812 budget deficit.

title: 2 WOMEN AND CHILD ARE SLAIN IN JERSEY
description: Two women and a fiveyearold boy were found dead with their throats slashed last night in the Fair Lawn, N.J., house where all three lived, the Bergen County Prosecutor's office said last night.

title: Merola and The News Seek Open Pretrial Hearing
description: The Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, and lawyers for The Daily News filed papers yesterday with the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan in an effort to compel a Bronx judge to permit the public to attend a pretrial hearing in a murder case.

title: City Opera Presents Premiere of Miss Havisham's Fire
description: The New York City Opera added another statistic to its history Thursday night. With its performance of Dominick Argento's Miss Havisham's Fire, the company now has 17 world premieres and 13 commissions to its credit. The opera was conducted by Julius Rudel, who on June 30 will step down as director of the company he has headed for so many years. Beverly Sills, his successor, was in the audience Thursday night.

title: North Dakota Six Reaches Final
description: DETROIT, March 23  Favored North Dakota defeated Dartmouth, 42, at the Olympia tonight to advance to the National Collegiate hockey championship game tomorrow night against Minnesota.

title: Illinois House Votes to Restrict Police Searches of Newsrooms
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 23 (AP) A measure that its sponsor says would limit searches of newsrooms and reporters homes has been approved by the Illinois House, which heeded pleas that the Legislature should protect freedom of the press.

title: Walter Legge, Record Producer And Founder of Orchestra, Dies
description: Walter Legge, an influential recording executive who founded the Philharmonia Orchestra of London in 1945 and husband of Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, died Thursday of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home at St. JeanCap Ferrat, on the southern coast of France. He was 72 years old.

title: Nets Lose Twice on Same Night
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 23  Jack McMahon, the 76ers assistant coach, pointed at the tired group of Philadelphia players, some resting on the floor, in the dressing room tonight, and said:

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 24.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M TO 4.30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900, WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500, SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691000 CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Once More For the Money
description: HIALEAH, Fla., March 23  Grover G. Delp, called Buddy, is a chubby man with apple cheeks and no especial gift for silence. He has worked with thoroughbreds for 24 of his 46 years, and he was saying that when he watched Secretariat win the Laurel Futurity in 1972 he told himself, That is the best horse I ever saw.

title: Business Records
description: BANRUPTCY PROCEEDINGA

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Consumer prices rose 1.2 percent in February, or at an annual rate of 15.4 percent, the Labor Department reported. The increase was the largest for any month since August 1974. The gain in February was led by big increases in food, beverage, housing and transportation costs, including a substantial jump in gasoline prices. [Page 1.] The rise in consumer prices has major implications for President Carter's antiinflation policies. [1.]

title: Schlesinger on Gas Costs
description: WASHINGTON. March 23 (UPI) Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger warned American motorists today that the price of gasoline was likely to soar to more than $2 a gallon over the next 10 years. His forecast came in Congressional testimony on a Government proposal to develop a fuelsaving automobile.

title: Billy Carter Is Not Alcoholic but Abuser, Doctor Says
description: AMERICUS, Ga., March 23  Billy Carter's personal physician said today that in his opinion Mr. Carter is not an alcoholic in that he is neither psychologically nor physically dependent on alcohol.

title: Letter: On Jobless Youth
description: To the Editor:

title: DUTCH LACK CLUES IN SLAYING OF ENVOY
description: THE HAGUE, March 23  Despite an intensive international manhunt, the Dutch police said tonight that they had no cluesor leads in the murder of the British Ambassador, who was slain at his home here yesterday morning.

title: Old Dominion, Louisiana Tech Gain
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 23Old Dominion's 25point halftime lead over the University of California, Los Angeles, dwindled to 4 points with 46 seconds to play tonight, but the Lady Monarchs held on to defeat the Bruins 8782, in the semifinals of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women basketball tournament at the Greensboro Coliseum.

title: Helping the Developing Nations to Help Themselves
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  Science and technology are seen increasingly as critical components of a development strategy for all countries, whatever their stage of economic growth. This is particularly evident for the developing countries, which need their own capability to select and adapt technology for their needs and to overcome the knowledge barriers to development.

title: City Police Get a New Chief of Patrol Services
description: Chief William R. Bracey, 58, got a big hug from grandchildren, William and Lisa, at Police Headquarters in Manhattan yesterday as he was named chief of patrol services. It is the secondhighest uniformed position in the department. Chief Bracey joined the force in 1946. Mayor Koch praised him by saying, You will be a role model and a tough act to follow for aspiring black New York police officers and all members of the force.

title: MidMarch Auto Sales In Decline
description: DETROIT, March 23 (UPI)  The nation's three largest automobile manufacturers reported today that sales of new cars declined nearly 13 percent in midNlarch from the record levels achieved in the yearearlier period.

title: Trade Bill Snag Seen in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI)Trade legislation regarded by the Administration as vital to a new world trade agreement faces trouble in the Senate, where several Republicans may use it as a vehicle for a controversial tax amendment.

title: White House Asks Dinner Donations
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The White House is inviting up to 20 major American corporations to contribute $5,000 each to help defray the costs of the state dinner and other events celebrating the signing of the IsraeliEgyptian peace treaty on Monday.

title: Radio
description: 8.9 A.M., WNCN. Sonetto 123 del Petraca, No. 6, Liszt; The Banks of Green Willow, Butterworth; Sonata in D. Leclair; Concerto for 3 Pianos No. 2, Bach.

title: Stutterer
description: No matter where he looks he jumps to his own breath, semiconscious in Xhosa semiliterate in Afrikaans news, his remembrance of English editorials he is forced to read.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, March 25 GUGLIELMO MARCONI (Italian Line Cruises International). Left St. Themes March 21; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Legislators Plan More Reductions In Budget Requests Urged by Carey
description: ALBANY, March 22Legislative staff members prepared today further cuts in Governor Carey's budget requests in an effort to find more money for the state's local governments and school districts.

title: Elk City: Fond of Carter, Unimpressed
description: ELK CITY, Okla., March 23  The Barbecue Rib Ranch was filling up with a lunchtime crowd of farmers and oil workers, accountants and car salesmen. In the kitchen, Robert Dedmon was tilling up their plates with spareribs and smoked sausage and talking about Jimmy Carter.

title: Coan Takes 200Yard Freestyle
description: CLEVELAND. March 23  When Andy Coan of Tennessee lost his 50yard freestyle title last night in the National Collegiate swimming championships, he was angry at himself.

title: FEBRUARY'S RISE 1.2%
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The United States suffered the most rapid burst of inflation in four and onehalf years last month, Government figures showed today, dealing a fresh blow to consumers and to the beleaguered priceandwage guidelines program of the Carter Administration.

title: Shavers Stops Norton in First (1:58) Round
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 23From the middle of the ring, Earnie Shavers's manager, Frank Luca, was waving to Ken Norton, who was being escorted through the crowd. C'mon, Kenny, he was yelling. C'mon Kenny. And before the first round ended, Shavers said goodbye to Norton with a knockout after only 1 minute 58 seconds.

title: Bell Increases Curran's Authority To Examine Carter Business Loans
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The full powers of a special prosecutor were given to Paul J. Curran today in the charter of his authority to investigate some $7 million in loans to President Carter's family peanut warehouse business.

title: 150 Radical Youths Riot in Paris After a March by 60,000 Workers
description: PARIS, March 23  Sixtythousand workers marched through Paris today protesting unemployment and Government plans to reduce the number of workers in much of the ailing steel industry. The demonstration ended with 150 radical youths rampaging, looting and fighting with the police in the worst violence here since the student riots of May 1968.

title: Right  Wing Terrorism Is Sweeping Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA CITY  A campaign of death threats and streetcorner assassinations directed against Guatemalan opposition politicians, labor leaders and university professors appears aimed at crushing the first mass movement that this country has known in 25 years.

title: A MarxistTurnedCapitalist Finds the Bottom Line Too Low
description: Tote that barge, life that bale, secure better financing, or lose that sale.

title: Vietnam Oil Search Faltering
description: SINGAPORE, March 23  After a fouryear lapse, exploration for oil has begun again off the coast of Vietnam in one of the last of Asia's large unexplored offshore regions. But the search for oil, which Vietnam's battered economy desperately needs, has gotten off to a poor start.

title: Seizing an Opportunity To Turn an Honest Yen, Mark and Franc
description: President Carter has proposed aiding the national economy by eliminating the United States Travel Service, the Federal tourist program, which is currently funded at a laughably inadequate $14 million, equivalent to two cents of every $100 overseas visitors spent here last year. Eliminating this is roughly analagous to cutting the cost of raising carrots through not buying carrot seed.

title: No Doubt Who's in Charge On Sunstruck Spanish Isle
description: IBIZA, Spain  On election day early in March, it rained on this pleasant little Mediterranean island, and the taxis disappeared from the town of Ibiza and set off into the countryside to carry people to the polls.

title: Phelps Rejected U.C.L.A. Offer
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 23 Richard (Digger) Phelps, the basketball coach at the University of Notre Dame, turned down an offer to become head coach at the University of California, Los Angeles, more than a month ago, an official of the athletic department at Notre Dame said today.

title: Ziff Completes Rust Craft Takeover
description: Rust Craft Greeting Cards Inc. said its acquisition by the Ziff Corporation for a total of about $89 million had been completed. As previously announced, Ziff, a privately held magazine publisher, has acquired the greeting card part of Rust Craft's business for $33.75 a share.

title: Dr. K. W. Mildenberger Of Language Group, 57
description: Dr. Kenneth W. Mildenberger, deputy executive secretary and treasurer for the Modern Language Association of America, died Thursday of cancer at Huntington Hospital on Long Island. He was 57 years old and lived in Northport, L.I.

title: Harsco Acquisition
description: The Harsco Corporation announced an agreement to acquire Fairmont Railway Motors of Fairmont, Minn., in exchange for 550,000 shares of Harsco common stock. The transaction is valued at more than $16 million.

title: Korean Air to New York
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 23 (AP)  Korean Air Lines will begin passenger service three times a week between Seoul and New York next Thursday, the Korean carrier announced today.

title: Cruyff Seen Renewing Cosmos Contract Talks
description: One of the few remaining outstanding soccer stars that the Cosmos have not signed, Johan Cruyff of the Netherlands, will come to New York in a few weeks on other business, but he also is expected to resume contract talks with the soccer team.

title: Holmes Stops Ocasio in 7th, Retains Heavyweight Title

It is well to remember, dear history reader, that Bach did not know he was a Baroque composer.

title: JAPANESE STRUGGLE WITH BRIBE SCANDAL

title: IN BRIEF
description: The Federal Reserve Board is planning a step toward interstate branching, which is now banned by Federal law. Banks are restricted to fullscale operations only within their home states, although they are permitted to maintain subsidiaries elsewhere strictly for conducting international business. The Fed's proposal, which could be implemented within weeks, would permit American banks, through subsidiaries, to provide full banking services throughout the country to any customers whose business is predominantly international. The plan would enable large banks from the nation's financial centers to compete far more effectively for business from internationally oriented customers.

description: WASHINGTON  I 'm one of those small savers who is being robbed by the Federal Government, said 75yearold Hilda Cloud, pointing to herself with a hand as gnarled as an old oak tree.

Long Island has also had a phantom road that has been listed on road signs ana maps as the Nassau Expressway, but, in fact, has never been built. Hownrer, at long last, one of the phantoms is coming to life.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Can We Afford SALT?

Nothing to do, for example, with a Soviet interest in expanded influence or control over Western Europe, northern Asia or the Middle East. In this new, SALT is about each side's spendrig for forces to destroy the other's population in retaliation for a nuclear attack on its homeland or longrange fluclear forces. Can't both sides cut such spending? Each side, it is said, :an kill the other's population many titnes. Isn't the ability to kill them just Dnce enough?

description: WASHINGTON  After meeting Defense Secretary Harold R. Brown to discuss Israel's high priority needs for tanks, armored personnel carriers and advanced deliveries of F16 fighter planes, Ezer Weizman, Israel's defense minister, stepped into the hallway outside Mr. Brown's Pentagon office last week and said firmly: People probably wonder why is it that on the eve of a peace treaty signature we talk about the military so much. I believe that nothing keeps and defends the peace better than a welldefended country.

The Triggering Town consists of Lectures and Essays on Poetry and Writing, and every page reads like a man talking, a man who celebrates, blames, remembers, argues, praises and reveals. We listen, alternately nodding and shaking our heads, always aware of one man's voice.

title: Letter TO THE EDITOR
description: J. Robert Oppenheimer's evaluation of Albert Einstein's productivity in later life ['his earlier tradition as a master of physics had failed him], as quoted in Celebrating Einstein (by William Stockton, Feb. 18) brings to mind a story told me by Prof. Eric M. Rogers, who lived next door to Professor Einstein in Princeton. While at the Rogerses for dinner one evening, Professor Einstein spotted a little puzzle of the kind that presents no problems to physicists. He quickly solved it and then put it down without comment. As he left that night, he asked if he could borrow the puzzle. A few days later, he appeared at the Rogerses door, holding the puzzle in front of him, and with a big smile on his face, announced: Oppie couldn't do it!

title: Triumphs and Symptoms
description: THE unfolding drama of Virginia Woolf's inner world, as reflected in her letters, reaches a moment in this newest volume when she has triumphed over her disasters family deaths, breakdowns, four years of war. Her climb to literary eminence has been hard and slow. She is famous. She can speak with the assurance of her reputation and with complete mastery of her modulated ironic mockery. There is less hesitation, less tergiversation, and there are fewer pirouettes. She is crisp, incisive, always to the point and penetrating in her grasp of human behavior and human expression. She has stirred the women's world into new awareness with A Room of One's Own, and she writes that she is writing The Waves to a rhythm and not to a plot. She calls this inspired elegiac novel a stunt book and a barren and frigid experiment ... Virginia hanging to a trapeze by her toe nails. The public doesn't agree; 10,000 copies are sold right off. Within her triumphs there exists a lingering insecurity; symptoms remain  headaches, mood swings, faintings, depression. She cannot completely siphon off into her art her deep pool of grief, rage, shame, guilt, the components of her melancholy and her genius. But she knows what she is doing. As an experience madness is terrific ... and in its lava I still find most of the things I write about.

title: Argentina May Accept Inspection of Atom Projects
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 24  Argentina, which has refused to sign the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, would consider accepting fullscope international inspection of its nuclear facilities under certain conditions, the head of its Atomic Energy Commission said yesterday.

title: Amin, Living by the
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Like the Prophet Mohammed, who sacrificed his life and his property for the good of Islam, I am ready to die for my country. The quotation over Radio Uganda, attributed to the PresidentForLife, was typically melodramatic and grandiose. But it went to the heart of question that preoccupied Africa last week: Is Idi Amin, who human rights organizations estimate is responsible for the murder of 300,000 of his countrymen, on the way out?

Pete Rose was hunkered down beside the batting cage when Pat Corrales, manager of the Texas Rangers, walked up, leading a minor league shortstop named Chester Wayne Pinkerton. description: The 26th running of the Distaff Handicap proved an easy touch for John Grodin's consistent Skipat at Aqueduct yesterday. The 5yearold daughter of Jungle Cove triumphed over nine rivals in the $54,200, sixfurlong event by six lengths.

title: Tales of Two Wars
description: TO anyone who has read very much of the voluminous literature on World War I, from A Farewell to Arms, Goodbye to All That and All Quiet on the Western Front to Paul Fussell's The Great War and Modern Memory, Phillip Rock's The Passing Bells will seem disturbingly familiar. I say disturbingly familiar not in the sense that the novel lacks originality  although thematically there is very little that such readers will not have encountered elsewhere  but in the sense that, no matter how often the contemporary audience may have contemplated that event, so skillful and engaging a narrative as Mr. Rock has written retains capacity to shock, to astonish and to engage.

title: On Language
description: Everyone who cares about the use of language is faced sooner or later with this problem: When the person you are talking to makes a mistake in grammar, or pronounces aword mistakenly, do you interrupt with a correction? Or would such a correction be seen as a putdown, the action of a wiseguy? Or would failure to correct be taken as agreement with the mistake?

description: IT SEEMS like the ultimate paradox. At one time, high prices for homes, high interest rates and everincreasing downpayment requirements might have cooled buyers demands for homes. However, today's buyers, who have accepted inflation as a permanent condition of life, want to purchase now, not tomorrow or next year.

title: WOLD'S TEAM VICTOR IN NORFOLK BRIDGE

At the end of six days of intense competition that featured virtually all the top players in North America, victory in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team championship of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals went to Eddie Wold of Houston, Mark Lair of Canyon, Tex., Cliff Russell of Miami, Richard Freeman and Lou Bluhm of Atlanta, and Tom Sanders of Nashville.

title: Putting Federal Brakes on Energy Use in Buildings
description: Much as the Federal government gave highway traffic a speed limit to cut gasoline consumption, it is planning to give new buildings an energy budget to put a limit on the amount of gas, oil and electricity that they are designed to consume.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: The material covered here ranges from the familiar to the genuinely interesting. (Does any child these days really believe cats have nine lives? On the other hand, haven't you always been told that raccoons washed their food?) Each piece of traditional lore is stated on one page and is labeled Fact or Fable on the overleaf. The real charm of the book is Diane de Groat's illustrations, cozily Beatrix Potterish for the fables, filled with natural details for the facts. If youngsters read this one more than once, it will be to giggle at the archer fish decked out with bow and arrow or the seducer snake villainously charming his little pigeon (the pun is the illustrator's) over a champagne bucket.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Last November Arthur Miller visited China with his, wife, the photographer Inge Morath. He had no thought of doing a book about it, but then, Mr. Miller told a reporter over the telephone, I began to meet and interview theater people, artists, poets, filmmakers. Some hadn't surfaced for 15 years and there had been no opportunity for them to talk to foreigners.

That people who have gone through a dozen years of schooling should not know where the Constitutional Convention was held or when Fort Sumter was fired on is of little moment; that they should have only the vaguest notion of the meaning of the Bill of Rights or the causes of the Civil War is a discouraging fact in a democracy.

title: From Vietnam To Yemen
description: WASHING; ON  Is the Vietnam era over? Do we really understand it? The war was a disaster. Vast amounts of blood and treasure brought no success in the 1960's, yet Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson continually increased the effort. Conventional wisdom says that they could not have realized what they were doing: Expectations of winning must have deluded them each time they escalated, advisers must have deceived them, they couldn't have foreseen that Vietnam would be a morass, or they flimflammed the American people. This view is comforting. It suggests that reforming the policymaking process would prevent future fiascos. But the conventional wisdom is false.

These are the major features of the overhaul of the Guaranteed Student Loan Program that is being proposed to Congress by two New Jersey legislators.
