title: SPORTS
description: MILFORD YOU have to believe in winning to believe in Muriel Grossfeld's School of Gymnastics. You have to believe in the ideals of competition, of youngsters knocking themselves out to become the best gymnasts in the world, the best gymnasts ever. You have to believe in exposing gifted children to the pressures of failing in public, of mental fatigue and of physical wear and tear and possible injury. You have to believe in gymnastics. But, most of all, you have to believe in winning at all cost.

title: A Dispute Over Releasing Funds Mires Federal Investigation of 175 Alleged Nazi War Criminals in
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  The Government's investigation of the estimated 175 alleged Nazi war criminals living in this country is mired in a complicated battle between Congress and the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: GARDENING
description: WHEN the forsythia blooms, prune the roses. This signal is one of the most reliable timetables nature provides. For the opening of the forsythia flowers indicates that the growing season is beginning.

title: Novel in A Novel
description: JOHN WAIN and Kingsley Amis. whose first novels, Hurry on Down and Lucky Jim, came out the same year, 1953, formed the most considerable part of the not particularly wellnamed Angry Young Man group in postwar English letters. They attended the same Oxford College and came from similar middle or lowermiddleclass backgrounds, though Mr. Wain is a Midlander and Mr. Amis is from the Greater London area. Both began by supporting themselves as illpaid English lecturers at provincial universities and then became fulltime professional writers after establishing themselves with the reading public. And both have been quite versatile and complete writers in that they write excellent poetry and criticism along with their novels and short stories.

title: A Happy Ending to a Worldwide Drama
description: THE state's Public Broadcasting Authority turned its recent search for a new executive director into a worldwide drama worthy of serialization, and then came up with a happy ending by picking a New Jersey resident for the job.

title: Inflation Hits a 4Year Peak
description: Sharply higher prices for food, housing and gasoline pushed consumer pnces up 1.2 percent in February, the biggest monthly increase in inflation in four and a half years. The rise in the Consumer Price Index  15.4 percent on an annual basis  represented more disappointing news for the Administration's battered antiinflation program.

title: Trees That Decorate The Island Scene
description: SMALL flowering trees are valuable assets in our landscape. They are large enough to be used alongside a large twostory house but small enough not to dwarf a low ranch home. They will fit nicely into the narrow planting area between sidewalk and street where a fullsized tree might eventually become too large and heave the sidewalk.

title: SHAKING THE BRICKS AT THE F.B.I.
description: Neil J. Welch, new director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York, jumped to his feet from a chair in his conference room and strode to the door of his adjoining office. Workmen were still putting things to rights there following the relocation of F.B.I. headquarters from East 69th Street to 26 Federal Plaza in downtown New York. Only Welch's massive desk was in place, a lone brick sitting on top of it.

title: Recycling: A Simple Solution
description: IN 1978, the 44,000 residents of Montclair recycled 1,700 tons of paper, glass and aluminum, earning a net profit of $16,500. In addition, the town saved $17,000 in collection and disposal costs, resulting in a $33,500 gain from recycling.

title: Testing Out Two Pocket Electronic Translators
description: DO YOU TAKE CREDIT CARDS? I asked my dining companion, a pocketsize computertranslator resting on the table top of the German restaurant where I had just finished lunch.

title: Paper Says Ford's Campaign Got South African Funds
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sunday, March 25  The Sunday Express of Johannesburg published a frontpage article today citing allegations, for which it offered no supporting evidence, that the South African Government secretly contributed up to 3.4 million rand  $3.9 million at prevailing rates of exchangeto former President Gerald R. Ford's unsuccessful bid for reelection in 1976.

title: Joan Hyman Will Be Married
description: Mrs. Alexander Hyman of Great Neck, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Joan Hyman, to Stuart Schemson, son of Mr. and Mrs Michael Scheinson of Massapequa.

title: How About Musical Buildings?
description: GREENWHICH you might have noticed that the movement to save the whale and the snail darter made little headway in Fairfield County. It wasn't just a matter of indifference. It boiled down to a matter of priorities Eskimos save whales, biology teachers save snail darters, Fairfield County people save buildings.

title: Mount Vernon Five Wins Class AAA Championship
description: ROCHESTER, March 24  Mount Vernon defeated Rush Henrietta Sperry of Rochester, 6:t56, tonight and won the New York State scholastic AAA basketball championship at the War Memorial. It was the 26th victory against only one loss for the Westchester team.

title: Gayle Gerard Roth Wed to TV Editor
description: St. James Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Gayle Gerard Roth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Gerard Roth of Atlantic Beach, L.I., to Edward Ramsay Warwick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Worthington Warwick of Chestnut Hill, Pa. The Rev. Carol Anderson and the Rev. Edward T. O'Conner, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WASHING machines have electrically operated valves that control the flow of water into the machines by turning it on and off as needed. These valves will shut the water off rather quickly, and this sometimes causes a condition known as water hammer in which the pipes bang or hammer each time the water flow is interrupted.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, March 24 (Reuters)  The 83yearold leader of the Soviet Seventhday Adventists was sentenced to five years at hard labor after his conviction yesterday on charges of slandering the state and infringing citizens rights under the guise of religious activities, according to informed sources.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: HOME fallout shelters have largely been abandoned as an answer to nuclear attack. So has the idea of Westchester residents trying to shelter  or fend off  millions of escapees from New York City.

title: 10,000 LAOTIAN AIDES REPORTED DETAINED
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 24  Souvanna Phouma, former Prime Minister of Laos and now a Government adviser, says 10,000 to 15,000 civilian officials and military officers who served under him have been detained since the Communists seized power in 1975.

title: Sunday Brunch Is Just a Flight Away
description: With energy conservation in mind, and the fact that the average price of a gallon of 80 or 100octane airplane fuel is 89 cents, it should have struck me as overindulgent when a friend invited me to meet him at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey to fly off for a Sunday brunch somewhere along the Eastern Seaboard. But since t had been smitten with aviator's fever a few months before and felt eager for any opportunity to fly, and my friend, Robert Eden, was also my flying instructor, I accepted.

title: Dr. Charles Chapple, Inventor of Incubator For Premature Infants
description: Dr. Charles C. Chapple, a retired pediatrician and professor who invented an incubator that revolutionized the care of premature and feeble infants, died Friday at a hospital in Lincoln, Neb. He was 75 years old.

title: MUSIC Border Crossing
description: THIS writer has long felt that there ought to be more cutural traffic across the WestchesterFairfield border, that New Yorkers should more readily partake of the musical bounties of such nearby Connecticut towns as Stamford, Greenwich and New Canaan, and Fairfield people should embrace the concert enticements just a few minutes drive away in places like Mamaroneck, Rye and Mount Vernon.

title: Saccharin Is 100 Years Old
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) The Calorie Control Council, an industry group representing the makers of diet soft drinks and other products, sent out a birthday card this week: Saccharin is 100 years old. The artificial sweetener was developed March 22, 1879, by two researchers at Johns Hopkins University.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE fairhaired young woman in front of me on the supermarket checkout line laughed as she unloaded a cart bursting with supplies.

title: Luring the Movies Back To Where It All Began
description: FORT LEE THE year was 1905. Fort Lee, a small country town, was just starting to attract small groups pioneer moviemakers, including D. W. Griffith and Maurice Tourneur. They ferried their primitive equipment across the Hudson from New York so they could shoot on location in a rural setting.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WASHING machines have electrically operated valves that control the flow of water into the machines by turning it on and off as needed. These valves will shut the water off rather quickly, and this sometimes causes a condition known as water hammer in which the pipes bang or hammer each time the water flow is interrupted.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Most of us have never seen a faun but we have no trouble recognizing one when we see one. For the past three weeks, he has been reclining on a rock inside the Mark Hellinger Theater, lazily playing his pipe and eating his grapes. When he sees three, then two, nymphs enter, he gives them nary a glance. Nor does he stir when the sixth appears. But when the seventh comes to bathe and shed her veillike outer garments, it is something else that stirs inside the creature. The object of his desire flees as he approaches her. Only her scarf remains to give him the satisfaction that leaves him lying spent upon the rock.

title: Manhattan's Crew Defeats Maritime by a HalfLength
description: Manhattan College's crew, which lost its shell and other equipment when its boathouse on the Harlem River was burned by arsonists last September, opened its season yesterday by winning t he Deering Cup regatta at the Orchard Beach Lagoon in the Bronx.

title: Birth Notice 1  No Title
description: Births

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Hercules to Challenge Holmes
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 24 Larry Holmes, who has been fighting here in the desert so long that he could be called Lawrence of Nevada, will make his next defense of the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship at Madison Square Garden in late May or early June, Don King, the promoter, announced today.

title: GARDENING
description: THE beginning of spring is a time when whether we look or whether we listen, we hear life murmur or see it glisten.

title: The Gaslight Era Is Ending All Over Again
description: The crowning touch of Peggy Mann Houlton's brownstone on West 94th Street used to be a gas lamp  a small, colonialstyle fixture that reminded her of an era when the New York skyline was bathed in the soft yellow glow of gas light.

title: Other World Events
description: France announced last week that it was withdrawing 2,500 soldiers from Chad because the civil war there had been ended through negotiations. There was another, unstated, reason. President Valery Giscard dEstaing's ambitious Africa policy, under which troops have also been sent to Djibouti, Mauritania and Zaire, costs too much at a time of domestic economic crisis. Unemployment in France is 1.3 million and rising, with workers in the uneconomic steel, textile and shipbuilding industries the hardest hit. On Friday, nearly 100,000 workers demonstrated in central Paris to demand jobs and protest Government plans to lay off more workers. The protests ended in violence  reminiscent of the student riots of May 1968  when ultraleftists attacked riot policemen with rocks and Molotov cocktails, and looted and smashed the windows of cafes and shops.

title: Unemployment Pay for Strikers Backed
description: The New York Telephone Company holds that state unemployment benefits paid to striking workers are an unfair intrusion in labormanagement disputes. But the Supreme Court last week held otherwise, ruling 6 to 3 that the practice in New York State was constitutional.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Deaths

title: ANTIQUES
description: For New York porcelain enthusiasts, March has become a month to remember. It's been several years, in fact, since ceramics collectors and dealers of this city had cause for, if not shouting, at least smiling. Interest in everything from Meissen figurines to Chelsea scent bottles appeared on the wane. Prices had either reached a plateau or dropped, and porcelain shows in museums and galleries were rare.

title: DINING OUT
description: SURVIVAL of the fittest is a fact of life more descriptive of the restaurant business than of any other, yet Parise's Steak House, which has been in Thornwood for a halfcentury, may put a chink in Darwin's theory. For while Parise's steaks and chops are quite deserving of recommendation, most of the food and the operation of the restaurant itself make one wonder how it has gained such a longstanding reputation.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: LEAVING the running of a condominium development entirely in the hands of hired professional management is tempting but may not necessarily be in the best interests of the owners, in the opinion of leaders of condominium owners groups in Connecticut. Robert Buescher, president of the 929unit Oronoque Village Condominium Owners Association in Stratford, says, I think we now realize that quality management makes a great deal of difference not only to values but also to monthly charges.

title: CRIME
description: Garry Wills. who has written pulverizing studies of contemporary men and society Nixon Agonistes and Inventing America are among his books  now turns his hand to thriller fiction. Apparently his vices include an addiction to mystery stories, and one gathers from his first novel, AT BUTTON'S (Andrews and McMeel, $8.95), that Rex Stout is one of his heroes. Thus Mr. Wills joins other American intellectuals, such as William F. Buckley Jr., in the parlor game of diddling the reader's imagination in honeyed prose about murder, espionage and assorted mayhem.

title: Churches Turning to Arms Race As Top Social Issue for the 1980's
description: The drive among United States churches for international disarmament is taking the place in church life once occupied by civil rights and the antiwar movement of the 1960's and early 1970's. For Protestants, Catholics and Jews, disarmament is becoming the most prominent social issue for the decade ahead.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The article Condominium Concept Vacations at Home [March 4] does not give a truly accurate picture of condominium ownership, leaving out one necessary expense.

title: Dr. Edward Deutscher Weds Laura Zwilich
description: Laura Zwilich, daughter of Mrs. Morris Kramer of Larchmont, N.Y., and Joseph Zwilich of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last evening to Dr. Edward M. Deutscher, son of Mrs. Sol Blumenthal of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Clifford Deutscher. Herbert F. Ryan, First Deputy City Clerk of Mount Vernon, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's brotherinlaw and sister, Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Bauman of Mount Vernon.

title: A $6 Million Y Set For Meadowlands
description: RUTHERFORD A$6 million Y.M.C.A. that will house extensive recreational and health facilities for the residents of nine communities in the Hackensack Meadowlands will be constructed on six acres owned by the Borough of Rutherford.

title: STAMPS
description: Lovers of dogs, flowers, horses, children books, flags and the past in general are all being wooed by the stamps of Great Britain this year, and not once but fourfold, for virtually all the British issues of 1979 are quartets.

title: High Winds Send Golfers' Scores Soaring
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., March 24 The Sawgrass course beat the best golf professionals in the business today with a vicious wind of 25 to 30 miles an hour and nasty, confusing gusts. The underpar red figures of Thursday, the first round of the Tournament Players Championship, and the evenpar black figures of yesterday gave way in the third round today to a mass of green numbers denoting scores over par.

title: I Love N.Y. Now Statewide Affair
description: WHITE PLAINS SEVERAL years ago, Sleepy Hollow Restorations Inc. began advertising Sunnyside, Van Cortlandt Manor and Philipsburg Manor on television with a script that started this way: Tucked among the hills along the Hudson River . . .

title: Police Say Bronx Youth Confesses To Wounding 2 in Sniper Attacks
description: The police said yesterday that a 17 yearold South Bronx boy had confessed to two apparently motiveless sniping incidents on Friday in which a young man and a teenaged girl were shot in the back as they walked near the suspect's apartment.

title: Mailbox: Participation, Not Winning, Is Key Element
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Miss Bernstein to Inform Koch Tomorrow Whether She Will Resign as H.R.A. Head
description: Blanche Bernstein, who was told by Mayor Koch Friday that she was being replaced as operating head of the city's Human Resources Administration, said yesterday that she would inform Mayor Koch by tomorrow whether she would resign.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Chicago Bulls play the New Jersey Nets at 1:45 P.M. today at Rutgers gymnasium in Piscataway, N.J. The Nets also have 8 P.M. home games on Wednesday against the Washington Bullets and on Friday against the Atlanta Hawks.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Today

title: Met Dissension Rises
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 24  As if they didn't have enough troubles already, the New York Mets suffered an acute case of dissension today, which led Manager Joe Torre to release Bobby Valentine, once one of the best prospects in baseball.

title: U.S. Casting About for Answers on Bluefish
description: WHEN it comes to bluefish. Long Island sport and commercial fishermen are in the same boat. Both groups are concerned that tuna fishermen, who are seeking new sources of revenue because of Federal catch limits on bluefin tuna, will turn to bluefish.

title: Cutbacks Squeeze GasStation Hoses
description: CITING the effects of recent cuts in deliveries from major oil companies, an increasing number of gas stations in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are reducing the number of days a week they are open, shortening their hours and limiting sales to customers .

title: Health  THECANCER SAFETY CONTROVERSY
description: Sometimes a simple question put by a layman can get to the heart of a complex scientific problem more surely than expert interrogation. So it was at the New York Academy of Sciences International Conference on Public Control of Environmental Health Hazards last year. Peter A. A. Berle, then New York State's Environmental Conservation Commissioner, had just unveiled a plan for dredging heavily contaminated hot spots along the upper Hudson River of 340,000 pounds of the PCB's that had been dumped into the waterway by the General Electric Company. A succession of health officials, scientists and corporate representatives rose to question Mr. Berle about the details of removing the PCB's (polychlorinated biphenyls  heatresistant chemicals used for insulating transformers and capacitors), which have been shown to cause birth defects, reproductive failure and cancer in animals, and are strongly suspected of being carcinogenic to man.

title: A Real Winner In Weight Losing
description: ' I look back at what was just a germ of an idea, said Albert Lippert, the chairman and chief executive officer of Weight Watchers International, and guess I still get goosebumps when I feel that I, as an individual, was instrumental in developing what today is the world's foremost weightreduction oranization.

title: Nakian
description: ONE afternoon this autumn, all goes according to plan, the city of Norwalk will unveil its first piece of public sculpture since the days when war was still memorialized in bronze. Excited city officials and local artists are regarding the acquisition as a major coup, because the artist is Reuben Nakian, the internationally acclaimed sculptor, and the purchase price is considered an astonishing bargain at $60,000.

title: If the Sailing Bug Bites You: Advice on How to Buy Boat
description: YOU have been bitten by the sailing bug, and you decide that you must become the owner of a sailboat. What next? How do you go about this very special search?

title: Wendy Lynn Moses Betrothed
description: The engagement of Wendy Lynn Moses, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Klaus W. Moses, to Steven Richard Hilmier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hilmier, has been announced by the future bride's parents. Both families live Roslyn Estates, L.I. Plans have been made for an August wedding.

title: Syria Says It Will Not Seek Oil Embargo Against U.S.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 24 (UPI) The Syrian Government said today that it would not ask for an Arab oil embargo against the United States to protest the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty because would divert attention from Egypt's treason against the Arab world.

title: Dissident Teamsters Call for National Strike April 1
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  Teamster dissidents warned the union's leadership today not to defraud the rankandfile workers in the current contract talks and called for a nationwide trucking strike on April 1 as the only way to win a settlement. The current contract expires midnight, March 31.

title: Quiet Jersey Community Stunned By Murder of 2 Women and Boy, 5
description: FAIR LAWN, N.J., March 24  As clusters of neighbors stared silently at the twostory house on the corner, detectives and police officers raked leaves from front yard shrubbery today, seeking clues to the murders of two women and a 5yearold boy who lived in the house. They found none.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Russians Report a Find Of LongBuried Butter
description: MOSCOW, March 24 (UPI) A thou sand years ago someone buried a big jar of butter in Aktobe, an ancient city in the western regions of what is now Central Asia.

title: Sludge From Stamford Harbor Poses Problems for the Sound
description: STAMFORD. CONN. IN the battle over harbor dredging, to the losers belong the spoils. Like it or not, the water on the Island's side of the Sound will be polluted with six toxic metals, according to Dr. Jeffrey Wenig, director of the Huntington Department of Environmental Protection, if the Army Corps of Engineers is allowed to dredge 241,000 cubic yards from the bottom of the Stamford and New Haven harbors and dump the spoils in 80 feet of water at a site 11 miles north of Shoreham in Lung Island Sound.

title: Gains Reported in Struggle Against Red Tape on Fund Applications
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  James T. McIntyre Jr., director of the Office of Management and Budget, said in a report released today that considerable progress had been made in simplifying Federal grant procedures, but he made it clear that a morass of red tape and duplication remains to be attacked.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Will history repeat itself? Will an 812page Doubleday novel called Hanta Yo do for the American Indian and its author, Ruth Beebe Hill, what Roots, another Doubleday book, did for black history and Arthur Haley? Scarcely six weeks after its publication, Hanta Yo is on the way. This week, for the fourth time, it's comfortably lodged on the Best Seller List. Plans are afoot to turn it into an ABCTV miniseries, the same treatment that was accorded Roots.

title: Pictures That Seem to Invite the Viewer
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR MODERN art criticism has tended to look down its long patrician nose at good technique in painting. If an artist has developed a talent for competent draftsmanship, able coloring and compositional precision, he must not have developed his expressive faculties. The artist doesn't have time or mental energy to develop both simultaneously. Technique has prevailed over feelings to the detriment of the art work.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: TALKING WITH
description: Our greatest actor, in an unusually frank threeday interview, discusses acting, why he left Vivien Lei! h and his will to survive.

title: Margaret A. Long Married in South
description: Margaret Anne Long and John Chapman Wilson Macauley were married yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church in Burlington, N.C., by the Rev. Thomas B. Anderson.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: Snakes Eaten in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 24 (AP)  Residents here eat an estimated 30,000 snakes a day at some 600 restaurants that serve only a snake soup called baim tang, according to the Korea Research Institute of Human Settlements. Snake meat is believed here to be healthful.

title: ART
description: HUNTINGTON IT'S been 25 years since the newly founded Huntington Township Art League met in the then dormant Heckscher Museum, and 24 years since the league first used the museum building for its annual Long Island art exhibition. The show has been a fixture at the Heckscher ever since, even after the museum reopened to the public in the early 1960's and the league moved to its own premises.

title: President, Disturbed by Inflation, To Step Up PriceMonitoring Drive
description: ELK CITY, Okla., March 24  President Carter promised tonight to take firm steps to deal with the inflation problem in the days ahead, including requiring regular reports from companies in industries with particularly large price increases.

title: The Washington Post Is Replacing Geyelin As Head of Editorials
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  Philip L. Geyelin, 56yearold Pulitzer Prize winner who has been editorial page editor of The Washington Post since 1968, has been replaced.

title: BRIDGE
description: In the ?? of ?? the supreme ?? ?? the Bobby Riggs of the period, was P. Hal Sims, who could and did ensnare unwary victims into competing against him at golf, tennis, billiards and trapshooting as well as bridge.

title: PUBLICISSUE FORUM IS CALLED PROMISING
description: What we want to create is a climate that will lead to wide public involvement. said Mildred Beece, president of the League of Women Voters of the TriState Metropolitan Region, and so the league, an unusual organization, is in tne midst of creating what could be likened to a goodgovernment club that aims to involve community groups throughout the metropolitan area in issues that affect them.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE Consumers Keep on Buying
description: It's a strange kind of phenomenon, said Fred Goldring, owner of Rudder's, which operates three fashion stores in California's lush San Joaquin Valley.

title: Peace With Egypt Will Not Mean Peace on West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  And now for the difficult part, joked a blearyeyed American diplomat who had witnessed the marathon debate in the Knesset last week that ended with a vote overwhelmingly in favor of the peace treaty with Egypt.

title: POETRY OF THE POPE PUBLISHED AS BOOK
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 24 For 25 years the poetry of Andrzej Jawien enriched the pages of Tygodnik Powszechny, Poland's leading Catholic newspaper.

title: Katherine Eliot Viek, Nurse, Is Bride of Arthur M. Pittis
description: Katherine Eliot Viek, daughter of Mrs. Robert E. Lee of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Peter Viek, was married last night in Chester Springs, Pa., to Arthur Mauder Pittis, son of Mr. andMrs. Walter F. Pittis of Glen Ridge and Ocean Grove, N.J. The Rev. W. Bradford Greeley, Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Inn at Yellow Springs.

title: Birth Notice 2  No Title
description: Births

title: Coming Attractions on the Jet Stereo and
description: Watching a movie or listening to music while in a plane can be like hearing Vivaldi through earphones while in a dentist's chair. The drilllike whir of the plane and those prongs sticking in the ears almost make entertainment a wasted effort.

title: 14 Hurt in a Chemical Explosion
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., March 24 (AP) A barrel of phosphorus exploded yesterday, injuring 14 members of a cleanup crew that was removing the chemical from the wreckage of a tractortrailer here. Four persons were admitted to a local hospital suffering from burns and inhalation of fumes. Firemen and chemical experts had been working since Thursday night to remove 21 tons of the chemical from the tractortrailer, which had caught fire and exploded.

title: HONE CLINIC A Cushion of Air to Quiet Banging Pipes
description: WASHING machines have electrically operated valves that control the flow of water into the machines by turning it on and off as needed. These valves will shut the water off ?? quickly, and this sometimes causes a condition known as water ?? m which the pipes bang or hammer each time the water flow is interrupted.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Barbara Kapelman, Physician, Married
description: Dr. Barbara Ann Kapelman, a fellow in gastroenterology at St. Luke's Hospital Center, was married in New Rochelle, N.Y., yesterday to Dr. Lawrence William Koblenz, an attendingphysician at Beth Israel Medical Center and a clinical instructor in medicine at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Rabbi Maurice L. Schwartz performed the ceremony at the Fountainhead.

title: FOOD
description: SYOSSET BIANCA BROWN began to describe Czech cooking as dumplings, dumplings, dumplings. Then she stopped short. That isn't all there is to it, she said, adding, The Czech people like to eat well and that goes for homestyle cooking as well as elaborate, fancy dishes.

title: A Trustee Scathes His Constituents as Hypocrites
description: FOR eight years, Patrick Westerman of Mount Kisco was buttonholed hy his neighbot:. over the ?? (of garbage pickups, ghat they fel.t WAS the ?? lence of zoning practices and the everrising cost of government. He was the target of latenight telephone calls from some who wanted to debate, and from others who lost wanted to vent their spleen.

title: Suzanne Nicholls Bride of John Thorndike
description: Suzanne Rutherfurd Nicholls, daughter of Guy Winfield Nicholls of Marathon, Fla., formerly of North Tarrytown, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Nicholls, was married yesterday afternoon to John Thorndike, son of Mr. and Mrs. T.William Thorndike of Kensington, N.H. State Supreme Court Justice Morrie Slifkin performed the ceremony at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in ScarboroughonHudson, N.Y.

title: INTERVIEW; Hollywood? She Prefers New Rochelle
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fred Allen once said, is a great place to live if you happen to be an orange. Nevertheless, if you want to be in pictures, that seems to be where you must be, so you can be available, get to the right parties, get to the right auditions and meet the right people.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: AVON  Collography by Minot, Pech, Rosenthal, through April 17. Tuesdays through Saturdays 11 to 4. Sundays 1 to 4, Farmington Valley Arts Center Gallery. 6781967. Photographs of China, Mexico and New England by Care Brett Smith, Studio 6A, 2 to 5 weekends only. 6772132.

title: A Service Station on the Thruway Where
description: To a driver coming from the Broax, the New York State Thruway takes on a relatively open look near Exit 5. Yonkers Raceway has disappeared from the rearview mirror. On the left passes the oranii,e rout of Howard Johnson, an American classic that seems to say.

title: Karl Arthur Horne Is Fianc Of Valerie Byam Hartmeyer
description: The engagement of Valerie Byam Hartmeyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bailey Hartmeyer of Locust Valley, L.I., to Karl Arthur Horne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ashton Horne of Milford, Conn., and Wareham, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Elizabeth A. Solbert Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter O.A. Solbert of New York and Lloyd Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Abernathy Solbert, to John S. Sheldon of Norwich, Vt. He is a son of Col. George C. Sheldon, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Sheldon of Jarrettsville. Md.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Today

title: Folk Art by Islanders at Work at Sea
description: WEST SAYVILLE AN intimate and very personal exploration of the Island's long affair with the sea is currently on view at the Suffolk Marine Museum here. The exhibition, Arts and Treasures of the Sailor, contains approximately 100 examples of both useful and purely decorative objects produced by local seamen, as well as souvenirs, both strange and beautiful, that were gathered by sailors during voyages to exotic ports of call.

title: Working on Music Like Crazy
description: I'M an original music freak, Cliff Abeles, owner of the Lion's Cage on New York Avenue in Huntington, said recently, and the music policy at his club bears him out.

title: BEGIN IS CONFIDENT ON SIGNING OF PACT AFTER SEEING VANCE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel said last night that the signing of the peace treaty between his country and Egypt would take place as scheduled tomorrow in Washington, but he offered no indication whether some lastminute difficulties had been resolved yesterday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Everglades Face Issues On Ecology, Economics
description: ISLAMORADA, Fla.,  Florida's Everglades National Park is being abused, and the Everglades Protection Association is striving to correct the situation.

title: Ayckbourn Comic Laureate of Britain's Middle Class
THE LIVELY ARTS
description: MINEOLA A MOON for the Misbegotten is one of Eugene O'Neill's most problematical plays, demanding a mood at once fatalistic and delicate and acting of positive transcendence to translate it to stage life. The play has suffered a beleaguered history, from its first production on tour in 1997, when it was temporarily closed on grounds of obscenity  Detroit's police censors objected to the words 1'mother and prostitute occurring in the same sentence. O'Neill himself began to resent the play and put it to rest in peace, following the suggestion of a number of critics.

title: POLITICS
description: A COMMON perception of public officials is that they never leave office voluntarily. They either have to be voted out or carted out.

title: Ray Leonard Puts Away Gonzales in 123 Seconds
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 24 (AP) Sugar Ray Leonard used two lightning rights to the jaw to dispose of Daniel Gonzales of Argentina in 2 minutes seconds of the first round in a nationally televised welterweight bout today.

title: The Nation In Summary
description: A special counsel was appointed last week to investigate loans made to President Carter's family peanut business during his campaign, even as evidence came to light that Mr. Carter may have known more about those loans than previously acknowledged.

title: New Messiahs and New Believers
description: It is June 1975. Chris Edwards, an intelligent and independent young man, fresh from Yale, is leaning against a signpost. A friendly young stranger

title: Carter's Talk in Dallas Being Broadcast Today
description: President Carter's speech in Dallas before the convention of the National Association of Broadcasters will be broadcast live today by National Public Radio and the Mutual Broadcasting System. It is tentatively scheduled to begin at 4:30 P.M., New York time, and is to be followed by a questionandanswer period.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Deaths

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Marshall McLuhan published thousands of printed words in the selfcontradictory hope of persuading readers that the age of print had come to an end, overcome by television's instantaneous images. Many literate people swallowed this canard feathers and all. Some of them, no doubt, are historians of the Renaissance and Reformation, who ought to have been turning their trained intelligences away from the glib and premature report of the death of the printing press and toward the revolutionary phenomenon of its birth during the very period in which they claim to be specialists.

title: John McNally, Student, Fianc of Nancy Curran
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Curran Jr. of Baldwin, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jane Curran, to John J. McNally Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. McNally of Stuart, Fla., formerly of Bayport, L.I.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: The thing I do best is talk, and that's what I'm going to do, said Joseph E. Levine, the 73yearold film producer who still likes to quote one of his early critics: She said my pictures run the emotional gamut from A to B.

title: Janet Hayes Becomes Bride Of E.D. Henry
description: Janet Marion Hayes of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Hayes of Sewickley, Pa., was married there yesterday to Edward Duerr Henry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward James Henry of Worcester, Mass. The Rev. Russell Turner performed the ceremony in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

title: Direct Primaries Called Best System for Nominations
description: THE 1978 state election campaign brought about a clamor of support for change in Connecticut's candidateselection system. Democrats and Republicansalike proposed major revisions of the process leading to the party endorsement, calling the system incomprehensible and complex. In October, the General Assembly established a study committee that recently issued a report containing piecemeal changes in the present system. As a member of the study committee I believe that we missed an opportunity for meaningful reform and have given reluctant incumbents a convenient excuse to avoid promises made in the heat of the election. As a result, the vast majority of our electorate remains at the sidelines, excluded from any signifcant participation or understanding of the way in which our parties chose their candidates.

title: BAKHTIAR ATTACKS NEW DICTATORSHIP
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 25  Shahpur Bakhtiar, who was ousted as Iran's Prime Minister last month by the revolutionary forces of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, sent a message from hiding today saying that the new Government had brought repression, chaos and a ruined economy.

title: Supper Club Fire Claims Ended
description: NEWPORT, Ky., March 24 (AP)  A final judgment dismissing all claims against the owners of the Beverly Hills Supper Club in the 1977 fire in which 165 persons died has been signed by Campbell Circuit Judge John Diskin. The decision approving a $3.02 million outofcourt settlement was expected after it was approved last month by Federal District Judge Carl Rubin.

title: POINT OF VIEW Work Opportunities Are Not Just Jobs
description: Ever since Hargreaves patented the spinning jenny in 1770 and triggered what we have come to call the industrial revolution, the attitudes of working people toward society have been shaped, more than anything, by society 's capacity to provide jobs.

title: Steinbrenner, a Farmer, Cultivates Young Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 24  After spending millions to build a winner with storebought free agents, George Steinbrenner now hopes to build a New York Yankee baseball dynasty with homegrown farm talent.

title: State Put 20th in Welfare Ranking
description: Not counting the separate payment for rent, New York State's maximum basic welfare grant ranks 20th among the nation's 50 states, according to a group of socialservice leaders.

title: Call Him KO 1 Earnie
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 24  In the fast shuffle of boxing's big money, some precocious pugilists have had a shot at the world heavyweight title long before they deserved it. Ossie Ocasio had only 13 fights before Larry Holmes destroyed him in the seventh round last night to retain the World Boxing Council championship. Leon Spinks had only eight fights before borrowing the World Boxing Association title from Muhammad Ali last year. One reason is that those two boxers can't punch as Earnie Shavers can. But perhaps there is some justice in the world, even the boxing world, because now Earnie Shavers is in line for a title shot with Larry Holmes and nobody begrudges him the opportunity not even Ken Norton.

title: Boston Specialist Saves Russian Woman's Life
description: MOSCOW, March 24 (AP)  Dr. Warren Zapol of Boston, without a visa or plane ticket, scrambled aboard a Moscowbound Aeroflot airliner early this month, on his way to help save the life of a 28yearold Russian woman who was dying of a lung ailment.

title: Headliners
description: Not so Joyful Reunion

title: Public Bombs, and Minds Born Secret
description: When the Carter Administration first went to court two weeks ago to censor an article in The Progressive, it led the world to believe that it was rushing to recapture its most precious secret, the instructions for building a hydrogen bomb. A district judge felt obliged to restrain the magazine temporarily, to let the Government meet its heavy burden of proving that such unprecedented suppression was justified by a grave, certain and irreparable hazard to the nation. The arguments on both sides have now been filed and the Administration 's case turns out to be lame in both logic and law. The shouts of alarm are more harmful than the danger they describe.

title: Other National Events
description: The Senate ethics committee delivered itself of its judgment last week that while Edward R. Brooke did violate the rules of Congressional conduct by giving false testimony under oath, that would be insufficient cause for disciplinary action. In any case, the point was actually moot. The Republican from Massachusetts is now former Senator Brooke. Still, he declared himself vindicated. Putting his liablilities at $49,000 while in a divorce court and at $2,000 in ?? his worth for the Senate was no more than a mistake. ?? said, that cost him his seat in the November ??

title: Medical School on Caribbean Isle Is Under a Cloud
description: ST. GEORGE'S. Grenada, March 24 (AP)  David Baras of Port Jervis. N.Y., one of 500 Americans at a medical school here, says he thinks he is as qualified as any student in the United States.

title: Benjamin Ginsberg Fianc of Jo Talbot
description: The engagement of Jo Anne Talbot to Benjamin Langer Ginsberg has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Talbot of Stockbridge, Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold S. Ginsberg of New York and Monterey, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: Cathryn Marie Andre Married To Alexander Miller, Student
description: Cathryn Marie Andre, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Charles Andre of Montclair, N.J., and Phoenix, was Married in Phoenix yesterday to Alexander Scott Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Christian Miller of Trumbull. Conn. The Rev. Thomas G. Allander performed the ceremony in the St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church.

title: Wendy J. Bainbridge Affianced
description: The engagement of Wendy Jean Bainbridge to Lawrence Gary Easier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman W. Easier of Tampa, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents, the Rev, and Mrs. Ralph Bainbridge of Greenwich, Conn. The couple, alumni of Emory university, plan to be married next July. Miss Bainbridge's father is pastor of the First United Methodist Church in Greenwich. Her fiance attends the Emory School of Dentistry.

title: Seeing the World With Homer,
description: There's nothing to see but some old cellar holes, said a disgruntled tourist, heading away from the site of Troy. My wife and I knew better, but we had Homer, Heinrich Schliemann and C. W. Ceram for guides.

title: George Oliva 3d, Actor, Fianc of Lynne Dennis
description: John S. Dennis of Lambertville, N.J., and Mrs. Raymond E. Fazio of Medford Lakes, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynne Diane Dennis, to George Oliva 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliva Jr. of Gates Mills, Ohio. A May wedding in Princeton, N.J., is planned.

title: Congressmen Seeking A Prisoner Exchange To Free Puerto Ricans
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  With tacit encouragement from the State Department, two New York Representatives are taking a new approach in trying to free four Puerto Rican nationalists imprisoned in the United States. They are calling for release of the Puerto Ricans as a way of freeing four United States citizens imprisoned in Cuba.

title: The Guns of August 1985
description: THERE has been no shortage of wars since 1945, but the one war that has not occurred, so far, is the one most to be feared: a clash between North Atlantic Treaty Organization and Warsaw Pact forces on the central front in Europe. The most critical issues are engaged on that line, and few doubt that conflict there could lead quickly to a strategic nuclear exchange. Thus the true containment doctrine has been an implicit agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union, at least since the Berlin blockade of 1948, to contain European crises so that no one stumbles over the trip wire that would detonate World World III.

title: Fitzsimmons Keeps His Hold on the Driver's Seat
description: WASHINGTON  Frank E. Fitzsimmons, the somewhat chubby, 70yearold president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, is a beleaguered man. Negotiations for a contract covering 300,000 truckingindustry employees are nearing a climax, and conducting them is a complex and demanding task in itself. But he is also under growing pressure from Federal investigators, union dissidents, and Alfred E. Kahn, the Administration's chief inflation fighter, who recently warned the union to stay within wage guidelines or face deregulation troubles.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: It is not a matter of a Shaw or an O'Casey or a Brendan Behan, but over the past year the Irish have been slipping a fair bit of life into our theater.

title: Miss Mattson Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Mattson of Stratford, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jeannette Amalie Mattson, to William H. Timbers Jr., son of Judge and Mrs. Timbers of Darien, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: Offstage, A New Voice In Politics
description: THE Economic Political Industry Committee, EPIC, as the Connecticut Business and Industry Association calls its politicalaction committee, raised about three times more money for campaign contributions in last year's state election than the 1976 election.

title: Black Troupes in Festival
description: To observe the 10th anniversary of many of the nation's black performingarts companies, the Richard Allen Center for Culture and Art is assembling more than two dozen theater and dance companies from across the nation for a fiveweek festival of drama and dance at Lincoln Center beginning May 1.

title: Al Arbour: The Innovator
description: The coach of one of the finer teams in the National Hockey League's 62 seasons dresses in a room he shares with a washing machine.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: SINCE this year marks tile 50th anniversary of Jones Beach, the Long Island State Park Commission is planning a little something extra for the flower beds and planters.

title: Jane Hiller Winter Sets June 30 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. Winter of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Winter's daughter, Jane Hiller Winter, to Donald Bruce Lawson, son of Clifton E.R. Lawson of Madison. Wis., and the late Ruth Fliegel Lawson. Plans have been made for a June 30 wedding.

title: An International Style
description: FOR those whose life took shape under the impact of two world wars, the Russian Revolution and the destructive might of Fascism, the 20th century had to be called a century of crisis. Its truth was volcanic, discontinuous, agonistic, disruptive. Yet now the very term crisis grows tired. The more distant vision of the present discerns as salient features of the century elements of stability, continuity and slow growth. What did survive speaks louder than what was survived. Despite and beyond massive economic breakdowns and social upheavals, Europe and America are perceived as having moved toward relatively stable welfare societies, in which class and national struggles are muted by bureaucratic rationality, political compro mise and skillful cooptation of cultural and social dissent.

title: IN THE NATION An Echoing Scandal
description: WASHINGTON  That burgeoning scandal in South Africa, involving secret Government funds to buy good will abroad, may yet implicate some bigname American politicians as having been among those purchased. But the affair is being watched with foreboding by the Carter Administration's African specialists because it is making headlines at the same time that difficulties have developed between South Africa and the United Nations over the U. N. plan for the independence of SouthWest Africa (Namibia).

title: Asia Society's Pursuit Of Authenticity
description: New York will have its first view of Yakshagana on Saturday when that religious dancedrama from the tropical coastal region of South Kanara, India is first seen here in performance at Carnegie Hall, under the aegis of the Performing Arts Program of Asia Society. In an art where the current standards of excellence often seem to be those of notoriety and each gravitydefying leap or dazzling multiplicity of turns seems to bring another fan or two into the dance fold, such an announcement is not likely to cause much of an upheaval. But for a growing number of danceconscious New Yorkers, the concert promises not an ?? ?? event but a thoughtprovoking look at the dance and society of another culture. And for that growth, Asia Society's Performing Arts Program is largely responsible.

title: ART VIEW
description: WASHINGTON The 1970's are drawing to a close, and the inevitable lists, estimates, retrospects and general toting up of accomplishments that now come regularly at a decade's end will soon be upon us. What are we going to make of this curious decade? So far as painting and sculpture and the hybrid visual arts that derive from them are concerned, it is not going to be an easy period to summarize and define.

title: Music Notes  The Rochester Success
description: Some years ago the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra was in a chaotic state. It was between music directors, and the players had been going through a series of difficult labor negotiations. It wanted, among other things, a voice in the choice of a new music director. It submitted a list of conductors it would like to have as guests, and the management agreed to bring in three of them for three programs each. After these concerts, the one who was clearly favored was David Zinman, an American who was head of the Netherlands Chamber Orchestra in Amsterdam. Two years went by, during which nothing happened. Finally, an insurgent group was able to dislodge the incumbent board of directors, and the first thing it did was to bring in Mr. Zinman. That was in 197273. In the past six years the orchestra has prospered to the point where it is coming to Carnegie Hall for a concert on Thursday night.

title: A Feisty Fish Imperiled, But a Fish Restored
description: This month and next, twoyearold hatchery salmon are being released into the rivers of New England. Once they reach the sea, the fish become objects of international concern as they grow and mature before returning to fresh water to spawn.

title: Visitor Dies in Apartment Fire
description: A 19yearold woman from a Detroit suburb who was visiting her sister was burned to death early yesterday in a fire that destroyed sister', Manhattan apartment. The victim was Katherine Reese of Birmingham, Mich. The fire at 279 East 10th Street also injured Katherine Lanth?? 19. a roommate of the dead wurnan's sister, Elizabeth, whose age was not determined. The fire was listed as accidental, perhaps caused by candles that were burning in the apartment.

title: Enrollment Is Booming At Private Schools
description: WHEN Rita and Robert Lipton moved to Westport from Manhattan nine years ago, they never expected to be sending their children to private school. After all, a good suburban school system was a major reason for moving out of the city.

title: Geographical Diversity in Guide's Tours
description: The Hudson River Valley Travel Guide features proposed tours of each county. The routes are linked by 10 attractions selected with an eye to geographical diversity as well as interest.

title: SHOP TALK
description: HICKSEVILLE THE Mid Island Plaza in Hicks. ville is the kind of mall where you can easily spend a day shopping. There are dozens of shops. restaurants and snack bars around the large carpeted mall on Route KC known locally as North Broadway.

title: DINING OUT
description: NORWALK IN case you haven't been looking lately, some interesting renovation efforts are under way in South Norwalk near the Norwalk River. A porno theater has been turned into a movie house featuring film classics, and nearby is a fourmonthold restaurant that is something of a sleeper.

title: Supporting Role of Israeli Military Women Belies Image
description: BEERSHEBA, Israel  By 11:45 A.M., the throbbing desert heat engulfs the airstrip. Mikhal Arbel, the I9yearold daughter of an Israeli pilot, sits in an A4 Skyhawk quietly checking the cockpit's electronic and transmission gear.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Anatole Broyard's ess?? Th?? Life After Moving to the Subur?? [Feb. 11) prompts ?? to tesound ?? former Nev York City resident who has been living in suburbia since ??

title: Occasional Pieces
description: Harry Crews's career as a magazine writer took off when Jimmy Carter was elected President. Editors, realizing that the South was no longer part of the third world, began looking for writers who could represent that longneglected constituency. Mr. Crews had the right credentials: He was born in rural Georgia, a sharecropper's son with the gift of the Muse, and his downhome, oldboy style read as if it had bubbled through an illegal still in the Bacon County back country. His was the moonshine of writing, raw and potent.

title: Leonardo's Last Supper Has Its Back to the Wall
description: ROME Leonardo da Vinci's The Last Supper in the Church of Santa Maria delle Grazie in Milan is distinguished not only as one of the most famous pictures ever painted but also as the most restored. Over the nearly 500 years of its existence it has been painted over, reconstructed, consolidated, scraped, scratched, glued, varnished, Xrayed and scanned by electronic devices in scores of efforts to save it. Another attempt is now in progress, and last week Milan authorities estimated that the work would take about two years to complete.

title: Ideas &Trends In Summary
description: Should strikers get unemployment benefits, thus prolonging a walkout? New York State lets them do so (as does Rhode Island) after a sevenweek waiting period. Management doesn't like the law, but now they will have to lump it. The Supreme Court upheld the statute last week, by a vote of 6 to 3.

title: Promised Land
description: Ever since the I973 Middle East war triggered the oil embargo and devastating price inflation that shook the world economy, United States diplomacy has pushed for a settlement that could win Arab favor and uncock the oil weapon. Years of negotiating are due to pay off tomorrow, when Anwar elSadat and Menachem Begin join President Carter in Washington to sign an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: SPREADING THE RISK
description: There are about 100,000 known natural chemical entities, 1 to 5 percent of which are thought to be carcinogenic, according to Dr. W. Gary Flamm, a toxicologist in the Food and Drug Administration's Bureau of Foods. So, what do toxicologists eat?

title: Around The Garden
description: This Week:

title: CAMERA
description: To people who concentrate mostly on color pictures, black and white blackandwhite photography may seem like a lost art, but it is still very much alive and thriving. At galleries and museums across the country, blackandwhite prints dominate exhibitions, and elevated prices (such as $5,500 for an Ansel Adams print of Moonrise, Hernandez, N.M.) attest to the lasting artistic qualities of this medium.

title: Meyer's New Goal: Final Two
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 24  It took 37 years for Ray Meyer to get this far. If he has to wait a little longer to get a little further, he won't mind. He had to settle for a forced shot at the end, when a quick, short one was what he had in mind. He had to watch his De Paul team lose, 7674, to Indiana State in the semifinals of the National Collegiate tournament.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: EyeOpener

title: Mr. Callaghan 's Troubles Could Very Soon Be Mrs. Thatcher 's
description: LONDON  It hasn 't happened for 55 years, not since Ramsay Macdonald, the first Labor Prime Minister, was brought down by the publication of the Zinoviev letter, a forgery purporting to contain instructions for a Communist uprising in England. But it seemed highly likely this weekend that a British Government was about to lose a vote of confidence, this time over the question of devolution.

title: Late TV Listings
description: Noon (Channel 2) Newsmakers: Deputy Mayor Haskell Ward.

title: Women With Problems
description: For Better and for Worse is a buzzing hive of tantalizing questions  often amusingly posed  about marital roles Unfortunately. Myrna Blvth seems afraid of getting stung, or of stinging the reader, and so backs away from every issue she raises.

title: Bid on Building Of Bus Shelters Roils City Hall
description: The contest for the franchise to build New York City's bus shelters and sell advertising on them has produced one of the bitterest battles in recent City Hall history  a battle characterized by sharp accusations on all sides and pressure by a battery of politically influential lawyers and publicrelations men.

title: Passenger Trains to Start Runs Between Hong Kong and Canton
description: HONG KONG, March 24 (AP)  The first through passenger train service between Hong Kong and Canton in 30 years is to begin April 4. the KowloonCanton Railway announced.

title: Panel Urges Change at Jersey's 17 County Colleges
description: EDISON, N.J., March 24  A special state commission studying the 17 twoyear colleges in New Jersey's county college system has recommended a broad restructuring of their boards of trustees to eliminate any undue political influence in their operations.

title: Writing on Writing
description: THIS volume's title is taken from C.H. Sisson's essay on the 19thcentury Dorset poet William Barnes, who is praised for contending that the avoidance of literature is indispensable for a man who wants to tell the truth. Barnes managed to escape from the literary foibles of his time more quickly and completely than he could otherwise have done; that is, if he had not written poems in the Dorset dialect. Mr. Sisson's demand for literary independence is consonant with arguments put forth by his predecessors Matthew Arnold and Wyndham Lewis, both of whom are mentioned by Michael Schmidt in his introduction to The Avoidance of Literature as writers who avoided fashionable critical and ideological formulas. It was their conviction that one could transcend the necessarily provisional, subjective literary attitudes of one's time by cultivating an awareness of objective standards in literature and criticism (see Arnold's The Function of Criticism or The Study of Poetry) or by adopting a deliberately subversive mode of address (see Lewis's early novels and his critical bad manners generally).

title: New Connally Sounds Very Like the Old Carter
description: BEDFORD, N.H.  Just as there was four years ago, there is a Presidential candidate today who sees his hopes in mining a deep vein of dissatisfaction over the way the Goverment does business. He sells himself neither as an innovator nor as the logical successor to recent leaders, but as a man who can bring back what is best in the American past.

title: The Doors of a Sculptor
description: WHAT would Betty Goldstein of Scarsdale be doing in an iron foundry in New Jersey? She was polishing doors  of solid aluminum, castlike bronze, rune feet high, six feet wide, weighing almost a ton  that would eventually defy engineering opinion by opening and closing smoothly and accurately (with the help of a simple pair of airlock hinges) in the sanctuary of the Westchester Reform Temple.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: It was envisioned as a monument that would last forever, but by late 1977 the Hall of Fame for Great Americans was headed for oblivion. Bereaved of funds, stripped to a single employee  Jerry Grundfest, the director  the bronzebust colonnade in the Bronx had a final hope: the Ad Hoc Committee to Save the Hall of Fame. The committee, made up of civic groups, announced a fund drive.

title: Thomas Battling Odds in N.F.L
description: What are the chances of Duane Thomas regaining a job in the National Football League this season? Minimal, in terms of precedent.

title: Plan to Block Road Agitates Two Hewletts
description: HEWLETT SINCE they are two adjoining, affluent villages in the Five Towns with populations that are similar in background and interest, one would expect Hewlett Bay Park and Hewlett Harbor to have a relationship toward each other akin to that of Damon and Pythias. Instead, the relationship these days is closer to that of Cain and Abel.

title: Long Island This Week
description: BALDWIN  Watercolors by Jean Shelton; through Saturday; Library, 2385 Grand Ave. For hours. 2236228.

title: SCIENTISTS CRITICIZE OIL SPILL CLEANUPS
description: LOS ANGELES, March 24  Despite the large amounts of money, manpower and research that have been devoted to cleaning up ocean oil spills, a number of scientists this week voiced harsh criticism of the results.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Ardtitecture
description: In Essex, Conn. on warm afternoons, people like to leave their front doors open as an invitation to friends to drop by. Set on the banks of the Connecticut River, the town is a pleasant blend of Colonial, Federal and Victorian homes; a real charmer, Essex, the kind of town lots of folks would move to  if anybody ever moved out. So when Mr. and Mrs. Donald Barnes had a chance to buy the 1840 Federal house shown here, they grabbed it, even though it was much too small for them. The tiny house, just 24 feet square, was divided into a basement and two living floors which were themselves chopped up into a maze of small, dark rooms.

title: What Fishermen Require on Boats
description: FISHERMEN are finding it increasingly difficult to determine what items aboard a boat are necessities and which can be classified as accessories. Boating enthusiasts are looking for all the help they can get in finding fish and are searching for laborsaving devices that will make life on the water more relax

title: Kidnapped Brazilian Found Dead
description: RIO DE JANEIRO. March 24 (UPI) Jose Jobim, a 69yearold former Brazilian diplomat who was abducted Thursday, was found dead today hanging from a tree in the city's southern suburbs, police sources said. Mr. Jobim, who entered the Foreign Service in 1938 and served as ambassador to the Vatican among other !posts, had lately been working as an adviser to the state governor.

title: Fashion
description: First, for fall and for fashion  that could be the slogan of the Italian designers and manufacturers who are showing their fall 79 collections right now. (Next comes Paris, then New York.) This week there will not be an empty hotel room, nook or cranny in this sprawling industrial city as the world's store buyers, press and hangerson all hoping for a fresh idea  converge in an often chaotic mass.

title: Will Orange County Housing Lead the Way Down?; The Bellwether
description: LAGUNA HILLS, Calif.  They stand in neat rows, empty houses that can find no buyers.

title: In Defense of Welfare Laws
description: MUCH has been written in the past few months regarding the controversy between the state and the city of Bordentown.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: WHEN any level or branch of government malfunctions on a grand scale, it is widely reported in the media. However, the little malfunctions  those that do not affect many people directly, but may be more important in the long runget very little publicity.

title: For a Contest Judge, It's Nolo Contendere
description: THE entries have been trickling in. A long manuscript by two students named Scott was accompanied by an impressive letter from their school principal. A newspaper article arrived from either Bridgewater or Woodbridge  I've forgotten which  and no doubt others will follow.

title: Notre Dame To Present Award to Helen Hayes
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 24  Helen Hayes, who is often called the first lady of the American stage, has been awarded the University of Notre Dame's Laetare Medal, the oldest of honors accorded American Roman Catholics.

title: Topics Out of Focus
description: In response to President Carter's suggestion that Government agencies participate in the 1979 International Year of the Child, the Transportation Department proposes to film teenagers at bus terminals around the country. Videotapes would be used to develop psychological profiles of young runaways, so as somehow to protect them from bad guys.

title: Liberal Hopes and Achievements
description: IN January 1944, with the Allied fortunes in World War II finally turning, President Franklin D. Roosevelt devoted his State of the Union address to a vision of the postwar society. Roosevelt's economic bill of rights, with its seemingly utopian promises of a guaranteed job, education, medical care, decent home, protection from the economic fears of old age, and so much more, accurately forecast what postwar liberalism would attempt.

title: De Paul, Penn Victims
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 24  Indiana State's undefeated basketball team had a much more difficult time winning than Michigan State did today as the two Midwestern colleges reached the final of the 41st annual National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tournament.

title: TV VIEW
description: In Harris and Company, a weekly series currently on a trial run on NBC, the widowed father is noble and saintly enough to make Daddy in Father Knows Best look like an insensitive meanie. Normally, this kind of phenomenon might be allowed to pass quietly into the electronic night of failed projects. But, in this case, the father, played by Bernie Casey with his usual stately dignity, is black. And this provides an example, in perfect miniature, of the sensitive question of the portrayal of minorities on television.

title: Westchester Income Levels Rise
description: WASHINGTON NEXT to Manhattan, Westchester has the highest per capita income levels among New York State's 62 counties and also continues to increase its income margin over its neighbors.

title: How to Play It Safe
description: NEWARK ALL ACROSS New Jersey, baseball teams little and big are starting their spring rituals with tryouts and practices. Coincidentally, on Thursday, the Division of Sports Medicine at the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey will offer a daylong symposium on baseball injuries.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Being of diehard feminist persuasion, I found my fancy caught by the title of Gloria Stashower's article, Can Women Succeed as Commuters? [March 4]. Aha, I said to myself, finally someone is going to deal with the difficult choice that many women are faced With: motherhood vs. career. When a woman joins the ranks of cattlecar commuters, one can almost assume that she is involved in a much more interesting, more challenging job than one that serves mainly to stave off impending boredom. It is more than likely that in this case, the lady is fighting her way up the ladder of success.

title: Hong Kong Governor Off to China, Marking Trend Toward Better Ties
description: HONG KONG, March 24  Sir Murray Maclehose left for Canton today on the first official visit to China by a Governor of Hong Kong since the Communists won power in 1949. The trip marks what some officials here like to call the normalization of relations between this small British colony and its Communist neighbor.

title: THE MILLION DOLLAR QUARTET
description: On a chilly day in late January 1957, a young singer and his band were huddled in a tiny recording studio in Memphis, Tenn. They had completed four songs and were taking a break when the street door was flung open and in strolled a jaunty young man and a girl, a dancer from the New Frontier Club in Las Vegas. Within minutes, all thought of continuing the session was abandoned. The recording engineer and the producer and a friend of the singer's came out of the control booth and joined in the excited talk about what the visitor had been up to lately. Was he really going to be drafted into the Army? The piano player  blond, brash and just 21 years old  demanded to be introduced, and eventually the visitor sat down at the piano and the other musicians grouped around him. The producer had his secretary call the newspapers while the musicians started fooling around with their instruments and someone started to sing. Then the engineer started the tape rolling  a tape that rumor would enshrine as the onceinalifetime music of the Million Dollar Quartet.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Kaufman Becomes Bride Of a Student
description: Susan Godbey Kaufmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kaufmann of New York and Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles Theodore Harris 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. C.T. Harris of Charlotte, N.C. The ceremony was performed at the Kaufmann home on Brush Island in Darien by the Rev. Donald B. Holmes, a Congregational minister.

title: Love and Madness
description: Caroline and Maggie, seniors at a Manhattan private school, both children of divorced parents, have simultaneous love affairs  Caroline with Justin, the 28yearold married (but separated) science teacher for whom she babysits, and Maggie with Todd, a boy from another school, whom she meets during a debating contest. Maggie, a raging feminist, fights the pull toward committed love that draws Caroline so dangerously. The problem is options  Is emotional security more important than freedom to search for one's own identity? Is marriage a valid alternative or a copout? The real question is, is this an adult book or a juvenile? The publisher says it will sell this one as an adult novel, but Miss Klein has written juveniles before, and I would suggest that she has done it again.

title: The Region
description: Continued

title: Where All Big Wheels Roll Along the Rocky Road to Glory
description: GOOD Evening, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the annual Macadamy Awards as we salute those people ... Here, the emcee paused to throw a salute at the audience: You, the people who make life on New Jersey's highways so full of excitement and adventure.

title: Carey Lynn Snyder Is Engaged
description: Carey Lynn Snyder and Ralph M. Gangitano plan to be married in June. Mr. and Mrs. Edward Snyder of Greenwich, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. James Gangitano of Eastchester, N.Y., and the late Mr. Gangitano. The future bride is a commercial interior designer with Neville Lewis Associates. Mr. Gangitano is vice president of R & G Affiliates Inc., dealer in office furniture.

title: Sunday Observer Cold Power
description: I recently worked in a group that was sharing a cold. One of the first people to take his turn at it went to a doctor who charged him $90 for the visit and called it tonsillitis.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Carter Horsley's article, [Communities Start to Challenge Gaudy Displays By Retailers, March 4] affords me the opportunity of again raising an important issue and that is the creation of a Design Review Board.

description: STAMFORD, Conn.  In the battle over harbor dredging, to the losers belong the spoils.

title: Bishop Loughlin Wins Team Track Titles

Bishop Loughlin, however, won the boys and girls team championships.

title: ANTIQUES
description: COLCHESTER SOMETIMES in this business you feel as if you were a detective looking for clues to solve a mystery, Arthur Liverant, a member of the wellknown antiques firm of N. Liverant & Sons remarked last week. Mr. Liverant referred to the research necessary to determine the history of a painting, identify the artist and his subject, or sometimes to discover the place and time a picture represents.

title: PPG: Out of the Frying Pan
description: PITTSBURGH  It is the nation 's largest maker of flat glass and ranks among the leading producers of coatings and resins, chemicals and fiber glass, yet PPG Industries is not one of your household words. It had sales last year of $2.79 billion, but few security analysts follow the company.
