title: HOME CLINIC
description: WASHING machines have electrically operated valves that control the flow of water into the machines by turning it on and off as needed. These valves will shut the water off rather quickly, and this sometimes causes a condition known as water hammer in which the pipes bang or hammer each time the water flow is interrupted.

title: Dances of Carol Conway Performed by Her Troupe
description: Carol Conway's choreography for the Carol Conway Dance Company Friday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, seesawed evenly between puremovement pieces and more dramatic works.

title: Charles (Chic) Anderson Dies; Well Known Race Caller Was 47; Inauspicious Start
description: Charles (Chic) Anderson, a nationally known caller of thoroughbred races, who had been an announcer for the New York Racing Association regularly since May 23, 1977, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Commack. L.I. He was 47 years old. His family said that funeral arrangements were incomplete and that burial would be in Evansville, lnd., where Mr. Anderson was born.

title: Catering To Fashion
description: BY her own admission, Linda Williams runs a catering service. But don't expect to munch on her offerings, unless you have a taste for cotton, wool or dacron.

title: Notes: Bicycle Touring, NightCoach
description: It is time once again to get out the 10speed bicycle, clean off the winter dust and check its tires  for three different cycling organizations have announced schedules for the 1979 season.

title: Baltimore's Black Community Angry Over Rioting
description: BALTIMORE, March 24 (AP)  The city's black community, rejecting oftenused social justifications for looting and rioting, has expressed anger and frustration over recent rioting here. It is an unusual community response to the sort of civil outbreaks that for 15 years have erupted from time to time in many of the nation's minority residential areas.

title: Caroline Remembers
description: CAROLINE MACLAREN, the 90yearold widow of a famous American composer and the heroinememoirist of Doris Grumbach's novel, has been asked by the Maclaren Foundation to set down a record of her life with Robert Maclaren, and of her life alone in the Maclaren Community after his early death. Confessions, in the modern sense, don't come easy to her, she warns us, because she grew up in a time when a scrim of silence surrounded what really happened in our lives. ... Secrets were surely no better kept than they are now, but they lived quietly under the breath. ... We closeted our secrets, or forgot them. This we called decorum. ... But now all the witnesses, family and lovers are dead, and Caroline announces her intention to put down extraordinary truths  for someone of her time.

title: D.J. Winton 2d Is Fianc Of Charlotte L. Vaughan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Vaughan of Wayzata, Minn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Charlotte Lindley Vaughan, to David J. Winton 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Winton, also of Wayzata. A May 26 wedding is planned.

title: A Team Effort Assists Schools in a Pinch
description: SETAUKET SOME customers may not have realized it, but having a raincoat cleaned at the Stony Brook Cleaners during January and February helped pay for student publications, teams and other programs of the Three Village School District that have been affected by an austerity budget.

title: Gas Stations Feel Tides Of Change
description: CITING the effects of recent cuts in deliveries from major oil companies and saying they fear possible shortages of gasoline by the end of the month, some of the state's gasoline retailers have begun to reduce their hours and impose limits on the amount a motorist can purchase.

title: Unauthorized and Admiring
description: This is Sophia Loren's life story (so far; she is not yet 45). It has enough drama, heartache and glory for at least four movies. Its reality puts the fic

title: Syracuse Growing as Its Style Changes
description: SYRACUSE, March 24  For more than a month, demolition crews have been working to demolish the 65yearold Eckel Theater, a oncepopular night spot on East Fayette Street here that fell into disuse. But, across the street, construction has begun on 1 Financial Plaza, a fivestory commercial building that, by year's end, will house offices of the Key Bank, the Travelers Insurance Company and a local law firm.

title: Diane M. Dokuchitz Engaged to Ensign
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter S. Dokuchitz of Unadilla, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Marie Dokuchitz, to Ens. John Spotswood Bowers, U.S.C.G., son of Mrs. Wolcott Bowers of Cooperstown, N.Y., and Sampson Pendleton Bowers of Carmel, Calif.A wedding is planned in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Oneonta, N.Y., on Aug. 4.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: STUDENTS at the State University of New York at Purchase say they are considering a court challenge to keep the college from changing the academic calendar to two 15week semesters. The calendar is now divided into semesters of 12 weeks and four weeks.

title: Sadat's Peace Path: From Never to a Pact
description: CAIRO, March 24  Don't ask me to make diplomatic relations with them, Anwar elSadat once said when asked to define his terms for peace with Israel. Never. Never. Leave it to the coming generations to decide that, not me.

title: The Region In Summary
description: When public officials start trotting out statistics to justify the soundness of their decisions, that's often the time that doubts arise about the accuracy of the figures. Such was the case last week, when City Hall reported that Mayor Koch's declared war on subway crime was turning into a rout. Three days after 900 uniformed officers were assigned to nighttime trains and to most of the system's 460 stations, officials claimed that the rate of crimes reported in an average day had been roughly halved.

title: 9 Named to Presidential Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) President Carter has appointed nine persons to the President's Committee on the National Medal of Science. Appointed on wednesday were W. Dale Compton, Birmingham, Mich.; Carl Djerassi, Stanford University; Mary Lowe Good, University of New Orleans; Leon M. Lederman, Columbia University; Calvin C. Moore and John R. Whinnery, University of California at Berkeley; Dorothy M. Simon, Greenwich, Conn.; John B. Slaughter, Chevy Chase, Md., and Steven Weinberg. Harvard University.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: NEW HYDE PARK WHEN he moved to Wantagh in 1943, Bill Chadwick was hardly an instant celebrity. Not only had few people there ever heard of him, he said, few of them even heard of the National Hockey League.

title: Leslie Kucker to Be the Bride Of Mitchell Modell on July8
description: Harriet Kucker of Woodmere, LI., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Leslie Kucker, to Mitchell Bruce Modell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Modell of Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

title: Barbara S. Wolf Married To Kenneth B. Shiers
description: Barbara Susan Wolf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Wolf of New York, was married yesterday evening to Kenneth B. Shiers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Shiers of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Tower Suite.

title: New Jersey Moves to Protect Its Shifting, but Valuable Sands
description: TRENTON  Over the years, New Jersey has spent millions on often uncoordinated attempts to protect its beaches from Atlantic Ocean currents and storms. Now the state is about to have the most comprehensive erosion control plan in the country, according to those in charge. It will be overseen and enforced by a state agency and include a prohibition on further construction on the beaches.

title: Carter Considers Oil Price Decontrol
description: What does the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have in store? The oil cartel convenes a special meeting tomorrow in Geneva amid speculation about further price increases and production cutbacks.

title: Direct Presidential Elections  The Cases Pro and Con
description: WASHINGTON  In the 1976 Presidential election, a shift of fewer than 10,000 votes in Ohio and Hawaii would have given Gerald R. Ford 270 electoral votes to Jimmy Carter's 268, keeping the Republican in the White House despite a popular majority of nearly 1.7 million votes for the Democrat. A shift of fewer than 15,000 votes in Ohio and Delaware would have left each contender with 269 electoral votes, and the decision would have passed to the House of Representatives, with each state entitled to one vote. If all House members had voted their party, Carter would have overwhelmed Ford, 36 to 11, with three states  New Hampshire, New Mexico and Virginia  unable to vote because their delegations were evenly divided.

title: Hidden in a German Fog
description: HUNDREDS of thousands of Germans have recently seen installments of Holocaust, the television program about the destruction German Jews under the Nazis, and, according to a friend of mine who was in Munich at the time, crowds walked about the streets for hours in stunned silence after seeing them. That a soapopera treatment of mass slaughter should have awakened German consciousness on such a scale is relevant to Daniel Lang's book, in which he reports on attitudes toward the Hitler period of Germans he interviewed for a series of articles published in The New Yorker in 1977 that form part of his book.

title: Investing in Park Slope Revival
description: Ten years ago Peter and Barbara Saltini bought a brownstone in the Park Slope area of Brooklyn. They moved in full of hope for longterm neighborhood improvement. Three years later neighborhood troubles had begun to fray the edges of these hopes.

title: Syracuse AT A GLANCE
description: Twentyfive square miles of rolling hills near the geographic center of New York State. It is the snowiest major city in the United States, with an average annual Snowfall of 110.7 inches. Syracuse is second, behind Seattle, for the title of cloudiest major city

description: WHEN the forsythia blooms, prune the roses. This signal is one of the most reliable timetables nature provides. For the opening of the forsythia flowers indicates that the growing season is beginning.

title: Around the Nation
description: PEORIA, III., March 24 (AP)  The Illinois River began falling today at Peoria, signaling better days ahead for thousands who fled their homes in some of the worst flooding in area history. Officials estimated damage in the millions of dollars.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Sensible people have a right to shudder at what is happening to photography now that it is being taught in the art schools and university art departments of this fair land. And they will not he reassured by exhibitions like the one now on view at the New Museum, 66 Fifth Avenue at 14th Street. through April 14.

title: REFUGEES FACE GUNS AT PIER IN MALAYSIA;
description: MERSING, Malaysia, March 19  At 8:30 P.M. on a recent Friday, 219 Vietnamese pulled up to the dark dock in the river channel here in a 42foot fishing craft.

title: Realty News Soft Landing Seen For Housing Market
description: The nation's housing market is headed for a soft landing from its 1978 peak, according to Robert J. Mylod, president of the Advance Mortgage Corporation, which has just completed its survey of housing trends in 17 metropolitan areas and 20 other significant markets.

title: RIDING THE SAUDI BOOM
description: His black TransAm sports car creeps along the Corniche Road on the edge of the Red Sea. To the left, skyscrapers jab into the humid air, a sight made more impressive by the desolation surrounding the ancient city of Jidda. Blaring horns mark one of the four daily rush hours. Absentmindedly, Ahmed honks his horn, too, though he's not in a hurry. He's in a fine mood. Not in the least concerned, for example, that there are those who talk about today's Saudi Arabia as though it were tomorrow's Iran. This 17yearold has just returned from a twomonth visit to England and excitedly relates the business deals he has been cooking up.

title: Koch Poll Finds 96% Would Donate Service To City in Emergency
description: More than 96 percent of the New York City municipal employees who replied to an informal questionnaire from Mayor Koch said they would volunteer to work overtime without pay during emergencies such as last summer's outbreak of legionnaires disease.

title: ART
description: JERSEY CITY A PHOTOGRAPH often remains just that: an inanimate object. The photographer has failed to make the physical characteristics of the object become something more than a combination of lines, mass and light. He has failed to give it a life of its own.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 25, 1979

title: Program Finds Jobs For Older Residents
description: WHITE PLAINS FOR Dorothy Brown, finding a job was a headache. For three and a half years, she made trips each week to the unemployment office looking for work.

title: New Head of Drug Abuse Center
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)  Dr. William Pollin today was named director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse. Now the director of research at the agency, he will succeed Dr. Robert L. Dupont, who resigned last July. Dr. Pollin, 57 years old, has been with the institute since its inception in 1973.

title: Gasoline Stations Retrenching
description: CITING the effects of recent cuts in deliveries by the major oil companies, more and more gasoline stations in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut are reducing the number of days they are open each week, shortening their hours and limiting sales to customers.

title: Why Hollywood Still Goes by the Book
description: Despite the muchtalkedabout film generation, the rash of new film schools, the growing prestige of movies and the visually oriented generation that grew up on television, American moviemakers are still looking to the literary world for material. The movie rights for Michael Crichton's next novel were recently sold to 20th CenturyFox for seven figures, while in similar development, Peter Benchley was reportedly paid a whopping $2.15 million for his next work, The Island. It is clear that some major novelists are beginning to wield the kind of power in Hollywood once held by only two or three directors and handful of stars. Nicholas Meyer, author of the bestselling SevenPerCent Solution (which was also a successful movie), is currently directing his own films, as is Michael Crichton, whose justreleased movie version of his own novel The Great Train Robbery has become a success. Paul Erdman, author of The Crash of 79, was paid $1 million to write a novel entitled Atlantic City in anticipation of film. Authors like James Michener have been known to demand a percentage of the gross profits on films. And Harold Robbins even has enough clout to run his own production company.

title: More Funds Sought for Care of Troubled Children
description: Concerned about the growing number of children that the public welfare system is maintaining outside their homes, the Carter Administration and members of Congress are moving to shift Federal financial incentives in an effort to reverse the trend.

title: The Competency Tests: Still No Answers
description: REGENT J., Edward Meyer of Armonk says he thinks they're terrific. Donald Ryan, president of the White Plains Board of Education, says he doesn't like them. The president of Bank Street College, Francis Roberts, recently ridiculed them, while Regent Kenneth Clark of Hastings strongly opposes any move to make them easier. Frank Macchiarola, Chancellor of the New York City schools, is very unhappy about them, and his feelings are probably Shared by most of the schools superintendents in Westchester County.

title: Business That Outgrew Home
description: IsLIp, L.I. THEY'RE on their boat and something has gone wrong. With the depth sounder, the direction finder, the bilge sensor, the knot meter, the tracer, hailer, radio, or Lorans ... What to do?

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: NOW that I'm old enough and rich enough to play indoor tennis at one of the posh Westchester courts, it's not working out. After the first halfhour of the game, I can't seem to remember the score. I keep shouting game when only one point has been played, and at other times when the game is really over, I can't quite grasp where all went.

title: Walter Marting Jr. And Nina Wemyss, Teacher, Are Wed
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle in Brookville, L.I., yesterday evening, Nina Anna Wemyss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Francis Wemyss of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I., became the bride of Walter Adelbert Marling Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mart ing of Gates Mills, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Galloway.

Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through April 21). $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

description: Kennebec Dories  a company that runs whitewater trips in wooden boats that are reproductions of the traditional dories used by Maine fishermen and loggers  will run its 1979 river trips from Memorial Day weekend to Labor Day.

title: INTERVIEW A Priest Who Helps Divorced Catholics
description: EAST ORANGE DESPITE several statements by Pope John Paul II on divorce, which some Roman Catholics regarded as characterizing divorce as something evil, there will be no lessening of the church's drive to reach out to divorced, separated and remarried Catholics.

title: Old Factory Towns
description: CAMDEN, N.J.  Come to Camden and pray. The St. James Apostle Temple has taken over one of the banks downtown. The Camden Miracle Center was a movie theater; the Pentecostal Church was a Horn & Hardart's. A worndown Woolworth's is still open, but Lit's, a department store which dominated the Broadway shopping hub, fled after racial rioting eight years ago. Unemployment, at 11 percent, is nearly double the national rate, and half the city is on public assistance  welfare or social security.

title: Transit Police Seize 2 After Man Is Shoved Onto Subway Tracks
description: Two young men, saying they were plainclothes Transit Police, confronted 50yearold man in a subway station in the South Bronx early yesterday morning, frisked him, went through his pockets, found nothing and, finally, shoved him onto the train tracks, the police said.

title: Democrats Rushing In To Contest Davits Seat
description: When John V. Lindsay gave up a sunny Saturday 's relaxation last weekend to trek to Buffalo for a St. Patrick 's Day luncheon, it wasn 't just to hear mistyeyed talk of leprechauns. Andrew Stein, President of the Borough of Manhattan, has added 12 political operatives to the city payroll; he 's not gearing up for the 1981 municipal elections.

title: Ranger Fever Spreads
description: ANN and Marianne had flown in from Toronto. Sue and Donny had driven from Philadelphia, as they have at least 20 times before and the rest were from Westchester and New York City. They all gathered around the side entrance to the Westchester Ice Skating Center in Hawthorne. Cameras focused and autographs were awaited.

title: THE MARKETS The Dow Hits a 5Month High
description: Stock prices pushed ahead last week to their highest levels since last October as the Dow Jones industrials, extending a flashy string of gains during March, rose 6.93 points to finish at 859.75.

title: MUSIC
description: I HAVE long felt that there ought to be more cultural traffic across the WestchesterFairfield border, that New Yorkers should more readily partake of the musical bounties of such nearby Connecticut towns as Stamford, Greenwich and New Canaan, while Fairfield folk should embrace the concert enticements just a few minutes drive away, in places like Mamaroneck, Rye and Mount Vernon. After all, if Israel and Egypt can work it out. . .

title: A Key Habitat for Birds Is Saved by British Unit
description: LONDON, March 24 (Reuters)  A British conservation group has bought a marshland considered to be one of the nation's most important bird habitats, saving the area from being converted to agricultural use.

title: Islanders Get 33 Tie On Kaszycki's Goal
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.. March 24 The Islanders, after their highspirited victory over Montreal last Thursday in the Forum, suffered a letdown tonight against the Pittsburgh Penguins at Nassau Coliseum. The New Yorkers needed a thirdperiod goal from Mike Kaszycki to gain a 33 tie.

title: Government Is Unwitting Source Of Air Craft for Drug Smugglers
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)  The pilot called for help as an old plane spottered toward an emergency landing at a small airport near Miami, and fire engines went to the runway.

title: Pentagon Is Accused of Understating by More Than 130 the Number of Americans to Be Sent to Yemen
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  A Democratic Congressman charged today that the number of American military instructors to be sent to Yemen would reach 230 , more than double the total announced by the Pentagon.

title: ToBreakfast or Not to Breakfast?; Women Who Make Breakfast
description: There are thousands of people who don't give a twit for breakfast. They don't eat it, they don't miss it, and they think the subject is just about as important as Patty Hearst's wedding gown.

description: Karen Alice DeCavalcante, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael R. Decaval cante of Wynnewood, was married yesterday to Salvatore J Monaco, son of Mr. arid Mrs. Vincent Monaco of Brooklyn. The Rev. James ??. a Roman Catholic priest. perform?? the ceremony In the ?? Chapel of the Church Center of the united Nations.

title: 5 Murders Suspected As Possible Aftermath Of Lufthansa Holdup
description: The authorities working to solve the $5.8 million robbery of Lufthansa's cargo building at Kennedy International Airport last Dec. 11 now suspect that five people may have been murdered in connection with the holdup.

title: Toy Maker Sued in Child's Death
description: ATLANTA, March 23 (AP)  The parents of a 4yearold boy who died when a toy missile lodged in his throat filed suits today seeking $14 million from Mattel Inc., the manufacturer of the toy. The parents are John D. Warren and his wife, Doris Warren, of Gwinnett County near Atlanta. Their son, Robert Jeffery, died last Dec. 31.

title: F.A.A. Ruling Is Likely to Curb Reports of Hazards
description: The Federal Aviation Administration plans to issue a new directive tomorrow that, starting on April 30, will sharply curtail the ability of those violating airsafety rules to avoid punishment by turning themselves in.

title: Goldfish in Water Pitchers
description: MUNSTER, France, March 24 (Reuters)  Restaurant owners in this eastern French town are providing an odd service for their customers  goldfish, shrimps and frogs in the water pitchers. They are protesting a regulation obliging them to put a jug of tap water on every table. The rule is aimed at stopping restaurant staff from bullying diners into paying high prices for bottled mineral water.

title: When You're Here Is There No Here Here?
description: IT'S time to beg the British to come back. Yes, I know. But they broke Enigma (the German code in World War II), didn't they?

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Flamingo Is a Romp For Spectacular Bid
description: HIALEAH, Fla., March 24  Hang on, Ronnie! bawled Ron Franklin's public as the 19yearold jockey paraded Spectacular Bid in the walking ring before the 50th running of the Flamingo Stakes today.

title: The Corporate World Is Her Beat
description: It 's important that we know everything, says Ron LeNoue, a pale, gaunt 25yearold. We have to establish our credibility.

title: Human Voices
description: In his new book on the Fugitives, Louis Rubin contends that the chief Southern writers of the 1920's and 30's were as successful as they had hoped to be.

title: When a Famous Architect Designed the House for Sale
description: For the third tim in 11 years, the Stuart Richardn house in Glen Ridge, N.J., is for sale. And for the third time Virginia Flick, a Glen Ridge real estate broker, stands between the house and buyers who would alter its Frank Lloyd Wright design.

title: Bulls Defeat Knicks In Double Overtime
description: Ollie Johnson was the unlikely hero in the Chicago Bulls 148143 doubleovertime victory over the Knicks last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Minnesota Takes Hockey Title
description: DETROIT, March 24  The University of Minnesota, taking a 31 lead in the first period, went on to a 43 victory over the University of North Dakota tonight at the Olympia to capture the National Collegiate hockey title.

title: Toll Traps: The FloridaBound Motorist's New Nemesis
description: There was a time when an automobile trip to Florida was not complete without the threat, if not the reality, of the bigbellied Southern police officer hiding behind a sign waiting to apprehend unwary Northern motorists.

title: Miss Chuma and Dennis Dance
description: Yoshiko Chuma and Charles Dennis are two young experimental dancerchoreographers who have appeared with a number of avantgarde theater and dance groups. On Friday they performed an untitled but apparently jointly choreographed dance at the Third Street Music School that indicated an interest in natural movement, in the name of which a good many sins are committed these days. In its unassuming way, this was an hour of dance that was a refreshing model of simplicity and understated wit.

title: Food Pasta for a Party
description: People who like to entertain are constantly on the lookout for a main course that is festive enough to be special yet can be made and served in one dish  thus minimizing the dreaded cleaningup process. A dish of lasagna is a firstrate solution to the dilemma of what to serve a party of 12 or more (and it is easy to double or triple the quantities). The problem, however, that in America most people's lasagna is apt to taste very much like that of their neighbors: a standard compendium of lasagna noodles, meat sauce, mozzarella and ricotta cheeses.

title: Urologist Is Fianc Of Robin Goland
description: Robin Goland, a thirdyear student at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, and Dr. John Birkhoff, a New York urologist, plan to be married April 22.

title: State Seeking New Regulations For Private Vocational Schools;
description: ALBANY, March 22  The state proposed new rules this week that would require private business and vocational schools to keep detailed records on attendance, admission and financial aid and would enable students who drop out to recover much of their tuition.

title: DINING OUT Style Is a Specialty, but.. .
description: IN many small or upstate or Middle Western cities, a place like the Lake House in West Sayville would probably be the best restaurant in town. All the niceties are observed, including embossed pewter service plates, a wellordered hierarchy of dining room personnel, big names like escargot, filet mignon and lobster tails on the menu, and a dish of celery and olives and a loaf of warm bread on a board.

title: Rudel Reflects on the City Opera
description: Does Julius Rudel feel a bit overlooked and unappreciated these days? After 36 years with the City Opera, 22 of them as the company's director and chief conductor,

title: REINVENTING CARS GAINS MORE BACKING
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  Transportation Secretary Brock Adams was nearly laughed out of Detroit three months ago when he called on the nation's automobile industry to reinvent the car. He was not quite sure what he was appealing for. he acknowledged, and industry executives were even less certain.

title: State Grant to Provide Sod for Sheep Meadow
description: New York State will give the city $310,000 to resod the wornout Sheep Meadow in Central Park, Governor Carey announced yesterday.

title: Peace on Campuses: What the Pact Does
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE $14 million settlement that ended last week's oneday strike by faculty members at eight state colleges and gave them an average $1,200ayear raise put in place for the first time at those schools a salaryincrease plan based on merit.

title: Editors' Choice
description: ALBERT CAMUS, by Herbert R. Lottman. (Doubleday, $16.95.) This first biography of a French writer who was more a cult than a man offers all the facts but renders no judgments.

title: Kathy Ellen Sperber Affianced
description: Anncuncement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Sperber of Mamaroneck, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Kathy Ellen Sperber, to Robert Jay Chalfin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Chalfin of Fords, N. J.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The most fascinating show in New York right now, from this museum goer's point of view, is an exhibition with the rather obscure name of MA, Space/Time in Japan at the CooperHewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design at 2 East 91st Street.

title: Nurses Assume Bigger Role in Health Care
description: LITTLETON, Colo.  Stethoscope around her neck, tongue depressor in hand, Ann Lemoine moved swiftly back and forth across the toy and instrumentfilled clinic room as she examined 3yearold Tyler Zimmerman and his baby brother, Travis.

title: Steichen's Photo Collection Given to Eastman House
description: In a move that has caught the world of photography by surprise, the negatives and prints of the late Edward Steichen will be entrusted to the International Museum of Photography at the George Eastman House in Rochester, and not to the Museum of Modern Art, where Steichen was for 15 years director of the department of photography.

title: Strike at Volkswagen Is Averted
description: NEW STANTON, Pa., March 24 (AP)  Operations continued without interruption today at Volkswagen's United States assembly plant after the company and the United Automobile Workers settled a list of grievances. The union had threatened to stage a walkout by 3,500 members today unless the company agreed to improve safety and working conditions.

title: Wayne State Captures N.C.A.A. Fencing Title
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 24 (AP)  Yuri Rabinovich scored a 52 fenceoff victory over Mike Sullivan of Notre Dame, a twotime defender, and led Wayne State to the team title in the 35th National Collegiate fencing championships today.

title: Beauty The New Spring Crop
description: Short hair is chic again. Women who once struggled with blowdryers, curling irons, setting lotions or hot rollers are now reveling in the freedom of shortcropped, washandwear hair. This year, the growing trend toward briefer hair was given an extra boost by Cher, that dazzling entertainer with the long black mane. Cher just pared down her hair to a smooth, skullhugging cap  and made big news. And so did that top eyestopping fashion model Esme (above), who burst on the scene with a mop trimmed to a minimum.

title: Oil, as the Catalyst, Is Blending New Orleans and Houston Styles
description: NEW ORLEANS  Ruthie the Duck Lady, so called because a pet duck follows her around, and Pork Chop, an aging tap dancer in the Bojangles style, are Runyonesque fixtures in the French Quarter. These days they dance for bistro customers tips, not only to Dixieland jazz, but also to the Texasflavored country and western music that has lately been added to the Bourbon Street gumbo.

title: Poor Schools Oppose Carey Plan
description: PATCHOGUE, L.I., March 24  Administrators of about 30 poor Long Island school districts declared today that they would challenge in the courts the proposed new state budget if it did not include Governor Carey's recommendation for a revision of schoolaid formulas to benefit districts with low realestate tax bases.

title: What's Doing in the SOUTHERN TIER
description: THE REGION  The Southern Tier of New York State, which stretches along the northern border of Pennsylvania for hundreds of miles, is largely terra incognita for most metropolitan New Yorkers. Because of that, it is an area of many unspoiled attractions. The region, encompassing seven counties of the state with unfamiliar names  Broome, Tioga, Chemung, Steuben, Allegany, Cattaraugus and Chautauqua  begins west of the familiar Catskill Mountains and ends on the shores of Lake Erie southwest of Buffalo. Roads through the Southern Tier traverse the scenic hills of New York's own Appalachia, the northern end of the beautiful ridges of Pennsylvania and West Virginia.

title: Conrail and Union Reach Accord
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (AP)Conrail, the federally chartered rail freight system, and the Brotherhood of Railroad and Airline Clerks reached an agreement in principle yesterday on a 39month contract retroactive to Jan. 1, 1978. The new pact will cover 20,000 railroad employees in 17 states, said the union president, Fred J. Kroll Conrail employees already have voted to accept the package, which calls for wage and fringe benefit increases of 36 percent over the 39month period.

title: Rebecca Jane Anderson Is Wed to Daniel Kitchin
description: The Roseland (N.J.) Presbyterian Church was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Rebecca Jane Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis B. Anderson of Essex Fells, N.J.,to Daniel Michael Kitchin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Neal R. Kitchin of Woodbury, Conn. The Rev. Charles H. Peet performed the ceremony.

title: Askew to Head Refugee Panel
description: WASHINGTON. March 24 (AP) President Carter has appointed former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida as chairman of the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy.

title: A Quiet Retreat on the Irish Coast
description: In County Cork they say that every stone thrown in Belfast means one less tourist for the south of Ireland. These words might apply in certain quarters of Eire, but they definitely do not in Kinsale, where tourism is booming.

title: Judith Lynn Harris Is Fiance Of Steven Austin, Consultant
description: Mr. and Mrs. Don R. Harris have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Lynn Harris, to Steven David Austin, son of Beulah Austin of Hackensack, N.J., and the late Maurice S. Austin.

title: Rene Marques, Writer From Puerto Rico, 59
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 24 (AP)Rene Marques, one of Puerto Rico's most acclaimed writers, died Thursday at the age of 59.

title: Springtime Chores By the Seaside
description: Spring comes late to my seashore garden. The salt water which keeps the shore garden warm and blooming into November, also keeps it cooler at this time of year. always become impatient to get started.

title: Trapping of Animals Worries North Shore
description: STONY BROOK WRILE international interest is focused on the struggle between animal lovers and seal hunters in Canada, a similar and equally intense battle has been brewing in Suffolk County.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: ART
description: WHITE PLAINS THE lot of tapestries in the modern age has not been favorable. They have been unkindly thought of as items of decoration, perhaps only slightly better than wall paper. They have been chosen as adjuncts for domestic color schemes or as backdrops for furniture and lobby dcor. No one ever seems to pay as much attention to them as to a painting or a sculpture.

title: Concerto for Virtuosos and School Groups
description: ?? AT first glance, the group on the stage of the South Woods Junior High School auditorium looked like any other school orchestra. But wait. Was there among the youngsters, an occasional wrinkled brow, a head of gray or a pair of hands that held an instrument with an unusual confidence?

title: Stuart Katz Fianc Of Suzanne Shemin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Shemin of Greenwich, Conn., and Hillsdale, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Shemin, to Stuart B. Katz, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold W. Katz of Ann Arbor, Mich. The couple will be married Aug. 26 at the Shemin home in Greenwich.

title: A Survivor of 18 Seasons Recalls Beauty of Hockey
description: You'll never make it in the National Hockey League, my junior coach, Hap Emms, told me. You're not tough enough.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, March 25

title: Japan 's Shift Toward China Takes a Lurch Into Reverse
description: TOKYO  And so the love affair between Japan and China lasted a short three months . .. .

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Crumlish Wed in Capital
description: In the Copley Chapel ?? of ?? ton yesterday, ?? ish, a ?? ?? to Werth ?? for of the Fondo del ?? Media Center in Washington ?? Thumas King performed the ?? Catholic ceremony.

title: WASHINGTON The Forgotten Servants
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  With the signing of the IsraeliEgyptian peace treaty, maybe a few words should be said for the large cast of characters that made possible this historic but still unfinished chapter in the history of the Middle East.

title: California Captures Swim Title
description: CLEVELAND, March 24  The National Collegiate swimming championships ended today at the Cleveland State University Natatorium with these historical developments:

title: Indiana State Story: Implausible Success
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 24  The star once worked on a garbage truck. the condition of both his psyche and his left thumb has been discussed in hundreds of newspapers. He has scored more points and grabbed more rebounds than most college basketball players. That is why he is the star.

title: JIM JONES 1960 VISIT TO CUBA RECOUNTED
description: The Rev. Jim Jones spent tour weeks in Havana in 1960, making plans to recruit 40 black families as the initial members of what was eventually to become the People's Temple, according to a naturalized Cuban who says he worked for Mr. Jones then.

title: Misses Navratilova And Austin in Final
description: Other than having her two favorite tennis racquets stolen by a New York cabbie the other day, it has been a peaceful week for Martina Navratilova. No temperamental traumas on the court, good times with Grandma Subertova, not even a deuce set in three matches at the women's wintertour championships.

title: Marvin Gaye Tests The Limits
description: In the hierarchy of emotional states the condition known as sour grapes occupies a lowly place, somewhere below regret and just above outright vindictiveness. Yet this niggardly emotion, which lacks any but the flimsiest vestige of nobility, has been responsible for some of the most golden moments in recent popular music. Several of Elvis Costello's love songs come to mind, and much of the Rolling Stones album Some Girls, and most recently an extraordinary tworecord set from Marvin Gaye, Here, My Dear. Mr. Gaye's album, a long rumination on the end of his marriage, goes further than its predecessors. It complains bitterly about the terms of the divorce settlement, it addresses the departed spouse by name, and it flaunts the macho selfpabsorption that must have had something to do with the marriage's faltering in the first place. The title is to be taken literally; Mr. Gaye is presenting the album to his exwife, since he has filed for bankruptcy and she will presumably be collecting royalties from it before he does. (Though curiously enough, no publisher is listed for any of the original songs on the album.)

title: New Wave of Trapping in Suffolk Is Denounced by Local Pet Owners
description: STONY BROOK, L.I.  While international Interest is focused on the struggle between animal lovers and seal hunters in Canada, a similar and equally intense battle has been brewing here in Suffolk County.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: AND I WORKED AT THE WRITER'S TRADE, by Malcolm Cowley. (Penguin, $3.95.) The situations and problems of American writers from Greenwich Village and Paris in the 20's through the Great Depression to the youth movements of the 60's and the return in this decade to a modified religion of art  60 years of literary history recounted by a man who played a pivotal role in it all.

title: His Forte Is Mixing Old and New Music
description: As a newcomer in my middle 20's, I was told that I better not do too much new music, or get too involved with new music people. because I'd be stereotyped and that would end my conducting career, recalls Dennis Russell Davies. That advice came from a very important music educator. That's no way to stimulate intellectual curiosity in a young artist. I think that sort of advice should be ignored.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: ARMONK  Pippin, starring Joey Fay and Michael Schaffer; Gene P. Bissell, director. Presented by Troupe 260 of International Thespian Society. Friday and Saturday at 8:30 P.M., next Sunday at 7 P.M. Through April 7. $4; students $3. Byram Hills High School Auditorium. 2739200.

title: CHESS
description: Beware the move that, although superficially clever, lacks a solid strategy to back it up. The tactic that makes only an ephemeral impression may ruin a game by distracting a player from the correct positional course.

title: Murder Trial of Newton Ends in Mistrial on Coast
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 24  The murder trial of Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, ended in a mistrial today with the jury divided 10 to 2 for ac??.

title: When Maazel Is Good, He's Very, Very Good
description: Lorin Maazel remains one of the most fascinating enigmas among contemporary conductors, and his orchestral recordings with the Cleveland Orchestra, on two record labels, contribute to the enigma as much as they help resolve it.

title: Pressure Mounting On Trade Packagers
description: WASHINGTON  Behind closed doors in committee chambers of the House and Senate, legislation is being hammered out that will set the posture of the United States in world trade for the next decade. The goal is to make American trade law conform to the liberalizing measures achieved in Geneva after five years of tough negotiations by representatives of the United States and 97 other nations.

title: R.P. Richman Weds Ellen Joan Schapps
description: Ellen Joan Schapps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Schapps of South Orange, N.J., was married last evening to Richard Paul Richman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Richman of Lake Success, L.I. Rabbi Jehiel Orenstein performed the ceremony at the Schapps home.

title: New Hope for a Road That's Just a Line on a Map
description: INWOOD, L.I.  Long Island has a phantom road that has been listed on road signs and maps as the Nassau Expressway but has never been built. However, at long last, the expressway seems to be nearing reality.

title: Carter Loans Investigation: How It All Got Started
description: ATLANTA  If there was one characteristic of Jimmy Carter's rise to political power in Georgia, it was that he drew the initial financial support for his early campaigns from his family's business. In both his 1966 and 1970 gubernatorial campaigns, it was this money, fed legally into state races, that got his campaigns started.

title: The World In Summary
description: The Nixon Administration tried so hard to stay in power that it fell. South Africa's Government is running the same risk. More revelations last week about an influencebuying scandal and coverup may force Prime Minister P.W. Botha to resign.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Some further thoughts about Hair, Richard Pryor and other matters: In the first few postcredit moments of Hair, Claude (John Savage), the Oklahoma farm boy en route to his induction in the Army, wanders into Central Park and comes upon a landscape suddenly alive with flower children, music and dancing police horses. As he is dazzled so are we. Claude's ordinary world has been transformed into a fantasy land that looks very much like the world we know  only brighter, sharper, as if lit by lightning, a land whose citizens have seemingly unlimited supplies of energy, good will, common sense and effrontery. Claude is skeptical but curious, as were Alice when she fell down the rabbit hole and Dorothy when she was whirled away to Oz. By immediately establishing Claude as the center of the film, Milos Forman, the director, not only gives Hair the focal point it never really had on the stage, but lures us into accepting this makebelieve not as a distortion of reality, but as an idealized extension of it.

title: Veteran Who Saw Atomic Tests Asks U.S. to Cite Radiation Peril
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (AP) Paul Hinkie, an Army veteran who lost one son to birth defects and has another who is retarded, blames the Government for not warning him about genetic risks when he witnessed atomic bomb tests in Nevada in 1955.

title: INVESTING Weighing Bank Company Stocks
description: If John Doe's income increased by 50 percent in 1978, and Richard Roe's earnings were up only 10 percent, would you lend to John or to Richard?

title: Hope for Calm, Fear of Unrest Tear Saudis
description: RIYADH, Saudi ArabiaThe United Statesmediated peace treaty between Egypt and Israel is presenting Saudi leaders with a dilemma they have tried for years to avoid. Deeply ingrained with the concept of consensus rule, the Saudis are being pressured toward a choice certain to alienate many of their Arab allies and, even more painful, to split their own ruling establishment.

title: Lee Mitgang Fianc Of Gina C. Saporito
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dominic A. Saporito of Fanwood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gina Christine Saporito, to Lee D. Mitgang, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Mitgang of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Following the Route Of the Faithful In Historic Poland
description: For 10 centuries  as long as there has been Roman Catholicism in Poland  Cracow has been a spot for pilgrims, both for tributes to St. Stanislaw, the patron saint of Poland, and as a stop on the route to the monastery of Jasna Gora in Czestochowa, a route walked by cardinals and kings as well as by other hundreds of thousands of the faithful.

title: La Malfa, Italian Deputy Premier, Is in Coma After a Heart Attack
description: ROME, March 24 (AP)  Deputy Prime Minister Ugo La Malfa ?? a heart attack today and lapsed into a coma, a spokesman for Rome's Villa Margherita Hospital said.

title: Behind the Scenes With Movie Makers
description: NEWARK WHEN New Jersey sets out to lure film makers and smooth the road for them before, during and after filming, it fights red with red, using its Red Carpet Service to cut through red tape. The service, an arm of the state's Motion Picture and Television Development Commission, is run by Joseph Friedman, the commission's director.

title: A New Track for Deregulation: Trains
description: The Carter Administration's deregulation bug, which has already bitten the airline and truck industries, took a bead on the railroads last week. Transportation Secretary Brock Adams unveiled legislation that would make it easier for the roads to merge, set their own rates and provide changes in service without the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Pine Barrens Construction Ban Stirs Up an Emotional Debate
description: BLUE ANCHOR H E'S got more people mad than I've ever seen in my 20 years in government, said one angry Assemblyman. We have to save the pinelands before they are paved over, said an equally adamant Senator.

title: ART Hans Richter and the Storm of Dada
description: STAMFORD AFIGURATIVE painter to begin with, Hans Richter was born in Berlin in 1888. He served in World War I until wounded, then in 1916 joined the newly formed movement of Dada in Zurich. Liberated by the notion of antiart, Richter turned to abstraction and. later, to film making, collaborating at first with Viking Eggeling, the Swedish artist. Some of his movers, such as Rhythm 21, involved abstract forms, and as such laid the foundations of today's nonobjective animated cartoons.

title: Argentina's Junta, Age 3, Delays Sharing Its Power With Civilians
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 24  Argentlna's military leaders, on the third anniversary of the overthrow of President Isabel Martinez de Perdn, said today that they would stay in power until all the structures of the nation are reorganized and the country achieves political maturity.

title: Penn's Advances Focus Attention on Admissions
description: The University of Pennsylvania had done something that few Ivy League schools had done before. By defeating, in short order, North Carolina, Syracuse and St. John's, Penn had become only the second basketball team in league history to make it to the championship round of the National Collegiate tournament. Princeton was the first, in 1965.

title: Coping With the Rise
description: SPRING. Time to peel off winter covers and open hatches. It's also time to begin fitting out with the thought that higher fuel prices are becoming a way of life.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, MARCH 26, 1979

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: U.S. JUDGE TO HEAR OHIO COAL DISPUTE
description: CATLETISBURG, Ky., March 2?? The constitutionality of a Federal ?? that the Ohio coal industry is seeking to invoke to protect itself from outofstate competition is to be tested in Federal District Court here, beginning tomorrow.

title: Vows for a Treaty Signing
description: We know what Jimmy Carter will be thinking when he guides Menachem Begin and Anwar Sadat down the aisle on the White House lawn this afternoon. Proud though he may be, he cannot afford many more such joyous weddings. The dowries alone are fit for a king of Arabia, which is the competition the President aims to meet. And more than most Sponsors of a wedding party these days, Mr. Carter knows the frailty of the vows that Egypt and Israel have made to honor their treaty, and the mess he will inherit if this bond fails.

title: Advertising
description: WHAT excitement! There were all sorts of movements of advertising accounts on Friday, with many millions of dollars involved.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, March 26

title: Recital: Becerra, A Tenor
description: FLAVIO BECERRA is a Mexican tenor who made a fine impression in his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last season. Thursday night, he returned to sing at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., and again impressed as an ingratiating artist with an unusually beautiful voice.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: NINETEEN TWENTYNINE being one of those years in which the world fell on its ear, it seemed to Tom Shachtman, playwright and documentary film maker, an appealing idea to write a book that would give a sense of the year's texture. Better yet. why not focus on one particular day, Oct. 24, The day of the stock market's first large crash? There were larger crashes, notably that of the following Tuesday, Oct. 29; some people call the Crash the entire three weeks from Oct. 24 to Nov. 13, 1929; and, of course, bottom was not reached until some years later. But Oct. 24 was the first big shock.

title: Benitez, on Decision, Keeps W.B.C. Title
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 25 (AP)Wilfredo Benitez of Puerto Rico used effective rightandleft combinations to retain his World Boxing Council welterweight title today, scoring a unanimous 15round decision over Harold Weston of New York, the fourthranked W.B.C. challenger.

title: Regan and Abrams Called Men to Watch in Albany
description: ALBANY, March 23  They were jostled and kidded and slapped on the back, the two newcomers in this city of ambitious transients, as they beamed and shook hands at a reception given for them recently by the Legislature.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 26, 1979

title: Lung Disease Is an Unspoken Issue In Trial of Coal Company Officials
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio. March 25  Federal District Judge Robert M. Duncan will not allow attorneys or witnesses to utter the words black lung disease in court because he does not want to arouse the jury's passion.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Collins & Aikman, a major supplier of textile products to the nation's automotive industry, has appointed Michael G. Frisch an executive vice president and a director. Also, Warren B. Irwin has been appointed to succeed Mr. Frisch as president of the company's automotive division.

title: Survey of Drivers Seeks To Cut Midtown Traffic
description: To help design new restrictions on parking and traffic in midtown Manhattan, city officials have, for the first time, surveyed in detail the drivers of private automobiles that pour daily into that teeming area.

title: Noah Tennis Victor
description: NANCY, Franco, March 26 (AP) Yannick Noah of France won the Nancy Grand Prix (Ten tennis tournament today, defeating a countryman, JeanLouis Haillet, 62, 57, 61, 75, in the final. Noah needed 2 hours :30 minutes to wear down who upset the tournament favorite Corrado Barazzutti of Italy, in the quarterfinals.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Please list all the major league baseball teams that have played in the New York City area since 1870, which leagues they were in and how long the franchises lasted.

title: U.S. Marine Units Struggle to Cope With Norway's Arctic
description: HARSTAD, Norway, March 24  The Marine Corps general entered the permafrost theater a bit later than planned. Unfortunately, someone had booked his ticket to the war on an airline that will not start flying there until next month.

title: More Rises In Oil Seen By Saudis
description: GENEVA, March 25 (AP)  Ahmed Zaki Yamani, oil minister of Saudi Arabia, said today that he would not press for additional oilprice increases but that, because of the cutback in Iranian Production. he expects prices to continue to rise whether or not the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries formally decides on an increase.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Fed's Money Policy Arousing Criticism
description: The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee met last week, and it evidently decided to leave monetary policy unchanged. To the disappointment of some bond market analysts, its holding action became evident just as the Government released consumerprice data for February showing the worst inflation since August 1974.

title: Jazz: Dreams Quartet
description: ORNETTE COLEMAN, the influential but seldom seen alto saxophonist, has never worked with a wide circle of musicians. It takes dedication and a particular kind of focus to play his music, which involves listening for sudden modulations that do not follow any prescribed pattern, so perhaps it should not be surprising that relatively few musicians have had the chance to play it in one of Mr. Coleman's groups.

title: Taxes Hurt Massachusetts Jobs
description: BOSTON, March 25 Leaders of the prized electronics industry of Massacnusetts say they are having a hard time recruiting engineers at salaries they can afford because of high local taxes.

title: Victor in Narrow Race Keeps an Eye on Loser
description: PIERRE, S.D., March 25 (AP) Representative Tom Daschle, the victor in the nation's closest Congressional race last November, is already running for reelection, casting overtheshoulder glances at the man he defeated.

title: To Keep on Right Track, Joggers Need Right Surface
description: SPR1NG is heralded by joggers emerging from winter hibernation to run on streets, paths and beaches. But a poor selection of track surface will cause many of them to incur shockabsorption injuries, sending them to doctors offices and prematurely ending their fitness programs.

title: Selecting the Running Shoe
description: After Abebe Bikila won the 1960 Olympic marathon barefoot he vowed never again to run without shoes, and in 1964, when he won again, he did so well shod.

title: ESSAY Never Say Never
description: WASHINGTON  Henry Ford II, the most famous businessman in the world, puts his philosophy in a stoical, arrogant aphorism: Never complain, never explain.

title: U.S. Oil Drilling Found Lagging
description: HOUSTON. March 2  The search for new supplies of oil and gas in the United States appears to be faltering despite the cutoff of Iranian oil, which has reemphasized the nation's dependence on imports.

title: Prosecutors Zero In on WhiteCollar Film Crime
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25 In the 15 months since the David Begelman scandal rocked. Hollywood, no other studio presidents have been caught with their fingers in the company till. However, middlelevel executives at three companies have pleaded guilty to stealing a total of $77,639, while nearly $2 million has allegedly been stolen by middlemanagement employees who have not yet come to trial.

title: Philadelphia Considers Proposal To Prevent Teenage Pregnancy
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 25  Vera Demchenko was 22 years old when she began teaching social studies six years ago at Simon Gratz High School in North Philadelphia.

title: BEGINSADAT TALKS APPEAR TO RESOLVE FINAL TREATY ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, March 25  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance indicated tonight that Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt had resolved the final issue in the negotiations for an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: Johnson: Magical by Nature
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 25  Earvin Magic Johnson. It is as if the name appeared just that way on the birth certificate, almost 20 years ago, like John Cameron Swayze, or Norman Vincent Peale. That is the way he is introduced by Jud Heathcote, the basketball coach at Michigan State University. and it is the way Johnson signs autographs when other students ask for them in class. I have to, he said. That's a request. You can call him Magic, and you can call him Earvin. You don't have to call him Johnson.

title: Flynt Says Ruling on Comparison Of Magazines Hurts His Defense
description: ATLANTA, March 25 (UPI)  The publisher of Hustler magazine, Larry Flynt, said today that the judge in his obscenity trial dealt a serious blow to his defense by ruling out comparisons to other men's magazines, but Mr. Flynt's attorney remained optimistic that a jury, comprised mostly of women, would acquit the publisher.

title: Jack Mills, 87, a Music Publisher
description: Jack Mills, founder of the Mills Music Publishing Company, who introduced many popular songs over a 50year span, died Friday in Hollywood, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: PLEDGE TO TAIWAN UPSETS THE CHINESE
description: WASHINGTON, March 25  A stiff protest by the Chinese Government against legislation that provides strengthened United States security guarantees for Taiwan has created a predicament for President Carter, Administration officials said today.

title: Five Men Arrested in Queens Raid On Alleged Clerical Center forgets
description: Five men were arrested yesterday morning in a raid on a Queens apartment that detectives believed was used as the accounting room for 20 bookmakers around the city.

title: Marine Returns to U.S. to Face Desertion Charges
description: CHICAGO, March 25 (UPI)  Pfc. Robert Garwood of the Marine Corps, who disappeared in Vietnam 13 years ago and is accused of aiding Communist forces, returned to the United States today and proclaimed: I love America.

title: Couple Who Fled U.S. Say Ruling Is a Vindication
description: PRAGUE, Monday, March 26  Alfred and Martha Dodd Stern say it has been a long, hard and lonely 22 years to vindication of lives that have brought them to a brown, stucco villa on the outskirts of Prague.

title: Sports World Specials
description: The dapper little man sat by himself in a quiet corner of the press box, in a sunny little corner of the state of Florida. He peered through binoculars and seemed to be mumbling to himself. Finally he said quite simply, The horses are in the gate.

title: Market Place
description: UNTIL January 1978, the American Dredging Company was just another undervalued overthecounter issue. American is the secondlargest publicly owned such company in the nation (after Great Lakes Dredging) and its primary business is dredging in the Delaware River at and near Philadelphia. But its 15 huge siltlifters also opearte along the East Coast and around the New York metropolitan area.

title: Allied Artists Sets Debt Plan
description: Allied Artists Industries said Friday that if cooperation from creditors of its troubled Allied Artists Pictures subsidiary was not forthcoming, the company either on its own behalf or with certain of its subsidiaries  might have to file for protection under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Dumping Law Draws G.A.O. Fire
description: WASHINGTON, March 25  The General Accounting Office, a watchdog agency of Congress, today accused the Treasury of failing to provide adequate protection for domestic industry against imports sold at unfairly low prices.

title: Misleading Statement Attributed to Vorster In Information Case
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 25  Former Information Minister Cornelius P. Mulder today accused President John Vorster of deliberately misleading South Africans about the role he played as Prime Minister in the secret projects of the scandalridden Information Ministry.

title: Mets Are Trounced Again
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25  The New York Mets continued their springtime slide today when they made five errors and took an 111 pounding from the Philadelphia Phillies for their fifth straight loss.

title: Pol Pot's Cambodians Denounce Agreements by New Government
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 25 (Reuters)  The routed Cambodian Government of Prime Minister Pol Pot today denounced all agreements signed by the proVietnamese Government in the capital, Phnom Penh.

title: Japan Sees Its Car Sales Off 10% in U.S. This Year
description: TOKYO, March 25  Japan's automobile industry, this nation's top export dollar earner, is throttling down its overseas sales drive.

title: Gerken to Columbia
description: Paul Gerken, a former United States Davis Cup player, was named yesterday to succeed Butch Seewagen as the Columbia tennis coach. The 29yearold Gerken was a member of the 1972 Davis Cup squad and was ranked 32d in the world in 1974. lie is a graduate of Trinity University in San Antonio, where he and Brian Gottfried were runnersup in the National Collegiate doubles championship.

title: Employees of Columbia Will Vote on a Walkout
description: The leaders of Columbia University's cafeteria and clerical workers union overwhelmingly recommended a strike by its membership after contract talks between the university and the union broke off last night.

title: Abrams Calling For a Disclosure Of Charity Funds
description: Spurred by hundreds of complaints, Attorney General Robert Abrams plans to ask the Legislature to require charities that solicit money from the public to disclose more clearly how they spend their funds and to limit the amount they spend on fundraising activities and administration.

title: Chicago Bank's Office in China
description: The First National Bank of Chicago, joining the trend in American banking to establish closer ties with China, said yesterday that it had been authorized to open a representative office in Peking.

title: Mondale Assisted by a Network of Alumni
description: WASHINGTON, March 25  It was one of those days when the White House, struggling to achieve agreement on a Middle East peace treaty, was on the brink of despair during the visit of Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel earlier this month. Vice President Mondale strolled out of his White House office, walked a few yards down a short corridor and turned into the office of David Aaron, deputy assistant to the President for national security affairs.

title: A Shortage of Electrical Engineers
description: The demand for engineers, particularly electrical engineers, greatly exceed:, the supply, according to educational and industry sources.

title: Paul Russell Performs With the Scottish Ballet
description: PAUL RUSSELL is probably most identified with his years at the Dance Theater of Harlem, where his razzledazzle technique made him an undisputed star. The dancer, now with the Scottish Ballet in Glasgow, returned to the United States on Saturday with the Scottish Ballet's Noriko O'Hara for a somewhat subdued guest appearance with the Massapequa (L.I.) Symphony Orchestra, at Massapequa's Berner High School.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: WILLIAM B. MONK

title: Some Light on Urban Arson
description: To help the inner cities recover from the flames and riots of the 1960's, the Federal Government devised a plan to help insure properties that were being denied reasonable private coverage. But it now appears that loose practices in this FAIR plan  Fair Access to Insurance Requirements  have made fires profitable. Rather than being saved, inner cities are being razed.

title: Treasury's Heavy Week
description: If Congress moves quickly this week to raise the ceiling on the national debt, the Treasury could be in the market every day to borrow a total of $16 billion or even more by selling a wide variety of bills, notes and bonds. In addition, Federal agency financing will be active, too.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHOENIX, March 25 (AP)  Bob Horner, the Atlanta Braves star rookie last season who is battling over how much he should be paid, said he would join his team tomorrow on a conditional basis.

title: OverAir Pay TV Succeeds at WTVG TV:
description: Wometco Enterprises raised a lot of eyebrows in the financial community, as well as the broadcasting industry, when it took over the debtridden Channel 68 in Newark in August 1977 and announced that it would continue the station's shaky venture in pay television.

title: Tired Bulls Lose To Nets in 9988 Rout
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., March 25 The Chicago Bulls 9988 loss to the New Jersey Nets today at the Rutgers Athletic Center highlighted some of the problems of the National Basketball Association that have caused slipping attendance and falling television ratings.

title: Dissidents Ally, in Siberia Exile, Reported in Peril
description: TEL AVIV, March 25  A Soviet Jewish dissident, banished to Siberia, sleeps with a knife under her pillow in case of attack by crirpinals housed in the same barracks, according to a recently freed prisoner who visited her before emigrating to Israel.

title: Austrian Chief Wages Vigorous Campaign
description: VIENNA, March 22  Austrians used to call their folksy leader Emperor Bruno, but now Chancellor Bruno Kreisky looks like a harried politician on the stump.

title: The Bomb's A Secret?
description: MADISON. Wis.  An article I wrote for The Progressive magazine titled The HBomb Secret has generated a national controverv. It has often been described as an attempt to give Idi Amin the hydrogen bomb. The Government, contending that the article contains restricted data, went to court and secured a temporary restraining order against publication. Even our friends wonder why we, who don't want anybody to have hydrogen bomb, should publish such an article. Part of the answer to that question can be found in Honolulu.

title: Captain &
description: TONIGHT at 8, Captain & TenMlle, the husbandwife musical team, returns for another special on the ABC network. This time, we are assured, there is difference.

title: U.S. AND MALDIVIANS SETTLE SHIP DISPUTE
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, March 25 A brief but violent encounter between group of Maldive Islanders and the crew of an American research vessel, which led to a dispute involving reports of piracy and kidnapping, has ended with the signing of a joint statement in which Maldivian and American spokesmen said that the affair was the result of misunderstanding and agreed to drop legal actions growing out of the matter.

title: Music: Octet of Cellists
description: THE cello is one of the rare instruments that can sound wonderful when played either by itself or in consort with more than one or two others of its own species. To some extent this versatility is accounted for by the cello's exceptionally wide ranges of pitch and dynamics, and for its ability in the right hands to suggest an entire orchestra of colors. The piano also has similarly great powers of suggestion but it is sadly true that groups of more than two pianos begin to sound hard, cold and downright feeble. No, the cello has something special to offer all across the board, and VillaLobos knew how to capitalize on its protean qualities.

title: Cosmos in 22 Tie
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 (UPI)  The New York Cosmos played to a 22 tie with the Universidad Autonoma de Guadalajara today in an international exhibition soccer game at Kesar Stadium. Giorgio Chinaglia scored both goals for the Cosmos.

title: TYPICAL U.S. TOWN KEEPS 1920'S VALUES
description: MUNCIE, Ind., March 24 (AP)  Fifty years ago, sociologists Robert and Helen Lynd lifted this city from comfortable obscurity and made it famous as an average midAmerican city. Their pioneering study, Middletown, painstakingly examined every sociological aspect of life in this community.

title: Rock: U.K., British Band
description: WHEN U.K. was formed last year, one eager critic hailed the British rock quartet as the great white hope of progressive music.' But last gasp is more like it, for the pretentious pompandcircumstance of English bands such as Yes and Emerson, Lake and Palmer is an exhausted idiom that persists only to be bastardized by American groups like Kansas. And if U.K. had one strike against it from the very outset, two more swiftly followed with the departures of the band's most imaginative musicians, the guitarist Allan Holdsworth and the drummer Bill Bruford.

title: 2Under 69 Overcomes Mrs. Young
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 25 (UPI)  Demonstrating the same prowess that earned her the Ladies Professional Golf Association playeroftheyear award as a rookie in 1978, 22yearold Nancy Lopez rallied today to win the $100,000 Sahara national proam by two strokes with a twounderpar 69.

title: Conference Criticizes Gynecology Methods
description: A picture of gynecologists who are frequently insensitive, patronizing, noncommunicative and arrogant during breast and pelvic examinations, and of medical students who are inadequately trained to give these uniquely female examinations, emerged at conference of women in medicine this past weekend.

title: Ben Lyon, 78, SilentScreen Star Who Discovered Marilyn Monroe
description: Ben Lyon, a darkhaired and darkeyed matinee idol of the silent screen who later helped start .the careers of Marilyn Monroe and Jean Harlow, died last Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, aboard the Queen Elizabeth 11 during a cruise in the Pacific. He was 78 years old and lived in Beverly Hills. Calif.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: A failing out apparently took place last week within the Hanson family of Forest City, Iowa, resulting in executive changes at the very top of Winnebago Industries, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of recreational vehicles.

title: Transcript of Carter's Replies to Queries at Broadcasters' Convention in Dallas
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's replies to questions in Dallas yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times from a broadcast by radio station WNYC:

title: Voters in East St. Louis Hope to Oust Graft
description: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., March 23  In an effort to shake this city's reputation of being hopelessly corrupt, voters here have ousted the scandalridden administration of Mayor William E. Mason and are pinning their hopes for reform on a 26yearold undertaker with little political experience.

title: Bullets Triumph And Clinch Title
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 25 (AP) Elvin Hayes scored 25 points and Bob Dandridge had 22 today as the Washington Bullets defeated the Detroit Pistons, 116107, to clinch their first Atlantic Division title.

title: Hidden Casinos Run Nightly in New York
description: There was no name beside the bell for apartment 15E, and no one was taking any chances on welcoming accidental visitors, even at 1 o'clock on a Sunday morning.

title: Splash of Colors Urged For New York Bridges
description: Saying that we can't have dull gray bridges leading to the Emerald City, Councilman Henry J. Stern suggested yesterday that New York City paint its bridges sky blue, forest green and other rainbow colors. The Councilman, a Manhattan Liberal, said his proposal would help travelers find their bearings and at the same time increase municipal pride.

title: Hope Is Hard to Muster at Fort Dix
description: FORT DIX, N.J., March 23  The wooden barracks where G.I.'s stoked coal have been replaced by permanent green dormitories and maintenance men, but two staples of army life still abound at this 55squaremile installation  inspections and rumors.

title: Soccer: Arrows Top Fever to Take Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 25  With Shep Messing scrambling in the goal mouth to make 26 saves, the New York Arrows ignited their wellbalanced offense in the second half to defeat the Philadelphia Fever, 95, today and win the first championship of the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: Some Physicists, Knowledgeable on Weapons, Oppose Publication of Article Detailing Hydrogen Bomb
description: A number of physicists privy to the design of hydrogen bombs and familiar to varying degrees with the article submitted to The Progressive that tells in some detail how to make one are deeply concerned lest that magazine publish it.

title: Parker Aims at Triple Crown
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 25 Manager Chuck Tanner of the Pittsburgh Pirates thinks Dave Parker is the best player in baseball.

title: N.C.A.A. FINAL
description: THE final game should be what I would call a classic confrontation, inasmuch as Michigan State and Indiana State are so evenly matched and similar in several respects: They play excellent defense, execute welldevised offenses, run and jump well, and feature truly superb players surrounded by good players.

title: Machine Tool Orders Up 44%
description: Orders for new machine tools in February totaled $417 million, 44 percent above the level of February 1978 but down 14 percent from the rate of orders in January, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend.

title: PRESIDENT OUTLINES PROGRAM TO REVISE REGULATORY SYSTEM
description: DALLAS, March 25  Declaring that it is time we take control of Federal regulations in America, President Carter today outlined his proposals to reduce, to rationalize and to streamline the regulatory burden throughout American life.

title: Zetailing Activity Strengthens
description: Fourthquarter results currently ??ing released by the country's major ??tailers are demonstrating surprising ??rength in both consumer buying and ??erchandisers profits, according to ??nancial and trade sources.

title: A True Ray Of Sunshine
description: VERO BEACH, FLA. THE Los Angeles Dodgers like to depict themselves as California sunshine boys. Tom Lasorda throws out oneline jokes in the chattering style of Henny Younaman. Don Rickles is always welcome in the clubhouse. Frank Sinatra is the patron saint. Yessir, we've got movie stars and the best attendance in the game and great weather and a private jet. Good morning.

title: Michigan State Slight Pick in Title Game
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 25  Even though Indiana State has become the eighth undefeated team to reach the final of a National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, Michigan State has been established a slight favorite to beat the Sycamores tomorrow night in the title game.

title: Once Home of Cheap Power, the South Is Battleground for Rising Utility Costs
description: ATLANTA, March 25  One recent morning, a public service commissioner. Billy Lovett. a 33yearold former racing driver, wheeled his Oldsmobile past reporters waiting outside his home here. Instead of heading for a scheduled appearance at the Capitol, he sped away to the Isolation of the north Georgia mountains.

title: Union Carbide's Move to Danbury Has Vast Ripple Effect
description: Three years ago, the Union Carbide Corporation decided to move from its Park Avenue headquarters in Manhattan to just outside Danbury, Conn. The decision has not only affected the company's workers; when the actual move begins next year, it will also have an obvious impact on New York City, which suffered extensive job losses in the last few years, and on the Danbury suburb to which the company is moving.

title: A Destroyer of Cancer In Mice Raises Hopes For Treating Humans
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 25 (AP)  An anticancer substance that was first isolated in the blood of mice has been found in human blood as well and may be a key component of the body's natural defenses against cancer, a researcher said today.

title: Giving Amin an HBomb
description: The Government has again invoked the power of prior restraint of publication that was written into the Atomic Energy Act of 1945. It has gone into court to try to enjoin The Progressive magazine from publishing an article about the hydrogen bomb. I say 'again because the Atomic Energy Commission threatened the same action in an attempt to stop publication of an article about that bomb in the April 1950 issue of Scientific Amencan. We acceded to ritual cuts made by A.E.C. agents on security grounds and published a mutilated article.

title: Welfare Grants Won't Increase, Experts Predict
description: Most experts predict that when the Legislature finishes work on the state budget at the end of this week, there will be no provision for an increase in the basic welfare grant, even though the rate of inflation dominates both headlines and policymakers concerns.

title: SPORTS ARENA. PLAN FOR BOSTON IS DEAD
description: BOSTON, March 25  The latest in a 12year series of attempts to build a new sports arena that would keep the Boston Bruins and the Boston Celtics here has sputtered to its death.

title: New Man Minding Federal Store
description: WASHINGTON, March 25  He has been acclaimed and decorated as an expert on military procurement, both as a superlative manager and a teacher of others in the most efficient ways of buying goods and services for the Government.

title: Escalators, Like Trains, Can Be Late
description: For four years, bureaucratic wrangling between Amtrak and the Long Island Rail Road over repair costs had kept a strategically placed escalator at Pennsylvania Station shut down. Passengers of both lines had been obliged to trudge up long flights of stairs to the street, and some came to think of it as an escalator to nowhere.

title: T.P.R.: Clippers Keep Climbing
description: The computerized team power ratings this week reflect the reclimb of the San Diego Clippers, a surprising team in the second half of the season. The Clippers won five straight home games to move into second, and are clearcut leaders in the consistency rating.

title: 3 to Sue Head of Hospital Union, Charging Treasury Was Looted
description: Contending that they will not get a fair hearing, three members of New York City's municipal hospital workers union have withdrawn internal union charges against the local president and have charged that the international president, Jerry Wort, interfered in the case.

title: QUEBEC SEPARATISTS SHOW GAINS IN POLL
