description: I saw the car in the area, said the Delaware highway patrolman, and was not answering any complaints so I decided to pull them off. That arbitrary decision, made in November 1976, was typical of what used to occur daily on American highways.

title: Suit Challenges Use Tax on Gas
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) Eight states, including New York, filed suit today in the Supreme Court challenging Louisiana 's new firstuse tax on natural gas, which they say will cost natural gas users in Eastern and Middle Western states $200 million a year.

title: Democrats Drop Fight For Funds to Enforce State's Lending Laws
description: ALBANY, March 29  Leaders of the Democraticcontrolled Assembly dropped their fight today for a $180,000 appropriation to enforce the state's new laws against geographic discrimination in lending.

title: G.A.O. Fears a $1 Billion Overrun On Northeast Corridor Rail Project
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  The investigative arm of Congress has accused the Government of mismanagement and mistakes in the handling of the Northeast Corridor rail modernization project and said that the work could exceed anticipated costs by more than $1 billion

title: Milk Dealers and Strikers Differ Over Proposal for Shorter Week
description: Milk dealers and their striking employees discussed proposals for a shift from a sixdayaweek operation to five days, with the employers emphasizing their desire for cost savings and the union insisting there be no loss of jobs as a result.

title: Obituary 9  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Rabbis Meeting Focuses on Proselytizing
description: PHOENIX, March 29  The growing attention being focused on the issue of the conversion of nonJews to Judaism by the most liberal branch of the Jewish faith was highlighted at the annual meet ing of Reform Rabbis that ended here today.

title: Energy Dept. FuelGap Report at Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  The chairman of the House Subcommittee on Energy and Power, Representative John D. Dingell, has questioned the candor and accuracy of the Department of Energy in its reports on what the Administration has said is an oil shortage.

title: 12 Percent Rise In Profits Seen
description: Pretax profits of United States corporations are expected to increase 12 percent this year, according to financial executives surveyed by the economics department of the McGrawHill Publications Company.

title: Washington Teachers End a Strike After Court Reinstates Labor Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  A 23day strike by more than half of the District of Columbia's 6,200 public school teachers ended here today after members of the Washington Teachers Union voted overwhelmingly this morning to return to their classrooms.

title: Islands of Ease and Beauty in DebrisLaden Yemen Capital
description: SANA, Yemen, March 29The capital of Yemen, where the United States seems ready to draw the line against Soviet expansionism in the Middle East, looks more like a construction site than a city with a cultural and com mertial heritage that stretches back 1,000 years.

title: Egypt Bolstering Troops Near Libya but There Is No War Mood in Cairo
description: CAIRO, March 29  Egypt has been reinforcing its troops along the border with Libya, but an Egyptian military spokesman said today that reports that the armed forces had been placed on full alert were not correct.

title: Mariana Lowell Barzun, Violinist, Music Teacher
description: Mariana Lowell Barzun, a violinist and the wife of Jacques Barzun, the former Columbia University scholar and critic, died in Boston Wednesday. She was 74 years old.

title: Callaghan Appeals for Votes, Sets Election for May 3
description: LONDON, March 29  Prime Minister James Callaghan, whose Government was defeated last night in the House of Commons, opened his reelection campaign today with a hardhitting appeal for votes.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar, buoyed by improved United States foreigntrade figures and the prospect of energy price deregulation, strengthened on most world money markets yesterday.

title: School Aid Plan For Connecticut Backed by Panel
description: HARTFORD. March 29  A fiveyear, $391.4 million formula for financing Connecticut's public schools more equitably was adopted today by the Education Committee of the General Assembly. The action set the stage for what is expected to be the major legislative battle of the year

title: House Gets Bill on TV; Cosponsored by Southerners; Resentment Over ??  Fee
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  A long awaited new version of the House bill to deregulate much of the vast communications industry was introduced today, including provisions that for the first time would charge radio and television stations to use the airwaves.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation
description: BRADDYVILLE, Iowa, March 29 (AP)  A tornado swept through this farming village near the Missouri state line this evening, leveling at least half the town and hospitalizing four persons, the authorities said

title: TRUCKING INDUSTRY AND THE TEAMSTERS CLOSER TO CONTRACT
description: ARLINGTON, Va., March 29  The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the trucking industry moved closer to a contract agreement today, and the prospects of a peaceful settlement were enhanced when the Government indicated for the first time that it was prepared to be flexible in applying its wage guidelines to a teamster settlement.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: A.P. Names New Bureau Chief

title: Mexico's Oil Will Rise to $15.30
description: MEXICO CITY, March 29  Mexico is expected to sell its oil at about $15.30 a barrel after April 1, maintaining its differential over the $14.55abarrel base price set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries because of cheaper transport costs, oil experts said here today.

title: The Credibility Meltdown
description: Halfway through The China Syndrome, a new movie about a nuclear power plant accident, a utility company engineer insists that what the accident demonstrated is that even with a stuck valve, that ... system ... works! Yesterday, a nuclear industry spokesman was talking about the accident at the Three Mile Island plant near Harrisburg, Pa. The system worked. he said. The system shut down.

title: U.S. Is Willing to Assist Shah In Finding Refuge
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)  A Government official said today that the United States would be willing to help Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the former ruler of Iran. who is now living in Morocco, find another place of refuge and that he was welcome in the United States.

title: Vance Finds the Mood in Congress Is Mixed on Aid to Egypt and Israel
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance encountered skepticism, but also support, from a key House subcommittee today as he opened the Administration's defense of an additional $5 billion in military and economic aid to Egypt and Israel as a result of their signing of a peace treaty.

title: At the Movies
description: IT was at the Cinema Alhambra on the Piazza Beccaria in Florence, a small, thirdnin house with unpadded wooden seats, that Franco Zeffirelli first saw The Champ, starring Wallace Beery and Jackie Cooper.

title: Council Attacks Some Koch Cuts, Rejecting Sections of Budget Plan
description: Calling proposed cuts in education funds and in the Police and Fire Departments unrealistic and undesirable, the City Council released a report yesterday rejecting large parts of Mayor Koch's budget plan for the 1980 fiscal year. The report also disputed the administration's estimate of the city's budget gap.

title: The Pop Life
description: EVER since the days of the late. unlamented third stream jazz, the term fusion has been in the air. But in recent years a different sort of fusion has been taking place. This is music with its own idiom and integrity that reflects the catholic listening habits of younger musicians and audiences today. The results, at their best, sound genuinely fresh and new, and not like an improbable grafting.

title: U.S. Said to Ask a Georgia Banker To Be Key Witness Against Lance
description: ATLANTA, March 29  Department of Justice lawyers are attempting to pleabargain with a top executive of the National Bank of Georgia here in the hope that he will become a key witness in the prosecution of Bert Lance, sources familiar with the case said today.

title: Panel Proposes Curbing Powers To Set Sentence
description: In a report highly critical of the New York State Legislature, the state prison system and parole authorities, a special committee of lawyers and prosecutors recommended yesterday that judicial discretion in sentencing criminals be limited and that the Parole Board be phased out.

title: Art: Graphic Mockery From Simplicissimus
description: THE impulse to mock the pieties and pretensions of people who wield power, either as individuals or as representatives of class, is all but irresistible. It appeals to something basic  an appetite for truth  both in the human personality and in the life of culture.

title: Kaiser Regroups Under Maier
description: We were walking on the razor's edge, said Cornell C. Maier, the chairman of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, as he gestured with a knife for emphasis.

title: Contest Aids Black Composers
description: The New Jersey part of a nationwide competition designed to encourage young classical pianists and string players to perform works by black composers was announced yesterday in Newark.

title: U.S. to Tighten Price Guidelines For Companies
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  The Carter Administration said today that it was tightening up its voluntary guidelines for price increases and was introducing its first requirement for periodic reporting by corporations.

title: Koch Faces Hostile S.I. Audience
description: Mayor Koch faced an angry audience of parents and schoolchildren last night as a town meeting on Staten Island turned into a noisy debate on the schoolbus strike.

title: Justice Bars Disclosure on KLM
description: Internal company documents that allegedly show that KLM Royal Dutch Airlines made millions of dollars of improper payments constitute trade secrets and may not be disclosed to the press, a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has ruled.

title: U.S. Sees No Cause for Concern
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  Administration officials declined to comment today about the situation on the EgyptianLibyan border, but they indicated there was no immediate concern here about a major outbreak of hostilities.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Oldies but goodies from the musical 1960 's are the attraction of Shindig, the musical revue starting performances tonight at the City Center downstairs theater, 131 West 55th Street. The performers are a young quintet called the Miamis, and they 're backed up by a fivepiece band. The show is a collection of 80 hit songs that we bopped, twisted and strolled to. There will be a little verbal reminiscing about the decade, but most of the nostalgia will come from the music. Performances tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2, 7 and 9:30 P.M., and Sunday at 3 and 7:30 P.M. Tickets range from $8 to $14.

title: Easter, 63, Killed by Holdup Pair
description: CLEVELAND, March 29 (UPI) Luscious (Luke) Easter, a former Cleveland Indian first baseman and one of the first blacks to break into major league baseball, was shot and killed today by two men who robbed him of more than $5,000 outside a bank in suburban Euclid, Ohio.

title: Stocks Up, But Gains Are Slight
description: The stock market made a very slight advance yesterday in slower trading with no particular group of issues making large price moves.

title: AntiSadat Arabs Suspend Talks
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 29  Ministers of Arab League countries, unable to agree on how to punish Egypt for signing a peace treaty with Israel, suspended their conference here for 24 hours to consult with their governments for one last effort for unity.

title: 4 New Computers Bow at Honeywell
description: Honeywell Inc. has announced four new computers as part of the continuing wave of new product introductions in the mainframe segment of the computer business.

title: Attacks on Goldin Grow Beyond BusShelter Issue
description: As Federal and New York City investigators continue to look into the role of the Comptroller's office in the awarding of a new franchise for shelters at bus stops, some city officials have criticized the office's broader role as New York's fiscal manager. The Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, has vigorously denied any improprieties.

title: There Go the Clowns
description: The word clown probably derives from klunni, which meant loutish in Old Norse. There have been three kinds of clowns. The whitefaces had sunny, quick, boyish souls. The pinkandredandwhite august clowns were foolish individuals, bumpkins, scapegoats and stuffed shirts. The character clowns, playing cops, farmers, ethnics and so on, depended upon costume and often wore darker makeup to add complexity to their temperament.

title: Begin Back in Israel After Signing
description: JERUSALEM, March 29  Prime Minister Menachem Begin returned to Israel today to celebrate the peace treaty with Egypt at a ceremony attended by legislators and ambassadors in the floodlighted plaza of Parliament.

title: Webster Is Slated For Knee Surgery
description: Marvin Webster, the Knicks 7foot1inch center who has been troubled with knee problems for several months, will undergo exploratory surgery on his right knee Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. Dr. Norman Scott, the Knicks team doctor, will perform the operation.

title: U.S. Postpones $3 Billion in Bills
description: The Treasury postponed yesterday the sale of $3 billion of 78day cashmanagement bills scheduled for this afternoon, raising to more than $10 billion the volume of borrowing disrupted recently by the failure of Congress to raise the ceiling on the national debt.

title: About Real Estate Vigorous Market Is Found By Queens Home Builders
description: The spot builder is back in action in Maspeth. Elmhurst and Middle Village in Queens. another sign of economic recovery in the city.

title: Liquid Air Corp. Buys a Gas Division
description: PITTSBURGH, March 29  Sale of the industrial gases division of the Chemetron Corporation, a subsidiary of Allegheny Ludlum Industries, to the Liquid Air Corporation of North America has been completed, it was announced here today.

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Restaurants
description: IT would be difficult to think of a New York restaurant that has more antique, oldworld charm than the gracefully beautiful Cafe des Artistes on 67th Street just off Central Park West. Housed in the Hotel Des Artistes and opened as a restaurant or tearoom continuously since that building went up in 1917, the cafe is aglow with the lush and sensuous murals of Howard Chandler Christy. That romantic glow would, of course, remain more intact if the tables were not jammed so closely together and the noise levels were just a little more bearable. As is, those features, plus poor ventilation, detract somewhat from the overall enjoyment, but even so, this remains a delightful setting for Sunday brunch, lunch or dinner.

title: SENATE UNIT URGING DECISION ON MISSILE
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  The Senate Armed Services Committee, after two weeks of bitter internal debate, agreed today to press the Carter Administration to make up its mind on how to deploy a new mobile intercontinental missile known as the MX.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN 1956, the late Nancy Mitford brought out a book she had edited, Noblesse Oblige, which created such a flap among its readers that even I, in the cozy womb of whatever I was doing at the time, became aware of it, though I didn't read it then and haven't since. According to her sister,Diana Mitford (who has contributed a small, mildly corrosive essay, Nancy Obliged, to the present volume), Nobless Oblige grew out of an article on aristocracy that Nancy was supposed to be writing for Encounter magazine. When she found that all she had to say on the subject wasn't enough to fill an article  In those days there was nothing as amusing as [presentday] honours lists...to comment on, Diana remarks  Nancy decided to pad it out with some comments on the use of language that a professor of philology named Alan C. Ross had sent her. These comments of course introduced to the language the expressions: U and nonU  for upperclass and nonupperclass. They serve to inform us that among other things, if one said, Pardon? instead of What? one was guilty of being genteel. Aristocrats smiled confidently at the news; the genteel tore out their hair. The rest is hysteria.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: I never felt better in my life, Edward L. Hennessy Jr. told an interviewer yesterday. No wonder. For Mr. Hennessy, 51 years old, executive vice president of the United Technologies Corporation, had just been named president and chief executive officer of the Allied Chemical Corporation.

title: 2 U.S. Airmen Killed in Scotland
description: LONDON, March 29 (Reuters)  Two airmen were killed when their United States Air Force Phantom jet crashed into a mountain in southwest Scotland late last night, the British Air Force said today. The victims were identified as Capt. Thomas J. Seagren, 26 years old, of San Leandro, Calif., the pilot, and Capt. Roy V. Spalding, 31, of Mesquite, Tex., the navigator. The plane, based at Alconbury in eastern Englarri, was on a routine training flight.

title: Amin Reported to Flee Kampala With Remnants of Uganda Army
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 29  President Idi Amin of Uganda has fled his capital, Kampala, the exile group that is challenging him said today. A mixed force of Tanzanian troops and Ugandan rebels was said to be able to take Kampala at will.

title: Egypt Mission in Peking Stoned
description: TOKYO, March 29 (AP)  More than 100 Arab students opposed to the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty stoned the Egyptian Embassy in Peking today after an embassy official rammed his car into the demonstrators and injured several of them, the Kyodo news service reported. The report said the students also clashed with about 100 unarmed Chinese soldiers.

title: Opera: First Meyerbeer
description: THE urge to revive forgotten operas brought Meyerbeer's II Crociato in Egitto to Carnegie Hall Wednesday night. As far as anybody seems to know, this opera, composed in Italy in 1824, had never before been performed in the United States. It was the work that launched Meyerbeer; after that he went to Paris and made history with his phenomenally successful operas, starting with Robert le Diable.

title: U.S. Halts Trade Talk With Japan
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  The United States Government announced today the collapse of talks with Japan aimed at easing restrictive government procurement policies in the two countries, one of the major goals in the current round of trade liberalization.

title: Tewell, a Struggler, Cards 68, Trails by 3
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND. S.C., March 29  Life on the PGA Tour is hard enough for a lowincome unknown but it's a living hell when he's playing badly. Occasionally he thinks of quitting and taking up some other line of work. But he finds some excuse to keep on pursuing the big dream, the obsessive fantasy that one day. one day . . . .

title: F.T.C. Is Sued By Ford Motor
description: DETROIT, March 29 (UPI)  The Ford Motor Company filed suit today seeking to halt a Federal antitrust investigation of the auto industry.

title: Preservation Hall Comes Marching In
description: One musician and a battery of electronic gear can now produce an almost believable approximation of the sound of a symphony orchestra, but it seems perfectly evident that no matter how far technology advances, electronics will never be able to reproduce the sound of a real New Orleans jazz band.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., Los Angeles, has established a new division, The Broadway Southwest, to operate the company 's Broadway stores in Arizona, New Mexico and southern Nevada, and named Wayne L. Badovi1111S its president and chief executive officer.

title: Screen: 'Buck Rogers' Glides on Automatic Pilot:'Millionaire's Row' Tour
description: "BUCK Rogers in the 25th Century," which opens today at the RKO 86th Street Twin 1 and other theaters, is to movie-going what corn flakes are to eating. Just to anticipate it is to know everything about it. Some intelligent, sophisticated people have knocked themselves out to transform bland into bland, and they have succeeded to the extent that anyone who fondly remembers the comic strip, or the old movie serial with Buster Crabbe, probably will not feel cheated. After all, people who order corn flakes seldom send them back to the chef.The screenwriters, Glen A. Larson and Leslie Stevens, the one-time Broadway playwright ("The Marriage-Go-Round"), appear to have been inspired as much by "Star Wars" as by the comic strip about the 20th century pilot who awakens in the 25th century. They've added a relentlessly cute drone, Twiki (voice by Mel Blanc), who's approximately the size of your extra gasoline can and who carries around his neck a computer named Theo, who looks like the headlight off a Cadillac and talks like a doctor in a commercial about stomach distress.As in "Superman," the movie never quite concludes, leaving the way open for the further adventures of Buck Rogers, and for the further serialization of feature-length motion pictures. If there were not already a second Buck Rogers film in the works, there'd be no explanation for the brief, now-you-see-him-now-you-don't appearance of Joseph Wiseman as the tyrant Draco, king of Draconia, the galaxy whose terrible plans for earth form what might loosely be called the story.The only other member of the cast who is familiar is Henry Silva, as the character who, in the comic strip, was known as Killer Kane but who here is called simply Kane, the chief flunky and minister-of-state to Draco's headstrong daughter, Princess Ardala.Gil Gerard, the new actor who plays Buck, looks quite right for the role  handsome in the undistinguished way of dozens of Hollywood actors of the 30's who never quite made the grade in A-pictures. He may well be the John Ridgely or Dennis O'Keefe of the 1970's, especially since his manner of delivering the script's laboriously updated wisecracks recalls Dennis O'Keefe with bad material. Erin Gray, a former photographer's model with high-fashion beauty, plays the virtuous Wilma and is much funnier in her serious intensity than Mr. Gerard when he attempts to be flip.Pamela Hensley is the film's most magnificent special effect as the wicked, lusty Princess Ardala, a tall, fantastically built woman who dresses in jewelry that functions as clothes and walks as if every floor were a burlesque runway.Daniel Haller, who learned his trade with Roger Corman, may not be the wittiest of directors but he displays a brisk, no-nonsense approach to filmmaking that is immensely helpful in this kind of film. The movie is paced to hold the interest of the smallest brain.The special effects? We see space ships, the 25th-century city that has replaced 20th-century Chicago, dread mutants deformed by the earlier holocaust and all sorts of other, theoretically unbelievable things. My problem is that after awhile all these movies look alike.One set, however, deserves special mention. It is Princess Ardala's command craft, a space ship so roomy that it contains a throne room as well as a bathtub as big as an Olympic-size swimming pool. The exterior of the ship looks very much like the temple of Queen Hatshepsut at Thebes, miraculously made airborne and set adrift in a serene cosmos."Buck Rogers in the 25th Century," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains one naughty 20th-century word of German roots and a lot of failed double-entendres that work only one way.

Among the restored material: Young Jesus preaching in the temple, and Jesus encounter with the rich young man.

title: F.B.I. Spied on Brecht For 13 Years, File Shows
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted a surveillance of Bertolt Brecht over a period of 13 years, tapping his telephone, getting reports from informants and obtaining private fetters and telegrams, while amassing hardly any politically useful information about the playwright's alleged Communist activities. The F.B.I.'s pursuit of Brecht was, according to James K. Lyon, chairman of the literature department of the University of California at San Diego, both comic and ominous and was not without its Keystone Kops comedy aspect.

A leg wheels an inch or two from the floor around the standing leg. A woman loons through a small. selfabsorbed circle, then another. So began Mix, seen on Thursday in an hour and a quarter of work choreographed by Judy Padow since 1977, presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Lepercq Space.

title: Red Rum: Invalid to A Legend
description: SOUTHPORT, England, March 30 The plot has all the elements of a Hollywood film. A taxi driver who trains horses and his millionaire passenger discover that they share a dream to have a horse who wins the world's toughest steeplechase. They buy a crippled 7yearold and nurse him back to health by running him along the seacoast. in the end, the horse wins Britain's Grand National steeplechase an unparalleled three times and goes on to make a fortune as the bestloved animal in the land.

title: Teamster Chief's Grandson Dies
description: DETROIT, March 30 (AP)  James Patrick Fitzsimmons, 19yearold grandson of Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president Of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, died last night, apparently from an accidental selfinflicted gunshot wound, the police said.

title: Money
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 30, 1979

title: Sub Discovers Giant Worms Beneath Pacific
description: Among hot springs in sea floor rifts near the Galapagos Islands in the Pacific Ocean, diving scientists have discovered creatures that live inside 10foot tubes of their own making. The creatures have no mouth, gut or eyes and their anatomy is so novel that some specialists consider them an entirely new phylum, or basic division of the animal kingdom.

title: The High Cost of Philippine Bases
description: Promoting human rights and protecting American interests are sometimes conflicting diplomatic objectives, but in the Philippines today they are intimately connected. Congress is considering an Administration proposal to provide $500 million more in aid for the Philippines, about threefifths of it military. Under an arrangement worked out with President Marcos, the aid would assure American use of air and naval bases at Clark Field and Subic Bay for four more years. Given the nature of the Marcos regime, this proposal poses both a moral dilemma and a practical challenge.

title: A Few Pitching Hopefuls Hurt Their Cause as Mets Lose Again
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30  I've got 14 pitchers for 10 jobs, Joe Torre said tonight, surveying the employment crunch on the New York Mets. You get to this point in spring training when one time at bat or one turn on the mound can decide.

title: Postal Station to Stay Shut Despite $70 Million Repairs
description: The Morgan Post Office Station on Manhattan's West Side, unused since a fire in 1967, will remain closed indefinitely despite a $70 million renovation.

title: The Urban Crisis Isn't Over
description: The nation heard some seemingly good news the other day in a report suggesting that cities are no longer in dire financial straits. But the study, by the First National Bank of Boston and the accounting firm of Touche Ross, turns out to be not only premature but something of a threat to cities. Members of Congress who are eager to cut Federal spending are using the findings to argue that the urban crisis is over. It not.

title: U.S. to Continue Oil Overcharge Suits
description: WASHINGTON. March 30 (AP) Federal judge ruled today that the Government could proceed with lawsuits that accuse nine of the nation's largest oil companies of having overcharged customers by more than $1 billion.

title: Fall Mountain's New Music
description: A new concert series devoted to live electronic music got off to a promising start Thursday night at the Public Access Synthesizer Studio, 16 West 22d Street, with a performance by the group Fall Mountain. Actually, the music was a mixture of electronic and acoustic sounds, with Robert Ostertag manipulating the electronics, Jim Natzin playing a violin through amplification and various tonal modifiers and Ned Rothenberg performing acoustically on saxophones, flute, bass clarinet and some ethnic flutes and whistles.

title: Metropolitan Area Monitors Radiation

title: Wherein a Man Reveals His Very Soul
description: NORTH BAY, Ontario  A childhood memento, like childhood itself, tends to be fragile  crippled dolls and headless soldiers are all too common. But my special memento is impervious to the ravages of the years. It all began with the purchase of a piano when I was 12..

title: Must the Poor Pay for Rich Schools?
description: The final countdown is under way for the New York Sate budget. From the latest legislative maneuverings in Albany, it appears that affluent school districts will emerge as winners; the losers will include the criminal justice system and financially troubled Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. The school outcome was predictable and may be irreversible. But the threat the criminal courts and to the hospital can and should be averted.

description: LONDON, March 30  A leading Member of Parliament was killed this afternoon when a bomb apparently set by Irish terrorists exploded in his car as he was driving out of the Parliament grounds.

title: Roxy Music Makes Return At Palladium
description: Some rock bands win loyal fans and retain them even when there's no band to be loyal to. Such was the case with Roxy Music, which made a return appearance Thursday night at the Palladium after several years of nonexistence. and was rewarded with a fervent ovation from a crowd that looked as if had stepped bodily from the ashes the Mercer Arts Center, that focus glitterpunkprogressive rock in New York in the early 1970's.

title: F.B.I. Holds Man Sought by Britain in $300 Million Bank Fraud
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that its agents had arrested a 45yearold Italian national in midtown Manhattan on a British fugitive warrant charging him with participating in a $300 million international banking fraud and escaping from a London courtroom cell 18 months ago while awaiting trial.

title: Government Asks Delay In Elimination of Nitrites
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)  The Carer Administration asked Congress today to permit food processors to continue to use the preservative sodium nitrite for at least another year, despite a study linking the substance to cancer in animals.

description: Ruth Bertrand Coates, long active in philanthropy, died Thursday in St. Mary's Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 68 years old and had been a resident of Palm Beach for a year after living in New Vernon, N.J., for more than 30 years.

title: Johnny Mince, Versatile Clarinetist at Crawdaddy
description: The clarinet, which was one of the more popular instruments in the Swing Era  three of the most important swing band leaders, Benny Goodman, Artie Shaw and Woody Herman, were clarinetists  virtually disappeared from jazz after World War II. It has never found a secure place in jazz style since then, and when it is heard in jazz, today, it is usually played by one of the Swing Era band leaders or younger musicians who play in preWorld War II styles, such as Bob Wilber or Kenny Davern.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOUR TO GOOpening on Broadway in November 1944, Noel Coward's comedy Quadrille, had a reasonably healthy run of 150 performances and stellar cast including Alfred Lunt, Lynn Fontanne, Edna Best and Brian Aherne. But the reviews endorsed the performers over the play and so, subsequently, did the playwright himself. However, according to Cole Lesley's biography, Mr. Coward also wistfully wondered if the peak of World War II might have been the wrong time to present a gentle, romantic lark set in the Victorian era.

description: In a room sealed in plastic, men wearing white jumpsuits and masks are attacking a substance that has seeped through the walls. They scrape, scrub, brush, wipe, dust and then carefully pack the flaky gray material into double plastic bags. After that, before they are permitted to come into contact with anyone or anything, the men must take a shower.

title: In Iran Balloting, Only Victory Margin Is in Doubt
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 30 The polling place was a long, open table set in the courtyard of a mosque in the Central Bazaar. Behind the table, women wearing scarves in the Moslem tradition stamped identification papers and handed out ballots.

title: Case of Impostor Doctor Starts New York Inquiry
description: WHITE PLAINS, Mar. 30  State health officials began an inquiry today into how Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital in Manhattan hired a 28yearold high school graduate as a physician in the surgery department last summer while he was on probation in Philadelphia for forgery of his medical records at a hospital there.

title: Fiji Reports Toll in Cyclone
description: SUVA, Fiji, March 30 (Reuters)More than 50 people are dead or missing in fierce storms that tore through Fiji. Government officials said today. At least 21 people were killed when a cyclone. hit the island of Oxo on Tuesday night, according to reports reaching Suva.

title: Ireland Cuts Pound Link To Britain
description: LONDON, March 30 (AP)  The Irish pound was wrenched from its historic partner, the British pound, today in what was also the first test of the European Monetary System, which began on March 13.

title: Carter Rejects a Plan to Reopen Steel Plant in Ohio
description: Just as the United Steelworkers of America threw its support behind a community effort to reopen a plant closed by the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company in October 1977, the Carter Administration informed the local coalition that it would not approve the project and the loan guarantees and grants that the group had sought.

title: Engagements
description: SANDOS LEVER

title: United Grounds Jets As Union Walks Out
description: United Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, was grounded today by a strike of 18,600 mechanics and other ground workers after they voted down a new contract tentatively agreed to by their union officers.

title: Within Sight of Stricken Plant, A Town's Main Street Is Empty
description: GOLDSBORO, Pa., March 30  At 5:15 P.M. today on Main Street here, the only living thing in sight was brownandwhite dog, wandering aimlessly, oblivious to the radiation that was leaking from the crippled nuclear power plant just across the muddy Susquehanna.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Metals futures fell yesterday as traders sold contracts before the weekend, reflecting a bearish mood over expected energy moves by the Carter Administration and an approaching strike deadline for truckers.

title: F.C.C. Rejects Bid for Equal Time To Rebut NBC Holocaust Series
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  The Federal Communications Commission dismissed today a complaint by a New York organization called the Ridgewood Group that had asked for equal time to refute the Holocaust television series.

title: Waste Water Is Spilled At Indian Point Plant
description: Three pints of waste mop water slightly contaminated by radiation spilled while it was being piped from one storage tank to another Monday at the Indian Point Power Plant in Buchanan, N.Y., a Con Edison spokesman said yesterday.

title: Air Conferees Seek Fare Pact
description: GENEVA, March 30  After three days of talks, executives of 70 airlines that fly international routes still cannot agree on how much passenger fares and cargo rates should be raised to offset soaring fuel costs.

title: David Zinman Conducts Rochester Philharmonic
description: For the last six years. the Rochester Philharmonic has grown and prospered into a majorsized symphonic ensemble under the care of its music director. David Zinman, and Thursday night the orchestra came to Carnegie Hall with an interesting, wellchosen program designed to showcase its newly acquired qualities. There were two virtuoso orchestral scores; Berlioz's Benvenuto Cellini Overture and Bartok's Miraculous Mandarin Suite; a recent composition receiving its New York premiere, Dominick Argento's In Praise of Music, and a noted pianist, Misha Dichter, to perform Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 3.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: SYRACUSE, March 30 (AP)  The final details of the takeover by the United Technologies Corporation of the Carrier Corporation have been worked out, it was announced today. The transaction, however, still faces an antitrust zest in Federal court.

title: Collapsing Bridge Is Barricaded, Creating Traffic Jams in Phoenix
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 30 (AP)  A collapsing bridge on the city's only freeway was barricaded today, diverting 110,000 cars onto already congested streets and creating massive traffic jams in this metropolitan area of 1.5 million people.

title: Unseeded Player Upsets Borg; Gerulaitis, McEnroe in Semifinal
description: MILAN, Italy, March 30 (AP)  Two New Yorkers, Vitas Gerulaitis and John McEnroe, won quarterfinal matches today in the $200,000 World Championship Tennis tournament. But topseeded Bjorn Borg of Sweden was upset by an unseeded Australian, John Alexander.

title: Court Rules Bank Units Cannot Aid Closed Funds
description: A Federal appeals court in Washington ruled yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board had erred in permitting bank holding companies to act as investment advisers to closedend investment funds.

title: A New Aide for U.S. Attorney
description: John H. Doyle 3d, a New York lawyer. was appointed yesterday as chief of the Criminal Division of the United State Attorney's office in Manhattan.

title: Prices Paid Farmers Up 2% in March
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Prices that farmers get for raw agricultural products rose another 2 percent in March, breaking records for the fourth straight month, and were up 23 percent from a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Mayor Halts Writ in Drivers' Strike
description: Mayor Koch intervened yesterday in contemptofcourt proceedings against striking schoolbus drivers to stop court orders from being served against them and their union until Monday.

title: Man Gets 7 Years for Bilking City
description: A 30 yearold accountant who was part of a group from Touche Ross & Company that was supposed to modernize the city's billpaying procedures was sentenced to up to seven years in jail yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan for stealing $172,000 from the Department of Finance.

title: Miss Washam Cards HoleinOne, but Trails Leaders by 2 at 141
description: COSTA MESA, Calif., March 30 Jo Ann Washam, a 29year old golfer who has not won a tournament since 1976, performed one of golf's top achievements today with a holeinone during the second round of a Ladies Prolessional Golf Association tournament. Miss Washam accomplished the feat on the 16th hole of the 6,134yard, par71 Mesa Verde Country Club course.

title: Soviet Skater Wins Title
description: AUGSBURG, West Germany, March 30 (UPI)  Despite four falls, Vitali Egorov of the Soviet Union won the men's junior world figure skating championship yesterday, heating Bohby Beacharnp of the United States. Egorov scored 12 ordinals and 168.78 points to Beachamp's 25 ordinals and 166.82 points.

title: Rehearsal of Census Gets Bad Reviews
description: Four censustakers were caught filing fictitous reports during a dry run in lower Manhattan for the 1980 census, and other enumerators encountered widespread refusal to respond to questions among the residents of lofts in SoHo, a Congressional subcommittee was told yesterday.

title: How to Brew a National Hockey League Treaty
description: Most celebrations are toasted with champagne. But beer is the drink for the treaty by which the National Hockey League owners have agreed to absorb four World Hockey Association teams next season  the beer that all those Canadians did not consume after the N.H.L. voted, 125, to reject a treaty proposal three weeks ago. Never underestimate the power of an empty glass, especially one that is supposed to be foaming with beer. When the Montreal Canadiens, owned by the Molson Brewery, voted against the treaty on March 8, beer drinkers in three of the W.H.A. cities  Winnipeg, Edmonton and Quebec City  voted against Molson. Mostly, they simply ordered other brands. Bullet holes also were discovered in the glass doors at Molson's Brewery in Winnipeg; a bomb threat was phoned to the Molson Brewery in Quebec City; a frontpage editorial in The Edmonton Journal requested readers to give up Molson's for Lent. Last week the Montreal Canadiens, along with the Vancouver Canucks, changed their vote. Yesterday the treaty was approved, 143, by the N.H.L. owners, pending the sanction of the Players Association, which will demand more liberal movement of free agents. But for now, bottoms up.

title: Deaths
description: PAULJulius. On March 29 in West Palm Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of Caroline, devoted father of Arthur. George, Herbert & Marilyn Brown. Adored grandfather & great grandfather. Services Sunday 10AM, the Riverside 76th St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 19.

title: Deaths
description: ALTMANJack, of 700 South Lake Drive, Lakewood, N.J. Beloved husband et Sylvia (nee Ginsburg). Devoted father of David, Nina Monesson and Lisa Seep. Funeral services will be held at Temple Beth Am, Madison Ave at Carey St, Lakewood. N.J. on Sunday, April 1, 1979 at 12 Noon. For further Information, please call BeMott Jewish Memorial Chapel. 2013640900

title: Skull Found in Wall at Alamo
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 31 (AP)  Archaeologists excavating along a wall of the Alamo have unearthed a skull believed to have been that of a casualty from the famous 1836 battle at the old Spanish missionfortress. Augustine Frkuska. 26 years old, of the University of Texas at San Antonio, found the skull Wednesday miraculously preserved and embedded between stones.

title: RUMANIA REPLACES ITS PRIME MINISTER
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30 The Rumanian Communist leadership re placed Manea Manescu as the nation's Prime Minister today. It was the latest in a series of toplevel party and Govern ment changes over the last year.

title: McDermott Chief in Plea
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 30 (AP)The chairman and chief executive officer of J. Ray McDermott & Company pleaded no contest today to Federal charges of antitrust conspiracy, mail fraud and wire fraud.

title: Yvonne Mitchell, British Actress
description: Yvonne Mitchell, a British actress on stage, screen and television who made many films and was singled out for her performance in the Broadway production of The Wall in 1960, died last Saturday of cancer in London. She was 53 years old.

title: A Defiant Mood Grows in Egypt In Reaction to Criticism by Arabs
description: CAIRO, March 30  Following the conchision of its peace treaty with Israel, Egypt has experienced an upsurge of nationalism that has left Egyptians generally unshaken by the hostility of other Arabs.

title: U.S. Denounces Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (Reuters) The United States today said the bombing of a northern Tanzanian town by a Sovietbuilt Libyan jet bomber yesterday was a serious stepup of a previously localized conflict

title: Nuclear Panel In a Statement
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) Following is the statement issued today by Frank Ingram of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission on the latest developments at the Three Mile Island atomic power plant:

title: Hungary To Borrow In U.S.
description: LONDON, March 30  Hungary is to become the first country in Eastern Europe to raise money in United States capital markets since World War II, banking sources disclosed here today.

title: 5 Die in Jersey City Tenement Fire
description: A tenement fire took the lives of five members of two families last night in downtown Jersey City, authorities there reported.

title: Mt. Vernon Five Gains AAA Final
description: SYRACUSE, March 30  Curtis Moore, a reserve forward for Mount Vernon High School, hit a short jumper with 53 seconds left to give the Knights the lead for good tonight as they held off Boys and Girls High and won their semifinal game in the state championship tournament, 5755, at the War Memorial Coliseum.

title: Brookhaven Aide Says Safety Equipment Held Up at Pennsylvania Plant
description: The head of the thermal reactor safety division at the Brookhaven National Laboratory said yesterday that the network of safety equipment at the Three Mile Island nuclear generating plant had held up well despite the failure of some of its components.

title: Sternly Marxist Benin Allows Business and French Cafe
description: COTONOU, Benin  A banner over the coastal highway running through this sleepy, sunbaked West African capital proclaims: Socialism is our way, MarxismLeninism is our guide. A billboard advertising the Soviet airline, Aeroflot, informs prospective travelers that the flying time to Moscow is 9 hours 55 minutes. The major public monument was donated by North Korea, and the Chinese are building a sports stadium.

title: Construction to Add Half an Hour to Metroliner's Trip
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  Amtrak said today that Metroliner running time would be lengthened from three hours to three and a half hours between here and New York this summer because of construction activity. Amtrak officials and representatives of the Federal Railroad Administration said today that tracklaying activity in the crowded and busy rail corridor would affect the operations of passenger trains, commuter carriers and Conrail, the freight hauler.

title: CHILDREN EVACUATED
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., March 30  Gov. Dick Thornburgh advised pregnant women and small children today to stay at least five miles away from the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear power plant as radioactivity continued to leak and another burst of contaminated steam had to be released for safety reasons.

title: Italian Cruise Liner Burns and Sinks at St. Thomas
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., March 30  The Italian cruise liner Angelo Lauro sank at a pier on the island of St. Thomas this evening after a fire of unknown origin had raged out of control for more than six hours.

title: Convict Acquitted in Death of 3 Girl Scouts
description: PRYOR, Okla., March 30  Gene Leroy Hart was found not guilty today of the June 1977 sex slayings of three Girl Scouts from the Tulsa area.

title: 76ers 129, Cavaliers 93
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 30 (AP) Julius Erving scored 27 points as the Philadelphia 76ers won their third straight game by defeating the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight, 12993.

title: Warriors 114, Knicks 98
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 30 (UPI)  Robert Parish pulled down a careerhigh 32 rebounds and scored 30 points to help the Golden State Warriors to a 11498 victory over the New York Knicks tonight.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 31, 1979

title: China Plans Law Journal
description: HONG KONG, March 30 (AP)  China will begin publishing a law magazine next month, the Peking newspaper People's Daily has reported. It said the magazine, Jurisprudence Study, would appear every two months to help promote the study of law.

title: Letter: On School Bus Contracts
description: To the Editor: A serious misstatement of fact in your March 17 editorial on competitive bidding for student bus transportation compels me to put the record straight. The editorial stated: The prospective new contracts will cost at least as much as the old contracts would have cost had they been extended. This is not so.

title: EXBUSBOY ACCUSED IN 2 BOSTON BLAZES
description: BOSTON, March 30  A former busboy at the Copley Plaza Hotel was arraigned here today on charges of having set fires that injured 69 persons and caused nearly $1 million damage at the Copley Plaza and Sheraton Boston hotels early Thursday morning.

title: God's Out. What's In?
description: WASHINGTON  Ours is a scientific age, and even a scientist must admit that whether God exists or does not exist has not, in fact, been scientifically proved.

title: Rickover Asserts Lawyers Tactics Hinder Military
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 Hyman G. Rickover, the outspoken and politically influential Admiral, slashed at the legal profession today, saying that many lawyers were mercenaries who worked with defense contractors to delay litigation, file excessive claims against the Navy and thwart the military in the performance of its duties.

title: Johanna Meier in Debut as Senta
description: Johanna Meier, a soprano who has been working more at the Metropolitan Opera this season than she had planned to chiefly in the title role of Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos  made her first appearance as Senta in the company's new production of Wagner's Der Fliegende Hollander on Thursday night.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Wells Drops T.W.A. Account
description: Wells, Rich, Greene Inc., the advertising agency that in 1968 resigned the Braniff International account in order to take on the larger account of Trans World Airlines, announced yesterday that it was resigning the T.W.A. account because it was about to acquire a majority interest in the current agency that handles Braniff's advertising.
